column2: X-35 History Inspires F-35 Capability
column3:
21st century threats required a transformation in combat aircraft. Military aviation capabilities at the turn of the century were set to be outpaced by the advanced sensors and weapons systems of U.S. adversaries. An elite team was assembled to develop the Fifth Generation combat capability required to secure air dominance in a rapidly-accelerating digital age.  

The resulting air systems (F-35, F-22) employed today are defined by supersonic speeds, stealth properties, precision weaponry, and software designed to evolve at the speed of global threats. None of these capabilities would have been possible without the groundbreaking work of those who matured futuristic concepts into operational reality. 

In her current position as the F-35 Joint Program Office’s Executive Director, Tanya Skeen recently reflected on her beginnings as a flight sciences engineer on the X-35 Program. Her love of space and airplanes set her on a path to contribute to ground-breaking technologies over the course of her career as an engineer, tester and accomplished program manager.

“I’m grateful to have been a part of the early days of the [X-35] Program, and to jump back in now in a leadership role on the [F-35] Program at this time; it’s an incredible honor. I never would have imagined, when I was a young engineer writing code and doing testing that I’d have the opportunity to work on the Program again at this level, and at this stage in capability delivery and operations C it’s awesome.”

The X-35, a concept demonstrator aircraft (CDA) developed by Lockheed Martin, would later be known as the ‘Joint Strike Fighter’. Following extensive development and tests on U.S. Service aircraft variants, the Fifth Generation air system entered production in the 2000s as the F-35 Lightning II. On October 24, 2000, Lockheed Martin's X-35A CDA completed its first flight from Palmdale, California, to nearby Edwards Air Force Base, using just over 2,000 feet of runway to take-off before climbing to 10,000 feet with the gear down. As described in 2000 by Tom Morgenfeld, Lockheed Martin’s X-35 head test pilot: “This aircraft looks and flies like a fighter.” 

The test flights subsequently carried out by the X-35 government-industry team validated engineering designs, and provided data later applied to production aircraft as the X-35 program matured into the F-35 program.

Being a test engineer appealed to many of Skeen’s natural interests. “Test gives us data, and I have always appreciated how data helps me understand things. My love of data, and my love of solving problems is what made test so appealing to me.”  When asked about career progression, Skeen shared that her husband, an active duty Air Force Officer, was also a test engineer. “The Air Force moved us to test places, and if you move to test places, you’d better love test especially because test bases tend to be a bit remote!”  

Engineering innovation was inspirational to many who worked on the X-35 program - new ideas and designs were being presented all the time to achieve results, but didn’t always work as planned.  The team learned resilience, and became even more innovative when recovering from failures. “When you speak about innovation - we saw drawings and mock ups of engines, and there was a lot of testing of engines. We refined data and learned from failures along the way,” Skeen recalled. “We tried, and failed…and we tried again.” 

From that experience, she learned a memorable leadership and life lesson. “Things don’t always work the way we expect, but we have to learn and adjust, and not let smaller failures get in the way of truly big successes.” 

When asked to recount the most ground breaking accomplishment she participated in during her days on the X-35 program, Skeen recalled working on the X-35B. “We were a young crew, writing control laws on the B [U.S. Marine Corps, short takeoff variant] aircraft, trying to get an airplane to move like it was a helicopter…which was very interesting for an aeronautical engineer.” Previous vertical lift aircraft had employed a direct lift engine, but the X-35B design included a new, shaft-driven lift fan system. “Building a lift fan had never been done before. I worked on flight sciences, and unlike most people on the flight sciences team, I got to work across the department C aerodynamics testing, propulsion testing, and coding of control laws - and pulling that all together. It was really exciting and rewarding” 

Skeen’s early years as an engineer shaped her leadership style as an industry executive, and are applied daily in her current Department of Defense role as a member of the Senior Executive Service (SES), and Executive Director of the F-35 Joint Program Office.  

“Leadership in the Department [Department of Defense] demands and requires that we bring data to drive our decision making. There are plenty of hard problems that we solve every day in acquisition. In addition to my test background, I appreciate the business side of acquisition as well. I love to talk to with our contracting community about the best acquisition strategy for a Program. Through those strategy conversations, we use data to define how best to tackle those hard problems.”

When asked what her current professional growth looks like, Skeen related that she’s focusing on personal attributes, such as communication skills and effective listening. “The engineering and hard sciences comes easy for me, but I have to also focus on improving my “softer side” and focusing on how I engage with people. I have an executive coach who helps me with blind spots, and [he] is one of the most valuable resources I have in this role.” Skeen focused on prioritizing her family as they moved from place to place during their military family experience. “My best advice is don’t get too caught up in the “perfect career”…do what makes sense to you, take on challenging positions that stretch you professionally, work really hard in every job, and remember your family is most important. Success will follow.”

Reuniting with former X-35 colleagues to celebrate the program’s anniversary and accomplishments is an exciting prospect for Tanya Skeen. “We formed a close bond, and focused on an ambitious mission that became a reality…it’s a huge privilege to be a part of that group and our shared experience.” 

Now, the F-35 Lightning II is a reality, with over 560 aircraft deployed around the globe, more than 300,000 flight hours logged, and air system capability that is unsurpassed in combat aviation. Being associated with the F-35 program over time has fortified Skeen’s belief that PEOPLE are the most important aspect of technology and innovation. “It takes a lot of smart, dedicated folks to deliver a technological marvel like the F-35. It doesn’t happen without the people writing contracts, managing finances, sustaining the air system, and working future development to keep this program healthy and relevant; the human factor simply cannot be automated.” 

As the F-35 Enterprise expands globally with each consecutive year, Skeen provided her outlook for the future of the program. “This air system, and F-35 capabilities are changing the way we look at warfighting. We are learning so much through current operations and our partners. With every exercise and each deployment, the impact of F-35 around the world is becoming more significant and profound.”
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿
column10: X-35的历史激发了F-35的能力
column11: 21世纪的威胁要求战斗机进行改造。在世纪之交，美国对手的先进传感器和武器系统将超越军用航空能力。组建了一支精英团队，发展第五代作战能力，以确保在快速加速的数字时代保持空中优势。由此产生的今天使用的空中系统（F-35、F-22）由超音速、隐身性能、精确武器和旨在以全球威胁速度发展的软件来定义。如果没有那些将未来概念成熟化为作战现实的人的开创性工作，这些能力都不可能实现。Tanya Skeen目前担任F-35联合项目办公室的执行主任，她最近回顾了自己作为X-35项目飞行科学工程师的最初经历。她对太空和飞机的热爱使她在作为工程师、测试人员和有成就的项目经理的职业生涯中走上了一条为开创性技术做出贡献的道路。“我很高兴能够成为[X-35]项目早期的一部分，现在又回到了[F-35]项目的领导岗位上。”这是一个令人难以置信的荣誉。当我还是一名年轻的工程师编写代码并进行测试时，我从未想过我会有机会在这个级别上，在能力交付和操作的这个阶段，再次参与该计划――这太棒了。”X-35，一架概念演示飞机（CDA）由洛克希德・马丁公司开发，后来被称为“联合攻击战斗机”。在对美国军用飞机变型进行了广泛的开发和测试之后，第五代空中系统作为F-35 Lightning II于2000年代投入生产。2000年10月24日，洛克希德・马丁公司的X-35A CDA完成了从加利福尼亚州帕尔代尔到附近爱德华兹空军基地的第一次飞行，使用了刚刚超过2000英尺的跑道起飞，然后降下起落架爬升到10000英尺。正如洛克希德・马丁公司X-35机头试飞员汤姆・莫根菲尔德（Tom Morgenfeld）在2000年所描述的：“这架飞机看起来和飞行起来都像一架战斗机。”随后，X-35政府工业团队进行的试飞验证了工程设计，随着X-35计划逐渐成熟为F-35计划，并提供了后来应用于生产飞机的数据。作为一名测试工程师吸引了Skeen的许多自然兴趣。“测试为我们提供了数据，我一直很欣赏数据如何帮助我理解事物。我对数据的热爱，以及我对解决问题的热爱，使测试对我如此有吸引力。”当被问及职业发展时，斯凯恩说，她丈夫是一名现役空军军官，也是一名测试工程师。“空军把我们带到了测试地点，如果你搬到了测试地点，你最好喜欢测试，特别是因为测试基地往往有点偏远！”工程创新对许多从事X-35项目的人来说是一种鼓舞――为了取得成果，不断有新的想法和设计出现，但并非总是按计划进行。团队学会了韧性，在从失败中恢复时变得更加创新。斯肯回忆道：“当你谈到创新时，我们看到了发动机的图纸和实物模型，并对发动机进行了大量测试。我们改进了数据，并从失败中吸取了教训。”。“我们尝试了，但失败了……我们又尝试了。”从那次经历中，她学到了一堂难忘的领导力和人生课。“事情并非总是按照我们预期的方式进行，但我们必须学习和调整，不要让较小的失败阻碍真正的大成功。”当被问及她在X-35项目期间参与的最具开创性的成就时，斯肯回忆起在X-35B上的工作。“我们是一名年轻的机组人员，在B[美国海军陆战队，短距起飞变体]飞机上编写控制法规，试图让飞机像直升机一样移动……这对航空工程师来说非常有趣。”以前的垂直升降飞机使用了直升发动机，但X-35B设计包括一个新的，轴驱动提升风扇系统。“以前从未建造过升降机风扇。我从事飞行科学工作，与飞行科学团队中的大多数人不同，我在整个部门工作――空气动力学测试、推进测试和控制律编码――并将这些工作结合在一起。这真的很令人兴奋和有意义。”斯凯恩早年的工程师生涯塑造了她作为行业高管的领导风格，她目前担任国防部高级执行官（SES）成员和F-35联合项目办公室执行主任，每天都在发挥作用。“国防部的领导能力”要求并要求我们提供数据来推动我们的决策。在收购过程中，我们每天都要解决很多难题。除了我的测试背景外，我也很欣赏收购的商业方面。我喜欢与我们的签约社区讨论项目的最佳收购策略。通过这些在战略对话中，我们使用数据来定义如何最好地解决这些难题。”当被问及她目前的职业发展情况时，Skeen表示，她专注于个人特质，如沟通技能和有效倾听。“工程和硬科学对我来说很容易，但我还必须专注于改善我的“软面”并专注于如何与人交往。我有一位高管教练，他帮助我克服盲点，而[他]是我在这个岗位上最有价值的资源之一。”斯凯恩专注于优先考虑她的家人，因为他们在他们的军事家庭经历中从一个地方搬到另一个地方。“我最好的建议是，不要过于沉迷于“完美的职业”……做对你有意义的事，接受挑战性的工作，在每一份工作中都要努力工作，记住你的家庭是最重要的。成功就会随之而来。”与X-35的前同事团聚，庆祝该项目的周年纪念和成就，对Tanya Skeen来说是一个激动人心的前景。“我们建立了紧密的联系，专注于一项成为现实的雄心勃勃的任务……成为该团队的一员和我们的共同经历是一种巨大的荣幸。”现在，F-35闪电II已经成为现实，全球部署了560多架飞机，飞行时数超过30万小时，以及在作战航空中无与伦比的空中系统能力。随着时间的推移，与F-35项目的联系加强了斯肯的信念，即人是技术和创新最重要的方面。“要创造F-35这样的技术奇迹，需要很多聪明、敬业的人。如果没有人撰写合同、管理财务、维护空气系统和致力于未来发展，以保持该计划的健康和相关性，这是不可能的；人为因素根本无法自动化。”随着F-35企业每年在全球扩张，Skeen对该计划的未来进行了展望。“这一空中系统和F-35的能力正在改变我们看待作战的方式。我们通过当前的作战行动和我们的合作伙伴学到了很多东西。随着每次演习和部署，F-35在世界各地的影响越来越显著和深远。”

column2: Denmark Welcomes First F-35
column3:
CRYSTAL CITY, Va. (APRIL 08, 2021) On April 7, Denmark's first F-35A, L-001, was delivered to the Royal Danish Air Force. The Kingdom of Denmark commemorated the milestone with members of the Ministry of Defence, Danish Defence, the Danish Defence Acquisition and Logistics Organization, the Royal Danish Air Force, U.S. Military Services, and industry partners at Lockheed Martin's Fort Worth, Texas facility.

"The roll-out ceremony of our first F-35 is a huge milestone for Denmark. The F-35 will play a major transformational role, not only for the Danish Air Force but for the Danish Armed Forces," said F-35 Joint Program Office, Denmark National Deputy, Col. Jonas Ottosen.

Denmark is the fifth European NATO nation to fly and operate the F-35. Their addition strengthens NATO's fifth-generation airpower and unites them with the air defenses of the United Kingdom, Italy, the Netherlands, and Norway.

"Denmark has been a partner in the F-35 program for more than 20 years. The F-35 partnership is an essential platform that unites its participants. Operationally and strategically, the F-35 will surpass anything we can do with our current inventory. It will continue to strengthen cooperation with our partners and allies. For our defense industrial base, the program has been a catalyst for technological development, closer industrial cooperation, and positioning Danish companies in a globalized supply chain," continued Col. Ottosen.

L-001 made its first flight in January 2021 and completed a series of comprehensive tests to ensure that all systems function properly in the aircraft before delivery. The aircraft will arrive at Luke Air Force Base, Arizona next week to facilitae the training of Danish F-35 pilots and maintainers.

The construction of brand new Danish F-35 facilities at Air Base Skrydstrup in Vojens, Denmark, specifically designed to support the fifth-generation aircraft, began in 2020. In October of 2023, Denmark is scheduled to receive their First F-35 Aircraft Arrival in-country. 

The F-35 is the premier multi-mission strike fighter of choice for three U.S. services, seven international partners, and six Foreign Military Sales customers. The F-35 routinely demonstrates its unmatched capabilities at the hands of our joint and international warfighters, performing combat operations from land and the sea. The F-35 system combines stealth, advanced weapons and sensors, and information sharing with joint and allied forces to dominate current and future threats.

Visit www.jsf.mil for more information on the F-35 Lightning II.
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿
column10: 丹麦欢迎第一架F-35
column11: 弗吉尼亚州水晶城（2021年4月8日）4月7日，丹麦的第一架F-35A、L-001交付给丹麦皇家空军。丹麦王国与国防部、丹麦国防部、丹麦国防采购和后勤组织、丹麦皇家空军、美国军事部门以及洛克希德・马丁公司德克萨斯州沃思堡工厂的工业合作伙伴一起纪念这一里程碑。“我们第一架F-35的推出仪式对丹麦来说是一个巨大的里程碑。F-35将发挥重大转型作用，不仅对丹麦空军，而且对丹麦武装部队，丹麦国家代表乔纳斯・奥托森上校说，丹麦是第五个驾驶和操作F-35的欧洲北约国家。他们的加入加强了北约的第五代空中力量，并将其与英国、意大利、荷兰和挪威的防空部队联合起来。“20多年来，丹麦一直是F-35计划的合作伙伴。F-35伙伴关系是团结参与者的重要平台。在作战和战略上，F-35将超越我们现有库存所能做到的一切。它将继续加强与我们的伙伴和盟国的合作。对于我们的国防工业基地来说，该计划是技术发展、更紧密的工业合作以及将丹麦公司定位于全球化供应链的催化剂，“Ottosen.L-001上校于2021年1月进行了首次飞行，并完成了一系列全面测试，以确保交付前所有系统在飞机上正常运行。该飞机将于下周抵达亚利桑那州的卢克空军基地，以促进丹麦F-35飞行员和维修人员的培训。丹麦Vojens Skrydstrup空军基地专为支持第五代飞机而设计的全新丹麦F-35设施于2020年开始建造。2023年10月，丹麦计划接收第一架F-35飞机抵达该国。F-35是三个美国军种、七个国际合作伙伴和六个外国军售客户首选的首屈一指的多任务攻击战斗机。F-35经常在我们的联合和国际作战人员手中展示其无与伦比的能力，从陆地和海上执行作战行动。F-35系统结合了隐形、先进武器和传感器以及与联合部队和盟军的信息共享，以控制当前和未来的威胁。有关F-35闪电II的更多信息，请访问www.jsf.mil。

column2: F-35 Joint Program Office begins deployment of new logistics hardware to F-35 squadrons
column3:
ARLINGTON, Va., August 9, 2021 C The F-35 Lightning II Joint Program Office (JPO), in partnership with Lockheed Martin, has achieved a milestone in the transition to the modernized Operational Data Integrated Network (ODIN) F-35 logistics information system by deploying ODIN hardware to two F-35 squadrons.

Personnel from the JPO, Lockheed Martin, and local squadron maintenance crews completed the installation of new computer hardware called the ODIN Base Kit (OBK) July 16 at Naval Air Station Lemoore, California, in support of Strike Fighter Squadron (VFA) 125, and Aug. 6 at Nellis Air Force Base, Nevada, in support of the 422nd Test and Evaluation Squadron (TES). 

These are the first of 14 scheduled OBK deployments from July 2021 through early 2022. 

With the installations at Lemoore and Nellis, there are three OBKs installed with F-35 Squadrons C one from each U.S. service. In September 2020, the United States Marine Corps test squadron VMX-1 at Marine Corps Air Station (MCAS) Yuma, Arizona, successfully evaluated the ODIN hardware over 30 days of testing, and the OBK hardware has remained in service there since installation.  There is one additional OBK installed at Naval Air Station Patuxent River, Maryland, where it is a key element of the F-35 Integrated Test Force’s flight test operations.  

As announced early in 2020, ODIN is the planned replacement of the F-35 Autonomic Logistics Information Systems (ALIS).  The successful deployment of this new ODIN hardware is an important step in the evolution to a modern, capable, and affordable logistics information system for the F-35 fleet.   

Designed by Lockheed Martin, the OBK replaces the legacy ALIS computer hardware called the Standard Operating Unit unclassified (SOU-U) server.  The new ODIN hardware is 75% smaller and lighter, has a nearly 30% lower cost, and is designed to run both the current ALIS software, as well as its future replacement ODIN software applications and data environment.

“The reduction in size and weight [of the OBK], not to mention the massive increase in performance, will provide maximum flexibility in the Air Force’s ability to project airpower,” said Air Force Master Sgt. James Ferrell, F-35 lead production superintendent, Bolt Aircraft Maintenance Unit, 57th Aircraft Maintenance Squadron (AMXS), Nellis AFB, Nevada. The 57th AMXS owns and operates the 422nd TES’ maintenance equipment.

The installations at Lemoore and Nellis were both accomplished by military maintenance personnel assisted by experts from JPO and Lockheed Martin.  At each site, the hardware installation and set-up were complete and systems ready for operation in a matter of days, demonstrating the suitability and ease of use for administrators of this new hardware.

Planning is underway to replace all remaining SOU-U servers starting in 2022. The timeline to complete upgrades will depend on available funding and squadron operational constraints.

“With this new server hardware, the JPO now has a viable successor to the aging ALIS system hardware that offers a significant performance upgrade to F-35 units, at lower cost, and in a readily supportable package,” said Air Force Col. Dan Smith, JPO Maintenance Systems director charged with overseeing ALIS and ODIN. “OBK allows us to replace hardware before obsolescence issues become critical, and provides faster service to the maintainers.” 

The new hardware design offers numerous improvements over the existing ALIS servers. Immediately obvious is its reduced size, with two transportable suitcase-sized cases replacing a full rack of electronics, thus reducing weight from over 800 pounds to just two modules weighing under 100 pounds each. Its next-generation computing performance improves the user experience by demonstrating processing times decreased by as much as 50%, system interactions with similarly reduced wait times, and improved efficiency in system administration. And because the servers are based on currently available commercial components, they are inherently more serviceable and supportable.

Looking ahead, JPO and Lockheed Martin are working together to further extend affordability advantages of the OBK, including evaluating the potential to host multiple operating squadrons on a single server, designing and evaluating similarly improved hardware for other classified functions, and further reducing the workload of system administrators at the installed sites.  These benefits will be realized as the OBK is extended across the entirety of the F-35 fleet, Smith added. 

For additional information, visit www.jsf.mil.

column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿
column10: F-35联合项目办公室开始向F-35中队部署新的后勤硬件
column11: 弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿，2021年8月9日―F-35 Lightning II联合项目办公室（JPO）与洛克希德・马丁公司合作，通过向两个F-35中队部署ODIN硬件，在向现代化作战数据综合网络（ODIN）F-35后勤信息系统过渡的过程中实现了一个里程碑，7月16日，当地中队维修人员在加利福尼亚州莱莫尔海军航空站完成了名为ODIN Base Kit（OBK）的新计算机硬件的安装，以支持打击战斗机中队（VFA）125；8月6日，在内华达州内利斯空军基地完成了名为ODIN Base Kit（OBK）的新计算机硬件的安装，以支持第422测试和评估中队（TES）。这是2021年7月至2022年初计划的14次OBK部署中的第一次。在Lemoore和Nellis安装后，有三个OBK安装了F-35中队――每个美国军种一个。2020年9月，位于亚利桑那州尤马市海军陆战队航空站（MCAS）的美国海军陆战队VMX-1测试中队在30天的测试中成功评估了ODIN硬件，OBK硬件自安装以来一直在那里使用。另外还有一个OBK安装在马里兰州帕塔克森特河海军航空站，它是F-35综合测试部队飞行测试行动的关键要素。正如2020年初宣布的那样，ODIN计划取代F-35自主后勤信息系统（ALIS）。这种新型ODIN硬件的成功部署是F-35机队向现代化、功能强大、价格合理的后勤信息系统发展的重要一步。由洛克希德・马丁公司设计的OBK取代了传统的ALIS计算机硬件，称为标准操作单元非机密（SOU-U）服务器。新的ODIN硬件体积更小、重量更轻75%，成本降低近30%，设计用于运行当前的ALIS软件，以及未来替代的ODIN软件应用程序和数据环境更不用说性能的大幅提升，将为空军提供最大的灵活性，以投射空中力量，”内华达州内利斯空军基地第57飞机维修中队（AMXS）博尔特飞机维修队F-35首席生产总监、空军少校詹姆斯・费雷尔（James Ferrell）说。第57届AMXS拥有并运营第422届TES的维修设备。Lemoore和Nellis的安装均由军事维修人员完成，并由JPO和洛克希德・马丁公司的专家协助完成。在每个站点，硬件安装和设置都已完成，系统在几天内即可投入运行，这证明了这种新硬件的适用性和易用性。正在计划从2022年开始更换所有剩余的SOU-U服务器。完成升级的时间表将取决于可用的资金和中队作战限制。“有了这种新的服务器硬件，JPO现在有了一个可行的替代品，取代了老化的ALIS系统硬件，以较低的成本和易于支持的包件，为F-35部队提供了显著的性能升级。”负责监督ALIS和ODIN的JPO维修系统总监、空军上校丹・史密斯（Dan Smith）说。“OBK允许我们在过时问题变得严重之前更换硬件，并为维护人员提供更快的服务。”新的硬件设计对现有ALIS服务器进行了大量改进。最明显的是它的体积缩小了，两个可移动的行李箱大小的箱子取代了一个完整的电子机架，从而将重量从800磅减少到两个模块，每个模块的重量不到100磅。它的下一代计算性能通过证明处理时间减少了多达50%，系统交互减少了等待时间，提高了系统管理效率，从而改善了用户体验。而且由于服务器基于当前可用的商用组件，因此它们本质上更易维护和支持。展望未来，JPO和洛克希德・马丁公司正在合作，进一步扩大OBK的可负担性优势，包括评估在一台服务器上托管多个作战中队的可能性，为其他分类功能设计和评估类似改进的硬件，并进一步减少已安装站点系统管理员的工作量。史密斯补充道，随着OBK在整个F-35机队中的推广，这些好处将得以实现。有关更多信息，请访问www.jsf.mil###

column2: FRCE marks 100th F-35 induction
column3:
Fleet Readiness Center East (FRCE) marked a milestone in its support of the F-35 Lightning II program when the depot inducted its 100th F-35 for modifications June 11. 

The induction signifies more than just a number C it represents eight years of efforts to stand up and grow the F-35 modification line at the depot, said FRCE Commanding Officer Col. Thomas A. Atkinson. 

“We are very proud to support the F-35 platform and achieve this important milestone,” Atkinson said. “The F-35 maintenance concept is different than what we see on other platforms. Our experience on these 100 jets has made us stronger as a command and we look forward to continuing our contribution as more F-35s are fielded.”

The depot has been able to meet this milestone only through the diligence and commitment of the team servicing the aircraft, said FRCE F-35 Branch Head Ike Rettenmair.

“The team has come a long way since the first induction, and is one of the most dedicated teams I have been a part of,” Rettenmair said. “This platform has challenges that are unlike most others, and the team takes them head on. FRCE is 100 percent behind the partnered effort to make the F-35 program successful and, although we are only one piece of the pie in the enterprise, we take pride in supplying the warfighter with a capable and quality aircraft.”

In addition to marking a milestone, the 100th F-35 induction also serves as a stepping stone to the future of the program at the depot, said Matt Crisp, FRCE site lead for the F-35 Joint Program Office. An additional workload of F-35 components, a new lift fan facility and expansion of the F-35 aircraft line’s capacity are all coming into view on the horizon. 

“This is not the finish line,” Crisp said. “We’re just getting up to speed at this point. We’ve come a long way, and things are looking good going forward for FRC East and the people who work here, who live here, and rely on this program as how they support their families. There are a lot of really good things coming to our area.”

Rettenmair said he also looks forward to watching the program continue to grow. 

“Although 100 is a great milestone, there are still may more years to go in support of the F-35,” he said. “I have only been on the F-35 program for a short stint and I’m still getting my feet wet; however, it didn’t take me long to realize this is a special team and I’m glad to help lead the way into the future. I hope I’m still here to see our 200th aircraft induction and beyond, as FRCE continues to meet the mission with pride, teamwork and C at times C frustration, and always safely and with quality.”  

FRCE inducted its first F-35 aircraft for modification in July 2013 after having just eight months to prepare for the workload, said Jeanie Holder, the F-35 Joint Program Office induction manager at FRCE. Despite the compressed timeline, the facility was able to induct its first F-35B short takeoff-vertical landing variant on schedule, and has since proven capabilities on the remaining two aircraft variants: the F-35C carrier variant, and the F-35A conventional takeoff and landing variant. 

“There have been a lot of hands-on work and tireless hours executed to make this depot sufficient to support a fifth-generation jet that, at the time, we weren’t used to doing here,” Holder said. “For us to hit 100 aircraft is a huge accomplishment that shows just how hard we’ve collectively worked. It’s not just FRC East or the F-35 Joint Program Office or Lockheed Martin C it’s been a real team effort.”

That team effort has made the program more efficient as relationships between key stakeholders have developed and strengthened, noted Allen Williamson, an overhaul and repair supervisor on the F-35 line. 

“A lot of our government and industry partnerships have grown, and we’re getting buy-in from the partners to be able to turn these jets around as quickly as possible,” Williamson noted. “We’ve opened up and taken advice from Lockheed Martin and the Joint Program Office, and when we run into an issue we now have a consolidated team coming together to address it and figure out a way forward that works for all of us. I think we’ve been really successful at that.”

Joseph Simonds, an F-35 airframes work leader who has been with the program since the very first induction eight years ago, said this teamwork has helped the program make great strides in efficiency.

“We've gotten better, we’ve gotten quicker,” Simonds said. “A lot of the processes have gotten smoother because, just like any other program, when we first started there were a lot of unknowns. Over the years, everything has slowly fallen into line and the program gets better with that. Now it’s like, Here’s everything you need to do your job, so have at it.”

While the program has been improving efficiency and strengthening partnerships, the workforce modifying the aircraft has made gains in knowledge, Williamson added, which helps them quickly and competently address any new aircraft issues that might arise. 

“We still run into new hurdles all the time, but teamwork has gotten us to the 100th induction and will take us well beyond,” he said. “We know where to go when we need help, and who can help us, and we don’t delay in going there.

“The knowledge our mechanics have accumulated in just 100 jets, it’s great,” Williamson continued. “It’s amazing that they can troubleshoot these jets with the knowledge they’ve developed through working on these aircraft, taking things apart and putting them back together, and they can go in and pinpoint problems in a timely manner.”

The facilities, skills and knowledge of the artisans and strong partnerships that have facilitated the growth of the F-35 program at FRCE since its first induction have laid the groundwork for future success, Crisp said. 

“It is pretty remarkable when you think about where we've come from eight years ago, strike a baseline here and then look forward at what's coming this way,” he said. “Over these eight years, we haven’t just added dock space and added people; we’ve developed every one of the supporting logistical elements that put the tools in place so the production floor can go and execute, and gotten better, faster and stronger at what we’re doing.

“We're talking 100 airplanes C that's hundreds of thousands of hours of touch labor, and engineering and logistics support, just on the aircraft that have come through FRC East, not to mention the Rapid Response Team, depot field teams, and weight and balance teams going out to the fleet to assist. We’re talking parts manufacturing, the facilities and infrastructure we have improved, building those relationships; these have all been absolutely critical for us to have gotten to where we are, and to get us to where we need to go in the future.”

As the F-35 program continues to grow at the depot, Crisp said he anticipates even further development of the key support elements. For example, FRCE declared capabilities on several F-35 components in 2020 - meaning FRCE is now a verified source of repair and testing for these items C and is on track to declare for additional components this year and in the future. A lift fan facility scheduled for groundbreaking this year will provide FRCE with one of only two sites in the world that can service that system, and the F-35 program has plans for expanding the amount of aircraft FRCE can accommodate at once. 

“FRC East is absolutely critical not only to the United States Marine Corps, but to all of our international partners who are procuring F-35B aircraft, of which there are multiple,” Crisp said. “There’s a lot of work, a lot of jobs and a lot of touch labor that we’re going to need in the future, so that’s very exciting. And then when you look three to five years out, we’re going to start having active F-35 squadrons that are arriving here at Cherry Point C we’ll be able to walk down the street to a whole flight line of deployable F-35s and share knowledge and expertise with the squadrons. We’ll continue to build relationships that will benefit both the squadrons and the depot.”

The success of the F-35 program at FRCE, lies with the depot’s people, Holder said, and those people will continue to push for excellence as the program grows into the future. 

“From the floor up to our leadership here, you’ve got an A-team and that’s the only reason we’ve been as successful as we have,” Holder noted. “We all take our jobs very seriously, we own them, and we do what we have to do to make sure we are successful in getting these jets back to the fleet on time.”

FRCE is North Carolina's largest maintenance, repair, overhaul and technical services provider, with more than 4,000 civilian, military and contract workers. Its annual revenue exceeds $1 billion. The depot provides service to the fleet while functioning as an integral part of the greater U.S. Navy; Naval Air Systems Command; and Commander, Fleet Readiness Centers.
column9: CHERRY POINT，北卡罗来纳州，美国
column10: FRCE标志着第100个F-35感应发动机
column11: 舰队准备中心东部（FRCE）标志着其支持F-35 Lightning II计划的一个里程碑，该基地于6月11日启用了其第100架F-35进行改装。FRCE指挥官Thomas a.Atkinson上校说，这次入职不仅仅意味着一个数字――它代表了八年来在基地建立和发展F-35改装线的努力。阿特金森说：“我们非常自豪能够支持F-35平台并实现这一重要里程碑。”。“F-35的维修概念与我们在其他平台上看到的不同。我们在这100架喷气式飞机上的经验使我们的指挥能力更强，我们期待着随着更多F-35的部署，继续做出我们的贡献。”FRCE F-35分公司负责人艾克・雷滕梅尔（Ike Rettenmair）说：“只有通过飞机维修团队的努力和承诺，基地才能实现这一里程碑。自第一次入职以来，该团队已经走过了漫长的道路，是我所参与的最敬业的团队之一。”。“该平台面临着与大多数其他平台不同的挑战，团队将迎头赶上。FRCE百分之百地支持合作努力，使F-35计划取得成功。尽管我们只是企业中的一块蛋糕，但我们为向作战人员提供能力强、质量高的飞机而感到自豪。”F-35联合项目办公室FRCE现场负责人马特・克里斯普（Matt Crisp）表示，除了标志着一个里程碑外，第100次F-35入职培训还将成为该项目在基地未来发展的踏脚石。F-35部件的额外工作量、新的提升风扇设施以及F-35飞机生产线的扩容都即将出现。“这不是终点线，”克里斯普说。“在这一点上，我们正在加快步伐。我们已经走了很长一段路，对于FRC East以及在这里工作、居住、依靠该计划养家糊口的人们来说，未来的前景是美好的。我们地区有很多真正美好的事物。”雷滕梅尔说，他也期待着看到该节目继续发展。“虽然100是一个伟大的里程碑，但支持F-35还有很多年，”他说。“我参加F-35项目的时间很短，但我仍在努力；然而，没过多久，我就意识到这是一支特殊的团队，我很高兴能够帮助领导未来。我希望我仍能在这里看到我们第200架飞机的入职培训以及以后的培训，因为FRCE继续以自豪、团队精神和团队精神迎接任务d――有时――令人沮丧，而且始终安全且有质量。”FRCE的F-35联合项目办公室入职经理珍妮・霍尔德（Jeanie Holder）说，FRCE在仅有八个月的时间为工作量做准备后，于2013年7月对其首架F-35飞机进行了改装。尽管时间紧迫，该设施仍能如期投入其第一架F-35B短起飞垂直着陆变型，并在其余两种飞机变型上证明了其能力：F-35C航母变型和F-35A常规起飞和着陆变型。霍尔德说：“为了使这个基地足以支持第五代喷气式飞机，我们进行了大量的实际工作和不知疲倦的工作，当时，我们在这里还不习惯这样做。”。“对我们来说，击打100架飞机是一项巨大的成就，它表明了我们的共同努力。这不仅仅是FRC东部或F-35联合项目办公室或洛克希德马丁公司――这是一项真正的团队努力。”F-35线大修和维修主管艾伦・威廉姆森（Allen Williamson）指出，随着关键利益相关者之间关系的发展和加强，团队的努力提高了项目的效率。威廉姆森指出：“我们的许多政府和行业伙伴关系已经发展壮大，我们正在得到这些伙伴的认可，以便能够尽快扭转这些飞机的局面。”。“我们已经开放并听取了洛克希德・马丁公司和联合项目办公室的建议，当我们遇到一个问题时，我们现在有一个整合的团队来解决这个问题，并找出一条对我们所有人都有效的前进道路。我想我们在这方面真的取得了成功。”约瑟夫・西蒙兹，一位自八年前第一次入职以来就一直参与该项目的F-35机身工作负责人表示，这种团队合作帮助该项目在效率方面取得了长足进步。“我们做得更好，做得更快，”西蒙兹说。“许多程序都变得更加顺利，因为，就像其他任何程序一样，我们刚开始时有很多未知因素。多年来，一切都逐渐趋于一致，程序也因此变得更好。现在就像是，这是你需要做的所有工作，所以要做好。”威廉姆森补充说，虽然该计划一直在提高效率和加强合作关系，但改装飞机的员工在知识方面取得了进步，这有助于他们快速、胜任地解决可能出现的任何新飞机问题。他说：“我们仍然不断遇到新的障碍，但团队合作已经让我们进入了第100次入职，并将使我们远远超越这些障碍。”。“当我们需要帮助时，我们知道该去哪里，谁能帮助我们，我们毫不迟疑地去那里。”威廉姆森继续说，“我们的机械师在100架喷气式飞机上积累的知识太棒了。”。“令人惊讶的是，他们能够利用在这些飞机上工作、拆卸和组装过程中积累的知识对这些飞机进行故障排除，并且能够及时发现问题。”Crisp说，自F-35项目首次入职以来，工匠们的设施、技能和知识以及强大的合作伙伴关系促进了F-35项目的发展，为未来的成功奠定了基础。他说：“当你想到八年前我们从何而来，在这里划出一条底线，然后展望未来，这是非常了不起的。”。“在这八年中，我们不仅增加了码头空间和人员；我们还开发了每一个支持后勤要素，将工具放置到位，使生产车间能够运转和执行，并在我们的工作中变得更好、更快和更强。“我们说的是100架飞机――这意味着几十万小时的人工、工程和后勤支持，就在经过FRC East的飞机上，更不用说快速反应小组、基地现场小组和重量与平衡小组前往舰队提供协助了。我们说的是零件制造、faci我们改善了基础设施和基础设施，建立了这些关系；这些对于我们达到现在的水平以及未来的发展都是至关重要的。”随着F-35计划在基地的持续发展，Crisp表示，他预计关键支持要素将进一步发展。例如，FRCE在2020年宣布了多个F-35部件的能力，这意味着FRCE现在是这些部件的经验证的维修和测试来源，并有望在今年宣布更多部件一个计划于今年破土动工的升降机风扇设施将为FRCE提供世界上仅有的两个能够为该系统提供服务的站点之一，F-35计划计划扩大FRCE可同时容纳的飞机数量。克里斯普说：“FRC East不仅对美国海军陆战队至关重要，而且对我们所有采购F-35B飞机的国际合作伙伴也至关重要，其中有多架。”。“我们未来需要大量的工作、大量的工作和大量的体力劳动，这非常令人兴奋。然后，当你展望三到五年后，我们将开始拥有现役的F-35中队，这些中队将抵达Cherry Point――我们将能够沿着街道走到depl的整个飞行线霍尔德说，F-35计划在FRCE的成功取决于该基地的人员，随着该计划在未来的发展，这些人员将继续努力追求卓越。霍尔德说：“从地面到我们的领导层，你们拥有一支一流的团队，这是我们取得如此成功的唯一原因。我们都非常认真地对待自己的工作，我们拥有这些工作，我们做我们必须做的事情，以确保我们能够成功地将这些飞机按时运回舰队。”FRCE是北卡罗来纳州最大的维护、维修、大修和技术服务提供商，拥有4000多名文职、军事和合同工。其年收入超过10亿美元。该基地为舰队提供服务，同时作为大美国海军、海军航空系统司令部和舰队指挥官的组成部分准备中心。

column2: F-35- Logistics at the speed of Lightning II
column3:
CRYSTAL CITY, VA. (May 26, 2021) U.S. Navy Lt. Cmdr. Glenn Uy believes the F-35 Lightning II Joint Program Office (F-35 JPO) is a place where employees can do great things because their work serves a higher purpose. As the F-35 JPO's Japan Foreign Military Sales In-Country Liaison Officer in Tokyo, Japan, Uy wears many hats. He is the Supply Chain Lead, Customs Clearance Officer, and Assistant Contracting Officer Representative for the Technology Security Support Team. Uy credits a former job assignment in preparing him for the culture at the F-35 JPO.

“During my second deployment to Afghanistan in 2016, I wore multiple hats as the Branch Chief for the Contracting Enabler Cell. I developed extensive skills and experience in learning how to stay calm, focused, prioritize and deescalate situations, and find creative ways to make things work. The transferable experience from Afghanistan helped me become confident, more effective, and efficient in my current job as a Customs Clearance Officer," Uy said.

Uy's arrival to F-35 JPO came through a connection made while serving in Afghanistan. “I met a fellow service member who would later go on to serve at the F-35 Program Office. We remained in contact following this time, and he reached out later to say there was a great job at F-35, and I was interested in going there," said Uy.

Uy reported in May 2019 and quickly grew accustomed to traveling back and forth between Tokyo and Washington D.C., then the COVID-19 pandemic's onset locked him down in Japan. 

“The initial lockdown and store closures was like a scene from the movie I Am Legend, but I had to go to work every day in person to fulfill our team’s part of the F-35 mission,” commented Uy.

Although physically separated from his teammates for over a year, Uy notes that it was a positive experience due to the supportive leadership of the Japan Foreign Military Sales team. "The leadership team facilitates open communication lines, encourages collaboration efforts, and exhibits a strong sense of commitment. Everyone on the team shares the same clear and important vision, serving the best interests of the F-35 organization as a whole, and is passionately dedicated to the mission,” said Uy, who made sure he is available to his team as much as possible even when hindered by the significant time difference.

Uy's job at the F-35 JPO requires him to be precise, meticulous, and patient. “Being an F-35 Supply Chain Officer and Customs Clearance Officer means I make sure the parts clear customs on time, and what the shippers declare on the customs form is indeed what they have described," said Uy. "A detailed review of their descriptions is required because as these parts clear customs, they are not opened and are not subject to customs inspection. Everything on the forms needs to be precise, the weight, the dimensions, signatures, and final destination of these parts."

The parts clearing customs in Japan are import and export shipments originating from and to global locations. The job entails problem-solving and requires excellent interpersonal skills, dealing with various shipping agents. 

The materials in the shipments are essential to the assembly and maintenance of F-35s. "We have factories in Japan that assemble the F135 engines, we have the Nagoya Final Assembly and Check-Out facility that builds the F-35 itself, and we get parts coming in for the Japan Air Self-Defense Force," said Uy. "A costly work stoppage can happen if a part doesn't come in or it is delayed in customs. My position is essential to keeping the assembly lines flowing."

The challenges within his role exist because "the target usually moves," and the teams must be prepared to adopt new procedures. 

“We have a new initiative with the Defense Logistics Agency and the U.S. Transportation Command, global asset management of parts will change and impact my role as the Customs Clearance Officer. This initiative will see the Transportation Management Officers take over some of the functions we carry out," said Uy. "To prep for that, we all participate in global asset management testing, or sending parts to different locations and guaranteeing that the process is followed with the right forms and correct clearances.” 

Uy has no doubt that the people, the culture, and the mission purpose contribute to the uniqueness of the JPO C and being inclusive will only refine it. “When you have a wide array of talents, we learn from one another and raise each other to a higher standard, and that boosts retention. Sharing each other's cultures celebrates the diversity of thought, perspectives, and backgrounds,” said Uy. “It is like the recipe for a gourmet meal. A diversity of ingredients makes the final result even better than its individual parts."
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿
column10: F-35-闪电速度下的后勤II
column11: 弗吉尼亚州水晶城（2021年5月26日）美国海军少校Glenn Uy认为F-35 Lightning II联合项目办公室（F-35 JPO）是员工可以做大事的地方，因为他们的工作有更高的目的。作为F-35 JPO在日本东京的日本对外军售联络官，Uy身兼数职。他是技术安全支持团队的供应链负责人、清关官和助理合同官代表。Uy将其为F-35 JPO的文化做准备归功于之前的工作任务。“在2016年我第二次部署到阿富汗期间，我担任合同启用单元的分支主管。我在学习如何保持冷静、专注、确定优先顺序和减少情况方面积累了丰富的技能和经验，并找到了创造性的方法使事情顺利进行。来自阿富汗的可转移经验对我有所帮助在我目前的清关官员工作中变得自信、更有效、更高效，”Uy说。Uy来到F-35 JPO是通过在阿富汗服役期间建立的联系。“我遇到了一位同事，他后来在F-35项目办公室工作。我们在这之后一直保持联系，他后来说F-35有一份很棒的工作，我有兴趣去那里。”said Uy.Uy于2019年5月报道，并很快习惯于在东京和华盛顿特区之间来回旅行，然后新冠病毒-19大流行的爆发将他锁定在日本。“最初的封锁和商店关闭就像电影《我是传奇》中的一幕，但我不得不每天亲自去工作，以完成我们团队在F-35任务中的一部分。”Uy评论道。虽然与队友身体上分离了一年多，但Uy指出，这是一次积极的经历，得益于日本对外军事销售团队的支持性领导。“领导团队促进开放的沟通渠道，鼓励合作努力，并表现出强烈的承诺感。团队中的每个人都有着相同的清晰而重要的愿景，服务于整个F-35组织的最佳利益，并热情地献身于使命。”乌伊说，他确保自己尽可能多地为团队服务，即使受到明显时差的阻碍。乌伊在F-35 JPO的工作要求他精确、细致和耐心。“作为一名F-35供应链官员和清关官员，意味着我确保零件按时清关，托运人在报关单上申报的内容确实是他们所描述的，”Uy说需要对其说明进行详细审查，因为这些零件在清关时不会打开，也不会接受海关检查。表格上的所有内容都需要精确，包括重量、尺寸、签名和这些零件的最终目的地。“在日本清关的零件是从全球各地进口和出口的货物。这项工作需要解决问题，并需要优秀的人际交往技巧，与各种货运代理打交道。货物中的材料对F-35的组装和维护至关重要。“我们在日本有工厂组装F135发动机，我们有名古屋总装和检查设施，自行建造F-35，我们还为日本航空自卫队提供零件，”Uy说如果一个零件没有进货或在海关被耽搁，可能会发生代价高昂的停工。我的职位对于保持装配线的正常运转至关重要。“他职责范围内的挑战是存在的，因为“目标通常会移动”，团队必须准备采用新的程序。Uy说：“我们与国防后勤局和美国运输司令部有一项新计划，零件的全球资产管理将改变并影响我作为清关官员的角色。这项计划将使运输管理官员接管我们执行的一些职能。”。“为了做好准备，我们都参与了全球资产管理测试，或将零件发送到不同的地点，并确保流程得到正确的表格和正确的许可。”Uy毫不怀疑，人民、文化和使命目标有助于JPO的独特性――而包容性只会使其更加完善。乌伊说：“当你拥有各种各样的人才时，我们会互相学习，提高彼此的水平，这会提高记忆力。分享彼此的文化可以庆祝思想、观点和背景的多样性。”。“这就像是一顿美餐的食谱。不同的配料使得最终的结果比单独的部分还要好。”

column2: MARCENT Commander meets with F-35 Squadron
column3:
MACDILL AIR FORCE BASE, Florida C Last week, Lieutenant General Carl Mundy III, Commander of Marine Corps Forces, Central Command, met with Marine Fighter Attack Training Squadron 501 (VMFAT-501), an F-35B squadron from 2nd Marine Aircraft Wing conducting training on MacDill Air Force Base.

The 2nd MAW training squadron, based out of Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort, South Carolina, trained for two weeks on MacDill executing simulated missions varying from close air support, to air-to-air combat operations.

“MacDill’s aviation ranges, and the Florida weather this time of year allows squadrons like ours to increase our operational tempo, and significantly benefits our student pilots and aircraft maintainers,” said VMFAT-501 commanding officer, Lieutenant Colonel Paul Holst.

Lieutenant General Mundy’s visit to MacDill’s flight line follows his most recent travel to the Central Command area of operations, during which he met with Marines from several different units currently deployed to the region. Among those Lt. Gen. Mundy visited was the Aviation Combat Element of the 15th Marine Expeditionary Unit, which employs F-35Bs.

“Some of these instructors have over 10 years of experience on the F-35B platform,” said Master Gunnery Sgt. Huber, VMFAT-501 maintenance chief, “but even in teaching student pilots and mechanics through advanced-level training operations, every Marine aviator is constantly maintaining, and expanding its proficiency on the aircraft.”

The F-35B is a 5th generation fighter, and has revolutionized air operations across the U.S. Armed Forces since the Marine Corps’ declaration of initial operating capability in 2015. In deploying units to different training environments the pilots and maintainers refine their abilities to not only efficiently utilize the complex systems of the F-35B, but fluidly react and implement them in diverse scenarios. The training conducted in VMFAT-501 will ready Marine aviators, as well as one pilot from the Australian Armed Forces, on the F-35B to operate in expeditionary environments, like that of the Aviation Combat Element on 15th MEU while deployed to the 5th Fleet in Central Command.

Lieutenant General Mundy and the Marines of VMFAT-501 discussed the significant technological advancements in the F-35B and the military advantage it brings to U.S. Central Command.

MARCENT provides Marine Expeditionary Forces capable of conducting a wide range of operations, offering Central Command a responsive and unique set of capabilities.


 -30-


For further questions, please contact U.S. Marine Corps Forces, Central Command Communication Strategy and Operations at MarcentCommstrat@usmc.mil.
column6: MACDILL AIR FORCE BASE, FL, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国佛罗里达州麦克迪尔空军基地
column10: 马森特指挥官会见F-35中队
column11: 佛罗里达州麦克迪尔空军基地――上周，中央司令部海军陆战队司令卡尔・蒙迪三世中将会见了海军陆战队攻击训练中队501（VMFAT-501），该中队是第二海军陆战队飞机联队的一支F-35B中队，在麦克迪尔空军基地进行训练，基地位于南卡罗来纳州波弗特海军陆战队空军基地，在麦克迪尔空军基地接受为期两周的训练，执行从近距离空中支援到空对空作战等各种模拟任务。“麦克迪尔的航程，以及每年这个时候佛罗里达州的天气，使我们这样的中队能够提高我们的作战节奏，并使我们的学生飞行员和飞机维修人员受益匪浅。”VMFAT-501指挥官保罗・霍尔斯特中校（Paul Holst）说。蒙迪中将访问麦克迪尔的飞行线之前，他最近一次访问了中央指挥部行动区，期间会见了目前部署在该地区的几个不同部队的海军陆战队。蒙迪中将访问了其中的航空兵第15海军陆战队远征部队作战分队，使用F-35B。“其中一些教员在F-35B平台上有超过10年的经验，”VMFAT-501维修负责人、枪手大师Huber中士说，“但是，即使通过高级训练操作来教授学生飞行员和机械学，每一位海军飞行员都在不断地维护和提高其对飞机的熟练程度。”F-35B是第5代战斗机，自海军陆战队于2015年宣布具备初始作战能力以来，它彻底改变了美国武装部队的空中作战。在将部队部署到不同的训练环境中，飞行员和维修人员不仅提高了他们的能力，而且有效地利用了F-35B的复杂系统-在VMFAT-501中进行的训练将使F-35B上的海军陆战队飞行员以及澳大利亚武装部队的一名飞行员做好在远征环境中作战的准备，如部署到中央指挥部第五舰队的15 MEU航空作战分队。利尤特南特・蒙迪将军和VMFAT-501的海军陆战队讨论了F-35B的重大技术进步及其给美国中央司令部带来的军事优势。马森特提供了能够进行广泛作战的海军陆战队远征部队，为中央司令部提供了一套反应迅速且独特的能力如有其他问题，请联系美国海军陆战队中央司令部通信战略与行动部，电话：MarcentCommstrat@usmc.mil.

column2: UPCOMING F-35 Night Flying Operations
column3:
Adjutant General of Vermont C State Public Affairs Officer
789 Vermont National Guard Road C Colchester, VT 05446-3004
State PAO:  CPT Mike Arcovitch (802) 338-3478, BB (802) 734-1677

TAG Release 20-27

Friday, October 23, 2020

UPCOMING F-35 Night Flying Operations 

SOUTH BURLINGTON, Vt. C The Vermont Air National Guard will begin night flying operations from Tuesday, Oct. 27 through Friday, Oct. 30, with takeoff’s occurring between 5-7 p.m. and landings occurring around 8-10 p.m.

Area residents may see and hear F-35A Lightning II aircraft taking off and landing from the Burlington International Airport from 5-10 p.m., which is later than our normal daytime flying operations. All night flight training missions are scheduled to be completed before 10 p.m.

“Night time flying is an important part in our training regimen at the 158th Fighter Wing, not only for our pilots, but for the maintainers as well,” said Lt. Col. Anthony Marek, the 134th Flight Squadron commander. “In order to remain ready to fly 24/7, operating and maintaining the F-35 in the hours of darkness keeps us tactically proficient no matter the time of day.” 
 
The 158th Fighter Wing professionals are required to conduct night operations to meet U.S. Air Force and Major Command requirements and proficiencies. The Vermont Air National Guard will continue regularly scheduled, daytime flying operations during drill weekends, which traditionally occur the first weekend of each month.
 
For more information contact Joint Force Headquarters; Maj. Scott Detweiler, 802.338.3434, john.s.detweiler.mil@mail.mil. 


###
column9: 美国佛蒙特州南伯灵顿
column10: 即将到来的F-35夜间飞行行动
column11: 佛蒙特州-州公共事务官员助理将军佛蒙特州国民警卫队路789号-科尔切斯特，VT 05446-3004州PAO:CPT迈克・阿科维奇（802）338-3478，BB（802）734-1677标签发布20-27 2020年10月23日星期五即将在伯灵顿南部进行的F-35夜间飞行行动，佛蒙特州-佛蒙特州国民警卫队将于10月27日星期二至10月30日星期五开始夜间飞行，起飞时间为下午5-7点，降落时间为晚上8-10点。当地居民可能会在下午5-10点看到并听到F-35A Lightning II飞机从伯灵顿国际机场起飞和降落。，这比我们白天正常的飞行时间要晚。第134飞行中队指挥官安东尼・马雷克中校说：“夜间飞行是158战斗机联队训练计划的重要组成部分，不仅对我们的飞行员，对维修人员也是如此。”。“为了随时准备全天候飞行，在黑暗中操作和维护F-35使我们无论在白天什么时候都能熟练掌握战术。”158战斗机联队的专业人员需要进行夜间作战，以满足美国空军和主要指挥的要求和熟练程度。佛蒙特州空军国民警卫队将在演习周末继续进行定期安排的日间飞行行动，通常在每个月的第一个周末进行。有关更多信息，请联系联合部队总部；斯科特・德特维勒少校，802.338.3434，约翰・s・德特维勒。mil@mail.mil. ###

column2: An inside look at F-35 pilot helmet fittings
column3:
HILL AIR FORCE BASE, Utah -- Reservists in the 419th Operations Support Squadron play a crucial role to ensure the safety of pilots assigned to the 419th Fighter Wing, the Air Force Reserve’s only combat-capable F-35 unit.  

“We are responsible for maintaining and repairing pilot gear to ensure everything is in proper working condition,” said Staff Sgt. AJ Arteaga, aircrew flight equipment reservist with the 419th OSS. “That also includes their helmet.”

Every helmet is custom-fitted to its pilot during a two-day process at a fit facility. To begin assembly of the helmet, pilots have their heads measured and scanned to secure the perfect fit. 

Once assembled, pilots need to have the optics aligned using a pupilometer, which measures the distance between their pupils within two millimeters of its center, so pilots see a single image on the helmet-mounted display.

On the display, pilots are able to view mission-critical information and obtain enhanced situational awareness of the battlefield simply by moving their head. The helmet gives pilots a 360-degree view of the F-35’s external environment without needing to tip the jet.

“The pilot can look down through a portion of their wing and see what’s below,” said Tech. Sgt. William Vass, 419th OSS. “When they look toward the cameras embedded on the F-35, that image projects onto their helmet display.”

The helmet’s innovative technology and precise fit require routine maintenance so pilots can complete their mission. In addition to pre- and post-flight fittings, the helmet is inspected every 105 days and has a 120-day fit check to ensure its functionality and safety.

“Pilots come in and put on all their gear so we can double-check to make sure everything fits properly and without issue,” Arteaga said. “Small things such as a new haircut or a couple of pounds gained could cause the helmet to not fit correctly.” 

Mask adjustments are also included within the helmet fitting. Pilots are sent to an oxygen tester where aircrew flight equipment technicians can identify any leaks around the mask that could prevent adequate oxygen flow.

“The next part is to ensure there is a proper distance between the mask and the visor,” Arteaga said.  “We have to make sure when the pilot moves or talks, the mask doesn’t hit the visor. If it’s too close, it will bend the visor and distort the display image.”

Reservists in the AFE shop are an integral part of helmet fitting process and maintenance intervals. They verify it remains as precise as possible to guarantee the safety of the 27 pilots in the 419th FW. The work is involved and in-depth, but essential to providing a seamless interaction between the helmets’ advanced capabilities and the exacting skills of the pilot wearing it.
column9: 美国犹他州
column10: F-35飞行员头盔配件的内部观察
column11: 犹他州希尔空军基地――419作战支援中队的预备役人员在确保419战斗机联队飞行员的安全方面发挥着至关重要的作用，419战斗机联队是美国空军预备役部队中唯一具有战斗能力的F-35部队。“我们负责维护和修理飞行员装备，以确保一切都处于正常的工作状态，”419 OSS机组飞行设备预备役中士AJ Arteaga说。“这也包括他们的头盔。”每一个头盔都是在一个fit设施的为期两天的过程中为飞行员定制的。在开始装配头盔时，飞行员要对头部进行测量和扫描，以确保完美贴合。一旦装配完成，飞行员需要使用瞳孔计校准光学元件，瞳孔计测量瞳孔中心两毫米范围内瞳孔之间的距离，以便飞行员在头盔显示器上看到单个图像。在显示器上，飞行员只需移动头部，就可以查看关键任务信息并增强战场态势感知。该头盔让飞行员可以360度地看到F-35的外部环境，而无需倾斜喷气机。“飞行员可以通过机翼的一部分向下看，看到下面是什么，”第419 OSS技术中士威廉・瓦斯（William Vass）说。“当他们看着嵌入F-35的摄像头时，图像会投射到头盔显示器上。”头盔的创新技术和精确配合需要日常维护，以便飞行员能够完成任务。除了飞行前和飞行后的装备外，头盔每105天检查一次，并进行120天的安装检查，以确保其功能和安全。“飞行员进来并穿上他们所有的装备，以便我们可以再次检查，以确保所有装备都正确无误地安装，”Arteaga说。“小事情，如新发型或体重增加几磅，可能会导致头盔无法正确安装。”头盔安装中还包括面罩调整。飞行员被送往氧气测试仪，在那里，机组飞行设备技术人员可以识别面罩周围可能阻止氧气充分流动的任何泄漏。“下一步是确保面罩和面罩之间有适当的距离，”阿尔泰加说。“我们必须确保当飞行员移动或说话时，面罩不会碰到面罩。如果太近，面罩会弯曲面罩并扭曲显示图像。”AFE车间的预备役人员是头盔安装过程和维护间隔的一个组成部分。他们证实它尽可能精确，以保证419 FW中27名飞行员的安全。这项工作涉及面广且深入，但对于在头盔的先进性能和佩戴头盔的飞行员的严格技能之间提供无缝交互至关重要。

column9: 美国犹他州
column10: F-35飞行员头盔配件的内部观察
column11: 犹他州希尔空军基地――419作战支援中队的预备役人员在确保419战斗机联队飞行员的安全方面发挥着至关重要的作用，419战斗机联队是美国空军预备役部队中唯一具有战斗能力的F-35部队。“我们负责维护和修理飞行员装备，以确保一切都处于正常的工作状态，”419 OSS机组飞行设备预备役中士AJ Arteaga说。“这也包括他们的头盔。”每一个头盔都是在一个fit设施的为期两天的过程中为飞行员定制的。在开始装配头盔时，飞行员要对头部进行测量和扫描，以确保完美贴合。一旦装配完成，飞行员需要使用瞳孔计校准光学元件，瞳孔计测量瞳孔中心两毫米范围内瞳孔之间的距离，以便飞行员在头盔显示器上看到单个图像。在显示器上，飞行员只需移动头部，就可以查看关键任务信息并增强战场态势感知。该头盔让飞行员可以360度地看到F-35的外部环境，而无需倾斜喷气机。“飞行员可以通过机翼的一部分向下看，看到下面是什么，”第419 OSS技术中士威廉・瓦斯（William Vass）说。“当他们看着嵌入F-35的摄像头时，图像会投射到头盔显示器上。”头盔的创新技术和精确配合需要日常维护，以便飞行员能够完成任务。除了飞行前和飞行后的装备外，头盔每105天检查一次，并进行120天的安装检查，以确保其功能和安全。“飞行员进来并穿上他们所有的装备，以便我们可以再次检查，以确保所有装备都正确无误地安装，”Arteaga说。“小事情，如新发型或体重增加几磅，可能会导致头盔无法正确安装。”头盔安装中还包括面罩调整。飞行员被送往氧气测试仪，在那里，机组飞行设备技术人员可以识别面罩周围可能阻止氧气充分流动的任何泄漏。“下一步是确保面罩和面罩之间有适当的距离，”阿尔泰加说。“我们必须确保当飞行员移动或说话时，面罩不会碰到面罩。如果太近，面罩会弯曲面罩并扭曲显示图像。”AFE车间的预备役人员是头盔安装过程和维护间隔的一个组成部分。他们证实它尽可能精确，以保证419 FW中27名飞行员的安全。这项工作涉及面广且深入，但对于在头盔的先进性能和佩戴头盔的飞行员的严格技能之间提供无缝交互至关重要。

column2: First Danish F-35s land at Luke AFB
column3:
LUKE AIR FORCE BASE, Ariz. C Royal Danish Air Force pilots delivered the first two RDAF F-35A Lightning II fighter jets to Luke Air Force Base, April 13, 2021, in preparation of pilot training.

The aircraft, assigned to the 308th Fighter Squadron will eventually be joined by five other Danish F-35s for use in the F-35 training program. According to the U.S. State Department, as stalwart NATO allies, the United States and Denmark cooperate extensively to promote peace and stability internationally.

“Today is a historical day for the partnership of the U.S. and Denmark,” said U.S. Air Force Lt. Col. Matt “HAIL” Cisar, 308th FS commander. “We’ve been preparing for the first Danish jets for years. Now that they’re here, we’re excited to train our first Danish fighter pilots.”

Pilots from all around the world participate in the F-35 training program. Royal Danish Air Force Lt. Col. Nick “KIN” Hansen, 308th FS senior national representative, mentions the importance of building relationships between allied countries.

“We have to be able to operate together with different nations in the fifth generation Air Force,” said KIN. “When we have to go in to fight war together, we find comfort knowing we’ve gone through training from the same place.”

Luke is currently training fighter pilots from many countries such as Italy, Netherlands, Norway, and Singapore. 

“It's truly remarkable to come into a fighter squadron in which a U.S. pilot might fly a Danish jet alongside a Dutch pilot flying a U.S. jet,” said Cisar. “It shows all the work that's gone into the F-35 program, the partnerships and how much we rely on each other to get the mission done.”

The F-35 training program is designed to integrate pilots, foreign and domestic, into a common set of tactics and advanced technologies enabling them to execute the mission as one unit.
column9: 美国亚利桑那州卢克空军基地
column10: 第一架丹麦F-35在卢克空军基地着陆
column11: 亚利桑那州卢克空军基地――2021年4月13日，丹麦皇家空军飞行员向卢克空军基地交付了首批两架RDAF F-35A Lightning II战斗机，为飞行员培训做准备。分配给308战斗机中队的这架飞机最终将与另外五架丹麦F-35战斗机一起用于F-35培训计划。据美国国务院称，作为北约的坚定盟友，美国和丹麦在促进国际和平与稳定方面进行了广泛合作。第308空军司令、美国空军中校马特・西萨尔（Matt“HAIL”Cisar）说：“今天是美国和丹麦结成伙伴关系的历史性日子。”。“我们多年来一直在为第一架丹麦战斗机做准备。现在他们来到这里，我们很高兴能训练我们的第一架丹麦战斗机飞行员。”来自世界各地的飞行员参加了F-35训练计划。第308届FS高级国家代表、丹麦皇家空军中校Nick“KIN”Hansen提到了在盟国之间建立关系的重要性。“我们必须能够在第五代空军中与不同国家一起作战，”KIN说。卢克目前正在训练来自意大利、荷兰、挪威和新加坡等许多国家的战斗机飞行员。西萨尔说：“进入一个战斗机中队，一名美国飞行员可能驾驶一架丹麦飞机，而另一名荷兰飞行员则驾驶一架美国飞机，这真是了不起。”。“它展示了F-35计划中的所有工作、合作伙伴关系以及我们在完成任务方面相互依赖的程度。”F-35训练计划旨在将国内外飞行员整合到一套通用战术和先进技术中，使他们能够作为一个整体执行任务。

column2: Upcoming April F-35 Night Flying Operations
column3:
SOUTH BURLINGTON, Vt. C The Vermont Air National Guard will begin three weeks of night flying operations starting Tuesday, April 6. Takeoffs are scheduled between 4:00 and 8:00 p.m. with landings between 9:00 and 10:00 p.m. on the following dates:

Tuesday, April 6 through Saturday, April 10
Tuesday, April 13 through Friday, April 16
Tuesday, April 20 through Thursday, April 22

The 158th Fighter Wing will not conduct morning or early afternoon F-35 training missions during this time except on Sunday, April 11, and Friday, April 23, takeoffs are scheduled between 12:00 p.m. and 1:30 p.m.

“The 158th Fighter Wing must be prepared to execute our federal mission at night in any weather condition,” said Lt. Col. Trevor Callens, the 134th Fighter Squadron director of operations. “Night flying proficiency is a crucial component of our training, especially as we prepare for an out-of-state night exercise in July.”

Airmen of the 158th Fighter Wing are required to conduct night operations to meet U.S. Air Force and Major Command requirements and proficiencies.

For more information contact Joint Force Headquarters; Maj. Scott Detweiler, (802) 338-3434, john.s.detweiler.mil@mail.mil.
###
column9: 美国佛蒙特州南伯灵顿
column10: 即将到来的4月F-35夜间飞行行动
column11: 佛蒙特州南伯灵顿――佛蒙特州空军国民警卫队将于4月6日星期二开始为期三周的夜间飞行行动。起飞时间为下午4:00至8:00，降落时间为9:00至10:00，具体日期如下：周二，4月6日至周六，4月10日周二，4月13日至周五，4月16日周二，4月20日至周四，4月22日第158战斗机联队在此期间不执行上午或下午早些时候的F-35训练任务，4月11日星期日和4月23日星期五除外，起飞时间安排在下午12:00至1:30之间。“第158战斗机联队必须做好准备，在任何天气条件下，在夜间执行我们的联邦任务。”第134战斗机中队作战指挥特雷弗・卡伦斯中校说。“夜间飞行熟练程度是我们训练的一个重要组成部分，尤其是在我们准备7月的州外夜间演习时。”158战斗机联队的飞行员需要进行夜间作战，以满足美国空军和主要指挥要求和熟练程度。有关更多信息，请联系联合部队总部；斯科特・德特维勒少校，（802）338-3434，约翰・s・德特维勒。mil@mail.mil.###

column2: F-35 Demo Team meets F135 Engine Team
column3:
Members of the F-35A Lightning II Demonstration Team visited Tinker Air Force Base to meet and thank the men and women of the Oklahoma City Air Logistics Complex Heavy Maintenance Center for their work on the F135 engine that powers their aircraft.

The May 25, 2021, visit featured an F-35 aerial demonstration and static display, allowing the maintainers to personally see the aircraft up close and their engine in action; a first for many HMC employees.

“The commander of Air Combat Command [Gen. Mark Kelly] said he wanted to do something to motivate the forces that are powering the F-35,” said Brig. Gen. Jeff King, Oklahoma City Air Logistics Complex commander. “This demonstration was all about them and the work they do for the United States and our warfighters.”

ACC directed the demo team visit to Tinker AFB as a show of appreciation for the men and women who perform depot-level maintenance on the F-35’s engine (the Pratt & Whitney F135) and related components.

The visit began with a familiarization briefing and a tour of the engine production line. The demo team ground crew was excited to meet the depot maintainers, and used the opportunity to discuss maintenance techniques. News that new, more advanced, borescopes, a flexible camera used to inspect internal engine components, would soon be headed to the field was well received.

Approximately 300 people gathered outside Bldg. 3001 in the afternoon to watch the Hill AFB, Utah-based F-35 perform aerobatic maneuvers that demonstrated its abilities as a 5th-generation fighter. Prior to the demonstration, maintainers and enterprise partners were able to get up close and explore a static display aircraft.

“This is exciting, this was the first time I’ve seen an F-35 up close,” said Troy Petty, a 544th Propulsion Maintenance Squadron senior inspector, who earlier in the day demonstrated the new borescope technology.

Petty also spoke about the importance of the demo for his team, noting that some of the members of his shop have never been close to an F-35.

The demonstration flight was initially delayed by weather but conditions allowed for a lower altitude, faster demonstration. This gave viewers on the ground better views of the jet, accentuated by vapor cones, visible clouds of condensed water created by aircraft flying through moist air at high speeds.

The F-35 completed high speed passes and tight turns, wowing the crowd. The slow speed pass, completed at 100 knots or 115 mph, demonstrated how slowly the F-35 can maintain level flight at a high angle of attack without stalling, due in large part to the powerful F135 engine.

After the demonstration, F-35 Demo pilot Maj. Kristin “Beo” Wolfe and the rest of the demo team met with the maintainers, thanking them for their work sustaining the engines that keep their aircraft flying.

“I just want to say thank you from all of us in the F-35 community,” Wolfe said. “We would not be combat ready without all the hard work of the F135 engine team.”

The OC-ALC HMC is the primary repair depot for the F135 engine, performing all aspects of engine maintenance. It supports all F-35 engine variants, including models operated by Navy and Marine Corps units, as well as those of partner nations.
column9: 美国
column10: F-35演示团队与F135发动机团队会面
column11: F-35A Lightning II演示团队的成员参观了Tinker空军基地，会见并感谢俄克拉荷马市航空物流综合体重型维修中心的男男女女，感谢他们在为飞机提供动力的F135发动机方面所做的工作。2021年5月25日的参观包括F-35空中演示和静态展示，允许维修人员亲自近距离观察飞机及其发动机的运行情况；这是许多HMC员工的第一次。布里格说：“空战司令部司令（马克・凯利将军）说，他想做些什么来激励为F-35提供动力的部队。”。杰夫・金将军，俄克拉荷马州城市航空物流中心指挥官。“这次演示是关于他们以及他们为美国和我们的作战人员所做的工作。”ACC指导演示团队访问Tinker空军基地，以表示对在F-35发动机（普惠F135）上执行基地级维修的男男女女的感谢参观开始于熟悉情况介绍和参观发动机生产线。演示团队地勤人员很高兴见到基地级维修人员，并借此机会讨论维修技术。新的、更先进的内窥镜，一种用于检查发动机内部部件的柔性摄像机，很快将被派往现场，这一消息广受欢迎。大约300人下午聚集在3001号大楼外观看希尔空军基地，总部位于犹他州的F-35进行特技飞行，展示了其作为第五代战斗机的能力。在演示之前，维修人员和企业合作伙伴能够近距离探索静态显示飞机。“这很令人兴奋，这是我第一次近距离看到F-35，”第544推进维修中队高级检查员特洛伊・佩蒂说，佩蒂在当天早些时候演示了新的内视镜技术。佩蒂还谈到了演示对他的团队的重要性，他指出，他的车间的一些成员从未接近过F-35。演示飞行最初因天气原因推迟，但条件允许进行低空、快速的演示。这让地面观众更好地看到了喷气式飞机，尤其是蒸汽锥，飞机在潮湿空气中高速飞行时产生的可见凝结水云。F-35完成了高速飞行和急转弯，让观众大吃一惊。低速飞行以100节或115英里/小时的速度完成，演示了F-35在大迎角下保持水平飞行而不失速的速度，这在很大程度上归功于强大的F135发动机。演示结束后，F-35演示飞行员克里斯汀・沃尔夫少校和演示团队的其他成员会见了维修人员，感谢他们为维持飞机飞行所做的工作。“我只想对F-35社区的所有人说声谢谢，”沃尔夫说。“如果没有F135发动机团队的辛勤工作，我们将无法做好战斗准备。”OC-ALC HMC是F135发动机的主要维修基地，负责发动机的各个方面维护。它支持所有F-35发动机型号，包括由海军和海军陆战队部队以及伙伴国家操作的型号。

column2: F-35 RRT meets maintenance needs in dual deployments
column3:
MARINE CORPS AIR STATION CHERRY POINT, N.C. C Aircraft maintenance professionals with Fleet Readiness Center East’s F-35 Rapid Response Team play a critical role in keeping the Marine Corps’ F-35B Lightning II fleet healthy.  

In support of this goal, FRCE’s F-35 Rapid Response Team (RRT) recently conducted simultaneous deployments to Marine Corps Air Station Yuma, Arizona, and aboard the USS Makin Island, underway in the Arabian Sea. RRT maintainers inspected and repaired 12 F-35B aircraft, all in under 40 days C including travel, precautionary restriction of movement and workdays. 

“The F-35 Rapid Response Team is a strategic asset within our Navy-Marine Corps team, and I couldn’t be more proud of the drive and dedication these individuals display with every mission,” said FRCE Commanding Officer Capt. Mark E. Nieto. “They’re ready to pack up and ship out to anywhere in the world at a moment’s notice and, when they arrive, they get to work and stay on task until the job is done. The RRT plays a vital role in aviation readiness, and you won’t find a finer crew of maintainers anywhere in the armed forces.”

The RRT consists of expert artisans cross-trained in multiple maintenance trades to ensure efficiency and flexibility. Having team members with multiple skill sets allows for a flexible configuration, which means the team can pick and choose which artisans to deploy to a mission based on what the technical requirements will be. 

The RRT arrives on-site with skill sets and tools that aren’t normally required for repairs at the squadron level or on a ship, said Maj. Randy Brazile, F-35B Detachment maintenance officer for Marine Medium Tiltrotor Squadron 164 (Reinforced), 15th Marine Expeditionary Unit, aboard the Makin Island. 

“The FRCE RRT was called to the USS Makin Island to execute repairs to the 15th MEU’s F-35s, with specialized tools that are not resident in a fleet F-35 squadron,” Brazile said. “They are very experienced artisans and possess qualifications that are not frequently required by operational squadrons. This combination of qualifications, tooling, and the ability to rapidly deploy worldwide provides a valuable resource to the fleet forces when specialized repairs are required.”

The team arrived quickly and showed up ready to perform and share their knowledge with the Marines aboard the Makin Island, Brazile added. 

“The RRT deployed in under 48 hours and arrived on ship eager to work,” he said. “The team worked very closely with the Marines of VMM-164 (Rein.) and RRT took every opportunity to teach and instruct the younger Marines.”

Having these repairs conducted on site, rather than having to send the aircraft to intermediate- or depot-level facilities for modifications helps reduce downtime for the aircraft, and get them back in the air as quickly as possible. 

“The ability of the RRT to execute repairs on ship allowed the 15th MEU and Makin Island Amphibious Ready Group to continue operations while the aircraft repairs were ongoing,” Brazile explained. “The 15th MEU F-35s continued flying combat sorties in support of the U.S. Central Command Area of Responsibility simultaneously to the RRT repairs. Overall, this was an excellent demonstration of the Naval Aviation Enterprise reacting to unexpected maintenance requirements while maintaining operational capability for the combatant commander.”

Reducing aircraft-on-ground time is especially important for forward-deployed units like VMM-164 (Rein.) and units scheduled for deployment, including Marine Fighter Attack Squadron 211 at MCAS Yuma.

Ike Rettenmair, F-35 branch head at FRCE, said the RRT provides a strategic capability in supporting F-35B readiness throughout the Marine Corps; however, the team doesn’t work alone. The F-35 Fleet Support Team provides critical support to the RRT. This team includes engineering, logistics and program management across both government and contractor agencies and is a key player in the success of the deployments. While much of the support team’s work is done in the background, these elements coordinated seamlessly with the RRT to ensure delivery of technical instructions, tooling and consumable supplies were staged and ready for use once the team arrived on site. 

“While the team was deployed, many government and contractor support groups were constantly working behind the scenes to be certain the forward-deployed teams were successful,” Rettenmair said. “The FST led daily phone conferences were held to keep all parties up to speed and informed of the needs of the team. From the moment we got the notice of need, it was all hands on deck for our F-35 modification team, the F-35 FST, the F-35 Joint Program Office, FRCE support equipment engineering and logistics, logistics management and Naval Aviation Logistics Command. 

“We deployed to two separate locations within 10 days of each other,” he continued. “Once we received notice of the need, the support team had less than 48 hours to work through the logistics of getting our artisans and the tooling to the USS Makin Island, including everything from COVID testing and orders to securing a military flight and gathering tools and consumables. It was truly a team effort.”

The RRT maintainers’ skill and passion for service, supported by the FST’s logistics and engineering capabilities, set the team apart in terms of what they can accomplish in challenging environments, Rettenmair said. 

“I had full confidence in what these artisans could do when given the opportunity to show not only the warfighter in need, but also the world what makes FRCE unique,” he said. “They performed very well under sometimes-less-than-ideal conditions, and proved again what a critical capability the RRT provides. 

“While most of the team was comprised of regular RRT-designated members, there were a few on each team who don’t normally work RRT missions but are trained and seasoned professionals, and were willing to volunteer in support of our warfighters,” Rettenmair added. “The majority of these artisan are military veterans, which gives them even more pride in what they do C they have been on the other side, and understand the need for support firsthand. And while the deployments were a team effort, these artisans deserve most of the credit for the events’ success.”

Matthew Crisp, F-35 Joint Program Office site lead at FRCE, said experience from previous missions has given the RRT a firm foundation to build upon, and that know-how paid dividends with these deployments.  

“This isn’t the first time the RRT has been deployed for unscheduled F-35 repairs and it most certainly will not be the last,” he explained. “We are fortunate to have had opportunities in the past for the RRT to come to the support of the fleet on less time sensitive and critical repairs which were good to ‘sharpen our pencils’ before this event. 

“This evolution certainly flexed the RRT and Fleet Support Team’s speed and agility to a new level and clearly showed the value that the team has,” Crisp continued. “This success has set the bar higher than ever for the RRT and support team and the collective team will continue to fill this much needed role across the F-35 program for years.”

Every event provides a learning opportunity, Rettenmair noted, that will help improve the team’s performance in the future.

“There are lessons learned and we will gather notes, brainstorm and make the next effort even better for all parties involved,” he said. “It all leads to FRCE and the RRT being better able, and always willing, to support the U.S. warfighter at any time, anywhere in the world.”

FRCE is North Carolina's largest maintenance, repair, overhaul and technical services provider, with more than 4,000 civilian, military and contract workers. Its annual revenue exceeds $1 billion. The facility is the lead site for depot-level maintenance on the F-35B (short takeoff-vertical landing) and F-35C (carrier) variants and generates combat air power for America’s Marines and naval forces while serving as an integral part of the greater U.S. Navy; Naval Air Systems Command; and Commander, Fleet Readiness Centers.
column9: CHERRY POINT，北卡罗来纳州，美国
column10: F-35 RRT满足双重部署的维修需求
column11: 海军陆战队CHERRY POINT航空站，N.C.C机队准备中心东部的F-35快速反应团队的飞机维修专业人员在保持海军陆战队F-35B Lightning II机队健康方面发挥着关键作用。为了支持这一目标，FRCE的F-35快速反应小组（RRT）最近同时部署到美国海军陆战队亚利桑那州尤马空军基地和正在阿拉伯海航行的美国海军陆战队马金岛上。RRT维修人员在40天内检查和维修了12架F-35B飞机，包括旅行、预防性行动限制和工作日。FRCE指挥官马克・涅托上尉说：“F-35快速反应小组是我们海军陆战队团队的一项战略资产，我对这些人在每次任务中表现出的干劲和献身精神感到无比自豪。”。“他们随时准备打包并运送到世界上任何地方，当他们到达时，他们开始工作并继续执行任务，直到工作完成。RRT在航空准备方面起着至关重要的作用，在武装部队的任何地方都找不到更优秀的维修人员。”RRT由在多个维修行业接受交叉培训的专业工匠组成，以确保效率和灵活性。拥有具有多种技能的团队成员可以实现灵活的配置，这意味着团队可以根据技术要求选择部署到任务中的工匠。海军陆战队第15远征分队海军中型倾转旋翼机中队164（加强型）F-35B分队维修官兰迪・布拉齐尔少校（Randy Brazile）在马金岛上说，RRT抵达现场时携带的技能和工具通常不需要在中队或船上进行维修。Brazile说：“FRCE RRT被召集到美国海军马金岛号航空母舰，用不在舰队F-35中队的专用工具对第15 MEU的F-35进行维修。”。“他们是经验丰富的工匠，拥有作战中队不经常需要的资格。这种资格、工具和在全球快速部署的能力的结合，在需要专门维修时为舰队部队提供了宝贵的资源。”Brazile补充说，该团队很快到达，并准备在Makin岛上表演，并与海军陆战队分享他们的知识。他说：“RRT在48小时内部署完毕，并迫不及待地登上了这艘船。”。“该团队与VMM-164（Rein.）的海军陆战队密切合作，RRT利用一切机会教授和指导年轻的海军陆战队。”在现场进行这些维修，而不是将飞机送到中级或基地级设施进行改装，有助于减少飞机的停机时间，尽快让它们飞回空中。Brazile解释说：“RRT能够对船舶进行维修，这使得第15 MEU和Makin岛两栖准备小组能够在飞机维修进行中继续作战。”。“第15架MEU F-35继续飞行战斗架次，以支持美国中央指挥部责任区，同时进行RRT维修。总的来说，这是海军航空企业对意外维修需求作出反应，同时保持战斗指挥官作战能力的一个极好证明。”减少飞机在地面的时间对于VMM-164（Rein.）等前沿部署部队和计划部署的部队尤其重要，包括MCAS Yuma的海军陆战队战斗机攻击中队211。FRCE F-35分队负责人艾克・雷滕梅尔（Ike Rettenmair）表示，RRT提供了支持整个海军陆战队F-35B战备状态的战略能力；然而，团队并不是单独工作的。F-35机队支持团队为RRT提供关键支持。该团队包括政府和承包商机构的工程、后勤和项目管理，是部署成功的关键参与者。虽然支持团队的大部分工作都是在后台完成的，但这些要素与RRT无缝协调，以确保技术说明、工具和耗材的交付在团队到达现场后准备就绪并可供使用。“在团队部署期间，许多政府和承包商支持小组一直在幕后工作，以确保前方部署的团队取得成功，”Rettenmair说。“FST领导的每日电话会议是为了让各方及时了解团队的需求。从我们收到需求通知的那一刻起，我们的F-35改装团队、F-35 FST、F-35联合项目办公室、FRCE支持设备工程和后勤、后勤管理和海军航空兵都已准备就绪他继续说：“我们在10天内分别部署到两个不同的地点。”。“一旦我们收到需要的通知，支持团队就只有不到48小时的时间来完成将我们的工匠和工具运送到美国军舰马金岛的后勤工作，包括从新冠病毒测试和订单到确保军事飞行以及收集工具和消耗品的所有工作。这确实是团队的努力。”Rettenmair说，RRT维修人员的技能和对服务的热情，加上FST的后勤和工程能力，使团队在具有挑战性的环境中取得了卓越的成就。他说：“我完全相信，当这些工匠有机会不仅向需要帮助的战士，而且向全世界展示FRCE的独特之处时，他们能做些什么。他们在有时不太理想的条件下表现得非常出色，再次证明了RRT提供的关键能力。雷滕梅尔补充说：“虽然团队的大多数成员都是由常规RRT指定的成员组成，但每个团队中都有一些人通常不从事RRT任务，但他们是经过培训和经验丰富的专业人员，愿意自愿为我们的作战人员提供支持。”。“这些工匠中的大多数都是退伍军人，这让他们对自己的工作更为自豪――他们一直站在另一边，并且理解对第一手支持的需要。虽然部署是团队的努力，但这些工匠应该为活动的成功赢得大部分荣誉。”F35的F-35联合项目办公室领导Matthew Crisp说，以前的任务经验使RRT成为一个坚实的基础，这些诀窍在这些部署中得到了回报。“这不是RRT首次部署在非计划的F-35修理中，而且肯定不会是最后一次。”他解释道：“我们很幸运，在过去，RRT有机会在时间敏感度较低和关键性维修方面向车队提供支持，这有助于在此次活动之前“磨砺我们的铅笔”。“这一演变无疑将RRT和舰队支持团队的速度和敏捷性提升到了一个新的水平，并清楚地表明了团队的价值，”Crisp继续说道。“这一成功为RRT和支持团队设定了比以往更高的标准，集体团队将继续在F-35项目中扮演这一急需的角色。”Rettenmair指出，每一项活动都提供了一个学习机会，这将有助于提高团队在未来的表现。“我们从中吸取了经验教训，我们将收集笔记，集思广益，为所有相关方做出更好的下一步努力，”他说。“这一切都将使FRCE和RRT能够，并且始终愿意，在世界任何地方的任何时间支持美国作战人员。”FRCE是北卡罗来纳州最大的维护、维修、大修和技术服务提供商，拥有4000多名文职、军事和合同工。其年收入超过10亿美元。该设施是F-35B（短起飞垂直着陆）和F-35C（航母）基地级维修的主要场所作为大美国海军、海军航空系统司令部和舰队战备中心司令部的一个组成部分，为美国海军陆战队和海军部队提供变型和生成战斗空中力量。

column2: FRCE accepts barge delivery of F-35 airframe for training
column3:
MARINE CORPS AIR STATION CHERRY POINT, N.C. -- Fleet Readiness Center East recently accepted delivery of an F-35 airframe transported by barge from Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort, South Carolina, to FRCE facilities aboard MCAS Cherry Point, North Carolina.

Working together with the F-35 Joint Program Office, FRCE received approval to accept the stripped down airframe for use in maintenance training and engineering testing, which will allow for the development of improved tooling, maintenance procedures and sustainment practices.

“As a depot maintenance trainer, the airframe will allow new employees an opportunity to test their skills on the proper maintenance and repair processes used on F-35 before being required to do it on a fleet aircraft,” said Matt Crisp, FRCE site lead for the F-35 Joint Program Office. “Our sustainment engineering efforts include the ability to prototype modifications and repairs, test new and improve existing support equipment, test new processes and materials, and support other efforts to investigate opportunities for sustainment cost and maintainability improvements.” 

The relocation process began March 1, when workers at MCAS Beaufort prepped the airframe and used a crane to load it onto the barge, which took four days to reach MCAS Cherry Point via the Intracoastal Waterway. At the MCAS Cherry Point docks, transportation specialists unloaded the airframe from the barge and used a self-propelled transport dolly to transport the airframe to FRCE during the night. Officials scheduled the unusual delivery method to Cherry Point and late-night transfer to FRCE to make the lowest possible impact along the transportation route. 

“The decision to move the airframe with a barge was largely due to the expected impacts of traffic along the route from Beaufort to Cherry Point,” said Crisp. “I can tell you that it gained a lot of attention as it made its way through the Intracoastal Waterway.

“We’re excited to have this airframe available because it allows us to train our workforce and test new engineering sustainment initiatives without impacting a fleet aircraft,” said Crisp. “It will only make us better prepared to support fleet readiness.“

FRCE is North Carolina's largest maintenance, repair, overhaul and technical services provider, with more than 4,000 civilian, military and contract workers. Its annual revenue exceeds $1 billion. The depot generates combat air power for America’s Marines and naval forces while serving as an integral part of the greater U.S. Navy; Naval Air Systems Command; and Commander, Fleet Readiness Centers.
column9: CHERRY POINT，北卡罗来纳州，美国
column10: FRCE接受驳船交付F-35机身进行培训
column11: 北卡罗来纳州海军陆战队CHERRY POINT航空站――舰队准备中心东部最近接受了一架F-35机身的交付，该机身由驳船从南卡罗来纳州海军陆战队博福特航空站运至北卡罗来纳州MCAS CHERRY POINT上的FRCE设施。与F-35联合项目办公室合作，FRCE获得批准，同意将拆卸下来的机身用于维修培训和工程测试，这将允许开发改进的工具、维修程序和持续性保障实践。F-35联合项目办公室FRCE现场负责人马特・克里斯普（Matt Crisp）说：“作为基地级维修培训师，机身将使新员工有机会在被要求在机队飞机上进行维修之前，测试他们在F-35上使用的正确维修和修理流程方面的技能。”。“我们的持续性保障工程工作包括原型改装和维修、测试新的和改进现有保障设备、测试新工艺和材料，以及支持其他工作，以调查持续性保障成本和维修性改进的机会。”搬迁过程始于3月1日，当时MCAS Beaufort的工人准备好机身，并使用起重机将其装载到驳船上，驳船经过海岸内水道花了四天时间到达MCAS Cherry Point。在MCAS Cherry Point码头，运输专家从驳船上卸下机身，并使用自行式运输娃娃y计划在夜间将机身运输至FRCE。官员们计划将不寻常的交付方式运送至Cherry Point，并在深夜将飞机运送至FRCE，以尽可能降低运输路线上的影响。克里斯普说：“决定用驳船移动机身，主要是因为预计从波弗特到切里角的航线上的交通会产生影响。我可以告诉你，它在通过内陆水道时引起了很多注意。Crisp说：“我们很高兴有了这种机身，因为它使我们能够在不影响机队飞机的情况下培训我们的员工和测试新的工程维持计划。这只会使我们更好地准备支持机队准备就绪。“FRCE是北卡罗来纳州最大的维护、维修、大修和技术服务提供商，拥有4000多名文职、军事和合同工。其年收入超过10亿美元。该基地为美国海军陆战队和海军部队提供战斗空军，同时作为大美海军的一个组成部分；海军航空兵系统司令部；以及舰队准备中心指挥官。

column2: F-35, Cavour sea trials also test logistics
column3:
NORFOLK NAVAL STATION, Va.― A container marked “PAX Flight Deck Gear CAVOUR DET 2021,” tri-wall boxes for the work centers, shipping containers with massive aircraft air & power units, engine trailers, and other aircraft support equipment (SE) were craned aboard, forklifted through the hangar, and positioned aboard Italian aircraft carrier ITS Cavour moored here over the last week of February.

The Italian navy flagship arrived here Feb. 13, 2021 as part of the Italian navy’s Ready for Operations (RFO) campaign to certify the recently upgraded ship’s compatibility with F-35 Lighting II aircraft and prepare to operate the 5th generation fighter as its key weapons system.

Before the arrival of the specially instrumented U.S. test jets that will be used to develop and expand a flight envelope, the special tools, parts (those required plus those possibly needed), and support equipment must be aboard and in its place. This undertaking is all in a (couple of) days’ work for F-35 Patuxent River Integrated Test Force (PAX ITF) logistics lead and his team, as well as the many who support the mission.

That effort comprises ensuring that “part of PAX” gets aboard the ship before two F-35B short takeoff and vertical landing (STOVL) test jets ferry from the southern Maryland naval air station to the aircraft carrier after it sets sail, said the PAX ITF logistics team supervisor.

“I love the challenge,” said F-35 PAX ITF logistics supervisor Pat DeLeon, in between a worker asking how to get a pair of leather gloves and another querying where to find the wire cutters. A day earlier he was driving a forklift on the flight deck, and tomorrow, … well, he’ll be wherever he’s needed.

For the moment, in the relative quiet before “Lightning II strikes,” there is a hum of languages, foreign and familiar, in the hangar. A look around makes it clear this is a coalition mission: “For Entry Contact … ”  and “NO SMOKING” on containers and boxes are backdropped by the ship’s “In Caso Di Necessita’” and In Questo Locale Vietato Fumare signage. This is a partnership, one Pat says has gone well so far.

“(The Cavour ship’s company) have been bending over backwards to help,” DeLeon says. “They’ve been great,” about some adjustments to the load plan, he said. Flexibility is a necessary characteristic of the relationship, he added, because there will be changes until the ship sets sail.

“’When we work together, it’s going to get better,’” DeLeon said his counterpart told him. “If we keep them happy, we’re happy.”

Mission achieved: The Cavour “hangar boss” is well pleased.

“At first glance, seeing so many people and so much material to get on this ship seemed an arduous and complex undertaking,” said Italian Navy Master Chief Petty Officer Silvio Cusano. “As the days went by and everyone collaborated, what seemed extremely complicated has materialized into an organizational success that made everyone aware of being able to overcome the most difficult obstacles.

“We are looking to the final goal with more confidence.”

It takes a team
DeLeon, a seasoned logistics supervisor who has detached to two U.S. ships, twice to the United Kingdom’s HMS Queen Elizabeth, and numerous land-based sites, praised his team of four currently embarked, which includes a night-shift supervisor and three material handlers, as well as the many organizations and teams behind what’s happening in the berthed ship.

“Without my team at PAX, none of this happens,” DeLeon said. “There’s no way I can do this by myself.” He said he coordinates with a lot of people to get this done: the PAX team, Lockheed Martin’s Fort Worth transportation, Norfolk Naval Station’s crane operators, and [ALGS] for aircraft parts.

The logistics team is part of a more robust embarked PAX ITF flight test team of almost 200 people. They will conduct sea trials for up to four weeks to collect data that will ultimately lead to the certification for Cavour’s company to safely conduct carrier operations with Italy’s own F-35Bs.
column9: 美国
column10: F-35，卡沃试航也测试后勤
column11: 弗吉尼亚州诺福克海军基地――一个标有“PAX Flight Deck CAVOUR DET 2021”的集装箱、用于工作中心的三面墙箱子、装有大型飞机空气和动力装置、发动机拖车和其他飞机支持设备（SE）的运输集装箱被吊上飞机，并通过机库叉起，意大利海军旗舰于2021年2月13日抵达这里，作为意大利海军准备作战（RFO）的一部分旨在证明最近升级的战舰与F-35 Lighting II飞机的兼容性，并准备将第五代战斗机作为其关键武器系统使用。在用于开发和扩展飞行包线的专用仪器化美国测试飞机抵达之前，专用工具、部件（需要的加上可能需要的）和支持设备必须在船上并就位。这项任务是F-35帕塔克森特河综合试验部队（PAX ITF）后勤领导和他的团队以及支持任务的许多人在几天内完成的。这项工作包括确保“PAX的一部分”“在两架F-35B短距起飞和垂直着陆（STOVL）测试喷气机从马里兰南部海军航空站飞到航空母舰开航后，在它上船之前，”PAX ITF后勤团队主管说，“我喜欢这个挑战，”F-35 PAX ITF后勤主管Pat DeLeon说，一名工人询问如何获得一副皮手套，另一名工人询问在哪里可以找到钢丝钳。一天前，他在飞行甲板上驾驶叉车，明天，……好吧，他将在需要的任何地方。目前，在相对安静的前一天“闪电II来袭”，机库里充斥着外国和熟悉的语言。环顾四周，可以清楚地看出这是一项联合任务：“为了进入接触……”和“禁止吸烟”在集装箱和箱子上被船上的“在Caso Di Essentiala”返回在Questo地区，Vietato Fumare标牌。帕特说，这是一种合作关系，到目前为止进展顺利。”（Cavour船的公司）一直在竭尽全力提供帮助，”德隆说。“他们很好，”关于装载计划的一些调整，他说。灵活性是这种关系的一个必要特征，他补充说，因为在船启航之前会有变化。“当我们合作时，情况会变得更好，”德隆说，他的同事告诉他。“如果我们让他们高兴，我们就高兴。”任务完成：卡沃尔“机库老板”非常高兴。“乍一看，看到这么多人和这么多材料登上这艘船似乎是一项艰巨而复杂的任务，”意大利海军少校首席中士西尔维奥・库萨诺说。“随着日子一天天过去，每个人都在合作，看似极其复杂的事情已经变成了组织上的成功，让每个人都意识到能够克服最困难的障碍。”我们满怀信心地期待着最终的目标一名经验丰富的后勤主管teamDeLeon曾派遣两艘美国军舰，两次前往英国皇家海军伊丽莎白女王号和多个陆上基地，他赞扬了目前由四名成员组成的团队，其中包括一名夜班主管和三名物料搬运员，以及支持这一计划的许多组织和团队发生在停泊的船上。“没有我的团队在帕克斯，这一切都不会发生，”德隆说。“我不可能一个人做这件事。”他说，他与很多人协调完成这件事：帕克斯团队、洛克希德・马丁公司的沃斯堡运输公司、诺福克海军站的起重机操作员和[ALGS]对于飞机部件。后勤团队是一个由近200人组成的更强大的PAX-ITF登船飞行试验团队的一部分。他们将进行长达四周的海上试验，以收集数据，最终获得Cavour公司使用意大利自己的F-35B安全进行航母操作的认证。

column2: F-35 simulator building unveiled during Winter Fury
column3:
MARINE CORPS AIR STATION MIRAMAR, Calif. C (January 25, 2021) 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing (MAW) dedicates its inaugural F-35 simulator building aboard Marine Corps Air Station Miramar January 21, 2021. This marks the next step in streamlining the training process of the fifth-generation joint strike fighter, which has been recognized as one of the most advanced aircraft in military history.

In addition to providing a much more efficient means of producing highly trained pilots to operate the fifth-generation stealth fighter, this simulator will allow 3rd MAW aviators to train, rehearse, and refine their integrated abilities alongside the Navy and other Marine Corps allies operating across the globe.

“This building coming together will train pilots to bring violence to the people that desperately need it,” said Maj. Gen. Christopher Mahoney, 3rd MAW Commanding General. “That’s what this represents, another step that forces our competitors and adversaries, whether they’re Chinese or anybody else, to think twice.”

Flight simulators are an essential tool and an integral part of Marine aviation training that allow 3rd MAW squadrons to hone critical skills in simulated environments that refine their ability to conduct operations with a variety of aviation platforms in multiple environments from a centralized location.

“Distributed mission training will have the ability to integrate with other Navy and Marine Corps assets that are off site,” said Jennifer Moore, Training and Operations Manager for Lockheed Martin. “So we’ve got the F-35 simulators here on site that we’re going to be able to link with air wing operations that Navy counterparts that they’re going to be flying with in combat, as well as integrates other Marine Corps units as well, and able to have everybody join on the same simulated environment. The Air Force has their own distributed mission training network and the next step would be to get connected and let all the services play in the same domain.”

“The building is a manifested result of the teamwork and dedication of Marines that everyone talks about,” said Mahoney. “To the team here that allows us to take another step against our adversaries, my hat’s off to you.”

3rd MAW continues to “Fix, Fly and Fight” as the Marine Corps’ largest aircraft wing, and remains combat-ready, deployable on short notice, and lethal when called into action.



For questions regarding this release, please contact the 3rd MAW Communication Strategy and Operations Office at 3rdmawmedia@usmc.mil.
-USMC-
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州米拉玛
column10: F-35模拟机大楼在冬季暴怒中揭幕
