column11: 加利福尼亚州米拉玛海军陆战队航空站（2021年1月25日）第三海军陆战队飞机联队（MAW）于2021年1月21日在米拉玛海军陆战队航空站上建造了首个F-35模拟器。这标志着被公认为军事史上最先进飞机之一的第五代联合攻击战斗机在简化训练过程方面迈出了下一步。除了提供一种更有效的手段，生产训练有素的飞行员来操作第五代隐形战斗机之外，该模拟器将允许第三代MAW飞行员与海军和其他海军陆战队盟军一起训练、排练和完善他们的综合能力。克里斯托弗・马奥尼少将说：“这座大楼将共同训练飞行员，为迫切需要它的人带来暴力。”，三军总司令。“这就是它所代表的，这是迫使我们的竞争对手和对手，无论他们是中国人还是其他任何人，三思而后行的又一步。”飞行模拟器是海上航空训练的一个重要工具和组成部分，使第三MAW中队能够在模拟环境中磨练关键技能，从而提高其在多个环境中从集中位置使用各种航空平台进行作战的能力。洛克希德・马丁公司的培训和运营经理詹妮弗・摩尔（Jennifer Moore）说：“分布式任务培训将能够与其他海军和海军陆战队非现场资产进行集成。”。“因此，我们在现场安装了F-35模拟器，我们将能够与海军同行在战斗中飞行的空中联队作战联系起来，并将其他海军陆战队部队整合在一起，使每个人都能加入到相同的模拟环境中。空军有自己的分布式系统任务训练网络和下一步将是建立联系，让所有服务在同一领域发挥作用。“这座建筑体现了每个人都在谈论的海军陆战队的团队合作和奉献精神，”马奥尼说。“对于让我们能够在对抗对手的过程中迈出新的一步的团队，我向你们致敬。”3rd MAW继续“修复、飞行和战斗”作为海军陆战队最大的飞机联队，保持战斗准备状态，可在短时间内部署，并在行动中致命。有关此次发布的问题，请联系第三MAW通信战略和运营办公室3rdmawmedia@usmc.mil.-美国海军陆战队-

column2: Armament shop maintains F-35 weapons system equipment
column3:
Luke Air Force Base, Ariz. C Airmen from the 56th Equipment Maintenance Squadron F-35A Lightning II armament shop are building a capability the Air Force may benchmark to store and maintain alternate mission equipment for the F-35’s weapons system.

While the Air Force has 17 F-35 units, only two have a similar capability, and the 56th EMS is establishing procedures for future F-35A units to employ.

The 56th Maintenance Group established the AME shop in May 2019 and, in addition to inspecting and ordering supplies including F-35 adapters, pylons and launchers. 

Alternate mission equipment is “basically, any equipment that’s needed to either launch a missile or drop a munition, or anything that deals with the gun system has to come through us,” said Staff Sgt. Peter Christopher, 56th EMS F-35 AME supervisor. “And there's quite a bit among each of the four F-35 squadrons. There are hundreds and hundreds of pieces of equipment.”

Before the Luke’s F-35 AME shop was established, F-35 aircraft maintenance personnel stored weapons equipment in hangars, warehouses and designated AME rooms. While maintenance Airmen stored the equipment in accordance with technical orders and instructions, a centralized storage facility to easily access the equipment was not available, said Christopher.

“Now there's a central point where somebody inspects and takes care of the equipment,” said Christopher.

After receiving and cataloging F-35 weapons parts, the 56th Logistics Readiness Squadron delivers the inventory to the AME shop where Airmen organize the equipment and store it in crates for future use.

“It's really a nonstop game of Tetris here,” said Christopher. “It's basically about finding the space to get in all the equipment.”

Not only is the F-35 armament shop one of few in the Air Force, it is one of the few with Airmen qualified to repair the F-35 bulk loader, an ammunition loading system that loads 25mm rounds into the F-35 GAU-22 25mm cannon’s linkless ammunition handling system.

“Every base that has F-35s currently has bulk loaders because they're used as long as they're firing the gun,” said Senior Airman Janey Sawmiller, 56th EMS F-35 maintenance supervisor. “Most bases just don't have a back shop that's working on them.”

Previously, if the bulk loaders required maintenance, maintenance Airmen sent the equipment to the manufacturing warehouse for repairs. Now all the maintenance is performed in the armament shop. Sawmiller said having maintenance in-house saves the Air Force time and money.

“I like learning something new that no one has ever done before,” said Sawmiller. “I also like the hands-on maintenance aspect.”

According to Christopher, the armament shop is creating benchmark for what a standard AME squadron should look like in the Air Force. 

“In a small capacity, we’re turning into the focal point for transfers and setups of new AME squadrons on other bases,” said Christopher. “It's not official, but we've managed to get a course of action such that allows other bases to use us as an interim for getting their new squadron set up.”

Story was originally posted to the Luke AFB website on November 16, 2020, and may be found at https://www.luke.af.mil/News/Article-Display/Article/2416121/armament-shop-maintains-f-35-weapons-system-equipment/
column6: LUKE AIR FORCE BASE, AZ, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国亚利桑那州卢克空军基地
column10: 武器车间维护F-35武器系统设备
column11: 亚利桑那州卢克空军基地――第56装备维修中队F-35A Lightning II武器车间的飞行员正在建立一种能力，空军可以以此为基准来存储和维护F-35武器系统的备用任务装备。虽然空军有17架F-35部队，但只有两架具备类似能力，第56次EMS正在为未来的F-35A机组建立使用程序。第56次维修小组于2019年5月建立了AME车间，并检查和订购了包括F-35适配器、挂架和发射器在内的供应品。第56届EMS F-35 AME主管、参谋中士彼得・克里斯托弗（Peter Christopher）说，备用任务设备“基本上是，发射导弹或投掷弹药所需的任何设备，或任何与火炮系统有关的设备，都必须经过我们。”。“四个F-35中队中的每一个中队都有相当多的武器装备。有成百上千的装备。”在卢克的F-35 AME车间建立之前，F-35飞机维修人员将武器装备储存在机库、仓库和指定的AME房间中。克里斯托弗说，虽然维修飞行员按照技术指令和指示储存设备，但却没有一个可以方便地存取设备的集中储存设施。“现在有一个中心点，有人在那里检查和保管设备。”第56后勤准备中队在收到F-35武器零件并对其进行编目后，将库存交付给AME车间，在那里，飞行员将设备整理好，并将其储存在板条箱中，以备将来使用。克里斯托弗说：“这真是一场不间断的俄罗斯方块游戏。”。“这基本上是为了找到进入所有装备的空间。”F-35武器车间不仅是空军中为数不多的几家，而且是少数几家有资格维修F-35散装装载机的航空公司之一，这是一种弹药装载系统，可将25毫米弹药装载到F-35 GAU-22 25毫米加农炮的无链接弹药处理系统中。第56届EMS F-35维修主管、高级飞行员珍尼・索米勒（Janey Sawmiller）说：“目前，每个拥有F-35的基地都有散装装载机，因为只要他们开火就可以使用。大多数基地都没有专门的后勤车间。”以前，如果散装装载机需要维修，维修飞行员会把设备送到制造仓库进行维修。现在所有的维修都在军备车间进行。索米勒说，内部维修可以节省空军的时间和金钱。“我喜欢学习一些以前没有人做过的新东西。”Sawmiller说，“我也喜欢动手维修方面。”据Christopher说，武器车间正在为空军的标准AME中队创建基准。“在小容量情况下，我们将成为在其他基地转移和设置新AME中队的焦点，”Christopher说。“这不是官方消息，但我们已经设法制定了一个行动方案，允许其他基地利用我们作为建立新中队的过渡。”故事最初于2020年11月16日发布在卢克空军基地网站上，可在https://www.luke.af.mil/News/Article-Display/Article/2416121/armament-shop-maintains-f-35-weapons-system-equipment/

column2: Royal Navy Teammate Brings Valued Engineering Skills to F-35
column3:
CRYSTAL CITY, VA. (June 28, 2021) As part of the F-35 Enterprise you get to work with talented colleagues to advance the affordability, capability, and availability of the most lethal aircraft in the global fleet. Royal Navy Lt. Cdr. Stuart Greenfield, a British teammate who works for the F-35 Joint Program Office (JPO) on the F-35 Assistant Program Manager of Logistics (APML) team, was fascinated at a young age by the military, its technology, and the value of a hard-working team that serves their country.

"My dad took me to the ‘International Festival of Sea’ at the Her Majesty’s Naval Base, Portsmouth. Every few years, naval ships from all over the globe visited. We got to go on different ships from different nations. I got a flavor for how we all complete our missions differently, but the end goal is the same,” reminisced Greenfield. “I took that idea of international teamwork with me. I remember vividly going onto the flight deck on one of the U.K.'s Invincible-class aircraft carriers, seeing the Harrier, and chatting with the pilots and engineers. It was amazing to experience as a kid, and it captured my imagination and sculpted me to join the Royal Navy."

The United Kingdom has been an integral partner since the F-35 Enterprise’s earliest days, even before the choice of a final aircraft concept. "While we all have the same end goal, we have slightly different ways of achieving it due to our cultures and the different core values found in our militaries, but that is what works well for the F-35," said Greenfield, who knew he would join the Royal Navy in 2009 following his university graduation.

After various assignments, including time with Rotary-Wing support for the Commando Helicopter Force and a stint as an engineering instructor, Lt. Cdr. Greenfield arrived in California in 2017 to support F-35 Initial Operational Test & Evaluation at Edwards Air Force Base.

"I was an engineering officer and did a year out there with the F-35. I then returned to Royal Air Force Base (RAF) Marham in 2018 to support the stand-up of the 617 Squadron," said Greenfield. "I was part of the engineering team that took the aircraft from Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort, South Carolina, where the U.K. team trained with the U.S., and stepped up F-35 operations at RAF Marham."

Greenfield reported to the F-35 JPO in February 2019 to join the F-35B Deputy APML team. There is an APML and at least one Deputy APML for each F-35 variant, and these teams are one of the main links between the warfighter and the program office. "On the Deputy APML team for the F-35B, it is a U.S. Marine Corps Major and me. The APML reports directly to the Product Support Manager, allowing us to have holistic oversight of sustainment across the JPO. Our primary focus is ensuring we meet the Warfighter's needs from a sustainment perspective," said Greenfield.

Greenfield discovered that when he came to the JPO, even with ten years of military experience, he had to learn new aspects of the program since it was an unfamiliar environment. He worried if his lack of acquisition experience would hinder his performance at the JPO.

"From my perspective, I had no acquisition background. My career thus far had been operationally focused. I was used to working on a small team that is at the end of a chain delivering an output," Greenfield said. "However, that is also the rewarding part of being here. It is building those diverse relationships across the program, across multiple disciplines, and also with both government and industry partners."

"It was a great entry to the JPO's U.K. team and Deputy APML role. My U.S. teammates welcomed me, and if it weren't for them, my learning curve would have been greater. I worked on F-35 squadrons for two years before the JPO, so I knew F-35, but I didn't know acquisition, I didn't understand the U.S. way of doing acquisition or how a U.S. program office worked, but my U.S. teammates were there for me and were very helpful with getting me acclimated,” said Greenfield. “Equally, I was the only one on our team who had experience on an F-35 squadron and had maintained the air system. It tied in with the fact that everyone has a unique skill that elevates the quality of your team here."

The learning curve at the JPO allowed Greenfield to realize that making mistakes means pushing boundaries and putting yourself outside of your comfort zone.

"It is easy to sit back and not put yourself out there and not ask the stupid questions, but, I learned we have to embrace the fact that we work in a complicated program where you need to ask those questions. If you don't put yourself out there, successful or innovative ideas won't just appear," Greenfield determined.

The F-35 is currently demonstrating its interoperability aboard the Royal Navy aircraft carrier HMS Queen Elizabeth (R08), and Lt. Cdr. Greenfield thinks that is both exciting and significant for the program.

"The milestone deployment is great! I joined the Navy in 2009, and our last operational carrier deployment with fixed-wing aircraft was in 2010. To see the Royal Navy and Royal Air Force operating on HMS Queen Elizabeth is very exciting. And to do it with U.S. Marines is a testament to the strong relationship between our two countries and the [F-35] B variant operators," said Greenfield. "We trained with the Marines at Beaufort, and to now be deployed at sea with them is fantastic. It shows the great benefits of this program and the interoperability of the F-35. We can deploy on a partner nation's aircraft carrier. I'm jealous of anyone that gets to sail with the Queen Elizabeth for the next couple of months!"

The F-35 global enterprise unites exceptional people with groundbreaking technology to preserve peace and security worldwide. Its international colleagues bring value, broader skills, and new ideas to the daily management of the F-35 program. With Lt. Cdr. Greenfield aboard, the F-35 will continue to maintain its global air dominance for years to come.
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿
column10: 皇家海军队友为F-35带来宝贵的工程技能
column11: 弗吉尼亚州水晶城（2021年6月28日）作为F-35企业的一部分，您可以与有才华的同事合作，提高全球机队中最具杀伤力的飞机的价格、性能和可用性。皇家海军中校。斯图尔特・格林菲尔德（Stuart Greenfield）是F-35联合项目办公室（JPO）的一名英国队友，在F-35后勤助理项目经理（APML）团队工作。他年轻时就对军队、军队的技术以及为国家服务的勤劳团队的价值着迷。“我爸爸带我去朴茨茅斯女王海军基地参加了‘国际海洋节’。每隔几年，来自世界各地的海军舰艇就会造访。我们必须乘坐来自不同国家的不同船只。我对我们如何以不同的方式完成任务有一种感觉，但最终目标是一样的，”格林菲尔德回忆道。“我接受了国际团队合作的想法。我记得我生动地登上了英国无敌级航空母舰上的一个飞行甲板，看到了鹞，和飞行员和工程师聊天。这是一个令人惊奇的童年经历，它激发了我的想象力，塑造了我加入皇家海军的想法。“从F-35企业早期开始，甚至在选择最终飞机概念之前，英国就一直是一个不可或缺的合作伙伴。“虽然我们都有相同的最终目标，但由于我们的文化和我们军队的不同核心价值观，我们实现这一目标的方式略有不同，但这正是F-35的优势所在。”格林菲尔德说，他知道自己将在2009年大学毕业后加入皇家海军。在完成各种任务后，包括为突击队直升机部队提供旋转翼支持以及担任工程讲师，格林菲尔德中校于2017年抵达加利福尼亚州，以支持F-35的初步作战测试和评估爱德华兹空军基地。“我是一名工程军官，在F-35上服役了一年。2018年，我回到皇家空军基地（RAF）马勒姆，支持617中队的起立，”格林菲尔德说。“我是工程队的一员，从南卡罗来纳州海军陆战队空军基地博福特乘坐飞机，英国队与美国队训练，并在皇家空军马拉姆加强F-35作战。“Greenfield于2019年2月向F-35 JPO报告加入F-35B副APML团队。每个F-35变型都有一个APML和至少一个副APML，这些团队是作战人员和项目办公室之间的主要联系之一。“在F-35B的APML副团队中，是一名美国海军陆战队少校和我。APML直接向产品支持经理报告，使我们能够对整个JPO的持续性保障进行全面监督。我们的主要重点是确保我们从持续性保障的角度满足作战人员的需求，格林菲尔德说。格林菲尔德发现，当他来到JPO时，即使有十年的军事经验，他也必须学习该项目的新方面，因为这是一个陌生的环境。他担心缺乏采办经验会阻碍他在JPO的表现。格林菲尔德说：“从我的角度来看，我没有收购背景。到目前为止，我的职业生涯一直专注于运营。我习惯于在一个小团队中工作，该团队位于交付产出的链条末端。”然而，这也是在这里获得回报的一部分。这是在项目、多个学科以及政府和行业合作伙伴之间建立各种各样的关系。”这是一个伟大的进入JPO的英国队和副手APML角色。我的美国队友欢迎我，如果不是他们，我的学习曲线会更大。我在F-PO之前工作了F-35中队两年，所以我知道F-35，但是我不知道收购，我不理解美国的收购方式，或者美国程序是怎样的。格林菲尔德说：“我的办公室工作了，但我的美国队友在那里支持我，他们非常帮助我适应环境。”。“同样，我是我们团队中唯一一个拥有F-35中队经验并维护过空中系统的人。这与每个人都有独特的技能这一事实相联系，这提高了你们团队的质量。“JPO的学习曲线让Greenfield意识到犯错误意味着突破界限，把自己置身于舒适区之外。“坐下来，不把自己放在那里，不去问那些愚蠢的问题是很容易的，但是，我学到了我们必须接受这样一个事实：我们在一个复杂的项目中工作，你需要问那些问题。如果你不把自己放在那里，成功或创新的想法就不会出现，“格林菲尔德决定了。F-35目前正在皇家海军航空母舰“伊丽莎白女王”号（R08）和中校（Cdr）上展示其互操作性。格林菲尔德认为，这对该项目来说既令人兴奋又意义重大。“里程碑式的部署是伟大的！我在2009年加入海军，我们最后一次使用固定翼飞机进行航母部署是在2010年。看到皇家海军和皇家空军在英国皇家海军伊丽莎白女王号上作战是非常令人兴奋的。而与美国海军陆战队合作则是我们两国和美国海军之间牢固关系的证明。”[F-35]B变体操作员，”格林菲尔德说我们在波弗特与海军陆战队一起训练，现在与他们一起在海上部署真是太棒了。这表明了该计划的巨大好处以及F-35的互操作性。我们可以部署在伙伴国家的航空母舰上。我很羡慕任何能在未来几个月与伊丽莎白女王一起航行的人！"F-35全球企业用突破性的技术将杰出的人才团结在一起，以维护世界和平与安全。其国际同事为F-35计划的日常管理带来价值、更广泛的技能和新的理念。随着格林菲尔德少校的加入，F-35将在未来数年内继续保持其全球空中主导地位来吧。

column2: Laser Shock Peening - life-extending technology at work in F-35
column3:
CRYSTAL CITY, Va. (APRIL 5, 2021) The F-35 Joint Program Office (JPO) teamed up with engineers at U.S. Fleet Readiness Center East (FRCE) in Cherry Point, North Carolina, and laser technology professionals to strengthen the airframe of the U.S. Marine Corps short take-off-vertical landing (STOVL) F-35B. In February 2021, the first F-35B was inducted at the FRCE to receive the procedure, known as laser shock peening, to enable the aircraft to reach its full structural life limit. Although not every F-35B requires this modification, there are enough aircraft to keep the new facility hard at work, reinforcing additional F-35B airframes.

"The first F-35B that completed the laser shock peening procedure is a huge milestone for the F-35 Program and culminates three months of hard work and continuous learning," said F-35 JPO Vehicle Systems Director Alex Stathopoulos. "The teams at the JPO and at the Fleet Readiness Center East now can offer a strategic capability to the U.S. Marine Corps and other F-35B variant customers that is only available today at FRCE. A second laser shock peening site will stand up later this year at Ogden Air Logistics Center, Utah. Only two sites are planned to support F-35 laser shock peening modification efforts worldwide."

Laser shock peening is a high-tech procedure that uses high-energy laser beams to strengthen materials on the aircraft's bulkhead and airframe without adding additional metal or weight to increase aircraft lifespan and reduce maintenance costs. The technique has built on the experience of more than 20 years of use on commercial aircraft components and military aircraft such as the F-22 and, most recently, the F-35.

High-energy laser beams are fired at the metal, and laser shock waves penetrate deep into metal surfaces to create residual stress patterns to counteract corrosion, cracking, and other symptoms of metal fatigue. Ultimately, it leads to a more durable airframe. Upon completion, the FRC-E will put the F-35Bs back together, perform all the flight test functions and get them back to the fleet.

"By strengthening the airframe with this advanced laser procedure, it keeps the F-35 flying because these solid structures remove critical life limits on the aircraft while not adding additional weight, allowing full fuel or weapons carrying capacity," explained Col. Michael Dehner, F-35 U.S. Marine Corps Service Deputy at the JPO. "The technology protects the warfighter and boosts our nation's defense by ensuring aircraft are ready for operational employment when called upon."

The additional safety and structural life that laser shock peening provides also allows the F-35, particularly the F-35B, to be more supportable, more affordable, and more lethal. F-35Bs are currently flying missions from deployed amphibious ships with the U.S. Marine Corps, certifying the ability to fly off the flight deck of ITS Cavour (Italian navy ship, CVH 550) while also training U.S. and allied nation pilots and maintainers to be ready to support and defend our nation's freedom.

The F-35 JPO comprises more than 2,000 uniformed, civilian, and contractor personnel, distributed across more than 40 locations around the world. The program provides fifth-generation weapons system technology in support of air combat missions for the U.S. Air Force, U.S. Navy, U.S. Marine Corps, seven F-35 cooperative partner nations, and a growing number of foreign military sales (FMS) customers. The F-35 JPO has delivered the F-35 aircraft in partnership with industry partners and a diverse team of subordinate suppliers. To date, more than 620 F-35s have been delivered, over 368,000 safe flying hours have been accumulated, and over 1,270 pilots and 10,150 maintainers have been trained.

Visit www.jsf.mil for more information on the F-35 Lightning II.
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿
column10: 激光冲击喷丸-F-35工作中的寿命延长技术
column11: 弗吉尼亚州水晶城（2021年4月5日）F-35联合项目办公室（JPO）与北卡罗来纳州樱桃角美国舰队准备中心东部（FRCE）的工程师和激光技术专业人员合作，加强美国海军陆战队短起飞垂直着陆（STOVL）F-35B的机身。2021年2月，第一架F-35B在FRCE被引入，以接受被称为激光冲击喷丸的程序，以使飞机达到其全部结构寿命极限。虽然并非每架F-35B都需要进行这种改装，但有足够的飞机使新设施继续运转，增强了额外的F-35B机身。“第一架完成激光冲击喷丸程序的F-35B是F-35计划的一个巨大里程碑，是三个月辛勤工作和不断学习的结晶。”F-35 JPO车辆系统主管Alex Stathopoulos说。“JPO和舰队准备中心东部的团队现在可以为美国海军陆战队和其他F-35B变型客户提供战略能力，这一能力目前仅在FRCE可用。今年晚些时候，第二个激光冲击喷丸基地将在犹他州奥格登航空物流中心设立。计划只在两个基地支持F-35激光shock世界范围内的喷丸改造工作。”激光冲击喷丸是一种高科技程序，使用高能激光束强化飞机舱壁和机身上的材料，而不增加额外的金属或重量，以延长飞机寿命并降低维护成本。该技术建立在商用飞机部件和军用飞机（如F-22和最近的F-35）20多年使用经验的基础上。高能激光束射向金属，激光冲击波深入金属表面，形成残余应力模式，以抵消腐蚀、开裂，以及金属疲劳的其他症状。最终，它将带来更耐用的机身。完成后，FRC-E将把F-35B重新组装起来，执行所有飞行测试功能，并将其送回机队。“通过使用这种先进的激光程序加强机身，它使F-35保持飞行，因为这些坚固的结构消除了飞机的关键寿命限制，同时又不增加额外重量，使其能够携带全部燃料或武器，”JPO的F-35美国海军陆战队副勤务官迈克尔・德纳上校解释道这项技术保护了作战人员，并通过确保飞机在需要时可随时投入作战使用来加强我国的国防。“激光冲击喷丸所提供的额外安全性和结构寿命也使F-35，特别是F-35B，更具支撑性、更经济实惠和更致命。F-35B目前正在美国海军陆战队部署的两栖舰艇上执行飞行任务，证明有能力从其Cavour（意大利海军舰艇，CVH 550）的飞行甲板上起飞同时还训练美国和盟国飞行员和维修人员随时准备支持和捍卫我们国家的自由。F-35 JPO由2000多名军警、文职人员和承包商人员组成，分布在全球40多个地点。该计划为美国空军、美国海军、美国海军陆战队、七个F-35合作伙伴国家以及越来越多的外国军事销售（FMS）客户提供第五代武器系统技术，以支持空战任务。F-35 JPO与行业合作伙伴和不同的下属供应商团队合作交付了F-35飞机。迄今为止，已经交付了620多架F-35，累计安全飞行时间超过368000小时，培训了1270多名飞行员和10150名维修人员。有关F-35 Lightning II的更多信息，请访问www.jsf.mil。

column2: International Business interest pursued at the F-35 Joint Program Office
column3:
ARLINGTON, Va. (March 22, 2021) -- Mehvish Khan accepted a Contract Specialist position at the F-35 Lightning II Joint Program Office (JPO) in 2019 while embarking on her post-graduate life. The challenge of pursuing her Master's Degree at Georgetown University in Security Studies and supporting the JPO's Contracts Department's mission is indicative of the hard-charging individuals at the JPO.

The Lakewood, New York native, was attracted to the program's international business side after an internship at the U.S. Embassy in London. While working on their political-military affairs team, she learned the importance of allied nations and how to work closely with others to develop innovative ideas; precisely the experience Khan would need to hit the ground running at the JPO.

"When I arrived at the JPO, I supported modification contracts for the F-35 aircraft, working with the Engineering Team. It is interesting because you put ideas to paper, solidify them, and make those ideas come to life,” said Khan. “Your actions have real-world implications on the lives of our military. As part of the contracts team, you are part of the implementation and execution of ideas. You then see these capabilities delivered, and that is the rewarding part." 

As Khan approached her second anniversary at the JPO, she realized that she had been given an opportunity to be a part of something bigger. She started seeking ways to support Foreign Military Sales (FMS) contracts for Israel and the Republic of Korea. Her energetic attitude and drive got her noticed and opened the door to a permanent FMS team position. 

"I was drawn by the news of a possible new customer for the F-35, and I asked if I could support it on the contract side. Showing my interest allowed me to do something inspiring and support FMS full-time," said Khan. "You have to dive into everything and be curious here. The more immersed you are, the better you will be in the long run."

Being proactive is the key to success at the JPO, according to Khan. 

Her advice to those starting their careers following college is to make your own way. "Do not be afraid to ask questions or ask for new opportunities; be the steward of your own career," Khan said.

Even though the JPO is divided into different Project Management Offices and Functional Teams, all those supporting F-35 warfighters agree: it is a full-team effort. "The mission doesn't work if everyone doesn't do their part," Khan added. The commitment to create an inclusive environment where we invite and encourage diverse perspectives, ideas, and people is essential for longevity. This inclusive approach allows us to remain competitive and innovative―now and in the future. "With diversity comes different perspectives and life experiences," said Khan. A variety of perspectives is vital to any organization. "When you get a group of unique human beings together from which to draw ideas, you are going to get the best final idea."

Khan's perspective and positivity are a model for both newcomers and seasoned members of the F-35 JPO.

For more information, visit www.jsf.mil.
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿
column10: F-35联合项目办公室追求的国际商业利益
column11: 弗吉尼亚州阿灵顿（2021年3月22日）--梅维什・汗于2019年接受了F-35闪电II联合项目办公室（JPO）的合同专家职位，同时开始了她的研究生生活。她在乔治敦大学攻读安全研究硕士学位，并支持初级专业人员合同部的使命，这一挑战表明了初级专业人员的努力。这位纽约本地人莱克伍德在美国驻伦敦大使馆实习后，被吸引到该项目的国际业务部门。在他们的政治军事团队工作期间，她了解到盟国的重要性，以及如何与其他国家密切合作，发展创新理念；Khan在JPO的起步体验正是如此。“当我来到JPO时，我支持F-35飞机的改装合同，与工程团队合作。这很有趣，因为你把想法写在纸上，巩固它们，让这些想法变为现实，”Khan说。“你的行动对我们军队的生活有着现实的影响。作为合同团队的一员，你是想法实施和执行的一部分。然后你会看到这些能力的发挥，这是值得的。”当Khan在JPO工作两周年之际，她意识到自己有机会成为更大事业的一部分。她开始寻找支持对外军售（FMS）的方法以色列和大韩民国的合同。她精力充沛的态度和干劲引起了她的注意，并为FMS团队的永久职位打开了大门。“我被F-35可能的新客户的消息吸引住了，我问我是否可以在合同方面支持它。表现出我的兴趣让我能够做一些鼓舞人心的事情，全职支持FMS，”汗说。“你必须深入到每件事中，并对这里充满好奇。你越是沉浸其中，从长远来看，你会做得越好。”。Khan说，积极主动是JPO成功的关键。她对大学毕业后开始职业生涯的人的建议是走自己的路。“不要害怕问问题或寻求新的机会；做自己职业生涯的管理者。”尽管JPO分为不同的项目管理办公室和职能团队，但所有支持F-35作战人员的人都同意：这是一个完整的团队工作。“如果每个人都不尽自己的职责，任务就无法完成。”Khan补充道。致力于创造一个包容的环境，让我们邀请和鼓励不同的观点、想法和人群，这对长寿至关重要。这种包容的方式让我们在现在和未来保持竞争力和创新。“多样化带来不同的观点和生活体验。”Khan说。各种视角对任何组织都至关重要。“当你让一群独特的人聚集在一起，从中得出想法时，你将得到最好的最终想法。”Khan的视角和积极性是F-35 JPO新成员和经验丰富成员的典范。有关更多信息，请访问www.jsf.mil。

column2: TF-76 conducts a Staff Exercise
column3:
WESTOVER, Mass. C The Task Force 76 (TF-76) out of Westover Air Reserve Base, Massachusetts, held its staff exercise or STAFFEX, Aug. 3-7.
The exercise is task organized between the senior leaders and various staff sections for briefings, battle rhythm, drills, rehearsals, staff estimate, and working group sessions designed to train the unit for its wartime missions.
 “How do we run estimate for the unit, into our SOPs?  How we do rehearsal, we need to understand and incorporate that into our SOP,” said Col Doug Mills, TF-76 chief of staff.  
One of the tasks to staff is to create sectional structure in accordance with 150 passengers battle roster and to identify key outputs and staffing shortfalls.  “The end of STAFFEX, the staff should give and back brief the chief of staff, and say sir, we looked at what we got, we looked at our resources, this is the structure that we want to use; it meets the commander’s intent, these are the titles and positions,” said Maj. Thomas Gingras, TF-76 operations officer.
Mills referenced his battle update brief (BUB) during his deployment, how the brief was at seven every morning because the North BUB was at eight in the morning.  “You have to be flexible and adaptable and be able to do those kinds of things.  That is why identifying these duties and responsibilities, and what you’re bringing to me, at least the ones that are standing, boards and working groups, allows that flexibility. It allows us to fill that bench players and the people that we pull in on short notice to fill those gaps.”
The STAFFEX group sessions included briefings from Massachusetts Emergency Management Agency (MEMA), Joint Task Force C Civil Support (JTF-CS), and Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA).
Bonnie Roy, Regional Planner at MEMA, provided an overview of the Web Emergency Operations Center (EOC).  The Soldiers were provided a multi-user account that will be the account that the Soldiers will take with them.  So if they activate their EOC and they want to use Web EOC, this will be the permanent login and password, from now and going forward.  “Web EOC is our primary communication tools and it operates 24/7 for our dispatch, if it’s actually for disasters, it moves over into the state EOC.  We also use it here in regional EOC,” said Roy.
MEMA is the state agency responsible for coordinating federal, state, local, voluntary and private resources during emergencies and disasters in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. 
Information Management Officer Bill Solar, JTF-CS, said that the Web EOC is a web-based database use to share information over the internet.  “It’s an emergency management tool.  We use it as our main emergency operations tool.”  During hands-on, Soldiers learned that the web-based also managed situational awareness activity log by being able to record, track and share information where everyone can see.  They are able to input after action review (AAR), update briefing slides for the command update brief, update personnel status (Red Cross, leave) and protocol biographies for distinguish visitors, built-in checklist (ex: aircraft accident), flight tracker for TF-Aviation, and request for information (RFI) tracker.  These are some of the boards examples created in the database.  The web-based also managed resource requests such as generators, chainsaw, tents, spill kits, and more during major incidents and disasters.
“Web EOC basically lets you know what’s going on in the state,” said Roy.
“EOC is a new system.  We do this to increase awareness.  How do you link that into your staff estimate,” said Mills.
The TF-76 leadership plans to use the knowledge gained and the work accomplished during STAFFEX to prepare for future exercises and missions.
The TF-76’s mission is to deploy to provide mission command to Department of Defense response forces, conducting operations in a Command and Control Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear Response Element C A (U.S. Army) role, and anticipates requirements in support of civil authorities, to save lives, alleviate suffering, and maintain public confidence.
column6: WESTOVER AIR FORCE BASE, MA, UNITED STATES
column9: 威斯托弗空军基地，马萨诸塞州，美国
column10: TF-76进行人员训练
column11: 马萨诸塞州威斯托弗8月3日至7日，马萨诸塞州Westover空军储备基地的第76特遣部队（TF-76）举行了员工演习或STAFFEX。该演习由高级领导和各员工部门组织，内容包括简报、战斗节奏、演习、彩排、员工评估、，以及为训练部队执行战时任务而设计的工作组会议。TF-76参谋长道格・米尔斯上校说：“我们如何在SOP中对部队进行评估？我们如何进行排练，我们需要了解并将其纳入SOP。”。工作人员的任务之一是根据150名乘客的战斗名册建立部门结构，并确定关键产出和人员短缺。托马斯・金格拉斯少校说：“斯塔夫克斯结束后，参谋部应该向参谋长汇报情况，并说，长官，我们看了我们得到的东西，我们看了我们的资源，这是我们想要使用的结构；它符合指挥官的意图，这些是头衔和职位。”，TF-76作战官。米尔斯在部署期间参考了他的作战更新简报（BUB），简报是如何在每天早上七点进行的，因为北部BUB是在早上八点进行的。“你必须具有灵活性和适应能力，能够做这类事情。这就是为什么确定这些职责和责任，以及你给我带来的东西，至少是那些站着的、董事会和工作组，允许这种灵活性。它允许我们填补替补球员和我们在短时间内吸引的人。”STAFFEX小组会议包括来自马萨诸塞州应急管理局（MEMA）、民事支持联合工作队（JTF-CS）和联邦应急管理局（FEMA）的简报。MEMA的区域规划师Bonnie Roy概述了网络应急运营中心（EOC）。士兵们被提供了一个多用户帐户，这将是士兵们随身携带的帐户。因此，如果他们激活自己的EOC，并希望使用Web EOC，那么从现在起，这将是永久登录名和密码。“网络平等机会委员会是我们的主要通信工具，它为我们的调度提供24/7的服务，如果它真的用于灾难，它将转移到州平等机会委员会。我们在地区平等机会委员会中也使用它，”罗伊说。MEMA是负责协调联邦、州、地方，马萨诸塞州联邦紧急情况和灾难期间的自愿和私人资源。JTF-CS信息管理官比尔・索拉（Bill Solar）表示，网络平等机会委员会是一个基于网络的数据库，用于在互联网上共享信息。“这是一种应急管理工具。我们将其用作主要的应急操作工具。”在实践中，士兵们了解到，基于web的系统还可以通过记录、跟踪和共享每个人都能看到的信息来管理态势感知活动日志。他们能够输入行动后回顾（AAR）、更新指挥更新简报的简报幻灯片、更新人员状态（红十字会、休假）和访客的协议传记、内置检查表（例如：飞机事故）、TF航空飞行跟踪器和信息请求（RFI）跟踪器。这些是在数据库中创建的一些板示例。在重大事故和灾难期间，基于网络的EOC还管理发电机、电锯、帐篷、泄漏工具包等资源请求。“网络EOC基本上让你知道该州发生了什么，”罗伊说。“EOC是一个新系统。我们这样做是为了提高意识。你如何将其与员工评估联系起来？”TF-76领导层计划利用在STAFFEX期间获得的知识和完成的工作，为未来的演习和任务做好准备。TF-76的任务是部署，为国防部反应部队提供任务指挥，在指挥和控制化学、生物、放射性、，核反应要素――一种（美国陆军）角色，预测支持民政当局的需求，以拯救生命、减轻痛苦和维持公众信心。

column2: Task Force 76 trains for the ‘what if’
column3:
CAMP ATTERBURY, Ind.C When catastrophes like hurricane Katrina hit the U.S., most Americans understand that the Federal Emergency Management Agent (FEMA) will arrive on the scene almost immediately to take the lead in the federal response. What most people don’t know is that there are three federal task forces that exist specifically designed to step in to support. The three military task forces are TF-76, TF-38 and Joint TF- Civil Support. 
Exercise Vibrant Response is a command post exercise that simulates the task force response to a nuclear detonation in a major U.S. city. The exercise is like a role playing game where participants interact with one another. This trains people to learn what to do from the good and bad decisions they make. So that if the situation ever does happen they will make the right decision.
“Task Force 76’s mission is to support the lead federal agency, and is one of three federal task forces that are set up for all-hazards response,” said Maj. Gen. Ricky Waddell, commander of Task Force 76, based out of Salt Lake City. “With special capabilities for chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear response, and our composition includes specialists in the “C-B-R-N” fields, but we have a variety of other support personnel. 
A total of about 570 service members from several branches of the military have taken part in the exercise. 
Key to the exercise is replicating complex scenarios the task force may face in responding to a real-world event. 
“This exercise is the culminating training event that we do to prepare the staff to deal with the chaotic conditions in an urban disaster environment,” said Col. Doug Mills, the Chief of Staff for Task Force 76. “We try to replicate those requirements that our civilian agencies are going to ask of us and work through coordination events so we can provide them on-time support.” 
Examples of the challenges thrown at task force during the exercise range from getting supplies and food to areas where roads and infrastructure have been destroyed to having nuclear experts track projected plume of nuclear fallout and the identify effects of exposure at different levels and times to dealing with a helicopter crash. The issues often come up at a moment’s notice and require efficient coordination and teamwork. 
Having the ability to practice with the other units in advance of a real world event is critically important, Mills said. “The worst thing that can happen to us is that we’re exchanging business cards on the ‘battlefield’ and during that time of crisis. We need to be able to trust and depend on the people who have the knowledge and expertise. So this is how we stay ready.”
column9: 美国阿拉巴马州阿特伯里营地
column10: 第76工作队为“假设”进行培训
column11: 印第安纳州阿特伯里营地――当卡特里娜飓风等灾难袭击美国时，大多数美国人都明白，联邦应急管理局（FEMA）几乎会立即赶到现场，带头采取联邦应对措施。大多数人不知道的是，有三个联邦特别工作组专门为支持这一计划而成立。三支军事特遣部队分别是TF-76、TF-38和联合TF-民事支援。演习Vibrant Response是一次指挥所演习，模拟特遣部队对美国主要城市核爆炸的反应。这个练习就像一个角色扮演游戏，参与者之间相互交流。这训练人们从他们做出的好的和坏的决定中学习该做什么。因此，如果情况真的发生，他们将做出正确的决定。“76号工作队的任务是支持主要的联邦机构，是为应对所有危险而成立的三个联邦工作队之一，”位于盐湖城的76号工作队指挥官Ricky Waddell少将说。“具有化学、生物、辐射和核反应的特殊能力，我们的组成包括“C-B-R-N”方面的专家”但我们有各种各样的其他支持人员。来自多个军种的总共约570名军人参加了演习。演习的关键是复制特遣部队在应对现实事件时可能面临的复杂场景。76号工作队参谋长道格・米尔斯上校说：“这次演习是我们为准备工作人员应对城市灾害环境中的混乱状况而进行的最重要的培训活动。”。“我们试图复制我们的民事机构将向我们提出的要求，并通过协调活动开展工作，以便我们能够及时向他们提供支持。”演习期间，工作队面临的挑战包括从获得补给和食品到道路和基础设施被破坏的地区，到让核专家跟踪预计的核沉降物羽流，以及确定不同程度和不同时间的暴露对处理直升机坠毁的影响米尔斯说，在一个现实世界的活动之前，有能力与其他单位一起练习是至关重要的。“可能发生在我们身上的最糟糕的事情是，我们在‘战场’上和危机期间交换名片。我们需要能够信任和依赖拥有知识和专业技能的人。因此，这就是我们如何做好准备的方式。”

column2: 76 Years Later- Remembering Pfc. Nelles
column3:
JOINT BASE PEARL HARBOR-HICKAM, Hawaii―When the Japanese attacked Hickam Field on Sunday, December 7, 1941, over 189 people lost their lives.  One in particular was a young chaplain’s assistant who was setting up for the morning service.  Seventy-six years later, a small group gathered in the Courtyard of Heroes for a remembrance service and Catholic Mass in honor of U.S. Army Air Corps Pfc. Joseph Nelles Dec. 10. 

“This is a sacred place today―not just because we gather to pray and worship; it’s also sacred because we gather to remember,” said Lt. Col. David Dersch, Pacific Air Forces staff chaplain. “Whatever our faith background, we share a common legacy of faith and courage.  Today, we are ohana―brought together by an amazing heritage.”

Nelles was a Catholic chaplain’s assistant stationed at Hickam Field in 1941. He was preparing the altar for Mass at the base theater that Sunday when a bomb hit.  The theater was completely destroyed and Nelles’ body was found at the altar. 

In a letter to Nelles’ parents, Col. Edmund C. Sliney, the base chaplain, wrote about their son’s dedication to both God and country. 

“I myself found his body, and from its position, I firmly believe that he had reached the altar and was probably kneeling before it,” said Sliney.  “Joe was a splendid boy who did much for the Holy Mother church while here, being untiring in his efforts to lead his fellow soldiers to God."

The ceremony was held at the at the Courtyard of Heroes in the Pacific Air Force headquarters building, which still bears the marks from the attack. 

“If these walls could speak, they would tell us of the courage, faith, and sacrifice of the heroes of Hickam Field who gave their all to defend our great land,” said Dersch.  “This sacred heritage is now passed on to every service member who defends our nation and the freedom we cherish.”
column6: JOINT BASE PEARL HARBOR-HICKAM, HI, UNITED STATES
column9: 珍珠港-希卡姆联合基地，美国
column10: 76年后――纪念Pfc.Nelles
column11: 当日本人在1941年12月7日星期日袭击希卡姆地区时，超过189人丧生。其中一位是一位年轻牧师的助手，他正在为晨祷做准备。76年后的12月10日，一小群人聚集在英雄院里，举行纪念仪式和天主教弥撒，纪念美国陆军航空兵Pfc.约瑟夫・内尔斯（Joseph Nelles）。太平洋空军参谋部牧师David Dersch中校说：“今天这里是一个神圣的地方，不仅因为我们聚集在一起祈祷和礼拜；它也是神圣的，因为我们聚集在一起纪念。”。“无论我们的信仰背景如何，我们都有着共同的信仰和勇气。今天，我们是由一份令人惊叹的遗产汇集在一起的奥哈纳。”内尔斯是1941年派驻希卡姆菲尔德的天主教牧师助理。那个星期天，当一枚炸弹击中他时，他正在基地剧院为弥撒准备祭坛。剧院被彻底摧毁，在祭坛上发现了内尔斯的尸体。在给内尔斯父母的一封信中，卑鄙的牧师埃德蒙・C・斯莱尼上校写到了他们的儿子对上帝和国家的奉献。斯莱尼说：“我自己发现了他的尸体，从尸体的位置上看，我坚信他已经到了祭坛，很可能是跪在祭坛前。”。“乔是一个出色的男孩，他在这里为圣母教堂做了很多事情，他坚持不懈地努力带领他的战友们走向上帝。”仪式在太平洋空军总部大楼的英雄庭院举行，那里仍然有袭击的痕迹。德希说：“如果这些墙能说话的话，它们将告诉我们希卡姆地区英雄们的勇气、信念和牺牲，他们为保卫我们伟大的土地付出了一切。现在，这一神圣遗产将传递给每一位捍卫我们国家和我们所珍视的自由的军人。”

column2: TF-76 prepares to save lives and mitigate the suffering
column3:
CAMP ATTERBURY, Ind. -- When disaster strikes and chaos sets in, people can forget their cities' emergency evacuation plans and highways get stacked with traffic. People get hurt and communication gets cut off.  

Vibrant Response 17 is an annual command post exercise here that simulates the detonation of a nuclear bomb in a major city within the United States. This year it was integrated with Guardian Response 17 at Muscatatuck Urban Training Center, Indiana.

The exercises enable emergency response organizations, both civilian and military, to integrate and provide relief during a catastrophic disaster.

The simulated detonation occurred May 2, 2017. Following the established national response framework, the state first responders and National Guard forces answered the first calls for help.

As the situation escalated and resources were exhausted, the state requested federal support. Per the federal response framework, the first federal agencies to respond are civilian. Support from the Department of Defense is then requested as necessary. Task Force 76  arrived at the scene on May 6, 2017.

Once at the scene, TF-76 provides support to the incident commander, state and Federal Emergency Management Agency in several areas. These include:  urban search and rescue, extractions, and mass casualty decontamination. They also have transportation assets that allow them to do patient evacuation and resupply both by ground and air. They have the ability to produce water and have operational, medical and logistical forces. The task force is made up of people assigned to the 76th Operational Readiness Command, a U.S. Army Reserve unit out of Salt Lake City.

Brig. Gen. James Blakenhorn, the deputy commanding general for TF-76, said the task force gains two main things out of this training event. First, it exercises the higher staffs to ensure they have processes, procedures, interfaces and communications established and ready to execute.  Secondly, it gives the folks in the field at GR17 confidence in their abilities to perform the mission. It also provides units with the confidence in their equipment, procedures and leadership to become more proficient.

During a catastrophic event such as VR17, FEMA is the primary agency requesting support from TF-76 and another task force, TF-46, the Michigan National Guard’s 46th Military Police Command.

According to Master Sgt. Trevor Smith, the future operations noncommissioned officer in charge for TF-76, FEMA can send down specific mission requests, or MAs, for support such as supplies, transportation and decontamination said. Following that initial request, the headquarters for TF-76 or TF-46 have to develop plans of action. They do this through battle rhythm briefings that then provide the information to create updated fragmentary orders. Once each task force knows their mission, they disseminate orders down to the commanders on the ground. 

These and other processes require time and practice to perfect. Training together prepares everyone for when it’s time to react to a real-world scenario, where the mission is to save lives and mitigate the suffering of the people of the United States.

“We always plan this exercise as if the worst had happened, however, what's great about our mission is that it doesn't have to be a nuclear detonation for us to get involved,” said Blakenhorn. “The catastrophe could be something like a hurricane or a wild fire. There's a number of natural disasters that can cause a great deal of pain and suffering where federal forces may be required.

“Due to the experience the Soldiers get here at this level, they also know they can perform if they were called up for some of these other missions as well,” added Blakenhorn. “We hope that we never have to use these assets, but if we do, we want the Soldiers to know, through these type of exercises, that they are fully capable of performing the mission at call.”
column9: 美国阿拉巴马州阿特伯里营地
column10: TF-76准备拯救生命和减轻痛苦
column11: 印第安纳州阿特伯里营地――当灾难来袭和混乱来临时，人们可能会忘记他们城市的紧急疏散计划，高速公路上塞满了车辆。人们受到伤害，交流中断。Vibrant Response 17是这里一年一度的指挥所演习，模拟美国一个主要城市的核弹爆炸。今年，它在印第安纳州马斯卡塔塔克城市培训中心与《卫报》第17号响应系统整合。演习使民间和军方的应急响应组织能够在灾难性灾难期间整合并提供救援。模拟爆炸发生在2017年5月2日。根据建立的国家反应框架，州第一反应者和国民警卫队部队响应了第一批求助电话。随着局势升级和资源耗尽，州请求联邦支持。根据联邦反应框架，第一批作出反应的联邦机构是民间机构。必要时请求国防部提供支持。第76特遣部队于2017年5月6日抵达现场。一旦到达现场，TF-76将在多个地区向事件指挥官、州和联邦应急管理局提供支持。这些措施包括：城市搜救、撤离和大规模伤亡人员净化。他们还拥有运输设备，可以通过地面和空中进行患者后送和再补给。他们有能力生产水，并拥有作战、医疗和后勤力量。该特遣部队由分配到第76作战准备司令部的人员组成，该司令部是盐湖城以外的美国陆军预备役部队。TF-76的副指挥官詹姆斯・布莱克霍恩将军说，特遣部队从这次训练活动中获得了两大收获。首先，它训练高层员工确保他们建立了流程、程序、接口和通信，并准备好执行。其次，它让GR17现场的人员对他们执行任务的能力充满信心。它还让部队对自己的装备、程序和领导能力充满信心，从而变得更加熟练。在VR17这样的灾难性事件中，联邦应急管理局是请求TF-76和另一个特遣部队TF-46（密歇根州国民警卫队第46军警司令部）支持的主要机构。据特雷弗・史密斯上士说，联邦应急管理局负责TF-76的未来作战士官可以发送具体任务请求，或MAs，以获得补给、运输和去污等支持。根据这一初步要求，TF-76或TF-46总部必须制定行动计划。他们通过作战节奏简报做到这一点，然后提供信息以创建更新的零碎订单。一旦每个特遣部队了解了他们的任务，他们就会向地面指挥官下达命令。这些和其他过程需要时间和实践来完善。共同训练让每个人都做好准备，以应对现实世界的情况，在现实世界中，任务是拯救生命和减轻美国人民的痛苦。Blakenhorn说：“我们总是把这次演习当作最糟糕的情况发生一样来计划，然而，我们的任务最大的好处是，我们参与演习不一定非得是核爆炸。”。“这场灾难可能是飓风或野火。在需要联邦军队的地方，有许多自然灾害可能会造成巨大的痛苦和痛苦。布拉肯霍恩补充道：“由于士兵们在这一级别上的经验，他们也知道，如果他们也被征召参加其他一些任务，他们也能胜任。”。“我们希望我们永远不必使用这些资产，但如果我们这样做，我们希望士兵们通过这些类型的演习知道，他们完全有能力执行随时待命的任务。”

column2: 45th SW supports successful Falcon 9 NROL-76 launch
column3:
SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket is carrying a classified national security payload for the U.S. National Reconnaissance Office. This will be SpaceX’s first launch for the NRO.

This launch marked the third launch to use the Autonomous Flight Safety System and the fourth successful landing of the Falcon 9 first stage booster on SpaceX’s Landing Zone 1 at CCAFS. AFSS takes ground-based mission flight control personnel and equipment out of the control center and replaces it with on-board Positioning, Navigation and Timing sources and decision logic.  The benefits of AFSS include increased public safety, reduced reliance on range infrastructure, reduced range spacelift cost, increased schedule predictability and availability, operational flexibility, and launch site flexibility.

The Falcon 9 NROL-76 launch was the seventh major launch operation for the Eastern Range this year. Before any launch can blast off from the range, a dedicated team of military, government civilians and contractors from across the wing provide the mission assurance to ensure a safe and successful lift-off for range customers.

“Assured access to space is a team sport here on the Eastern Range."

"We continue to play a vital role in assuring access to space and this launch demonstrates our capability to keep up the pace as we move closer to our goal of 48 launches a year,” said Brig. Gen. Wayne Monteith, 45th Space Wing commander.  “It takes less than a minute to get a rocket safely out of our atmosphere, but this launch was the culmination of many long hours and preparation though a series of rigorous rehearsals, readiness reviews and pre-operational checkouts.  This mission once again clearly demonstrates the successful collaboration we have with our mission partners at NRO and SpaceX as we continue to shape the future of America’s space operations and showcase why the 45th Space Wing is the ‘World's Premiere Gateway to Space.’”
column6: CAPE CANAVERAL AIR FORCE STATION, FL, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国佛罗里达州卡纳维拉尔角空军基地
column10: 第45软件支持Falcon 9 NROL-76成功发射
column11: SpaceX的猎鹰9号火箭为美国国家侦察局携带一枚国家安全机密有效载荷。这将是SpaceX首次为NRO发射。这次发射标志着第三次使用自主飞行安全系统发射，以及Falcon 9一级助推器第四次成功着陆在SpaceX的着陆区1 CCAFS。AFSS将地面任务飞行控制人员和设备带出控制中心，代之以机载定位、导航和定时源以及决策逻辑。AFSS的好处包括提高公共安全性、减少对靶场基础设施的依赖、降低靶场空间提升成本、增加计划的可预测性和可用性、操作灵活性和发射场的灵活性。猎鹰9号NROL-76发射是今年东部靶场的第七次主要发射操作。在任何发射可以从靶场发射之前，一支由军方、政府文职人员和整个机翼的承包商组成的专门团队提供任务保障，以确保靶场客户安全成功地发射。“确保进入太空是东区的一项团队运动。”我们在确保进入太空方面继续发挥着至关重要的作用，这次发射表明我们有能力跟上步伐，因为我们正朝着每年48次发射的目标迈进，”布里格说。韦恩・蒙提斯将军，第45空间联队指挥官。“火箭安全离开大气层只需不到一分钟的时间，但这次发射是经过一系列严格的排练、准备就绪审查和运行前检查的长时间准备工作的高潮。这次任务再次清楚地表明，我们与我们的任务伙伴在NRO和SpaceX将继续塑造美国空间运营的未来，并展示为什么第45太空翼是“世界首屈一指的太空门户”

column2: ARNORTH, TF 76, others wrap up virtual annual disaster response exercise
column3:
SAN ANTONIO, Texas C U.S. Army North, U.S. Northern Command’s Joint Force Land Component Command, Task Force 76 and 750 military and civilian personnel from across the country participated in Vibrant Response, an annual disaster response training exercise, Apr. 26 to May 8, through virtual collaborative software.
 
“The purpose of Vibrant Response is to prepare a command and control headquarters to command and control a response in support of simulated chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear (CBRN) events,” said Col. Scotty Lene, the Vibrant Response Commander Operations Group (COG), for U.S. Army North. 

Task Force 76, the headquarters being evaluated, is a deployable reserve component element that, when activated, provides command and control of military response forces in support of civilian responders to manage catastrophic CBRN incidents.
 
“We’ve really watched this unit evolve over the last couple of years,” said Lene. “We gave them a rigorous problem set, they stepped up to the challenge, and then performed exceptionally.”

Vibrant Response 21 involved participants from the Department of Defense, Federal Emergency Management Agency, and other military and civilian agencies across the United States.
 
“This headquarters, along with its two-sister headquarters, one in the National Guard, and the other in the active component; all three responded in support of COVID last year,” explained Lene. 
 
These types of exercises help ensure they are ready to take on disasters of this magnitude, Lene said.

“They performed exceptionally in the [COVID-19] response,” said Lene. 
 
While Vibrant Response is a virtual exercise, it provides realistic training to every echelon of the formation. 
 
“It’s real life, they make it as real as they can get here. Nothing fake about it, which, I think this is really good training,” said Spc. Kimberly Soto, a human resources specialist with the 338th Medical Brigade, 3rd Medical Command Deployment Support, supporting the simulation team for Vibrant Response 21.

Realistic training lends itself to real world success and Task Force 76 has applied those training lessons over the years. 

 “Everything we do is in support of things that are happening in America, whether it's hurricane response, disaster response, wildland firefighting… pretty much everything happened in 2020, we were there, and that's a great mission to be able to give back to the American population.” said Lene.
column9: 美国德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥
column10: 76号特遣部队的阿诺思和其他人完成了虚拟年度救灾演习
column11: 德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥―美国陆军北部司令部、美国北部司令部联合部队陆上部分司令部、76号特遣部队以及来自全国各地的750名军事和文职人员通过虚拟协作软件参加了4月26日至5月8日举行的年度灾难响应训练演习。“振动响应的目的是准备一个指挥和控制总部，指挥和控制响应，以支持模拟化学、生物、辐射和核（CBRN）事件，”振动响应指挥官行动小组（COG）Scotty Lene上校说76特遣部队总部正在评估中，是一个可部署的预备役部队组成部分，一旦启动，将提供军事反应部队的指挥和控制，以支持民事反应人员管理灾难性CBRN事件。“我们真的看到了这个部队在过去几年的发展。”莱恩说：“我们给了他们一套严格的问题集，他们接受了挑战，然后表现得异常出色。”来自国防部、联邦应急管理局以及美国其他军事和民用机构的参与者参与了21项充满活力的响应。“这个司令部，连同它的两个姐妹司令部，一个在国民警卫队，另一个在现役部队；去年这三个司令部都响应支持新冠病毒，”莱恩解释说。莱恩说，这些类型的演习有助于确保他们准备好应对如此规模的灾难。“他们在[新冠病毒-19]中表现出色。”“反应，”莱恩说。虽然“活力反应”是一种虚拟训练，但它为编队的每个梯队提供了逼真的训练。“这是真实的生活，他们尽可能做到真实。没有任何虚假之处，我认为这是一种非常好的训练。”Spc.Kimberly Soto说，他是第三医疗司令部第338医疗旅部署支持部门的人力资源专家，支持模拟团队实现活力应对21。现实训练有助于现实世界的成功，76号工作队多年来一直在应用这些训练课程。“我们所做的一切都是为了支持美国正在发生的事情，无论是飓风应对、灾难应对、荒地灭火……几乎所有事情都发生在2020年，我们都在那里，这是一项伟大的使命，能够回报美国人民。”莱恩说。

column2: Halyburton Medical Health Clinic Honors Namesake 76 Years after Medal of Honor Actions
column3:
Sailors and Staff serving aboard Halyburton Medical Clinic paused Monday, May 10 to honor the memory and sacrifice of the clinic’s namesake who sacrificed his life 76 years ago in the service of his nation during World War II.

Pharmacist’s Mate Second Class William D. Halyburton posthumously received the Medal of Honor for his actions May 10, 1945 while serving as a corpsman with 2d Battalion, 5th Marines, 1st Marine Division during the WWII Battle of Okinawa.  He became the clinic’s namesake in a ceremony held October 1, 1994.

“Every day, Sailors and staff of Halyburton Medical Clinic honor the memory and actions of Pharmacist’s Mate Second Class William Halyburton Jr,” said Navy Capt. Patrick Fitzpatrick, the clinic’s Executive Officer.  May 10th is a day we hold in our hearts as we recognize Halyburton’s courage and sacrifice that his comrade may live.”

Throughout the day, Fitzpatrick read Halyburton’s Medal of Honor Citation over the clinic’s intercom system to staff and patients while staff read vignettes of his life and service.  

Marian Halyburton Rosse, Halyburton’s sister-in-law, transferred his Medal of Honor to the clinic during a ceremony held Friday, May 27, 2016.  The medal and numerous other artifacts showcasing Halyburton’s personal life and service continue to be displayed to all clinic visitors.
column9: CHERRY POINT，北卡罗来纳州，美国
column10: 哈利伯顿医疗卫生诊所在荣誉勋章行动76年后授予同名者荣誉
column11: 5月10日，星期一，在哈利伯顿医疗诊所服务的水手和工作人员暂停活动，以纪念该诊所的同名人员，他在76年前的第二次世界大战中为国家服务时牺牲了自己的生命。药剂师的助手二等兵威廉・哈利伯顿因其5月10日的行为在死后获得荣誉勋章，1945年，在二战冲绳战役中，担任海军陆战队第一师第五海军陆战队第二营的医务兵。在1994年10月1日举行的一次仪式上，他与诊所同名。诊所的执行官、海军上尉帕特里克・菲茨帕特里克（Patrick Fitzpatrick）说：“每天，哈利伯顿医疗诊所的水手和工作人员都在缅怀药剂师的助手二等兵威廉・哈利伯顿（William Halyburton Jr.）。5月10日是我们铭记在心的一天，因为我们认识到哈利伯顿的勇气和牺牲，他的同志可以活下去。”在这一天，菲茨帕特里克通过诊所的对讲机系统向医护人员和患者宣读了哈利伯顿的荣誉勋章，而医护人员则阅读了他的生活和服务的小插曲。2016年5月27日，星期五，在一个仪式上，哈里伯顿的嫂子玛丽安・哈里伯顿・罗斯将他的荣誉勋章移交给了诊所。展示哈利伯顿个人生活和服务的奖章和许多其他文物继续向所有诊所访客展示。

column2: Grissom Marines help return World War II Marine home after 76 years
column3:
From the shores of the Gilbert Islands to home in Marion, Indiana, Marine Private Fred Freet’s journey took 76 years. The the final stretch was aided by Marines from Grissom Air Reserve Base, Indiana.

A Marine Corps honor guard from Grissom participated in the dignified transfer of Marine Corps Pvt. Fred Freet, 18, of Marion, Indiana, at the Indianapolis International Airport April 16.

Freet was killed in action during World War II, and initially declared by the military as unrecoverable killed in action until Aug. 6, 2018 when the U.S. Navy positively identified his remains.

“From day one we teach Marines to never leave another Marine behind, so to be part of the process of returning him to his family after all these years is a huge honor,” said Capt. Pierce Virag, Detachment One, Communication Company, Combat Logistics Regiment 45, 4th Marine Logistics Group inspector instructor. “We hope that this will help bring closure to his family.

In November 1943, Freet was assigned to Company F, 2nd Battalion, 8th Marines, 2nd Marine Division, Fleet Marine Force, which landed against stiff Japanese resistance on the small island of Betio in the Tarawa Atoll of the Gilbert Islands, in an attempt to secure the island. Over several days of intense fighting, approximately 1,000 Sailors and Marines were killed and more than 2,000 were wounded, but the Japanese were virtually annihilated. Freet died on the first day of the battle, Nov. 20, 1943, during the first waves of the assault.

In the immediate aftermath of the fighting, U.S. service members who died in the battle were buried in a number of battlefield cemeteries on the island, but Freet’s remains were not identified.

In 2015, The Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency received a unilateral turnover from History Flight, Inc., a nongovernmental organization, of remains recovered on Betio Island. To identify Freet’s remains, scientists from DPAA used dental, anthropological and chest radiograph comparison analysis, as well as circumstantial and material evidence.

Attending the dignified transfer were several relatives of Freet, who came to show their support to their long lost relative who gave the ultimate sacrifice for his country.

“Before today he was just a picture on a mantle to us,” said Bill Freet, a nephew who was born several years after his uncle joined the Marines. “This feels like a huge victory for our family because for so many years no one knew what happened to him.”

“The military and community has been extremely supportive throughout the process and we are grateful,” he said. 

 “Grissom is so proud to play a part in this hero’s return,” said Col. Larry Shaw, 434th Air Refueling Wing commander. “The culture of military heritage and the bond that we have for those that served before us was on full display with our Marines taking care of one of their own.”

Freet will be buried at the Marion National Cemetery in Marion Indiana on April 18, a resting place for over 8,000 veterans.

Freet’s personnel profile can be viewed at https://dpaa.secure.force.com/dpaaProfile?id=a0Jt0000000XklQEAS

The 434th ARW is the largest KC-135R Stratotanker unit in the Air Force Reserve Command. The Citizen Airmen from the Hoosier Wing routinely deploy around the world in support of the Air Force mission.

Stay connected with the 434th ARW on Facebook and Twitter.
column6: GRISSOM AIR RESERVE BASE, IN, UNITED STATES
column9: 格里松空军储备基地，位于美国
column10: 格里松海军陆战队在76年后帮助二战海军陆战队重返家园
column11: 从吉尔伯特群岛海岸到印第安纳州马里恩的家，海军陆战队士兵弗雷德・弗里特的旅程耗时76年。最后一段由印第安纳州格里松空军储备基地的海军陆战队协助。格里松海军陆战队仪仗队于4月16日在印第安纳波利斯国际机场参加了印第安纳州马里恩市18岁海军陆战队列兵弗雷德・弗里特的庄严交接。弗里特在二战期间阵亡，在2018年8月6日前，美国海军积极确认了他的遗骸。皮尔斯・维拉格上尉说：“从第一天起，我们就教育海军陆战队永远不要丢下另一名海军陆战队士兵，因此，在这么多年后，能够参与将他送回家人的过程是一项巨大的荣誉。”，通信连一支队，作战后勤团45，第四海军陆战队后勤大队督察教员。“我们希望这将有助于关闭他的家庭。1943年11月，弗里特被分配到舰队海军陆战队第二海军陆战队第二师第八海军陆战队第二营F连，该连在吉尔伯特群岛塔拉瓦环礁的小贝蒂奥岛上抗击日军的顽强抵抗，试图保卫该岛经过几天激烈的战斗，大约有1000名水兵和海军陆战队士兵被杀，2000多人受伤，但日军几乎被歼灭。1943年11月20日，弗里特在战斗的第一天，即第一波进攻中死亡。战斗结束后，在战斗中死亡的美军士兵是布里在岛上的多个战场墓地中发现了一具尸体，但弗里特的遗体没有被确认。2015年，国防部战俘/米亚会计局收到了非政府组织History Flight，Inc.单方面移交的贝蒂奥岛上发现的遗体。为了确认弗里特的遗体，DPAA的科学家使用了牙科、人体测量学等方法医学和胸片对比分析，以及旁证和物证。参加这次庄严的转移的有弗里特的几位亲属，他们来支持他们失散已久的亲属，他们为国家做出了最大的牺牲。“在今天之前，他对我们来说只是披风上的一张照片。”比尔・弗里特（Bill Freet）是他叔叔加入海军陆战队几年后出生的侄子。他说：“这对我们的家庭来说是一个巨大的胜利，因为这么多年来，没有人知道他发生了什么事。”“军队和社区在整个过程中给予了极大的支持，我们对此表示感谢。”。第434空中加油联队指挥官拉里・肖（Larry Shaw）上校说：“格里松非常自豪能在这位英雄的归来中扮演一个角色。我们的海军陆战队正在照顾他们自己的一名士兵，这充分展示了我们的军事传统文化和我们与那些在我们之前服役的人之间的纽带。”弗里特将于4月18日被安葬在印第安纳州马里恩的马里恩国家公墓，这里是8000多名退伍军人的休息地。弗里特的个人资料可在https://dpaa.secure.force.com/dpaaProfile?id=a0Jt0000000XklQEASThe 434ARW是美国空军预备役司令部最大的KC-135R层流加油机部队Hoosier Wing定期部署在世界各地支持空军任务。在Facebook和Twitter上与第434次ARW保持联系。

column2: A 76-year-old man medevaced from charter fishing vessel off Georgetown coast
column3:
GEORGETOWN, S.C. C The Coast Guard medevaced a 76-year-old man with dangerously low blood pressure 44 miles east of Georgetown, Saturday.

Watchstanders at Coast Guard Sector Charleston received the initial report from the captain of the Continental Shelf, an 81-foot charter fishing vessel, at approximately 1:30 p.m., stating that a man aboard was experiencing temporarily lapses in consciousness.

An aircrew aboard an MH-65 Dolphin helicopter from Coast Guard Air Facility Charleston was diverted to assist. Upon arriving on scene, the crew hoisted the man and transported him to Grand Strand Medical Center in Myrtle Beach, S.C.
column9: 乔治敦，SC，美国
column10: 一名76岁男子从乔治敦海岸外的包租渔船上进行医疗后送
column11: 乔治敦，南卡罗来纳州――周六，海岸警卫队在乔治敦以东44英里处对一名76岁患有危险低血压的男子进行了医疗后送。海岸警卫队查尔斯顿区的值班人员在下午1:30左右收到了大陆架船长的初步报告，这是一艘81英尺长的包租渔船。，声明机上一名男子暂时失去知觉。从查尔斯顿海岸警卫队空军基地起飞的一架MH-65海豚直升机上的一名机组人员被转移协助。到达现场后，工作人员将该男子吊起，并将其送往南卡罗来纳州默特尔海滩的格兰德斯特兰德医疗中心。

column2: How a 76-year-old Vietnam Veteran was able to carry a fallen friend to the top of Hamburger Hill
column3:
In 1968, Spc. James Baylor was one month away from his 26th birthday when he received his call to duty on his front doorstep. 
“I have this ability to go numb when things like that happen,” said Baylor about his draft notification from the U.S. Army.  “I’ll say to myself, ‘Ok, that’s what it is,’ and I’ll go numb.”
Baylor attended basic training and advanced individual training at Fort Ord, California. Upon course completion the senior drill sergeant called a formation for the trainees to notify them of their duty assignments. “Private Johnson, Hawaii!” the drill sergeant exclaimed. At that moment Baylor became excited about the possibilities that lie ahead until the drill sergeant opened his mouth again and said, “Everyone else, pack your bags, you’re going to the Republic of Vietnam.”  Yet again, Baylor went numb. 
A few weeks after he received his orders, Baylor was on a commercial flight to war. 
“One thing I remember about that experience is that when we started out, the flight attendants were young and attractive, and as we got closer and closer, they got older and older,” Baylor laughs as he recalls his deployment process. “I remember flying into country, and two jet fighters approached on either side of our plane. I had never seen a jet fighter up close, and I remember thinking then, that was it, and we were coming into something heavy.” 
As Baylor disembarked the aircraft, he passed veterans who were headed home. He distinctly remembers the battle hardened Soldiers looking at the inbound Soldiers and saying “There’s one, there’s one.” There’s one what? He thought. 
“These guys had obviously been through something; you could tell by their faces, they were hard,” Baylor recalls. 
Later, he found out they were pointing out the Soldiers they perceived would not make it home from Vietnam alive. 
When Baylor made it to in-processing to receive his assignment, he learned he was heading to the 101st Airborne Division. Baylor recalls his reaction thinking, “Hey, hey wait a minute, I’m not even Airborne.” 
The personnel officer quickly replied that he was ‘airborne now’ and to lace his boots tight. 
While in the rear echelon, Baylor met another Soldier who was headed to the 101st Airborne Division, Private Ralph Crutts, a 21-year-old college student who joined the military for college benefits to finish his degree. 
“I was 26 and Crutts was 21. I think he looked up to me because I was older and from Los Angeles. He thought I was rough and tough or something, that I was going to protect him,” said Baylor. 
Baylor and Crutts became extremely close during their time in Vietnam together as they were assigned to the same platoon in Charlie Company, 3rd Battalion, 187th Infantry Regiment. Baylor describes Crutts as vigilant, always listening for enemy movement and ready to protect them. So vigilant that Baylor would often times read a book while their platoon was stationary because he knew he could count on his best friend to look out for them both. 
“He was very alert and always looking to see what was going on,” said Baylor. “I would relax a little bit, truly read a book in the boonies because I knew Crutts was always watching.”
As time passed, the 3rd Battalion, 187th Infantry Regiment was tasked with clearing the A Shau Valley, particularly hill 937, or Dong Ap Bia. On May 10, 1969, the battalion was dropped on the landing zone at the base of the hill. Each company moved out to their assigned axis of advance and Charlie Company moved further and further onto the base of the hill. 
While navigating the steep jungle terrain of the A Shau Valley and passing over the first moments of what would eventually culminate in a grueling 11 day battle, Baylor took guidance and direction from his platoon leader Lt. Joel Tautmann.
“We didn’t take any contact the first few days of the battle,” said Trautmann, the platoon leader for 1st Platoon, Charlie Company in an interview with the West Point Center for Oral History. “We could hear contact over the radio from the other companies, but the jungle was too thick to hear the fighting.” 
It wasn’t until the 14th of May that 1st Platoon was tasked with linking up with the company headquarters to reinforce 2nd and 3rd platoon, who were charging the hill. 
“When I reached Charlie Company’s position, 2nd and 3rd Platoons were both pinned down,” said Trautmann.  “I asked my commander for guidance, for a task and purpose, but he did not respond. He couldn’t even look me in the eye C mentally, he was gone.” 
Trautmann moved forward on the line to gain perspective on the situation. When he turned around, the commander was nowhere to be found. In the middle of a battle, the commander left the company for the night defensive position. 
“At that moment the weight of the world was on my shoulders,” Trautmann recalls. 
After taking heavy fire, Trautmann immediately organized all three platoons to lay down suppressive fire and retrieve their casualties. Baylor was tasked with recovering the wounded and killed in action. 
“I couldn’t recognize them,” said Baylor, “except for one man who wore a wrist watch on both arms. Their faces were completely gone. That memory would haunt me forever.” 
After being demoralized, Charlie Company reconsolidated and was tasked to secure the battalion command post for the next three days. On the 18th of May, the men of 1st Platoon would yet again face another test of courage. 
Delta Company was currently pinned down in active engagement. Trautmann was tasked to put together a squad-sized element to maneuver on the west flank to draw enemy fire and allow Delta Company to retrograde. When Trautmann told his men of the upcoming mission, they were apprehensive to say the least. 
“Hell no, we will not go. This mission is suicide,” said Trautmann, explaining his Soldiers’ emotional response. 
Knowing the state of morale of the platoon Trautmann knew of only one thing to do. 
“I didn’t know if they would follow me or not, but I grabbed my rifle and my pack and I walked right through my men and said ‘Follow me,’” Trautmann recalls. 
Eight men picked themselves up and followed the lieutenant, two of whom were Baylor and his best friend, Crutts. They approached the edge of the foliage that led to a vast opening of dirt without cover or concealment, and they charged. As they assaulted up the hill, they opened fire, and within moments one of the men yelled out, “Crutts is hit!” 
Baylor, with his eyes toward the enemy, then saw Trautmann take a bullet to the femur and drop. Concerned for his friend, Baylor turned around and grabbed Crutts and held him in his arms. 
“Are you ok? Crutts are you with me?” recalled Baylor. 
By then he was already gone, and while Baylor was holding Crutts, kneeling low, a round penetrated his side and Baylor went down. 
“If I wasn’t kneeling with Crutts, if I was standing, the round would have hit my spine. Crutts saved my life,” said Baylor. 
Baylor was evacuated off the hill without ever making it to the top.
These memories would stay buried deep in Baylor’s memory for the rest of his life, and as he grew older, his curiosity for the top of Hamburger Hill grew. 
“I’ve always envied those who have made it to the top,” he said.  “What was that like? When I heard members of the battalion were making a trip back to Vietnam with veterans, it was a no brainer for me.” 
Baylor summited Hamburger Hill at 76 years old. 

How vision became a reality for veteran Rakkasans 
This is just one of Baylor’s war stories, and many veteran’s stories would be lost or untold if it weren’t for guardians of history and heritage who facilitate opportunities for communion and reconciliation. That is exactly what Lt. Col. Martin Bowling facilitated during his command of the 3rd Battalion, 187th Infantry Regiment, Iron Rakkasans. 
“The Iron Rakkasans have a heritage, legacy, and reputation of being the most aggressive battalion, which always accomplishes the mission, and never backs down from a challenge,” said Bowling. “Those that have come before us earned that reputation in blood, sweat, and tears, and it is our duty to honor them for their sacrifices, and recognize them for their valor.”
During his two years in command, the month of May became a special month to reunite with the Rakkasans of Korea, Vietnam, Desert Storm, Afghanistan, and Iraq to pay tribute and honor them, especially the veterans of the famous, Battle of Hamburger Hill. Veterans across the country conduct reunions each year. The “Hamburger Hill Vets” reunite in the same location, Fort Campbell, Kentucky, home of the 101st Airborne Division. They do this to stay consistent in the hope that more veterans from the battle will hear of these reunions and stay connected to today’s generation of Rakkasan.
In May of 2019, current Rakkasan Soldiers honored the veterans of the Battle of Hamburger Hill, to include Spc. James Baylor, by returning to that hallowed battlefield in the A Shau Valley for on the battle’s 50th anniversary. 
It all started with a commander’s vision. Upon taking command in 2017, Bowling announced his first two priorities. The first, to build the most lethal platoons in the 101st Airborne Division who are ready to deploy, fight, and win in the most austere environments at any time. Second, to significantly enhance the relationships between currently serving and previous generations of Iron Rakkasans, Army veterans, and community leaders. 
It just turned out that his command window landed on the 49th and 50th anniversaries of the Battle of Hamburger Hill. However, the events that would occur in the next two years were much more deliberate than the timing of his career. 
From May 10 to May 20 1969, the men of the 3rd Battalion, 187th Infantry Regiment would assault up a massive hill in the A Shau Valley of Vietnam known as Dong Ap Bia or “the Crouching Beast.” Then, Lt. Col. Weldon Honeycutt would command these brave Soldiers through the most trying times of their lives. The 11-day battle resulted in 70 percent of the formation wounded or killed in action while imparting 600 killed in action on the enemy. 
In a war that some would rather forget, and memories that are most times too hard to face, how do we honor such men who were called to make the ultimate sacrifice? Bowling’s answer was simple. 
“We will bring them in, execute a physical challenge that represents the sacrifices they made, wrap our arms around them, and welcome them home,” said Bowling. “Oh yeah, and we’re going to take them back to Vietnam.” 
On the 50th Anniversary of the Battle of Hamburger Hill, hundreds of Screaming Eagle Soldiers and local citizens welcomed home 87 Hamburger Hill veterans for the first time at Fort Campbell. The next day, nine veterans and 11 Soldiers boarded an aircraft and flew to Da Nang Airport, for a five-day journey recounting the steps they took exactly 50 years earlier. 
“I’m proud of myself for being able to hike up that mountain at 76,” said Baylor. “And while I was hiking, I said a little prayer. I told Crutts I was going to make it to the top of the hill for both of us, that I was determined! Even if I had to crawl, I was going to get to the top. And we did, we made it to the top of the hill together.”
column9: 美国田纳西州
column10: 一位76岁的越战老兵是如何将一位倒下的朋友抬到汉堡包山的山顶的
column11: 1968年，Spc.詹姆斯・贝勒在离他26岁生日还有一个月的时候接到了在前门台阶上值勤的电话。贝勒在谈到美国陆军的征兵通知时说：“当这种情况发生时，我有能力变得麻木。”。“我会对自己说，‘好吧，就是这样，’然后我会变得麻木。”贝勒在加利福尼亚州的福特参加了基础训练和高级个人训练。课程结束后，高级军士长召集学员列队通知他们的任务。“二等兵约翰逊，夏威夷！”教官惊叫道。就在那一刻，贝勒对未来的可能性感到兴奋，直到训练中士再次张开嘴说：“其他人，收拾好行李，你要去越南共和国。”贝勒再次变得麻木。贝勒接到命令几周后，他乘坐商业航班前往战场。贝勒回忆起自己的部署过程时笑着说：“我记得那次经历的一件事是，我们刚开始时，空乘人员年轻而有魅力，随着我们越来越近，他们也越来越老了。”。“我记得我飞到这个国家，两架喷气式战斗机从我们飞机的两侧飞过来。我从来没有近距离看到过喷气式战斗机，我记得当时在想，就是这样，我们遇到了一件很重的事情。”贝勒下飞机时，经过了正在回家的退伍军人。他清楚地记得那些身经百战的士兵看着入境的士兵说：“有一个，有一个。”有一个什么？他想。贝勒回忆道：“这些人显然经历了一些事情；从他们的脸上可以看出，他们很坚强。”。后来，他发现他们指出，他们所看到的士兵不会活着从越南回来。当贝勒到达处理中心接受任务时，他得知自己正前往101空降师。贝勒回忆起当时的反应：“嘿，嘿，等一下，我甚至还没有空降。”人事官员很快回答说他“现在空降了”，并系紧了靴子。在后方梯队时，贝勒遇到了另一名前往101空降师的士兵，二等兵拉尔夫・克鲁茨（Ralph Crutts），他是一名21岁的大学生，为了大学福利参军完成学业。贝勒说：“我当时26岁，克鲁茨21岁。我想他之所以尊敬我，是因为我年纪大了，而且来自洛杉矶。他认为我粗鲁、强硬，或者其他什么，我会保护他。”。贝勒和克鲁茨在越战期间非常亲密，因为他们被分配到第187步兵团第3营查理连的同一排。贝勒形容克鲁特机警，总是倾听敌人的动向，随时准备保护他们。贝勒非常警觉，经常在他们的排停着的时候读一本书，因为他知道他可以依靠他最好的朋友来照顾他们。贝勒说：“他非常警觉，总是想看看发生了什么。”。“我会放松一点，在乡下读一本书，因为我知道克鲁茨一直在看。”随着时间的推移，第187步兵团第3营的任务是清理阿绍山谷，特别是937山，或称东阿比亚。1969年5月10日，该营降落在山脚的登陆区。每个连队都向指定的前进轴移动，查理连队向山脚移动得越来越远。当贝勒在阿绍山谷陡峭的丛林地带航行，经过最终将在一场艰苦的11天战斗中达到高潮的最初时刻时，他接受了排长乔尔・陶特曼中尉的指导和指示。“我们在战斗的最初几天并没有取得任何联系，”特劳特曼说，查理连第一排的排长在接受西点军校口述历史中心采访时说。“我们可以通过无线电听到其他连队的联系，但丛林太厚，听不到战斗声。”直到5月14日，第一排才接到与连队总部联系的任务，以增援正在冲锋的第二排和第三排。“当我到达查理连的位置时，第二排和第三排都被牵制住了，”特罗特曼说。“为了一项任务和目的，我向我的指挥官寻求指导，但他没有回应。他甚至不能直视我的眼睛――精神上，他已经走了。”特劳特曼继续前行，以了解形势。当他转过身来时，指挥官已无处可寻。在战斗中，指挥官离开了公司进行夜间防御工作。“当时，世界的重担压在我的肩上，”特劳特曼回忆道。在遭受猛烈炮击后，特劳特曼立即组织所有三个排放下压制火力，取回伤亡人员。贝勒的任务是抢救行动中受伤和死亡的人。“我认不出他们，”贝勒说，“除了一个两臂都戴着手表的人。他们的脸完全消失了。那种记忆将永远萦绕在我的心头。”在士气低落后，查理连重新团结起来，并被派去在接下来的三天里保卫营指挥所。5月18日，第一排的士兵将再次面临勇气的考验。德尔塔公司目前正在积极参与。特劳特曼的任务是组建一个小队大小的分队，在西侧机动，吸引敌人火力，并允许三角洲连逆行。当特罗特曼告诉他的部下即将进行的任务时，他们至少有点担心。“不，我们不会去。这次任务是自杀，”特劳特曼解释士兵们的情绪反应说。了解排的士气状况，特劳特曼只知道一件事要做。“我不知道他们是否会跟着我，但我抓起我的步枪和背包，径直穿过我的士兵说‘跟着我’，”特劳特曼回忆道。八个人站起来，跟着中尉，其中两人是贝勒和他最好的朋友克鲁茨。他们走近树叶的边缘，这导致了一个巨大的没有遮盖或隐藏的泥土开口，他们冲锋。当他们向山上发起进攻时，他们开火了，不一会儿，其中一名男子大声喊道：“克鲁兹中弹了！”贝勒眼睛盯着敌人，然后看到特劳特曼的股骨中了一颗子弹，然后倒下了。出于对朋友的关心，贝勒转过身，抓住克鲁特，将他搂在怀里。“你还好吗？克鲁特，你和我在一起吗？”贝勒回忆道。这时他已经走了，贝勒正抱着拐杖跪着，一颗子弹穿透了他的身体，贝勒倒了下去。贝勒说：“如果我不是用拐杖跪着，如果我站着，子弹就会击中我的脊柱。拐杖救了我的命。”。贝勒没有登上山顶就被疏散了。这些记忆将在贝勒的余生中深深地埋藏在他的记忆中，随着年龄的增长，他对汉堡包山顶的好奇心也在增长。“我一直羡慕那些登上顶峰的人，”他说。“那是什么样子的？当我听说营里的人正和老兵们一起回越南旅行时，这对我来说是一件轻而易举的事。”贝勒在76岁的时候对汉堡包山说。这只是贝勒战争故事中的一个，如果没有历史和遗产的守护者为交流与和解提供机会，许多退伍军人的故事将会丢失或不为人知。这正是马丁・鲍林中校在指挥第187步兵团第3营铁拉卡桑时所促成的。保林说：“铁拉卡桑人有着作为最具侵略性的营的传统、遗产和声誉，他们总是完成任务，从不放弃挑战。”。“那些在我们面前的人以鲜血、汗水和眼泪赢得了这一声誉，我们有责任对他们的牺牲表示敬意，并表彰他们的英勇。”在他执政的两年中，5月成为一个特殊的月份，与朝鲜、越南、沙漠风暴、阿富汗的Rakkasans人团聚，伊拉克向他们致敬，特别是著名的汉堡山战役的老兵。全国各地的退伍军人每年都会举行团聚。“汉堡包山兽医”在肯塔基州坎贝尔堡的同一地点团聚，这里是101空降师的所在地。他们这样做是为了保持一致，希望更多的退伍军人能够听到这些团聚，并与今天的拉卡山一代保持联系。2019年5月，现任拉卡山士兵向汉堡山战役的退伍军人致敬，其中包括Spc.詹姆斯・贝勒，在战争50周年之际，回到阿绍山谷的神圣战场。这一切都是从指挥官的远见开始的。2017年担任指挥职务后，保龄球宣布了他的前两个优先事项。第一，在101空降师建立最具杀伤力的排，他们随时准备在最严峻的环境中部署、作战并获胜。第二，显著加强现役和前几代铁人、退伍军人和社区领袖之间的关系。事实证明，他的指挥窗口是在汉堡包山战役49和50周年纪念日登陆的。然而，未来两年发生的事件比他职业生涯的时间安排要深思熟虑得多。1969年5月10日至5月20日，第187步兵团第3营的士兵将向越南阿绍河谷的一座巨大山丘发起进攻，这座山丘被称为“东阿彼亚”或“蹲着的野兽”。随后，韦尔登・霍尼卡特中校将指挥这些勇敢的士兵度过他们一生中最艰难的时期。在11天的战斗中，70%的编队在战斗中受伤或死亡，600人在战斗中阵亡。在战争中

column2: Coast Guard Cutter Sherman returns home from Bering Sea, final deployment
column3:
HONOLULU ― The crew of Coast Guard Cutter Sherman (WHEC 720) returned home Tuesday after a 76-day patrol in the Bering Sea.

This homecoming was the last time Sherman will return from deployment as the crew prepares to decommission the ship in March, after nearly 50 years of meritorious service.

During the three-month patrol, the crew supported the safe transit of a disabled vessel over 800 miles to Dutch Harbor, enforced fisheries regulations in the Bering Sea and the Gulf of Alaska. They also provided a command and control platform capable of embarking a helicopter, thus providing search and rescue coverage to those operating in the Bering Sea.

Sherman has a storied history including being the last active remaining U.S. warship in the Coast Guard or Navy to have sunk an enemy vessel. It is also one of only two cutters to hold the Vietnam Service Award and the only cutter to hold the Combat Action Ribbon for action in the Vietnam War.

In 2001, it became one of the few cutters to circumnavigate the world, after conducting U.N. sanctions enforcement duty in the Persian Gulf and goodwill projects in Madagascar, South Africa and Cape Verde.

Adding to Sherman’s history, in March of 2007, a boarding team dispatched from the cutter discovered 17 metric tons of cocaine on the Panamanian-flagged freighter, Gatun. This seizure remains the largest drug bust in U.S. history with an estimated street value of $600 million. As the record holder, Sherman proudly wears the Golden Snowflake.

The crew rounded out the cutter’s storied career in the Bering Sea; conducting 16 fisheries boardings, issuing four fisheries violations and one safety violation, ensuring the integrity of the $6 billion fishing industry. As the primary search and rescue asset in the region at the time, Sherman also ensured the safe transit of the crew of the Resolve Pioneer, a Dutch Harbor-based ocean-going tug, following a severe casualty at the far end of the Aleutian chain, restricting their speed and maneuverability.

“As Sherman and her crew return home from this final patrol, it is humbling to look back on the history and the accomplishments of this crew and the previous,” said Capt. Steve Wittrock, commanding officer of Sherman. “This final patrol has been significant in that the Bering Sea mission is one of the most demanding and historically important in the Coast Guard and I am very proud of the way that the crew has performed throughout the last two challenging months.”

Sherman is one of the Coast Guard’s four remaining 378-foot high endurance cutters still in operation. The 1960s era fleet of cutters is presently being replaced by the national security cutters, which will soon serve as the Coast Guard's primary, long-range asset. Honolulu will serve as a homeport to two of the national security cutters, replacing Sherman and the already decommissioned Morgenthau.
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: 海岸警卫队切割机谢尔曼从白令海返回家园，最终部署
column11: 檀香山-海岸警卫队“谢尔曼”号航母（WHEC 720）的船员周二在白令海进行了76天的巡逻后返回家园。这次返乡是谢尔曼号航母在服役近50年后准备于3月份退役时最后一次返回家园。在为期三个月的巡逻中，船员们支持一艘残疾船只在800英里外安全通过荷兰港口，在白令海和阿拉斯加湾执行渔业条例。他们还提供了一个能够登上直升机的指挥和控制平台，从而为在白令海作业的人员提供搜索和救援。谢尔曼有着悠久的历史，包括作为海岸警卫队或海军中最后一艘击沉敌舰的现役美国军舰。它也是唯一两个获得越战服务奖的切割机之一，也是唯一一个在越战中获得战斗行动丝带的切割机。2001年，它在波斯湾执行联合国制裁执行任务和在马达加斯加执行友好项目后，成为为数不多的环球航行切割机之一，除了谢尔曼的历史，2007年3月，卡特号派出的一个登机队在悬挂巴拿马国旗的货轮“加顿”上发现了17公吨可卡因。这次缉获的毒品仍然是美国历史上最大的一次缉毒行动，估计街头价值6亿美元。作为纪录保持者，谢尔曼自豪地佩戴着金色雪花。船员们在白令海圆满结束了这位切割者传奇般的职业生涯；进行了16次渔业登船，发布了4次渔业违规和1次安全违规，确保了60亿美元渔业的完整性。作为当时该地区的主要搜救资产，谢尔曼还确保了位于荷兰港口的远洋拖船“Resolve Pioneer”的船员安全通过，因为阿留申链远端发生了严重伤亡，限制了他们的速度和机动性。谢尔曼的指挥官史蒂夫・威特罗克上尉说：“当谢尔曼和她的船员们结束最后一次巡逻回家时，回顾他们的历史和成就是一件令人谦卑的事。”。“这次最后的巡逻意义重大，因为白令海任务是海岸警卫队中要求最高、历史上最重要的任务之一，我对船员在过去两个充满挑战的月中的表现感到非常自豪。”谢尔曼是海岸警卫队剩余的四艘仍在使用的378英尺高耐久性切割机之一。1960年代的切割机舰队目前正被国家安全切割机所取代，这将很快成为海岸警卫队的主要远程资产。火奴鲁鲁将作为两艘国家安全切割机（replac）的母港ing谢尔曼和已经退役的摩根索。

column2: Reflections, Respect on Clinic Namesake
column3:
Navy Hospital Corpsman 2nd Class David R. Ray would have been 76 years old this year.  

The Congressional Medal of Honor recipient (posthumously) and namesake of Navy Medicine Readiness and Training Unit (NMRTU) Everett was killed in action - a lifetime ago - for his actions at Phu Loc 6 near An Hoa in Quang Nam Province, Republic of Vietnam, on March 19, 1969. 

Gone but never forgotten. 

From that fateful day 52 years ago, the legacy of the man is embodied by staff at NMRTU Everett, located within the David R. Ray Branch Medical Clinic, caring for eligible beneficiaries in the greater Naval Station Everett area.

For hospital corpsman stationed at the clinic, there is symbolic significance following in such hallowed footsteps.

“I find it very significant to work anywhere named after someone who came before. There is a lot of pride knowing you represent someone who made the highest sacrifice for our country, and seeing their picture and citation every day as you walk in,” said Hospital Corpsman 2nd Class Emilio Alejandro Lugo, a Poulsbo, Washington native who has been assigned to the clinic for two of his eight years in the Navy. 

 “It is very significant to work within a facility named after a hospital corpsman who’s a Medal of Honor recipient, as it sets the highest standard while wearing the cloth of our nation and assisting those in need of healthcare,” added Hospital Corpsman 3rd Class Crystal Jeanette Zamora, from Douglas, Arizona, who has been stationed at the clinic for three of her four years in the Navy.

The high regard that the clinic Sailors have for Ray has even become a mobile form of respect, venturing far beyond the clinic. The command’s guidon has become an emblematic source of pride and esprit de corps for staff members, especially during the ongoing pandemic and helping to stop the spread of COVID-19. Through rain and snow, in urban and rural backdrops, at work and off duty, clinic corpsmen have carried and displayed the guidon.

“The outings with the guidon enable us to show these incredible characteristics off with great pride, honor, and commitment that will encourage us to carry on such a legacy,” exclaimed Zamora. “This sentiment is significant and noteworthy in a way that demonstrates the bravery, selflessness, and act of heroism shown by HM2 David R. Ray.”

Chief Hospital Corpsman Sam Hutcheson affirms that NMRTU Everett Sailors taking the David R. Ray guidon on various outings is a notable way to show HM2 Ray’s memory is still alive. 

“I am really blessed to be surrounded by so many talented and motivated Sailors. The level of creativity that went into the preparation and execution of demonstrating the pride and admiration that we have for David R. Ray was next level. To be able to get out into our surrounding areas, through various weather conditions and take a moment to reflect on his sacrifices, is the very least we could do for a hero who gave the ultimate sacrifice for his country and his comrades in arms. His legacy lives on through these sailors. They take tremendous pride in knowing that,” stressed Hutcheson, from Gainesville, Florida, who has been at the clinic for three of his 23 active duty years.

“It shows the value in honoring the legacies of those who have gone before. Going out with the guidon is significantly better than just a cake or something because we aren’t just getting something out of it. We’re going out in what many people consider less than ideal weather while upholding Navy core values to show a commitment to honor,” Lugo said, readily acknowledging that the Navy Hospital Corps rate is known for putting service before self, and that very notion C exemplified by David R Ray C is inspirational.

“I chose this rate because of that legacy,” continued Lugo. “When people ask what it is I do in the Navy, I love being able to say I’m a corpsman. Every veteran knows what a corpsman is, what we do, and the legacies that we are willing to live up to. That legacy is also a great motivational tool that require us to put in a bit more work. We’re the most decorated rate in the Navy for a reason.” 

Zamora attests the legacy of service before self inspires her. 

“It motivates me to do everything in my power to assist those in need and assist my fellow Sailors around me. I’m inspired to be selfless and always caring as HM2 David R. Ray was. I hope these characteristics are passed on, and have such an effect and purpose on future hospital corpsmen,” said Zamora. 

As a senior enlisted leader, Hutcheson candidly states that putting service before self has been the standard since the inception of the Navy Hospital Corps, with Ray the epitome of that trait.

“Read his citation of action and try not getting motivated, I dare you. Everything is about perspective. When you think you’re having a rough day, just thinking about being under enemy fire and still going from parapet to parapet tending to wounded Marines while being injured, helps bring everything into focus,” explained Hutcheson. 

When asked how would you respond to someone with no real knowledge about the Navy who is curious enough to ask, ‘who was HM2 David R. Ray,’ Lugo replied,  “Beyond a Medal of Honor recipient, he was a kid from Tennessee who died putting the welfare of the Marines under his charge ahead of his own. Because of him, someone else’s son was able to come home from the jungles of Vietnam during a time when military service wasn’t voluntary. Neither of them may have wanted to be there, and both of them could have potentially died out there, but because of HM2 Ray’s sacrifice, at least one of them came back. Now, he inspires future generations of hospital corpsmen to uphold that same level of fidelity during the most difficult of times.”

Asked the same question, Zamora answered, “the hospital corpsman rate is one of the most honorable and decorated rates in the United States Navy. David R. Ray resembles the exact reason for this, as he risked his life beyond the call of duty, rendering aid to his Marines and portraying acts of heroism by sacrificing his own life for a patient, all while being wounded himself. It is this legacy and inspiration that make being a hospital corpsman so honorable, rewarding, and selfless.” 

“For conspicuous gallantry and intrepidity at the risk of his life above and beyond the call of duty while serving as a HM2 with Battery D, 2d Battalion, at Phu Loc 6, near An Hoa. During the early morning hours, an estimated battalion-sized enemy force launched a determined assault against the battery's position, and succeeded in effecting a penetration of the barbed-wire perimeter. The initial burst of enemy fire caused numerous casualties among the marines who had immediately manned their howitzers during the rocket and mortar attack. Undaunted by the intense hostile fire, HM2 Ray moved from parapet to parapet, rendering emergency medical treatment to the wounded. Although seriously wounded himself while administering first aid to a marine casualty, he refused medical aid and continued his lifesaving efforts. While he was bandaging and attempting to comfort another wounded marine, HM2 Ray was forced to battle two enemy soldiers who attacked his position, personally killing one and wounding the other. Rapidly losing his strength as a result of his severe wounds, he nonetheless managed to move through the hail of enemy fire to other casualties. Once again, he was faced with the intense fire of oncoming enemy troops and, despite the grave personal danger and insurmountable odds, succeeded in treating the wounded and holding off the enemy until he ran out of ammunition, at which time he sustained fatal wounds.
