column11: 加利福尼亚州彭德尔顿海军陆战队大本营――“别害怕尝试，”海军陆战队第一师第三突击两栖营排长莫莉・科曼上士宣称。“有了21个地区的导师研讨会计划，所有人都受到欢迎。这是一个向不同级别的海军陆战队学习的绝佳机会；学习如何成为更好的领导者，以便我们能够塑造他人，超越我们对海军陆战队未来的期望。”突击两栖动物学校营后勤官托尼・威廉姆斯上尉（AAS Bn），训练司令部，于今年6月创建了21区导师研讨会计划。研讨会每两个月在Del Mar Beach Resort举行一次，向任何有基地访问权的人开放。该计划的使命是鼓励领导者通过在精神、情感、身体和精神上相互提升，努力实现最佳自我。Ove本次研讨会为领导者在不断变化的环境中可能面临的一些独特挑战做好准备。本课程向参与者介绍各种培训、观点和资源，向领导者展示如何提高他们在日常生活和职业生涯中与同事和同事合作的技能威廉姆斯说：“我的意图是从内到外工作，因为有太多不同类型的领导者。我真的想为人们创造一个空间，让他们作为领导者开始或继续锻炼（精神）肌肉。”21区导师研讨会计划旨在团结海军陆战队、水手和各行各业的平民，无论是个人还是专业人士，在彭德尔顿MCB营地。鼓励他们相互工作和学习，以获得实现目标的新视角。该计划还侧重于不同类型的精神，以创造强大的团队自我意识。研讨会通常从一个叫做“人类结”的小组活动开始它促进团队合作和沟通，然后立即进行团队讨论。参与者随后进行瑜伽，由威廉姆斯和海军陆战队社区服务部的瑜伽教练安娜・帕卡姆（Anna Packham）带领。瑜伽后，参与者有一小时的午餐时间和关于营养的讨论。下一个活动称为“完美循环”旨在加强领导技能，然后再进行一次小组讨论。训练司令部AAS Bn突击两栖车辆技术员Pfc.Cameron McCain感叹道：“瑜伽是我的最爱。”。“瑜伽出人意料地难。有些人比其他人好，但我认为这是课程的一部分。不是每个人都是平等的，但我们都必须竭尽全力。”威廉姆斯说，精神健康的工作让她对自己的目标有了清晰的了解。这反过来又会与她的海军陆战队建立更好的关系，她能够理解并尊重每个人都是独一无二的。“你会听到这样一句话，我们必须始终成为一名全面发展的海军陆战队，”科曼说。“大多数时候，这被误解为我们必须在[战斗体能测试]中获得300分，成为射程专家，并获得[专业军事教育]完成。你还需要实践你的核心信念和价值观。作为一个个体，拥有这些积木很重要，这样当你开始工作并且必须领导他人时，你就可以做好准备，因为你已经采取了这些步骤。”欲了解更多关于21区导师研讨会计划的信息或注册查询，请发送电子邮件至tonie的Williams上尉。williams@usmc.mil或者莫莉的科曼上士。koman@usmc.mil.

column2: 82nd ADSB Paratroopers prepare for Air Assault school
column3:
FORT BRAGG, N.C. C As the brisk morning air nips at his fingers, Pvt. Jon-Luk Cole fights to keep his grasp on the rope as he pulls himself up reaching the top of the obstacle.
	Cole and fellow Paratroopers from the 82nd Airborne Division Sustainment Brigade and Fort Bragg battled with the chilly air as they negotiated their way through the Air Assault obstacle course on Fort Bragg, N.C., January 4, 2017.
	“The course was more challenging than I thought,” said Cole, a parachute rigger assigned to the 151st Division Aerial Delivery Company, 189th Combat Sustainment Support Battalion.  “It showed me what I need to work on before going to Air Assault.”
	More than 120 Paratroopers and Soldiers traversed the course with the intent of completing a prerequisite to attend an upcoming Air Assault class on Fort Bragg.
	The DeGlopper Air Assault School hosted this prerequisite training as a way for Fort Bragg units to certify Paratroopers and Soldiers on the course.
	“Attending our monthly obstacle course is not a requirement for entry into Air Assault,” said Sgt. 1st Class Joshua Bronson, Air Assault Chief Instructor.  “Soldiers must have their commanders state they are able to complete the course prior to enrollment.  We host the course monthly to allow units on [Global Response Force] or smaller units who cannot certify their Soldiers themselves due to circumstances.”
	The school graduates approximately 1,000 Soldiers and Paratroopers per year from the Air Assault course.  Air Assault instills confidence in service members to use rotary wing assets to accomplish the mission.
	The DeGlopper Air Assault School offers Air Assault, Rappel master and Fast Rope Insertion and Extraction System master courses since opening in 2014.
	“We update our courses and doctrine to meet the needs of commanders,” Bronson said.  “It’s important to maintain skill sets we haven’t used in the past few years and possibly use in the future.”
column9: 美国北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡
column10: 美国陆军部第82空降兵准备空袭学校
column11: 布拉格堡，北卡罗来纳州――清晨清新的空气刺痛了他的手指，副官长乔恩・卢克・科尔奋力抓住绳子，奋力爬上障碍物的顶端。2017年1月4日，科尔和来自第82空降师维持旅和布拉格堡的伞兵同伴在北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡的空中突击障碍物路线上进行了艰苦的战斗。“这门课比我想象的更具挑战性，”分配到第189战斗维持支援营第151师空投连的伞兵科尔说，“它向我展示了在进行空袭之前需要做的工作。”120多名伞兵和士兵通过了这门课程，目的是完成参加即将在布拉格堡举行的空袭课程的先决条件。德格洛普空袭学校主办了这门先决条件培训，作为布拉格堡部队认证课程上伞兵和士兵的一种方式。“参加我们每月的障碍课程并不是进入空袭的必要条件，”空袭首席教练、一等兵Joshua Bronson中士说。“士兵必须让指挥官在报名前说明他们能够完成课程。我们每月举办课程，让部队参加[全球反应部队]或因情况原因无法证明其士兵身份的较小单位。”该校每年约有1000名士兵和伞兵从空中突击课程毕业。空中突击培养了服役人员使用旋转翼资产完成任务的信心。自开放以来，DeGlopper空中突击学校提供了空中突击、Rappel master和快速绳索插入和拔出系统master课程布朗森说：“我们更新了课程和条令，以满足指挥官的需要。保持过去几年没有使用过的技能组合，并可能在未来使用，这一点很重要。”

column2: Single Marines keep each other strong
column3:
MARINE CORPS BASE CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. C Many Marines enlist looking for adventure, a chance to travel and experience things they never could have from home. Unfortunately for some Marines, those adventures just aren’t in the budget.

Since 1995, the Single Marine Program has been giving Marines and Sailors the opportunity to participate in trips and events, such as weekends in San Francisco or Las Vegas, at reduced prices. They also provide places to relax and unwind with fellow service members at facilities across the country.

“If you’re happy and stable then it’s going to allow you to work better,” said Travis Zeller, the manager of the Camp Del Mar SMP Recreation Center. 

Even with Department of Defense budget constraints, Marines can be confident that the SMP will continue offering an ever-growing range of activities and opportunities.

“The Single Marine Program is looked at as health and wellness because it supports mental strength,” said Zeller, a native of Temecula. “The commandant has always looked at the program as crucial for the wellness of Marines.”

Many young Marines who are away from their home, family and friends for the first time can feel a sense of loneliness. According to Cpl. Ashton Haymore, a food service specialist with Combat Service Support Company, I Marine Expeditionary Force Headquarters Group, some of the greatest tools to help Marines are Marines.

“I’ve run into quite a few Marines who are depressed,” said Haymore, a native of Woodbridge, Virginia, who is temporarily assigned to work at an SMP recreation center. “Some Marines only have someone to talk to because they come here and socialize. People who aren’t even in my office come up and talk to me about personal things because they know they can trust me.”

Haymore said she wishes she had gotten involved with the program earlier in her career. She explained that it is consistently a relaxing place for Marines to process the pressures and stress in their lives.

In addition to a number of recreational activities, including musical instruments, pool tables, top of the line video game systems, and hundreds of movies, the SMP provides places for Marines to make connections.
“We always respect each other, but to build that camaraderie between the ranks, getting together and enjoying time off is what’s really important,” said Haymore.
 
Information seems to be the biggest obstacle preventing Marines from participating in trips and events or visiting recreation centers, said Zeller. He explained that there seems to be a problem communicating what is available to the Marines who need it.

“There are guys who have lived in the barracks next to our building for years and don’t know what we do,” said Zeller. “We just want people to know that we’re here and we have lots of opportunities to have fun and relax.”

Zeller said the most rewarding part of working for the SMP is seeing the difference it makes for Marines and Sailors who are thousands of miles from home. 

Keeping Marines’ minds healthy and focused makes them more resilient and prepared to face unknown challenges around the world.
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州彭德尔顿营地
column10: 单身的海军陆战队保持彼此强大
column11: 加利福尼亚州彭德尔顿海军陆战队大本营――许多海军陆战队士兵参军是为了寻找冒险，一个旅行和体验他们在家中永远无法拥有的东西的机会。不幸的是，对于一些海军陆战队来说，这些冒险并不在预算之内。自从1995以来，单一的海军项目给海军陆战队和水手们提供了参加旅行和活动的机会，比如在旧金山或拉斯维加斯的周末，价格降低了。他们还提供了与全国各地的服务人员一起放松和放松的场所。“如果你感到快乐和稳定，那么这将让你工作得更好，”Camp Del Mar SMP娱乐中心经理特拉维斯・泽勒（Travis Zeller）说。即使国防部预算有限，海军陆战队也有信心SMP将继续提供越来越多的活动和机会。“单一海军陆战队计划被视为健康和健康，因为它支持精神力量，”特梅库拉本地人泽勒说。“指挥官一直认为这个项目对海军陆战队的健康至关重要。”许多年轻的海军陆战队士兵第一次离家、家人和朋友都会感到孤独。据我海军陆战队远征军总部战斗服务支持公司的食品服务专家阿什顿・海莫尔下士说，帮助海军陆战队的一些最伟大的工具是海军陆战队。“我遇到过不少情绪低落的海军陆战队士兵，”海莫尔说，他是弗吉尼亚州伍德布里奇的一名土生土长的人，临时分配到SMP娱乐中心工作的人员。海莫尔说：“有些海军陆战队员来这里参加社交活动，所以只有一个人可以和他们交谈。甚至不在我办公室的人都会过来跟我谈一些私人事情，因为他们知道他们可以信任我。”她希望自己在职业生涯的早期就参与到这个项目中来。她解释说，对于海军陆战队来说，这里一直是一个放松的地方，可以让他们处理生活中的压力。除了一些娱乐活动，包括乐器、台球桌、顶级视频游戏系统和数百部电影，SMP还为海军陆战队提供了建立联系的场所。“我们总是互相尊重，但要在队伍之间建立友谊，聚在一起享受假期才是真正重要的。”海莫尔说。泽勒说，信息似乎是阻止海军陆战队参加旅行和活动或参观娱乐中心的最大障碍。他解释说，向需要信息的海军陆战队传达可用信息似乎存在问题。泽勒说：“有些人在我们大楼旁边的兵营里住了很多年，他们不知道我们在干什么。我们只是想让人们知道我们在这里，我们有很多机会去娱乐和放松。”泽勒说，为SMP工作最有意义的部分是看到它为海军陆战队和离家数千英里的海军陆战队带来的不同。保持海军陆战队的头脑健康和专注，使他们更有弹性，并为应对世界各地未知的挑战做好准备。

column2: All American Week 2016 Prayer Breakfast
column3:
82nd Airborne Division Paratroopers and veterans attended the 82nd Abn. Div. All American Prayer Breakfast during All American Week 2016 on Fort Bragg, N.C., May 24.
	All American Week is an opportunity for 82nd Abn. Div. Paratroopers, past and present, and their Families to come together, enjoy camaraderie and celebrate being members of the All American Division.  This year's All American Week theme is "Tomorrow's Force, Today!"
	Past and present Paratroopers in attendance listened to life lessons and advice from Chaplain (Col. Ret.) Alvin “Sonny” Moore III, a past 82nd Abn. Div. chaplain and guest speaker for the event.
	Moore explained three aspects that have guided him, such as a smile goes a long way, the power of relationships, and teamwork.  He used amusing anecdotes to explain each aspect, eliciting smiles and agreement from those in attendance.
	This year’s All American Week marks the 99th anniversary of the 82nd Airborne Division.
column9: 美国北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡
column10: 2016全美周祈祷早餐
column11: 第82空降师伞兵和老兵参加了第82届Abn。2016年5月24日在北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡举行的“全美周”期间的“全美祈祷早餐”节目。第82届荷兰银行将有机会参加“全美周”。师伞兵，过去和现在，和他们的家人走到一起，享受同志情谊，庆祝成为全美师的成员。今年的全美伞兵周主题是“明天的部队，今天！”过去和现在的伞兵在现场听取了牧师阿尔文・桑尼・摩尔三世的生活课程和建议。阿尔文・桑尼・摩尔三世曾是荷兰第82任牧师。本次活动的副牧师兼嘉宾演讲者。摩尔解释了引导他前进的三个方面，比如微笑，人际关系的力量和团队合作。他用有趣的轶事来解释每一个方面，引起了在场人员的微笑和赞同。今年的全美航空周标志着第82空降师成立99周年。

column2: Paratroopers work together during Best Squad Competition
column3:
Paratroopers from across the 82nd Airborne Division relied on teamwork and tactical expertise to overcome the challenges of the Best Squad Competition during All American Week 2016 on Fort Bragg, N.C., May 23.
	The competition integrated scenarios the Paratroopers might encounter in a combat environment with an obstacle course.
	Each squad was comprised of nine Paratroopers working as a team to complete the obstacle course, disassemble and reassemble various weapons, recover a disabled vehicle, treat a casualty and fire their weapons under stress.
	The tasks were designed to test each Paratrooper’s mental and physical stamina and endurance.
	All American Week is an opportunity for 82nd Airborne Paratroopers, past and present, and their Families to come together, enjoy camaraderie and celebrate being members of the All American Division. This year's All American Week theme is "Tomorrow's Force, Today."
column9: 美国北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡
column10: 伞兵在最佳阵容比赛中齐心协力
column11: 来自第82空降师的伞兵依靠团队合作和战术专业知识，在北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡举行的2016全美周最佳阵容比赛中战胜了挑战。，5月23日。比赛综合了伞兵在有障碍路线的作战环境中可能遇到的场景。每个班由九名伞兵组成，作为一个团队完成障碍路线，拆卸和重新组装各种武器，回收一辆残废车辆，治疗伤员并在压力下发射武器。这些任务旨在测试每位伞兵的身心耐力和耐力。整个美国周都是第82名空降伞兵、过去和现在以及他们的家人团聚的机会，享受同志情谊，庆祝成为全美分部的成员。今年的全美周主题是“明天的力量，今天”

column2: 82nd ADSB welcomes 151st DAD
column3:
FORT BRAGG, N.C. C The 82nd Airborne Division Sustainment Brigade welcomed the newest unit, the 151st Division Aerial Delivery Company, to the 82nd Airborne Division during a ceremony here, October 21, 2016.
	The company’s projected size of approximately 200 Paratroopers will increase the Division’s capability to air drop more equipment to the warfighter.
	"The activation today of the 151 DAD clearly demonstrates the Army's commitment to the readiness and training of the 82d Airborne Division as it maintains its ability to fight tonight as part of our XVIII Corps' Global Readiness Force mission,” said Col. Gavin Gardner, 82nd ADSB Commander.
	The 151st DAD assumes responsibility of the Brigade’s heavy drop and air items maintenance mission.
	“The company will increase the Division’s capability of dropping 400,000 lbs. per day to 500,000 lbs.,” said Capt. Colton Crawford, 151st DAD Commander.  “We split from the 11th Quartermaster Company to better optimize the productivity between the parachute pack shed, air items maintenance and aerial delivery”
	The new Rigger company will essentially double the brigade's ability to rapidly prepare equipment and supplies for aerial delivery.
        An additional Platoon of Riggers was created in the 11th QM enabling the 82nd ADSB to pack more than 10,000 individual parachutes a month for the division.
	“It is a tremendous honor to be the inaugural commander starting the history of the unit,” Crawford said.  “The amount of trust from the Rigger motto ‘I will be sure always’ put into every piece of equipment packed and dropped is exciting to be a part of.”
column9: 美国北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡
column10: 第82届ADSB欢迎第151届爸爸
column11: 布拉格堡，北卡罗来纳州――10月21日，在这里举行的仪式上，第82空降师维持旅欢迎最新的部队151师空投连来到第82空降师，2016年，该公司预计的大约200名伞兵规模将提高该师向作战人员空投更多装备的能力。加文・加德纳上校说：“151 DAD今天的启用清楚地表明了陆军对82 D空降师的准备和训练的承诺，因为作为我们第十八军团全球准备部队任务的一部分，该师保持了今晚作战的能力。”，第82位ADSB指挥官。第151位DAD指挥官负责该旅的重型空投和空中物品维修任务。第151位DAD指挥官科尔顿・克劳福德上尉说：“该连将提高该师每天空投40万磅至50万磅的能力。”。“我们从第11军需官连中分离出来，以更好地优化降落伞包棚、空中物品维护和空中交付之间的生产力。”新的索具公司将使该旅快速准备空中交付设备和物资的能力增加一倍。在第11次QM中，增加了一个装配工排，使第82 ADSB能够每月为该师打包10000多个单独的降落伞。“作为开创该部队历史的首任指挥官，我感到无比荣幸，”克劳福德说。“索具装配工的座右铭‘我将确保永远’对每一件打包和丢弃的设备都充满了信任，成为其中的一员令人兴奋。”

column2: Love is a battlefield- Marines prepare to take on marriage
column3:
MARINE CORPS BASE CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. C The Marine Corps is often referred to as the nation’s 9-1-1 force because they are ready to take on any challenge at a moment’s notice. This readiness includes not only weapons and equipment proficiency, but also stability on the homefront.

Cmdr. James Johnson, the chaplain for I Marine Expeditionary Force Headquarters Group, presented pre-marital training at Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton, Jan. 26, 2016.

The class was the second of three in the Intimate Relationship Awareness, Training, and Enrichment Program. The first section, “How to succeed at intimate relationships,” focused on being aware of intimate relationships and how they evolve over time. The second class, “Before saying I do,” prepares couples who have already decided to tie the knot for some of the challenges they might face and puts the idea of marriage into perspective.

“We want to get these young Marines to be fully aware of what an intimate relationship is and how to embrace and engage all levels of that relationship,” said Johnson, a Lake Park, Minnesota, native.

The presentation included the results of a survey conducted by Loma Linda University showing the need for the Marine Corps to take action to prepare their Marines. According to the study, young Marines are getting married and divorced at three times the rate of civilians the same age. 

“Marines were overestimating their readiness to get married and underestimating the challenges of being married,” said Johnson.

According to Johnson, the high divorce rates keep Marines emotional and distracted, which detracted from the readiness within their unit. The iRelate pre-marital training reduces the risk of divorce by ensuring that Marines understand themselves, their partner, and have the tools to overcome challenges they might face in their relationship.

A large portion of the class was dedicated to understanding some common obstacles to effective communication.

“I learned a lot about the ways men and women think differently,” said Sgt. Joselyn Alvarez, the assistant warehouse chief for Assault Amphibian School Supply, School of Infantry C West.

Alvarez, from Palmdale, said the class made her think about her emotions and communicating what she really feels instead of just her frustration.

“Anger can cover sadness and fear,” said Alvarez. “It makes a lot of sense when you think back to when you were mad, but maybe you were just covering another emotion with anger.”

Her fiancé, Brandon Keifer, from Assumption, Illinois, said that he’s caught himself doing just that on a few occasions.

“I’ve gotten upset with her before out of fear for her safety,” said Keifer. “I didn’t articulate myself well enough for her to understand why I was upset.”
Alvarez and Keifer met in Russia through the Marine Embassy Security Guard program. Their wedding is scheduled for July and they have been seeking out different forms of pre-marital preparation by reading and speaking with a chaplain.

They agreed that their research brought them a deeper understanding of what marriage is and a more solemn perspective of the commitment that they are making.

“Marriage is not something you should just do on a whim; you need to plan and think about what is going to happen,” said Alvarez. “You have to be mentally prepared, mature, and understand what you’re doing isn’t just moving in. Marriage is an allegiance.”

During the training, Johnson exposed the myth of “Hollywood love” where true love means never having any problems and feeling more in love every day. He also stressed the importance of patience, effort, and commitment through good times and bad.

“There is a tendency to think that a good marriage happens automatically and you either have one or you don’t,” said Johnson. “No Marine bases a deployment on hope; they base it on preparation, readiness, and full engagement of what it means to take on the challenges in front of them.”

Johnson stressed the proven benefits of pre-marital counseling, through iRelate or any other program, to reduce the risk of divorce and help Marines have more fulfilling marriages.

“It’s wonderful that the Marine Corps is keeping faith by offering programs like iRelate,” said Johnson. “If things are good on the homefront they go much better [while] deployed.”

In addition to combat training and job skills, the Marine Corps offers countless programs to prepare Marines for deployment in every part of their lives so they can be focused and ready C mind, body and spirit.
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州彭德尔顿营地
column10: 爱情是战场――海军陆战队准备接受婚姻
column11: 加利福尼亚州彭德尔顿海军陆战队大本营――海军陆战队经常被称为美国的9-1-1部队，因为他们随时准备迎接任何挑战。这种准备状态不仅包括武器和装备熟练程度，还包括homefront.Cmdr的稳定性。2016年1月26日，I海军陆战队远征军总部集团牧师詹姆斯・约翰逊在彭德尔顿海军陆战队大本营进行婚前培训。该课程是亲密关系意识、培训和充实计划三个课程中的第二个。第一部分“如何成功建立亲密关系”，重点关注亲密关系以及它们如何随时间演变。第二节课，“在说“我愿意”之前，“为已经决定结婚的夫妇做好准备，迎接他们可能面临的一些挑战，并把婚姻的想法放在正确的角度。“我们想让这些年轻的海军陆战队队员充分意识到什么是亲密关系，以及如何拥抱和参与这种关系的各个层面。”来自明尼苏达州湖泊公园的约翰逊说。报告中包括了洛马琳达大学进行的一项调查的结果，该调查显示海军陆战队需要采取行动，为海军陆战队做好准备。根据这项研究，年轻的海军陆战队士兵结婚和离婚的比率是同龄平民的三倍。约翰逊说：“海军陆战队士兵高估了他们结婚的准备程度，低估了结婚的挑战。”约翰逊说，高离婚率让海军陆战队士兵情绪激动、心烦意乱，这降低了他们部队的准备程度。iRelate婚前培训通过确保海军陆战队士兵了解他们自己、他们的伴侣，并拥有克服他们在关系中可能面临的挑战的工具来降低离婚风险。课程的大部分内容致力于了解有效沟通的一些常见障碍。“我学到了很多关于男人和女人不同思维方式的知识，”西步兵学校突击两栖动物学校补给副仓库主任Joselyn Alvarez中士说。Palmdale的Alvarez说，这门课让她思考自己的情绪，交流自己的真实感受，而不仅仅是沮丧。“愤怒可以掩盖悲伤和恐惧，”阿尔瓦雷斯说。“当你回想起你发疯的时候，这很有意义，但也许你只是用愤怒掩盖了另一种情绪。”她的未婚夫布兰登・基弗（Brandon Keifer）来自伊利诺伊州的埃博顿（Association），她说他自己也曾在一些场合这样做过。“我以前因为担心她的安全而对她感到不安，”基弗说，“我没有很好地表达自己，让她理解我为什么不安。”阿尔瓦雷斯和基弗通过海军陆战队大使馆保安计划在俄罗斯会面。他们的婚礼定于7月举行，他们一直在通过阅读和与牧师交谈来寻找不同形式的婚前准备。他们一致认为，他们的研究使他们对婚姻有了更深入的理解，也使他们有了更严肃的视角阿尔瓦雷斯说：“婚姻不是你一时兴起就应该做的事情；你需要计划和思考将要发生的事情。你必须做好心理准备，成熟，明白你所做的不仅仅是搬进来。婚姻是一种忠诚。”在训练期间，约翰逊揭露了“好莱坞之爱”的神话，即真爱意味着永远不会有任何问题，每天都能感受到更多的爱。他还强调了耐心、努力和承诺的重要性，无论是好时光还是坏时光。约翰逊说：“有一种倾向认为，美满的婚姻是自然而然发生的，你要么有，要么没有。没有一个海军陆战队的部署是建立在希望的基础上的；他们的部署是建立在准备、准备和充分参与的基础上的，这意味着要接受他们面前的挑战。”约翰逊强调，通过iRelate或任何其他计划，婚前咨询已被证明有助于降低离婚风险，帮助海军陆战队拥有更美满的婚姻。“海军陆战队通过提供类似iRelate的计划来保持信心，这真是太好了，”约翰逊说。除了战斗训练和工作技能外，海军陆战队还提供了无数项目，让海军陆战队在生活的各个方面做好部署准备，以便他们能够集中精力，做好心理、身体和精神上的准备。

column2: Love is a battlefield- Marines train to combat divorce
column3:
CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. - The Marine Corps is known for finding ways to overcome any challenge, but not every fight is on the battlefield.

Navy Lieutenant Cmdr. Aaron Kleinman, the chaplain for Assault Amphibian School Battalion, School of Infantry C West, presented a program succeeding at intimate relationships as part of the iRelate program, Jan. 12.

The iRelate program, which focuses on jumior enlisted, is made up of three different classes designed to help Marines make informed decisions whether they are already married, currently engaged, or are preparing for future relationships.

“iRelate was originally developed by Chaplain Michael Foskett as part of his thesis,” said Kleinman, a native of Norfolk, Virginia. “It is now a Loma Linda University PhD study being sponsored by I Marine Expeditionary Force.”

According to Kleinman, Marines can lose up to 90 work days while going through a divorce as well as emotional and physical health consequences. This stress can severely impact the combat readiness of a Marine, and in turn, the readiness of the unit.

The classes focused on intimate relationship awareness and used facts and statistics to disprove myths about marriage and long-term relationships.

“The most common misconception about marriage is that love is all you need,” said Kleinman. “People, especially junior Marines, go into marriage looking at it from a perspective of what they are going to get from it rather than what they are going to have to put in to make it work.”

Sergeant Danielle Auld, an ammunition technician with I MEF Logistics Office, said that the training did a good job of breaking down the information to show how relationships progress based on the effort and perspective of the people involved.

“They showed how all marriages aren’t going to be great all the time, you have to work for it,” said Auld from Cedar Rapids, Iowa. “You have to find yourself and be the person that the person you want to find is looking for.”

Countless books and classes are available to prepare couples for the ups and downs of long-term relationships, but iRelate gives unique insight into marriage for Marines.

“It’s the first marriage program that’s been developed from the ground up by Marines for Marines,” said Kleinman. “Most of the data that’s drawn for the iRelate presentation comes from a study of I MEF Marines.”

According to Kleinman, Loma Linda University is monitoring the program to provide accurate measurements of its long-term effectiveness, but that it really comes down to each individual who attends the classes.

“The real impact comes from whether a young Marine is willing to take on some of what they have learned and actually make a change,” said Kleinman. 

The other classes in the series are pre-marital training and marriage enrichment, which provide hands-on assistance to Marines and their spouses, not just for mental and emotional preparation, but filing official paperwork and command involvement.

The relationship awareness training the second Tuesday of every month and the marital trainings the fourth Tuesday of every month encourage healthier relationships, decrease divorce rates, and improve unit readiness.
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州彭德尔顿营地
column10: 爱情是战场――海军陆战队训练对抗离婚
column11: 彭德尔顿营地，加利福尼亚州――海军陆战队以找到克服任何挑战的方法而闻名，但并非每一场战斗都是在战场上进行的。海军少校艾伦・克莱曼（Aaron Kleinman）是西部步兵学校突击两栖动物学校营的牧师，他提出了一项成功建立亲密关系的计划，作为iRelate计划的一部分，1月12日。iRelate计划以jumior入伍为重点，由三个不同的课程组成，旨在帮助海军陆战队做出明智的决定，无论他们是否已经结婚、是否正在订婚或是否正在为未来的关系做准备。“iRelate最初由牧师Michael Foskett开发，作为其论文的一部分，”Kleinman说，弗吉尼亚州诺福克人。“现在这是洛马琳达大学的一项博士研究，由I海军陆战队远征军赞助。”克莱曼说，海军陆战队在经历离婚以及身心健康后果时，可能会损失多达90个工作日。这种压力会严重影响海军陆战队的战备状态，进而影响部队的战备状态。这些课程侧重于亲密关系意识，并利用事实和统计数据来反驳关于婚姻和长期关系的神话。“对婚姻最常见的误解是爱就是你所需要的一切，”克莱曼说。“人们，尤其是海军陆战队的年轻人，结婚时都是从他们将从中得到什么的角度来看待它，而不是从他们必须投入什么才能使它发挥作用的角度来看待它。”I MEF后勤办公室的弹药技术员Danielle Auld中士，艾奥瓦州锡达拉皮兹市的奥尔德说，培训很好地分解了信息，展示了关系是如何根据相关人员的努力和观点进展的。“他们展示了并非所有的婚姻都是美好的，你必须为此而努力。”。“你必须找到自己，成为你想找到的人正在寻找的人。”无数的书籍和课程都可以让情侣们为长期关系的起伏做好准备，但iRelate为海军陆战队提供了独特的婚姻观。“这是海军陆战队为海军陆战队开发的第一个婚姻计划，”克莱曼说，“iRelate报告中的大部分数据来自于对I-MEF海军陆战队的研究。”根据克莱曼的说法，洛马琳达大学正在监控该计划，以提供对其长期有效性的准确测量，但这实际上取决于每个上课的人。“真正的影响来自于一名年轻的海军陆战队队员是否愿意接受他们所学的一些知识并真正做出改变。”克莱曼说。该系列的其他课程是婚前培训和婚姻充实课程，为海军陆战队及其配偶提供实际帮助，不仅是心理和情绪准备，还包括提交正式文件和指挥参与。每个月的第二个星期二将进行关系意识培训，并对婚姻状况进行评估每个月的第四个星期二进行培训，鼓励建立更健康的人际关系，降低离婚率，提高部队的准备状态。

column2: Setting an example
column3:
WHITECLOUD, Mich. -- More than one million and counting, is how many COVID-19 tests the state of Michigan has done in the last few months, after the first known cases were identified in the beginning of March.
Many of the tests have been performed by medics with the Michigan National Guard, who have gone into prisons and nursing homes to administer the tests to the most vulnerable. Now they are conducting it on Michiganders who want the peace of mind of knowing if they have it or not. 
“We are doing community-based testing for COVID-19 in partnership with District Health Department #10 and the Army National Guard, and serving the folks here in Newago County,” said George Davis, a clinical supervisor with District Health Department #10. “We know that this virus has a very scary fatality rate for people innocently living their lives, and we want to prevent the spread,” said Davis.
A spread that is ravaging the rest of the country, but has slowed down in Michigan. By testing as many as possible, the state health community would like to see it slowed down even more. District Health Department #10 did its part by helping conduct community testing and by having themselves tested as well. 
“We want to set an example that screening is an important part of health and community,” said Davis. “If we are recommending our community to do something, we are going to do it, too.”
Many had heard the test could hurt and were scared to do it, but were there encouraging each other to get it done, because as essential workers they know it is important for them to stay healthy. 
“We can provide information and encouragement after going through it ourselves,” said Kate Gilley, a community health worker for District Health Department #10. “It’s one more way we can advocate and support people. There is anxiety about doing the test and now having gone through it, it’s not nearly as bad as I had thought it to be.”
Gilley is out there most days helping those in her community get the resources they need to get through this pandemic. Whether this is helping to link them up to the resources or dropping food off in a safe way to their house, she feels fortunate to be helping. 
 “I felt my job was even more important, and I’ve seen communities coming together to help people and that’s been amazing,” said Gilley.
Helping the community is what the Michigan National Guard medics are doing. They have been performing thousands of tests on civilians, to help everyone reclaim their lives.  
“I think everybody’s on the same page and has the same common goal in mind,” said Spc. Derek Conaway. “I don’t think I would have ever pictured myself in a full set of personal protective equipment testing people for a virus, but we do what we have to do.”
Conaway, who is with Assembly Area Lugnuts, joined the National Guard to help his community and state, and has had the best experiences of his life all while helping others.
 “There’s nothing better I don’t think, especially in times like now, when we get to be there and help each other out,” said Conaway. “Being there for your community and everyone at home, it’s a really good feeling.”
By having the test done on themselves by National Guard medics, the community health workers are proving that part of helping is partnering. (Story by Michigan Army National Guard Staff Sgt. Tegan Kucera)
column9: 美国密苏里州白云
column10: 以身作则
column11: 密歇根州怀特克劳德市――在3月初发现第一例已知病例后，密歇根州在过去几个月内进行了100多万次新冠病毒-19检测。许多检测是由密歇根州国民警卫队的医务人员进行的，他们进入监狱和疗养院为最弱势群体进行测试。现在，他们正在对米奇甘德人进行调查，他们想知道自己是否拥有这种武器，从而获得内心的平静。“我们正在与地区卫生部和陆军国民警卫队合作，进行以社区为基础的新冠病毒-19检测，并为纽瓦戈县的居民服务，”地区卫生部10的临床主管乔治・戴维斯说。戴维斯说：“我们知道这种病毒对无辜生活的人有着非常可怕的致死率，我们希望阻止这种传播。”这种传播正在肆虐美国其他地区，但在密歇根州已经放缓。通过尽可能多的测试，州卫生界希望看到它进一步放缓。地区卫生部（District Health Department#10）尽了自己的一份力量，帮助开展社区测试，并对自己进行了测试。戴维斯说：“我们想树立一个榜样，证明筛查是健康和社区的重要组成部分。”。“如果我们建议我们的社区做些什么，我们也会去做。”许多人听说测试可能会带来伤害，并害怕这样做，但他们互相鼓励去做，因为作为重要的工作者，他们知道保持健康对他们很重要。地区卫生部的社区卫生工作者凯特・吉利（Kate Gilley）说：“我们可以在亲自经历之后提供信息和鼓励。”。“这是我们可以倡导和支持人们的另一种方式。人们对做这项测试感到焦虑，而现在已经通过了测试，它还没有我想象的那么糟糕。”吉莉大部分时间都在那里帮助社区中的人们获得度过这场流行病所需的资源。无论这是帮助他们与资源联系起来，还是以安全的方式把食物送到他们家，她都感到很幸运能够提供帮助。吉利说：“我觉得我的工作更重要，我看到社区团结起来帮助人们，这真是太棒了。”帮助社区就是密歇根州国民警卫队的医务人员正在做的事情。他们对平民进行了数千次测试，以帮助每个人恢复生命。“我认为每个人都站在同一页上，心中都有着相同的目标，”Spc.德里克・康纳威说。“我不认为我会想象自己穿着一整套个人防护装备测试人们的病毒，但我们做我们必须做的事情。”Conaway是聚集区Lugnuts的成员，他加入国民警卫队帮助他的社区和州，并在帮助他人的同时获得了他一生中最美好的经历。康纳威说：“我认为没有什么比这更好的了，尤其是在现在这样的时候，当我们来到那里，互相帮助的时候。”。“为你的社区和家里的每个人服务，感觉真的很好。”通过让国民警卫队的医生对自己进行测试，社区卫生工作者证明了帮助的一部分是合作。（密歇根州陆军国民警卫队参谋特甘・库塞拉上士的故事）

column2: Flying high- II MEF Marines participate in air show
column3:
MARINE CORPS AIR STATION BEAUFORT, S.C. - Marines with various units with II Marine Expeditionary Force participated in an air show hosted by Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort, South Carolina, to showcase the capabilities of the Marine Corps aboard the air station April 10 C 12, 2015.

The air show consisted of static displays, aircraft from different military branches and food vendors for those in attendance to enjoy during the show. Marines with various units brought static displays of their own for the show, including: 2nd Battalion, 2nd Marine Regiment; 1st Battalion, 10th Marine Regiment; 2nd Assault Amphibian Battalion; 2nd Light Armored Reconnaissance Battalion and 2nd Intelligence Battalion.

Some of the Marines participated in a demonstration for the attendees of the air show to exhibit the capabilities of a Marine Air-Ground Task Force.

“The MAGTF demo was a [Tactical Recovery of Aircraft and Personnel] scenario,” said Maj. Jeremy Siegel, the Personnel Support Detachment company commander for Marine Aircraft Group 31. “We were assigned to demonstrate a downed pilot, and then the Marine TRAP team was put in place to rescue that downed pilot.” 

Many of the same aircraft used in the MAGTF demonstration were on display to the public along the flight-line.

“We are showcasing the CH-53E Super Stallion to the public so they can see what Marine heavy lift is all about,” said Capt. David Harris, the operations and scheduling officer with Marine Heavy Helicopter Squadron 464, Marine Aircraft Group 29. “It’s an integral piece of the MAGTF, and heavy lift is essential to the Marines on the ground and that’s what we are here for - to support the infantry. We carry food, troops, cargo, mail, parts, bullets - you name it.”

The Marines who participated in the MAGTF demonstration were proud of their performance and enjoyed showing those who attended the air show the capabilities of their aircraft and their pilots’ abilities.

“There are civilian air shows that don’t have this kind of exposure of military aircraft and military [operations],” Harris said. “These air shows are the only opportunity that the public has to see what their tax money is doing for them and how essential the Marine Corps and the armed services are to national security.”
column6: MARINE CORPS AIR STATION BEAUFORT, SC, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国南卡罗来纳州波弗特海军陆战队航空站
column10: 飞高-II MEF海军陆战队参加航展
column11: 南卡罗来纳州波弗特海军陆战队航空站――海军陆战队与第二海军陆战队远征军各部队参加了由南卡罗来纳州波弗特海军陆战队航空站主办的航展，以展示海军陆战队在航空站上的能力。航展包括静态显示，来自不同军种和食品供应商的飞机，供观众在展会期间享用。海军陆战队和不同的部队带来了他们自己的静态显示器，包括：第二营，第二海军陆战队团；海军陆战队第十团第一营；第二突击两栖营；第二轻装甲侦察营和第二情报营。一些海军陆战队成员参加了一次展示海军陆战队空地特遣部队能力的演示。杰里米・西格尔少校说：“MAGTF演示是一个[飞机和人员的战术恢复]场景。”，海军陆战队31组人员保障支队连指挥官。“我们被派去演示一名被击落的飞行员，然后海上捕鲸队被派去营救那名被击落的飞行员。”MAGTF演示中使用的许多飞机在飞行线上向公众展示。“我们正在向公众展示CH-53E超级种马，这样他们就可以了解海上重型起重是什么，”海军陆战队29飞机组464海军陆战队重型直升机中队的作战和调度官戴维・哈里斯上尉说。“它是MAGTF不可分割的一部分，重型起重对地面上的海军陆战队至关重要，这就是我们在这里的目的――支持步兵。我们运送食物、军队、货物、邮件、零件、子弹――你可以说得通。”参加MAGTF演示的海军陆战队为他们的表现感到自豪，并乐于向参加航展的人展示他们飞机的性能和飞行员的能力。“有一些民用航展没有这种军用飞机和军事行动的曝光，”哈里斯说。“这些航展是公众唯一的机会，让他们了解他们的税收为他们做了什么，以及海军陆战队和武装部队对国家安全的重要性。”

column2: Fort Campbell medics test their expertise
column3:
FORT CAMPBELL, Ky -- Service members of the 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault), tested their knowledge, patience, strength and endurance as they sought to earn the Expert Field Medical Badge, from June 5 through June 22.
The EFMB is a special skill badge that was established in 1965. It is earned through an annual qualification event and is awarded to military personnel who successfully complete a set of tests including performance based exercises that test medical knowledge and proficiency. 
“It’s not an easy badge to get statistically,” said Sgt. 1st Class Matthew Vecchione, medical platoon sergeant, 2nd Battalion, 506th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault). “That’s why people want to come out here and get the badge because it’s a mark of excellence.”
Soldiers participated in various challenging events such as a comprehensive written exam, three Combat Testing Lanes, day and night land navigation, and a 12-mile road march. Soldiers had to complete these tasks with little to no error to receive a passing grade on each event.
The EFMB testing is a completely voluntary event and is not a requirement for the medical field. In 2013 the attrition rate for obtaining the EFMB was 19%, making it one of the most prestigious and difficult special skill badges to be earned.
“We usually expect 10 to 20% to pass,” said 1st Lt. Taylor Allen, the officer in charge of CTL1 at the EFMB testing course.
The candidates received training at their home unit, then arrive at the EFMB testing course. The testing phase is five days but the candidates spent two weeks at the course getting familiar with the CTL’s, conducted study halls, and observed the cadre go through the lanes to see how to properly maneuver the course.
According to Vecchione, you definitely have to want it. There’s people out here who have tried multiple times to get their EFMB. 
This training event challenges soldiers in medical tasks, Chemical, Biological, Radioactive and Nuclear tasks and evacuation tasks, said Allen. It gives home units an idea if their medics are equipped for anything that the enemy can throw at them.
“To me it shows that I am proficient at memorizing things and putting my mind to the test,” said Spc. Tyler Miller, medic, 1st Battalion, 32nd Cavalry Regiment, 1st Brigade Combat Team. “I was very excited when I found out that I was going to be able to come.”
Out of 107 candidates that started the EFMB testing, only 18 were honored to receive the coveted EFMB. Not only does this show how difficult it can be to obtain the EFMB, but it gives other soldiers an idea of what to expect as they train and prepare to take on the grueling challenge of the EFMB test course.
                                                             - 30 -
column9: 坎贝尔堡，肯塔基州，美国
column10: 坎贝尔堡的医生测试他们的专业技能
column11: 肯塔基州坎贝尔堡――第101空降师（空袭）的服役人员，在6月5日至6月22日期间，为了获得专家级野战医疗徽章，他们测试了自己的知识、耐心、力量和耐力。EFMB是1965年建立的一种特殊技能徽章。它是通过年度资格赛获得的，授予成功完成一系列测试的军事人员，包括测试医学知识和熟练程度的基于性能的演习。“从统计上来说，这不是一个容易获得的徽章，”101空降师第三旅第506步兵团第二营医疗排中士马修・维奇奥尼中士（Matthew Vecchione）说。“这就是为什么人们想来到这里并获得徽章，因为它是一种优秀的标志。”士兵们参加了各种具有挑战性的活动，如综合笔试、三条作战测试车道、昼夜陆地导航和12英里的公路行军。士兵们必须在几乎没有错误的情况下完成这些任务，才能在每个项目上获得及格分数。EFMB测试是完全自愿的，不是医疗领域的要求。2013年，获得EFMB的自然减员率为19%，这使其成为获得的最具声望和难度的特殊技能徽章之一。EFMB测试课程CTL1负责人第一中尉泰勒・艾伦（Taylor Allen）说：“我们通常期望通过10%到20%。”候选人在其所在单位接受了培训，然后到达EFMB测试课程。测试阶段为五天，但考生花了两周时间在课程上熟悉CTL，开设学习大厅，观察干部穿过车道，看如何正确操作课程。根据Vecchione的说法，你肯定需要它。有人在这里谁已经尝试过多次，以获得他们的EFMB。艾伦说，这项训练活动在医疗任务、化学、生物、放射性和核任务以及撤离任务方面对士兵提出挑战。它让部队了解他们的医疗兵是否装备有敌人可以向他们投掷的任何东西。“对我来说，这表明我在记忆东西和集中精力进行测试方面非常熟练，”第一旅战斗队第32骑兵团第1营医疗兵泰勒・米勒说。“当我发现自己能够参加EFMB考试时，我非常激动。”在107名参加EFMB考试的考生中，只有18人获得了令人垂涎的EFMB。这不仅表明获得EFMB有多么困难，而且也让其他士兵了解了他们在训练和准备迎接EFMB测试课程的艰巨挑战时的期望30 -

column2: MEET YOUR GUARD- SPC. BRION HOUSTON
column3:
Name: SPC Brion Houston
Military Specialty: 15P, Aviation Operations Specialist 
Years of Service: 10 years
Unit: Charlie Company, 3rd Battalion, 126th Aviation Regiment (Air Ambulance)
Hometown: St. Albans, Vt.
Current Town: Fairfax, Vt.
High School/Graduation Year: Graduated 2008 from BFA St. Albans 

Q. Why did you join the National Guard?
A. I joined the National Guard because it became a family tradition. My grandfather, my great-uncle, my uncle, my aunt, my father, my mother, my older sister, and I joined and then my younger brother joined. So it became a family tradition. 

Q. What do you do in the Vermont National Guard?
A. I’m an aviation operations specialist. Essentially we are a lot of the admin for aviation operations. We do a lot of the flight logs, we do weather, and flight planning, that’s one of the biggest, flight planning. We receive their missions, and we also stay in radio contact with the aircraft. We are like their admin and the dispatch for aviation. 

Q. Is this your first deployment?
A. It is my second deployment. My mom and I deployed together in 2009 to Bagram, Afghanistan. 

Q. How do you train and prepare for deployment?
A. Each drill and each AT (annual training) prepares us and each year is also a different cycle in a crawl-walk-run phase. 

Q. What drew you to aviation and medevac? 
A. What drew me to aviation is that I wanted to change my career and I became stagnant where I was and I wanted something that was more advanced, and more exciting and the aviation field was what I wanted. Being a state police dispatcher, the 15P series was the equivalent as far as operations. More hands on operations and more importantly the mission itself, for medevac requests in the battlefield, and they need operations to help things run smoothly. 

Q. What do you do for civilian work?
A. I am a 911 operator and state police dispatcher for the Vermont State Police. 

Q. What do you think is the greatest benefit of being in the National Guard?
A. I think one of the greatest benefits of the National Guard is their benefits for college and education. Also, the other benefits are staying in shape, the Guard helps maintain your physical fitness. 

Q. How long have you lived in Vermont?
A. I have lived in Vermont since 1992. I was born in Fort Drum, N.Y., and my parents moved over to Vermont and went from active duty to National Guard. Because my mom is originally from Vermont. 

Q. What is your favorite part about serving in the Vermont National Guard?
A. My favorite part is the family feeling, there are a lot of families connected. The National Guard is excellent about their state benefits. The biggest part is the feeling of a close-knit community, whether it’s the VFW, or the Family readiness Group, or the unit itself, there are a lot of close-knit connections.

Q. How many push-ups did you get on your last physical fitness test?
A. it was 75.
column9: 美国南伯灵顿
column10: 见见你的警卫-布莱恩・休斯顿
column11: 姓名：SPC Brion Houston军事专业：15P，航空作战专家服务年限：10年单位：查理连，第126航空团第3营（空中救护车）家乡：佛蒙特州圣奥尔本斯市当前城镇：费尔法克斯，高中/毕业年份：2008年从BFA圣奥尔本毕业问：你为什么加入国民警卫队？答：我加入国民警卫队是因为它成为了一种家庭传统。我的祖父、我的叔公、我的叔父、我的姑姑、我的父亲、我的母亲、我的姐姐和我都加入了，然后我的弟弟也加入了。因此，它成为了一个家庭传统。问：你在佛蒙特州国民警卫队做什么？答：我是一名航空运营专家。从本质上说，我们是航空运营的管理者。我们做了很多飞行日志，天气预报和飞行计划，这是最大的飞行计划之一。我们接收他们的任务，我们还与飞机保持无线电联系。我们就像他们的管理员和航空调度。这是你的第一次部署吗？答：这是我的第二次部署。2009年，我和妈妈一起部署到阿富汗的巴格拉姆。问：你是如何训练和准备部署的？答：每次训练和每次AT（年度训练）都为我们做好准备，而且每年也是爬行-行走-跑步阶段的不同周期。是什么吸引你去航空和医疗后送？答：吸引我进入航空业的是，我想改变我的职业生涯，我在那里停滞不前，我想要更先进、更激动人心的东西，而航空领域正是我想要的。作为一名州警察调度员，15P系列在操作方面与之相当。更多的实际操作，更重要的是任务本身，用于战场上的医疗后送请求，他们需要操作来帮助事情顺利进行。问：你做什么文职工作？答：我是911接线员，也是佛蒙特州警察局的州警察调度员。问：你认为国民警卫队最大的好处是什么？答：我认为国民警卫队最大的好处之一是他们在大学和教育方面的好处。此外，其他好处是保持身材，护卫有助于保持身体健康。问：你在佛蒙特州住了多久？答：我从1992年起就住在佛蒙特州。我出生在纽约州的德拉姆堡，父母搬到了佛蒙特州，从现役军人变成了国民警卫队。因为我妈妈来自佛蒙特州。问：在佛蒙特州国民警卫队服役，你最喜欢的部分是什么？答：我最喜欢的部分是家庭的感觉，有很多家庭是相互联系的。国民警卫队对他们的国家福利非常了解。最大的部分是一个紧密联系的社区的感觉，无论是VFW，家庭准备小组，还是单位本身，都有很多紧密联系。你上一次身体健康测试做了多少俯卧撑？答：是75。

column2: A Falcon swoops through Fort Campbell
column3:
FORT CAMPBELL, Kentucky C Andre Roberts, wide receiver for the Atlanta Falcons, came to teach Fort Campbell children, not only football skills, but the importance of hard work, during his Procter and Gamble Andre Roberts Football ProCamp, here July 15-16. 
This is the second time Fort Campbell has hosted the ProCamp, an opportunity made possible by the base commissary’s participation in a P&G display contest, from which it was selected among 11 communities to hold the two-day event.
According to a Defense Commissary Agency press release, “Our communities, especially the children, benefit from our partnership with industry that brings these football stars to their installations,” said Sallie Cauthers, DeCA’s marketing and mass media specialist. “At the same time, our commissary patrons save significantly on quality products versus what they’d have to pay outside the gate.”
More than 100 children, dependents of active duty service members, retirees, and Department of Defense civilian employees, participated in the ProCamp. The campers were divided into three divisions for different ages; the Vikings, Bulldogs and the Falcons. Campers received hands-on instructions, motivational talks, and participated in skill stations such as offense and defense drills, quarterback drills, and how to run lanes. At the culmination of each day the campers played non-contact football games to determine a division champion by the end of camp.
“Just work hard no matter what, if you get tired it doesn’t matter,” said Roberts. “Just make sure you’re working hard and having fun.”
The campers had the opportunity to have Roberts help them with various drills and received autographed memorabilia. They were also able to ask Roberts questions about his football journey. Most of the campers wanted to know how Roberts became so good in high school.
 “First and foremost you have to get good grades,” said Roberts. “Make sure when you go to school, you listen to your teachers and get those good grades. It doesn’t matter if you want to play football or not,” said Roberts. “If you want to do anything in life, you have to work hard and that begins in school getting good grades.”
Bill Conley, the Master of Ceremonies for the ProCamp, gave praise to the answers given by Roberts, reaffirming the importance of hard work and effort.
“As a player, you have to be a guy that is an inspiration to those under you,” said Conley, “Learn from others and carry on that tradition.” 	
When speaking to the campers, Roberts mentioned the fact that when he was younger he did not play football due to his mother being worried about him getting hurt. He used this opportunity to express the advantage of playing other sports.
“When I was kid I played baseball, soccer, and I played basketball, and basketball was my passion,” said Roberts. “That’s a good thing for you guys to do, too; don’t just focus on one sport. Soccer can help you with footwork, baseball will help you with hand and eye coordination, and things like that will help you with football.”
At the culmination of the camp, Roberts gave the campers some words of encouragement, and a backstory of what it was like growing up in a military family.
Roberts shared with the campers that he too was born into a military family and both his parents served in the Army. He told them he moved around a lot, living in Alaska, Texas, Columbia; twice; and St. Croix.
 “I know everything you guys may be going through right now and may have to go through as kids, “said Roberts. “I’m here to let you know that anything you want to do is possible, doesn’t matter where you come from or what walk of life you come from, anything you want to do is possible, but the only way you get there is putting in the effort.”
“I saw a lot of effort out there, a lot of hustle, a lot of kids having fun and that’s what you have to do each and every day when it comes to football and when it comes to school, said Roberts. “Everybody out here, learn from today, no matter what you want to be, you have to put in the effort.”
          					 - 30 C
column9: 坎贝尔堡，肯塔基州，美国
column10: 一只猎鹰掠过坎贝尔堡
column11: 坎贝尔堡，肯塔基州――亚特兰大猎鹰队（Atlanta Falcons）的边线接球手安德烈・罗伯茨（Andre Roberts）在7月15日至16日的宝洁（Procter and Gamble）安德烈・罗伯茨（Andre Roberts）足球宝洁（football ProCamp）中，向坎贝尔堡的孩子们传授了不仅是足球技能，而且是努力工作的重要性。这是坎贝尔堡第二次主办ProCamp，这是基地军委参加宝洁展示比赛的机会，从中选出11个社区举办为期两天的活动。根据国防军委局新闻稿，“我们的社区，特别是孩子们，受益于我们与行业的合作，这些足球明星被带到了他们的设施中，”DeCA的营销和大众媒体专家Sallie Cauthers说。“与此同时，我们的小卖部顾客在优质产品上比他们在大门外所需支付的费用节省了很多。”超过100名儿童、现役军人家属、退休人员和国防部文职人员参加了该项目。露营者分为三个不同年龄段：维京人、斗牛犬和猎鹰。露营者接受了动手指导、激励性讲座，并参加了技能培训例如进攻和防守训练，四分卫训练，以及如何跑车道。在每天的训练结束时，露营者进行非接触式足球比赛，以在训练结束时确定分区冠军。“不管怎样，只要努力工作，如果你累了，那没关系，”罗伯茨说。“只要确保你工作努力，玩得开心就行了。”露营者们有机会让罗伯茨帮助他们进行各种训练，并收到了亲笔签名的纪念品。他们还可以向罗伯茨询问有关他的足球之旅的问题。大多数露营者都想知道罗伯茨在高中时是如何变得如此优秀的。罗伯茨说：“首先，你必须取得好成绩。上学时一定要听老师的话，取得好成绩。你想不想踢足球并不重要。如果你想在生活中做任何事情，你必须努力学习，这从学校取得好成绩开始。”普罗坎普的司仪比尔・康利（Bill Conley）赞扬了罗伯茨的回答，重申了努力工作的重要性。康利说：“作为一名球员，你必须成为一个激励下属的人，向他人学习并继承这一传统。”在与露营者交谈时，罗伯茨提到，他年轻时，由于母亲担心他受伤，他没有踢足球。他利用这个机会表达了参加其他运动的优势。“我小时候打棒球、足球和篮球，篮球是我的激情。”罗伯茨说：“这对你们来说也是一件好事；不要只关注一项运动。足球可以帮助你们进行步法，棒球可以帮助你们进行手眼协调，诸如此类的事情可以帮助你们踢足球。”在夏令营的高潮，罗伯茨给了露营者一些鼓励的话，并讲述了在军人家庭中成长的经历。罗伯茨告诉露营者，他也出生在军人家庭，父母都在军队服役。他告诉他们，他经常搬家，住在阿拉斯加州、德克萨斯州、哥伦比亚；两次；罗伯茨说：“我知道你们现在可能要经历的一切，也知道你们小时候可能要经历的一切。”。“我来这里是想让你知道，你想做的任何事情都是可能的，不管你来自哪里，也不管你来自哪个行业，你想做的任何事情都是可能的，但你要做到这一点的唯一途径是付出努力。”罗伯茨说：“我看到外面有很多努力，很多喧闹，很多孩子玩得很开心，这就是你每天在足球和学校必须做的事情。这里的每个人，从今天开始学习，无论你想成为什么样的人，你都必须付出努力。”

column2: Commentary- Dear Alcohol ...
column3:
ROBINS AIR FORCE BASE, GA. -- Dear Alcohol, I’m sure you’ve been wondering where I’ve been the last few years. And although I know you feel you deserve an explanation, it’s really none of your business. Even so, here you go.

There’s no denying that you’ve always been there for me. In fact, you’ve been a part of my life for as long as I can remember. Regardless whether it was a birthday, wedding, cookout, or a family vacation there you were just chilling in the corner or mixing it up with the sodas and fruit juice. 

Yep, you were the fun one in the crowd. It seems like someone was always talking about whether or not you were invited, if you needed a ride to the party or if you were going to be available for the work functions we were to attend. Some of my friends got along with you well, but you and me? We were tight. 

From the first time we hung out together, I felt like you made everything easier. It didn’t matter if it was meeting new people, interacting with old friends or winding down from a stressful day at work. I could always count on you to make things more relaxed … more manageable … more exciting.

And, you were there for the tough times too. You were right beside me when deaths, illnesses and conflicts crippled me with anxiety or broke me down spiritually and emotionally. You knew just the right way to numb the pain. 

Yeah, we were the best of friends.

I could handle anything if you were along for the ride ... Unfortunately those rides ended up landing me in jail on more than one occasion. Still, I told myself it had nothing to do with you. When our other friends began to hang out with you less, I just found new friends who liked you better. And, over the years, that became a pattern. 

What I didn’t notice was that it wasn’t just you our friends were avoiding, it was me. The baggage started piling up. I tried ever so valiantly, but I couldn’t seem to gain control of the seemingly countless suitcases filled with issues on the revolving track at baggage claim after each flight.

Those flights became more frequent. 

With every trip we took together, I spent less time with my wife and children. I isolated myself from my parents and brother … my dearest friends. Hey, but with all the frequent flier miles I was accumulating, it seemed a travesty not to cash them in for another trip.

Even as things became darker, I sought refuge and ill-placed solace in your company. I tried skipping out on a few occasions without you, but it always ended up with you there C enticing me with promises of an end to my uncertainty and my damaged self-esteem.

There were weekends when I would wake up shaking, nauseous and ill … until you showed up for breakfast. And, I was thankful to see you. But then breakfast led to lunch followed by dinner. You were a houseguest who overstayed your welcome, and I was losing more of myself with each visit.

That’s when I started blaming you. When I took inventory of the bad things in my life, there was always one constant C you. Not only that, but fun was no longer part of the equation. The only thing you were offering me was a soulless black hole where I began depositing my hopes, my dreams and my desires.

When you started stealing time from me I knew our trip had just about run its course. It was only upon great reflection that I realized you were only stealing time from my memories … not from those of the people who love and care about me who were hopelessly watching me circling the drain through a funnel into the bottom of a bottle.

So here we are. When I’m with you everything that means anything to me is at risk C my life, my marriage, my children, my friendships and my livelihood. 

That said, I can’t lay the blame solely on your shoulders. I chose to take part in your plots and schemes. It was I who turned my back on those offering help, and I who continued to hang around with you even when I knew our relationship was only leading to hopelessness and despair. 

So I’ll own up to my end of it. And, my end of it means that we can’t be friends anymore. There is nothing you can offer me to solve my problems … nothing you can provide that I can’t get with the help of God, my family or on my own … and nothing you can do will change my mind.

Yeah, we’ll still see each other around … on TV, in magazines, at restaurants and in corner markets. And, I know that I’ll see you hanging out with my friends. But don’t mistake my tolerance for acceptance. Our adventure has come to an end, and I’ve been on a new quest with the truest friend I’ve ever known … my sobriety.

From the author: Do you or someone you care about have a drinking problem? Help is available. I know it’s hard, but  if you just reach out and ask for help, you’ll get it. I know it can be a scary and embarrassing thing to face, but if you want it badly enough, you can do it.  In my experience, the payoff is so well worth it. It’s been more than three years since I quit drinking, and everything in my life has improved dramatically.  For me, not one single thing  was made worse.  If you’re looking for a place to start, check out the information below. 

For a list of Middle Georgia Alcoholics Anonymous meetings, visit http://www.aageorgia.org/7b-meetings.html. Other resources include:

The Employee Assistance Program at 1-800-222-0364.
The Alcohol and Drug Addiction Prevention Treatment program at Robins at 478-327-8398.
The Alkanon Club at 1001 N. Carl Vinson Pkwy, Warner Robins, Ga. 31093 C Open meeting at 8 a.m. each Sunday.
Macon Alcohol and Drug Rehabilitation Services: 1-800-304-2219 
Free Alcohol, Drug and other Rehab resources in Warner Robins, 1-800-780-2294.
Trinity Treatment Center Inc., 221 Newberg Avenue, Macon, Georgia , 31206 - 478-788-5600.
Trinity Treatment Center provides substance abuse treatment services for adult men and women in an outpatient setting. These services include but are not limited to trauma related counseling, individual and group counseling, motivational interviewing, anger management and relapse prevention.
New Pointe Treatment Center LLC - 1031 Keith Drive Perry, Georgia, 31069, 478-987-7912.
column9: 华纳罗宾斯，佐治亚州，美国
column10: 评论-亲爱的酒精。。。
column11: 乔治亚州罗宾斯空军基地――亲爱的酒鬼，我肯定你一直在想，过去几年我去了哪里。虽然我知道你觉得你应该得到一个解释，但这真的不关你的事。即便如此，你还是来了。不可否认，你一直在我身边。事实上，从我记事起，你就一直是我生活的一部分。不管是生日、婚礼、外出野餐还是家庭度假，你都只是在角落里冷着，或者把它和苏打水和果汁混在一起。是的，你是人群中最有趣的一个。好像总有人在谈论你是否被邀请，你是否需要搭车去参加聚会，或者你是否可以参加我们要参加的工作活动。我的一些朋友和你相处得很好，但是你和我？我们很亲密。从我们第一次一起出去玩起，我觉得你让一切都变得容易了。不管是结识新朋友、与老朋友互动还是从紧张的工作中放松下来。我总是可以指望你让事情变得更轻松…更容易管理…更令人兴奋。而且，你也在艰难的时刻。当死亡、疾病和冲突使我焦虑不安或精神和情感崩溃时，你就在我身边。你知道让疼痛麻木的正确方法。是的，我们是最好的朋友。如果你一起去的话，我可以处理任何事情。。。不幸的是，我不止一次乘坐这些车进了监狱。不过，我告诉自己这与你无关。当我们的其他朋友开始少和你在一起的时候，我只是找到了更喜欢你的新朋友。多年来，这已成为一种模式。我没有注意到的是，我们的朋友回避的不仅仅是你，还有我。行李开始堆积起来。我曾如此勇敢地尝试过，但每次飞行后，在行李提取处的旋转轨道上，我似乎无法控制似乎数不清的装满问题的行李箱。这些航班变得越来越频繁。每次我们一起旅行，我花在妻子和孩子身上的时间都少了。我把自己和我的父母和兄弟隔离开来……我最亲爱的朋友。嘿，但是由于我积累了这么多的飞行里程，不把它们兑换成另一次旅行似乎是一种滑稽。即使事情变得更糟，我还是在你的公司寻求庇护和不适当的安慰。有几次我尝试在没有你的情况下跳出去，但结果总是你在那里――诱惑我的是承诺结束我的不确定性和受损的自尊。有几个周末，我醒来时浑身发抖、恶心、生病……直到你出现在早餐前。我很高兴见到你。但早餐之后是午餐，然后是晚餐。你是一个逾期逗留的客人，每次来访我都会失去更多的自我。从那时起，我开始责怪你。当我清点生活中的坏事时，总有一件事是不变的――你。不仅如此，乐趣也不再是等式的一部分。你提供给我的唯一东西就是一个没有灵魂的黑洞，我开始在那里寄托我的希望、梦想和欲望。当你开始从我身上偷走时间时，我知道我们的旅程就要结束了。经过深思熟虑，我才意识到你只是从我的记忆中偷走了时间……而不是那些爱我和关心我的人，他们绝望地看着我通过漏斗把排水管转进瓶底。所以我们到了。当我和你在一起的时候，对我来说意味着一切的一切都处于危险之中――我的生命、我的婚姻、我的孩子、我的友谊和我的生计。也就是说，我不能把责任完全推到你的肩上。我选择参与你的阴谋和计划。是我拒绝了那些提供帮助的人，是我继续和你在一起，即使我知道我们的关系只会导致绝望和绝望。所以我会承认这一点。我的结局意味着我们不能再做朋友了。你不能给我提供任何东西来解决我的问题……没有任何东西是你能提供的，而这些东西是我在上帝、我的家人或我自己的帮助下得不到的……你所能做的任何事情都不会改变我的想法。是的，我们仍然会在周围见面……在电视上、杂志上、餐馆里和街角市场上。我知道我会看到你和我的朋友们在一起。但不要把我的宽容误认为是接受。我们的冒险已经结束，我和我所认识的最真诚的朋友开始了新的探索……我的清醒。作者：你或你关心的人有酗酒问题吗？可以提供帮助。我知道这很难，但如果你伸出手来寻求帮助，你会得到的。我知道这可能是一件令人害怕和尴尬的事情，但如果你非常想要它，你可以去做。根据我的经验，回报是非常值得的。我戒酒已经三年多了，生活中的一切都有了显著的改善。对我来说，没有一件事情变得更糟。如果你正在寻找一个开始的地方，请查看下面的信息。有关佐治亚州中部酗酒者匿名会议的列表，请访问http://www.aageorgia.org/7b-meetings.html. 其他资源包括：员工援助计划（电话：1-800-222-0364）、罗宾斯酒精和药物成瘾预防治疗计划（电话：478-327-8398）、阿尔卡农俱乐部（地址：1001 N）、加利福尼亚州华纳罗宾斯卡尔・文森・普克维（Carl Vinson Pkwy）、31093――每个周日上午8点的公开会议。麦肯酒精和药物康复服务：1-800-304-2219免费酒精，华纳罗宾斯的药物和其他康复资源，1-800-780-2294。三一治疗中心有限公司，乔治亚州梅肯纽伯格大道221号，31206-478-788-5600。三一治疗中心在门诊为成年男女提供药物滥用治疗服务。这些服务包括但不限于创伤相关咨询、个人和团体咨询、动机式访谈、愤怒管理和复发预防。New Pointe治疗中心有限责任公司-1031 Keith Drive Perry，Georgia，31069478-987-7912。

column2: Marines attack the North Carolina beach in armored vehicles
column3:
CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C. - “My AMTRAC and I are the defenders of our country. We are the masters of gunnery. We are the saviors from the ocean.”  Marines from 2nd Assault Amphibian Battalion, 2nd Marine Division know these lines well because it comes from their AMTRAC creed.

An AMTRAC (Amphibious Tractor) is an amphibious assault vehicle used to provide the necessary transportation of troops from land to sea, and vice versa. Not only do AAV operators bring Marines where they need to go, but they can also fight alongside their brothers-in-arms.

“My job is very important; I know that for a fact,” said Lance Cpl. Jorge De Jesus, an AAV operator with 3rd Platoon, Alpha Company, 2nd AA Bn., and a Bronx, New York native. “I transport troops, I’m able to shoot, move and communicate, and I take the fight closer than what other people can.”

As a department of the Navy, the Marine Corps and its sister-service work closely together, especially when it comes to amphibious operations.

Members of 2nd AA Bn. embarked on the multipurpose amphibious assault ship USS Kearsarge (LHD-3), April 12, 2015.  Sailors aboard the ship guided the AAV operators through the well-deck of the ship as part of a Joint Operations Access Exercise. The ship hosted the 2nd AA Bn. Marines for one night, until they transported Marines from 1st Battalion, 6th Marine Regiment to a training area aboard Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune, North Carolina.

“We’re both helping each other out,” said De Jesus of the sailors. “They need qualification for their ground guides, and we need the qualification to get on ship and know what we need to do during [Marine Expeditionary Brigade] floats and [Marine Expeditionary Units]. The relationship between the 
two services is crucial.”

After securing their vehicles in the well deck of the USS Kearsarge, the Marines performed proactive maintenance on their vehicles by changing oil and fixing small problems while on ship. Operators and mechanics of AAVs know that taking care of the vehicles is a huge part of achieving mission accomplishment, especially since one hour of 
operating an AAV requires eight hours of maintenance. 

Despite the long hours it may take to maintain an amphibious vehicle, many Marines feel a sense of pride in the important role they play for the Marine Corps.

“It’s a rewarding feeling knowing that you actually make a difference in the fight,” said De Jesus.  “Sometimes [our job requires] long hours, but at the end of the day… when you plan something and it comes together, the hours don’t really matter anymore. I love what I do.”
column9: 美国北卡罗来纳州勒琼营
column10: 海军陆战队用装甲车袭击北卡罗来纳海滩
column11: 北卡罗来纳州勒琼营―“我和我的AMTRAC是我们国家的捍卫者。我们是射击大师。我们是海洋的救世主。”海军陆战队第二师第二突击两栖营的海军陆战队非常熟悉这些路线，因为它来自他们的AMTRAC信条。AMTRAC（两栖拖拉机）是一种两栖突击车，用于将部队从陆地运送到海上，反之亦然。AAV操作员不仅可以将海军陆战队带到他们需要去的地方，还可以与他们的战友并肩作战。“我的工作非常重要；我知道这是事实，”兰斯下士Jorge De Jesus说，他是AAV第二连阿尔法连第三排的AAV操作员，也是纽约本地人。作为海军的一个部门，海军陆战队和它的姐妹部队紧密合作，特别是在两栖作战方面。第二海军陆战队成员。2015年4月12日，登上多用途两栖攻击舰Kearsarge号（LHD-3）。作为联合行动进入演习的一部分，船上的水手引导AAV操作员穿过船上的钻井甲板。该船主办了第二次美航。海军陆战队一个晚上，直到他们从海军陆战队第六团第一营运送海军陆战队到北卡罗莱纳州海军陆战队大本营Lejeune上的一个训练区。“我们都在互相帮助，”海军陆战队的De Jesus说。“他们需要获得地面向导的资格，我们需要获得上船的资格，知道我们在[海军陆战队远征旅]浮标和[海军陆战队远征部队]期间需要做什么。这两个军种之间的关系至关重要。”在将他们的车辆固定在Kearsarge号航母的钻井甲板上后，海军陆战队通过在船上换油和解决小问题对车辆进行了主动维护。AAV的操作员和机械师都知道，维护车辆是完成任务的重要组成部分，特别是因为一个小时的AAV操作需要八个小时的维护。尽管维修两栖车辆可能需要很长的时间，但许多海军陆战队对他们在海军陆战队中扮演的重要角色感到自豪。“知道你在战斗中确实发挥了作用，这是一种值得的感觉，”德・耶酥说。“有时候[我们的工作]需要很长的时间，但在一天结束的时候……当你计划某件事并把它结合在一起时，时间真的不再重要了。我喜欢我所做的。”

column2: Air Force reservists, active duty train to survive
column3:
FORT WORTH, Texas - More than 70 reservists and active duty service members from three different units participated in water survival training at Naval Air Station Key West, Florida, Sept. 14 - 18, 2015.

Service members from the 301st Fighter Wing here and its geographically separated F-22 unit, the 44th Fighter Group at Tyndall Air Force Base, Florida, teamed up with the 920th Rescue Wing, Patrick AFB, Florida, and Naval Air Station Key West Base Operations, Key West, Florida, to provide this training.

"This training is a combat training requirement that keeps pilots deployment-ready," said Master Sgt. John Gibson, 301st Operations Support Flight Aircrew Flight Equipment.

During the five-day water training spearheaded by AFE, pilots learned how to escape parachute entanglements, use a signal mirror to reflect sunlight up to 50 miles away and survive on a one-man life raft. 

"Out there, they learned longevity, ways to increase their chances of survivability and how to use their equipment properly in a real-world training scenario," Gibson said. "This also helps our AFE members to sharpen their skills by getting real hands-on training."

While the pilots learned how to disengage their parachutes so they aren't drug under water, the PJs honed their particular skills as well.

"We're going to hoist them up out of the water and deal with the dangers and procedures that come with that," said Master Sgt. Blain Morgan, 308th Rescue Squadron pararescueman jumper attached to the 920 RQW. "There will also be a medical exercise where we extract an Airman, evaluate him and treat him as necessary. It's a good experience for everybody." 

This type of combat training is required every three years and there is also a 180-day equipment training requirement. For some, this was a necessary refresher. For others, this was a first-time experience.

"It's an opportunity which our young guys have never seen and they get academics on it, but until you're actually in the water with the helicopter beating down on you ... it's an eye-opening experience," 301st Fighter Wing Vice Commander Col. Robert Buchanan said. "It's great training for everyone and a great chance to come together both as a wing and as the Reserve."

This exercise provided the unique opportunity for all participants to demonstrate the individual training they have learned and apply it in a total force integration hands-on training effort.

"There's a definite synergy in joint training because you bring together so many different experiences and training expertise," Col. Brian Neal, 44th Fighter Group commander, said. "The training we're going to garner this week is going to be unmatched. It's going to be exactly like (what) they might encounter, should something misfortunate happen."

The goal is to continue with this total force training setting and keep it as realistic as possible.

"There are some things you can simulate and some things you can't," Buchanan said. "If we are going to train like we are going to fight, here's the one chance where we can actually go out, perform the training, get picked up and rescued. So if it comes down to it, in wartime, we're ready to go."
column9: 美国德克萨斯州沃思堡
column10: 空军预备役人员，现役训练以生存
column11: 德克萨斯州沃思堡―2015年9月14日至18日，来自三个不同部队的70多名预备役军人和现役军人参加了佛罗里达州基韦斯特海军航空站的水上生存训练。来自这里的3011战斗机联队及其地理位置不同的F-22部队，廷德尔空军基地的第44战斗机群的现役军人，与佛罗里达州第920救援联队、佛罗里达州帕特里克空军基地和佛罗里达州基韦斯特海军航空站基韦斯特基地作战部合作，提供这项训练。“这项训练是一项战斗训练要求，可使飞行员随时做好部署准备，”约翰・吉布森上士说，301行动支持飞行机组的飞行设备。在AFE牵头的为期五天的水上训练中，飞行员学会了如何摆脱降落伞缠绕，使用信号镜反射50英里以外的阳光，并在单人救生筏上生存。吉布森说：“在那里，他们学会了长寿、提高生存能力的方法以及如何在真实训练场景中正确使用设备。”。“这也有助于我们的AFE成员通过实际动手训练来提高他们的技能。”虽然飞行员学会了如何解开降落伞，这样他们就不会在水下吸毒，但PJ也磨练了他们的特殊技能。“我们将把他们吊离水面，并处理随之而来的危险和程序。”隶属920 RQW的第308营救中队助理营救员跳伞员布莱恩・摩根上士说。“我们还将进行一次医疗演习，对一名飞行员进行解救、评估和必要的治疗。这对每个人来说都是一次很好的经历。”这种战斗训练每三年进行一次，还需要180天的装备训练。对一些人来说，这是必要的复习。对于其他人来说，这是第一次体验。“这是我们的年轻人从未见过的机会，他们对此进行了学术研究，但除非你真的在水中被直升机击倒……这是一次令人大开眼界的体验，”第301战斗机联队副指挥官罗伯特・布坎南上校说。“这对每个人来说都是一次很好的训练，也是一次很好的机会，可以作为一个联队和预备队走到一起。”这一练习为所有参与者提供了一次独特的机会，展示他们所学到的个人训练，并将其应用到整个部队整合的实践训练中。第44战斗群指挥官布赖恩・尼尔上校说：“联合训练有着明确的协同作用，因为你汇集了这么多不同的经验和训练专业知识，我们本周要进行的训练将是无与伦比的。布坎南说：“我们的目标是继续进行这种全力以赴的训练，并尽可能保持现实。有些事情你可以模拟，有些事情你不能模拟。如果我们要像战斗一样训练，这是一个机会，在这里我们可以真正走出去，进行训练，被接走并获救。因此，如果归结起来，在战时，我们准备好了。”

column2: All Americans never stop being Paratroopers
column3:
“I jumped out of my first airplane in April of 1995,” said Master Sgt. Travis Cooke, the 1st Battalion, 73rd Cavalry Regiment battalion sergeant major of operations. “Back then we graduated on Fryar Drop Zone.
“My wife and one-year-old son came down to watch my last jump, and the wing pinning ceremony,” he added.
Little did Cooke know that 22 years later, the same son that watched him graduate Airborne School, would be jumping out of an airplane with his father. The jump that carried both father and son would be a millstone for the pair. For Travis, it would be his first jump with his son. For Cpl. Michael Cooke, an Alpha Company, 2nd Battalion, 325 Airborne Infantry Regiment team leader, it would be his fifth jump and qualify him as a paratrooper.
	While visiting the Airborne School, Travis was able to jump not once, but twice with his son.
	“I was able to jump twice with my son,” said Travis. “Mirroring our family experience, his two-year-old daughter was running around Fryar Drop Zone, and watched her daddy jump for the fifth time.”
	For Michael, the contrast in attitudes between his classmates and father when preparing to exit the aircraft spoke volumes.
	“Anybody that’s been to Airborne School knows that there’s terrified faces all on that plane,” said Michael. “Everybody is fricking scared; it’s their first time jumping out, their first couple of times.
“You look past all those terrified faces, you just see my dad happy as hell, just smiling ear to ear, loves what he does and that was a pretty big turning point for me; (that’s) when I realized that jumping out of an airplane can be fun. It doesn’t have to be just scary,” Michael added.
	Travis was able to share another pivotal moment for paratroopers when he was able to pin the coveted silver wings up Michael’s chest.
	“But it gets even better; Airborne School allows 2nd and 3d generation Paratroopers to be pinned by their predecessors, so I got to go up and put his airborne wings on his chest,” said Travis.
	After their shared experience at Airborne School, Travis went back to Fort Bragg, N.C. with the intent to have his son become a paratrooper within the 82nd Airborne Division. With the help of his chain of command, Travis was able to secure a spot for Michael within the division.
	“A few short months later he signed into division,” said Travis.
	Michael spoke of the culture shock that comes with the dawning of the red beret and wearing the double A patch.
“When you come here to the 82nd the loyalty to the division runs deep,” said Michael. “It means something different to everybody, but every single person is proud of their unit. They’re proud of the division.”
Travis shared the passion his Michael relayed to him after his first day in division.
“I asked Mike, after his first day at work, what he thought of Alpha Company, 2/325 Airborne Infantry Regiment,” said Travis.  “He said it felt like “coming home,” that the people spoke in ways that we do around the house, they act as we act, they are always walking around singing about putting on their boots, boots, boots, and parachutes, chutes, chutes.”
Travis felt the same emotions when he first stepped into the coveted jump boots.
“When I first saw the reflection of myself wearing class As, beret and boots as a corporal it changed the goals I had in my life,” said Travis. “I never wanted to do anything other than to be a paratrooper, to be surrounded by paratroopers and to lead paratroopers.
“It turns out the same is true of my son,” Travis added.
Those shared experiences continued to accumulate as Travis had the opportunity to perform his 100th airborne jump when Michael made his first jump in division. 
“This time was different,” said Travis. “At Benning, I jumped ahead of him, and my brain saw it as me training him by doing it first. This time he insisted on exiting ahead of me.”
Travis said that as they sat on the aircraft, his mind kept drifting back to the fact that he was sitting next to his child, a kid whose diapers he had changed, and that he was about to throw himself out of the aircraft they were riding in.
“It’s hard to emphasize enough how weird that is,” said Travis. “But every one of us is someone’s kid, and every paratrooper’s parents worry about them, I just happened to be exiting with my kid.
“And for real, if the job weren’t a little dangerous, it wouldn’t be cool,” Travis added.
 Though he cares for his son’s safety, Travis has confidence in the training of the division paratroopers and once the doors opened all of those thoughts disappeared.
“He kept his elbow high, didn’t ride the pack tray ahead of him and exited without hesitation,” said Travis. “That’s some proud dad stuff right there, my boy is a paratrooper!”
	After a safe jump, Michael was able to official proclaim himself as a paratrooper within the 82nd Abn. Div. and Travis was able to achieve the highly prized 100th jump. A moment that was commemorated officially on the parade field.
	“A friend of mine and previous co-worker Sgt. 1st Class Matt Thompson was a member of the Silver Wings Parachute club,” said Travis. “On the demonstration jump for the pinning ceremony, (he) jumped in with Mike’s wings and my static line from my 100th exit and gave them both to us on the parade field.”
	After his first jump in division, Michael saw the difference between jumping at the school and division.
	“I found that jumps at division, there’s more confidence involved,” said Michael. “You’re more confident in your own abilities; you’re more confident in your jumpmasters. These are jumpmasters that you know, you see every day and you know they’re proficient.
“As proficient as the jumpmasters at Fort Benning might be you don’t see them every single day at work,” Michael added.
For Travis, the division is more than just a unit within the armed forces of the United States.
	“Sons following in their father’s footsteps is a different thing between other divisions and the 82nd,” said Travis. “From my perspective, America’s Guard of Honor has its own persona, it is a living thing that reaches beyond the end of paratroopers’ careers and lives. It becomes a way that our families think and live with. All Americans never stop being Paratroopers.”
-30-
column9: 美国北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡
column10: 所有美国人都是伞兵
column11: “我在1995年4月跳下了我的第一架飞机，”第73骑兵团营第一营作战中士特拉维斯・库克上士说。“那时我们毕业于Fryar Drop Zone。”我妻子和一岁大的儿子下来观看我的最后一次跳伞和翅膀固定仪式他补充道。库克一点也不知道，22年后，看着他从空降学校毕业的同一个儿子，将和他的父亲一起从飞机上跳下来。这一跳带着父亲和儿子，对他们来说将是一个沉重的负担。对特拉维斯来说，这将是他和儿子的第一次跳伞。对迈克尔・库克下士来说，他是第二营阿尔法连，325空降步兵团团长，这将是他第五次跳伞，使他有资格成为一名伞兵。在参观空降学校时，特拉维斯不仅能跳一次，而且能和儿子跳两次。“我能和儿子跳两次，”特拉维斯说。“与我们的家庭经历相似，他两岁的女儿在Fryar Drop Zone附近跑来跑去，第五次看到她的爸爸跳了起来。”对迈克尔来说，他准备离开飞机时，同学和父亲的态度形成了鲜明的对比。“任何上过空降学校的人都知道飞机上都有吓坏了的面孔，”迈克尔说，“每个人都吓坏了；这是他们第一次跳出来，第一次和第二次。“你从那些惊恐的脸上看过去，你只看到我爸爸高兴得要命，面带微笑，热爱他的工作，这对我来说是一个相当大的转折点；（那时）我意识到从飞机上跳下来可以很有趣。不必只是吓人。”迈克尔补充道。特拉维斯能够为伞兵们分享另一个关键时刻，他能够将梦寐以求的银色翅膀固定在迈克尔的胸前。“但这变得更好了；空降学校允许第二代和第三代伞兵被他们的前辈固定住，所以我不得不上去把他的空降翅膀固定在他的胸前。”特拉维斯说。在他们分享了在空降学校的经历后，特拉维斯回到北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡，打算让他的儿子成为第82空降师的一名伞兵。在他的指挥链的帮助下，特拉维斯为迈克尔在该师找到了一个位置。“几个月后，他签约加入了该师。”特拉维斯说。迈克尔谈到了红色贝雷帽和双A补丁的出现带来的文化冲击。“当你来到第82届时，对该部门的忠诚根深蒂固，”迈克尔说。“这对每个人都意味着不同的东西，但每个人都为他们的单位感到骄傲。他们为该部门感到骄傲。”特拉维斯分享了他在师里的第一天迈克尔向他传达的激情。“我问迈克，在他工作的第一天之后，他对阿尔法连，2/325空降步兵团有什么看法，”特拉维斯说。“他说感觉像是“回家了。”人们说话的方式和我们在家里的方式一样，他们的行为和我们的行为一样，他们总是走来走去，唱着关于穿靴子、靴子、靴子、降落伞、降落伞、降落伞、降落伞、降落伞、降落伞、降落伞、降落伞、降落伞、降落伞的歌。”特拉维斯第一次穿上令人垂涎的跳伞靴时也有同样的感受。特拉维斯说：“当我第一次看到自己以下士的身份穿着军装、贝雷帽和靴子时，这改变了我的人生目标。除了成为一名伞兵、被伞兵包围和带领伞兵，我从来都不想做任何事情。事实证明，我的儿子也是如此。”特拉维斯补充道。当迈克尔在分区第一次跳伞时，特拉维斯有机会完成他的第100次空中跳伞，这些分享的经验继续积累。“这次不同了，”特拉维斯说。“在本宁，我跳到他前面，我的大脑认为这是我先做的训练他。这次他坚持要比我先离开。”特拉维斯说，当他们坐在飞机上时，他的思绪不停地回到这样一个事实：他坐在他的孩子旁边，一个他换过尿布的孩子，他正要从他们乘坐的飞机上跳下来。“很难强调这有多奇怪，”特拉维斯说。“但我们每个人都是别人的孩子，每个伞兵的父母都担心他们，我只是碰巧带着我的孩子离开了。”说真的，如果这份工作没有一点危险，那就不酷了，”特拉维斯补充道。虽然他关心儿子的安全，但特拉维斯对师伞兵的训练充满信心，一旦门打开，所有这些想法都消失了。“他保持肘部高，没有坐在前面的行李架上，毫不犹豫地离开了，”特拉维斯说。“这真是令人自豪的爸爸的事，我的孩子是一名伞兵！”在安全跳伞后，迈克尔能够正式宣布自己是第82 Abn分区的伞兵，特拉维斯也能够完成备受赞誉的第100次跳伞。这一时刻在阅兵场上被正式纪念。特拉维斯说：“我的一位朋友、前同事、一等军士马特・汤普森是银翼降落伞俱乐部的成员。在固定仪式的演示跳跃中，（他）从我的第100个出口带着迈克的翅膀和我的静态线跳了进来，并在阅兵场上把它们都给了我们。”在他第一次参加分区赛后，迈克尔看到了在学校和分区赛中跳跃的区别。“我发现在分区赛中跳跃，更有信心，”迈克尔说。“你对自己的能力更有信心；你对你的跳跃大师更有信心。这些跳跃大师你知道，你每天都能看到，你知道他们很熟练。“尽管本宁堡的跳跃大师可能很熟练，但你不会每天都看到他们在工作。”迈克尔补充道。对特拉维斯来说，这个师不仅仅是美国武装部队中的一个单位。特拉维斯说：“儿子们追随父亲的脚步，与其他师和第82师不同。”。“在我看来，美国的仪仗队有它自己的个性，它是一个活生生的东西，超越了伞兵职业生涯和生活的终点。它成为我们家庭思考和生活的一种方式。所有的美国人永远都不会停止做伞兵。”-30-

column2: Lead the way
column3:
CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C. C The rumbling sound of explosives detonating and the motivated shouts of Marines yelling to their peers to take cover permeate the air as the Marines with 2nd Combat Engineer Battalion, 2nd Marine Division conducted their Marine Corps Combat Readiness Evaluation, April 4-8, 2016.
The Marines with 2nd Assault Amphibian Battalion, and 2nd Tank Battalion, 2nd Marine Division provided support for the Marines of 2nd CEB, which allowed the engineers to work in conjunction with units that they would support in a real combat situation.
The MCCRE consisted of multiple scenarios, including route clearance exercises in between operations, survivability training, an urban breaching exercise, and their culminating event which consisted of a company breach with the support of 2nd Tank Bn. and 2nd AA Bn.
Throughout the scenarios, the Marines’ performance was evaluated. [The evaluation] allows the Marine Corps to give us feedback, whether positive or not, so that we may improve for the better of the unit and the mission, said Capt. Curtis Register, the unit’s operations officer in charge.
This training helped reinforce the battalion’s mission to provide close-combat engineer support to the 2nd Marine Division in order to enhance their mobility, counter-mobility, and survivability.
 “We train like this to be ready. The MCCRE is about evaluation and it will let us know if we are ready to deploy. It’s important that the Marine Corps is ready when the country is least ready,” said SSgt. Matthew Monteforte, a platoon sergeant for Charlie Co. “We do what we have to. Working with these different units to accomplish a mission is what the Marine Corps is about.”
column9: 美国北卡罗来纳州勒琼营
column10: 带路
column11: 北卡罗来纳州勒琼营――4月4日至8日，海军陆战队第二师第二战斗工兵营的海军陆战队进行了他们的海军陆战队战备评估，爆炸声隆隆，海军陆战队士兵高声呼喊，要求同僚掩护，2016年。海军陆战队第二突击两栖营和第二海军陆战队师第二坦克营为第二行政首长协调会的海军陆战队提供了支持，使工程师能够与他们将在实战情况下支持的部队协同工作。MCCRE由多个场景组成，包括作战间隙的路线清理演习、生存能力训练、城市突袭演习以及最终事件，包括第二坦克Bn支援下的连队突袭。在整个场景中，对海军陆战队的表现进行了评估。柯蒂斯・雷斯特尔上尉说：“（评估）允许海军陆战队向我们提供反馈，无论是正面反馈还是负面反馈，以便我们能够为部队和任务的发展做出更好的改进。”，该部队的行动负责人。该训练有助于加强该营的任务，为海军陆战队第二师提供近战工程师支持，以增强其机动性、反机动性和生存能力。SSgt说：“我们这样训练是为了做好准备。MCCRE是关于评估的，它会让我们知道我们是否准备好部署。海军陆战队在国家最不准备的时候做好准备是很重要的。”。查理公司的排长Matthew Monteforte说：“我们做我们必须做的。与这些不同的部队合作完成任务是海军陆战队的任务。”

column2: African alumni, US Army highlight leadership, global security at symposium
column3:
VICENZA, Italy C Thirty-seven senior officers from 19 African partner nation militaries recently returned to the United States to attend the 2020 African Alumni Symposium at the U.S. Army Heritage and Education Center in Carlisle, Pennsylvania, March 9-12.

Participants in the U.S. Army Africa-conducted and U.S. Army War College-hosted event included African alumni of U.S. Army professional military education programs at the USAWC in Carlisle and the U.S. Army Command and General Staff College in Leavenworth, Kansas. Twenty African fellows currently enrolled at the USAWC and nine Army National Guard representatives from the Defense Department’s State Partnership Program were also in attendance.

This year’s event was the largest AAS to date, with approximately 66 participants representing 27 African nations and nine of the continent’s 13 SPP partnerships.

The symposium, a U.S. Africa Command initiative, brings participants together to strengthen existing partnerships as well as build new relationships among African senior military leaders and the U.S. Army and facilitate discussion about shared security concerns, as well as encourage regional cooperation in addressing challenges.

The event also offers participants an opportunity to reexamine current models of leadership decision making, and to discuss ways to improve those processes not just for current leaders, but also for decision makers of the future, said Maj. Gen. John S. Kem, the USAWC commandant.

“How can we do this in a better way? Because that’s the challenge that we all face,” he said. “We all have hard problems; we all have questions. We’ve all got ways we can do things differently or better. How do you generate an idea and get it to impact? That’s really what we are here to talk about.”

During his opening ceremony remarks, Col. Ed Williams, the USARAF security cooperation directorate director, expressed that this event is a priority for the command because global security depends upon security on the African continent, which requires long-term partnerships of trust and common purpose between military leaders.

“Global security is impossible without a secure, stable and prosperous Africa, and we’ll achieve that by working together through a network of partnerships,” he said. “No one nation can do this alone.”

The event’s overarching theme was “Security Tomorrow Demands Leadership Today.” Participants met in plenary sessions and breakout groups to discuss defense leadership-related topics, including 21st century challenges for military leaders, developing leaders through defense institutions, and defense leadership in a multinational environment. The event also included a staff ride to American Civil War battle site Antietam National Battlefield in Sharpsburg, Maryland.

Williams encouraged the participants to be candid in their discussions to promote understanding and continued regional cooperation and coordination and secure a stable and prosperous Africa.

“The world is complex and dynamic and African militaries face some of the most diverse security challenges in the world: insurgencies, armed conflicts, illicit trafficking, piracy, organized crime and violent extremist organizations,” he said. “As you know, these threats have no boundaries C crossing borders, destabilizing regions, and often requiring coordinated multinational responses. The military is of course not the solution in Africa, but is certainly part of the solution.”
column9: 美国
column10: 非洲校友、美国陆军在研讨会上强调领导力、全球安全
column11: 意大利维琴察―来自19个非洲伙伴国家军队的37名高级军官最近返回美国，参加在宾夕法尼亚州卡莱尔美国陆军遗产和教育中心举行的2020年非洲校友研讨会，3月9日至12日。参加美国陆军非洲部举办和美国陆军战争学院主办的活动的有卡莱尔USAWC和堪萨斯州利文沃斯美国陆军指挥与参谋学院美国陆军专业军事教育课程的非洲校友。目前有20名非洲研究员参加了USAWC，来自国防部州合作项目的9名陆军国民警卫队代表也参加了。今年的活动是迄今为止规模最大的AAS，代表27个非洲国家和该大陆13个SPP伙伴关系中的9个的约66名参与者。研讨会是美国非洲司令部的一项倡议，将与会者聚集在一起，加强现有的伙伴关系，在非洲高级军事领导人和美国军队之间建立新的关系，并促进关于共同安全问题的讨论，USAWC指挥官约翰・S・凯姆少将说，此次活动还为参与者提供了一个机会，让他们重新审视当前的领导决策模式，并讨论改进这些流程的方法，不仅针对现任领导人，也针对未来的决策者。“我们如何才能以更好的方式做到这一点？因为这是我们所有人都面临的挑战，”他说。“我们都有困难的问题；我们都有问题。我们都有不同或更好的方法。你如何产生一个想法并使其产生影响？这才是我们在这里讨论的真正问题。”美国皇家空军安全合作局局长埃德・威廉姆斯上校（Col.Ed Williams）在开幕式致辞时表示，这项活动是司令部的优先事项，因为全球安全取决于非洲大陆的安全，而非洲大陆的安全需要军事领导人之间建立长期信任和共同目标的伙伴关系。他说：“没有一个安全、稳定和繁荣的非洲，全球安全是不可能的。我们将通过伙伴关系网络共同努力实现这一目标。没有一个国家能够独自做到这一点。这次活动的首要主题是“明天的安全需要今天的领导。”与会者在全体会议和分组会议上讨论了与国防领导力相关的话题，包括军事领导人面临的21世纪挑战、通过国防机构培养领导人以及多国环境下的国防领导力。活动还包括员工乘车前往美国内战战地安提坦国家威廉姆斯鼓励与会者在讨论中坦诚相见，以促进理解和持续的区域合作与协调，确保非洲的稳定与繁荣。他说：“世界是复杂和动态的，非洲军队面临着世界上最多样化的安全挑战：叛乱、武装冲突、非法贩运、海盗、有组织犯罪和暴力极端主义组织。”。“正如你所知，这些威胁是没有边界的――跨越边界、破坏地区稳定，而且往往需要协调的多国反应。军队当然不是非洲的解决方案，但肯定是解决方案的一部分。”

column2: 594th Transportation Company Homecoming Ceremony
column3: FORT CAMPBELL, KENTUCKY - Soldiers from the 594th Transportation Company, 129th Combat Sustainment Support Battalion, 101st Sustainment Brigade, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault), return to Fort Campbell, Kentucky, August 8, 2019, from a nine-month deployment to Kuwait in support of Operation Spartan Shield and Operation Inherent Resolve.
