column10: 19 AW继续推进ACE整合
column11: 2月20日，第61空运中队结束了为期一周的有机生成演习，展示了以机动空军和作战空军一体化为重点的敏捷作战使用（ACE）战术、技术和程序的有效性。这项被称为“卡塔琳娜武器混合器”的站外训练旨在整合三架C-130J超级大力士和六架A-10霹雳II型战机之间的作战，这些战机是从亚利桑那州的戴维斯-蒙坦空军基地分配给第354战斗机中队的。此次联合演习涵盖三个州、七个军事设施以及来自空中机动司令部、空战司令部、美国海军和美国海军陆战队的部队，验证了一小批C-130Js能够在几乎没有开销的情况下有效地支持多个联合用户。61岁的特雷弗・卡特勒（Trevor Cutler）是这次演习的飞行员和主要策划人之一。他说，卡塔琳娜武器混合器的首要目标之一是超越模拟ACE战术，而将演习用作真实世界实验和评估的场所。他说：“OST的最大目标是根据2018年国防战略规划和执行TTP，并响应参谋长的要求，加速变革。”。“因此，OST分为两条工作线：完善ACE战术、技术和程序，并以陌生的方式执行核心Herk能力。”随着空军各部队不断开发和完善其特定任务集的ACE外观，第19空运联队积极进行作战试验，以告知新出现的就业概念，以及C-130平台在这一更大的空军图景中的位置。“为了减少空军对大型海外基地的依赖，我们需要为决策者提供可靠的能力，整个部队必须变得更加灵活，”卡特勒说。“C-130J在地理、技术和文化上都处于完美的位置，有助于领导部队实现这一转型。”值得注意的是，ACE结构下的加油作业是OST寻求进一步评估的核心战术。在这次演习中，一架C-130J湿翼飞机向一辆R-11卡车卸下24000磅的燃油，然后在战略远征登陆场（SELF）的坡道上为两架a-10飞机加油，标志着AMC飞机首次通过TTP为CAF提供实际加油支持。“这是一项假设性能力，但据我们所知，以前从未进行过。”61岁的飞行员兼演习首席计划员亚历山大・汉弗莱上尉说。“进行燃料转移突出了该能力的一些局限性，并确定了我们在作战环境中执行此任务所需的微调。”根据卡特勒的说法，利用这个训练场地来加强对MAF和CAF资产的熟悉和整合也是OST的一个主要目标。这包括飞行两架C-130J和两架a-10沿低空航线模拟紧急情况，低成本、低空空投，磨练两支部队的空中护送技能。Cutler说：“在C-130J中，我们非常擅长在部署时所做的工作，并保持在大规模空投或空地行动中支持陆军的能力。但是，如果我们要在未来的冲突中保持灵活性和弹性，我们需要能够与空军中每一个想象得到的用户合作。“我们需要以一种有效的方式训练到不熟悉的地方，以突破我们舒适区的界限，并吸取适用于各种场景的经验教训。”他补充道。主要是在加利福尼亚州北岛海军航空站外作战，第61架战斗机为第354架FS提供的支援使A-10也能参加在加利福尼亚州二十九棕榈岛海军陆战队空地中心举行的“冬季狂暴21”海军陆战队演习。此外，C-130Js还提供了敏捷的作战空运ift在整个USMC演习期间，与5/11海军陆战队一起在加利福尼亚州彭德尔顿营地进行定位、解除定位和训练，为模拟火力执行两次高机动性火炮火箭系统（HIMARS）提升。卡特勒说：“海军陆战队做生意的方式不同于士兵或飞行员，学习如何直接与CAF用户进行计划，而无需像TACC（油轮空运控制中心）或AMD（空中机动部门）这样的中央计划机构，这是非常有价值的。”。“军队和整个政府的时间和资源都是有限的，因此我们需要能够有效地与联合部队的用户以及战士的心态进行整合。”为了让ACE发挥作用，该服务必须重新思考其运作方式。传统上，空军只有一个空军专业代码（AFSC）仅执行AFSC定义的任务和功能。然而，有了ACE，飞行员必须准备好并能够执行其他任务。这意味着小规模的飞行员团队必须具备“多功能”这就要求灵活性和变革。总体而言，OST集合了来自19空运联队内众多AFSC的25名人员，以评估多能力飞行员的概念。“我们从小石城带来的团队能够为我们在该领域面临的问题找到创造性的解决方案，”卡特勒说。“演习结束时，我们的装载机管理员在没有MPC（任务规划小组）或AMD的情况下参与了从维修到装载的计划。我们有美国海军陆战队人员支持小石城LRS（后勤准备中队），以确保我们带来的R-11燃料车能够飞回家。”卡特勒补充说，空军中的许多工作都是免费的“筒仓式”意味着军种总体上需要更好地掌握不同专业的职责或目标。“如果我们要成为CSAF和AMC指挥官所谈论的多才多艺的飞行员，我们需要提高意识，”他说。“我们的训练试图拥抱这种精神，即使在我们面临困难的时候，我们从个人和制度上都学到了难以置信的东西。”这项特别的OST证明了C-130J提供了显著的作战能力，可以直接转化为提高战斗力。汉弗莱说：“C-130J是国防部为数不多的专门用于战术空运任务的飞机之一。”。“从支持军队与CAF和USMC更深层次融合的传统角色中走出来，表明我们的社区在我们可以做什么以及我们可以作为联合作战伙伴与谁融合方面是多么灵活。”

column2: Crew chief apprentice earns ACE award
column3:
SHEPPARD AIR FORCE BASE, Texas --
 Nine blocks. Eighty training days. Six hundred forty hours of hard work and concentration. This is what it takes to become an Air Force crew chief apprentice.

Airman 1st Class Christian Fischer, a Wisconsin native and Sheppard AFB 362nd Training Squadron crew chief apprentice course student, did what it takes and more.

Fischer completed the training with a score of 100 percent on every progress check and block test, earning himself the ace award.

Rank and Name: Airman 1st Class Christian Fischer

Unit: 115th Fighter Wing, Truax Field Air National Guard Base, Madison, Wisconsin

Duty title: F-16 crew chief apprentice

Hometown: Sun Prairie, Wisconsin

Time in Service: 4 months

Why you joined the Air Force: To serve the country and get an education

Family: Parents, Anne and Bruce (both retired lieutenant colonel); siblings, Adam (staff sergeant) and Luke

Hobbies: Playing the guitar and trumpet, hiking, camping and snowboarding

Favorite aspect of the job: Working with my hands and being able to see the results of my work

Most memorable Air Force experience: Graduating basic military training

How do you make responsible choices: By always having a plan and trusting my wingmen

Instructor comment: “In my entire career, I have never heard of someone getting the ace award, which makes this achievement very momentous. This award takes a lot of determination and hard work to accomplish. Airman 1st Class Fischer has displayed this determination throughout the entire course and displays the whole Airman concept by leading his class and aiding them to achieve better grades and floor task completion.” C Staff Sgt. Kenneth Evans, 362nd TRS crew chief apprentice course instructor
column9: 威奇托瀑布，德克萨斯州，美国
column10: 船员首席学徒获ACE奖
column11: 德克萨斯州谢泼德空军基地――九个街区。80个训练日。640小时的努力工作和专注。这就是成为空军机组首席学徒所需要的。一级飞行员克里斯蒂安・菲舍尔，威斯康星州人，Sheppard AFB第362训练中队机组首席学徒课程的学生，做了所需要的和更多的事情。菲舍尔以100%的成绩完成了每项进度检查和模块测试，获得ace奖。军衔和姓名：飞行员一级克里斯蒂安・费舍尔部队：威斯康辛州麦迪逊市特鲁克斯空军国民警卫队基地第115战斗机联队工业头衔：F-16机组首席学徒家乡：威斯康辛州太阳草原服役时间：4个月为什么加入空军：为国家服务并接受教育家庭：父母，安妮和布鲁斯（都是退役中校）；兄弟姐妹，亚当（上士）和卢克霍比：弹吉他和小号，徒步旅行，露营和滑雪板工作中最喜欢的方面：用手工作，并能看到我的工作成果最难忘的空军经历：毕业基本军事训练如何做出负责任的选择：始终有一个计划并相信我的僚机教员评论：“在我的整个职业生涯中，我从来没有听说过有人获得ace奖，这使得这一成就非常重要。这一奖项需要很大的决心和努力才能完成。一级飞行员费舍尔在整个过程中都表现出了这种决心，并通过领导他的班级和帮助them以实现更好的成绩和完成地面任务。”C参谋中士Kenneth Evans，第362 TRS乘员首席学徒课程讲师

column2: AC-130U Spooky Gunship Rolls Into Retirement
column3:
The last armed AC-130U “Spooky” gunship, tail number 513, retired to the 309th Aerospace Maintenance and Regeneration Group at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base, Ariz., Aug. 19, 2019.

This aircraft was the last AC-130U with its guns still installed and one of the very last to retire altogether.

The AC-130 has a rich history that includes support of military operations in Vietnam, Panama and Iraq as well as performing in many combat missions since it was fielded in the late 1960’s. The primary function of this aircraft was close air support, air interdiction and armed reconnaissance.

“This aircraft has provided tons of close air support,” said Brig. Gen. Brenda Cartier, Director of Operations for Air Force Special Operations Command. “There’s no telling how many lives of friendly ground forces it has saved over its time in service.”

Brig. Gen. Cartier flew the AC-130U to its final resting spot at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base from Hurlburt Field, Florida.

“It’s very bittersweet,” Cartier said. “I came onboard with the ‘Spooky’ gunships in 1997 so I’ve been with them most of my career.”

The AC-130U Spooky II and its crews have been deployed constantly for nearly two decades. The AC-130U will now be replaced by the AC-130J “Ghostrider.” AFSOC is slated to have completely converted to the fourth-series gunships in 2021. 

“The Air Force is moving to the next variant of the AC-130, the J-model, which is a very capable aircraft with new technology and a lot more weaponry,” Cartier said.

America is building a more lethal and ready Air Force through development of our warfighting capabilities.

Story was originally posted to the Davis-Monthan website on Aug. 21, 2019, and may be found at https://www.dm.af.mil/Media/Article-View/Article/1940777/ac-130u-spooky-gunship-rolls-into-retirement/
column9: 美国亚利桑那州图森
column10: AC-130U恐怖武装直升机退役
column11: 8月19日，最后一艘武装的AC-130U“幽灵”武装直升机（机尾号513）在亚利桑那州戴维斯-蒙坦空军基地的第309航空航天维修和再生小组退役，2019年。这架飞机是最后一架安装了火炮的AC-130U，也是最后一架完全退役的飞机之一。AC-130有着丰富的历史，包括支持越南、巴拿马和伊拉克的军事行动，以及自1960年代末部署以来执行的多个作战任务。这架飞机的主要功能是近距离空中支援、空中拦截和武装侦察。“这架飞机提供了数吨的近距离空中支援，”布里格说。Brenda Cartier将军，空军特种作战司令部作战总监。“不知道在服役期间它挽救了多少友军地面部队的生命。”布里格说。卡地亚将军将AC-130U从佛罗里达州赫尔伯特菲尔德飞到戴维斯-蒙坦空军基地的最后一个休息点。卡地亚说：“这真是苦乐参半。”。“我在1997年随“幽灵”武装直升机上船，所以我职业生涯的大部分时间都与他们在一起。”AC-130U“幽灵II”及其机组人员在近二十年来一直在不断部署。AC-130U现在将被AC-130J“Ghostrider”取代。AFSOC计划在2021年完全转换为第四系列武装直升机。卡地亚说：“美国空军正在转向AC-130的下一个变种，即J-model，这是一种功能强大的飞机，拥有新技术和更多的武器。”美国正在通过发展我们的作战能力来建设一支更具杀伤力和准备就绪的空军。这篇报道最初于2019年8月21日发布在Davis Monthan网站上，可在https://www.dm.af.mil/Media/Article-View/Article/1940777/ac-130u-spooky-gunship-rolls-into-retirement/

column2: Ohio native ACEs Aerospace Propulsion course
column3:
SHEPPARD AIR FORCE BASE, Texas --
As with success, making a positive impact on someone is noticeable … after a long, long and (sometimes) tortuous process. Whether working to get good grades or working to see a friend get back on their feet you most likely won't see results right away. But that's when diligence and perseverance comes in. When people see success, that's all they see. They do not see the sweat, the calloused hands, the exhausted eyes. The people see the successful people triumphantly walking out of the fires, but not the burns on their back. Getting an award like this is not easy, but Airman 1st Class Girardot enjoys the challenge, and that's why he is one of the few to ACE this course.

Girardot was awarded the ACE award after passing the Aerospace Propulsion apprentice course at Sheppard AFB, the course consists of nine blocks of instruction fit into 72 days.

 

Rank / Name: A1C Alexander N. Girardot

Unit: 361 TRS with assignment to 718th AMXS, Kadena AB Japan

Duty title: Aerospace Propulsion Apprentice

Hometown:  Dayton, Ohio

Time in Service: 6 Months

Why you joined: I wanted to do something that would be a positive impact on people’s lives.

Family: Mother: Jennifer Holbrook, Step-Father: Jeremy Holbrook, Step-Brothers’: Jacob, Caleb and Quinten Holbrook, Grandmother: Deborah Girardot, Grandfather: Jack Girardot and Great Grandmother: Jakie Stutz

Hobbies: Riding my motorcycle, trying new things, road trips, outdoor activites, video games and spending times with friends

Favorite aspect of job: The satisfaction of completing a long and difficult task.

Most memorable Air Force experience: Serving in the airman leadership program.

How do you make responsible choices: I ask myself what my grandmother would think

Instructor: Mr. Gaylon Hawkins

Question for Instructor: The turboprop apprentice course encompasses three engine systems and two propeller systems. The Rolls Royce T56-A-15 and AE2100D3 turboprop engines are used on C-130 aircraft. The General Electric T700-701C turboshaft engine is installed on the HH-60G Pave Hawk helicopter. The Dowty propeller is installed on the C-130J and the Hamilton Standard propeller is installed on the C-130H aircraft.  The course is divided into nine blocks of instruction in 72 days. To ACE this course is uncommon. In my 19 years of instruction only six have achieved this honor. A1C Girardot’s strong work ethic and professionalism are key to his success. He truly reveals the standard of the total Airman.
column6: SHEPPARD AIR FORCE BASE, TX, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国德克萨斯州谢帕德空军基地
column10: 俄亥俄州本土ACEs航空推进课程
column11: 德克萨斯州谢泼德空军基地――与成功一样，在经历了漫长、漫长（有时）曲折的过程后，对某人产生积极影响是显而易见的。无论是为了取得好成绩还是为了看到朋友重新站起来，你很可能不会马上看到结果。但这正是勤奋和毅力的体现。当人们看到成功，那就是他们所看到的一切。他们看不到汗水、长满老茧的手和疲惫的眼睛。人们看到的是成功人士胜利地走出火海，而不是他们背上的烧伤。获得这样的奖项并不容易，但一级飞行员吉拉多喜欢挑战，这就是为什么他是少数在这门课程中取得优异成绩的人之一。吉拉多在通过谢泼德空军基地航空推进学徒课程后获得了ACE奖，本课程由九个教学模块组成，共72天。等级/名称：A1C Alexander N.GirardotUnit:361 TRS，分配给日本嘉手纳第718 AMXS，标题：航空航天推进学徒：代顿，服役时间：6个月加入原因：我想做一些对人们生活有积极影响的事情家庭：母亲：詹妮弗・霍尔布鲁克继父：杰里米・霍尔布鲁克继兄弟：雅各布、卡莱布和昆顿・霍尔布鲁克祖母：黛博拉・吉拉多，祖父：杰克・吉拉多和曾祖母：杰基・斯图茨爱好：骑摩托车，尝试新事物，公路旅行，户外活动，电子游戏和与朋友共度时光避免了工作的另一个方面：完成一项长期而艰巨的任务的满足感。最难忘的空军经历：在飞行员领导计划中服役。你如何做出负责任的选择：我问自己我祖母会怎么想教练：盖伦・霍金斯涡轮螺旋桨学徒课程包括三个发动机系统和两个螺旋桨系统。劳斯莱斯T56-A-15和AE2100D3涡轮螺旋桨发动机用于C-130飞机。通用电气T700-701C涡轴发动机安装在HH-60G Pave Hawk直升机上。道蒂螺旋桨安装在C-130J上，汉密尔顿标准螺旋桨安装在C-130H飞机上。本课程在72天内分为九个教学单元。在这门课上取得优异成绩是很少见的。在我19年的教学生涯中，只有6人获得了这个荣誉。A1C吉拉多强烈的职业道德和专业精神是他成功的关键。他真实地揭示了全体飞行员的水平。

column2: 726th ACS conducts deployment training exercise
column3:
During the exercise, 726th Airmen aim to sharpen their skills, increase their mobility, and enhance their readiness to execute their command and control mission down range.

The orders for the exercise were issued July 9, 2019, at which time the 726th ACS began “pack up”, which is the first phase of their process to set up their operations on a simulated Mobile Operating Air Base (MOAB).

This required them to do maintenance on vehicles, inventory, vehicle weight checks, accountability of manning, and secure cargo to be transported on their Medium Tactical Vehicle (MTV).

One of the goals for the 726th ACS was to pack up their MTV’s with the shelters, communication systems, tents and tools needed for the exercise and leave for MOAB within 72 hours. 

“We’re focused on mobilizing, deploying and employing,” said Chief Master Sgt. Michael Lopez, 726th ACS director of operations.

Establishing their operating area on the MOAB requires the 726th ACS to conduct security checks, hazard checks, Chemical, Biological, Radiological Nuclear and Explosive materials (CBRNE), and Mission Oriented Protective Posture (MOPP) procedures.

Additionally, grounding circuits will be used to enable net communication equipment, radar systems and generators to be set up and remain secure and protected from electrical damage. They’ll also be able to communicate with the various fighter squadrons who are participating in Gunfighter Flag.

“The whole point of the exercise is to increase readiness,” said Lt. Col. Richard Barber, 726th ACS commander. “We want to focus on cultivating those skill sets needed to mobilize our system.”

This story was published July 6, 2019 at https://www.mountainhome.af.mil/News/Article-Display/Article/1904024/726th-acs-conducts-deployment-training-exercise/
column6: MOUNTAIN HOME AIR FORCE BASE, ID, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国印第安纳州山地家园空军基地
column10: 726 ACS进行部署训练演习
column11: 在这次演习中，726航空兵的目标是提高他们的技能，增加他们的机动性，并增强他们执行远程指挥和控制任务的准备。演习命令于2019年7月9日发布，此时726 ACS开始“打包”，这是他们在模拟移动作战空军基地（MOAB）上建立作战的第一阶段。这要求他们对车辆进行维护、库存、车辆重量检查、人员配备问责，并确保在中型战术车辆（MTV）上运输的货物安全。第726届ACS的目标之一是在72小时内将MTV打包，配备演习所需的避难所、通信系统、帐篷和工具，前往摩押。“我们专注于动员、部署和使用，”第726届ACS行动总监迈克尔・洛佩兹少校说。在摩押建立他们的行动区需要第726届ACS进行安全检查、危险检查、化学、生物、放射性核和爆炸材料（CBRNE），此外，接地电路将用于设置网络通信设备、雷达系统和发电机，并保持安全，防止电气损坏。他们还可以与参加“枪战旗帜”演习的各个战斗机中队进行沟通。“演习的全部目的是提高战备状态，”ACS第726指挥官理查德・巴伯中校（Richard Barber）说。“我们希望专注于培养动员我们系统所需的技能。”这篇文章发表于2019年7月6日的https://www.mountainhome.af.mil/News/Article-Display/Article/1904024/726th-acs-conducts-deployment-training-exercise/

column2: Guardians of the Last Frontier honor triple ace
column3:
EIELSON AIR FORCE BASE, Alaska ― “I feel that I could probably take on the whole North Korean army myself right now,” said the 43-year-old from Los Angeles. “You are bulletproof once you grow a mustache ― that’s straight from Robin Olds.” 

This quote is from a 2018 Stars and Stripes article about Airmen at Kunsan Air Base, South Korea, celebrating “Mustache March” and remembering the service of Robin Olds. 

Olds was a triple ace, scoring his first 12 kills while flying a P-38 Lighting and P-51 Mustang during World War II. During the Vietnam War he flew the F-4 Phantom, shooting down four enemy jets, and growing his iconic handlebar mustache. 

“It became the middle finger I couldn’t raise in the [public relations] photographs,” Olds once said. “The mustache became my silent last word in the verbal battles … with higher headquarters on rules, targets and fighting the war.”

Many of those who serve now might not be looking for a way to “raise the middle finger as a silent word,” yet Airmen of the 168th Wing did observe the distinguished aviator.
 
Chief Master Sgt. Clint Miller, 168th Logistics Readiness Squadron vehicle fleet manager, said, “I support Mustache March in honor of Robin Olds and my perception of the spirit of the USAF. The innovators that tread on the fringes of our established norms and sometimes blast through the barriers of how we do things are a unique breed and this simple, unruly, ‘out of regs’ mustache is my salute to thinking outside of the box.”

Several of them said they participated in the annual event to show respect, honor and thankfulness to the legendary heroes and patriots of our Air Force past. Others spoke about Air Force heritage and leadership by example, or how growing a mustache is a conversation starter that allowed them to talk about Air Force history while paying homage to those who paved the way for today’s Airmen.
 
Some unit members had different interpretations of Mustache March.
 
One deployed Airman said, “I mainly do it to be comic relief. March happened to be the last full month of my deployment and I knew that letting it grow out would be some cheap entertainment for my flight over here.”

Entertainment motivated many unit members to grow mustaches, knowing that their haphazardly grown facial hair would start dialogues or sometimes incite laughter, both motives that boosted unit morale and camaraderie.
 
For reasons unknown, a large number of maintenance personnel take part in the tradition.
 
“I participate in Mustache March because it is part of our Air Force heritage from a time when our country was in a bit of political turmoil and an Air Force officer decided to push back a little about things that didn’t matter and tried to focus our Airmen on things that did matter. I think we need to get there again,” said Master Sgt. Ray Allen, production superintendent with the 168th Aircraft Maintenance Squadron.

Maybe it is fitting to close this out with an Airman who has been a member of the 168th Wing since its inception in 1986, Senior Master Sgt. Bob Fine, 168th Maintenance Group plans and scheduling noncommissioned officer in charge.

Fine is currently deployed to Southwest Asia and said, “It’s a tradition every year in maintenance [so] I thought I would get a jump on growing my ‘just because I can’ facial hair heading into retirement.”
 
He will retire this year shortly after returning home.

Come April 1, though, most of these furry expressions are washed away.
column6: EIELSON AIR FORCE BASE, AK, UNITED STATES
column9: 艾尔森空军基地，AK，美国
column10: 最后边疆卫士荣誉三重王牌
column11: 阿拉斯加州艾尔森空军基地――“我觉得我现在很可能自己就能打败整个朝鲜军队，”这位43岁的洛杉矶人说。“一旦你长出了胡子，你就是防弹的――这是罗宾・奥尔兹直接说的。”这句话摘自2018年《星条旗》杂志上一篇关于韩国昆山空军基地飞行员庆祝“胡子游行”并纪念罗宾・奥尔兹服役的文章。奥尔兹是一名三重王牌选手，在二战期间驾驶P-38照明和P-51野马时，他先杀了12人。在越南战争期间，他驾驶F-4幻影，击落了四架敌机，并蓄起了标志性的手把胡子。奥尔兹曾说：“它成了我在（公共关系）照片中无法举起的中指。”。“胡子成了我在口头战斗中沉默的最后一句话……与上级司令部就规则、目标和战争进行交锋。”现在服役的许多人可能不会想办法“举起中指作为沉默的话语”，但168联队的飞行员确实观察到了这位杰出的飞行员。首席少校克林特・米勒，第168后勤准备中队车队经理说，“我支持为纪念罗宾・奥尔兹和我对美国空军精神的理解而进行的胡子游行。踩在我们既定规范边缘，有时冲破我们做事方式的障碍的创新者是一个独特的品种，这种简单、不受约束的“脱节”胡子是我对跳出框框思考的致敬。”他们中的一些人说，他们参加了一年一度的活动，以表达对我们空军历史上传奇英雄和爱国者的尊重、荣誉和感谢。其他人则谈到了空军的传统和领导榜样，或者说留胡子是一个如何让他们在向空军致敬的同时谈论空军历史的话题那些为今天的飞行员铺平道路的人。一些部队成员对胡子游行有不同的解释。一名部署的飞行员说：“我这么做主要是为了喜剧性的缓解。三月恰好是我部署的最后一个月，我知道让它长出来对我飞到这里来说是一种廉价的娱乐。”娱乐活动促使许多部队成员留胡子，因为他们知道自己随意长出的面部毛发会引发对话，有时会引发笑声，这两种动机都能提高部队士气和同志情谊。出于未知的原因，大量维修人员参与了这一传统。“我参加胡子游行是因为它是我们空军传统的一部分，当时我们的国家正处于政治动荡之中，一名空军军官决定对无关紧要的事情稍作退让，并试图让我们的飞行员专注于真正重要的事情。我想我们需要再次做到这一点。”第168飞机维修中队的生产主管雷・艾伦上士说。也许应该与自1986年成立以来一直是第168联队成员的一名飞行员、第168维修小组计划和调度士官鲍勃・费恩高级上士（Bob Fine）达成协议。费恩目前是d他来到了亚洲西南部，说：“这是每年保养的传统，所以我想我会在退休前把我的“因为我能行”的面部毛发剪掉。”他今年回家后不久就会退休。不过，到了4月1日，这些毛茸茸的表情大部分都被洗掉了。

column2: CIWT Cryptology Courses Undergo ACE Review
column3:
PENSACOLA, Fla. -- Members of the American Council on Education (ACE) visited the Center for Information Warfare Training (CIWT) to evaluate six cryptology courses offered by the Information Warfare Training Command (IWTC) Corry Station, May 1-2.

The team reviewed five courses related to the cryptologic technician (technical) (CTT) rating as well as the Cryptologic Warfare Officer Basic Course. Their review included an examination of each course curriculum as well as interviews with enlisted and senior enlisted CTTs.

ACE recommends equivalent college credits for members of the armed forces for certain types of military training and service experiences, based on high quality standards of practice. They provide a collaborative link between the U.S. Department of Defense and higher education through their evaluation process.

“We want to ensure our Sailors are getting their skills reflected as college credits that will help them not only advance professionally, but also help them along the path to success when they transition to the civilian world,” said Denise Myers from CIWT’s training directorate. “We ensure that our courses are up to date with the latest industry requirements and what they are learning is relevant outside of the Navy as well.”

ACE occupation reviews are focused on validating the Navy’s job standards and expectations. Before the interviews begin, faculty evaluators review the occupation description, occupation standards, job task analysis and manuals used on the job.

A final report that outlines the consensus on the alignment of credit recommendations for the occupation is usually completed by the ACE team within 30 working days of the evaluation. The credit recommendations determined by ACE appear on the service member’s Joint Services Transcript (JST).

Each of the ratings taught at CIWT receives an ACE evaluation every 10 years at a minimum.

Center for Information Warfare Training delivers trained information warfare professionals to the Navy and joint services, enabling optimal performance of information warfare across the full spectrum of military operations.

For more news from Center for Information Warfare Training organization, visit http://www.navy.mil/local/cid/, http://www.netc.navy.mil/centers/ciwt/, http://www.facebook.com/NavyCIWT, or http://www.twitter.com/NavyCIWT.
column9: 彭萨科拉，佛罗里达州，美国
column10: CIWT密码学课程接受ACE审查
column11: 佛罗里达州彭萨科拉――5月1日至2日，美国教育委员会（ACE）成员访问了信息战训练中心（CIWT），以评估信息战训练司令部（IWTC）科里站提供的六门密码学课程。该小组审查了与密码学技术员（技术）（CTT）相关的五门课程以及密码学作战军官基础课程。他们的审查包括对每门课程的审查，以及对入伍和高级入伍CTT的采访。ACE根据高质量的实践标准，建议武装部队成员在某些类型的军事训练和服役经历方面获得同等的大学学分。他们通过评估过程在美国国防部和高等教育之间建立了协作联系。CIWT培训董事会的丹尼斯・迈尔斯（Denise Myers）说：“我们希望确保我们的水手们将他们的技能体现为大学学分，这不仅有助于他们在专业上的提升，而且有助于他们在向平民世界过渡的过程中走向成功。”。“我们确保我们的课程符合最新的行业要求，他们所学的内容也与海军以外的相关。”ACE职业审查的重点是验证海军的工作标准和期望。在面试开始之前，教员评估员审查职业描述、职业标准、工作任务分析和工作中使用的手册。最终报告概述了关于职业信用建议一致性的共识通常由ACE团队在评估后30个工作日内完成。ACE确定的信用建议出现在服务成员的联合服务记录（JST）上。CIWT教授的每个评级至少每10年接受一次ACE评估。信息战训练中心为海军和联合军种提供训练有素的信息战专业人员，使信息战在整个军事行动中发挥最佳性能。有关信息战训练中心的更多新闻，请参阅信息战训练组织，参观http://www.navy.mil/local/cid/, http://www.netc.navy.mil/centers/ciwt/, http://www.facebook.com/NavyCIWT或http://www.twitter.com/NavyCIWT.

column2: A guide to ace-ing the new academic year
column3:
School starts on Aug. 7 and 8 for Hawaii’s public school students, and many campuses are hosting orientations, school-supply drop-offs and other new-school events to get students and parents ready to get back in the classrooms. (See the list of orientations below or contact your child’s school for more information.)

This is especially helpful for military families who are constantly on the move and must regularly navigate the process of enrolling children in a new school system. 

The Hawaii State Department of Education estimates that the Aloha State is the temporary or long-term home for over 300,000 military personnel and their families. Military children make up about 8 percent of the state’s public school enrollment and Hawaii has the highest number of military dependent children per capita in the nation, according to the HIDOE website.

“Going to these orientations gives families an opportunity to meet the principal, staff and teachers at their child’s school,” said Cherry Torres Okahara, the military school liaison for HIDOE. 

She said that parents who reach out to the schools and the various military School Liaison Offices are less likely to be stressed because they have taken the opportunity to have their questions answered and concerns addressed. 

She also encouraged military families to familiarize themselves with their children’s school curriculum and interests. Students who join clubs or try out for sports are more likely to be involved in their new school and less likely feel alienated and homesick, she said. 

The HIDOE has many resources to help military families with school-age children, including a page on its website dedicated to answering those questions most frequently asked by service members (visit hawaiipublicschools.org and search “military faq”). 

What follows is a roundup of general information to help families start the school year on the right foot. (More specific information may be found by visiting hawaiipublicschools.org and searching “how to enroll.”)

Bus Service
School bus service is available for students from kindergarten to fifth grade who live a mile or more from their school. It’s available to students in sixth to 12th grade who live a mile and a half or more from their school. Students who do not meet these criteria may be able to receive the service on a space available basis. 

Free bus passes are available to students who qualify for HIDOE’s free lunch program, students who are foster children, students who are homeless, students whose special education plan includes regular transportation as a related service, students who are directed to attend a school outside their district and students who have three older siblings who are fare-paying bus riders. 

For more information on the school bus program, including cost and routes, visit your school’s office and the HIDOE website (hawaiischools.org and search “bus service”). 

Takai Transition Centers
Named for the late U.S. Rep. Mark Takai, these transition centers and their affiliated programs connect new students with student ambassadors who conduct school tours, arrange group lunches and offer social and academic support throughout the school year.

Most of the Army-impacted schools on the island have a Takai Transition Center.

Torres Okahara singled out the centers at Leilehua High School and Aliamanu Elementary School as being outstanding examples. 
Daniel K. Inouye Elementary School and Solomon Elementary School on Schofield Barracks also have Takai Transition Centers as does Wheeler Elementary and Middle schools. 

Contact your child’s school to find out whether it has a Takai Transition Center on campus.  

Traffic and Safety
With the start of the school year comes increased traffic. Guardians dropping off students in the morning and picking them up after school should plan accordingly.

Also, be aware of policies regarding school-age children on any of U.S. Army Garrison-Hawaii’s installations. Children younger than 10 are not allowed to be unsupervised at bus stops, recreation areas and public facilities, nor are they allowed to walk to or from school alone. 

Motorists should be aware of increased pedestrian traffic near schools and crosswalks and exercise caution. 

7th Grade Physical Exams
New for the 2017-2018 academic school year is the HIDOE requirement that all students complete a physical examination one year prior to enrolling in the seventh grade. These exams are covered by the Affordable Healthcare Act. For more information visit hawaiipublicschools.org and search “7th grade physical exam.”

Under Construction
Construction at the new Solomon Elementary School campus on Schofield Barracks will be underway during the upcoming school year. Because the new campus is adjacent to the current campus, the school has had to make some adjustments. 

? A barrier around the construction site will help mitigate noise.
?The kindergarten playground gate will open at 7:30 a.m. and families with strollers may congregate there before the first school bell rings at 7:50 a.m. The Designated stroller areas will conserve space, which will be extremely limited due to construction.  
?The gate at the corner of Trimble and Carpenter streets will no longer be available; families are asked to access the campus through the other available gates. 
?The school’s courtyard will be closed for improvements to create additional green space. The surrounding walkways will be congested. Families, especially those with strollers, are asked wish their first to fifth grade students well in the front play space. Staff will be available to help students find their classrooms. 

Orientations
Below is orientation information for schools in and around U.S. Army Garrison-Hawaii. A full list of military-impacted schools in Hawaii is available at hawaiipublicschools.org.

column9: 瓦希瓦，你好，美国
column10: 在新学年取得优异成绩的指南
column11: 夏威夷公立学校的学生将于8月7日和8日开学，许多校园正在举办定向活动、学校用品发放和其他新的学校活动，让学生和家长做好重返教室的准备。（请参阅下面的方向列表或联系您孩子的学校以了解更多信息。）这对经常外出的军人家庭尤其有用，他们必须定期了解新学校系统中的儿童入学流程。夏威夷州教育部估计，阿罗哈州是30多万军人及其家属的临时或长期住所。根据HIDOE网站的数据，军校儿童约占该州公立学校入学人数的8%，夏威夷的人均军校儿童人数是全国最高的。“参加这些定向活动，让家庭有机会与孩子所在学校的校长、工作人员和教师见面。”HIDOE军校联络人Cherry Torres Okahara说。她说，接触学校和各军校联络处的家长不太可能感到压力，因为他们利用这个机会回答了他们的问题，解决了他们的担忧。她还鼓励军人家庭熟悉子女的学校课程和兴趣。她说，参加俱乐部或参加体育活动的学生更有可能进入新学校，也不太可能感到疏远和想家。HIDOE有很多资源帮助有学龄儿童的军人家庭，包括其网站上的一个页面，专门回答军人最常问的问题（访问hawaiiplicschools.org并搜索“军人常见问题”）。以下是帮助家庭正确开始新学年的一般信息综述。（更多具体信息请访问hawaiiplicschools.org并搜索“如何注册”）校车服务校车服务适用于从幼儿园到五年级居住在离学校一英里或一英里以上的学生。六年级到十二年级的学生，住在离学校一英里半或更远的地方，都可以使用。不符合这些标准的学生可以在可用空间的基础上接受服务。有资格参加HIDOE免费午餐计划的学生、寄养儿童学生、无家可归的学生、特殊教育计划包括定期交通作为相关服务的学生均可获得免费巴士通行证，被要求在所在地区以外的学校上学的学生，以及有三个哥哥姐姐的学生，他们都是付车费的公交车乘客。有关校车计划的更多信息，包括费用和路线，请访问学校办公室和HIDOE网站（hawaiischools.org并搜索“校车服务”）。Takai过渡中心为已故美国众议员Mark Takai设计，这些过渡中心及其附属项目将新生与学生大使联系起来，学生大使负责学校参观，在整个学年安排集体午餐，并提供社会和学术支持。岛上大多数受军队影响的学校都有一个高井过渡中心。Torres Okahara将雷乐华高中和Aliamanu小学的中心作为突出的例子。Schofield兵营上的Daniel K.Inouye小学和Solomon小学也有Takai过渡中心，惠勒小学和中学也是如此。联系您孩子的学校，了解学校是否在校园内设有Takai过渡中心。交通与安全随着学年的开始，交通量增加了。监护人在早上接送学生并在放学后接送他们时应做出相应的计划。此外，还应了解有关美国驻夏威夷部队设施中学龄儿童的政策。不允许10岁以下的儿童在公共汽车站、娱乐区和公共设施无人看管，也不允许他们独自步行上学或放学。驾驶人士应留意学校及人行横道附近的行人流量增加,并小心驾驶。七年级体检2017-2018学年的新规定是HIDOE要求所有学生在七年级入学前一年完成体检。这些检查受平价医疗法案的保护。欲了解更多信息，请访问hawaiiplicschools.org并搜索“7年级体检”。Schofield兵营新所罗门小学校园的施工将在下一学年进行。由于新校区与现有校区相邻，学校不得不做出一些调整施工现场周围的障碍物将有助于降低噪音。?幼儿园操场大门将在上午7:30打开，在上午7:50第一次上课铃响之前，带婴儿车的家庭可能会聚集在那里。指定的婴儿车区域将节省空间，这将因施工而受到极大限制。?Trimble街和Carpenter街拐角处的大门将不再可用；家庭被要求通过其他可用的大门进入校园学校的庭院将关闭以进行改善，以创造更多的绿地。周围的人行道将会拥挤不堪。家庭，尤其是那些有婴儿车的家庭，被要求祝愿他们的一年级到五年级的学生在前面的游戏空间玩得好。工作人员将帮助学生找到教室。以下方向是美国驻夏威夷部队及其周围学校的方向信息。夏威夷受军事影响的学校的完整列表可在HawaiPublicSchools.org.Fort Shafter/Aliamanaliamanu小学Fort Shafter盐湖大道3265号获得。（808-421-4280）8月2日上午8:Meet and greet/open house Shafter小学2 Fort Shafter（808-832-3560）8月4日上午9:School Reading time（关于公共汽车票、午餐付款、a+计划、CYS计划、校服等的信息）8月4日下午3:open house Aliamanu中学Fort Shafter盐湖大道3271号。（808-421-4100）8月7日，上午8:15：学校食堂家长入职培训霍菲尔德军营丹尼尔K.伊诺耶小学Waianae和Ayers column2: ACS helping soldiers after hurricane Matthew
column3:
The Center provides emergency food assistance, legal assistance for damage claims, evacuation travel order assistance and Military Family Life Counselors assistance. The Center is a central location for any help Soldiers, family members and retirees may need.
	The EFAC will help provide short and long-term recovery aid to anyone around Fort Stewart and Hunter Army Airfield. After hurricane Matthew, people who had been affected by the storm are looking for any help they can get. 
	“We went through a similar situation with the tornado in February,” said Tonya Imus, the Supervisory Mobilization, Deployment and Stability Support Operations program manager here. “People feel overwhelmed after a severe weather incident. They don’t want to run all over post looking for the help they need.”
	Imus’s home is still without power. Despite this, she still helped set up the EFAC so that people can get the help that they need. 
	“We assist people to help themselves,” said Imus. “It’s about getting people back to the new normal as quickly as possible.”
	Throughout the day there was a steady stream of Soldiers and families that were looking for recovery assistance from the hurricane. One such Soldier who was seeking aid at the EFAC was Spc. Cronje Helm, a cable systems installer-maintainer with the 123rd Division Signal Battalion. 
Helm is living in the barracks on post and needed to replace the perishables he lost due to the hurricane. The EFAC was offering vouchers to help anyone who had suffered from this.  
	“I was crushed to lose the food,” said Helm. “I got the message about the food vouchers and felt that there was some hope left.”
	Service providers at the EFAC help Soldiers such as Helm receive the help that they need. One service provider is James Fleming, the Financial Readiness program manager at the EFAC. Fleming was one of the main individuals responsible for helping Soldiers, family members and retirees receive food assistance. 
	“We’ve had a plethora of individuals come in to assist the Soldiers, family members and retirees whose homes have been damaged during the hurricane,” Fleming said. “It warms your heart to provide assistance to those individuals that are in need.”
column9: 美国佐治亚州斯图尔特堡
column10: 飓风“马修”过后，ACS在帮助士兵
column11: 该中心提供紧急食品援助、损害索赔的法律援助、疏散旅行订单援助和军事家庭生活顾问援助。该中心是士兵、家庭成员和退休人员可能需要的任何帮助的中心。EFAC将帮助斯图尔特堡和亨特陆军机场周围的任何人提供短期和长期恢复援助。“马修”飓风过后，受飓风影响的人们正在寻求他们能得到的任何帮助。“我们在2月份经历了类似的龙卷风情况，”监管动员、部署和稳定支持行动项目经理Tonya Imus说。“在恶劣天气事件后，人们感到不知所措。他们不想到处奔波寻找他们需要的帮助。”艾默斯的家仍然没有电。尽管如此，她仍然帮助建立了EFAC，以便人们能够得到他们需要的帮助。“我们帮助人们自助，”伊默斯说。“这是为了让人们尽快回到新的正常状态。”一整天都有源源不断的士兵和家庭从飓风中寻求恢复援助。其中一名在EFAC寻求帮助的士兵是Spc.Cronje Helm，他是123师信号营的电缆系统安装维护人员。赫尔姆住在哨所的营房里，需要更换因飓风而丢失的易腐物品。EFAC正在提供代金券，以帮助任何遭受这种情况的人。“我被压垮了，失去了食物，”赫尔姆说。“我得到了关于食品券的信息，觉得还有一些希望。”EFAC的服务提供商帮助士兵，如赫尔姆，获得他们需要的帮助。其中一家服务提供商是EFAC财务准备项目经理詹姆斯・弗莱明（James Fleming）。弗莱明是负责帮助士兵、家庭成员和退休人员获得粮食援助的主要人员之一。弗莱明说：“我们已经有过多的人前来帮助在飓风中房屋遭到破坏的士兵、家庭成员和退休人员。”。“为那些需要帮助的人提供帮助会温暖你的心。”

column2: Longtime ACS volunteer to be recognized with award for service
column3:
JOINT BASE MYER-HENDERSON HALL, Va. - As a volunteer with Army Community Service on Joint Base Myer-Henderson Hall, retired Army Lt. Col. C.J. Buche contributed 3,758 hours of service over five years. In April, she’ll receive the Emma Marie Baird Award at the JBM-HH Volunteer Recognition Award Ceremony for her efforts.

The award is presented annually by the Department of the Army in recognition of those who have contributed “outstanding service” to ACS, according to the award’s official website.

Buche is an Army veteran and military spouse to retired Army Lt. Col. Joe Buche, former commander of the 3rd U.S. Infantry Regiment (The Old Guard). She began her volunteer work when she was still in uniform, working as a Family Readiness Group adviser to help Soldiers and their families find necessary resources and prepare for deployments.

After retiring from the Army, Buche said she volunteered in her local community and at church, and while those were great experiences, she missed that connection she had forged with Soldiers and their loved ones.

“For me, I get so much out of interacting with people,” Buche told the Pentagram. “In Northern Virginia, you can kind of blend into the local community and not do a whole lot with the military ... I found that I missed the connection to Soldiers and their families. Having grown up in the military, if you will, being able to share that was really cool.”

During her time with ACS, Buche worked as the ACS Volunteer Board president, ACS Volunteer supervisor and a front desk volunteer.

As volunteer board president and volunteer supervisor, Buche raised funds, supervised and trained 26 volunteers and recruited new volunteers.

She also organized holiday toy drives specifically for Joint Base Myer-Henderson Hall from 2012 to 2014, distributing donated toys to more 1,100 Army and Marine children on the joint base. Of her many accomplishments, Buche is most proud of the toy drive.

“When a Soldier picked up a toy for his daughter and said, ‘This is exactly the one she wants,’ it was awesome,” Buche said.

The Emma Marie Baird Award for Outstanding Volunteer Service was established in August 1988 in memory of the late retired U.S. Army Lt. Col. Emma Marie Baird, considered the founder of Army Community Service.

“I am truly honored and humbled to receive this particular award,” Buche said. “To receive an award that acknowledges the contributions of an Army officer who was also a woman and a volunteer means quite a bit.”

But Buche stressed that she wouldn’t have been able to do any of her work alone, and thanked the many people who made it possible along the way.

“Nothing I have done was done on my own,” she said. “Everything I did was done by a whole lot of other people helping and a whole lot of people for inspiration. That applies to ACS and to everywhere that I’ve been.”

In addition to her work with ACS, Buche also volunteered at the Fort Myer Thrift Shop and at the chapel. Before coming to JBM-HH, Buche volunteered at Fort Belvoir with the Army Family Team Building (AFTB) and Army Family Action Plan (AFAP) programs. She and her husband now live in Yorktown, Pennsylvania.

“I’ve gotten a whole lot in life and I would like to be able to give back, and it sure feels good when I do,” she said.

For more information on the Emma Marie Baird award, visit http://goo.gl/2zEyVW.

For more information about ACS, visit www.jbmhhmwr.com/army-community-service-acs.
column6: JOINT BASE MYER-HENDERSON HALL, VA, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州迈尔-亨德森大厅联合基地
column10: ACS长期志愿者获得服务奖
column11: 弗吉尼亚州迈尔-亨德森霍尔联合基地――作为迈尔-亨德森霍尔联合基地陆军社区服务的志愿者，退役陆军中校C.J.Buche在五年中贡献了3758小时的服务时间。4月，她将在JBM-HH志愿者表彰仪式上获得艾玛・玛丽・贝尔德奖，以表彰她的努力。该奖每年由陆军部颁发，以表彰那些为ACS做出“杰出贡献”的人，根据该奖项的官方网站，布赫是一名退伍军人，也是退役陆军中校乔・布赫（Joe Buche）的军事配偶，乔・布赫曾任美国第三步兵团（老卫队）指挥官。当她还穿着制服时，她就开始了她的志愿工作，作为一名家庭准备小组顾问，帮助士兵及其家人找到必要的资源并为部署做好准备。从军队退役后，布赫说她在当地社区和教堂做志愿工作，尽管这些都是很好的经历，她错过了她与士兵和他们所爱的人建立的联系。“对我来说，我从与人交往中获得了很多东西，”Buche告诉五角星报。“在北弗吉尼亚州，你可以融入当地社区，而不是与军队打交道……我发现我错过了与士兵及其家庭的联系。在军队长大，如果你愿意的话，能够分享这一点真的很酷。”在她与ACS共事期间，Buche曾担任ACS志愿者委员会主席、ACS志愿者监督员和前台志愿者。作为志愿者委员会主席和志愿者监督员，Buche筹集资金、监督和培训26名志愿者并招募新志愿者。2012年至2014年，她还专门为迈尔・亨德森联合基地组织了节日玩具活动，向联合基地的1100多名陆军和海军陆战队儿童分发捐赠玩具。在她众多的成就中，布赫最为玩具驱动感到自豪。“当一名士兵为女儿捡起一个玩具并说，‘这正是她想要的’，那真是太棒了，”“艾玛・玛丽・贝尔德杰出志愿服务奖”成立于1988年8月，以纪念已故退休的美国陆军中校艾玛・玛丽・贝尔德，他被认为是陆军社区服务的创始人。“我真的很荣幸和谦卑地获得了这个特别的奖项，”布赫说。“获得一个表彰一名陆军军官，同时也是一名女性和一名志愿者所做贡献的奖项意义重大。”但布赫强调，她不可能独自完成任何工作，并感谢一路走来的许多人。“我所做的一切都不是我自己做的，”她说。“我所做的每一件事都是由许多其他人帮助和许多人寻求灵感所做的。这适用于ACS和我去过的任何地方。”除了她与ACS的合作外，Buche还在迈尔堡旧货店和教堂做志愿者。在来到JBM-HH之前，Buche在贝尔沃堡志愿参加了陆军家庭团队建设（AFTB）和陆军家庭行动计划（AFAP）项目。她和她的丈夫现在住在宾夕法尼亚州的约克敦。她说：“我在生活中得到了很多，我希望能够回馈，当我回馈的时候感觉很好。”有关艾玛・玛丽・贝尔德奖的更多信息，请访问http://goo.gl/2zEyVW.For 有关ACS的更多信息，请访问www.jbmhhmwr.com/army-community-service-ACS。

column2: ACS celebrates volunteers during annual luncheon
column3:
JOINT BASE MYER-HENDERSON HALL, Va. - Joint Base Myer-Henderson Hall Army Community Service celebrated its many volunteers during its annual volunteer recognition luncheon Nov. 6.

Those who give their time to ACS programs were treated to a lunch in the executive room at Spates Community Club on the Fort Myer portion of the joint base.

About 24 volunteers C the majority of whom work in the ACS reception area and on other special projects throughout the year C were recognized, said Marcia O’Connor, the ACS volunteer board vice president and assistant volunteer supervisor.

Laurie Brown, chief of ACS, thanked all of the volunteers who attended the luncheon, as well as those who were unable to attend.

“We do have volunteers in many capacities, and many of them are volunteering today in other capacities, so we do appreciate all of you being here,” she said.

Brown told the volunteers in the room that they might not know the impact they have on the people they meet through their work every day.

“One of my favorite quotes is ‘To the world you may be one person, but to one person you may be the world,’” she said. “We have the opportunity every day to witness this when it comes to our volunteers.

“You may never know the profound effect you have on a person’s life. A kind word, a gentle touch, a listening ear can mean so much to someone who is seeking service.”

And whether they volunteered at the ACS front desk, knitted baby blankets for Soldiers and their families or worked in one of ACS’ many special projects, Brown assured volunteers that they help their community.

“You make a difference in others’ lives,” she said. “You may volunteer for many different reasons, but for whatever reason you volunteer, you provide support, skills, talents and abilities to the joint base and to the Army as a whole.”

Mike Jordan, president of the ACS volunteer board, has only held his position since May, but that doesn’t mean he doesn’t understand the great difference volunteers make for ACS, he said.

“I really appreciate what your volunteering means to the great folks in the Army Community Service programs,” Jordan said. “I also know, even more significantly, how your selfless service translates to improving quality of life programs for service members and their families. Very often, they’re survivors.”

During his keynote speech, JBM-HH Chief of Staff Glenn Wait said ACS volunteers contributed 2,225 total hours for Fiscal Year 2015, the equivalent of $51,342 in the private sector.

“Without volunteers, we wouldn’t be able to do what we do,” Wait said. “It just means so much.”

Volunteering takes understanding, empathy, compassion, patience and dedication, according to Wait.

“You’ve shown these qualities and much more,” he said. “Throughout the last year we have seen your enthusiastic community spirit and dedicated volunteer service. Your unwavering demonstration of support reflects positively on your values of patriotism, generosity and selfless dedication.”

On behalf of himself and JBM-HH Commander Col. Mike Henderson, Wait offered his heartfelt thanks to everyone who gives their time for ACS programs.

“You’re part of the ACS family,” he said. “Regardless of your role I want you to know that this command is deeply grateful for you.”
column6: JOINT BASE MYER-HENDERSON HALL, VA, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州迈尔-亨德森大厅联合基地
column10: ACS在年度午餐会上庆祝志愿者
column11: 迈尔-亨德森大厅联合基地，弗吉尼亚州-迈尔・亨德森・霍尔联合基地陆军社区服务部在11月6日的年度志愿者表彰午餐会上庆祝了其众多志愿者。那些花时间参加ACS项目的志愿者在联合基地迈尔堡部分斯帕茨社区俱乐部的行政室享用了午餐。约有24名志愿者，其中大部分是志愿者ACS志愿者委员会副主席兼助理志愿者主管Marcia O'Connor说，ACS接待区和全年其他特殊项目的工作都得到了认可。ACS负责人劳里・布朗感谢所有参加午餐会的志愿者以及无法参加午餐会的志愿者。她说：“我们确实有很多能力的志愿者，他们中的许多人今天也以其他能力做志愿者，所以我们非常感谢你们所有人来到这里。”布朗告诉房间里的志愿者，他们可能不知道他们每天的工作会对他们遇到的人产生什么影响。“我最喜欢的一句话是‘对世界而言，你可能是一个人，但对某个人来说，你可能是全世界’，”她说，“我们每天都有机会在志愿者面前见证这一点。“你可能永远不会知道你对一个人的生活有多么深远的影响。一句好话、一次温柔的抚摸、一只倾听的耳朵对寻求服务的人来说意义重大。”无论他们是在ACS前台志愿服务，还是为士兵和他们的家人编织婴儿毛毯，还是在ACS的许多特殊项目中工作，布朗都向志愿者保证，他们会帮助他们的社区。“你会改变别人的生活，”她说。“你可以出于许多不同的原因志愿服务，但无论出于何种原因，你都会为联合基地和整个军队提供支持、技能、才能和能力。”迈克・乔丹（Mike Jordan）是ACS志愿者委员会的主席，他从5月份才开始担任这一职务，但这并不意味着他不理解志愿者对ACS的巨大影响，他说：“我真的很感激你的志愿工作对军队社区服务项目中的伟大人物意味着什么。”。“我还知道，更重要的是，你的无私服务如何转化为改善服务人员及其家庭的生活质量。他们通常是幸存者。”JBM-HH办公室主任格伦・韦特（Glenn Wait）在其主旨演讲中表示，ACS志愿者为2015财年贡献了2225小时的总时数，相当于私营部门的51342美元。“没有志愿者，我们就无法做我们所做的事情，”韦特说。“这意义重大。”根据Wait的说法，志愿工作需要理解、同理心、同情心、耐心和奉献精神。“你已经展示了这些品质，还有更多，”他说。“在过去的一年中，我们看到你们热情的社区精神和奉献的志愿服务。你们坚定不移的支持体现了你们的爱国主义、慷慨和无私奉献的价值观。”Wait代表他自己和JBM-HH指挥官迈克・亨德森上校向所有为ACS项目付出时间的人表示衷心的感谢。“你是ACS大家庭的一部分，”他说。“无论你扮演什么角色，我都希望你知道，这个司令部对你深表感谢。”

column2: Bagels, coffee and history served up by ACS
column3:
JOINT BASE MYER-HENDERSON HALL, Va. - Bagels, coffee, juice and the history of Army Community Service’s 50 years of service to the Joint Base Myer-Henderson Hall community were served up June 24 at Building 201 on the Fort Myer portion of the joint base.

The event marked the last in a series of events commemorating ACS’s golden anniversary and brought dozens to the building. ACS staff members and volunteers discussed the importance of their organization. 

Carla Moss, ACS information and referral/outreach program manager, said having that interaction with the community is the best part of her job.

“To be able to share and give back to the community is so important,” she said.

Throughout the building, displays were set up that told the JBM-HH ACS story across the decades. Scrapbooks were filled with photographs and newspaper clippings dating back to the 1960s. On a coat rack near the entrance door to the building hung a brown skirt and blazer and orange blouse that was the uniform for ACS volunteers decades ago.

Mary Cargill of the ACS New Parent Support Program, said helping service members who give so much is the most important aspect of her job.

“Helping people that give so much, our Soldiers and Marines give so much, their families give so much, that is the best,” she said.

Army Community Service was designed to provide a framework for the operation of a viable system of social services within the Army community and was “born” July 25, 1965, when Gen. Harold K. Johnson, then-Army chief of staff, sent a letter to all commanders announcing the approval and establishment of ACS, according to an article on Army.mil. With the publication of Army Regulation 608-1 on Nov. 19, 1965, ACS was formalized. 

ACS opened its doors on the Fort Myer portion of the joint base in the spring of 1966, according to ACS Chief Laurie Brown.

For a complete listing of current ACS programs and services, visit www.jbmhhmwr.com/army-community-service-acs.
column6: JOINT BASE MYER-HENDERSON HALL, VA, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州迈尔-亨德森大厅联合基地
column10: ACS提供的百吉饼、咖啡和历史
column11: 弗吉尼亚州迈尔-亨德森大厅联合基地-百吉饼、咖啡、，juice和陆军社区服务的历史6月24日在迈尔堡迈尔堡部分的201号大楼为迈尔亨德森霍尔联合基地社区服务了50年。该活动是纪念ACS成立50周年的一系列活动中的最后一次，并为该大楼带来了数十人。ACS工作人员和志愿者讨论了他们组织的重要性。ACS信息和转诊/外展项目经理卡拉・莫斯（Carla Moss）表示，与社区互动是她工作中最好的部分。“能够分享和回馈社区是非常重要的，”她说。在整个建筑中，都设置了展示，讲述了数十年来JBM-HH ACS的故事。剪贴簿上满是20世纪60年代的照片和剪报。在大楼入口附近的衣架上，挂着一条棕色的裙子、一件运动夹克和一件橙色的衬衫，这是几十年前ACS志愿者的制服。ACS新家长支持计划的玛丽・卡吉尔说，帮助付出这么多的服务人员是她工作中最重要的方面。她说：“帮助那些付出如此之多的人，我们的士兵和海军陆战队付出如此之多，他们的家人付出如此之多，这是最好的。”陆军社区服务旨在为陆军社区内可行的社会服务体系的运作提供一个框架，并“诞生”1965年7月25日，时任陆军参谋长的哈罗德・K・约翰逊将军致函所有指挥官，宣布批准并建立ACS。根据《陆军条例》第608-1号于1965年11月19日发布，ACS正式成立。ACS在SPI联合基地的迈尔堡部分开门根据ACS负责人劳里・布朗（Laurie Brown）的说法，ng于1966年发布。有关当前ACS项目和服务的完整列表，请访问www.jbmhmwr.com/army-community-service-ACS。

column2: Defenders compete in Aces Cop Combat Challenge
column3:
MALMSTROM AIR FORCE BASE, Mont. - Security forces personnel from Malmstrom Air Force Base had the chance to compete for first place during the Fourth Annual Aces Cop Combat Challenge held on base June 5. During the competition, Airmen were required to work in teams of four and push themselves to their physical and mental limits to complete each station of the event in record time.

Throughout the 22 stations, team members solved critical thinking scenarios, performed physical feats, combined their efforts to defeat mental games, assembled firearms from pieces and displayed expert marksmanship skills, all while under constant duress and physical stress. 

“This competition is very physically challenging,” said Staff Sgt. Joann Ayon, 341st Security Forces Group competition judge. 

The infamous Team Pain station required participants to complete five staggered push-ups in a mud pit, flip a massive tire four times and repeat the entire process for 15 minutes, or until the point of exhaustion. 

The Chemical Warfare and Box of Guns stations tested competitors’ career-specific understanding while creating an environment where without the help and combined knowledge of each team member, success would be impossible.

“Teamwork and a lot of strategy [helped us accomplish each station],” said Senior Airman John Carlson, 341st Missile Security Forces Squadron member. “I think these events definitely help to build that teamwork also.”

In total, 18 teams participated in the competition.

“This is my second year participating in the challenge,” said Carlson. “The hardest part is the physical aspect of each event and keeping that teamwork.” 

According to Carlson, being able to participate in the event was something his entire team was very excited about and they trained intensely in order to be prepared for what they were about to undertake. 

The 341st Tactical Response Force fire team earned the championship title and bragging rights until next year’s competition.

Malmstrom’s 341st MSFS team came in second and the 341st Security Forces Squadron fire team took third. 

As home to one of the largest security forces groups in the U.S. Air Force, the competition served to strengthen the bond of Malmstrom’s security forces members. Success of the event was only made possible due to volunteers, spectators and most importantly, the competitors.
column6: MALMSTROM AIR FORCE BASE, MT, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国蒙特州马尔姆斯特罗姆空军基地
column10: 防守者参加Aces Cop战斗挑战赛
column11: 蒙大拿州马尔姆斯特罗姆空军基地6月5日，在基地举行的第四届年度Aces Cop战斗挑战赛中，来自马尔姆斯特罗姆空军基地的安全部队人员有机会争夺第一名。在比赛期间，飞行员被要求四人一组工作，并竭尽全力以创纪录的时间完成比赛的每一站。在22个站中，队员们解决了批判性思维场景，完成了身体壮举，共同努力击败心理游戏，在不断的胁迫和身体压力下，用碎片组装枪支，展示出专业的射击技能。341安全部队团体竞赛评委Joann Ayon上士说：“这场比赛在身体上非常具有挑战性。”。臭名昭著的团队疼痛站要求参与者在泥坑中完成五次错开的俯卧撑，翻转一个巨大的轮胎四次，然后重复整个过程15分钟，或者直到筋疲力尽。化学战和枪械箱站测试了竞争对手对职业的理解，同时创造了一个没有团队成员的帮助和综合知识就不可能成功的环境。“团队合作和大量战略（帮助我们完成了每个站），”高级飞行员约翰・卡尔森说，341导弹安全部队中队成员。“我认为这些活动肯定也有助于建立团队精神。”总共有18支球队参加了比赛。“这是我第二年参加挑战赛，”卡尔森说。卡尔森说：“最困难的部分是每项活动的身体状况以及保持团队精神。”能够参加这项活动是他的整个团队非常兴奋的事情，他们进行了紧张的训练，以便为即将进行的活动做好准备。第341战术反应部队消防队赢得了冠军头衔，并在明年的比赛前拥有自夸的权利。马尔姆斯特罗姆的第341战术反应部队消防队获得了第二名，第341安全部队中队消防队获得了第三名。作为美国空军最大的安全部队组织之一的所在地，这次比赛加强了马尔姆斯特罗姆安全部队成员之间的联系。只有志愿者、观众，最重要的是竞争对手，比赛才能取得成功。

column2: Shaw Airmen execute ACE concepts at MCAS Beaufort
column3:
The launch of an F-16 Viper involves a team of both aggressively trained maintenance Airmen as well as combat ready pilots. Together they move the aircraft into the skies to execute close air support, suppression of enemy air defenses, and other missions as dictated by their air tasking orders. However, as the future fight builds towards a more austere destination, the entire team trains with the intent to operate in a contingency location.

A small team of pilots and maintenance Airmen from the 20th Fighter Wing trained together on agile combat employment functions May 17-21, at Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort.

“In the world we live in today with our near-peer adversaries, it’s very likely in our next conflict that we won’t have (traditional) ground support,” said Capt. Jacob Impellizzeri, 79th Fighter Squadron F-16 pilot. “In the event we land in contingency operations, my wingmen and I need to know how to post-flight these jets, and prepare them for potential combat sorties.”

Simulating an environment of ACE models, the pilots trained on how service and turn their own aircraft and potentially launch again to continue delivering sorties. The maintenance team trained alongside one another as well to better develop each other in multi-capable concepts.

“We trained here on tasks like servicing fuel, oil, hydraulics, and serviceability through inspections,” said Staff Sgt. Zachary Szalay, 79th Fighter Generation Squadron crew chief. “This training is important because it provides the opportunity for all of us to become more well-rounded in other fields.”

Fielding the exercise at MCAS Beaufort was necessary to participate in a joint training opportunity fostering interoperability between the services as well as simulate an environment for our pilots without the support offered by their home station.

Capt. Impellizzeri further explained that tomorrow’s conflict requires the team to continue building towards the idea of operating in the unknown and preparing for all possibilities.

“We need to be more agile, and flexible about how we fight our next wars,” said Impellizzeri. “This entire week that we’re down here is only proving that point.”
column6: SHAW AIR FORCE BASE, SC, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国南卡罗来纳州肖空军基地
column10: 肖空军在MCAS博福特执行ACE概念
column11: F-16“毒蛇”战斗机的发射需要一个由经过积极训练的维修飞行员和战备飞行员组成的团队。他们一起将飞机送入天空，执行空中近距离支援、压制敌人防空系统，以及根据空中任务指令执行的其他任务。然而，随着未来战斗向更为严峻的目标迈进，整个团队都在进行训练，以期在应急地点作战。5月17日至21日，来自第20战斗机联队的一小队飞行员和维修飞行员在海军陆战队博福特空军站进行了敏捷作战使用功能的训练。第79战斗机中队F-16飞行员雅各布・利泽里上尉说：“在我们今天与近邻对手共同生活的世界中，我们很可能在下一次冲突中没有（传统的）地面支援。”。“如果我们在应急行动中着陆，我的僚机和我需要知道如何对这些飞机进行后置飞行，并为可能的战斗架次做好准备。”在模拟ACE模型的环境中，飞行员们训练如何维修和转动自己的飞机，并可能再次发射以继续交付架次。维修团队彼此并肩训练，以便更好地在多功能概念方面相互发展。第79代战斗机中队队长扎卡里・萨莱上士说：“我们在这里接受了燃料、油、液压和检查维修等任务的培训。这次培训很重要，因为它为我们所有人提供了在其他领域更加全面的机会。”在MCAS Beaufort部署演习对于参加联合训练机会、促进军种之间的互操作性以及在没有母站支持的情况下为我们的飞行员模拟环境是必要的。Pumplezzeri上尉进一步解释说，明天的冲突需要团队继续建设“我们需要更灵活，更灵活地对待下一场战争，”利泽里说，“我们在这里呆了整整一周，这只是证明了这一点。”

column2: POL drives ACE during Exercise Mobility Guardian
column3:
Air Mobility Command petroleum, oils and lubricants Airmen pushed the boundaries of Agile Combat Employment and how it pertains to expeditiously refueling aircraft during Exercise Mobility Guardian, May 15-27, 2021.
 
Throughout the exercise, POL Airmen received hands-on training on the Aerial Bulk Fuel Delivery System, Fuels Operational Readiness Capability Equipment mobile fuel bladder, wet-wing defuel and hot-pit refuel operations.
 
“Without fuel, the Air Force mission does not get accomplished,” said Staff Sgt. Garrett Huntoon, 374th Logistic Readiness Squadron fuels service center controller. “Mobility Guardian offers a training environment to test capabilities of how we can provide fuel in different environments and change the way we get after ACE.”
 
The ABFDS, a portable 3,000-gallon fuel bladder, can be loaded on a C-130J Super Hercules, C-5 Galaxy, or C-17 Globemaster III and transported anywhere around the world. A fighter, helicopter or ground vehicle simply pulls next to the respective aircraft and receives fuel while engines remain on, allowing them to quickly refuel and carry on with the mission with minimal time spent on the ground.
 
“The Air Force is taking notice and seeing the capabilities the ABFDS brings to the fight and is pushing that concept forward,” said Master Sgt. Jared Bicker, Alpena Combat Readiness Training Center Fuels operator. “If we want to maintain that flexibility and air combat effectiveness, then we need exercises like this to push initiatives such as these that make an impact on the way we operate.”
 
FORCE is a 210,000-gallon bladder that is generally set up in deployed environments negating the need to build hardened tanks or bring fuel trucks, while simultaneously reducing the overall footprint by not leaving hardened facilities behind.
 
“By reducing the footprint, these refueling initiatives allow aircraft to continuously hop around a wide array of locations within shorter timeframes C exponentially boosting capabilities and keeping the enemy guessing,” Huntoon said.
 
POL also participates in wet-wing defueling and hot-pit refueling operations. While neither of these concepts are new, under the scope of contingency operations, these are not commonly executed within the same mission set. 

Wet-wing defueling is the offloading of fuel from an aircraft onto an R-11 fuel truck, all while engines are still running. POL can then turn and hot-pit refuel a fighter aircraft. Hot-pit refueling occurs when an aircraft is fueled immediately after landing, while the aircraft keeps one engine running.
 
These refueling capabilities showcase the agility of mobility aircraft while demonstrating the global reach AMC provides across the Air Force.  
 
“This exercise is conducive to a more effective and agile Air Force,” said Master Sgt. Patrick King, AMC logistics readiness manager. “AMC POL Airmen generally don’t get hands-on time with these operations unless they are in a deployed environment. Mobility Guardian offers an opportunity to experiment with these concepts before having to use them in a real-world scenario.”
column6: ALPENA COMBAT READINESS TRAINING CENTER, MI, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国密苏里州阿尔皮纳战备训练中心
column10: POL在运动中驾驶ACE Guardian
column11: 2021年5月15日至27日，在《机动性卫报》演习中，空军机动司令部石油、机油和润滑油飞行员突破了敏捷作战部署的界限，以及如何为飞机快速加油。在整个演习过程中，波兰航空兵接受了有关空中散装燃料输送系统的实际操作培训，燃料战备能力装备移动燃料囊、湿翼除油和热坑加油作业。第374后勤战备中队燃料服务中心控制员、参谋长Garrett Huntoon说：“没有燃料，空军任务无法完成。”。“Mobility Guardian提供了一个训练环境，以测试我们如何在不同环境中提供燃料，以及如何在ACE后改变我们获得燃料的方式。”ABFDS是一种便携式3000加仑燃料囊，可装载在C-130J超级大力神、C-5银河系或C-17 Globemaster III上，并运输到世界各地。战斗机、直升机或地面车辆只需靠近各自的飞机，并在发动机保持打开的情况下接收燃油，使其能够快速加油并以最少的地面时间执行任务。阿尔皮纳战备训练中心燃料操作员Jared Bicker上士说：“空军正在注意并看到ABFDS为战斗带来的能力，并正在推进这一概念。”。“如果我们想保持这种灵活性和空战效能，那么我们需要这样的演习来推动对我们作战方式产生影响的举措。”FORCE是一个210000加仑的气囊，通常安装在部署环境中，无需建造硬化油箱或携带燃油卡车，同时通过不留下硬化设施来减少总体占地面积。“通过减少足迹，这些加油计划使飞机能够在较短的时间内连续在广泛的地点跳跃，从而成倍提高能力，并保持敌人的猜测。”Huntoon说。POL还参与湿翼除油和热坑加油作业。虽然这两个概念都不是新概念，但在应急行动范围内，这些概念通常不会在同一任务集内执行。湿翼除油是将飞机的燃油卸载到R-11燃料车上，同时发动机为still运行。POL可以转弯并对战斗机进行热坑加油。热坑加油发生在飞机着陆后立即加油，同时飞机保持一个发动机运行。这些加油能力展示了机动飞机的灵活性，同时展示了AMC在整个空军中提供的全球覆盖范围。陆军装备司令部后勤准备经理帕特里克・金上士说：“这次演习有助于建立一支更有效、更灵活的空军。”。“AMC POL飞行员通常不会亲自参与这些行动，除非他们处于部署环境中。Mobility Guardian提供了一个机会，在将这些概念用于实际场景之前，可以对其进行试验。”

column2: 167th and 175th demonstrate ACE concept in training exercise
column3:
The 167th Airlift Wing recently teamed up with the 175th Wing, Maryland Air National Guard, to conduct their first agile combat employment exercise Feb. 17.
During the single-day exercise, cargo and Airmen were transported via a C-17 Globemaster III from Warfield Air National Guard Base at Martin State Airport, Baltimore, Md.,
to Martinsburg, W.Va. Two A-10C Thunderbolt II aircraft joined the equipment and personnel to mimic operations from a forward location.
Capt. Trebor Taylor, C-17 pilot and exercise planner said the primary goal was to help another unit. The objective was to transport their cargo and personnel to Martinsburg,
set up their equipment and operate out of this location, simulating an austere environment, and the exercise accomplished that.
“The unit is fully deployed forward and you’re able to take a chunk of your organic elements and move them elsewhere and be able to operate at both places,” he said.
“So essentially, you’re doing more with less.”
A forecasted snowstorm forced participants to shorten the exercise from two days to one, but Taylor said it created a secondary element to the training, requiring the
movement of cargo and people quicker, efficiently, and safely.
The ACE exercise also provided unique training opportunities to the C-17 aircrew and aerial port specialists, requiring them to work with equipment specifically for the A-10.
During the exercise Airmen moved 44,000 pounds of cargo, including MJ-1B/C Bomblifts, GF-7/E Ammo Loading Systems, and MHU-141 Bomb Trailers.
“It’s beneficial for everybody, not only the guys requesting it, but our guys are getting something out of it, too,” Taylor said.
column9: 马丁斯堡，威斯康星州，美国
column10: 第167次和第175次在训练演习中展示ACE概念
column11: 第167空运联队最近与马里兰州国民警卫队第175联队合作，于2月17日进行了第一次敏捷作战使用演习。在单日演习中，货物和飞行员通过C-17 Globemaster III从马里兰州巴尔的摩市马丁国家机场的沃菲尔德空军国民警卫队基地运送到西弗吉尼亚州的马丁斯堡。两架A-10C Thunderbolt II飞机与设备和人员会合，模拟前方位置的操作。上尉。C-17飞行员和演习策划人特雷伯・泰勒（Trebor Taylor）表示，主要目标是帮助另一个部队。演习的目的是将他们的货物和人员运送到马丁斯堡，安装他们的设备，并在这个地点以外进行操作，模拟一个严峻的环境，演习完成了这一目标。他说：“部队完全部署在前方，你可以将一大块建制部队转移到其他地方，并在两个地方都能作战。因此，基本上，你是在用更少的资源做更多的事情。”一场预测的暴风雪迫使参与者将演习时间从两天缩短为一天，但泰勒表示，这是训练的第二要素，要求货物和人员的移动更快、更高效、更安全。ACE演习还为C-17机组人员和机场专家提供了独特的训练机会，要求在这次演习中，飞行员运送了44000磅的货物，包括MJ-1B/C炸弹升降机、GF-7/E弹药装载系统和MHU-141炸弹拖车。泰勒说：“这对每个人都有好处，不仅是那些提出要求的人，而且我们的人也从中受益。”。

column2: Fort Leavenworth ACS launching volunteer management system
column3:
Katie Peterson | Fort Leavenworth Lamp

FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kansas (Jan. 7, 2021) ― After three years of planning and development, U.S. Army Installation Management Command and Army Community Service are launching a new Volunteer Management Information System Jan. 11. 
“(VMIS) is an online program that helps volunteers track their volunteer hours so that their volunteer hours are certified,” said interim Fort Leavenworth ACS Volunteer Coordinator Jessica Brushwood. “We have points of contact that oversee the system for their organization. After a volunteer enters their hours, that person certifies the hours.” 
Brushwood said the new VMIS is a modernized update from the previous system. 
“The last system was very old and … ‘glitchy,’ so people had a lot of issues with accessing it on certain browsers or they would go in and not find the information they needed,” Brushwood said. “It was not a really intelligent system, so there were some functions that it could’ve done that it didn’t do.
“(The new VMIS) is something that is accessible from anywhere, so it keeps their volunteer history. It is going to be a lot more streamlined and modernized and easier to access,” she said. “For soldiers working toward the Military Outstanding Volunteer Service Medal, they need a certain document to put in for that medal; (VMIS) will actually generate that document for them.” 
All service members, family members and Department of the Army civilians volunteering on Fort Leavenworth can use the new VMIS system, logged under Army Family Web Portal. Service members can also log hours volunteered at off-post organizations upon providing a memo proving the hours to Brushwood.
Brushwood said she has high hopes for the new system.
“My overall hope is that the system will be easier to use and that more people will want to use it as a result so that we have more people logging their volunteer hours,” Brushwood said. “The Army likes to know how much money they’ve saved based on the number of volunteer hours that we have.
“(The Army) also uses volunteer hours sometimes to justify a needed position,” she said. “If they see lots of volunteers (performing) a certain job and that there’s lots of volunteer hours going toward a certain job, they may use that to justify hiring somebody to do that job.”
Volunteers who have logged hours on the old system will have their hours automatically transferred over to the new system. 
New volunteers can visit www.armyfamilywebportal.com before Jan. 11 and https://vmis.armyfamilywebportal.com after Jan. 11 to register.
For more information, e-mail Brushwood at jessica.h.brushwood.civ@mail.mil.
column9: 美国堪萨斯州利文沃思堡
column10: 利文沃思堡ACS启动志愿者管理系统
column11: Katie Peterson | Fort Levenworth LampFORT Levenworth，堪萨斯州（2021年1月7日）-经过三年的规划和开发，美国陆军设施管理司令部和陆军社区服务部于1月11日启动了一个新的志愿者管理信息系统。“VMIS”是一个在线项目，帮助志愿者跟踪他们的志愿者时间，以便他们的志愿者时间得到认证，”利文沃思堡ACS志愿者临时协调员杰西卡・拉什伍德说。“我们有联络点监督他们组织的系统。志愿者进入他们的工作时间后，该人会确认工作时间。”Brushwood说，新的VMIS是对以前系统的现代化更新。Brushwood说：“上一个系统非常陈旧，而且……‘有故障’，因此人们在某些浏览器上访问它时会遇到很多问题，否则他们会进去找不到所需的信息。”。她说：“这不是一个真正的智能系统，所以有些功能是它可以做到的，而不是它没有做到的。”（新的VMIS）是一个可以从任何地方访问的东西，因此它保留了志愿者的历史。它将更加精简、现代化，并且更容易访问。”。“对于致力于获得军事杰出志愿服务奖章的士兵，他们需要一份特定的文件来申请该奖章；（VMIS）将实际为他们生成该文件。”在利文沃思堡志愿服务的所有服务人员、家庭成员和陆军部文职人员都可以使用新的VMIS系统，该系统登录在陆军家庭门户网站上。服务人员还可以在提供一份备忘录证明在非邮政组织志愿服务的时间后，记录志愿服务的时间。拉什伍德说，她对新系统寄予厚望“我的总体希望是，该系统将更易于使用，因此会有更多的人希望使用它，这样我们就有更多的人记录他们的志愿者时间，”Brushwood说。“军队想知道他们根据我们的志愿者时间节省了多少钱。”（军队）她说：“有时也会用志愿者的时间来证明一个需要的职位是正当的。如果他们看到很多志愿者（执行）某项工作，而且有很多志愿者的时间去做某项工作，他们可能会用这些时间来证明雇人做这项工作是正当的。”在旧系统上记录小时数的志愿者将自动将其时间转移到新系统。新志愿者可以在1月11日和11日之前访问www.armyfamilywebportal.comhttps://vmis.armyfamilywebportal.com 1月11日后注册。有关更多信息，请发电子邮件至jessica.h.Brushwood。civ@mail.mil.

column2: 305th AMW supports ACE exercise Razor Talon
column3:
A C-17 Globemaster III and four KC-10 Extenders from the 305th Air Mobility Wing supported the multiday exercise Razor Talon at Seymour Johnson Air Force Base, North Carolina, Dec. 1-4. 

While the KC-10s have been a participant in Razor Talon since the exercise was established nearly a decade ago, this was the first time that the C-17 participated. 

“The 305th’s role in exercises like Razor Talon just go to show how vital rapid global mobility is to what the Air Force and Department of Defense does,” said Col. Scott Wiederholt, 305th Air Mobility Wing commander. “We provide a stable and solid backbone to combat employment by enabling the air and ground fights through fuels, cargo, personnel and more.” 

Razor Talon is a quarterly Agile Combat Employment and large-force composite training exercise that allows the Air Force to train in a fully-developed threat scenario environment with joint and combined warfighters across multiple domains, according to Lt. Col. Taylor Francis, Director of Staff for the 4th Fighter Wing at Seymour Johnson AFB. 

This exercise and others like it help create multi-capable Airmen, which Gen. Charles Q. Brown, Chief of Staff of the Air Force, announced as a priority in his vision “Accelerate Change or Lose.” 

ACE training focuses on preparing Airmen for short or no-notice contingencies by having forces operate from locations with varying levels of capacity and support in a training environment.

This style of exercise also helps our units train to be strategically predictable, but operationally unpredictable, according to Wiederholt. Razor Talon helps the 305 AMW train with its joint partners to enhance passive and active defense capabilities while validating new and innovative ways to deploy and maneuver assets.

This year’s exercise involved participants from 19 different units across the Air Force, Army and Marine Corps. In total, Razor Talon featured 11 different mission design series and 145 total aircraft ranging from F-15Es and F-35Bs, to E-8Cs and HC-130Js. 

The 305th AMW KC-10s demonstrated the wing’s aerial refueling capabilities in a joint environment. However, for the first time ever, the Wing also demonstrated its capabilities to support operations in austere environments through the C-17, according to Capt. Trevor Leeming, a C-17A instructor pilot and the 305th AMW lead planner for the exercise.

“We provided the ability to actually complete the Agile Combat Employment concept with an integrated joint force,” Leeming added. “We allowed a further projection of force than previously attainable, with as few assets as possible to get the job done.”

The 305th AMW is expected to continue to participate in these exercises, further demonstrating its role in rapid global mobility and active role in a joint environment. 

“We’re excited to see these types of exercises develop as they continue to test and improve our Airmen and capabilities,” Wiederholt added. “We’re proud to participate and look forward to seeing the progress that will come as a result.”

column10: 305AMW支持ACE训练剃须刀爪
column11: 12月1日至4日，在北卡罗来纳州西摩约翰逊空军基地，一架C-17 Globemaster III和四架KC-10扩展器从第305空中机动联队支援了“剃刀爪”多日演习。虽然KC-10自近十年前建立“剃刀爪”演习以来一直是该演习的参与者，但这是C-17首次参加。“第305航空机动性联队指挥官斯科特・维德霍尔特上校说：“第305航空机动性联队在“剃刀爪”等演习中的作用只是为了说明快速全球机动性对于空军和国防部的工作是多么重要。”。“我们通过燃料、货物、人员等实现空中和地面作战，为打击就业提供了稳定而坚实的支柱。”西摩约翰逊空军基地第四战斗机联队参谋长泰勒・弗朗西斯中校表示，Razor Talon是一项季度敏捷作战部署和大型部队综合训练演习，允许空军在充分发展的威胁情景环境中，与跨多个领域的联合和联合作战人员进行训练。这次演习和其他类似的演习有助于培养多才多艺的飞行员，空军参谋长查尔斯・Q・布朗上将在他的愿景中宣布，这是“加速变革或失败”的优先事项ACE训练的重点是通过让部队在训练环境中从不同能力和支持水平的地点作战，为飞行员在短时间或不通知的紧急情况下做好准备。Wiederholt说，这种演习方式还帮助我们的部队训练在战略上可预测，但在作战上不可预测。Razor Talon与联合伙伴一起帮助305 AMW训练提高被动和主动防御能力，同时验证部署和机动资产的新方法和创新方法。今年的演习包括来自空军、陆军和海军陆战队19个不同单位的参与者。总的来说，Razor Talon拥有11个不同的任务设计系列和145架飞机，从F-15Es和F-35Bs，到E-8Cs和HC-130Js。第305架AMW KC-10s展示了该联队在联合环境中的空中加油能力。然而，据C-17A教练飞行员、第305届AMW演习主要策划人特雷弗・利明上尉（Trevor Leeming）称，联队还首次通过C-17展示了其在严峻环境中支持作战的能力。Leeming补充道：“我们提供了通过一体化联合部队实际完成敏捷作战使用概念的能力。我们允许比以前更进一步的力量投射，用尽可能少的资产完成任务。”第305AMW预计将继续参加这些演习，进一步展示其在全球快速机动中的作用以及在联合环境中的积极作用。Wiederholt补充道：“我们很高兴看到这些类型的演习在不断测试和提高我们的飞行员和能力的同时得到发展。”。“我们很荣幸能够参与，并期待看到由此带来的进展。”

column2: AETC general talks pilot training at Alamo ACE
column3:
By David DeKunder | 502nd Air Base Wing Public Affairs
In order to maintain readiness, the Air Force is utilizing innovation and technology to transform pilot training to be faster while also teaching skills that will make effective warfighters, according to the Air National Guard assistant to the commander at Air Education and Training Command who spoke during this year’s Alamo Chapter of the Armed Forces Communications & Electronics Association virtual Alamo ACE conference Nov. 19. 

Maj. Gen. John Hronek discussed initiatives and programs AETC is implementing to transform pilot training, and he explained how technologies, including virtual reality, artificial intelligence and analytics, have important roles in how AETC instructors are training pilots.  

“As we recruit pilot candidates, we try to build the most diverse, best candidates we have out there, that really have the passion, that want to be part of the Air Force, and we are finding ways to do that better - getting the wings into the Air Force,” Hronek said.  

There are two main objectives in accomplishing the task of transforming pilot training, enhancing lethality and readiness, and transforming the way pilots learn, Hronek said.  

“Being lethal and ready requires the Air Force to have access to the latest technology for pilot training,” he said. “We have competition from the Russians and the Chinese, who have basically developed their technologies and their capabilities. We need to not only keep up with, but be ahead of them. That has been our greatest strength as Americans, as we’ve always been leaders in our technology. I think that’s something that we really need to work on within our future.” 

Another initiative to enhancing lethality and readiness is adjustable training timelines and modularized technical training techniques, which have cut idle time in certain training pipelines by 40 percent, enabling Airmen to get through training and to their first duty locations faster and more ready, he said.  

Hronek also discussed AETC’s Pilot Training Next initiative, which focuses on training pilots better and faster, while helping them foster deeper learning. This is based on utilizing advanced immersive training, remote simulator operations, and innovations in the advanced phases of pilot training by working with industry partners.  

Through the Pilot Training Next initiative, Hronek said AETC has been able to decrease some portions of pilot training by several months. 

“As we improved our effectiveness with what we’ve learned in our Pilot Training Next experiments since 2018, we are trying to operationalize the proven innovation concepts in the limited scale,” he said.  

“We want to transition to a student-centered learning, not just one class. We also want to deliver quality instruction that gives feedback to the instructors on how that student is progressing and how they can progress them faster, making sure they are not missing something,” Hronek said. “In order to accelerate change, we must embrace the pace of technology and change that which currently exists in our world.”
column9: 美国德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥
column10: AETC通用讲座阿拉莫ACE飞行员培训
column11: David DeKunder | 502空军基地联队公共事务为了保持战备状态，空军正在利用创新和技术将飞行员训练转变为更快的训练，同时教授能够培养高效作战人员的技能，据空军教育和训练司令部司令的空军国民警卫队助理说，他在今年11月19日举行的武装部队通信与电子协会阿拉莫分会虚拟阿拉莫ACE会议上发表了讲话。John Hronek少将讨论了AETC为改变飞行员培训而实施的举措和计划，并解释了包括虚拟现实、人工智能和分析在内的技术如何在AETC教员培训飞行员方面发挥重要作用。“在招募飞行员候选人的过程中，我们会努力培养出最多元化、最优秀的候选人，他们真正有激情，希望成为空军的一员，我们正在寻找更好的方法――让机翼进入空军，”赫勒克说。Hronek说，完成转变飞行员训练、提高杀伤力和战备能力以及转变飞行员学习方式的任务有两个主要目标。他说：“要想成为致命的、随时准备好的飞行员，美国空军必须能够获得最新的飞行员训练技术。”。“我们有来自俄罗斯和中国的竞争，他们基本上开发了他们的技术和能力。我们不仅要跟上他们，而且要走在他们前面。这是我们作为美国人最大的优势，因为我们一直是我们技术的领军者。我认为这是我们真正需要与我合作的事情。”他说：“提高杀伤力和战备能力的另一项举措是可调整的训练时间表和模块化的技术训练技术，这将某些训练管道中的空闲时间减少了40%，使飞行员能够更快、更充分地完成训练并到达首个执勤地点。”。Hronek还讨论了AETC的飞行员培训下一步计划，该计划侧重于更好更快地培训飞行员，同时帮助他们培养更深层次的学习。这是基于利用先进的沉浸式培训、远程模拟器操作，以及通过与行业合作伙伴合作在飞行员培训的高级阶段进行创新。Hronek说，通过飞行员培训下一步计划，AETC已经能够将飞行员培训的某些部分减少几个月。“自2018年以来，随着我们在试点培训下一个实验中所学到的知识提高了我们的效率，我们正试图在有限的规模内实施经验证的创新概念，”他说。“我们希望过渡到以学生为中心的学习，而不仅仅是一门课。我们还希望提供高质量的教学，向教师反馈学生的进步情况，以及他们如何更快地进步，确保他们不会遗漏什么，”Hronek说。“为了加速变革，我们必须跟上技术的步伐，改变当今世界的现状。”

column2: 337th ACS continues mission through COVID-19
column3:
COVID-19 has brought many new challenges to units across the United States Air Force, but each unit has found ways to fight through while reducing the risk of exposure. For the 337th Air Control Squadron, Air Battle Managers have continued to train and graduate.

“We have continued to graduate students through our course as planned with class sizes of 8 students rather than 12, and we have implemented split operations for our squadron and students in order to minimize the risk of spreading COVID-19,” said Senior Airman Jordyn Jones, 337th ACS weapons simulation technician.

In addition to reducing class sizes and separating operations, students from each team worked different days and hours and were not allowed to be in contact with any student from the other team.

“Face masks are required to be worn at all times and hand sanitizer is located at all entry points,” said Jones. “All briefings are either online or are held in the auditorium where they can maintain a six-foot distance between themselves.”

With these added measures, future Air Battle Managers can focus on training for the critical role they play in the operational Air Force.

“Air Battle Managers perform the tactical and operational command and control for the Combatant Commanders, said Maj. Michael Davis, 337th ACS director of operations. “Command and Control is a core mission for the USAF and battle management is a force multiplier in combat operations.” 

Maintaining mental fitness during COVID-19 has been a challenge and leaders across the Air Force are trying to find ways to help their Airmen.

“Teamwork is paramount to the command and control community, especially in the dynamic schoolhouse setting with an ever-changing and complex schedule,” said Davis. “Each Airmen helps their teammates out on the ops floors, classroom, and with life events, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic.”

Supervisors from the 337th ACS made care packages for Airmen in the dorms, flight chiefs dropped off food for those who had to be in quarantine, and many Airmen received a personal call from the commander.

“We trust each other to make good decisions outside of work to not threaten the health of all of us here,” said Jones. “We trust our leadership to be transparent with all of the changes that occur and we trust that they have the best intentions for us and for our safety when they decide how to move forward with our mission.”

Throughout the past year, Air Battle Managers have continued to graduate on time.

“We strengthened our ability to adapt and overcome in challenging circumstances and proved that we could still carry on our mission, even during a global pandemic,” said Jones.
