column10: 337 ACS通过新冠病毒-19继续执行任务
column11: 新冠病毒-19给美国空军部队带来了许多新的挑战，但每个部队都找到了克服这些挑战的方法，同时降低了暴露的风险。对于337空管中队，空战管理人员继续进行培训和毕业。“我们继续按照计划在课程中培养学生，每班人数为8人，而不是12人，我们为中队和学生实施了分班作战，以最大限度地降低传播新冠病毒-19的风险。”高级飞行员Jordyn Jones说，他是第337届ACS武器模拟技术员。除了减少班级人数和分班作业外，每个团队的学生工作的时间和时间都不同，不允许与其他团队的任何学生接触。琼斯说：“任何时候都需要戴口罩，所有入口都有洗手液。所有的简报要么在线进行，要么在礼堂举行，在那里他们可以保持六英尺的距离。”有了这些额外的措施，未来的空战管理者可以专注于训练他们在作战空军中发挥的关键作用。“空战管理者为作战指挥官执行战术和作战指挥和控制，第337届ACS作战总监迈克尔・戴维斯少校说。“指挥和控制是美国空军的核心任务，作战管理是作战行动中的一个力量倍增器。”在新冠疫情期间保持心理健康一直是一项挑战，整个空军的领导人都在设法帮助他们的飞行员。戴维斯说：“团队合作对指挥和控制社区来说至关重要，尤其是在时刻变化和复杂日程的动态校舍环境中。每个飞行员都在行动楼层、教室和生活事件中帮助他们的队友，特别是在新冠肺炎流行期间。”来自337 ACS的主管为宿舍的飞行员制定了护理计划，飞行主管为需要隔离的飞行员送去了食物，许多飞行员接到了指挥官的私人电话。“我们相互信任，在工作之外做出正确的决定，以免威胁到我们所有人的健康，”琼斯说。“我们相信我们的领导层对发生的所有变化都是透明的，我们相信他们在决定如何推进我们的任务时对我们和我们的安全有着最好的意图。”在过去一年中，空战管理人员一直在按时毕业。琼斯说：“我们加强了我们在挑战性环境中的适应和克服能力，并证明了我们仍然能够履行我们的使命，即使在全球大流行期间也是如此。”。

column2: 4th SOS, AMU make history with AC-130U
column3:
HURLBURT FIELD, Fla. -- An AC-130U Spooky gunship named ‘Big Daddy’ made history by being the first Spooky to ever receive a black letter initial on its status page before a flight, June 18, 2020. 
	This was a momentous accomplishment for Air Commandos in the 4th Special Operations Squadron and the 4th AMU. 
“A black letter is significant because it means there are absolutely no discrepancies whatsoever on the plane,” said U.S. Air Force Tech. Sgt. Mark Lennon, a section chief with the 4th Aircraft Maintenance Unit. “A black letter is when there’s no discrepancies on the status page. The crew chief’s last name and first initial goes in that place. It shows that aircraft has really been maintained with excellence.”
	This standard of excellence is only achieved through teamwork. 
	“It’s a huge teamwork effort and accomplishment for everyone,” said Lennon. “It takes a lot of hard work and pride to make this happen.”
	The last Spooky named ‘Gunslinger’ retired to the boneyard at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base, Arizona, June 26, 2020. However, Big Daddy will be the last to retire and will be placed in the Hurlburt Field Air Park.
	Any time an aircraft flies, it could come back with any number of discrepancies, or those discrepancies which can be found when maintainers do their inspections.
	“Aircraft across the Air Force usually fly with discrepancies, so it’s really rare to see a black letter initial,” said Lennon. “In my 11 years in service, I’ve only seen it one other time.”
	The Spookys have been operational since 1995, providing combat overwatch for 18 of those years. The heavily armed aircraft incorporates side-firing weapons integrated with sophisticated sensor, navigation, and fire control systems to provide surgical firepower or area saturation during extended loiter periods, at night and in adverse weather.
	The mission down range has been taken over by the AC-130J Ghostrider gunships since July 2019. The same aircraft the 4th SOS and AMU will now be working with.
	“After 25 years of service, we’re closing one chapter and starting another with the AC-130Js,” said U.S. Air Force Capt. Hannah Boeman, officer in charge with the 4th AMU. “Talking to a lot of the maintainers at the 4th AMU, it’s kind of a bittersweet moment for them. Since most of them have spent a majority of their career working with these aircraft, I know it’s sad to see them go.”
column9: 美国佛罗里达州赫尔伯特菲尔德
column10: 第四个SOS，AMU用AC-130U创造历史
column11: 佛罗里达州赫尔伯特菲尔德――2020年6月18日，一艘名为“大爸爸”的AC-130U恐怖武装直升机创造了历史，它是第一艘在飞行前状态页面上收到黑色字母首字母的恐怖飞机。这是第四特种作战中队和第四陆军军事大学空中突击队的一项重大成就。美国空军技术中士马克・列侬（Mark Lennon）是第四飞机维修队的一名科长，他说：“黑色字母很重要，因为它意味着飞机上绝对没有任何差异。”。“黑色字母是指状态页面上没有差异。机组长的姓氏和首字母都在该位置。这表明飞机的维护非常出色。”这一卓越标准只有通过团队合作才能实现。列侬说：“这对每个人来说都是巨大的团队合作和成就。”。“实现这一目标需要付出大量的努力和骄傲。”最后一位名叫“枪手”的恐怖分子于2020年6月26日在亚利桑那州戴维斯-蒙坦空军基地的墓地退休。然而，“大爸爸”将是最后一个退休的，并将被安置在赫尔伯特机场的空中公园。任何时候，飞机飞回来时，都可能出现任何数量的差异，或者在维修人员进行检查时发现的差异。列侬说：“空军的飞机通常飞行时会有不一致之处，所以很少看到黑色字母的首字母。在我11年的服役中，我只见过一次。”幽灵战机自1995年开始运作，其中18年提供战斗警戒。全副武装的飞机采用侧射武器，集成了先进的传感器、导航和火控系统，在夜间和恶劣天气下长时间游荡期间提供外科手术火力或区域饱和自2019年7月以来，AC-130J Ghostrider武装直升机已经接管了任务下射程。第四SOS和AMU现在将使用同一架飞机。“在服役25年后，我们将以AC-130Js结束一个章节，并开始另一个章节，”美国空军上尉、第四AMU负责人汉娜・博曼（Hannah Boeman）说。“与第四航空管理大学的许多维修人员交谈，这对他们来说是一个苦乐参半的时刻。因为他们中的大多数人在职业生涯的大部分时间里都在与这些飞机一起工作，我知道看到他们离去是很悲哀的。”

column2: Call of Support- ACS reaches out to Bragg residents
column3:
FORT BRAGG, N.C. - Face coverings. Pandemic. Social distancing. A few months ago these were all foreign ideas and terms to most people. Today, they are all too familiar in our everyday lives. As we adjusted the way we lived our lives, we also had to adjust how we communicate and interact with each other. Fort Bragg’s Army Community Service was no exception. They needed to find a way to continue to communicate and help their customers.

The decision was made for ACS staff to call on-post residents to reach out to our soldiers and Families, connect them with resources, and to let them know assistance is always available, if and when needed. 

Staff members making the calls were asked to come into the office to do so. Since the ACS offices were closed to the public, this allowed employees to maintain safety and social distancing. An added benefit of having staff members come into the office for the calls, was the ability to check in and check on each other, giving managers some face time to ensure staff members were doing well and staying healthy.

“Due to a lot of our employees not having government phones, we asked for staff to voluntarily come in and assist with the calls,” said Barbara Trower-Simpkins, ACS Director. “Employees thought this was a great opportunity to expose more families to ACS services, especially those who might possibly be in crisis mode, due to the circumstances.”

Simpkins added approximately 50 of their 88 staff members came in to help every Thursday and Friday. Those who had government phones assisted off-site. Additionally, program managers with government phones came in to work right along with their employees.

 “Our number one priority was to ensure that all staff were safe upon entering the building,” Simpkins said. “We required a face mask and ensured that each person had their own space to make calls.  Not only did our government employees assist, but our contracting teams in Family Advocacy, Exceptional Family Member program and Relocation came in to help with the calls.  Everyone saw this as a great opportunity to assist our Families with resources and services that they may need during this unprecedented time.”

Phone calls were made over a five-week period. Each household received one call per week, reaching 4,273 on-post residents at least once. An average of 900 messages were left each week for residents. The messages let residents know where and how to reach out for help. 

ACS employees were provided with a script to help ensure the same message was being presented during each phone call.  Many of those being called had questions beyond the scope of ACS services; such as, where the COVID-19 screening locations were, where to find updates on installation facilities, and the Womack Army Medical Center Nurse Advice Line. In addition, Families that were not aware of the services ACS provided now had a one-on-one opportunity to ask questions and receive an answer from an expert. 

The phone calls came as a surprise to some residents that ACS and installation leaders would take the time to call and check on their wellbeing. Residents were connected with necessary resources, and ACS contact information was provided, in case they needed something or had more questions. During this unsure time, Families were left with a sense of security knowing they had someone to reach out to no matter their need.

“Residents largely welcomed the calls, appreciating that someone cared to check on them and offer assistance during this uncertain and stressful time,” said Audra Satterlee, ACS Specialist. “There was an impressively warm reception to the weekly calls. Because we ended up calling weekly, ACS staff members were even able to follow up on some of the questions asked and information provided from previous calls.”

Overall, most residents appreciated the welfare calls. However, some were not as receptive to the phone calls. Since the calls were unannounced, some Families were not sure if they were receiving a scam phone call or not. Additionally, others felt the questions about recent travel and recent health issues were an invasion of privacy and chose to not answer the questions. Hang-ups and blocking ACS phone numbers happened as well.

Although tedious during chaotic times, the phone calls produced positive interactions and exposure for Fort Bragg’s Army Community Service. 

“Some Families do not have a support network in the area,” Satterlee said. “Some had just arrived to the area. Some just had new babies and were basically on their own during the stay-at-home order. So to be able to engage with those Families and help ensure they were managing the new norm in a positive way was imperative to us. They might not have otherwise reached out to anyone for support.”

As we continue to navigate through our new normal in a COVID-19 world, it is important to remember that something as simple as a phone call can make an impact on the lives around us.
column9: 美国北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡
column10: 支持呼吁-ACS联系布拉格居民
column11: 北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡-面部覆盖物。流行病社交距离。几个月前，对大多数人来说，这些都是外来的想法和术语。今天，他们在我们的日常生活中都太熟悉了。当我们调整我们的生活方式时，我们也必须调整我们彼此沟通和互动的方式。布拉格堡的军队社区服务也不例外。他们需要找到一种方式来继续沟通和帮助他们的客户。ACS的工作人员决定呼吁派驻人员与我们的士兵和家属联系，向他们提供资源，并让他们知道，如果需要，随时都可以提供援助。打电话的工作人员被要求进入办公室。由于ACS办公室对公众关闭，这使得员工能够保持安全和社交距离。让员工到办公室接电话的另一个好处是，他们可以登记入住并互相检查，给经理们一些面对面的时间，以确保员工身体健康。ACS主管芭芭拉・特罗威尔・辛普金斯（Barbara Trower Simpkins）说：“由于我们的许多员工没有政府电话，我们要求员工自愿来协助接听电话。”。“员工们认为这是一个让更多家庭接触ACS服务的绝佳机会，尤其是那些由于环境原因可能处于危机状态的家庭。”辛普金斯补充说，他们的88名员工中约有50人每周四和周五都会来帮忙。那些使用政府电话的员工在场外得到帮助。此外，使用政府电话的项目经理也会直接与员工一起工作。“我们的首要任务是确保所有员工进入大楼时都是安全的。”辛普金斯说。“我们需要一个面罩，并确保每个人都有自己的空间打电话。不仅我们的政府雇员提供了帮助，而且我们在家庭倡导、特殊家庭成员计划和搬迁方面的合同团队也来帮助打电话。每个人都认为这是一个利用资源和资源帮助我们家庭的绝佳机会他们在这前所未有的时期可能需要的服务。”电话通话持续了五周。每家每户每周都会接到一个电话，至少一次到达4273个居民邮箱。平均每周给居民留下900条信息。这些信息让居民知道在哪里以及如何寻求帮助。ACS员工被提供了一个脚本，以帮助确保同样的信息被发送出去ing在每次通话中都会出现。许多被呼叫者的问题超出了ACS服务的范围；例如，新冠病毒-19筛查地点在哪里，在哪里可以找到安装设施的更新，以及沃马克陆军医疗中心护士咨询热线。此外，不知道ACS提供服务的家庭现在已经知道了d一对一的提问机会，并从专家那里得到答案。这些电话让一些居民感到意外，因为ACS和安装领导会花时间打电话检查他们的健康状况。居民们与必要的资源联系，并提供ACS联系信息，以防他们需要什么或者有更多的问题。在这段不确定的时间里，家人都有一种安全感，他们知道无论需要什么都有人可以联系。“居民们基本上欢迎这些电话，感谢有人在这段不确定和紧张的时间里关心他们并提供帮助，”ACS专家Audra Satterlee说。“每周电话都受到了令人印象深刻的热情接待。因为我们最终每周都会打电话，ACS的工作人员甚至能够跟进之前电话中提出的一些问题和提供的信息。”总的来说，大多数居民都很欣赏这些福利电话。然而，一些居民对这些电话不太愿意接受。由于这些电话是未经通知的，一些家庭不确定他们是否收到了诈骗电话。此外，其他人认为有关最近的旅行和最近的健康问题是对隐私的侵犯，因此选择了nT回答问题。挂断电话和封锁ACS电话号码也发生了。虽然在混乱时期很乏味，但这些电话为布拉格堡的军队社区服务带来了积极的互动和曝光。“一些家庭在该地区没有支持网络，”Satterlee说。“一些人刚到该地区。一些人刚生了婴儿，在家庭生活期间基本上是自己一个人。因此，能够与这些家庭接触并帮助确保他们以积极的方式管理新规范对我们来说至关重要。否则，他们可能不会向任何人寻求支持。”当我们在一个新的世界中继续探索新的常态时，重要的是要记住，像电话这样简单的事情可以对我们周围的生活产生影响。

column2: 364th Training Squadron students earn ACE award
column3:
SHEPPARD AIR FORCE BASE, Texas C To earn the ACE award, an Airman must maintain a 100% average throughout an entire training course.

 

Two Airmen from the 364th Training Squadron electrical and environmental course were able to remain dedicated to their training and earn this noteworthy award. 

 

Rank and Name: Airman 1st Class Patrick Lahey and Airman 1st Class Laura Sachwitz

 

Unit: 364th Training Squadron 

 

Duty title: Electrical and environmental apprentice course students

 

Hometown: 

Lahey- Castro Valley, California

Sachwitz- St. Paul, Minnesota

 

Time in Service:

Both- 1 year

 

Why I joined: 

Lahey- To start a new career that is practical and honorable

Sachwitz- I grew up going to air shows and I’ve always loved aircraft. I also                          wanted to continue my education.

 

Family: 

Lahey- Brothers, Taylor and Sean; Parents Mike and Mei-Lung

Sachwitz- Siblings, Kirsten and Gabriel; Parents David and Elizabeth 

 

Hobbies:

Lahey-  Basketball, Volleyball, board games, reading

Sachwitz- Fishing, hiking, traveling

 

Favorite aspect of the job: 

Lahey- I love learning to work with my hands and navigate the systems

Sachwitz- Working on the aircraft

 

Most memorable Air Force experience: 

Lahey- The Airman’s run

Sachwitz- My tech school experience of being taught by awesome instructors

 

How do you make responsible choices:

Lahey- I keep the movie  “The End Game” in mind and execute accordingly

Sachwitz- By remembering that I’m representing myself and my career field

 

Instructor comment: 

“Lahey is one of the most dedicated students I’ve had in years.” - Robert Honeycutt, 364th TRS electrical and environmental course instructor

 

“It was a pleasure to teach Airman 1st Class Sachwitz. She was an awesome student and dedicated Airman.” - Robert Honeycutt, 364th TRS electrical and environmental course instructor
column9: 威奇托瀑布，德克萨斯州，美国
column10: 第364训练中队学生获得ACE奖
column11: 德克萨斯州谢泼德空军基地―要获得ACE奖，一名飞行员必须在整个训练课程中保持100%的平均成绩。来自第364训练中队电气与环境课程的两名飞行员能够继续致力于他们的训练，并获得这一值得关注的奖项。军衔和姓名：空军一等兵帕特里克・拉希和空军一等兵劳拉・萨切维茨部队：第364训练中队职务：电气和环境学徒课程学生肖梅敦：拉希-卡斯特罗谷，加利福尼亚州阿萨维茨-圣保罗，明尼索塔州服役：两者-我加入的原因：Lahey-开始一个实用而光荣的新职业Sachwitz-我是在航空展上长大的，我一直喜欢飞机。我也想继续我的教育。家庭：拉希兄弟，泰勒和肖恩；父母Mike和Mei LungSachwitz――兄弟姐妹Kirsten和Gabriel；父母大卫和伊丽莎白的爱好：篮球、排球、棋盘游戏、阅读、钓鱼、徒步旅行、，旅行工作中最喜欢的方面：Lahey-我喜欢学习用手操作和导航系统Sachwitz-在飞机上工作最难忘的空军经验：Lahey-飞行员的runSachwitz-我在科技学校的经历是由很棒的教员教我如何做出负责任的选择：Lahey-我保留这部电影“最后的游戏”记在心里，并按照Lysachwitz执行――记住我是代表我自己和我的职业领域讲师评论：“Lahey是我多年来最专注的学生之一。”-Robert Honeycutt，第364届TRS电气与环境课程讲师“很高兴能教空军一等兵萨克维茨。她是一名出色的学生，也是一名敬业的飞行员。”-罗伯特・霍尼卡特，第364届TRS电气与环境课程讲师

column2: 726th ACS commander and spouse renovate mothers’ room
column3:
Often times, the achievement of military members are held in high regards, while the actions of their spouses are seen as the support of their greatness. Some stand out though, and find their own greatness in the support of their military partners, and the units they belong to.

Lt. Col. Richard Barber, 726th Air Control Squadron commander, and his wife, Kath Barber, provide an example of initiative by renovating the ACS mothers’ room, Sept. 20 2019. 

The new additions were made possible due to the Barbers’ donations, and most of the work was done by Kath herself. 

 "We funded it completely,” Kath said. “I probably spent a little more than most would, but it doesn’t have to be expensive to be nice, it just needs a few touches to make it more personal.”

The changes include painting the walls, bringing in various sanitation items and a donated couch adding to the overall comfort of ACS mothers.

“We really didn’t want it to feel like a sterile Air Force room,” Kath said. “The less stressed a mother is the better she can express breast milk. I collectively pumped and breastfed for four and a half years, so I know how hard it is.”

The renovations fall in line with the recent update to Air Force Guidance Memorandum 2019-36-02, though Kath stated she wanted to do more for ACS moms.

"When I was pumping for my first kid, it was just a back office - it felt really awkward," said Staff Sgt. Tawnee Ash, 726th ACS quality assurance evaluator. "[The mothers’ room] is wonderful. It feels like home here and not like I’m pumping at work."

The Barbers wanted to support their working moms by providing a stress-free environment to pump and feel comfortable.

“It is Air Force regulation that every squadron has a mothers’ room, but there are no guidelines further than a comfortable chair, a hard surface and a lock on the door,” Kath said. “We decided to take it up a notch.”

People like the Barber family help improve the lives of base personnel by making changes themselves. Kath providing a renovated mothers’ room shows her compassion for ACS moms, and her drive to help them.
column6: MOUNTAIN HOME AIR FORCE BASE, ID, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国印第安纳州山地家园空军基地
column10: 726 ACS指挥官和配偶翻修母亲房
column11: 很多时候，军人的成就受到高度评价，而他们配偶的行为则被视为他们伟大的支撑。然而，有些人脱颖而出，在他们的军事伙伴和所属部队的支持下发现了自己的伟大。理查德・巴伯上校（Col.Richard Barber），726空管中队指挥官，和他的妻子凯思・巴伯（Kath Barber），于2019年9月20日通过翻修ACS母亲病房提供了一个先例。由于理发师的捐赠，新增加的理发师成为可能，而且大部分工作都是由Kath自己完成的。“我们完全资助了这项活动，”Kath说。“我可能比大多数人花得多一点，但做得漂亮并不一定要花很多钱，只需要几下就可以让它更个人化。”这些变化包括粉刷墙壁，带来各种卫生用品和捐赠的沙发，为ACS妈妈们增添整体舒适感。“我们真的不想让它感觉像一间无菌的空军房间，”凯思说。“母亲压力越小，母乳分泌就越好。我集体抽奶和母乳喂养了四年半，所以我知道这有多难。”尽管Kath表示她想为ACS的妈妈们做更多的事，“当我为我的第一个孩子抽水时，这只是一个后台办公室――感觉真的很尴尬，”ACS第726质量保证评估员Tawnee Ash上士说理发师们想为工作中的妈妈们提供一个无压力的环境，让她们感到舒适，以此来支持她们。凯思说：“根据空军的规定，每个中队都有一间母亲病房，但除了舒适的椅子、坚硬的表面和门锁之外，没有其他指导方针。我们决定把它提高一个档次。”像巴伯一家这样的人通过自己的改变来帮助改善基地人员的生活。凯丝提供了一个翻新的母亲房间，这表明她对ACS母亲的同情，以及她帮助她们的动力。

column2: 729th ACS enhance readiness with Raging Bull Exercise
column3:
-- During the month of September, the 729th Air Control Squadron participated in Raging Bull, the unit’s largest exercise of the year. Airmen from the squadron convoyed from Hill Air Force Base to historic Wendover Airfield located in Utah’s western desert.

At Wendover, Airmen from 729th ACS set up a remote radar site, extending the unit’s abili9ty to control aircraft beyond the limitations of using a single location. In addition, a center and reporting contingent was setup within their compound back at Hill AFB that was staffed by several hundred personnel from various career fields. 

In addition to setting up a remote radar site, the squadron set up a campsite and established services such as power and heating, ventilation, and air conditioning to exercise for future deployments.

“These are an amazing group of Airmen,” said 2nd Lt. Jaceson Powell. “They came out here with operation goal of getting the site set up in 72 hours and they did it in 48 hours.”

During the exercise, the Airmen realistic readiness training. The squadron participate in multiple chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear scenarios, along with anti-terrorism and force protection responses, as well as medical training in self-aid buddy care.

Readiness exercises such as Raging Bull prepare the 729th ACS a meet a potential world-wide tasking at any given time.

“Our mission is to deploy on short notice to anywhere in the world and provide combatant commanders with persistent 24/7 battle management command and control of joint air operations,” said Lt. Col. Jeffrey Digsby, 729th ACS commander. 

The 729th ACS provides the theater Air Force commander a rapid reaction mobile air control system and control and reporting center during worldwide contingencies.

“This exercise honed the Airmen’s deployment skills,” Powell said. “We deploy …so we need to keep them ready for the next deployment when we carry out the actual mission. This keeps them in that deployment mindset, because it can happen at any time.”
column9: 温多弗，犹他州，美国
column10: 729 ACS通过狂怒公牛训练增强准备状态
column11: --9月份，第729空管中队参加了该部队本年度最大规模的演习《愤怒的公牛》。该中队的飞行员从希尔空军基地护送到位于犹他州西部沙漠的历史悠久的温多弗机场。在温多弗，来自729 ACS的飞行员建立了一个远程雷达站，使该部队控制飞机的能力超越了使用单一地点的限制。此外，在他们位于希尔空军基地的大院内设立了一个中心和报告小组，由数百名来自不同职业领域的人员组成。除了建立一个远程雷达站，该中队还建立了一个营地，并为未来的部署提供电力、供暖、通风和空调等服务。“这是一支令人惊叹的飞行员队伍，”第二中尉杰克森・鲍威尔说。“他们来到这里的行动目标是在72小时内建立现场，并在48小时内完成。”在演习期间，飞行员进行了实际的准备训练。该中队参与多种化学、生物、辐射和核场景，以及反恐和部队保护响应，以及自助伙伴护理方面的医疗培训。准备就绪演习（如《愤怒的公牛》）为729 ACS做好准备，随时满足潜在的全球任务。“我们的任务是在接到通知后立即部署到世界任何地方，并为作战指挥官提供持续的全天候作战管理指挥和联合空中作战控制。”第729 ACS指挥官杰弗里・迪格斯比中校（Jeffrey Digsby）说。第729 ACS为战区空军指挥官提供了一个快速反应移动空中控制系统，以及在全球紧急情况下的控制和报告中心。鲍威尔说：“这次演习磨练了飞行员的部署技能。”。“我们部署……因此我们需要在执行实际任务时让他们为下一次部署做好准备。这让他们保持部署心态，因为这随时都可能发生。”

column2: Surface Combat Systems Courses Recommended for ACE Accreditation
column3:
Dahlgren, Va. C The Center for Surface Combat Systems (CSCS) recently announced that the American Council on Education (ACE), an academic accreditation agency, has recommended college credit for over 660 surface combat systems courses.

A team of academic experts in May evaluated five ratings; Fire Controlman (FC), Gunner's Mate (GM), Interior Communications Electrician (IC), and Sonar Technician (Surface) (STG), which were approaching academic expiration, and Fire Controlman Aegis (FCA), which was gaining college credits for the first time.

“The purpose was to determine whether a given military occupation contains the type of knowledge and skills that would be comparable to learning acquired in college-level courses,” explained Ms. Nadine Galazka, CSCS’ ACE program manager.  “The academia subject matter experts interviewed Sailors from our sites and dets, who assembled at CSCS Det East, and conducted interviews via teleconference.  The discussions focused on responsibilities, functions, duties, and skills of the job.”

Other commands and ships were involved in this vital effort as well, including Commander, Naval Surface Force, Atlantic; Commander, U.S. 3rd Fleet; Commander, Destroyer Squadron 22; Naval Sea Systems Command’s Supervisor of Shipbuilding, Conversion, and repair; Afloat Training Group, Norfolk; Naval Air Station Patuxent River; Naval Station Norfolk Air Operations; Mid Atlantic Regional Maintenance Center; Navy Supply Fleet Logistics Center; Afloat Media Systems; USS Arleigh Burke (DDG 51); USS Cole (DDG 67); USS Oscar Austin (DDG 79); USS Winston S. Churchill (DDG 81); PCU Delbert D. Black (DDG 119); USS Normandy (CG 60); USS George H.W. Bush (CVN 77); and USS Gerald R. Ford (CVN 78).  

“The advantage of this accreditation is that many service members and veterans have been able to receive recommended credit at a college or university,” Galazka explained.  “At approximately 500 dollars per credit, it is about a 331,000 dollars savings for Sailors seeking degrees.” 

The ACE evaluation provides recommendations only and therefore, Sailors should visit a local Navy College Office to determine if the credits will be accepted at the college or university of their choice.

"The expertise of the surface combat systems community played a vital role in receiving these college, recommended credit hours for our students," Galazka said.  "As a global, educational institution, CSCS strives each day to provide the tools that Sailors need to excel not only in the fleet, but in society as a whole.”

CSCS' mission is to develop and deliver surface ship combat systems training to achieve surface warfare superiority. CSCS headquarters' staff oversees 14 learning sites and detachments located throughout the continental United States, Hawaii, and Japan and manages and operates a Naval Education and Training Command (NETC) training division in Rota, Spain.  CSCS provides over 538 courses, awards 114 different Navy Enlisted Classifications (NECs), and trains over 38,000 Sailors a year.  CSCS delivers specialized training for Officer and Enlisted Sailors to tactically operate, maintain, and employ shipboard and shore-based weapons, sensors, and command and control systems utilized in today's Navy.

For information on the Center for Surface Combat Systems, visit: https://www.netc.navy.mil/centers/cscs/

column9: 达尔格伦，弗吉尼亚州，美国
column10: 水面作战系统课程推荐ACE认证
column11: 弗吉尼亚州达尔格伦――地面作战系统中心（CSCS）最近宣布，学术认证机构美国教育委员会（ACE）已为660多门地面作战系统课程推荐大学学分；消防队员（FC）、炮手大副（GM）、内部通信电工（IC）和声纳技术员（水面）（STG）即将学业期满，消防队员宙斯盾（FCA）首次获得大学学分。CSCS ACE项目经理Nadine Galazka女士解释说：“目的是确定某一特定军事职业是否包含可与大学课程学习相媲美的知识和技能类型。”。“学术界的主题专家采访了来自我们现场和Det的海员，他们聚集在CSCS Det East，并通过电话会议进行了采访。讨论的重点是职责、职能、职责和工作技能。”其他司令部和舰艇也参与了这项重要工作，包括大西洋海军水面部队司令部；美国第三舰队司令部；第22驱逐舰中队司令部；海军海洋系统司令部造船、改装和维修主管；诺福克海上训练组；帕塔克森特河海军航空站；诺福海军站lk航空公司；大西洋中部地区维修中心；海军补给舰队后勤中心；水上媒体系统；美国航空母舰阿利・伯克（DDG 51）；美国航空母舰科尔（DDG 67）；美国航空母舰奥斯卡・奥斯汀（DDG 79）；美国航空母舰温斯顿・S・丘吉尔（DDG 81）；PCU・德尔伯特・D・布莱克（DDG 119）；美国航空母舰诺曼底（CG 60）；美国航空母舰乔治・H・W・布什（CVN 77）；美国航空母舰杰拉尔德・R・福特（CVN 78）。加拉兹卡解释说：“这种认证的好处是，许多服役人员和退伍军人能够在学院或大学获得推荐学分。每个学分大约500美元，对于寻求学位的海员来说，大约可以节省331000美元。”ACE评估只提供建议，因此，水手应该访问当地的海军大学办公室，以确定是否将在他们选择的学院或大学接受学分。“地面作战系统社区的专业知识在接收这些学院，推荐的学分对我们的学生起着至关重要的作用。”加拉兹卡说：“作为一个全球性的教育机构，CSCS每天都在努力提供水手们所需要的工具，使他们不仅在舰队中，而且在整个社会中脱颖而出。”CSCS的任务是开发和提供水面舰艇作战系统训练，以实现水面作战优势。CSCS总部的工作人员负责监督遍布美国大陆、夏威夷和日本的14个学习基地和分遣队，并管理和运营海军教育和训练司令部（NETC）训练师位于西班牙罗塔。CSCS提供超过538门课程，奖励114种不同的海军士兵分类（NEC），每年培训38000多名水手。CSCS为军官和士兵提供专业培训，使他们能够在战术上操作、维护和使用当今海军使用的舰载和岸基武器、传感器以及指挥和控制系统。有关水面作战系统中心的信息，请访问：https://www.netc.navy.mil/centers/CSC/在Facebook上访问我们：https://www.facebook.com/pages/Center-for-Surface-Combat-Systems/1480366868885239?ref=hl

column2: Video chat technology transforms ACS, fosters readiness
column3:
The Army Community Services (ACS) lifeline between Tobyhanna Army Depot and Picatinny Arsenal, New Jersey, went live earlier this summer rebooting a series of programs lost to budget cuts in 2017.

The inventive workaround, developed by depot experts, gives eligible personnel stationed at Picatinny easy access to services more than a year after Army ACS ceased operations. Point to point video chat technology is making it possible for military and family members to meet face-to-face with ACS program managers at Tobyhanna, though miles separate them.
 
“It’s often the emotionally charged situation that causes an individual to reach out to ACS for assistance,” said Andrew Ciccolella, Picatinny Morale, Welfare and Recreation director.  “There is something so personal about a video call versus a phone call.  Callers can see they have the manager’s undivided attention and are able to put a face to the name.”

In a few minutes, customers can live chat with a subject matter expert at Tobyhanna by following easy to understand prompts on a computer monitor. The non-CAC (common access card) enabled system in the Picatinny ACS office is connected to three workstations in the Installation Services Directorate’s Army Community Services Branch. The plan is to have the entire staff equipped to support the new way of doing business by 2020. 

“Soldiers and their families are going to find this new way of doing things very helpful,” said Staff Sgt. Edward Morris, religious affairs noncommissioned officer at Picatinny. “Spouses who don’t have common access cards no longer need to rely on the service member to take advantage of the various ACS programs. This is significant, especially when a Soldier deploys.”  

Picatinny and Tobyhanna officials were able to restore ACS programs at the arsenal by implementing a hub and spoke type of network last year. Operating as a regional hub, Tobyhanna helped Picatinny expand their support services from one-day-a-week visits conducted by a depot staff member to a functional, on-site office featuring state-of-the-art equipment and staffed with an ACS specialist. 

ACS Specialist Isabelle Yaroch makes sure necessary documents are available, directs customers to the right people, and schedules meetings or classes. She also oversees the volunteer program for Tobyhanna and Picatinny.  

“I’m thrilled to be a part of this new way of doing business,” Yaroch said.  “My job is to take care of the community, so the warfighter can focus on the mission.”

The idea to leverage technology was born from a desire to improve the quality of life for military members and their families.  The ability to video chat with trained professionals who are miles away is just the first step toward creating a new normal for the Army’s ACS mission. 

Plans for this technology includes offering virtual training classes on how to write a resume, apply for a government job or manage personal finances.  All classes offered at Tobyhanna will be taught at Picatinny once the capability is developed, according to Lisa Crews, Army Community Services Branch chief at Tobyhanna.  

“It’s possible to build on the hub and spoke network by partnering with other installations facing the same issues as Picatinny,” Crews said. “Picatinny and Tobyhanna were successful because of the strength of teamwork.”
column9: 美国宾夕法尼亚州
column10: 视频聊天技术改变了ACS，提高了准备能力
column11: 今年夏天早些时候，位于新泽西州Tobyhanna陆军基地和Picatinny兵工厂之间的陆军社区服务（ACS）生命线上线，重新启动了2017年因预算削减而失败的一系列计划。由基地专家开发的创新解决方案，在陆军ACS停止运作一年多后，使驻扎在皮卡汀尼的合格人员能够轻松获得服务。点对点视频聊天技术使军人和家庭成员能够在Tobyhanna与ACS项目经理面对面会面，尽管miles将他们分开。“通常是情绪激动的情况导致个人向ACS寻求帮助，”Picatinny Taila的Andrew Ciccolela说，福利及康乐事务署署长。“视频通话与电话通话相比，有着非常私人的一面。打电话的人可以看到他们得到了经理的全神贯注，并且能够给名字贴上一张脸。”几分钟后，客户可以按照计算机显示器上易于理解的提示，与Tobyhanna的主题专家进行实时聊天。Picatinny ACS办公室的非CAC（公共访问卡）启用系统连接到安装服务董事会陆军社区服务处的三个工作站。该计划是到2020年，让全体员工都能支持新的经营方式。“士兵和他们的家人会发现这种新的做事方式非常有帮助，”皮卡廷尼宗教事务士官爱德华・莫里斯上士说。“没有公共访问卡的配偶不再需要依靠服役人员来利用各种ACS计划。这一点非常重要，尤其是当士兵部署时。”Picatinny和Tobyhanna官员去年通过实施一种中心辐射式网络，得以恢复兵工厂的ACS计划。作为一个区域中心，Tobyhanna帮助Picatinny将其支持服务从一名仓库工作人员每周一天的访问扩展到一个功能齐全的现场办公室，该办公室配备最先进的设备和ACS专家。ACS专家Isabelle Yaroch确保提供必要的文件，指导客户找到合适的人，安排会议或课程。她还负责监督托比安娜和皮卡汀尼的志愿者项目。“我很高兴能成为这种新的商业方式的一部分，”Yaroch说。“我的工作是照顾社区，让战士能够专注于任务。”利用技术的想法诞生于改善军人及其家庭生活质量的愿望。能够与数英里外训练有素的专业人员视频聊天只是为陆军ACS任务创造新常态的第一步。这项技术的计划包括提供虚拟培训课程，内容包括如何撰写简历、申请政府职位或管理个人财务。托比汉纳陆军社区服务处处长丽莎・克鲁斯（Lisa Crews）表示，一旦能力得到发展，托比汉纳提供的所有课程都将在皮卡汀尼授课。克鲁斯说：“通过与面临与皮卡汀尼相同问题的其他装置合作，可以在中心辐射网络上进行建设。”。“Picatinny和Tobyhanna的成功是因为团队合作的力量。”

column2: 607th ACS all female mission makes history
column3:
For the first time in Air Force history, the Command and Control Battle Management Operations career field executed a mission on its newest weapon system, the Battlefield Control System, with an entirely female crew. From scheduling and mission planning to communications equipment set up and maintenance, a full crew of women from the 607th Air Control Squadron at Luke Air Force Base left their mark on history. 

The 607 ACS is a schoolhouse tasked with developing the future of command and control, one Airman at a time. They are responsible for seven different courses ranging from the initial Surveillance Technician course for recent graduates of their preliminary technical training to the Undergraduate Weapons Director course, teaching Airman aerial engagement and combat weapon system employment and management tactics. Normally, at any given time, there are nearly 80 Airmen in training at the 607 ACS. 

“We teach our students how to interpret radar data and make sure that we are controlling the battle and keeping our pilots as safe as possible in what are usually the busiest air spaces in the world when we deploy,” said Master Sgt. Summer Chenault, 607th Air Control Squadron Alpha Flight Chief. 

Mission planning is an all-day event and starts the day before the mission. The team uses intelligence gathered to plan a war-time battle management scenario from beginning to end. They look at types of friendly and enemy aircraft anticipated, how many air bases are in the area, political borders and what they can expect from each crew member. 

“It is very detailed because if you don’t understand what you’re doing when you step out there, then you’re not going to understand what you should be doing while you’re performing the mission,” Chenault said.

With 18 members involved in the mission in some way and in an operations environment that has traditionally been male dominated, the opportunity to conduct a mission with this type of crew had never presented itself on this weapon system.  

“In such a small career field with very few women and even fewer in weapons controller positions, it’s been difficult to accomplish a mission like this,” said Staff Sgt. Amber Hoedebeck, 607 ACS Weapons Director Initial Qualification Training course manager. “To look across the board and see all of my mentors and peers that I am working with and to see that they are females, there is nothing greater in a day like today.” 

Although the mission itself was conducted by an entirely female crew, the excitement was felt throughout the 607 ACS.

“Our leadership team and everyone else were very supportive,” said Chenault.  “We are a family and they looked at it as ‘heck yeah’ and thought it was awesome that we were out there doing this.” 

Whether it’s carrying out an all-female mission or any daily mission, the instructor cadre aims to inspire and takes pride in sending the best trained Command and Control Battle Managers out into the combat Air Forces. 

“There is nothing like it,” said Chenault. “I get emotional because I am so proud of what we do. It’s incredible to watch them from start to finish, and I know when they leave here with the training they’ve received, the future of our career field is in safe hands.”
column6: LUKE AIR FORCE BASE, AZ, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国亚利桑那州卢克空军基地
column10: 第607届ACS全女性使命创造历史
column11: 在空军历史上，指挥与控制作战管理职业领域首次在其最新的武器系统――战场控制系统上执行任务，全体机组人员为女性。从日程安排和任务规划到通信设备的安装和维护，来自卢克空军基地第607空中控制中队的全体女性机组人员在历史上留下了他们的印记。607ACS是一所学校，负责开发未来的指挥和控制，一次一名飞行员。他们负责七门不同的课程，从初级技术培训的应届毕业生的初级监视技术员课程到本科武器主管课程，教授飞行员空中交战和作战武器系统使用和管理战术。通常，在任何特定时间，都有近80名飞行员在607 ACS接受训练。“我们教我们的学生如何解读雷达数据，确保我们在部署时能够控制战斗，并在通常是世界上最繁忙的空域尽可能保证我们的飞行员的安全，”第607空中控制中队阿尔法飞行负责人萨默特・切诺上士说。任务规划是一项全天活动，从任务开始的前一天开始。该团队利用收集到的情报从头至尾规划战时作战管理场景。他们研究了预计的敌友飞机类型、该地区有多少空军基地、政治边界以及他们对每个机组成员的期望。Chenault说：“这是非常详细的，因为如果你不明白你在那里做什么，那么你就不会明白你在执行任务时应该做什么。”有18名成员以某种方式参与了任务，而且在一个传统上以男性为主的作战环境中，在这种武器系统上，从未出现过用这种类型的乘员执行任务的机会。607 ACS武器总监初始资格培训课程经理、参谋中士Amber Hoedebeck说：“在这样一个职业领域，女性人数很少，担任武器控制员职位的女性更少，很难完成这样的任务。”。“放眼全局，看看我所有的导师和同事，看看他们都是女性，在今天这样的日子里，没有什么比这更伟大的了。”虽然任务本身是由一个完全由女性船员执行的，但整个607 ACS都感受到了兴奋。“我们的领导团队和所有其他人都非常支持。”切诺说。“我们是一家人，他们认为这是‘见鬼，是的’，并认为我们在那里做这件事太棒了。”无论是执行全女性任务还是任何日常任务，教练干部都旨在激励并自豪地将训练有素的指挥和控制战斗管理人员派遣到作战空军。“没有比这更好的了，”切诺说。“我很激动，因为我为我们所做的感到骄傲。从开始到结束都能看到他们，这是难以置信的。我知道，当他们带着接受的训练离开这里时，我们职业领域的未来就在安全的手中。”

column2: Top Secret- The Forgotten Fighter Ace of the Korean War
column3:
Retired Navy Capt. E. Royce Williams has been keeping a secret for more than 50 years. 
To his friends, family, and others he served with, Williams was known as a decorated fighter pilot, who led a successful career in the Navy, where he served for more than 30 years and flew more than 220 missions in Korea and Vietnam. However, even his wife wasn’t aware of what he’d done on Nov. 18, 1952. 
That morning, Williams was continuing what had become a daily routine for him as a young Navy pilot stationed onboard the USS Oriskany off the coast of Korea during the Korean War; flying his F9F-5 Panther fighter aircraft over the skies of North Korea to attack targets in support of operations on the ground. On this particular morning, the only difference was the targets were further north than usual C close to the country’s border with the Soviet Union. 
Despite a blizzard sweeping in with heavy winds and snow, Williams said the mission began successfully, with minor amounts of anti-aircraft fire. However, they hadn’t counted on the nearby Soviet base to notice their presence. Within minutes, the Soviets went to general quarters and scrambled seven MiG-15 fighters to react to the situation. 
“Our combat information center notified us that there were inbound bogeys,” said Williams. “I spotted seven contrails coming from the north, and identified them as MiGs.”
Once the MiGs passed over Williams and his wingman, they circled around and split into two groups C four to the right, and three to the left. Williams lost sight of the aircraft, and was ordered to move closer to the strike group to protect it in case the Soviets attacked. 
That’s when they dropped back in on Williams. 
“They dropped back in and started shooting,” said Williams. “Since they started the fight, I shot back.”
Williams quickly locked on to one of the aircraft and hit it, watching as it caught fire and billowed smoke on its way down. His wingman followed it, leaving Williams alone with the remaining MiGs. 
In another intense moment, Williams was able to dodge the weapons fire and shoot back, downing another MiG, leaving two of the original four in the fight. 
“I’m on the defensive C I’m not really declaring war on them,” said Williams. 
As he kept maneuvering to avoid being hit by the hundreds of bullets being fired, one of the Soviet pilots made a grave mistake, putting his aircraft directly in Williams’ sights. He took the opportunity and opened fire, downing a third MiG. 
On another turn, Williams felt his aircraft shake violently as it was hit by a MiG’s 37mm cannon C ripping holes in his fuselage and exploding, leaving his aircraft severely damaged. 
As he struggles to stay in the fight, something else goes wrong C Williams runs out of ammunition. 
The remaining MiGs followed Williams as he turned his damaged aircraft into the storm, using the high winds to shield himself from the incoming rounds as he headed full speed back towards his task force. 
“I could see the bullets coming over me, and under me,” said Williams. 
As he approached the task force, the remaining MiGs quickly retreated, assuming Williams probably wouldn’t make it back to the Oriskany due to severe damage regardless. Williams knew if he ejected, he’d end up freezing to death before he could be rescued, and his communications were now severed due to the damage done to his aircraft. He had no choice but to attempt a landing. 
To make matters worse, the task force had gone to general quarters with orders to open fire on any unidentified aircraft; since Williams couldn’t communicate with them, they opened fire on his aircraft C luckily stopping once he got close enough to identify. 
His Panther was unable to slow down or it would stall, which forced Williams to make his landing at 200 miles per hour. Somehow, he was still able to catch a wire on the flight deck and emerged unscathed. 
The next day, the crew inspected his Panther and found 263 holes in the aircraft. 
“You’d be surprised, it was almost like a training mission,” said Williams, recounting the story. “I was pretty stable.”
Soon after returning, Williams was ordered into a meeting with his Admiral and a representative of a brand new government agency C the National Security Agency. The NSA had been testing new communications equipment that was intercepting radio chatter from the Soviets, and they knew if any details from Williams’ mission went public, the Soviets would know the United States could hear their communications. Therefore, Williams was ordered not to tell a soul about his mission C it was classified as Top Secret. 
For the rest of his accomplished Navy career, and for decades after retirement, the details of Williams’ dogfight with Soviet MiGs over North Korea remained a secret. When he was finally contacted by the government and told his mission was declassified, the first person Williams said he told was his wife.
column9: 加利福尼亚州，美国
column10: 绝密-被遗忘的朝鲜战争王牌
column11: 退休的海军上校E・罗伊斯・威廉姆斯（E.Royce Williams）已经保守秘密50多年了。对他的朋友、家人和其他同事来说，威廉姆斯是一位被授予勋章的战斗机飞行员，他在海军服役30多年，在韩国和越南执行了220多项任务，并取得了成功。然而，就连他的妻子也不知道他在1952年11月18日做了什么。那天早上，威廉姆斯继续着他在朝鲜战争期间作为一名年轻的海军飞行员在朝鲜海岸外的奥里斯卡尼号上的日常生活；驾驶他的F9F-5黑豹战斗机在朝鲜上空攻击目标，以支持地面行动。在这个特殊的早晨，唯一的区别是目标比平时更北――靠近该国与苏联的边界。威廉姆斯说，尽管暴风雪伴随着大风和大雪席卷而来，但任务成功开始，只进行了少量的防空火力。然而，他们没有指望附近的苏联基地会注意到他们的存在。几分钟后，苏联人前往总司令部，紧急派出7架米格-15战斗机对局势作出反应。威廉姆斯说：“我们的作战信息中心通知我们有入境的转向架。”。“我发现了七条从北方飞来的轨迹，并确认它们是米格。”一旦米格飞过威廉姆斯和他的僚机，它们就盘旋并分成两组――四组在右边，三组在左边。威廉姆斯失去了飞机的视线，并被命令向攻击群靠近，以防苏联袭击。就在那时，他们又拜访了威廉姆斯。威廉姆斯说：“他们回来后开始射击。”。威廉姆斯迅速锁定其中一架飞机并将其击落，看着飞机着火并在降落过程中冒出滚滚浓烟。他的僚机尾随其后，留下威廉姆斯一人和其余的米格。在另一个紧张的时刻，威廉姆斯躲过了武器的火力并进行了反击，击落了另一架米格，留下了最初四架中的两架。威廉姆斯说：“我处于守势――我并不是真的向他们宣战。”。当他继续机动以避免被数百发子弹击中时，一名苏联飞行员犯了一个严重错误，把他的飞机直接放在威廉姆斯的视线中。他抓住机会开火，击落了第三架米格。在另一个转弯处，威廉姆斯感觉到他的飞机被米格37毫米加农炮击中时剧烈摇晃――撕裂机身上的孔并爆炸，使他的飞机严重受损。当他挣扎着要留在战斗中时，另一件事出了问题――威廉姆斯的弹药耗尽了。其余的MIG跟随威廉姆斯，他将损坏的飞机转入风暴，在全速返回特遣部队时，利用大风保护自己不受来袭炮弹的影响。威廉姆斯说：“我可以看到子弹从我身上、身下飞过。”。当他接近特遣部队时，剩余的米格战斗机迅速撤退，假设威廉姆斯可能因为严重的破坏而无法返回奥里斯坎尼号。威廉姆斯知道，如果他弹射，在获救之前，他将被冻死，他的通讯现在由于飞机受损而中断。他别无选择，只好尝试着陆。更糟糕的是，特遣部队已前往总部，下令向任何身份不明的飞机开火；由于威廉姆斯无法与他们沟通，他们向他的飞机开火――幸运的是，一旦他靠近并确认身份，飞机就停了下来。他的黑豹无法减速或失速，这迫使威廉姆斯以每小时200英里的速度着陆。不知何故，他仍然能够抓住飞行甲板上的一根电线，毫发无损地走了出来。第二天，机组人员检查了他的黑豹，发现飞机上有263个洞。威廉姆斯在讲述故事时说：“你会感到惊讶，这几乎像是一次训练任务。”。“我很稳定。”返回后不久，威廉姆斯奉命与他的海军上将以及一个全新的政府机构――国家安全局的代表会面。美国国家安全局一直在测试新的通讯设备，以拦截来自苏联的无线电聊天，他们知道如果威廉姆斯任务的任何细节公开，苏联人就会知道美国可以听到他们的通讯。因此，威廉姆斯被命令不要告诉任何人他的任务――这被列为绝密。在他成功的海军生涯的剩余时间里，以及退休后的几十年里，威廉姆斯与苏联米格在朝鲜问题上的混战细节一直是个秘密。当政府最终联系到他并告知他的任务已经解密时，威廉姆斯说他告诉的第一个人是他的妻子。

column2: SMDC builds, tests satellite components with ACES RED
column3:
REDSTONE ARSENAL, Alabama C When dealing with the future of Army satellite technologies, SMDC keeps its ACES RED.

The Army Cost Efficient Spaceflight Research Experiments and Demonstrations, or ACES RED, is a U.S. Army Space and Missile Defense Command/Army Forces Strategic Command technology demonstration for small satellites in support of Army and command technical objectives with support from Radiance Technologies and the University of Alabama in Huntsville, or UAH, System Management and Production Center.

ACES RED was developed in the USASMDC/ARSTRAT Technical Center’s Concepts Analysis Laboratory, or CAL. The CAL brings together high school and college students, under the supervision and mentorship of SMDC Tech Center government employees, to perform hands-on tasks for government projects and SMDC research.

“ACES RED is built to increase the technology readiness level of different components for flight-based missions for other programs within the command,” said Mason Nixon, ACES RED principle investigator. “We are taking different technologies and trying to advance them while reducing risks so other programs don’t have to. We also want to train the incoming workforce and build up technical competencies in those core areas that support our missions.”

This experiment looks to quickly mature various commercially available off-the-shelf technologies that will reduce the cost and complexity as well as maintain the performance of future Army small satellites.

Its main technical goal is to solve vectoring problem solutions by implementing multiple sensors in various combinations or configurations. ACES RED’s secondary objectives include maturation of non-traditional and commercial off-the-shelf, or COTS, industrial-grade components in the place of traditionally hardened and more expensive space systems, such as flight computers, memory devices, imaging sensors and attitude determination devices.

“We are also using ACES RED as a pilot program to build up test capabilities for space hardware,” Nixon said. “We are hoping to gain future capabilities such as more refined attitude determination and control for satellites to help orient them when in space, as well as taking industrial-grade computers and testing them in a space environment. 

“Where you might see possibly tens of thousands of dollars for a piece of existing hardware, we are looking at hundreds of dollars,” he added.

One engineer added that this will mean SMDC can create something in-house with most of the parts that are going into space being designed and assembled here on Redstone Arsenal by in-house engineers.

“In the future the turnaround time, lead time and creating another iteration of ACES RED is going be quicker, faster and we are going to be able to get space hardware up there a lot faster and all the capabilities were designed here so we won’t have to outsource any of the design,” said Gauge Day, ACES RED chief engineer.

Day said initially his main role on ACES RED was working with the mechanical team and they had to figure out what direction the team was going to take with the design. He then took on the role of lead structural designer.

“My main focus and what I want to see come out of ACES RED is that we design a modular system for space,” Day said. “With it we are able to take modular trays out and can plug and play with different hardware, and any time we need to change something or something fails, we are able to swap it out and replace it. There is no stack feature so it is different from what most space systems have seen before with CubeSats.

“I want to see this become successful. Through vibrations and environmental testing so far we have been successful with something that is not native to space,” he added.

Day explained how the ACES RED modular system design is more convenient than a stackable system because replacing parts in stackable system is more difficult.

“With a stackable system, if your fourth board breaks, then you have to take the three on top of it off to get to the fourth one,” Day said. “ACES RED actually had this problem during an environmental test where a board needed replacing and we were able to slide a board out and replace it with a new one and it worked just fine.”

ACES RED is scheduled to be launched on a Falcon 9 rocket and attached to the outside of the International Space Station through the Department of Defense Space Test Program.

“Right now our payload is down at Johnson Space Center in Texas and it is being integrated into a full launch payload pallet with other experiments on it,” said Elizabeth Neilson, ACES RED lead systems engineer and integration specialist. “That pallet will then go through its own iteration of environmental testing and once it is finished we will be able to fix any issues that may come up during that time.

“We have definitely had a lot of lessons learned with ACES RED,” she added. “Our team was almost entirely composed of young engineers or college students and recent college graduates. There was a big learning curve and this was one of the first projects for a lot of people where people are actually designing space hardware that is going to be launched. There were a lot of things that tripped us up that we didn’t know going into it.”

Neilson said the support team at SMDC, leaders, and the research and technology team are always there to help them whenever they discover a problem.

She described how the CAL trains and mentors college students and young professionals via the Department of Defense's Science, Mathematics And Research for Transformation, or SMART, scholarship, which pays students full scholarship, stipend, insurance, and more to encourage science and technology studies.

Neilson also added that students at UAH can also work in the CAL via the Students working at the Army in parallel, or SWAP, where they are hired through a contract with UAH.

“Everybody on this team brought their own unique flair to it,” Neilson said. “The more experienced engineers know how things are supposed to work whereas it is nice to have younger engineers who get tripped up with issues and they have to think through the process.

“Then you have younger engineers who are asking questions and trying to learn along the way,” she added. “There are people coming in who have only designed theoretical projects for their classes and by the end of ACES RED they are making something that is going into space. So they are making all the mistakes that can be made and have learned lessons for future reference and they will wind up being really good engineers for the next project.”
column9: 美国阿尔卑斯州红石兵工厂
column10: SMDC使用ACES RED构建、测试卫星组件
column11: 阿拉巴马州红石兵工厂―在处理陆军卫星技术的未来时，SMDC保持其ACES红色。陆军成本效益太空飞行研究实验和演示，或ACES红色，是美国陆军航天和导弹防御司令部/陆军向小卫星提供战略司令部技术示范，以支持辐射技术和阿拉巴马大学亨茨维尔分校或UAH的陆军和指挥技术目标。系统管理和生产中心.ACES-RED是在USASMDC/ARSTRAT技术中心的概念分析实验室（简称CAL）开发的。CAL将高中生和大学生聚集在SMDC技术中心政府员工的监督和指导下，为政府项目和SMDC研究执行实际任务。“ACES RED旨在提高指挥部其他项目飞行任务不同组件的技术准备水平，”ACES RED主要调查员梅森・尼克松（Mason Nixon）说。“我们正在采用不同的技术，并试图在降低风险的同时推进这些技术，以便其他项目不必如此。我们还希望培训新员工，并在支持我们任务的核心领域建立技术能力。”该实验旨在快速成熟各种商用现货技术，以降低成本和复杂性，并保持未来陆军小型卫星的性能。其主要技术目标是通过以各种组合或配置实现多个传感器来解决矢量问题。ACES RED的次要目标包括成熟非传统和商用现货（COTS），即工业级组件，以取代传统的加固和更昂贵的空间系统，如飞行计算机、存储设备、成像传感器和姿态确定设备。尼克松说：“我们还将使用ACES RED作为试点项目，以建立太空硬件的测试能力。”。“我们希望获得未来的能力，例如更精确的卫星姿态确定和控制，以帮助卫星在太空中定向，以及携带工业级计算机并在太空环境中进行测试。“你可能会看到一件现有的硬件可能要花费数万美元，但我们要花几百美元，”他补充说。一位工程师补充说，这意味着SMDC可以在内部创造一些东西，将进入太空的大部分零件由内部工程师在红石兵工厂设计和组装。“在未来，ACES RED的周转时间、交付周期和创建另一个迭代将越来越快，我们将能够更快地获得空间硬件，所有功能都是在这里设计的，因此我们不必将任何设计外包。”ACES RED首席工程师Gauge Day说。Day说，最初他在ACES RED上的主要角色是与机械团队合作，他们必须确定团队在设计方面的方向。然后，他担任首席结构设计师。Day说：“我的主要关注点和我想看到的是，我们设计了一个模块化的空间系统。”。“有了它，我们可以取出模块化托盘，并可以使用不同的硬件进行即插即用，并且在任何时候我们需要更改某些内容或某些内容出现故障时，我们都可以将其交换并更换。由于没有堆叠功能，因此它与大多数空间系统以前使用立方体卫星看到的情况不同。他补充道：“我希望看到这项技术取得成功。通过振动和环境测试，到目前为止，我们已经成功地开发出了一些非太空固有的产品。”Day解释了ACES RED模块化系统设计如何比可堆叠系统更方便，因为更换可堆叠系统中的部件更困难。Day说：“在可堆叠系统中，如果第四块板子坏了，那么你必须把上面的三块板子取下来，才能找到第四块板子。ACES RED在一次环境测试中遇到了这个问题，当时有一块板子需要更换，我们可以将一块板子滑出来，换上一块新的，效果很好。”ACES RED计划由猎鹰9号火箭发射，并通过国防部空间测试计划连接到国际空间站外部。“目前，我们的有效载荷在德克萨斯州约翰逊航天中心降落，并与其他实验一起集成到一个完整的发射有效载荷托盘中。”ACES红铅系统工程师和集成专家Elizabeth Neilson说：“然后，该托盘将进行自己的环境测试迭代，一旦完成，我们将能够解决在此期间可能出现的任何问题。”她补充道，“我们肯定从ACES红铅系统中吸取了很多经验教训。”。“我们的团队几乎完全由年轻的工程师或大学生以及新近的大学毕业生组成。这是一个巨大的学习曲线，这是许多人的第一个项目之一，他们实际上正在设计即将发射的空间硬件。有很多事情让我们绊倒，我们不知道“去吧。”Neilson说，SMDC的支持团队、领导者以及研究和技术团队在他们发现问题时总是在那里帮助他们。她描述了加州大学如何通过国防部的科学、数学和转型研究或SMART奖学金培训和指导大学生和年轻专业人员，该奖学金向学生支付全额奖学金、津贴、保险等，以鼓励科学和技术学习。Neilson还补充说，UAH的学生也可以通过与UAH签订合同在陆军并行工作或交换的学生在加州大学工作。“这个团队中的每个人都有自己独特的才能。”Neilson说：“经验更丰富的工程师知道事情应该如何运作，而年轻的工程师被问题绊倒，他们必须思考整个过程，这是很好的。”她补充道：“然后，年轻的工程师会提出问题，并试图一路学习。”。“进来的人只为他们的课程设计了理论项目，到ACES RED结束时，他们正在做一些即将进入太空的事情。因此，他们犯下了所有可以犯的错误，并吸取了经验教训供将来参考，他们最终将成为下一个项目的真正优秀工程师。”

column2: 337th ACS- training international brothers and sisters in arms
column3:
To aid and augment the aerial capabilities of U.S. allies, one Tyndall squadron teaches a portion of Air Force techniques to international military officers.

“The mission of the 337th Air Control Squadron International Studies is to teach international military officers U.S. techniques for command and control of combat air operations,” said Lt. Col. Alexander Maclean, 337th ACS director of international studies. “Our building block approach to instruction offers a student the tools necessary to become proficient with core skills on both the tactical and operational level of war.”

The 337th ACS offers two classes, the International Air Weapons Controller Course and the Theater Air Operations Course four times per year, lasting approximately two and a half months and three weeks respectively, as part of the curriculum offered under the Air Force Security Assistance Training Program. 

“Of the 56 nations offered the class, currently there are an approximate 18 countries sending between 50 to 60 students annually,” Maclean said. 

Maclean explained that through this partnership, international students were not the only beneficiaries of the training opportunity. 

“We offer students and U.S. cadre a unique opportunity to foster lasting relationships with friendly nations through open dialog regarding professional differences, doctrine and culture,” he said. “This course pays dividends down-range when our cadre and personnel interact with course graduates in an operational environment.”

In an environment of Total Force Integration and joint environments the training that occurs at the 337th ACS can be viewed as the future of air dominance, albeit not a new advent.

“The 337th ACS has been training international students from over 56 countries for more than 50 years,” Maclean said. “Training has evolved to incorporate the latest techniques for counter-air and counter-land operations employed by Airborne Warning and Control Systems, Joint Surveillance and Target Attack Radar System, Control and Reporting Centers, and Air Operations Centers.” 

Maclean closed with his thoughts of the importance of the capabilities his squadron provides to the war fighting effort. 

“In today’s multi-national environment, the International Studies Directorate offers an opportunity for Tyndall personnel to interact with our international partners. It offers team Tyndall personnel to help foster the building of partnership capacity,” he concluded.
column6: TYNDALL AIR FORCE BASE, FL, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国佛罗里达州廷德尔空军基地
column10: 337 ACS-训练国际武装兄弟姐妹
column11: 为了帮助和增强美国盟国的空中能力，一个廷德尔空军中队向国际军官传授一部分空军技术。“337空中控制中队国际研究的任务是向国际军官传授美国对作战空中行动的指挥和控制技术。”第337届ACS国际研究主任亚历山大・麦克莱恩中校说。“我们的积木式教学法为学生提供了精通战争战术和作战层面核心技能所需的工具。”337 ACS提供了两门课程，即国际空中武器控制员课程和战区空中作战课程，每年四次，分别持续约两个半月和三周，作为空军安全援助培训计划课程的一部分。麦克莱恩说：“在提供这门课程的56个国家中，目前大约有18个国家每年派出50至60名学生。”。麦克莱恩解释说，通过这种合作关系，国际学生并不是培训机会的唯一受益者。他说：“我们为学生和美国干部提供了一个独特的机会，通过就职业差异、教义和文化进行公开对话，与友好国家建立持久的关系。”。“当我们的干部和人员在作战环境中与课程毕业生互动时，这门课程会在一定范围内产生回报。”在部队全面整合和联合环境中，337 ACS的训练可以被视为未来的空中优势，尽管这不是一个新的发展。麦克莱恩说：“50多年来，337 ACS一直在培训来自56个国家的国际学生。”。“训练已经演变为将机载警报和控制系统、联合监视和目标攻击雷达系统、控制和报告中心以及空中作战中心所采用的最新空对地作战技术结合起来。”麦克莱恩最后谈到了他的中队提供的作战能力的重要性。他总结道：“在当今的多国环境中，国际研究理事会为廷德尔团队人员提供了与国际合作伙伴互动的机会。它为廷德尔团队人员提供了帮助，以促进伙伴关系能力的建设。”。

column2: FRCE aces quality management surveillance audit with zero findings
column3:
MARINE CORPS AIR STATION CHERRY POINT, N.C. C Every industry has certifications that indicate standards of excellence achieved through the use of best practices. At a restaurant, diners may look to health inspection scores as a signal of safety; when it comes to vehicle repairs, consumers might seek a mechanic that is Automotive Service Excellence (ASE) certified. 

In the aviation maintenance, repair and overhaul industry, Aerospace Standard (AS) 9110 serves as the benchmark for excellence. Following a recent third-party surveillance audit, Fleet Readiness Center East (FRCE) became the first aviation depot within Commander, Fleet Readiness Centers (COMFRC) to pass an AS9110 audit with no findings. 

The result represents years of hard work and collaboration between many of FRCE’s internal departments, including Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul (MRO) Production, MRO Logistics, MRO Engineering, Facilities and Infrastructure Management, and Compliance and Quality. 

“As the first Fleet Readiness Center to complete an AS9110 audit with zero findings, it’s clear that our team’s hard work is paying off,” said Tina Rowe, MRO Production director at FRCE. “We are becoming the benchmark for the enterprise in how we do business; now, we need to keep the momentum going and sustain our standings so our customers continue to send work and to entice new customers and their potential workload.”

AS9110 assesses the processes, procedures and efficiencies of an organization’s quality management system. Conformance to the AS9110 standard is voluntary, and represents an above-and-beyond commitment to quality, said David Spencer, director of the Standards Division within FRCE’s Compliance and Quality Department.

“Customers can bring their business here knowing that our services are going to meet or exceed the intent of industry certification standards,” he explained. “Because we maintain this industry standard, our customers don’t need to come into our depot and do their own review of our processes. They can rest assured knowing that we're certified, that our systems are going to be right and tight, and that we’re going to get the job done with their products.”

Having the AS9110 certification makes FRCE an attractive choice for potential industry customers and helps the command retain existing customers, added FRCE Quality Manager Jeffrey O’Connell.  

“In the public-private partnership environment that we’re in, a lot of private industry weighs the AS9110 certification heavily in considering where they go for work,” O’Connell said. “For some of the companies that work with us, having this certification makes it easier for them to partner with us than it would have been without it.”

The AS9110 standard, developed by the International Aerospace Quality Group, is not prescriptive C it doesn’t provide an organization with specific instructions to do the things required for certification, Spencer noted. Rather, it provides an outline of the requirements and certification to this standard assesses conformance to those requirements through a series of audits. A full recertification audit takes place every three years; in between, annual surveillance audits like the one conducted this summer take place at certified facilities to ensure continued conformance to the standard. 

Whether assessing parts control and traceability, artisan training, product safety or a top management review, the standard doesn’t tell an organization how to do something, Spencer explained. “Instead, it breaks down the things you need to have, and the different layers of the organization that do those things. It’s really an external set of eyes that can come in and give us a good scrub.”

In addition to being the first FRC to complete AS9110 certification or surveillance with no audit findings, FRCE also became the first depot to earn certification from fence-to-fence, geographically speaking, rather than working to earn certification in individual buildings or lines. The cross-disciplinary, top-down approach toward quality management required to achieve whole-depot certification also helped FRCE shine in its most recent audit.

Daily meetings with MRO Production leadership provide a venue in which the team can rapidly address and resolve any quality management issues identified, Spencer said. The Facilities and Infrastructure Department head often sits in these meetings, as well, providing another level of support. Weekly meetings that also bring in MRO Logistics, MRO Engineering and the Compliance and Quality Department, offer opportunities to solve higher-level issues. 

“This is not a triage meeting,” O’Connell explained. “We’re not trying to find and address a specific issue C we’re trying to determine why an issue occurred and whether we can get a process in place to address it. We’re dedicating some time to problem-solve, rather than simply triaging and firefighting, because firefighting never ends.”

The commitment from top management to addressing quality management issues at the root level has made a huge difference in the team’s ability to address concerns, which in turn leads to better performance in audit situations and improved throughput and cost efficiency. 

“It’s management that’s gotten us to the point we’re at,” O’Connell said. “We could be here 20 hours a day and, without that management support, we would still be nowhere near the level we’re performing at now.”

Confidence in the depot’s quality management systems led the team to implement a new approach when the auditors arrived; instead of having a set tour schedule, Spencer and O’Connell let the auditors guide the process. 
“It was completely open: This is our business, and this is how we’re doing it. If you see things to improve, we want to know because we want to improve it,” O’Connell said. 

Spencer said the level of performance required to be comfortable with this free-range approach took years to achieve. 

“If the auditors wanted to go see a process at the materials lab, we’d call the materials lab. They asked when the auditors wanted to come over, and I’d tell him they’d be there in five minutes,” Spencer said. “And then it was, what would you like to see next? And the auditors had entourages of leadership, from the senior to junior levels, guiding them around throughout the entire process. That’s indicative of a remarkable commitment to the program and level of support, and it has taken years to get here.”

In addition to leadership commitment, an organizational restructuring to a mission-aligned organization, which took place at FRCE and across the Naval Air Systems Command enterprise in 2019, has helped improve results. 

“Each department’s goals are more aligned to a single end goal then they have ever been,” O’Connell said. “In the past, if an audit turned up a finding, the team would work to define whose problem that was. Now it’s everybody’s problem because if it’s a quality issue, that’s going to hamper all of us in getting to the end goal. People are engaged, and we fix it.”

The changes in the way quality issues get addressed represent a culture change within FRCE, Spencer added. 

“We now attack issues and get them resourced, make them manageable and get them under control before they become problems,” he said. “We’re seeing excitement in a lot of people, not just the leadership but throughout the workforce and the people who are the customers of these processes. The rapid execution is helping with morale, it’s helping change the culture, and it’s impressive. 

“This certification is a big deal, and the leadership commitment and support to the program has put us light years ahead of where we’ve ever been,” Spencer said.

FRCE is North Carolina's largest maintenance, repair, overhaul and technical services provider, with more than 4,000 civilian, military and contract workers. Its annual revenue exceeds $1 billion. The depot provides service to the fleet while functioning as an integral part of the greater U.S. Navy; Naval Air Systems Command; and Commander, Fleet Readiness Centers.
column9: CHERRY POINT，北卡罗来纳州，美国
column10: FRCE aces质量管理监督审核零发现
column11: 北卡罗来纳州海军陆战队CHERRY POINT航空站――每个行业都有证书，表明通过使用最佳实践达到的卓越标准。在餐厅，用餐者可能会将健康检查分数视为安全的信号；当涉及到车辆维修时，消费者可能会寻求获得汽车卓越服务（ASE）认证的技工。在航空维护、维修和大修行业，航空航天标准（AS）9110是卓越的基准。在最近的第三方监督审计之后，东部机队准备中心（FRCE）成为机队准备中心司令部（COMFRC）内第一个通过AS9110审计且无任何发现的航空基地。结果表明，FRCE的许多内部部门，包括维护、维修和大修（MRO）生产部门、MRO物流部门、MRO工程部门、设施和基础设施管理部门以及合规性和质量部门，经过多年的辛勤工作和协作。FRCE MRO生产总监Tina Rowe说：“作为第一个完成AS9110审核且没有发现任何问题的车队准备中心，我们团队的努力显然是有回报的。”。“我们正在成为企业开展业务的基准；现在，我们需要保持势头，保持我们的排名，以便我们的客户继续发送工作，吸引新客户及其潜在工作量。”AS9110评估组织质量管理体系的流程、程序和效率。FRCE合规和质量部标准司司长David Spencer表示，符合AS9110标准是自愿的，代表着对质量的超越承诺。他解释说：“客户可以将他们的业务带到这里，因为他们知道我们的服务将达到或超过行业认证标准的意图。”。“因为我们保持这一行业标准，我们的客户不需要进入我们的仓库，对我们的流程进行他们自己的审查。他们可以放心，知道我们经过认证，我们的系统将是正确的和严密的，我们将完成他们产品的工作。”FRCE质量经理杰弗里・奥康奈尔（Jeffrey O’Connell）补充说，拥有AS9110认证使FRCE成为潜在行业客户的一个有吸引力的选择，并有助于司令部留住现有客户。奥康奈尔说：“在我们所处的公私合作环境中，许多私营企业在考虑他们去哪里工作时都非常重视AS9110认证。对于一些与我们合作的公司来说，拥有该认证比没有该认证更容易与我们合作。”斯宾塞指出，由国际航空航天质量集团开发的AS9110标准不是规定性的――它没有向组织提供认证所需的具体说明。相反，它提供了要求的概要，并根据本标准认证评估了这些要求的合规性通过一系列审核进行。每三年进行一次全面的重新认证审核；在此期间，每年的监督审核，如今年夏天在认证设施进行的监督审核，以确保持续符合标准。无论是评估零件控制和可追溯性、技工培训、产品安全还是高层管理人员斯宾塞解释说：“回顾过去，标准并没有告诉一个组织如何去做某件事。相反，它分解了你需要的东西，以及组织中做这些事情的不同层次。它实际上是一组外部的眼睛，可以进来给我们一个很好的洗刷。”除了成为第一个在没有审计发现的情况下完成AS9110认证或监督的FRC外，FRCE还成为第一个从一个围栏到另一个围栏（从地理上讲）获得认证的仓库，而不是在单个建筑物或线路中获得认证。跨学科、自上而下的质量管理方法需要获得全厂认证的ent也帮助FRCE在其最近的审计中大放异彩。斯宾塞说，与MRO生产领导的日常会议提供了一个场所，团队可以在其中快速解决和解决发现的任何质量管理问题。设施和基础设施部门负责人经常参加这些会议，如好的，提供另一个级别的支持。每周的MRO物流、MRO工程和合规与质量部门会议也会提供解决更高级别问题的机会。“这不是一个分类会议，”O'Connell解释道。“我们不试图发现和解决特定问题――我们试图确定问题发生的原因，以及我们是否能够制定解决问题的流程。我们正在花一些时间解决问题，而不是简单地进行分类和灭火，因为灭火永远不会结束。”最高管理层致力于从根本上解决质量管理问题，这大大提高了团队解决问题的能力，进而提高了审计情况下的绩效，提高了吞吐量和成本效率。“正是管理层让我们走到了这一步，”奥康奈尔说：“我们可以每天在这里工作20个小时，如果没有管理层的支持，我们仍然无法达到目前的水平。”对仓库质量管理体系的信心使团队在审计员到达时实施了一种新的方法；斯宾塞和奥康奈尔没有设定参观时间表，而是让审计员指导流程。“这是完全开放的：这是我们的业务，这就是我们的工作方式。如果你看到需要改进的地方，我们想知道，因为我们想改进它，”O'Connell说。斯宾塞说，适应这种自由放养方式所需的绩效水平需要多年才能达到。斯宾塞说：“如果审核员想去材料实验室看看流程，我们会打电话给材料实验室。他们问审核员什么时候想来，我会告诉他他们五分钟后到。”。“然后是，你接下来想看到什么？审计人员有从高层到基层的领导随行人员，在整个过程中指导他们。这表明他们对该计划做出了卓越的承诺，并提供了一定程度的支持，这需要多年的时间。”除了领导承诺外，2019年在FRCE和整个海军航空系统司令部企业进行的任务一致组织的组织重组也有助于改善结果。“每个部门的目标比以往任何时候都更符合单一的最终目标，”O'Connell说。“过去，如果审计发现了问题，团队将努力确定问题出在谁身上。现在，这是每个人的问题，因为如果是质量问题，这将阻碍我们所有人实现最终目标。人们都参与其中，我们会解决问题。”斯宾塞补充说，质量问题解决方式的变化代表了FRCE内部的文化变化。他说：“我们现在应对问题，为其提供资源，使其易于管理，并在问题出现之前加以控制。”。“我们在很多人身上看到了兴奋，不仅是领导层，还有整个员工和这些流程的客户。快速执行有助于提高士气，有助于改变文化，令人印象深刻。“这项认证意义重大，领导层对该项目的承诺和支持使我们比以往任何时候都领先了几光年。”Spencer said.FRCE是北卡罗来纳州最大的维护、维修、大修和技术服务提供商，拥有4000多名文职、军事和合同工。其年收入超过10亿美元。该基地为舰队提供服务，同时作为大美国海军、海军航空系统司令部和Com的组成部分曼德，舰队准备中心。

column2: AMC commander speaks at 30-4-30 Series
column3:
SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, Ill.--The commander of Air Mobility Command spoke to members of U.S. Transportation Command July 10 in the Seay Auditorium, as part of USTRANSCOM’s 30-4-30 Distinguished Speakers Series.
 
Gen. Carlton D. Everhart II spoke on squadron revitalization, modernization and readiness during the event, which is designed to celebrate USTRANSCOM’s 30th anniversary in October 2017 and provide enhanced insight into the linkages between the command and the senior leader’s organization and mission.
 
Everhart highlighted AMC’s role as the air component of USTRANSCOM, and the command’s partnerships with other component commands and allied partners.
 
During his speech, Everhart described AMC as “the most joint major command in the entire Air Force.”
 
“I say this because whether it’s airlift, aeromedical evacuation, mobility or air refueling, we are always looking at supporting someone in a different uniform,” he said.
 
Everhart used the Misawa Air Base’s aeromedical evacuation mission and the 821st Contingency Response Group’s air base opening in Syria as examples of joint partnerships working together to get the mission done.
 
“When the joint force needs medical care, our AE teams answer,” Everhart said. “When the warfighter needs to move to a region where there is no established presence, they call on our contingency response Airmen.”
 
Everhart continued by discussing the four aspects of AMC’s “Rapid Global Mobility Now and Tomorrow” concept ― readiness, growing and developing Airmen, modernization and nuclear operations.
 
“Our Airmen are the foundation of everything we do,” he said. “In today’s high end fight, everyone should be thinking about Rapid Global Mobility Now and logistics.”
 
The general stated the word “tomorrow” was added because he wanted his Airmen to not only remember what they do each day, but also consider AMC’s future.
 
“I want to emphasize the importance of looking at today’s victories, but also how we are setting ourselves up for the future in all four of these focus areas,” he said. “What we’re setting the table with right now is what we’re going to live with in 2030, so I need my folks to think about that and how it affects joint operations.”
 
The general touched on readiness, saying AMC recognizes the world has changed over the past decade, and the command has worked with commercial partners and industry in developing new and innovative ideas that enhance AMC’s ability to meet mission demands.
 
Over the past decade, AMC has improved processes, including increasing cargo efficiency from 60 percent to 90 percent, and improving tanker scheduling processes to make better use of AMC’s existing fleet.
 
“We’re looking at how we prioritize missions,” the general said. “Advocating for global command and control of mobility assets ensures that, when the capacity is not there to meet all mission demands, we are getting after the most important missions.”
 
Everhart stated AMC will execute its first Mobility Guardian exercise this August. The exercise will help enhance skills and identify where AMC needs to make further improvements.
 
“Mobility Guardian is going to be AMC’s premier exercise,” Everhart said. “It will test our ability to prepare the force, sustain the force, and after the mission is over, come in and clean it all up. If you need to go by air to accomplish this, then it’s AMC you call. That’s what Mobility Guardian is designed to do ― exercise our wartime mission.”
 
The importance of squadron revitalization and the command’s ability to grow and develop its Airmen was another area the general focused on, saying “the squadron is the heartbeat of the organization and growing our Airmen starts in the squadron.”
 
“Development is about giving our Airmen the tools and training to achieve their potential, whether that’s being the best maintainer on the flight line, the best aviator in your squadron or a future commander,” he said.
 
When speaking on modernization, Everhart said the KC-46 is the first step in modernizing the tanker fleet but it’s only one aspect of modernization in AMC.
 
“AMC is pursuing several initiatives to stay ahead of our adversaries and ensure rapid global mobility for the nation, including how we can strengthen our role in multi-domain command and control, as well as examining what air refueling looks like in contested airspace in 2030 and beyond.”
 
The general ended his speech by thanking members of USTRANSCOM and its component commands for helping AMC accomplish its mission.
 
“Rapid Global Mobility is not just an AMC or USTRANSCOM concept, it is a national concept. Rapid Global Mobility is a national treasure,” he said. “I hope you understand that AMC can’t do its mission without you.”
column6: SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, IL, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国伊利诺伊州斯科特空军基地
column10: 陆军装备司令部司令在30-4-30系列节目上讲话
column11: 伊利诺伊州斯科特空军基地――7月10日，空军机动司令部司令在Seay礼堂向美国运输司令部成员发表讲话，这是USTRANSCOM 30-4-30杰出演讲者系列的一部分。Carlton D.Everhart II在活动期间就中队振兴、现代化和准备就绪发表了讲话，其目的是在2017年10月庆祝USTRANSCOM成立30周年，并进一步深入了解司令部与高级领导人的组织和任务之间的联系。埃弗哈特强调了AMC作为USTRANSCOM空中部门的作用，埃弗哈特在讲话中称AMC是“整个空军中最联合的主要司令部”“我之所以这么说，是因为无论是空运、航空医疗后送、机动还是空中加油，我们都在考虑为穿着不同制服的人提供支持。”埃弗哈特以米萨瓦空军基地的航空医疗后送任务和821应急响应小组在叙利亚的空军基地开放为例，说明了为完成任务而共同合作的伙伴关系。埃弗哈特说：“当联合部队需要医疗护理时，我们的AE团队负责。”。“当作战人员需要移动到一个没有现成存在的地区时，他们会呼叫我们的应急响应飞行员。”埃弗哈特继续讨论了AMC“现在和未来快速全球机动”概念的四个方面――准备就绪、空军的成长和发展、现代化和核作战。“我们的飞行员是我们所做的一切的基础，”他说，“在今天的高端战斗中，每个人都应该考虑现在全球快速的流动性和后勤。”将军说“明天”这个词是因为他希望飞行员不仅记住他们每天做的事情，而且还考虑AMC的未来。“我想强调看到今天的胜利的重要性，以及我们如何在所有四个重点领域为未来做准备，”他说。“我们现在要做的是在2030年我们将要面对什么，所以我需要我的家人思考这一点，以及它如何影响联合作战。”这位将军谈到了战备情况，他说，陆军装备司令部认识到过去十年来世界发生了变化，司令部与商业伙伴和工业界合作开发了新的创新理念，以增强陆军装备司令部满足任务需求的能力。在过去十年中，陆军装备司令部改进了流程，包括提高了从60%至90%，并改进油轮调度流程，以更好地利用AMC现有船队。“我们正在研究如何确定任务优先级，”将军说。“倡导对机动资产进行全球指挥和控制，可确保在能力无法满足所有任务需求时，我们能够完成最重要的任务。”埃弗哈特表示，AMC将于今年8月进行其第一次机动卫士演习。该演习将有助于提高技能，并确定AMC需要进一步改进的地方。“机动卫士将是AMC的首要演习，”埃弗哈特说。“这将考验我们准备部队、维持部队的能力，在任务结束后，进来把一切清理干净。如果你需要乘飞机来完成这项任务，那你就呼叫陆军装备司令部。这就是机动卫士的设计目的――执行我们的战时任务。”中队振兴的重要性以及司令部增加和发展其飞行员的能力是将军关注的另一个领域，他说“中队是组织的心脏，增加我们的飞行员从中队开始。”“发展是为我们的飞行员提供工具和培训，以实现他们的潜力，无论他们是飞行线上最好的维修人员、中队最好的飞行员还是未来的指挥官。”埃弗哈特在谈到现代化时说，KC-46是油轮船队现代化的第一步，但这只是AMC现代化的一个方面。“陆军装备司令部正在实施多项举措，以保持领先于我们的对手，确保国家在全球范围内快速机动，包括如何加强我们在多领域指挥和控制中的作用，以及研究2030年及以后有争议空域的空中加油情况。”这位将军在演讲结束时感谢美国陆军司令部及其下属司令部的成员帮助美国陆军装备司令部完成任务。“快速全球机动不仅是美国陆军装备司令部或美国陆军司令部的概念，也是一个国家概念。快速全球机动是一件国宝，”他说。“我希望你明白，没有你，美国陆军装备司令部无法完成使命。”

column2: 30 seconds of green
column3:
Team McChord Airmen along with Airmen from other Air Mobility Command units recently participated in the Battalion Mass Tactical Week exercise at Pope Army Airfield, North Carolina, Feb. 27 through March 2.  

More than 100 Airmen from Joint Base Lewis-McChord, Washington; Dyess Air Force Base, Texas; Joint Base Charleston, South Carolina; Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam, Hawaii; and Little Rock AFB, Arkansas, participated in the exercise to airdrop more than 2,400 Soldiers.    

The exercise took place to provide hands-on training to AMC aircrews while supporting Soldiers from the 82nd Airborne Division stationed at Fort Bragg, N.C. 

“Overall throughout the week we were able to accomplish quite a bit of training that goes a long way in things we are not necessarily able to accomplish at home-station,” said Lt. Col. Jaron Roux, 62nd Operations Support Squadron commander and the exercise air mission commander. “The interoperability that we gain when we bring the C-17 Globemaster III and C-130J crews together here is fantastic.”

During the exercise, aircrews received training in a variety of areas to include formation flying, airdrop, static-line jumps of Army personnel and the experience of working with Airmen from different squadrons. 

“This week the primary training is for us to support the 82nd Airborne Division as well as supporting C-17 and C-130J upgrade training,” said Roux. “The 82nd is an airborne unit that’s postured to respond to different contingencies all over the globe and parachute operations is essential to their readiness.”

For some McChord Airmen this was their first opportunity to airdrop Soldiers from the C-17. 

"This was a great experience; I learned a lot,” said Staff Sgt. Justin Baez, 7th Airlift Squadron loadmaster. “Seeing that this is a new qualification for me, I appreciate the opportunity to work with everyone here and receive this training in a realistic training environment.” 

Aircrews flew day and night shifts each day of the exercise and flew in formations ranging from three-to-six aircraft. The exercise schedule stuck to a fixed timeframe that required aircrews to drop personnel and cargo at specified drop zones that allowed only 30-50 seconds of a “green light” to make the drop. 

Aircrews from McChord Field were provided a unique training opportunity during the exercise because it’s not often that they’re able to train in environments like these, said Roux.      

“It really makes you appreciate all the mission planning that takes place prior to these exercises,” said Baez. "I had to be adaptable and ready to make any last minute changes. There are countless hours that lead up to 30 seconds over the drop zone.” 

Though only a week-long, the exercise planning started at the beginning of the year by the 62nd OSS, said Roux. Planning took into consideration the training needs of all aircrew and support personnel participating in the exercise.     

“We bring the whole team out here to include maintenance personnel, weather professionals and squadron aviation resource management Airmen,” said Roux. “It’s a joint-training effort that happens throughout the week.”

Although Airmen faced some challenging weather during the week, the exercise was a success, said Roux. 

“I think each time we come out here and do these exercises we learn things as an enterprise,” said Roux. “We learn if there are shortfalls we need to work on, but we also see things that we do very well and this week was no different.”
column6: POPE ARMY AIRFIELD, WA, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国华盛顿州波普陆军机场
column10: 30秒绿灯
column11: 2月27日至3月2日，麦克霍德空军和其他空中机动司令部的空军最近参加了在北卡罗来纳州波普陆军机场举行的营大规模战术周演习。来自华盛顿刘易斯・麦考德联合基地的100多名飞行员；德克萨斯州戴斯空军基地；南卡罗来纳州查尔斯顿联合基地；夏威夷希卡姆珍珠港联合基地；阿肯色州小石城空军基地参加了空投2400多名士兵的演习。演习的目的是为陆军装备司令部空勤人员提供实践训练，同时为驻扎在北卡罗来纳州布拉格堡的第82空降师的士兵提供支持。“总的来说，这一周我们完成了相当多的训练，这些训练对我们在本站不一定能够完成的事情大有帮助。”第62作战支援中队指挥官兼演习空中任务指挥官Jaron Roux中校说。“当我们将C-17 Globemaster III和C-130J机组人员聚集在一起时，我们获得的互操作性非常好。”在演习期间，机组人员接受了多方面的培训，包括编队飞行、空投、陆军人员的静态跳线以及与不同中队的飞行员合作的经验。“本周的主要训练是支持第82空降师以及支持C-17和C-130J升级训练，”鲁克斯说。“第82空降队是一支空降部队，它的姿态是应对全球不同的突发事件，降落伞行动对他们的准备工作至关重要。”对于一些麦科德空军来说，这是他们第一次有机会空投C-17的士兵。“这是一次很好的经历；我学到了很多，”第七空运中队装载员上士贾斯汀・贝兹说。“看到这对我来说是一项新的资格认证，我很高兴有机会与这里的每个人一起工作，并在现实的培训环境中接受培训。”空勤人员每天日夜轮班飞行，编队从3架飞机到6架飞机不等。演习日程固定，要求空勤人员将人员和货物降落在指定的降落区，只允许30-50秒的“绿灯”在这次演习中，来自麦考德机场的空勤人员获得了一次独特的训练机会，因为他们很少能够在这样的环境中训练，鲁克斯说。“这让你真正体会到在这些演习之前进行的所有任务规划，”贝兹说我必须适应环境，随时准备在最后一刻做出任何改变。在降落区有数不清的时间长达30秒。“虽然只有一周的时间，但演习计划在今年年初由第62届OSS开始，Roux说。计划考虑了所有参与演习的机组人员和支援人员的培训需求。“我们把整个团队带到这里来，包括维修人员、气象专业人员和中队航空资源管理飞行员，”鲁克斯说。“这是一项为期一周的联合训练。”鲁克斯说，尽管飞行员在这一周面临着一些具有挑战性的天气，但这次演习还是成功的。“我认为，每次我们来到这里，做这些练习，我们都会作为一个企业来学习，”鲁克斯说。“我们知道是否有不足需要解决，但我们也看到我们做得很好的事情，本周也不例外。”

column2: The Gulf War turns 30
column3:
The Gulf War turns 30
MUSEUM DISPLAY, MEMORIAL STONE COMMEMORATE DESERT SHIELD, DESERT STORM


FORT LEONARD WOOD, Mo. ― August 2, 1990, was the date many Americans first learned about the country of Kuwait, and that Iraq ― which had been a U.S. ally ― invaded it. Soon, millions would be glued to cable news, watching Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm unfold, from U.S.-led coalition building and training to deployment, combat operations and victory ― all in just over six months.

It’s been 30 years since the Gulf War captivated the nation’s attention. While the U.S. has conducted multiple operations since that time, many reminders of the Gulf War remain, including two permanent fixtures at Fort Leonard Wood.

The Desert Storm Memorial Stone has been a part of Memorial Grove since it was installed and dedicated in 2016. Veterans, family members and others still place coins, pins, dog tags and other mementos on the stone in remembrance of those who served and sacrificed.

Another reminder is the 1991 Desert Storm Display, located in the U.S. Army Engineer Museum inside the John B. Mahaffey Museum Complex.

“It’s basically commemorating all engineers (serving) in Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm,” explained Troy Morgan, Engineer Museum director.

A part of the museum since the early 1990s, the display features multiple photos and artifacts from the Gulf War, from a U.S. Army uniform from the era to U.S. and Iraqi weapons and equipment.

“That piece of shrapnel in there ― that’s from a S.C.U.D. missile,” Morgan said as he gave an overview of the display. “You’ll see an Iraqi helmet, an Iraqi canteen. These yellow and black signs are the Iraqi minefield markers. And this license plate is from an Iraqi Army vehicle.”

The Gulf War turns 30
1 / 2
SHOW CAPTION +
The Gulf War turns 30
2 / 2
SHOW CAPTION +
According to the “1991 Engineer Center Annual Command History,” the Gulf War impacted nearly every activity on Fort Leonard Wood in some way in 1990 and 1991, with nearly 4,000 Soldiers passing through the installation for processing, training and deployment.

Three Fort Leonard Wood units, the 5th Engineer Battalion, the 93rd Evacuation Hospital and the 515th Engineer Company (Pipeline), were deployed to the Persian Gulf.

Of the three, the 5th Engineers were involved in major combat operations in support of the 1st Battalion, 24th Infantry Division.

According to the unit’s history listed on its official Facebook page, the “Fightin’ Fifth” was notified Aug. 12, 1990, of its deployment, which began in late October with their arrival in Saudi Arabia. There, they constructed Sapper Base, an 800-Soldier base camp and were responsible for conducting long-range reconnaissance along the border between Saudi Arabia and Iraq. 5th Engr. Bn. Soldiers were on the front lines with the 24th ID once U.S. forces began their attack. The unit breached 8-meter high, double earthen berms, fought as infantry against Iraqi forces and destroyed Iraqi war materials, including hundreds of bunkers, weapons, rail lines and more.

Like many Soldiers throughout history, several 5th Engr. Bn. Soldiers picked up souvenirs during their tour, many of which were donated to the museum. In fact, Morgan said, most of the items now in the museum display were donated by the 5th Engineer Battalion, including a distinctive highway sign that hangs above the hallway where it is located.

“You can see it says ‘Baghdad,’ ‘Highway 1’ and it also has a small brass plaque in the corner that’s sometimes hard to see,” Morgan said.

Although the 5th Engineer Battalion’s scope of training and operations have changed somewhat over the past 30 years, the Gulf War remains an important chapter in the history of the unit, according to Maj. Tyson Behnke, 5th Engr. Bn. executive officer.

“As a battalion in (U.S. Army Forces Command), the (5th Engineer Battalion) and its subordinate units are still expected to maintain readiness and deploy in support of contingency and non-contingency operations throughout the world,” Behnke said. “The battalion no longer has organic construction assets but maintains the ability to command and control and sustain those assets if assigned.”

While the museum complex has been closed to the public since March due to COVID-19 mitigation procedures, the 1991 Desert Storm display isn’t going anywhere. In fact, Morgan noted, the display is scheduled for an upgrade in the near future.

“We try to upgrade all the time. This is scheduled for an upgrade in 2022,” he said. “We’ll basically change the artifacts, rip down the carpet and widen this (window) to make it easier for visitors to see it as they approach the display.”

Visitors can also be assured that the display commemorating the Gulf War will be around for many years to come, Morgan said.

“We have what we call temporary displays and long-term displays ― this is a long-term display,” he said.
column6: FORT LEONARD WOOD , MO, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国密苏里州伦纳德伍德堡
column10: 海湾战争即将结束
column11: 1990年8月2日是许多美国人第一次了解科威特这个国家的日子，当时伊拉克是美国的盟友，入侵了这个国家。很快，数百万人就会被有线电视新闻所吸引，观看沙漠盾牌行动和沙漠风暴的展开，从美国领导的联盟建设和训练到部署、作战行动和胜利――所有这些都发生在短短六个多月的时间里。海湾战争吸引了美国的注意力，至今已有30年了。尽管美国从那时起已经进行了多次行动，但海湾战争的许多提醒仍然存在，包括莱昂纳德伍德堡的两个永久性设施。沙漠风暴纪念石自2016年安装并投入使用以来一直是纪念林的一部分。退伍军人、家庭成员和其他人仍然在石头上放置硬币、别针、狗标签和其他纪念品，以纪念那些曾经服役和牺牲过的人。另一个提醒是1991年的沙漠风暴展览，位于约翰・B・马哈菲博物馆综合体内的美国陆军工程师博物馆。“它基本上是为了纪念所有（服役的）工程师。”“在沙漠盾牌行动和沙漠风暴中，”工程师博物馆馆长特洛伊・摩根解释说。该展览自20世纪90年代初以来一直是博物馆的一部分，展出了海湾战争时期的多张照片和文物，从当时的美军制服到美国和伊拉克的武器装备。“那片弹片在那里――那是一枚s.C.U.D.导弹的碎片，”摩根一边概述展示一边说。“你会看到一个伊拉克头盔，一个伊拉克食堂。这些黄色和黑色的标志是伊拉克雷区的标志。而这个车牌来自一辆伊拉克军车。”海湾战争变成301/2显示字幕+海湾战争变成302/2显示字幕+根据“1991年工程师中心年度指挥历史，”1990年和1991年，海湾战争以某种方式影响了莱昂纳德伍德堡的几乎所有活动，近4000名士兵通过该设施进行加工、训练和部署。莱昂纳德伍德堡有三个部队、第五工兵营、第93疏散医院和第515工兵连（管道）部署到波斯湾。在这三名工程师中，第五名工程师参与了支持第24步兵师第一营的主要作战行动。根据该部队在其官方Facebook页面上列出的历史，“第五次战斗”1990年8月12日，他们被通知部署该部队，该部队于10月下旬抵达沙特阿拉伯。在那里，他们建造了一个800人的工兵基地，并负责沿沙特阿拉伯和伊拉克之间的边界进行远程侦察。第5名英国士兵与第24名伊拉克士兵在前线nce美国军队开始进攻。这支部队突破了8米高的双土护堤，以步兵身份与伊拉克军队作战，摧毁了伊拉克战争物资，包括数百个掩体、武器、铁路线等。与历史上的许多士兵一样，几名英国第五军士兵在旅途中捡到了纪念品，其中许多是wMorgan说，事实上，博物馆陈列的大部分物品都是由第五工程营捐赠的，包括悬挂在其所在走廊上方的一个独特的公路标志。“你可以看到上面写着‘巴格达’，‘1号公路’，在角落里还有一块小铜牌，有时很难看到。”摩根说。尽管第五工程营的训练和作战范围在过去30年中有所改变，但根据第五工程营执行官泰森・贝恩克少校的说法，海湾战争仍然是该部队历史上的重要篇章。“作为（美国陆军司令部）的一个营，（第五工程营）贝恩克说：“该营不再拥有建制建筑资产，而是保持指挥、控制和维持这些资产的能力。”尽管由于新冠病毒-19的缓解程序，博物馆自3月以来一直不对公众开放，但1991年的沙漠风暴展览不会有任何进展。摩根指出，事实上，展览计划在不久的将来升级。“我们一直在努力升级。计划在2022年升级，”他说。摩根说：“我们将基本上改变文物，撕开地毯并拓宽这扇窗户，以便游客在接近展览时更容易看到它。”游客们还可以放心，纪念海湾战争的展览将在未来许多年内举行。“我们有所谓的临时显示器和长期显示器――这是一种长期显示器，”他说。

column2: 30 years of service, marriage
column3:
In 1990, Desert storm was in full swing, “Hold On” was the No. 1 song, “Ghost” was the No. 1 movie, and Michael Jordan had yet to win an NBA championship.
