“It’s the very first serious game that had a big impact. It became one of the top five played games online in the years that it was out and it was the most successful recruiting tool ever built by the U.S. Army,” Zyda said.

Unlike the carnal gore which defines the genre, America’s Army focuses on team-based, coordinated gameplay among characters using accurately modeled weapons systems. In doing so, the game aims to stimulate interest in the Army for potential recruits.

“The fact that NPS was involved in things like America’s Army was really significant because we recognized that you can immerse people to some degree. The whole idea behind America’s Army was envisioning what it would be like to be in the Army and then trying to use that kind of environment to immerse you in a virtual reality,” said Dr. Imre Balogh, current director of the MOVES Institute.

“It’s not just that we cared about a particular technology, but about creating that virtual environment.”
America’s Army was originally intended as a recruitment tool, but has since morphed into a training tool.

Repurposing its engine has enabled a myriad of virtual reality training simulators, including advance gunnery on the M1A2 Abrams, driving Mine-Resistant Ambush Protected vehicles, calling for artillery fire and conducting electronic warfare. A 2016 Government Accountability Office report specifically called on the Army to up its game with virtual reality training in order to confront the world’s increasingly complex security environment.

It’s not just Army, though. All services are heavily investing in virtual reality-based training, such as the Navy’s Fleet Integrated Synthetic Training/Testing Facility (FIST2FAC) on Ford Island, Hawaii.

"This is the future of training for the Navy," said Terry Allard, head of the Office of Naval Research's Warfighter Performance Department. "With simulation, you can explore endless possibilities without the expense and logistical challenges of putting hundreds of ships at sea and aircraft in the sky."

The drive towards virtual reality training is reflective of the efficiency it affords: time, manpower and resources are saved and logistic stress loads lightened. It also provides training opportunities that wouldn’t be possible otherwise, explained Dr. Amela Sadagic, research associate professor with the MOVES Institute.

“A typical example would be emergency procedures for aircraft: some elements of that can be practiced in the real world with real aircraft, but by and large can only be tried and trained in simulators,” she said.

Sadagic cited the thesis work of her former student, Lt. Clay Greunke, as an example. Greunke, a Navy pilot who also served as a Landing Signal Officer (LSO), created a virtual reality training simulator for inexperienced LSOs to practice guiding in aircraft landing on carriers. He had identified a gap in training: LSOs spend a total of six hours in a large, two-story simulator in Oceana, Virginia to work out the fundamentals of landing planes on carriers. Most training occurs on-the-job once new LSOs arrive on a ship, passively observing more seasoned LSOs.

"The first time you go to the aircraft carrier, you have no idea what's going on," Greunke said. "Planes are going by, people are screaming, people are running across the flight deck ... You don't know what to cross, when to cross, what you can and can't do, you are just holding on to the person who's leading you with dear life so you don't get hit."

So Greunke developed a lightweight, portable kit as a “gym bag solution.” The light-weight virtual reality LSO trainer kit can be taken just about anywhere to better familiarize LSOs with flight deck operations and offer refresher training. 

For his work, he received honorable mention at the 2016 Secretary of the Navy Innovation Awards C Innovation Scholar (Professional Military Education). The winner was fellow NPS graduate student Lt. Brendan Geoghegan, also an advisee of Sadagic, for his thesis on using virtual reality head-mounted displays to augment ship navigation.

Greunke’s and Geogheghan’s work underscores the unique contribution NPS’ MOVES Institute brings to the field. Advanced virtual reality research is by nature interdisciplinary, and while NPS faculty actively collaborate to share insight from a wide variety of fields C from computer vision to cognitive psychology C students bring to the table a wealth of operational and technical expertise from their diverse military careers.

“The students come in with ideas and then start using those because they’re the ones who have the operational background,” Balogh said. “We enable them to understand virtual reality and they then say, 
‘Oh boy, I can see how I can use this to address this particular problem in the military.’ That’s our place.” 

This contrasts sharply with civilian academia throughout the rest of the country. Most university simulation programs emphasize cultivation of new skills, and today that emphasis is on the gaming industry. NPS students, already armed with intimate knowledge of their domains, return to their respective services after graduating, bringing new insights directly to end user communities.

“For me, this is unique compared to my colleagues at other universities; they don’t have this proximity to the end users,” Sadagic said. “When it comes to knowledge of a domain, you can’t replicate that.

“Anything that I want to know about aviation, ship navigation or urban warfare, all I need to do is open the door and somebody will know,” she added. “And we do; we do that to a great extent.”

This creates a critical niche for NPS. Thirty years ago, there weren’t many people exploring virtual reality, which meant NPS could be a big fish in a very small pond. The exponential growth of commercial gaming, however, outpaced the institution’s competitiveness in new technology development.

A company like Microsoft, for example, is able to invest in a single product on orders of magnitude several times greater than the entire NPS annual budget. Yet navigating these waters is not a zero-sum game, and the unique position of the MOVES Institute allows it to integrate new technologies to solving complex problems throughout DOD.

“One of the most important things we can do is bring that taught knowledge into the Navy and DOD,” Balogh said. In some ways, then, NPS can act as a clearinghouse of sorts to bring together often disjointed virtual reality technology in application to training requirements across the services.

“We as an entity can get better connections to those pieces of the fleet. We won’t be able to solve all problems, but we can play the role of making sure that all the different efforts connect,” Balogh added.

This unique aspect of NPS was echoed when the Secretary of the Navy shared vision for the future of the university. Addressing students, faculty and staff in February, the Honorable Richard V. Spencer shared how the Navy, DOD and the nation can capitalize on NPS’ strengths.

“I want this institution to be the primary education and research enterprise, with the private sector, government sector and academia coming together at the research level,” he said. “This institution is a primary incubator for the capabilities that we need now.”
column9: 蒙特利，加利福尼亚州，美国
column10: NPS的移动研究所回顾了30年的虚拟现实
column11: 在过去的30年里，虚拟现实已经被证明是一项基础技术，它彻底改变了人类与机器的互动方式，开启了至今仍在被发现的新大门和可能性。在国防部（DOD）内部，这种影响同样强大，VR技术从根本上改变了国防部的主要职能。这项先进技术的最前沿是一所小型研究生大学――海军研究生院（NPS）及其建模、虚拟环境和仿真（MOVES）研究所，30年前首次创造了“虚拟现实”，在这里，前卫的教员和敬业的学生为虚拟现实的使用打开了无数的大门，而虚拟现实在整个服务中已经司空见惯。士兵和海军陆战队制定出新的战术，在无数复杂的战场上与敌人交战，而不会开枪或造成伤亡；飞行员可以在飞行训练模拟器中反复坠毁；外科医生能够磨练他们的技能，而不会使人类患者处于危险之中；学生们可以坐在数百英里以外的教室里。NPS的学生和教员一直在不断地突破沉浸式技术的界限：3D建模、人工智能、仿真、人机交互和网络。这些技术改变了美军在虚拟步枪靶场、网络战场、后勤、征兵和航空母舰着陆等不同领域开展业务的方式。“简言之，虚拟现实是一种在三维计算机生成环境中移动并与之交互的技术，”MOVES Institute的创始人Mike Zyda博士解释说，MOVES Institute是NPS在虚拟现实领域的先驱，也是国防部如何使用它的。这使得训练模拟更加真实。现实世界的挑战，特别是高风险、危险或昂贵的挑战，可以反复练习，而不会产生现实世界的后果。Zyda补充道：“重要的是要排练并知道在哪里，在哪里，你要做什么。”。“在激烈的战斗中，一旦闪电爆炸，你所有的认知功能都会消失，留在你大脑中的就是你训练过的东西。”2000年，NPS正式成立了MOVES研究所，将其作战研究部的军事分析工作与其计算机科学部的仿真和软件开发专业知识联系起来。自1996年以来，MOVES一直是一个跨学科的学术项目，但其起源要深得多。20世纪80年代初，NPS学生开始探索在Silicon Graphics Iris 2400工作站上创建3D虚拟环境和游戏，这是当时的最前沿。1986年，两名学生开发了FOG-M反坦克导弹模拟器作为他们的毕业论文。模拟器工作得非常出色，精确地模拟了真实物体的物理动力学。唯一的问题是，射击是针对一个静止的目标的：在真实战场上的坦克往往不会静止不动。“如果它四处移动不是更好吗？”学生顾问Zyda回忆道。因此，他们开发了一种导弹和坦克在3D世界中互动的方法，他们称之为NPSNET网络。“现在我们可以驾驶坦克绕过导弹，”Zyda说。“下一件事你知道，我们正在建造多辆坦克并驾驶它们四处走动。”这引起了美国陆军的注意，美国陆军最近开始通过国防高级研究计划局（DARPA）探索坦克模拟器。DARPA的努力产生了一个名为SIMNET的系统，该系统的价格高达1.4亿美元。相比之下，NPS使用的商用Iris 2400工作站每台成本为60000美元。当军方在1990年采用SIMNET时，美国政府中很少有人知道如何有效地使用它，NPSNET提供了一种低成本的方法来利用其数据库和网络格式。NPSNET小组的NPS学生后来发展成为MOVES项目，他们为各种平台开发了硬件并构建了虚拟仿真，包括飞机、水下航行器、指挥和控制车辆以及前方观察员。“我们在网络方面做了开创性的事情，”Zyda说。到1994年，公众对互联网的兴趣爆发，亚马逊等初创公司开始了他们的迅速崛起。就在那时，NPS打破了互联网。在加州圣莫尼卡与兰德公司进行联网能力演示时，他们要求购买一些自动驾驶汽车。兰德公司发送了2000份。NPSNET处理这些问题非常出色，但是从加利福尼亚到芬兰，车辆之间的高优先级信息包的数量使互联网一路崩溃，NPS很快就被“令人惊讶的敌意”电话淹没，要求他们停止。“如果你今天这样做，FBI可能会出现在你的门口，”Zyda说。“这只是一个小小的测试，看看我们能做什么的极限……但你知道，当你把事情弄糟的时候，你正在做你最好的研究。”即使是错误也会有好的结果――这是科学研究的好处――该小组很快就获得了充足的资金，寻求正式成立MOVES研究所。“我们有赞助商，他们会给我们一大笔钱，并说，‘请帮助我们学会如何做到这一点，’”Zyda回忆道。当时，并不是所有人，即使是在NPS校园里，都相信虚拟现实技术是未来的潮流。但在一位三星级上将的支持下，以及每年200万美元的担保资金，NPS学术委员会批准了MOVES研究生学位项目。“突然间，我有40名学生来了，”Zyda回忆道：“我们有一个预算，接管了Spanagel大厅的二楼。”1997年，Zyda主持了国家研究委员会的一项研究，以探索军事模拟和商业游戏之间的巨大重叠。他们的报告《建模与仿真：娱乐与防御的联系》从根本上改变了国防部在建模与仿真系统中对娱乐技术的使用和态度。这导致这将成为MOVES Institute的大满贯全垒打：它成为了美国陆军的诞生地，这是一款第一人称射击游戏，玩家可以在真实、高质量的环境中进行班级战术战斗。该游戏于2002年由陆军推出，是一款免费的、可下载的招募工具，目前仍在继续数百万活跃用户记录了数十亿小时的游戏时间。“这是第一款具有重大影响的严肃游戏。它在推出后的几年内成为五大在线游戏之一，也是美国陆军有史以来最成功的招募工具。”Zyda说。与定义这一类型的《肉体戈尔》不同，美国军队专注于使用精确建模的武器系统在角色之间进行基于团队的协调游戏。这样做的目的是激发潜在新兵对军队的兴趣。“NPS参与美国军队等活动的事实非常重要，因为我们认识到，在某种程度上，你可以让人沉浸其中。美国军队背后的整个想法是设想在军队中会是什么样子，然后试图利用这种环境让你沉浸在虚拟现实中。”MOVES研究所现任所长Imre Balogh博士说，“我们不仅关心某项特定技术，还关心创建虚拟环境。”美国陆军最初是作为征兵工具使用的，但后来演变成了一种训练工具。对其引擎的重新调整使无数虚拟现实训练模拟器得以实现，包括M1A2艾布拉姆斯上的先遣炮兵、驾驶防地雷伏击保护车、呼叫火炮射击和进行电子战。2016年政府问责办公室的一份报告特别呼吁陆军加大虚拟现实训练的力度，以应对世界日益复杂的安全环境。但不仅仅是陆军。所有军种都在大力投资基于虚拟现实的训练，如海军的舰队综合合成训练位于夏威夷福特岛的训练/测试设施（FIST2FAC）。“这是海军训练的未来，”海军研究办公室作战人员绩效部门负责人特里・阿拉德说。“通过模拟，你可以探索无限的可能性，而无需花费费用和后勤挑战，将数百艘船只置于海上，将飞机置于空中。MOVES研究所的研究副教授阿米拉・萨达吉克博士解释说：“虚拟现实培训的发展反映了它所提供的效率：节省了时间、人力和资源，减轻了后勤压力。它还提供了否则不可能提供的培训机会。”。“一个典型的例子是飞机的应急程序：其中的一些要素可以在现实世界中用真实的飞机进行实践，但大体上只能在模拟器中进行试验和培训。”她说。萨达奇以她的前学生克莱・格伦克中尉的论文工作为例。格伦克是一名海军飞行员，同时担任着陆信号官（LSO）他创建了一个虚拟现实训练模拟器，供没有经验的当地官员练习在航空母舰上进行飞机着陆指导。他发现了训练中的一个空白：当地官员在弗吉尼亚州奥西纳市的一个两层楼高的大型模拟器中总共花了六个小时来研究飞机在航空母舰上着陆的基本原理。一旦有了新的当地官员，大部分训练都会在工作中进行登上一艘船，被动地观察经验丰富的LSO。“第一次去航空母舰时，你根本不知道发生了什么，”格伦克说。“飞机飞过，人们尖叫着，人们跑着穿过飞行甲板……你不知道该穿越什么，何时穿越，你能做什么，不能做什么，你只是紧紧抓住那个用宝贵生命引导你的人，这样你就不会被击中。”所以

column2: Career Marine recalls 30 years of service to Corps, nation
column3:
Maj. Gen. Craig C. Crenshaw, retiring official and commanding general, LOGCOM, said Murphy’s retirement was bittersweet. 
“We are very fortunate to have had Sergeant Major Murphy in our ranks and I say that with the most utmost sincerity,” Crenshaw said. “The impact of what she has done in such a short time for this command is remarkable. Her fingerprints are all over Marine Corps Logistics Command and certainly are all over the Marine Corps.
“She is going to put her boots up,” he continued. “Sergeant Major Murphy is a Marine at heart (but) she does not have to wear the uniform to know that she is a Marine.
“Our Marine Corps is better today because of her and I am better today as an officer having had the privilege to serve with (her) for three years,” he concluded.
According to Murphy, the Marine Corps was not her first choice of military service.
“I chose to join the Navy first because my sister and my daughter's father were in the Navy,” Murphy admitted.  “I was drawn to the Navy because of the people I knew. I showed up at the recruiting station to join and my appointment. 
“When I arrived, the Navy recruiter was not there but a Marine Corps recruiter was standing outside,” she said. “I had no idea what a Marine was. So, I asked him who he was and he said, ‘We are the Marines.’
“I said ‘Oh, what do you have to do to join the Marine Corps?,” she asked. “He went on his spiel and while he was talking I looked down at the bottom of the glass window and there was a quote that said ‘We are looking for a few good men.’
“I looked up at him and said I am looking for the same thing y'all are looking for,” she said. “What do I have to do to join? He moved to the side of the hatch and said ‘volunteer,’ because at that time the Marine Corps was not looking for women.”
In March 1988, the native of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, enlisted and went to boot camp at Parris Island, South Carolina. 
Upon graduating, she attended training at Fort Eustis, Virginia, where she obtained military occupational specialty, traffic management specialist.
Throughout her career, Murphy has been promoted nine times, served in a variety of billets and deployed in harm’s way. 
Her fondest memory was when being a drill instructor at MCRD, Parris Island, South Carolina, where she discovered her purpose in life. 
“Many Americans are patriotic so they join the military,” she said. “It's little bit more than patriotism, it's about giving.
“That's what I learned as a drill instructor and I learned it well enough to instill that into civilians and make them Marines,” she continued. “I wanted to ensure they understand why they joined so it would not take them as long as it did for me to figure it out. This was the turning point in my career.”
In 1999, Murphy, then a staff sergeant, was stationed at Marine Corps Logistics Bases where she served as the staff noncommissioned officer in charge of the Traffic Management Office. 
After an accelerated promotion to the rank of gunnery sergeant, Murphy requested orders to Naval Air Station Pensacola, Florida, to train Naval Officer Candidates. This would be the toughest assignment of her career. 
“I was not accepted or welcomed,” she said. “But like all good Marines do, I pushed forward.”
After completing her first class, Murphy was awarded a Congressional Record by the 107th Congress, honoring her as the first female Marine drill instructor at Naval Officer Candidate School. 
As the end of her career came in to view, she requested to be stationed in Albany one more time.
 “I have been stationed here before so I was comfortable with the location,” she said. “I requested orders to Marine Corps Logistics Command for my last assignment. I thought this would be a good job for me and one I would succeed in because of my understanding and background in logistics.”
In June 2015, Murphy assumed her role as the senior enlisted advisor for LOGCOM. 
 “When you are a sergeant major working for a general officer or colonel, you
want to have some background knowledge in the job so that you don't look like someone who just started learning the (military occupational specialty),” she said. “I came here with the determination of doing the same thing that I have done everywhere else, which is taking care of Marines.
“Although my job was a little bit further away from the Marines than I would
have wanted to be, I was still able to adapt and overcome,” she continued. “Whenever I was not traveling with the general or doing something on the general’s schedule, I got on the Marines' schedule.
“We did professional military education classes with the Marines at the noncommissioned officer level, Staff NCO level and combined,” she pointed out. “I did as many
as I possibly could do. Those PMEs included dinner functions, mess nights and professional dinners.”
Murphy’s plan was to illustrate the Marines the importance of camaraderie.
“I thought bringing the NCOs and Staff NCOs together would give them a better
appreciation of one another,” she stated. “Once they began to appreciate one another, they
worked better together.”
The importance of caring, humbleness, striving for perfection, hard work and dedication is the legacy Murphy wants to leave behind. 
“When you care about someone deeply, you are going to do the right thing for
them whether it means punishment or reward,” she said. “Because a lot of times people
view punishment in a negative manner but they are not always negative. Sometimes there are lessons that need to be taught.
“Part of our Staff NCO Creed in the Marine Corps is to strive for perfection
and we do,” she added. “We are not perfect. There is no perfect person but we strive for
perfection.”
Overall, Murphy described her 30-year career as a “struggle” with blood, sweat, tears, dirt and pain.
“Life is not easy and it's not supposed to be,” she said. “Anything good does not come easy. Marines have a saying, ‘Pain is weakness leaving the body.’ I believe that.  
“If it does, it is not something you want,” she pointed out. “I don't think we get anything easy and honestly it's got to be some hard work involved. The good times you will have in the Marine Corps are the result of caring, humbleness, striving for perfection, hard work and dedication.”
Murphy confessed she is still in disbelief that she is retiring.
“My future plans are to continue to serve, be it the military, taking care of the homeless or a girls school,” she said. “My focus is not on a paycheck but to continue my life of service.”
Until then, her immediate plan is to complete her dissertation to become Dr. Murphy.
She expects to finish her doctorate in Organizational leadership from the University of Phoenix within the next six months.
column9: 美国佐治亚州奥尔巴尼
column10: 职业海军陆战队召回在美国陆军服役30年
column11: 即将退休的政府官员兼后勤司令部司令克雷格・C・克伦肖少将说，墨菲的退休是苦乐参半的。克伦肖说：“我们非常幸运，我们的队伍中有墨菲少校，我非常诚恳地说。”。“她在这么短的时间内为这个司令部所做的事情所产生的影响是显著的。她的指纹遍布海军陆战队后勤司令部，当然也遍布海军陆战队。“她要穿上靴子，”他继续说。“墨菲中士在本质上是一名海军陆战队（但是）她不必穿制服就知道自己是海军陆战队。“我们的海军陆战队今天更好，因为她，而我今天更好，因为我有幸与她一起服役三年，”他总结道。墨菲说，海军陆战队不是她服兵役的第一选择。“我选择先加入海军是因为我的姐姐和女儿的父亲都在海军，”墨菲承认。“我被吸引到海军是因为我认识的人。我出现在征兵站加入，还有我的约会。“当我到达时，海军征兵员不在那里，但一名海军陆战队征兵员站在外面。”她说：“我不知道什么是海军陆战队。所以，我问他是谁，他说，‘我们是海军陆战队’。”我说‘哦，你要做什么才能加入海军陆战队？’”她问。“他接着说，当他说话的时候，我低头看了看玻璃窗的底部，有句话说‘我们正在寻找一些好男人’。”她说：“我抬头看了看他，说我在寻找你们都在寻找的同样的东西。”。“我该怎么做才能加入呢？他走到舱口边说‘志愿者’，因为当时海军陆战队不找女人。”1988年3月，阿肯色州派恩布拉夫人应征入伍，参加了南卡罗来纳州帕里斯岛的新兵训练营。毕业后，她参加了弗吉尼亚州尤斯蒂斯堡的训练，在那里她获得了军事职业专业，交通管理专家。在她的职业生涯中，墨菲曾九次晋升，在各种bil服务她最美好的记忆是在南卡罗来纳州帕里斯岛的MCRD担任训练教练时，在那里她发现了自己的人生目标。“许多美国人爱国，所以他们参军，”她说。“这不仅仅是爱国主义，而是奉献。”。“这就是我作为一名训练教练所学到的，我学得足够好，可以把这一点灌输到平民中，让他们成为海军陆战队，”她继续说。“我想确保他们理解他们为什么加入，这样他们就不会像我一样花那么长时间去弄明白。这是我职业生涯的转折点。”1999年，时任上士的墨菲驻扎在海军陆战队后勤基地，担任交通管理办公室的参谋士官。在加速晋升为炮兵中士后，墨菲请求命令佛罗里达州彭萨科拉海军航空站培训海军军官候选人他将是她职业生涯中最艰难的任务。“我没有被接受或欢迎，”她说。“但就像所有优秀的海军陆战队一样，我向前推进。”完成第一堂课后，墨菲被第107届国会授予国会记录，作为海军军官候选学校的第一位女性海军陆战队训练讲师。随着职业生涯的结束，她要求再次驻扎在奥尔巴尼。“我以前在这里驻扎过，所以我对这里的位置很熟悉，”她说。“我在上一次任务中向海军陆战队后勤司令部申请了命令。我认为这对我来说是一份好工作，而且由于我对后勤的理解和背景，我会成功的。”2015年6月，墨菲担任了后勤司令部的高级应征顾问。“当你是一名军士长，为一名将军或上校工作时，你希望在工作中有一些背景知识，这样你就不会看起来像刚开始学习（军事职业专业）的人，”她说。“我来到这里的决心与我在其他地方所做的一样，那就是照顾海军陆战队。“虽然我的工作离海军陆战队有点远，但我仍然能够适应和克服，”她继续说。她指出：“每当我不跟随将军旅行或做将军日程上的事情时，我都会参加海军陆战队的日程安排。我们为海军陆战队的士官级、参谋士官级和综合级人员开设了专业军事教育课程。”。“我尽我所能去做了很多事。那些PME包括晚宴、晚餐之夜和专业晚宴。”墨菲的计划是向海军陆战队说明友情的重要性。“我认为把士官和参谋士官聚在一起会让他们更好地相互欣赏，”她说。“一旦他们开始互相欣赏，他们就合作得更好了。”墨菲想留下的遗产是关爱、谦逊、追求完美、努力工作和奉献。她说：“当你深深地关心一个人时，无论是惩罚还是奖励，你都会为他做正确的事情。”。“因为很多时候人们都以消极的态度看待惩罚，但他们并不总是消极的。有时，有些教训需要传授。“我们海军陆战队的士官信条中有一部分是追求完美，我们做到了。”她补充道。“我们并不完美。没有完美的人，但我们追求完美。”总的来说，墨菲将她30年的职业生涯描述为一场与血、汗、泪、污垢和痛苦的“斗争”。她说：“生活不容易，也不应该如此。任何好的事情都来之不易。海军陆战队有句谚语，‘痛苦是离开身体的弱点’。我相信这句话。“如果是这样，那就不是你想要的。”她指出：“我不认为我们能得到任何容易的事情，老实说，这需要一些艰苦的工作。你在海军陆战队的美好时光是关爱、谦逊、追求完美、努力工作和奉献的结果。”墨菲承认，她仍然不相信自己即将退休。她说：“我未来的计划是继续服役，不管是当兵，照顾无家可归的人还是女子学校。我的重点不是薪水，而是继续我的服役生涯。”在那之前，她的计划是完成博士学位，成为Murphy博士。她希望在未来六个月内完成凤凰城大学的组织领导博士学位。

column2: Caring for generations of children, Youth Services celebrates 30 years
column3:
TOBYHANNA ARMY DEPOT, Pa. ― In the late 1980s a new program director introduced the Army-sponsored In-Home Child Care Program to caregivers living in eight of Tobyhanna Army Depot’s 40 military family housing units. Today she leads a staff of 36 in caring for nearly 300 children in a 20,000 square foot, state-of-the-art facility equipped with computer labs and a multi-purpose sport room.

For 30 years parents have elected to enroll their children in on-post child care programs. In the beginning officials worried if there would be enough interest to support the program. These days Child and Youth Services (CYS) boasts a number of Defense Department certified, state certified and nationally accredited programs for infants, toddlers, preschoolers and teenagers.

Anne Wombacker, CYS coordinator, has been a driving force behind the evolution of the local programs. She’s the one who set things in motion in 1987and recalls there were about 30 children enrolled in the original program. 

The scope of the program has changed; however, the quality of care remains the same. Wombacker says the key to their success is the skilled staff that delivers expert child care to working parents. Classroom and support staff, plus managers, participate in annual, mandatory training. New hires start off with a 40-hour training orientation.

“We’re one of the smallest programs in the Army, which gives us the opportunity to try more things,” she said. “The ultimate goal is to make sure the children are safe, comfortable and happy.”

Programs are always changing, said Wombacker, who pointed out that the current preschool program covers a lot of what people would have seen in a kindergarten class 30 years ago. Staff members are always finding new ways to help the children thrive, she added.

What the children notice is the fun in the fundamental care they receive every day.

“I like doing activities like art,” said one toddler. A 5-year old boy mentioned that he likes to draw and play with toys during school. A couple children claim the train tracks and a large garbage truck are their favorites.  “I just like to play,” said another boy.

Over the years CYS has been able to fine tune a long list of activities available to their target audience. The Little Dragons karate class is still going strong after two years and dozens of children participate in the annual Fun Fitness Day event. Summer Camp is a hit with the school age set; those slots fill up fast. 

Last year, parents were introduced to an open recreation night on every other Thursday; it’s free to anyone enrolled in one of the programs.

“Parents can schedule a date night or shopping trip from 4:30 to 7:30 p.m. on those nights,” said Jen Williams, facility director. “We serve the children a light dinner and plan an activity around a theme. The kids really enjoy it.”

First and foremost, staff members are focused on providing a fun, yet challenging, learning environment for the children. Summer hires, college students and local teachers augment CYS capabilities throughout the year. They all love working with children.

“The most rewarding thing for me is when I come to work and the children are excited for the day to begin,” said Yvette, CYS staff member for nine years.

It’s been less than a year since Lisandra joined the staff and she tells everyone the children “brighten” her days. Ten years ago, Patti accepted a job she’s passionate about. She loves it when the children run to greet her every morning and how their eyes light up when learning new things.

“I think the most rewarding part of my job is the impact I have on the children’s lives,” said Jeanette, a nine year veteran. “Encouraging the children to try new things and learn about different things is priceless.”

Tobyhanna Army Depot is a recognized leader in providing world-class logistics support for command, control, communications, computers, intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance systems across the Department of Defense. Tobyhanna's Corporate Philosophy, dedicated work force and electronics expertise ensure the depot is the Joint C4ISR provider of choice for all branches of the Armed Forces and industry partners.

Tobyhanna's unparalleled capabilities include full-spectrum logistics support for sustainment, overhaul and repair, fabrication and manufacturing, engineering design and development, systems integration, post production software support, technology insertion, modification, foreign military sales and global field support to our Joint Warfighters.

About 3,200 personnel are employed at Tobyhanna, which is located in the Pocono Mountains of northeastern Pennsylvania. Tobyhanna Army Depot is part of the U.S. Army Communications-Electronics Command. Headquartered at Aberdeen Proving Ground, Maryland, the command’s mission is to research, develop, acquire, field and sustain communications, command, control computer, intelligence, electronic warfare and sensors capabilities for the Armed Forces.
column6: TOBYHANNA ARMY DEPOT, PA, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国宾夕法尼亚州托比汉纳陆军仓库
column10: 关怀一代又一代的儿童，青年服务庆祝30周年
column11: TOBYHANNA陆军基地，宾夕法尼亚州――20世纪80年代末，一位新的项目主管向居住在TOBYHANNA陆军基地40个军人家庭住房单元中8个单元的看护者介绍了陆军赞助的家庭内儿童保育项目。如今，她带领36名员工在一个占地20000平方英尺、配备有计算机实验室和多功能运动室的最先进设施中照顾近300名儿童。30年来，家长们一直选择让孩子参加后期托儿项目。起初，官员们担心是否会有足够的兴趣支持该计划。如今，儿童和青年服务局（CYS）拥有一系列国防部认证、州认证和国家认证的婴幼儿、幼儿、学龄前儿童和青少年项目。CYS协调员安妮・沃贝克（Anne Wombacker）一直是推动当地项目发展的原动力。她是1987年启动这项计划的人，她回忆说，最初的计划大约有30名儿童参加。计划的范围已经改变；然而，护理质量保持不变。Wombacker说，他们成功的关键是有熟练的工作人员为在职父母提供专业的儿童保育服务。教室和支持人员以及管理人员参加年度强制性培训。新员工从40小时的培训开始。“我们是军队中最小的项目之一，这给了我们尝试更多东西的机会，”她说。“最终目标是确保孩子们安全、舒适、快乐。”Wombacker说，课程总是在变化，他指出，目前的学前课程涵盖了30年前人们在幼儿园班上看到的很多内容。她补充说，工作人员总是在寻找新的方法来帮助孩子们茁壮成长。孩子们注意到的是他们每天接受基本护理的乐趣。“我喜欢做艺术之类的活动，”一个蹒跚学步的孩子说。一个5岁的男孩提到他喜欢在学校里画画和玩玩具。一对孩子声称火车轨道和一辆大型垃圾车是他们的最爱。“我只是喜欢玩，”另一个男孩说。多年来，CYS已经能够为他们的目标观众调整一长串的活动。两年后，小龙空手道班仍然很活跃，数十名儿童参加了一年一度的“趣味健身日”活动。夏令营是一个热门的学校年龄设置；那些位子很快就满了。去年，父母每隔一个星期四就被介绍参加一个开放的娱乐之夜；参加其中一个项目的任何人都可以免费参加。设施主任Jen Williams说：“家长们可以安排约会之夜或购物之旅，时间为下午4:30至7:30。”。“我们为孩子们提供一顿轻松的晚餐，并围绕一个主题计划一项活动。孩子们真的很享受。”首先也是最重要的是，工作人员致力于为孩子们提供一个有趣但富有挑战性的学习环境。暑期招聘、大学生和当地教师全年都在增强CYS的能力。他们都喜欢和孩子们一起工作。“对我来说，最有回报的事情是当我开始工作时，孩子们为这一天的开始感到兴奋，”CYS工作了九年的Yvette说。利桑德拉加入工作人员不到一年了，她告诉每个人孩子们“点亮”了她的日子。十年前，帕蒂接受了一份她热爱的工作。她喜欢孩子们每天早上跑来迎接她，喜欢孩子们学习新事物时眼睛闪闪发光。“我认为我工作中最有价值的部分是我对孩子们生活的影响，”九岁的老兵珍妮特说。“鼓励孩子们尝试新事物，学习不同的东西是无价的。”托比汉纳陆军基地是公认的为国防部的指挥、控制、通信、计算机、情报、监视和侦察系统提供世界级后勤支持的领导者。Tobyhanna的企业理念、专业的劳动力和电子专业知识确保了该基地是武装部队所有分支机构和行业合作伙伴首选的联合C4ISR供应商。Tobyhanna无与伦比的能力包括全谱后勤支持，用于维持、大修和维修、制造和制造，工程设计和开发、系统集成、后期制作软件支持、技术插入、修改、国外军事销售和对我们联合作战人员的全球野战支持。位于宾夕法尼亚州东北部波科诺山脉的Tobyhanna雇用了大约3200名人员。Tobyhanna陆军基地是美国陆军通信电子司令部的一部分。总部设在马里兰州阿伯丁试验场，司令部的任务是研究、开发、获取、部署和维持武装部队的通信、指挥、控制计算机、情报、电子战和传感器能力。

column2: 30 years of archaeology builds foundation for more at Fort McCoy
column3:
For 30 years until 2016, phase I and phase II archaeological field investigations took place at Fort McCoy.

During this time, the work was conducted by government and contract personnel to systematically locate archaeological sites on Fort McCoy and then evaluate their eligibility for the National Register of Historic Places.

“Over those past 30 years, archaeologists working at Fort McCoy recovered a rich cultural tapestry covering more than 10,000 years of human occupation in the Fort McCoy area,” said Alexander Woods, Ph.D., an archaeologist with Colorado State University’s Center for Environmental Management of Military Lands under contract with Fort McCoy.

“They examined ancient quarries where the first people to enter the state mined stone for their weapons and tools, documented the homes and farmsteads of pioneer Families, and rediscovered the remains of the very first infantry maneuvers from Camp Emory Upton in 1909-10,” Woods said. 

Fort McCoy first was called the Sparta Maneuver Tract, which was divided into a maneuver camp named Camp Emory Upton and an artillery camp known as Camp Robinson.

Mark McCarty, chief of the Directorate of Public Works Environmental Division Natural Resources Branch, said the archaeologists’ work benefits both the installation and researchers.

“Fort McCoy’s investment in professional archaeological work has been a huge win-win, simultaneously benefiting the installation, military training, taxpayers, and the scientific community,” he said. “Knowing the locations of sensitive archaeological sites prior to project planning saves the installation vast amounts of time and money.”

Construction and other projects can be approved much more quickly because the archaeological surveys already have been completed, McCarty said. Known archaeological deposits are protected from disturbance, and the likelihood of costly project delays or relocations is greatly reduced.

“We surveyed every safe-to-dig-and-walk inch of Fort McCoy,” Woods said. “Fort McCoy has been very proactive in making sure cultural resources are preserved and understood. That’s why there was more than three decades of phase I and phase II field work.”

Woods said the archaeology effort at Fort McCoy is much different than other archaeology projects in Wisconsin that might take place in conjunction with a transportation project, such as the building of a new highway.

“At Fort McCoy, we know exactly where we are going to be doing projects, and the (archaeology) work has helped produce a very powerful project planning tool,” Woods said. 

“For instance, if someone wants to put in a tank trail somewhere on post, it is a long project that covers a lot of ground and has the potential to interact with some archaeology. Normally, that would be a huge amount of surveying that would need to be done. Now with the planning tool, we can better help planners decide where they should and shouldn’t go with something like a tank trail. So in addition to all of this archaeology work being very cost effective for the military and the taxpayer, it has also produced a wonderful archaeology collection.”

The 30 years of work also has generated a large amount of valuable scientific information as well as hundreds of thousands of archaeological artifacts, which are cared for by the University of Wisconsin-La Crosse, Woods said. The artifacts are available to qualified researchers for study.
 
“There’s probably 100 master’s degree theses waiting to be written if students would get out there,” he said.

Some of the artifacts from the many digs also are displayed at the Fort McCoy History Center, building 902. 

These include a selection of artifacts from Camp Emory Upton and old horseshoes that were found on South Post. 

“Fort McCoy cultural-resources staff will continue to monitor and protect the condition of the installation’s known archaeological sites, working to ensure there is never a conflict between the military training mission and archaeological preservation,” McCarty said.

Recently, in June and July, Woods’ archaeological team embarked on the first phase III dig on the installation’s South Post. The dig was more intensive and produced more artifacts dating back thousands of years.

“This work was much different than the phase I and phase II work,” Woods said. “With the phase III dig, artifacts were getting place-plotted with a laser and marked on how and where the artifact was found. It’s a highly detailed bit of work. The phase III dig also helps us understand bigger questions we’ve had from earlier surveys.”

McCarty reminded everyone that any artifacts spotted while on Fort McCoy or other federal properties should be left alone. It is illegal to dig for or remove artifacts from federally owned land without permission.

(The Directorate of Public Works Environmental Division Natural Resources Branch contributed to this article.)
column9: 美国威斯康星州麦考伊堡
column10: 30年考古为麦考伊堡奠定基础
column11: 在2016年之前的30年中，第一阶段和第二阶段考古现场调查在麦考伊堡进行。在此期间，政府和合同人员开展了工作，系统定位麦考伊堡考古遗址，然后评估其是否符合国家历史遗迹登记册的资格。科罗拉多州立大学军事用地环境管理中心考古学家亚历山大・伍兹博士说：“在过去30年中，在麦考伊堡工作的考古学家们在麦考伊堡地区发现了一幅丰富的文化挂毯，覆盖了人类在麦考伊堡地区10000多年的历史。”。“他们检查了最早进入该国的人开采石头作为武器和工具的古代采石场，记录了先驱者家庭的房屋和农场，并在1909-1900年从埃默里厄普顿营地重新发现了第一批步兵机动的遗迹。”伍兹说。麦考伊堡最初被称为斯巴达机动区，该机动区分为一个名为埃默里厄普顿营的机动营地和一个名为罗宾逊营的炮兵营地。公共工程环境司自然资源处处长马克・麦卡蒂说，考古学家的工作既有利于安装，也有利于恢复他说：“麦考伊堡在专业考古工作上的投资是一个巨大的双赢，同时受益于装置、军事训练、纳税人和科学界。”。“在项目规划之前了解敏感考古遗址的位置可以节省大量的时间和金钱。”麦卡蒂说，建筑和其他项目可以更快地获得批准，因为考古调查已经完成。已知的考古矿藏受到保护，不会受到干扰，项目延期或搬迁的可能性大大降低。“我们调查了麦考伊堡每一个安全的挖掘和步行地点。”伍兹说：“麦考伊堡一直非常积极地确保文化资源得到保护和理解。这就是为什么一期和二期实地工作进行了30多年的原因。”伍兹说，麦考伊堡的考古工作与威斯康星州的其他考古项目大不相同，后者可能与交通项目（如修建一条新公路）同时进行。“在麦考伊堡，我们确切地知道我们将在哪里开展项目，以及（考古学）这项工作有助于产生一个非常强大的项目规划工具，”伍兹说。“例如，如果有人想在柱子上的某个地方放置坦克踪迹，这是一个很长的项目，覆盖了很多地面，并且有可能与一些考古学相互影响。通常，这将需要进行大量的调查。现在有了规划工具，我们可以更好地帮助规划者决定他们应该去哪里，去哪里。”除了对军队和纳税人来说非常划算的考古工作外，它还产生了一批很棒的考古收藏品。”30年的工作也产生了大量有价值的科学信息以及成千上万的考古文物，这些都是威斯康星大学LaCulse所关心的，Woods说。这些文物可供合格的研究人员进行研究。“如果学生们愿意去那里，可能有100篇硕士学位论文等着写，”他说。许多挖掘中的一些文物也在902号楼的麦考伊堡历史中心展出。这些文物包括从埃默里厄普顿营地挑选的文物和在南邮报上发现的旧马蹄铁。“麦考伊堡文化资源部的工作人员将继续监测和保护该设施已知考古遗址的状况，努力确保军事训练任务与考古保护之间不存在冲突。”麦卡蒂说。最近，在6月和7月，伍兹的考古团队在该装置的南柱上进行了第一次第三阶段挖掘。挖掘更加密集，产生了更多可追溯到数千年前的文物。“这项工作与第一阶段和第二阶段的工作大不相同，”伍兹说。“在第三阶段的挖掘中，文物被激光标绘出来，并标记出文物的发现方式和地点。这是一项非常详细的工作。第三阶段的挖掘还帮助我们了解早期调查中遇到的更大问题。”麦卡蒂提醒所有人，在麦考伊堡或其他联邦财产上发现的任何文物都应该单独留下。未经许可从联邦所有的土地上挖掘或移除文物是违法的。（公共工程环境司自然资源处董事会为本文撰稿。）

column2: ARMEDCOM Outgoing Chief of Staff Celebrates 30 Years of Service
column3:
PINELLAS PARK, Fla. C There’s a new beginning for a pillar of the Army Reserve medical community as Col. Elizabeth A. Baker, the Army Reserve Medical Command outgoing chief of staff, recognized her retirement on Aug. 5, 2017, at the C.W. Bill Young Reserve Center in Pinellas Park, Florida. 

ARMEDCOM’s Commanding General, Maj. Gen. Mary Link, officiated the ceremony held in Bakers' honor.  Baker, a Glen Cove, New York native, enters retirement after 30 years of honorable service to the Nation, and has served in increasing roles of responsibility, culminating with her final assignment as chief of staff here at ARMEDCOM.

“Elizabeth has made a tremendous impact not just for ARMEDCOM, but for the entire medical community.  The Army Reserve, the Army and specifically Army Medicine during the thirty years of service she has provided to our Nation.  Her expertise and passion for serving will continue to positively affect our organization for years to come,” Link said.  

Army Reserve Medical Command provides trained, equipped, ready, skill-rich Citizen-Soldiers to meet medical requirements across a full spectrum of military operations.  Concurrently, they provide more than 2,000 Soldiers annually to total force training and mission support, engaged in 64 major exercises across 41 locations designing, executing and assessing individual and collective training while delivering health care to Soldiers and communities around the world.

After receiving the Legion of Merit, Baker spoke of her experiences throughout her career. “Being in the Army, for me, was most certainly an affair of the heart.  As the saying goes, if you love what you do, you will never work a day in your life.  My father liked to put it this way, be like a kindergartner skipping out to recess.  I skip to work every day. . . I'm going to look back at my time in the Army Reserve and the National Guard as some of the most proud and profound and humble moments of my life,” said Baker.

Baker holds a Bachelor of Science in Finance, a Masters of Arts with high honors in security management, and a Masters in strategic studies from the Army War College.

Baker served in all corners of America from New York to Hawaii, and Washington D.C. to Florida along with a deployment to Afghanistan.  She will be joining her husband, Col. Richard G. Loony (Ret.), in retirement and reside in the Tampa Bay area.
column9: 美国佛罗里达州皮内拉斯公园
column10: ARMEDCOM即将卸任的参谋长庆祝30周年
column11: 佛罗里达州皮内拉斯公园――陆军预备役医疗司令部即将卸任的参谋长伊丽莎白・a・贝克上校于2017年8月5日在佛罗里达州皮内拉斯公园的C.W.比尔・杨预备役中心宣布退休，这标志着陆军预备役医疗界的一个新的开始。陆军司令部司令玛丽・林克少将主持了以贝克为荣的仪式。贝克是纽约格伦湾人，在光荣地为国家服务了30年后退休，并承担了越来越多的责任，最终被任命为ARMEDCOM的参谋长。“伊丽莎白不仅对ARMEDCOM，而且对整个医疗界都产生了巨大的影响。在她为我们国家服务的三十年中，陆军预备役部队、陆军，特别是陆军医学。她的专业知识和服务热情将在未来几年继续对我们的组织产生积极影响。”林克说。陆军预备役医疗司令部提供训练有素、装备精良、准备就绪、技能丰富的公民士兵，以满足全方位军事行动的医疗需求。同时，他们每年为部队训练和任务支持提供2000多名士兵，在41个地点进行64次重大演习，在向世界各地的士兵和社区提供医疗服务的同时，执行和评估个人和集体培训。在获得功勋军团后，贝克讲述了她在整个职业生涯中的经历。“对我来说，当兵当然是一件心事。俗话说，如果你热爱你所做的事情，你一辈子都不会工作。我父亲喜欢这样说，就像一个幼儿园的孩子跳出去休息。我每天都跳着去工作……我要回顾我在陆军预备队和国家队的时光这是我一生中最骄傲、最深刻、最卑微的时刻。”贝克说。贝克拥有金融学学士学位、安全管理学硕士学位和陆军战争学院战略研究硕士学位。贝克曾在美国各地服役，从纽约到夏威夷，从华盛顿特区到佛罗里达，并被派往阿富汗。她将加入她的丈夫Col、 理查德・鲁尼（Ret.）退休后居住在坦帕湾地区。

column2: Embrace the grit-  Ultimate warrior athlete preliminaries June 30
column3:
Jeremy Beale
Staff Writer
For the third year in a row, the High Intensity Tactical Training program (HITT) will answer the question, “Who among the few and proud are the toughest tactical warrior athletes within the Marine Corps?” as instillations across the world host preliminary competitions for a chance to travel to Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton, California, August 28-31, to compete in the HITT finals to prove who is the best of the best.  
Marine Corps Base Quantico’s HITT program will host its final preliminary June 30 from 8?10:30 a.m. at Butler Stadium.
The competition is open to active duty Marines only and every Marine will participate on an individual basis in their Marine issued boots and utes.
Preliminary events will be facilitated and validated by the HITT program coordinator, as no deviation from the preliminary event protocols will be allowed.
Marines who participate must have command approval and a complete registration form submitted to the installation HITT program coordinator prior to the preliminary event June 30; otherwise participation will not be allowed.
The registration forms can be found on the Quantico Semper Fit Facilities HITT website (click on 2017 HTAC registration link), or at the trainer’s desk at the Barber Physical Activities Center. Completed registration forms can be emailed to HITT Coordinator Charles Yackle at charles.yackle@usmc-mccs.org, or submitted in person at the trainer’s desk.
“We want to send the best Marine-athletes to compete in the championship from Marine Corps Base Quantico,” Yackle said. “Other HITT program coordinators use this competition as a bragging right for the entire year and every installation wants to send the winners to the championship.”
Last year, Staff Sgt. Lauren Schoener, an agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation from Marine Corps Air Station Yuma, Arizona and Cpl. Joshua Boozer from 29 Palms, brought the title back to their installations last year.  Marine Staff Sgt. Amanda Jenks, Marine Corps Forces Cyberspace Command, represented MCBQ last year and placed third, an honor, considering the difficulty of the competition.
In an interview between Marine Corps Community Services and Schoener, the female Marine said she was inspired to push through to the end, especially when she found herself in first place by the end of day two.  
“My secret to success is to be tenacious, consistent and always try anything twice,” said Schoener.
The competition consists of three events meant to push Marines past their breaking point by combining the five unified components of functional based training―movement prep; strength and power; speed, agility and endurance; flexibility and core stability; recovery and mobility.
Marine warrior athletes will take part in the HITT performance combine, a test of athletic prowess comprised of the pro agility drill, 3-cone drill, kneeling med ball throw, standing broad jump, prone 25-yard sprint and the 300-yard shuttle. 
A 400-yard tactical shuttle run and strength challenge will also be included. The 400-yard tactical shuttle run is a test on anaerobic capacity and mettle, consisting of a 50-yard sprint with the Frog training device, 100-yard fireman’s carry with a sandbag, 100-yard run with kettle bells and a 100-yard bear hug run with a sandbag.
The strength challenge consists of a kettle bell dead lift, TRX (utilizing straps) inverted row, and TRX atomic push-up. The objective is to complete as many repetitions as possible in one minute for each movement.
HITT performance combine and the 400-yard tactical shuttle run will be scored by time and the strength challenge will be scored based on repetitions.
According to Yackle, the set-up is very structured, meaning all competitors will move from one event to the next in an orderly fashion and while all events are expected to be completed with maximum effort, Marines are provided ample time for rest―something that is not usually incorporated in CrossFit type workouts or functions.
“I want this competition to bring attention to the benefits the HITT program has on Marines aboard Quantico,” Yackle said. “As a professional strength and conditioning coach, I fully endorse the HITT program as a superior training platform for the active duty Marine and right now not enough Marines are utilizing the program and the professionals running it.”
According to the National Strength and Conditioning Association’s (NSCA) Tactical Strength and Conditioning (TSAC) NSCA-TSAC Department, the HITT program methodology offers a comprehensive and balanced strength and conditioning approach specific for combat readiness and physical resiliency. 
The primary purpose of the HITT program is to enhance operational fitness levels and optimize combat readiness and resiliency for the active duty Marine. 
This comprehensive strength and conditioning program takes into consideration the physical demands of operational related activities in order to optimize physical performance while in combat by implementing the latest cutting edge training methods and fundamental scientific principles. 
HITT  has many advantages including preventing  potential injuries through a well-designed, balanced and progressive prevention program, thus minimizing muscle imbalances, strengthening tendons and ligaments, along with increasing work capacity.
It also increases performance levels that support combat-specific tasks through sound strength and conditioning programs designed around a comprehensive approach, balancing all facets of performance enhancement and exercises that will transfer to the demands of combat. 
The goal is to build strong Marines and further optimize their mobility and speed so these mobilized warriors may deliver more force on demand.
Check the MCCS Semper Fit Facilities website (quantico.usmc-mccs.org/index.cfm/semper-fit/semper-fit-facilities/hitt-high-intensity-tactical-training-center/) or call the HITT coordinator at 703-432-0592 for the most up-to-date information.
jbeale@quanticosentryonline.com
column9: 匡蒂科，弗吉尼亚州，美国
column10: 拥抱勇气-终极勇士运动员预赛6月30日
column11: Jeremy BealeStaff Writer高强度战术训练计划（HITT）将连续第三年回答这样一个问题：“海军陆战队中为数不多且引以为傲的战术勇士运动员中，谁是最坚韧的？”8月28日至31日，世界各地的教育机构举办了预备赛，希望有机会前往加利福尼亚州彭德尔顿海军陆战队大本营，参加HITT总决赛，以证明谁是最棒的。海军陆战队匡蒂科基地的HITT计划将于6月30日上午8时至10时30分在巴特勒体育场举行最后一场预赛。比赛仅对现役海军陆战队开放，每位海军陆战队士兵将穿着海军陆战队发行的靴子和UTE参加。预赛将由HITT计划进行促进和验证协调员，因为不允许偏离初步活动协议。参加的海军陆战队必须在6月30日初步活动之前获得司令部批准，并向安装HITT项目协调员提交完整的登记表；否则将不允许参与。注册表格可在Quantico Semper Fit Facilities HITT网站（点击2017 HTAC注册链接）或理发师体育活动中心的培训师处找到。填妥的注册表格可通过电子邮件发送至Charles的HITT协调员Charles Yackle。yackle@usmc-Yackle说：“我们希望派遣最好的海军陆战队运动员从海军陆战队匡蒂科基地参加锦标赛。”。“其他HITT项目协调人利用这场比赛作为全年的吹牛权，每个装置都想把获胜者送上锦标赛。”去年，亚利桑那州尤马海军陆战队航空站联邦调查局特工Lauren Schoener上士和来自29 Palms的Joshua Boozer下士，去年他们的装置又恢复了这个名称。海军陆战队网络空间司令部的海军陆战队参谋中士Amanda Jenks去年代表MCBQ获得第三名，考虑到比赛的难度，这是一项荣誉。在海军陆战队社区服务部和Schoener之间的一次采访中，这位女海军陆战队士兵说，她受到了激励，能够坚持到底，尤其是在第二天结束时，她发现自己名列第一。“我成功的秘诀是坚持不懈，始终如一，任何事情都要尝试两次，”Schoener说。比赛包括三个项目，旨在通过结合功能训练运动准备的五个统一组成部分，推动海军陆战队突破极限；实力,；速度、敏捷性和耐力；灵活性和核心稳定性；恢复力和灵活性。海军陆战队战士运动员将参加HITT performance combine，这是一项运动能力测试，包括专业敏捷训练、三锥训练、跪式医疗球投掷、站立跳远、俯卧25码短跑和300码穿梭。还将包括400码战术穿梭跑和力量挑战。400码战术穿梭跑是对无氧能力和勇气的测试，包括50码蛙式短跑、100码消防员背沙袋跑、100码壶铃跑和100码熊抱沙袋跑。力量挑战包括壶铃式死举，TRX（使用背带）倒排和TRX原子上推。目标是在一分钟内完成每个动作尽可能多的重复。HITT性能组合和400码战术穿梭跑将按时间计分，力量挑战将根据重复计分。Yackle表示，设置非常结构化，这意味着所有参赛者将以有序的方式从一项赛事转移到下一项赛事，而所有赛事都将以最大的努力完成，海军陆战队将获得充足的休息时间，这通常不是交叉型训练或功能中所包含的。亚克尔说：“我希望这次比赛能让大家注意到HITT计划对匡迪科号上的海军陆战队的好处。”。“作为一名专业的力量和训练教练，我完全赞同HITT计划作为现役海军陆战队的高级训练平台，目前没有足够的海军陆战队使用该计划以及运行该计划的专业人员。”根据国家力量和训练协会（NSCA）的说法战术力量与训练（TSAC）在NSCA-TSAC部门，HITT计划方法为战备和体能恢复提供了一种全面、平衡的力量和调节方法。HITT计划的主要目的是提高现役海军陆战队的作战适应水平，优化战备和恢复能力。这一全面的e力量和体能训练计划考虑到作战相关活动的身体需求，通过实施最新的尖端训练方法和基本科学原理，在战斗中优化身体表现。HITT具有许多优势，包括通过ll设计、平衡和渐进的预防计划，从而最大限度地减少肌肉失衡，加强肌腱和韧带，同时提高工作能力。它还通过围绕全面方法设计的合理力量和调节计划，提高性能水平，以支持战斗特定任务，平衡各个方面性能提升和演习将转变为作战需求。目标是建立强大的海军陆战队，进一步优化其机动性和速度，以便这些动员的战士能够根据需要提供更多的兵力。请访问MCCS Semper Fit Facilities网站（quantico.usmc mccs.org/index.cfm/semper-fit/semper-fit facilities/hitt高强度战术训练中心/）或致电703-432-0592联系hitt协调员以获取最新信息。jbeale@quanticosentryonline.com

column2: In the company of heroes- Pararescue chief retires after 30 years
column3:
“It’s not just retiring a Special Tactics Chief,” said Col. Michael Flatten, vice commander of the 24th Special Operations Wing and the retirement ceremony officiant. “It’s retiring a close friend, a brother in arms, one of my heroes…and one of the best men Special Tactics has ever produced.” 

Keaton’s service began when he enlisted in the Air Force in 1987 as Law Enforcement installation patrol C today’s Security Forces career field. After five years, Keaton realized the job wasn't a good fit for him, despite being credited with saving three lives during that time. 

“I routinely say bloom where you’re planted,” said Flatten. “But sometimes you may be planted in the wrong place, and Keaton was like a Palm tree in Shemya, Alaska.” 

Keaton’s time in Security Forces ended in 1992, when he made the decision to cross train into the Pararescue career field. 

“In law enforcement, there wasn’t a lot of job satisfaction for me; it was a spur of the moment decision to join pararescue because it was the only job available to me at the time,” said Keaton. “I had no idea what I was getting myself into, but I said ‘I’ll do whatever I have to do.’” 

Pararescuemen are among the most highly trained technical rescue and emergency trauma specialists in the U.S. military. They must maintain an Emergency Medical Technician- Paramedic qualification throughout their careers. With this medical and rescue expertise, along with their deployment capabilities, PJs are able to perform life-saving rescue missions in the world's most remote areas. 

After completing the pararescue pipeline, a difficult two-year training process of psychological and physical challenges, his career took a dramatic turn. 

“In every annual report [since he cross trained], Dave’s maturity, drive, professionalism, pursuit of training, selfless service and focus on team are highlighted,” said Flatten. “He continued to save people, on the battlefield and off… including 2 military working dogs.” 

Over the course of his time as a PJ, he attained paramedic, static line and freefall jumpmaster, and dive medical tech qualifications. He trained a generation of new PJs, earning the Outstanding Instructor Award and serving as interim Commandant of Indoctrination Cthe first chapter of the PJ pipeline infamous for its high standards 

“I love pararescue: I loved my career, I loved the men I served with and the ST community as a whole,” said Keaton. “That’s why I stuck around it for so long: it was home for me.” 

Keaton deployed more than 15 times throughout his career in support of Operations FIERY VIGIL, SOUTHERN and NORTHERN WATCH, JOINT ENDEAVOR, ENDURING FREEDOM, IRAQI FREEDOM, COPPER DUNE and NEW DAWN. 

Each deployment served to showcase Keaton’s courage; he was credited numerous times with charging behind enemy lines to rescue fallen teammates and save lives C epitomizing the pararescue creed C “These things we do … that others may live.” 

“He set the standard for service in a selectively-manned unit tasked with the nation’s toughest missions, including a hostage rescue in 2008 and a combat military free fall infiltration in Afghanistan in 2009,” said Flatten. 

Leaders in Special Tactics describe him as an “absolute juggernaut,” “trusted advisor and right hand man,” “the most powerful SNCO I’ve ever supervised,” “proven warrior and leader”….and most importantly to many Special Tactics Airmen, “trusted teammate.” 

He accomplished all that despite challenges he faced, never losing focus on the mission nor his love for those around him. 

“I now know what sacrifice is,” said Keaton of his time in Special Tactics. “I know firsthand what loss is, and what those families go through when they lose loved ones overseas to protect our freedoms.” 

This dedication to the fallen was epitomized when he participated in an  812-mile memorial ruck march from San Antonio, Texas, to Hurlburt Field, Fla. in 2014. It came at a time when the Special Tactics community was reeling from the loss of two operators, Capt. Matthew Roland and Staff Sgt. Forrest Sibley, who were killed in an ambush during a deployment to Afghanistan that year.

Unbeknownst to his teammates, Keaton had broken three ribs a week before the ruck march began, but kept that to himself. Matching Cand sometimes outdoing-- the pace of teammates 20 years his junior the entire trip, he rucked 128 miles with a 50-pound rucksack and a baton engraved with one of the 19 Special Tactics Airmen killed in action. 

“I’m not going to complain about broken ribs -- the pain I felt during the march paled in comparison to what the Roland and Sibley families are going through, so having three ribs is something I can deal with."

Keaton ran the last 12 miles of the memorial ruck to meet the waiting Gold Star families at the finish line...despite suffering a stress fracture in his leg.

“I’m thankful to serve with incredible people that have made that ultimate sacrifice. Not one day goes by where I don’t think about at least one of those guys,” added Keaton. 

According to Keaton, life after retirement will be spent catching up with friends and making time for the things that are important outside of work. But, the Special Tactics community is now left with big shoes to fill-- someone who will never quit.

“He is the epitome of a teammate and I have never, in my life met anyone more concerned about the welfare of those around them as him,” said Flatten “He rightly walks in the company of heroes.”
column9: 美国佛罗里达州赫尔伯特菲尔德
column10: 在英雄的陪伴下，救援队长30年后退休
column11: 第24特别行动部副指挥官兼退休仪式主礼人迈克尔・弗拉特上校说：“这不仅仅是让一名特别战术指挥官退休。”。“一位亲密的朋友、一位战友、我的英雄之一……以及有史以来最优秀的特种战术人物之一即将退休。”基顿的服役始于1987年，当时他应征加入空军，担任执法设施巡逻队――今天的安全部队职业领域。五年后，基顿意识到这份工作并不适合他，尽管在那段时间里他挽救了三条生命。“我经常说你种的地方开花，”弗拉特说。“但有时你可能被安置在错误的地方，而基顿就像阿拉斯加谢米亚的一棵棕榈树。”基顿在安全部队的时间结束于1992年，当时他决定交叉训练进入救援职业领域。基顿说：“在执法部门，我的工作满意度不高；加入pararescue只是一时冲动，因为这是当时我唯一能找到的工作。”。“我不知道自己陷入了什么境地，但我说‘我会做我必须做的一切’。”助理救援人员是美国军方训练有素的技术救援和紧急创伤专家之一。他们必须在整个职业生涯中保持急救医疗技术员-护理人员资格。凭借这一医疗和救援专业知识以及部署能力，PJ能够在世界最偏远地区执行救生救援任务。在完成了为期两年的心理和生理挑战的艰苦训练后，他的职业生涯发生了戏剧性的转变。“在每一份年度报告中（自他交叉培训以来），Dave的成熟、干劲、专业精神、对培训的追求、无私的服务和对团队的关注都得到了强调，”Flatte说。“他继续在战场内外救人……包括两只军用工作犬。”在担任PJ期间，他获得了护理人员、静态线路和自由落体跳跃大师以及潜水医疗技术资格。他培训了一代新的PJ，获得了杰出讲师奖，并担任了灌输的临时指挥官――PJ管道的第一章，因其高标准而臭名昭著。“我爱Parasure：我爱我的事业，我爱与我一起服务的人以及整个ST社区，”基顿说。“这就是为什么我在这里呆了这么久：这里是我的家。”基顿在他的职业生涯中部署了超过15次，支持“火焰守夜行动”、“南方和北方守望行动”、“联合奋进行动”、“持久自由”、“伊拉克自由”、“铜沙丘”和“新黎明”行动。每一次部署都展示了基顿的勇气；他曾多次在敌后冲锋营救倒下的队友并拯救生命――这是副营救信条的一个缩影――“我们所做的这些事……其他人可能会活着。”Flatte说：“他为一支有选择性地配备人员的部队制定了服务标准，该部队担负着国家最艰巨的任务，包括2008年的人质营救和2009年在阿富汗的战斗军事自由落体渗透。”特种战术领导人形容他为“绝对的神像”、“值得信赖的顾问和得力助手”“我所监管过的最强大的SNCO”，“久经考验的战士和领袖”…对许多特种战术飞行员来说最重要的是，“值得信赖的队友”。他完成了所有这些，尽管他面临挑战，从未失去对任务的关注和对周围人的爱。“我现在知道牺牲是什么。”基顿在《特别战术》中谈到他的时代时说，“我第一手知道损失是什么，以及这些家庭在海外失去亲人以保护我们的自由时所经历的一切。”2014年，他参加了从得克萨斯州圣安东尼奥到佛罗里达州赫尔伯特菲尔德的812英里纪念游行，这体现了他对堕落者的奉献精神。当时，特种战术团体正因失去两名操作员而感到震惊，他们是马修・罗兰上尉和福雷斯・西布里上士，他们在一次d那年，基顿被派往阿富汗。他的队友们不知道，基顿在游行开始前一周折断了三根肋骨，但他自己保持着这一点。在整个行程中，他用一个50磅重的背包和一根刻有19种特殊技巧之一的指挥棒跑了128英里ics飞行员在战斗中阵亡。“我不想抱怨肋骨骨折――与罗兰和西布利一家所经历的相比，我在行军期间感到的疼痛相形见绌，所以有三根肋骨是我可以应付的。“基顿跑完最后12英里，在终点线迎接等待着的金星家庭……尽管他的腿受了应力性骨折。“我很感谢与做出最终牺牲的不可思议的人一起服务。没有一天我不去想这些人中的任何一个。”基顿补充道。根据基顿的说法，退休后的生活将花在与朋友的交流上，并为工作之外的重要事情腾出时间。但是，特殊策略社区现在剩下的是要填补的大空缺――一个永远不会放弃的人。“他是队友的缩影，在我的一生中，我从未遇到过像他这样关心周围人福利的人，”弗拉特说，“他与英雄同行是正确的。”

column2: Officer developmental education application window opens Jan. 30
column3:
Eligible active duty officers can apply for intermediate and senior developmental education opportunities starting Jan. 30.

The nomination process starts via the web-based form 3849, available on AFPC Secure (https://w45.afpc.randolph.af.mil/afpcsecurenet40/PKI/MainMenu1.aspx). Officers may select up to five IDE/SDE programs in which they are interested and should ensure they meet the minimum criteria for each selected program as requirements and eligibility vary. 

“The Air Force embraces the concept of lifelong learning, which draws meaningful connections between the distinct educational experiences throughout a career,” said Kris Hunter, officer DE deputy chief at the Air Force Personnel Center.

Intermediate programs include the Air Command and Staff College, sister service and international schools, a variety of fellowship programs and more. Senior programs include the Air War College, Air Force and national defense fellowships, National Defense University programs, sister service and international schools, and more. 

“Our education builds the foundation for training and developing transformational leaders at all levels,” Hunter said.

Applications, including senior rater nominations, must be submitted by March 3. Officers nominated by their senior raters will have until March 28 to review their records in the Personnel Records Display Application (https://w45.afpc.randolph.af.mil/afpcsecurenet40/PKI/MainMenu1.aspx) to verify all personal information is accurate and their latest officer performance reports are on file.
 
Final results from the Developmental Education Designation Board, identifying the DE programs for which officers have been selected, will be released in October.

Stay informed on the most current developmental education information on the officer Force Development page on myPers (https://mypers.af.mil/). Alternatively, select “Active Duty Officer” from the dropdown menu and search “IDE” or “SDE.”

The call for nominations for civilian developmental opportunities will be at a later date. 

For more information about Air Force personnel programs, go to myPers. Individuals who do not have a myPers account can request one by following these instructions (http://www.afpc.af.mil/myPers).
column6: JOINT BASE SAN ANTONIO-RANDOLPH, TX, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥-伦道夫联合基地
column10: 警官发展教育申请窗口于1月30日开放
column11: 符合条件的现役军官可从1月30日起申请中级和高级发展教育机会。提名过程通过AFPC Secure上的基于网络的3849表格开始(https://w45.afpc.randolph.af.mil/afpcsecurenet40/PKI/MainMenu1.aspx). 官员可以选择最多五个他们感兴趣的IDE/SDE计划，并应确保他们满足每个选定计划的最低标准，因为要求和资格不同。空军人事中心副主任克里斯・亨特（Kris Hunter）说：“空军信奉终身学习的理念，这将在整个职业生涯中不同的教育经历之间建立有意义的联系。中级课程包括空军指挥和参谋学院、姐妹服务和国际学校，各种奖学金计划等等。高级课程包括空战学院、空军和国防研究金、国防大学课程、姐妹服务和国际学校等。“我们的教育为各级培训和发展变革型领导奠定了基础，”猎人说，包括高级提名者在内的申请必须在3月3日前提交。由高级评分员提名的人员将在3月28日前审查其在人事记录显示应用程序中的记录(https://w45.afpc.randolph.af.mil/afpcsecurenet40/PKI/MainMenu1.aspx)核实所有个人信息准确无误，并将其最新的军官绩效报告存档。发展教育指定委员会的最终结果，确定已选定军官的DE计划，将于10月发布。请随时了解myPers军官部队发展页面上的最新发展教育信息(https://mypers.af.mil/). 或者，从下拉菜单中选择“现役军官”并搜索“IDE”或“SDE”。平民发展机会提名将在稍后日期进行。有关空军人事计划的更多信息，请访问myPers。没有myPers帐户的个人可以按照以下说明申请myPers帐户(http://www.afpc.af.mil/myPers).

column2: 30 years past- 20th FW role in Victor Alert
column3:
SHAW AIR FORCE BASE, S.C. C Thirty years ago, the first of November marked the end of the decades-long nuclear stalemate between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Soviet Union.

For 28 years, forces on both sides of the Cold War stood vigilant against threats from the opposition.

During that time, the 20th Fighter Wing, based in England C first at Royal Air Force Wethersfield, and then RAF Upper Heyford C was a part of the mission known as Quick Reaction Alert, more commonly known as Victor Alert. Their job was to provide tactical nuclear weapons at a moment’s notice, providing targeting options in Eastern Europe and deterring Soviet forces from concentrating conventional forces and firepower.

“This was more of a deterrent than anything,” said Christopher Koonce, 20th FW historian. “Just to show them ‘hey, we’re here if you want to start trouble. We can handle it.’”

To retain their mission-ready status, crews remained on alert for 72-hour periods, prepared to take off within 15 minutes of an alert order.

Aircraft remained fully loaded with nuclear weapons, fueled and ready to go, said Koonce. Nearby in the alert facility aircrews slept, ate and remained for their alert shift. If the call ever came to deploy the weapons, all they had to do was run out the door, get on the jet and go.

Even though that call never came, the crews still had to practice to keep their skills sharp. Crews participated in drills where they would scramble as though it were a real-world situation, but before takeoff the nuclear weapons would be removed and returned to storage. Afterward, the pilots would fly as the mission directed.

“The Fulda Gap was the big thing during that time frame,” said Koonce. “All of the exercises, everything had to do with that C the Russians going and taking over Western Germany and moving across Western Europe like a plague.”

According to a March 1987 Los Angeles Times article, a key point of defense against the Soviet threat was the Fulda Gap in West Germany. The gap was pinpointed by NATO planners as a likely invasion route into Western Europe; there the United States maintained nearly 250,000 troops, part of a larger NATO force of about 990,000. These forces were poised to face off against more than 1 million Warsaw Pact personnel.

Though Victor Alert officially ended Nov. 1, 1986, today’s aircraft such as the F-16CM Fighting Falcon and F-15E Strike Eagle still retain the capability to arm nuclear weapons if necessary to combat today’s adversaries.

Editor’s Note: Information from March 2011 Air Force Magazine article Victor Alert by Rebecca Grant was used in this story
column6: SHAW AIR FORCE BASE, SC, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国南卡罗来纳州肖空军基地
column10: 30年过去-第20 FW在Victor Alert中的角色
column11: 南卡罗来纳州肖空军基地――30年前的11月1日标志着北大西洋公约组织（North Atlantic Treaty Organization，简称北约）和苏联之间长达数十年的核僵局的结束。28年来，冷战双方的部队一直对反对派的威胁保持警惕。在此期间，第20战斗机联队，总部设在英国――先是在英国皇家空军威瑟斯菲尔德，然后是英国皇家空军上海福德基地――是快速反应警报任务的一部分，通常称为维克托警报。他们的任务是在接到通知的瞬间提供战术核武器，在东欧提供目标选择，阻止苏联军队集中常规力量和火力。“这比任何东西都更具威慑力，”FW第20届历史学家克里斯托弗・孔斯（Christopher Koonce）说。“只是为了向他们展示‘嘿，如果你想制造麻烦，我们就在这里。我们可以处理它’。”为了保持其任务就绪状态，机组人员保持72小时的戒备状态，准备在发出警报命令后15分钟内起飞。飞机仍然满载核武器，充满燃料，随时可以起飞，库恩斯说。在警戒设施附近，空勤人员睡觉、吃饭，并在警戒换班时留下来。如果有人要求部署武器，他们所要做的就是冲出大门，登上喷气式飞机出发。尽管这一要求从未出现，但机组人员仍必须练习以保持技能的敏捷。机组人员参加了演习，在演习中，他们会像在现实世界中一样进行攀爬，但在起飞前，核武器将被移除并返回仓库。之后，飞行员将按照任务指示飞行。“在这段时间内，富尔达缺口是一件大事，”库恩斯说。《洛杉矶时报》1987年3月的一篇文章称，抵御苏联威胁的一个关键点是西德的富尔达缺口。北约规划者指出，这一缺口可能是一条进入西欧的入侵路线；在那里，美国维持着近250000名士兵，是北约约990000名更大部队的一部分。这些部队准备与100多万华约人员对抗。尽管维克托警戒正式于1986年11月1日结束，今天的飞机，如F-16CM战斗猎鹰和F-15E攻击鹰，仍然保留在必要时武装核武器的能力，以打击今天的对手。编者按：这篇报道使用了2011年3月《空军》杂志文章《丽贝卡・格兰特的维克多警报》中的信息

column2: After 30 Years of Dedication, Escalante retires from the Corps
column3:
Colonel Yori R. Escalante, during a ceremony at John A. Lejeune Hall, retired after 30 years of selfless service to the Marine Corps at Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune, Oct. 14. 

“How does someone define 30 years in the Marine Corps,” said Col. Yori R. Escalante, deputy commander of Marine Corps Installations East-Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune. “In my opinion it’s the people, it’s the people that you serve with, it’s the people who have influenced you and molded and shaped you into what you are today.”

Escalante deployed to Aviano, Italy in support of Operation Joint Endeavor, to Afghanistan in support of Operation Enduring Freedom and twice to Iraq in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom. Maj. Gen. Charles L. Hudson first met Escalante at Iraq during Operation Iraqi Freedom and enjoyed having him as chief of staff.

“I’ll tell you what, (there’s) no finer chief of staff (that I’ve) ever had than this man right here,” said Hudson. “And I say that because at that particular point in time there were numerous issues that had to be resolved, joyfully resolved at the chief of staff level.” 

Over his career Escalante earned the Defense Superior Service Medal, the Legion of Merit with gold star, the Bronze Star, the Meritorious Service Medal with two gold stars, and the Navy and Marine Corps Commendation Medal with gold star. 

Escalante also received the Navy Achievement Medal, the Presidential Unit Citation, and NATO Medals for Former Republic of Yugoslavia and the International Security Assistance Force, Afghanistan.

“If I could use one word to describe Col. Yori Escalante I couldn’t come up with a word,” said Hudson. “I came up with several, but I couldn’t come up with any one. I mentioned tenacity and tenaciousness; deeply committed to God; country and Corps; deeply passionate about his profession; and deeply passionate about his family. I mean he spent 30 years of honest and faithful service in many a clime and place.” 

Escalante went to Texas A&M University earning a Bachelor of Science in Building Construction in December 1986 then became a combat engineer in the Marine Corps the next year in 1987. During his career he earned his Master of Arts in Management from Webster University and Master of Science in National Resource Strategy from the Industrial College of the Armed Forces. He is now married with two children and ready for retirement.

“This is just the end of one chapter and the beginning of another, the next chapter I think will be good,” said Hudson.
column9: 北卡罗来纳州，美国
column10: 经过30年的奉献，埃斯卡兰特从兵团退休
column11: 10月14日，在列琼海军陆战队大本营为海军陆战队无私服务30年后，尤里・R・埃斯卡兰特上校在约翰・a・列琼大厅举行的仪式上退休。海军陆战队设施部副指挥官约里・R・埃斯卡兰特上校（Yori R.Escalante）说：“人们如何定义海军陆战队的30年？”。“在我看来，是人民，是与你一起服务的人民，是人民影响了你，塑造了你，塑造了你今天的样子。”Escalante部署到意大利阿维亚诺，支持联合奋进行动，阿富汗支持持久自由行动，两次伊拉克支持伊拉克自由行动。查尔斯・哈德逊少将在伊拉克自由行动期间第一次见到埃斯卡兰特，并很高兴他能担任参谋长。“我告诉你，（我）这里没有比这个人更好的参谋长了，”哈德逊说。“我之所以这么说，是因为在那个特定的时刻，有许多问题需要解决，在参谋长一级，这些问题都得到了愉快的解决。”在他的职业生涯中，埃斯卡兰特获得了国防高级服务奖章、金星功勋勋章、铜星功勋奖章和两颗金星功勋奖章，海军和海军陆战队金星奖章。埃斯卡兰特还获得了海军成就勋章、总统单位奖章以及前南斯拉夫共和国和阿富汗国际安全援助部队的北约奖章。“如果我能用一个词来形容尤里・埃斯卡兰特上校，我想不出一个词来，”哈德森说。“我想出了几个，但我一个也找不到。我提到了坚韧和坚韧；深深地忠于上帝；忠于国家和军队；深深地热爱他的职业；深深地热爱他的家庭。我的意思是，他在许多地方和地方诚实而忠诚地服务了30年。”埃斯卡兰特于1986年12月进入德克萨斯A&M大学获得建筑工程理学学士学位，然后于1987年成为海军陆战队的战斗工程师。在他的职业生涯中，他获得了韦伯斯特大学管理学硕士学位和武装部队工业学院国家资源战略科学硕士学位。哈德森说：“这只是一个章节的结束，另一个章节的开始，我认为下一个章节会很好。”。

column2: Charlie 9 BEB Soldiers raise 30-meter mast
column3:
FORT STEWART, Ga. C Soldiers with Charlie Company, 9th Brigade Engineer Battalion, 2nd Infantry Brigade Combat Team, 3rd Infantry Division conducted 30-meter mast familiarization and training at Fort Stewart, Georgia, June 27-28.

“Today we are conducting training on how to properly raise and secure the 30-meter masts,” said Sgt. Laurelin Mathis, a multichannel transmission systems operator with C Co.

The 30-meter mast is a large deployable tower capable of elevating two 55-pound antennas to a maximum height of 98 feet. A three-legged base and a series of support cables are used to stabilize the structure in place, according to Army doctrine.

“This training is extremely important for the safety of all Soldiers involved with a mission,” said Sgt. Travis Davis, a multichannel transmission systems operator and noncommissioned officer in charge of the training with C Co. “If Soldiers are not properly trained and something is done incorrectly or not secured properly there is a real potential for it to fall and cause serious injury.”

The signal Soldiers utilize this equipment to adapt to environmental circumstances, such as hills or vegetation, which may interfere with transmission between two communicating high capacity line-of-sight, or HCLOS, shelters.  

"The 30-meter and 15-meter masts are components of the HCLOS shelters,” said Spc. John Smarr, a multichannel transmission systems operator with Co. C. “We use whichever is most efficient to establish connectivity with our distant end.”

Prior to working with the equipment Soldiers participated in classroom training led by subject matter experts.

“A lot of the newer [multichannel transmission systems operators] have little experience with the 30-meter mast,” Davis said. “We are focusing this training on familiarization and explaining basic operation of how to safely set up the 30-meter masts.”

The two-day training was a successful according to Mathis and some of the participants.

“Each of the Soldiers were able to increase their understanding on how the mast is constructed,” Mathis said. “This is training that we will continue to build on so Soldiers are able to increase their proficiencies.”

“This was a great training event. The terrain here at Fort Stewart is relatively flat, so there is little need for such a large mast,” Smarr said. “However, we never know where a mission may take us so training like this is a great way to maintain and improve our skills.”
column9: 美国佐治亚州斯图尔特堡
column10: 查理9号BEB士兵举起30米长的桅杆
column11: 佐治亚州斯图尔特堡――6月27日至28日，第三步兵师第二步兵旅战斗队第九旅工兵营查理连的士兵在佐治亚州斯图尔特堡进行了30米桅杆熟悉和培训。“今天，我们正在进行如何正确提升和固定30米桅杆的培训。”C公司的多通道传输系统运营商劳雷林・马蒂斯中士说。30米长的桅杆是一个大型可展开塔，能够将两个55磅重的天线提升到98英尺的最大高度。根据陆军条令，一个三条腿的基地和一系列的支撑电缆用于将结构稳定在适当的位置。“这项训练对于所有参与任务的士兵的安全至关重要，”特拉维斯・戴维斯中士说，多通道传输系统操作员和负责C公司培训的士官。“如果士兵没有得到适当的培训，并且某些事情做得不正确或没有得到适当的保护，那么很有可能坠落并造成严重伤害。”信号兵利用该设备适应可能干扰两个通信高容量视线或HCLOS掩体之间传输的环境条件，如丘陵或植被。“30米和15米的桅杆是HCLOS掩体的组成部分，”C公司多通道传输系统运营商Spc.John Smarr说，“我们使用最有效的方法与远端建立连接。”在使用这些设备之前，士兵们参加了由学科专家领导的课堂培训。“许多较新的[多通道传输系统操作员]对30米桅杆几乎没有经验，”戴维斯说。“我们的培训重点是熟悉和解释如何安全安装30米桅杆的基本操作。”马蒂斯和一些参与者表示，为期两天的培训是成功的。“每个士兵都能够提高他们对桅杆构造的了解，”马蒂斯说。斯马尔说：“这是我们将继续加强的训练，以便士兵们能够提高他们的熟练程度。”“这是一次伟大的训练活动。斯图尔特堡的地形相对平坦，因此不需要这么大的桅杆。”。“然而，我们永远不知道任务会把我们带到哪里，所以像这样的训练是保持和提高我们技能的好方法。”

column2: Combat Center Sgt. Maj. retires after 30 years
column3:
Marines, sailors, distinguished guests and loved ones of Marine Air Ground Task Force Training Command gathered at Lance Cpl. Torrey L. Gray Field to wish fair winds and following seas to Sgt. Maj. Karl Villalino, former Combat Center Sergeant Major, during a relief, appointment and retirement ceremony, May 10, 2016. 
During the ceremony, Villalino retired from the Marine Corps after 30 years of honorable service. He received the Legion of Merit for his dedication to duty while serving as the installation sergeant major since August of 2013. 
“Today is not just a tribute to the time-honored tradition of a relief and appointment,” said Maj. Gen. Lewis A. Craparotta, Combat Center Commanding General. “It’s certainly a reflection of the impact that [Villalino] had on Marines throughout his career.”
Villalino then passed the noncommissioned officer sword to Sgt. Maj. Michael J. Hendges, oncoming Combat Center Sergeant Major, representing the transfer of authority and responsibilities from one sergeant major to the next.
“I’m looking forward to learning everything the base does and how I can better support and serve the Marines and sailors of [the Combat Center],” Hendges said. 
As Villalino prepares to move on to the next chapter in his life, one of his sons, Pfc. Karl M. Villalino Jr., is beginning a new chapter in his. Villalino Jr. recently graduated from recruit training prior to his father’s retirement.
“I’m incredibly grateful to my father for being such an enthusiastic mentor and for his willingness to pass on his wisdom,” Villalino Jr. said. “I’m proud of his accomplishments and especially thankful for the path that has been cleared by all the Marines that came before me.”
Prior to the pass in review, Villalino concluded the ceremony with a message to all those who continue to wear the uniform of a United States Marine.
“We stand on the shoulders of those who came before us,” Villalino said. “Continue to build on that foundation; continue to build upon the legacy of the Marine Corps. That’s your responsibility.”
column6: MARINE CORPS AIR GROUND COMBAT CENTER TWENTYNINE PALMS, CA, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州二十九棕榈岛海军陆战队空地作战中心
column10: 战斗中心少校中士30年后退休
column11: 2016年5月10日，海军陆战队陆空特遣部队训练司令部的海军陆战队士兵、水手、贵宾和亲人聚集在兰斯・托里・L・格雷下士场，向前战斗中心军士长卡尔・维拉利诺少校（Sing.Maj.Karl Villalino）致以“顺风顺水”的祝愿。在仪式上，维拉利诺在光荣服役30年后从海军陆战队退休。自2013年8月起，他在担任装置军士长期间，因其尽忠职守而获得了荣誉军团。战斗中心司令刘易斯・克拉帕罗塔少将说：“今天不仅仅是对救济和任命这一悠久传统的致敬。”。“这当然反映了（维拉利诺）在其职业生涯中对海军陆战队的影响。”随后，维拉利诺将军士军刀交给即将到来的作战中心军士长迈克尔・亨吉斯少校，代表着从一名军士长到下一名军士长的权力和责任转移。“我期待着学习基地所做的一切，以及我如何更好地支持和服务海军陆战队和[作战中心]的水兵。”当维拉利诺准备迈入人生的下一个篇章时，他的一个儿子小卡尔・M・维拉利诺亲王（Pfc.Karl M.Villalino Jr.）正在他的人生中开始新的篇章。小维拉利诺最近在父亲退休前从新兵培训中毕业。小维拉利诺说：“我非常感谢我的父亲，因为他是一位如此热情的导师，并且愿意传授他的智慧。我为他的成就感到骄傲，尤其感谢在我之前的所有海军陆战队为我开辟的道路。”在检阅通行证之前，维拉利诺在仪式结束时向所有继续穿着美国海军陆战队制服的人传达了一个信息。“我们站在前面的人的肩膀上，”维拉利诺说。“继续建立在这个基础上，继续建立海军陆战队的遗产，这是你的责任。”

column2: 30 Years after Desert Storm, Military Medicine Evolving ‘Phenomenally’
column3:
For Dale Smith, a longtime author and a professor of military medicine and history at the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences in Bethesda, Maryland, Desert Storm comes down to a single word.

"Survival," he said, without hesitation.

Smith, said the "immediacy of care" for those wounded in war became a clear priority in the early conflicts of the 20th century, but "we fundamentally didn't change our system of care from World War II through the Gulf War."

Medics or corpsmen were decently trained, but they may or may not have had blood on hand for wounded fighters, for example, or penicillin, or morphine.

"That was true in Italy in '44 and it was true as we launched [Operations] Desert Shield and Desert Storm in '91," Smith said.

By the Gulf War, he explained, the military's portable, auxiliary, or mobile surgical units were not portable, auxiliary, or mobile.

"We had improved the medicine so much that it would have taken every wheeled vehicle in Saudi Arabia to move a MASH (mobile army surgical hospital)," Smith said. "They had portable CT (computerized tomography) scanners that weren't really portable, for taking care of head injuries."

Coming out of the desert, he said, big changes were in order. Evacuation or fleet hospitals had multiple operating rooms and hundreds of beds and were enormously expensive to move. This lack of medical mobility likely delayed the kickoff of Desert Storm by 30 to 60 days, Smith estimated.

"Casualty projections in the summer of 1990 were astronomical," he said. "Thousands of people on both sides would be wounded or killed. Iraq had the fifth largest military in the world, and this coalition (of nations allied with the United States) was at the end of a mighty long string. So, it was thought it might be a peer-on-peer, even-up fight. Now, it turned out the Iraqi military was big on paper but not big on training, and morale wasn't any good, and they mostly rolled over when confronted."

Still, some of the lessons learned were staggering. But teasing them out took longer than expected, other experts agreed.

"Since ground combat generated relatively few casualties, especially compared to what was anticipated, there were very few innovations in the practice of medicine as a result," said Alan Hawk, manager of historical collections for the National Museum of Health and Medicine at the Defense Health Agency. "However, the big lesson of the Persian Gulf War was that the medical footprint was way too large and too cumbersome to keep up with a rapidly moving front."

Because of the clear logistical problems, Smith said that things were undertaken in 1991 that were "not yet doctrine" but based on small conflicts from the 1980s, in Grenada and later Panama.

"In both of those [conflicts] we recognized that you could move smaller medical assets quicker," he explained.

For instance, Navy SEALs in Panama - just a year before the Gulf War - advanced high-level Special Forces medical care and learned to better stabilize patients. New techniques for transporting and using fluids and antibiotics were developed.

"Then they put [casualties] on an airplane and flew them to San Antonio, with no intermediate hospitals, and they survived," Smith said.

In the Gulf, "we didn't have enough patients get hurt to be statistically significant, but we did recognize that that system was not going to get patients on operating tables quickly," Smith said. "And the surgeons at those operating tables for the most part were not trauma surgeons."

One Army physician who served in the conflict who can identify with that statement is Dr. Leopoldo "Lee" Cancio, a retired colonel now serving as director of the U.S. Army Institute of Surgical Research Burn Center at Joint Base San Antonio-Fort Sam Houston in Texas. During the Gulf War, Cancio was a young Army captain, attached to the 82nd Airborne Division and only a few years out of medical school.

Smith said a challenge for the military 30 years ago was how to prepare doctors for downrange conditions when they were only accustomed to stateside care facilities. These days, some of the same concerns hold, he said, particularly for Reserve and Guard physicians, nurses, and medics.

"I was used to taking care of injured people, but I was used to doing so in a trauma center setting," Cancio said. "I didn't have much training at all in how to translate that into the field environment."

Trauma training for military and civilian doctors alike is still "intermittent," Cancio noted.

"So that is a challenge," he said. "What has definitely improved and totally transformed combat casualty care, pre-hospital, has been the concept of tactical combat casualty care."

Tactical casualty care was an application of the lessons learned based on data collected during the Vietnam War and analyzed with computers in the 1990s, Hawk noted. This resulted in the development of improved hemorrhage control techniques for use by EMTs and combat medics.

In the Gulf, Cancio took a course called Basic Trauma Life Support, which was designed for civilian emergency medical technicians. Other pre-hospital courses and trainings did gain traction eventually, Cancio said.

But it was tactical combat casualty care that "provided a set of priorities and a sequence of events for people taking care of combat casualties, whether they're under fire, or care en route, which really served as a foundation for everything that we now teach medics and general medical officers, physician assistants, etc., for the pre-hospital environment," Cancio said.

But it was tactical combat casualty care that "provided a set of priorities and a sequence of events for people taking care of combat casualties, whether they're under fire, or care en route, which really served as a foundation for everything that we now teach medics and general medical officers, physician assistants, etc., for the pre-hospital environment," Cancio said.

"Knowing what to do when someone is injured and you're being shot at is really important," he added.

The combat casualty is different from the average victim of a car wreck in the United States, Cancio said. The severity of something like losing one or both legs to an improvised explosive device is unusual stateside during peacetime.

"One of the important early changes on the battlefield was in how we resuscitate patients, both pre-hospital and upon arrival at a medical unit," he said.

To that end, Cancio noted that the availability and portability of blood products and blood transfusions have evolved much in the past 30 years, especially in terms of battlefield care. In addition, much of stateside general surgery these days is minimally invasive and done through scopes, he said. On the battlefield you still must make big incisions on large body parts like the abdomen. That's where additional trauma surgery training becomes vital for military-specific skills.

Likewise, egregious burns are not common peacetime injuries, but are to be expected in combat - something on the order of 5% to 10% of casualties, Cancio said. If you combine burns with a traumatic brain injury, or an amputation, you're talking about truly rare levels of care, and of training for the caretakers.

Coming next week: Part 2, which shows that not all battlefield life-saving measures improved since the Gulf War are highly technical.

*

Continuing this summer:

(June): Part 2 of overview. (July): Advances in prosthetic limbs and quality of life after traumatic injury. (August): How 3-D printing is re-writing what's possible in post-traumatic care.
column9: 美国
column10: 沙漠风暴30年后，军事医学“惊人地”发展
column11: Dale Smith是马里兰州贝塞斯达美国卫生科学军队服务大学的一位长期撰稿人和军事医学和历史教授，他把沙漠风暴归结为一个词：“生存，”他毫不犹豫地说，史米斯说“关怀的即时性”。对于那些在战争中受伤的人来说，这在20世纪早期的冲突中成为了一个明确的优先事项，但是“从第二次世界大战到海湾战争，我们没有从根本上改变我们的医疗体系。”医生或医务人员都受过良好的训练，但他们可能手头上有受伤战士的血液，例如青霉素或吗啡。史密斯说：“44年在意大利是这样，91年我们发起了沙漠盾牌和沙漠风暴行动时也是这样。”他解释说，海湾战争期间，军队的便携式、辅助性或移动式外科手术装置不是便携式、辅助性或移动式的。”史密斯说：“我们对药物的改进如此之大，以至于沙特阿拉伯的每一辆轮式车辆都需要搬动一所移动的陆军外科医院。他们有便携式CT（计算机断层扫描）扫描仪，但实际上并不便于携带，用于治疗头部损伤。”。“走出沙漠，他说，大的变化是有序的。后送医院或舰队医院有多个手术室和数百张病床，搬家费用非常昂贵。史密斯估计，医疗机动性的缺乏可能将沙漠风暴的开始推迟了30到60天。“1990年夏天的伤亡预测是天文数字，”他说。“双方都将有数千人受伤或死亡。伊拉克拥有世界第五大军队，这个联盟（由与美国结盟的国家组成）在一条长长的绳子的末端。因此，人们认为这可能是一场势均力敌的战斗。现在，事实证明，伊拉克军队在纸面上很强大，但在训练上并不强大，士气也不好，他们在面对敌人时大多会翻身。”尽管如此，一些经验教训还是令人震惊。但是，其他专家也同意，挑逗他们的时间比预期的要长。“由于地面战斗造成的伤亡相对较少，特别是与预期相比，因此在医学实践中很少有创新，”艾伦・霍克说，国防卫生局国家健康和医学博物馆历史收藏品经理。“然而，波斯湾战争的重大教训是，医疗足迹太大、太麻烦，无法跟上快速移动的前线。”由于明显的后勤问题，史密斯说，1991年进行的事情“还不是理论”，而是基于20世纪80年代格林纳达和后来的巴拿马的小冲突。“在这两次[冲突]中，我们都认识到你可以更快地转移更小的医疗资产，他解释说，例如，就在海湾战争前一年，巴拿马的海豹突击队（Navy SEALs）推进了高级特种部队的医疗护理，并学会了更好地稳定病人。运输和使用液体和抗生素的新技术被开发出来。“然后他们把（伤员）放在飞机上，飞到圣安东尼奥，没有中间医院，他们活了下来，”史密斯说，史密斯说：“我们没有足够多的病人受伤到统计上的显著程度，但我们确实认识到，这一系统不会让病人很快上手术台，而那些手术台上的外科医生大部分都不是创伤外科医生。”。“一位曾在冲突中服役的军医能够认同这一说法，他是Leopoldo“Lee”Cancio博士，退休上校，现任德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥-萨姆-休斯顿联合基地美国陆军外科研究所烧伤中心主任。海湾战争期间，坎西奥是一名年轻的陆军上尉，隶属于第82空降师，仅在医学院学习了几年。史密斯说，30年前，军队面临的一个挑战是，当医生们只习惯于美国本土的医疗设施时，如何为他们的下射条件做好准备。他说，这些天来，一些同样的担忧依然存在，特别是对于后备和警卫医生、护士和医生。“我习惯于照顾受伤的人，但我习惯于在创伤中心这样做，”坎西奥说。坎西奥说：“我根本没有接受过如何将其转化为野外环境的培训。军医和文职医生的创伤培训仍然是“间歇性的”。因此，这是一个挑战。”。Hawk指出：“毫无疑问，改善和彻底改变了战伤护理（院前护理）的是战术战伤护理的概念。战术战伤护理是基于越南战争期间收集的数据和1990年代计算机分析的经验教训的应用。这导致了改进的出血控制技术的发展，供急救人员和战斗医疗人员使用。在海湾地区，坎西奥参加了一个名为“基本创伤生命支持”的课程，该课程是为平民急救医疗技术人员设计的。坎西奥说，其他院前课程和训练最终也取得了进展，但真正需要的是战术战斗伤亡护理“提供了一系列的优先事项和一系列事件，以照顾战斗伤亡人员，无论他们是在火下，还是在途中护理，这确实是我们现在教医护人员和一般医务人员、医生助理等的一切基础，作为院前环境的基础，坎西奥说，但这是战术战斗伤亡护理Cancio说：“提供了一系列的优先事项和一系列事件，以照顾战斗伤亡人员，无论他们是在火灾中，还是在途中护理，这确实是我们现在教医护人员和一般医务人员、医生助理等的一切基础。他补充说：“知道当有人受伤，你被枪杀时该怎么办真的很重要。”坎西奥说，战斗伤亡人数不同于美国车祸中的普通受害者。在和平时期，类似于因简易爆炸装置而失去一条腿或双腿的严重程度在美国是不寻常的。”战场上一个重要的早期变化是如何在院前和到达医疗单位后对患者进行复苏，为此，坎西奥指出，血液制品和输血的可用性和便携性在过去30年中有了很大的发展，特别是在战场护理方面。此外，他说，现在美国大部分的普通外科手术都是微创的，并且是通过内窥镜完成的。在战场上，你仍然必须在像腹部这样的身体部位做大切口。坎西奥说，在这一点上，额外的创伤手术培训对于军事技能至关重要。同样，严重烧伤在和平时期并不常见，但在战斗中是可以预料的――大约占伤亡人数的5%到10%。如果你将烧伤与创伤性脑损伤或截肢结合起来，你所谈论的是真正罕见的护理水平，以及护理人员的培训。下周：第2部分，这表明并非所有自海湾战争以来改善的战场救生措施都是高度技术性的。*今年夏天继续：（6月）：概述第2部分。（7月）：创伤后假肢和生活质量的进展。（8月）：3D打印是如何重新书写创伤后护理的可能。

column2: Sentry Eagle- A look back across 30 years of the exercise
column3:
KLAMATH FALLS, Ore. - Col. Steve “Slick” Harper remembers the first Sentry Eagle which took place in 1986 when he was the base commander. After seeing another guard base do an open house Harper thought it would be a good idea to host one at Kingsley Field.

Simultaneously, one of his fellow instructor pilots pointed out that the Klamath Basin provided every opportunity to host a large number of fighter aircraft because there was enough space and enough people to pull it off.

Harper quotes Capt. Jesse James, one of his instructor pilots, saying, “‘besides that, we’re all getting stale just writing out grade sheets and we want to go fight somebody.’”

Harper agreed to allow the multi aircraft exercise with the stipulation that he be able to open the front gates to the families and the community. Among his reasons, the Air National Guard’s tenure at Kingsley was very young and he felt they needed to make a name for themselves. 

“We were new, just a couple years old and we wanted to build our street cred among the fighter community,” said Harper. “We knew we were good but we needed to show everybody else ― and we did.”

He goes on to temper that just a bit saying, “We just wanted somebody to see our stuff and take it home; we weren’t really showing off on purpose.”

On that week in June, 37 aircraft convened for more than 80 separate sorties to practice Dissimilar Air Combat Training, or put another way to control the airspace in scenarios ranging from bomber sweeps to air interdiction and maybe even a dogfight or two. In those days Sentry Eagle drew a large variety of aircraft: F-106s, F-4s, A-7s, F-16s and F-15s, all of which refueled from a loitering KC-135 tanker. Today units still fly in from around the country but only F-16s, F-15s and the KC-135 are still a part of the line-up. Future plans include fifth generation fighters but it remains to be seen when they will actually participate. 

In any event, the things the inaugural exercise showcased are still true today; every participant would see that the range space is large and convenient to the base, and enjoy some of the 300-plus days of sunshine, also known as good flying weather, the area boasts every year.
