These early years for the ANG at Kingsley catalyzed a piece of culture that endures today. Col. Billy “Rogue” Cox, a former base commander, remembers how the base earned its moniker.

“An early class in the F-4 named us the Land of No Slack,” said Cox. “We were very thorough in our job, if a student had any deficiency or issue on a ride we made real sure they got a chance to do it again.” 

Visiting Airmen could take the name back to their home units and to this day every Kingsley pilot wears the orange “No-Slack” patch on their left arm.

Cox reflects back from those early years when Sentry Eagle was brand new to today where it is a fixture for the base and the community and says what began as an exercise has endeared itself to the local community and become a fixture. 

He goes on to say that as the base’s longevity increases it has added key audiences. This includes a younger generation, some of which have joined the ranks of 173rd Fighter Wing Airmen including Cox’s own son who is currently an instructor pilot at the “Land of No Slack.”  He describes Sentry Eagle as “more of a family-plus-public-plus-the training the aircrews get out of it.”

Initially Kingsley Field hosted Sentry Eagle every year but at some point it became an every-other-year affair. This time around it’s been four years as sequestration cut funding for a 2013 Sentry Eagle. 

One thing that hasn’t changed was best expressed in the lead-up to the very first Sentry Eagle in the local paper June 19, 1986, “Continual training is a requirement, even if it is a lot of fun!” said then Lt. Col. Steven “Slick” Harper.
column9: 克拉马斯瀑布，或称美国
column10: 哨兵之鹰――30年演习回顾
column11: 克拉马斯福尔斯，俄勒冈州――史蒂夫・哈珀上校“滑头”记得1986年当基地指挥官时第一只哨兵鹰。在看到另一个警卫基地进行开放式训练后，哈珀认为在金斯利球场举办一次是个好主意。同时，哈珀的一位教练飞行员同伴指出，克拉马斯盆地提供了容纳大量战斗机的一切机会，因为那里有足够的空间和足够的人来完成任务。哈珀引用他的教练飞行员之一杰西・詹姆斯上尉的话说，“‘除此之外，我们写成绩表的时候都会感到厌倦，我们想去和别人打架。’”哈珀同意允许进行多机演习，并规定他能够向家庭和社区敞开大门。他的理由之一是，空军国民警卫队在金斯利的任期非常年轻，他认为他们需要成名。“我们是新来的，才几岁，我们想在拳击手社区中建立我们的街头信誉，”哈珀说。“我们知道我们很好，但我们需要向其他人展示――我们做到了。”他接着说，“我们只是想有人看看我们的东西，把它带回家；我们并不是故意炫耀。”在6月的那一周，37架飞机分别进行了80多架次的空战训练，或者以另一种方式控制空域，从轰炸机扫荡到空中拦截，甚至可能进行一两次混战。当时，“哨兵鹰”吸引了各种各样的飞机：F-106、F-4s、a-7、F-16和F-15，所有这些飞机都是从一艘游荡的KC-135加油机上加油的。今天，部队仍然从全国各地飞过来，但只有F-16、F-15和KC-135仍然是阵容中的一部分。未来的计划包括第五代战斗机，但它们何时真正参加还有待观察。无论如何，首场演习展示了一个重要的事实We’今天仍然如此；每个参与者都会看到靶场空间很大，对基地来说很方便，并享受300多天的阳光，也被称为良好的飞行天气，该地区每年都吹嘘。金斯利的ANG的这些早年催生了一种延续至今的文化。比利上校“流氓”考克斯，一位前基地指挥官，记得这个基地是如何赢得这个称号的。考克斯说：“一个早期的F-4班把我们命名为“无懈怠之地”。我们在工作中非常认真，如果一个学生在旅途中有任何缺陷或问题，我们会确保他们有机会再次这样做。”来访的飞行员可以把这个名字带回他们的部队，直到今天，金斯利的每位飞行员都穿着橙色的“不松懈”他们左臂上的补丁。考克斯回忆起早期哨兵鹰是全新的，现在它是基地和社区的固定设备。他说，开始时作为一项运动已经受到当地社区的喜爱，并成为固定设备。他接着说，随着基地寿命的延长，它增加了关键观众is包括年轻一代，其中一些人已经加入了第173战斗机联队飞行员的行列，包括考克斯的亲生儿子，他目前是“无懈怠之地”的指导员飞行员。他将哨兵鹰描述为“更多的是一个家庭加上公众，再加上机组人员从中得到的训练。”最初，金斯利・菲尔德每年都会接待哨兵鹰，但在某种程度上，它变成了每隔一年举办一次的活动。这一次是四年前的事了，因为封存削减了2013年哨兵鹰的资金。有一件事没有改变，那就是1986年6月19日当地报纸上第一只哨兵鹰的诞生，“持续的训练是一项要求，即使它很有趣！”当时的史蒂文中校“斯里克”哈珀说。

column2: Kansas ROTC program commissions first officers in nearly 30 years
column3:
WICHITA, Kan. C Wichita State University’s Reserve Officer Training Corps program celebrated its first commissioning ceremony since 1993 on May 14. The two new officers, 2nd Lt. José Garcia and 2nd Lt. Gabriel Schrag, are now members of the Medical Service Corps, Kansas Army National Guard, and the Nurse Corps, Active Duty, respectively. 

After more than 25 years since being disbanded, the WSU ROTC program was reestablished in the fall of 2019 as the result of a collaboration between Dr. Marché Fleming-Randle, vice president of WSU, and the KSARNG. The program’s uniformed cadre and instructors are entirely staffed by the KSARNG, a unique arrangement compared to other ROTC programs, which are usually staffed by Active-Duty Army officers and noncommissioned officers. 

Maj. Eric Hollingsworth, assistant professor of military science, who was brought in by KSARNG leadership to help rebuild the program in 2019, said that since its revival WSU ROTC has been flourishing. The program has nearly 60 students enrolled currently and is looking to grow to 75 or 80 in the fall 2021 semester. 

“At first I didn’t think it was possible that we'd be able to commission two cadets in two years,” Hollingsworth said. “It was just the right time timing of how these things came together. 

“It's been a lot of work, a lot of sleepless nights,” he laughed. 

As the two most senior students in the program, Hollingsworth said Garcia and Schrag has a lot of additional responsibilities juniors and seniors in already-established programs might not have to think about. 

“We sent them to a lot of recruiting events the last couple of years and do a lot of extra stuff in the community,” said Hollingsworth, explaining that WSU ROTC has had to work diligently to get the word out about the return of the program and the opportunities once again available to students looking to pursue a military career while earning a degree from WSU.  

“These guys helped run the program the last two,” Hollingsworth said. “And to see the growth that we've had because of their leadership and support the program continues to see, it's awesome. It's exciting. I’m very proud of them and of all their hard work and effort.”

Keynote speaker for the ceremony, Brig. Gen. John Aarsen, deputy commander, 79th Theater Sustainment Command and WSU alumni, class of 1989, addressed the graduates and the audience. 

“ROTC has been a proud tradition for nearly a hundred years,” Aarsen said. “One of creating agile and adaptive leaders who have led our country and our Army from the battlefields of World War I to the far corners of the world today. You will travel a path that many others have traveled ahead of you; ROTC has commissioned over seven hundred thousand lieutenants. It's a well-worn path, but you get to define where it goes for you.

“It is the strength of our Army is that you are judged by your accomplishments,” Aarsen said. “Your heart and your head - they are what will define you and move your career.”

Garcia hails from Hutchinson and has been a member of the KSARNG for 6 years and was the KSARNG Soldier of the Year in 2014. He earned his degree in communication science and disorders, maintained a GPA of 3.9 and was recognized as a distinguished military graduate, finishing in the top 10 percent of cadets in the 2021 commissioning class nation-wide. He will begin his doctors of audiology program this summer through Wichita State.

Schrag hails from Newton. He earned his degree in nursing, maintaining a GPA of 3.8, and will attend the basic officer leadership course at Fort Sam Houston in San Antonio before embarking on his Active-Duty career. 

“I can't begin to say how proud all the leadership at Wichita State is,” Hollingsworth said. “Both of you and of this program and its future success.”
column9: 威奇托，KS，美国
column10: 堪萨斯州后备军官训练团计划在近30年中委任了第一批军官
column11: 堪萨斯州威奇托威奇托州立大学预备役军官训练团项目于5月14日举行了自1993年以来的首次启用仪式。两名新军官，第二中尉JoséGarcia和第二中尉Gabriel Schrag，现在分别是堪萨斯州陆军国民警卫队医疗服务团和现役护士团的成员。在解散25年多之后，由于WSU副校长马奇・弗莱明・兰德尔博士与KSARNG的合作，WSU ROTC计划于2019年秋天重新建立。该计划的军装干部和教员全部由KSARNG配备，这是一种独特的安排，与其他ROTC计划相比，后者通常由现役军官和士官配备。军事科学助理教授埃里克・霍林斯沃思少校（Maj.Eric Hollingsworth）在2019年被克萨恩领导层请来帮助重建该项目。他说，自该项目恢复以来，WSU后备军官训练团一直蓬勃发展。该项目目前招收了近60名学生，预计在2021年秋季学期将增至75或80名。霍林斯沃思说：“起初，我认为我们不可能在两年内任命两名学员。”。“这正是这些东西结合在一起的正确时机。”这是一项艰巨的工作，许多不眠之夜他笑了。霍林斯沃思说，加西亚和施拉格是该项目中两个最高年级的学生，他们在已经建立的项目中可能不需要考虑很多额外的责任。他说：“过去几年，我们让他们参加了很多招聘活动，在社区中做了很多额外的事情。”霍林斯沃思说，他解释说，WSU后备军官训练团必须努力工作，让外界知道该计划的回归，以及希望在获得WSU学位的同时从事军事生涯的学生再次获得机会。霍林斯沃思说：“在过去两个月里，这些人帮助管理了该计划。”。“看到他们的领导和对项目的支持使我们取得了持续的增长，这太棒了。这太令人兴奋了。我为他们以及他们所有的辛勤工作和努力感到骄傲。”典礼主旨演讲人、第79战区维持司令部副指挥官兼1989届WSU校友约翰・奥尔森准将向毕业生和观众致辞。“ROTC是近百年来引以为傲的传统，”奥尔森说。“他是一位创造敏捷、适应性强的领导者，带领我们的国家和军队从第一次世界大战的战场走向当今世界的遥远角落。你将走一条许多其他人都走在你前面的道路；后备军官训练团已经委任了超过70万名中尉。这是一条老生常谈的道路，但你需要定义它的走向对你来说。“我们军队的力量在于你的成就，”Aarsen说，“你的心和你的头脑――它们将决定你的命运，推动你的事业。”加西亚来自哈钦森，6年来一直是KSARNG的成员，2014年成为KSARNG年度最佳士兵。他获得了通信科学和疾病的学位，GPA保持在3.9，被公认为杰出的军事毕业生，在2021年全国-w委托班学员中名列前10%ide。今年夏天，他将通过威奇托州开始他的听力学博士课程。施拉格来自牛顿。他获得了护理学位，GPA保持在3.8，并将参加圣安东尼奥山姆休斯顿堡的基本军官领导力课程，然后开始他的现役生涯。霍林斯沃思说：“我不能说威奇托州立大学的所有领导层有多自豪。你们和这个项目以及它未来的成功都让我感到自豪。”

column2: Morgan’s Men recognize 30 years since start of Gulf War
column3:
The Gulf War officially began 30 years ago. On Aug. 2, 1990, the Iraq Army had taken over Kuwait, and President George H. W. Bush sent troops to Saudi Arabia to support Operation Desert Shield. 

Missions during Desert Shield included defense and preparation operations within Saudi Arabia leading to the culminating combat phase, codenamed Operation Desert Storm, which signified actively pushing the Iraq Army out of Kuwait to protect the surrounding region.

Coalition forces ceased fire on Feb. 28, 1991, thus ending the Gulf War.

The 1st Battalion, 623rd Field Artillery, also known as Morgan’s Men, deployed in December 1990, after pre-mobilization training at Fort Campbell, Ky. They returned in June 1991.

Soldiers in the unit recall their deployment to the Persian Gulf as a successful team effort, with shared goals to accomplish the mission, care for each other, and return home safely.
“I took an absolutely fearless group of Soldiers to war,” said then Capt. Rondal L. Turner, commander of Charlie Battery through the deployment. “The things they accomplished were incredible, and the thing I am most proud of is that I brought every person I left with back home.”

The 1-623d is an artillery battalion and has activated into federal service for the Korean War, Desert Shield and Desert Storm, and Operation Enduring Freedom.

“The field artillery’s job is to destroy, neutralize or suppress the enemy by cannon, rocket and missile firers and to integrate all fires into the combined arms operation,” Turner continued.
Turner stayed actively involved and served as chief of staff for the KYNG prior to his retirement at the rank of colonel. His unit’s accomplishment reflects his hard work and dedication to his men and this country.

“I spent my career always trying to make the Guard a better organization, and I lead some of the best Soldiers on Earth during my 29 years in the Guard,” said Turner.
The early 1990s deployment to the Middle East required training and readiness from Soldiers of all ranks. Soldiers from the 1-623d were prepared to take on the difficult mission they faced.

“I feel like there were no problems at all,” said Staff Sgt. Edward Donahue, supply sergeant for Headquarters and Headquarters Battery, 2nd Battalion, 138th Field Artillery. “I feel like it was a good mission, and we completed our tasks with no issues.”

At the time of the deployment, Donahue was a cannon crew member on a M110A2 Self-Propelled Howitzer team assigned to Charlie Battery. The unit promoted him to sergeant shortly after returning home from Desert Storm.

1st Sgt. Joe Fair and Soldiers of the Kentucky National Guard’s Bravo Battery, 1st Battalion, 623rd Field Artillery provide food to Iraqi Army prisoners of war while deployed to the Persian Gulf for Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm from Jan-April 1991 (Kentucky National Guard historical photo)

Donahue claims the deployment helped him mature as a Soldier and as a person.

“As a young soldier who hasn’t deployed―or ever been around others who deployed―you are not really paying a lot of attention to training; you are just, kind of, checking the blocks,” said Donahue. “I think once this reality hits you, you will pay attention. That deployment eventually taught me the self-discipline I needed to survive and build myself a long-lasting career.”

The 30 year anniversary of the deployment represents something different for each Soldier who deployed.

“For me, it is a time to remember and honor all who served,” said the retired 1st Sgt. Joseph E. Fair, who deployed with Bravo Battery during the conflict. “Especially, it belongs to those killed in action. It also serves as a reminder of the importance of service to our great nation.”

Fair said that he feels blessed to have been a part of something so important in history.

“As a combat veteran of both Vietnam and the Gulf War, I realize Soldiers train to fight to maintain peace but don’t yearn for war,” said Fair. “Both wars were my booster shot for helping me to realize America is the greatest place in the world and living here is such an honor.”

Revisiting moments of the past allowed these Veterans to reflect on what they learned.

Capt. Joseph “Lonnie” Culver, battalion executive officer, stands with his Humvee while on maneuvers in Iraq, early 1991. Culver and Soldiers of the Kentucky Army National Guard’s 1st Battalion, 623rd Field Artillery deployed to the Persian Gulf for Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm from Jan-April 1991 (Kentucky National Guard historical photo)
Retired Maj. Gen. Joseph “Lonnie” Culver served as battalion personnel officer during their mobilization. He later served as battalion executive commander once the 1-623d arrived in Saudi Arabia.

“The lessons learned stuck with me,” said Culver. “Each Soldier needs to be technically and tactically proficient in their position, the right person should be selected for the right job, training opportunities should be provided so they know and understand their jobs, and excellence should be demanded in their performance.”
Culver spoke highly of the group of Soldiers he deployed with.

“The 30th anniversary is a time to celebrate the accomplishments of one of the finest groups of men―and some of the best-trained Soldiers―I served with throughout my career,” said Culver.

John Wayne Smith, also a retired colonel and former chief of staff for the KYNG, commanded the battalion as a major. Typically, the battalion command assignment is reserved for a higher rank. However, Maj. Smith’s battalion outperformed the other National Guard combat arms battalions.

Maj. John Wayne Smith, battalion commander of 1st Battalion, 623rd Field Artillery, meets with leaders of the 196th Field Artillery Brigade in Iraq, early 1991. Smith and his Soldiers from the Kentucky Army National Guard deployed in support of Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm from Jan-April 1991 (Kentucky National Guard historical photo)

“In honor of our status in the only combat arms brigade and one of the four combat arms battalions, we were asked to lead the National Guard contingent in the victory parade in Washington, D.C., and the ticker-tape parade in New York City,” Smith said. “I was honored to be in the center of the photo on the back of a book recounting the story of the National Guard in Desert Storm.”

The actions and efforts of Morgan’s Men of 1-623d never went unnoticed during the Gulf War. Today, we remember and honor them. Their commitment and dedication to our nation reflect greatly on the professionalism of these Soldiers, their Leaders, and, overall, the Kentucky National Guard.
column9: 美国肯塔基州诺克斯堡
column10: 摩根的手下承认海湾战争爆发已经30年了
column11: 海湾战争正式开始于30年前。1990年8月2日，伊拉克军队占领了科威特，乔治・H・W・布什总统派遣军队前往沙特阿拉伯支持“沙漠盾牌”行动。沙漠盾牌期间的任务包括在沙特阿拉伯境内进行防御和准备行动，最终进入战斗阶段，代号为“沙漠风暴行动”，这意味着积极将伊拉克军队赶出科威特，以保护周围地区。联军于1991年2月28日停止开火，从而结束了海湾战争。第一营，623野战炮兵，也称为摩根的人，在肯塔基州坎贝尔堡进行动员前训练后于1990年12月部署。他们于1991年6月返回。部队中的士兵回忆起他们在波斯湾的部署是一次成功的团队努力，他们有共同的目标来完成任务，互相关照，安全回家。“我带了一群毫无畏惧的士兵去打仗，”当时的上校Rondal L.Turner说，他是查理炮台的指挥官。“他们所取得的成就令人难以置信，我最自豪的是，我把所有随行人员都带回了家。”1-623d是一个炮兵营，已经为朝鲜战争、沙漠盾牌和沙漠风暴以及“持久自由行动”服役。“野战炮兵的任务是用大炮、火箭和导弹火力摧毁、压制或压制敌人，并将所有火力整合到联合兵种作战中。”特纳继续说道。特纳继续积极参与，并在退役上校军衔前担任KYNG的参谋长。他的部队的成就反映了他对士兵和国家的辛勤工作和献身精神。“我的职业生涯一直在努力使卫兵成为一个更好的组织，在我29年的卫兵生涯中，我领导着一些世界上最好的士兵。”特纳说。20世纪90年代初部署到中东需要各级士兵的训练和准备。1-623d的士兵已经准备好承担他们面临的艰巨任务。“我觉得根本没有问题，”第138野战炮兵第二营指挥部和指挥部连的补给中士爱德华・多纳休上士说，“我觉得这是一次很好的任务，我们顺利完成了任务。”部署时，多纳休是分配给查理炮台的M110A2自行榴弹炮小组的一名炮兵队员。该部队在从沙漠风暴中返回后不久将他提升为中士。第一中士乔・费尔和肯塔基州国民警卫队布拉沃炮台第一营第623野战炮兵的士兵为他提供食物1991年1月至4月，伊拉克军队战俘被部署到波斯湾执行沙漠盾牌和沙漠风暴行动（肯塔基州国民警卫队历史照片）。多纳休声称，这次部署帮助他成长为一名士兵和一个人。多纳休说：“作为一名年轻的士兵，你没有部署过部队，也没有和其他部署过部队的士兵在一起，你并没有真正把注意力放在训练上；你只是在检查障碍。”。“我认为，一旦这个现实击中你，你会注意到的。那次部署最终教会了我生存所需的自律，并为自己建立了一个持久的职业生涯。”部署30周年纪念对每个部署的士兵来说都是不同的。“对我来说，这是一个纪念和纪念所有服役士兵的时刻。”退役的第一中士约瑟夫・费尔（Joseph E.Fair）在冲突期间随同布拉沃炮台（Bravo Battery）一起部署。费尔说：“特别是，它属于在战斗中阵亡的人。它也提醒我们为我们伟大的国家服务的重要性。”费尔说，他感到很幸运，能够成为历史上如此重要的一部分。费尔说：“作为一名越战和海湾战争的老兵，我意识到士兵们训练是为了维护和平，但并不渴望战争。这两次战争都是我的助推器，帮助我认识到美国是世界上最伟大的地方，生活在这里是一种荣誉。”重温过去的时刻让这些退伍军人反思他们所学到的东西。约瑟夫上尉“朗尼”1991年初，在伊拉克进行军事演习时，营执行官卡尔弗手持悍马站在那里。卡尔弗和肯塔基州国民警卫队第1营第623野战炮兵的士兵从1991年1月至4月部署到波斯湾进行沙漠盾牌和沙漠风暴行动（肯塔基州国民警卫队历史照片）退役少将约瑟夫・卡尔弗（Joseph“Lonnie”Culver）在动员期间担任营人事官。他后来在1-623d飞机抵达沙特阿拉伯后担任营执行指挥官。卡尔弗说：“我从中吸取了教训。”。“每个士兵都需要在技术和战术上精通自己的岗位，应该为正确的工作选择合适的人，应该提供培训机会，让他们了解和理解自己的工作，并且在他们的表现中应该要求优秀。”卡尔弗高度评价了与他一起部署的士兵团队。“30周年纪念日是庆祝一批最优秀的人和一些训练有素的士兵取得成就的日子――我在整个职业生涯中与他们一起服役。”卡尔弗说。约翰・韦恩・史密斯（John Wayne Smith）也是一名退役上校，曾担任KYNG的参谋长，作为少校指挥该营。通常情况下，该营的指挥任务是为更高的军衔保留的。然而，史密斯少校的营表现优于其他国民警卫队战斗武器营。约翰・韦恩・史密斯少校，第1营指挥官1991年初，第623野战炮兵营会见了伊拉克第196野战炮兵旅的领导人。史密斯和他的肯塔基州国民警卫队士兵从1991年1月至4月部署，支持沙漠盾牌和沙漠风暴行动（肯塔基州国民警卫队历史照片）史密斯说：“为了纪念我们在唯一的战斗武器旅和四个战斗武器营中的地位，我们被要求率领国民警卫队特遣队参加华盛顿特区的胜利阅兵和纽约市的阅兵。”。“我很荣幸能站在一本书背面照片的中间，这本书讲述了沙漠风暴中国民警卫队的故事。”在海湾战争期间，摩根的1-623d士兵的行动和努力从未被忽视。今天，我们纪念并尊敬他们。他们对我们国家的承诺和奉献精神极大地反映了这些士兵、他们的领导人以及肯塔基州国民警卫队的专业精神。

column2: Three Packs to 30 Miles- Sgt. 1st Class Robert Reeves
column3:
ATLANTA ― Sgt. 1st Class Robert Reeves smoked his first cigarette at age six and didn't put them down until he was 38. By the time he quit, the Alabamian was smoking three packs a day and couldn't walk to his mailbox without getting winded. 

Then a recruiter knocked on his door.

Reeves, the son of a Green Beret, enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1983 and got out after three years. Nearly two decades later, his then-wife called a recruiter after her son entered the Army. Her reasoning, she didn't want her son to join alone.

Reeves thinking the recruiter was coming for his stepson, told him that the young man had already shipped to basic training. He found out that the recruiter was there to talk to him about joining the Army Reserve. 

After 18 years out of uniform, Reeves joined in the winter of 2004. He attended his first battle assembly in Huntsville, Alabama. Per usual, he chain-smoked four cigarettes before entering the gates of the reserve center. 

His new commander watching Reeves light one cigarette after another took note. 

"My battalion commander wanted to get rid of me," Reeves said. "He said, 'I don't want that guy in my unit. That guy is a train!'"

The train's habit led his commander to think he couldn't pass the Army Physical Fitness Test, and he made Reeve's an offer. 

Pass the PT test and get promoted, or fail, and get the boot.

"Right beside the promotion paperwork was a counseling statement to start to kick me out," Reeves said. "The battalion commander gave it to the S1, and the S1 said he would give me a PT test the next day." 

Early the next morning, Reeves set out to take the APFT. He stepped into 20-degree weather and frost on the ground. "It was freezing. My lungs were full of tar," he said. 

Reeves passed the pushup and situp events with ease but said he was winded and waited the full ten minutes before attempting the run. The test administrator told Reeves, "It's gonna suck if you have to grind up your promotion paperwork." 

Determined not to get kicked out, Reeves went full throttle. 

"I had four laps," he said. "I forced my pace and got to where I just couldn't breathe. I got down to the third lap, and I was sweating blood. I had blood coming out of my mouth. It was bad."

On his final lap, Reeves said he felt himself slipping into darkness. 

"The walls were closing in," he said. "The guy yells, 'He's gonna grind up your promotion!' I got to the finish line, and everything was starting to go, I was going sideways. I fell over the line. The last thing I heard was 'he passed.'"

 Reeves quit smoking Christmas Day 2004.

"I said a little prayer. I can put it down for one day, I'll give it to you for your birthday, and God you gotta take it from there. I never picked them up since," he said. 

Fast forward 16 years and Reeves, who turned 54 in May, is running ultramarathons. He's run three 50K races and also a Half Ironman Triathlon under his belt. He was training for a 100-mile race before getting notified for deployment to southwest Asia. 

"This year, I was trying to do a 100 mile run by October, but I'm deploying," he said. "I'm going to continue running while I'm over there. I'm not going to do extreme because of the heat, but as soon as I return, I'm going to pick it back up." 

Reeves, who is from Gadsden, Alabama, serves as the operations and training NCO with the 335th Signal Command (Theater), Headquarters, and Headquarters Company outside of Atlanta. He joined the Army Reserve's Active Guard Reserve program after losing his civilian retirement during the Great Recession and continues to serve because of the camaraderie and diversity.

"I think diversity is one of the best things I've found in the military. I've met a lot of different people. Some of the best people have not been like me," he said. "People that I trust my life with have not been or looked like me. It may shock you at first, but it gives you more hope about the world in general. It's not just your corner of the world that's going to matter."
column9: 亚特兰大，佐治亚州，美国
column10: 三包30英里-罗伯特・里维斯上士一等舱
column11: 亚特兰大――罗伯特・里夫斯上士六岁时抽了第一支烟，直到38岁才放下。当他戒烟时，阿拉巴马人已经每天抽三包烟了，走到邮箱前都会喘不过气来。接着，一名征兵员敲了敲他的门。里维斯是一名绿色贝雷帽的儿子，1983年应征入伍，三年后退伍。将近二十年后，他当时的妻子在儿子参军后给一名征兵员打电话。根据她的推理，她不想让儿子单独加入。里夫斯认为招聘人员是来找他的继子的，告诉他，这个年轻人已经接受了基础训练。他发现征兵员是来跟他谈加入预备役部队的事的。在脱掉制服18年后，里夫斯于2004年冬天加入。他参加了在阿拉巴马州亨茨维尔举行的第一次战斗集会。像往常一样，他在进入预备中心大门前连续抽了四支烟。他的新指挥官看着里夫斯一支接一支地点着烟，注意到了这一点。“我的营长想除掉我，”里夫斯说。“他说，‘我不想那个家伙进入我的部队。那个家伙是火车！’”火车的习惯让他的指挥官认为他不能通过陆军体能测试，于是他向里夫提出了一个条件。里夫斯说：“通过PT考试就可以升职，或者不及格就可以被解雇。升职文件旁边有一份咨询声明，打算把我踢出去。”。“营长把它交给了S1，S1说他第二天会给我一次PT测试。”第二天一早，里夫斯出发去参加APFT。他踩进了20度的天气，地面上结了霜。“天气很冷。我的肺里充满了焦油，”他说。里夫斯轻松地通过了俯卧撑和仰卧起坐项目，但他说，在尝试跑步之前，他已经喘不过气来，等了整整十分钟。测试管理员告诉里夫斯，“如果你必须认真处理你的晋升文件，那就糟透了。”里夫斯决定不被开除，全力以赴。“我跑了四圈，”他说。在最后一圈，里夫斯说他感觉自己滑入了黑暗之中。他说：“墙越来越近了。”。“那家伙喊道，‘他会让你升职的！’我到了终点线，一切都开始走了，我在侧身。我从终点线摔了下来。我最后听到的是‘他通过了’。”里夫斯在2004年圣诞节戒烟。“我做了一个小小的祈祷。我可以把它放下来一天，我会在你生日的时候送给你，上帝啊，你必须从那里拿走它。“从那以后，我就再也没有学过，”他说。快进16年，5月年满54岁的里夫斯正在跑超级马拉松。他参加过3次50公里赛跑，还参加过一次半铁人三项全能。在接到通知部署到西南亚之前，他正在训练100英里赛跑。“今年，我试图在10月之前完成100英里赛跑，“但我正在部署，”他说，“我将在那里继续跑步。”。由于天气炎热，我不打算做极端运动，但我一回来，就要把它捡起来。”里夫斯来自阿拉巴马州的加兹登，是第335信号司令部（战区）的作战和训练士官他在大萧条期间失去了平民退休后加入了陆军预备队的现役警卫预备队计划，并继续服役，因为他的同志情谊和多样性。“我认为多样性是我在军队中发现的最好的东西之一。我见过很多不同的人。“一些最优秀的人并不像我，”他说，“那些我信任我的人并不像我，也不像我。一开始它可能会让你震惊，但它让你对整个世界充满了希望。重要的不仅仅是你的世界一角。”

column2: MARADMIN 285/30 details permanent change of station tier system
column3:
While adapting to the current Department of Defense-wide Stop Movement Order in response to COVID-19, the Marine Corps addresses the latest guidance regarding Permanent Change of Station (PCS) in MARADMIN 285/20. This guidance outlines the actions of the HQMC, Manpower Management Division and Reserve Affairs Management that will affect the permanent change of station (PCS) orders for the remainder of 2020.
 
MARADMIN 285/20 explains the tier system that will be followed beginning July 1, 2020. The tier system is a framework that ensures Marines arrive at their specific units to meet prioritized mission requirements. 

“The ‘Tiers’ are a decision support tool for M&RA, and there will be exceptions made on individual Marine cases,” states the order.

"As stop move comes to an end, the Marine Corps will execute PCS moves in a phased approach by tier as indicated in the MarAdmin," said MGySgt Bryant Lodge, career planner for I Marine Expeditionary Force. "As orders are issued Marines must take the necessary steps to execute orders.  This includes checking MOL for orders/modifications, contacting DMO, and enlisted Marines ensuring they have the required obligated service to execute orders."

Tier 1 is scheduled for July-August 2020 and will focus on PCS moves that contribute to force generation actions. For example, aboard Camp Pendleton, this will include Marines inbound as instructors to Staff Noncommissioned Officer Academy.

Tier 2 is scheduled for August-September 2020 and focuses on orders that contribute to institutional priorities, which includes but is not limited to those Marines that are inbound to and from an accompanied overseas assignment. 

As for Tier 3, which is scheduled for September-November 2020, Marines whose moves will contribute to readiness generation will be eligible.

“The Service retains operational capability while prioritizing PCS moves between July-November 2020 to accommodate the expected insufficient transportation industry capacity.”

Manpower Management will maximize the use of Permanent Change of Assignment (PCA) and Low-Cost Permanent Change of Station (LCPCS) orders to mitigate the expected shortfalls in the United States Transportation Command/ Distribution Management Office.  PCA and LCPCS orders are exempt from the tier system and will be executed with in the timeline directed on their orders. 

Before June 30, 2020, a movement request can be completed with an Exception to Policy (ETP.) This can be granted for orders that are determined as mission essential, necessary for humanitarian reasons, or warranted due to extreme hardship. Marines granted an ETP may not take leave in conjunction with their PCS if their order coincides with the Stop Move.

As the Marine Corps continues to adapt its policies in response to COVID-19, MARADMINS will be a vital source of information for Marine Corps-wide updates. For more information regarding MARADMIN 285/20, please visit: https://www.marines.mil/News/Messages/Messages-Display/Article/2183862/supplemental-guidance-to-permanent-change-of-station-assignments-due-to-2019/
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州彭德尔顿营地
column10: MARADMIN 285/30详细说明车站层级系统的永久变更
column11: 海军陆战队在适应当前国防部针对新冠病毒-19的全停移命令的同时，针对MARADMIN 285/20中关于永久性换站（PCS）的最新指南进行了阐述。本指南概述了总部质量管理委员会、人力资源管理部和预备役事务管理部的行动，这些行动将影响2020年剩余时间内的电站（PCS）永久变更订单。MARADMIN 285/20解释了自2020年7月1日起将遵循的层级系统。分层系统是一个框架，可确保海军陆战队到达其特定部队，以满足优先任务需求。“分层”是M&RA的决策支持工具，个别海军陆战队案例也会有例外，”该命令称，“随着停止行动的结束，海军陆战队将按照MarAdmin中的指示，分阶段执行PCS行动，”I海军陆战队远征军职业规划师MGySgt Bryant Lodge说。“在发布命令时，海军陆战队必须采取必要的步骤执行命令。这包括检查MOL是否有命令/修改，联系DMO，以及应征海军陆战队确保他们有执行命令所需的义务服务。”第1级计划于2020年7月至8月，重点关注有助于部队生成行动的个人计算机移动。例如，在彭德尔顿营地，这将包括作为参谋士官学院讲师入境的海军陆战队。第二级计划于2020年8月至9月，重点关注有助于机构优先事项的订单，其中包括但不限于随同海外派遣入境或离开的海军陆战队。至于计划于2020年9月至11月进行的第3级，其行动将有助于准备就绪生成的海军陆战队将有资格。“该服务保留作战能力，同时优先考虑2020年7月至11月期间的PCS行动，以适应预期的运输业能力不足。”人力资源管理将最大限度地利用永久性任务变更（PCA）和低成本永久性车站变更（LCPCS）订单，以缓解美国运输指挥部/配送管理办公室的预期不足。PCA和LCPCS订单不受tier系统的约束，并将按照其订单上指示的时间表执行。在2020年6月30日之前，可以完成移动请求，但政策（ETP）除外。对于被确定为任务关键、出于人道主义原因必要或由于极端困难而需要的订单，可以批准移动请求。如果获得ETP的海军陆战队士兵的订单与停止行动一致，则他们不得与个人电脑一起休假。随着海军陆战队继续调整其政策以应对新冠疫情，MARADMINS将成为海军陆战队范围内更新的重要信息来源。有关MARADMIN 285/20的更多信息，请访问：https://www.marines.mil/News/Messages/Messages-Display/Article/2183862/supplemental-guidance-to-permanent-change-of-station-assignments-due-to-2019/

column2: The ACV Through an AAV Crewman’s Eyes
column3:
MARINE CORPS AIR GROUND COMBAT CENTER TWENTYNINE PALMS, Calif. (April 5, 2021) -- “Being an ACV crewman is at the root of what the Marine Corps is,” Lance Cpl. Gaven Sack said. “It encompasses a lot of things, on land and in the water.”
Sack, an Assault Amphibious Vehicle (AAV) crewmember with Co. D, 3rd Assault Amphibian Battalion, 1st Marine Division, is part of the only military unit that has tested and fielded the new Amphibious Combat Vehicle (ACV) to date.
The ACV is an eight-wheel drive, armored vehicle with open-ocean amphibious capabilities and land mobility. It’s a unique combination of previously fielded amphibious vehicles and new technological advances to the fleet’s amphibious capabilities.
For Sack, the desire to operate the ACV began before he joined the Marine Corps. “I worked in concrete before I joined and I talked to one of the truck drivers at a job site I was on, who was formerly a Marine. I told him I was working on joining and he told me he was an 1833 tracker [AAV crewmember].” After that conversation, Sack said being a tracker interested him. AAV crewmen are nicknamed ‘trackers’ due to the first iterations of these vehicles, developed around 1935, having tracks instead of the wheels they have today.
“I’m from Grand Rapids, Minnesota, born and raised,” he said. “You know, as a kid I played army and always dreamed of being in the military … I never thought I would get to be a part of something this big.”
Marines with Co. D were the first to get their hands on a prototype of this vehicle. The senior members of this unit were able to use the knowledge they gained from years of operating AAVs to provide feedback so the ACVs could better fit the needs of the Marine Corps.
While he was in training for his job, Sack got to see the ACVs as they were in the testing phase. According to Sack, he learned how to be an effective crew member in an AAV and did not get to experience the ACV until November 2020, when he was trained by other Marines in Co. D on how to operate the vehicles properly.
“The last few exercises I have done with these vehicles have really proven to me how effective they really are,” Sack explained. “They’re lethal, they’re fast, they’re armored, they’re easily camouflaged and they are just, all around, a great vehicle.”
The vehicle itself has aided in the interaction between the crewmembers and the Marines they transport, Sack said. 
“Honestly, I think these benefit not only the track crews that operate them, but also all the Marines we transport by providing comfort, security and a lot of armor,” he expressed while he relaxed in one of the rear seats of the ACV. “I haven’t had a single unit of Marines get on and off this vehicle with any complaints. I think that so far, from what I have seen, the infantry units have done a great job of learning the vehicle, its capabilities and employing the vehicles to best support them.”
“I am excited to see these vehicles get fielded throughout the rest of the Marine Corps. I think it will benefit the Marine Corps overall in a big way,” Sack said.
column6: MARINE CORPS AIR GROUND COMBAT CENTERTWENTYNINE PALMS, CA, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州二十九棕榈岛海军陆战队空地作战中心
column10: 通过AAV机组人员的眼睛检查ACV
column11: 海军陆战队空地作战中心加利福尼亚州二十九棕榈岛（2021年4月5日）――“作为一名ACV机组人员是海军陆战队的根本，”兰斯・加文・萨克下士说。“它包括很多东西，在陆地上和水中。”萨克是海军陆战队第一师第三突击两栖营的一名突击两栖车（AAV）乘员，是迄今为止唯一一支测试和部署新型两栖战车（ACV）的军事部队的一员。ACV是一种八轮驱动，具有远洋两栖能力和陆地机动能力的装甲车辆。这是以前部署的两栖车辆和舰队两栖能力的新技术进步的独特结合。对于萨克来说，在他加入海军陆战队之前，就开始渴望操作ACV。“在我加入之前，我在混凝土行业工作，我和我所在工作现场的一名卡车司机交谈，他以前是一名海军陆战队。我告诉他我正在加入，他告诉我他是1833年的追踪者[AAV机组成员]。”在那次谈话之后，萨克说，作为一名追踪者，他很感兴趣。AAV机组人员被昵称为“追踪器”，这是因为这些车辆在1935年左右开发的第一代，使用的是履带而不是现在的车轮。“我来自明尼苏达州的大急流城，出生和长大，”他说。“你知道，当我还是个孩子的时候，我就在军队里打球，一直梦想着在军队里……我从没想过我会成为这么大事业的一部分。”Co.D公司的海军陆战队是第一个得到这辆车原型的人。该部队的高级成员能够利用他们从多年操作AAV中获得的知识提供反馈，从而使ACV能够更好地满足海军陆战队的需要。当Sack正在为工作进行培训时，Sack看到了处于测试阶段的ACV。据萨克说，他学会了如何在AAV上成为一名高效的乘员，直到2020年11月，他才体验到ACV，当时他在Co.D接受了其他海军陆战队关于如何正确操作车辆的培训。“我对这些车辆所做的最后几次练习向我证明了它们是多么有效。”萨克解释道。萨克说：“它们是致命的，速度快，有装甲，很容易伪装，而且到处都是一辆很棒的车。”这辆车本身有助于他们运送的船员和海军陆战队之间的互动。“老实说，我认为这些不仅有利于操作它们的轨道工作人员，也有利于我们运输的所有陆战队员，因为它们提供了舒适、安全和大量的装甲，”他在ACV的一个后座上放松时表示。“我没有任何一支海军陆战队士兵带着任何抱怨上下这辆车。我认为，到目前为止，从我所看到的情况来看，步兵部队在学习这辆车、它的能力以及使用这些车来最好地支持他们方面做了大量工作。”萨克说：“我很高兴看到这些车辆在海军陆战队的其他部队中得到部署。我认为这将对海军陆战队整体带来巨大的好处。”。

column2: Marines test new ACV’s ability to integrate with naval shipping
column3:
U.S. Marines with Amphibious Vehicle Test Branch, Marine Corps Tactical Systems Support Activity, with the assistance from the amphibious transport dock ship USS Somerset (LPD 25), tested the Marine Corps’ new Amphibious Combat Vehicle off the shore of Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton, California, Jan. 27-28.

The testing was the first time Marines have taken the ACV on and off of a naval vessel through the well deck, assessing and verifying the vehicle’s ability to integrate with naval shipping.  

 “AVTB has been conducting testing with the ACV for approximately three years,” said U.S. Marine Maj. Justin Davis, the deputy director of AVTB. “As we look to replace the legacy platform (Amphibious Assault Vehicle), it goes without saying the ACV needs to do exactly what the AAV does.” 

The multi-day test consisted of embarking and debarking the naval vessel and multiple on-ship operations. The Marines conducted the embarking and debarking operations while the ship was moving at various speeds and with the ACV’s configured at different weights. While inside the ship, the Marines tested the ACV’s towing, pushing and pulling capabilities. 

“It's good to see these changes happening within the amphibious community,” said  Sgt. Nicholas Vickers, a vehicle commander with AVTB. “We are setting the standard operating procedures for these vehicles so when they hit the Fleet Marine Force, there is a smooth transition.”

The ACV has proven in its testing to bring enhanced lethality, survivability and maneuverability compared to the AAV. The AVTB’s role in testing the ACVs in their developmental stage is essential to pass on to the operating forces for when it is fielded. Performing successful ship to shore operations takes the ACV one step closer to securing a spot in Marine Corps history.
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州彭德尔顿营地
column10: 海军陆战队测试新型ACV与海军舰船集成的能力
column11: 美国海军陆战队两栖车辆测试分队，海军陆战队战术系统支持活动部，在两栖运输码头舰USS Somerset（LPD 25）的协助下，在加利福尼亚州海军陆战队彭德尔顿大本营海岸外测试了海军陆战队的新型两栖作战车辆，1月27日至28日。该测试是海军陆战队首次通过钻井甲板将ACV从海军舰艇上取下，评估和验证该车辆与海军舰船集成的能力。AVTB副主任、美国海军陆战队少校贾斯汀・戴维斯（Justin Davis）说：“AVTB已经用ACV进行了大约三年的测试。“在我们寻求更换传统平台（两栖攻击车）时，不用说ACV需要做AAV所做的事情。”多日测试包括登上和卸下军舰以及多个船上操作。海军陆战队在船舶以不同速度移动时进行登船和卸货操作，ACV配置为不同重量。在船内，海军陆战队测试了ACV的牵引、推拉能力。AVTB的车辆指挥官尼古拉斯・维克斯中士说：“很高兴看到这些变化在两栖动物社区内发生。”。“我们正在为这些车辆制定标准操作程序，以便当它们撞上舰队海军时，平稳过渡。”ACV在其测试中证明，与AAV相比，其杀伤力、生存能力和机动性都得到了增强。AVTB在ACV开发阶段测试中的作用对于将其部署到作战部队至关重要。执行成功的船对岸作战使ACV距离确保海军陆战队历史上的地位又近了一步。

column2: Marine Corps Systems Command awards contract to produce ACV
column3:
Marine Corps Systems Command awarded a contract to produce Amphibious Combat Vehicles―a much-needed modernization to the Marine Corps’ ground combat element.

Following a successful Milestone C decision by the Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Research, Development, and Acquisition, the contract options worth $198 million will allow BAE Systems to build 30 low rate production vehicles, which will start delivering in the fall of next year. These vehicles will begin the transition of a portion of the Assault Amphibious Vehicle fleet.

The Assault Amphibious Vehicle has been in service for more than 40 years, and many of its components and parts are obsolete and no longer manufactured. Because of this, the vehicles are becoming increasingly costly and difficult to maintain. That, and the changing environment in which Marines find themselves plagued by the improvised explosive device threat, has produced a need for a new, more survivable combat vehicle that can maneuver from ship to shore and beyond.  

“In order to be a step ahead of our adversaries in the future, the Marine Corps needed to find a modern vehicle at an affordable price range that provided significant capability enhancement and performance over the AAV,” said Col. Kirk Mullins, ACV 1.1 product manager in Program Manager Advanced Amphibious Assault in the Program Executive Officer Land Systems.

The ACV is an eight-wheeled vehicle that will provide protection akin to the Mine-Resistant Ambush Protected Vehicle, with landward maneuverability and mobility that is superior to that of the AAV. It will be outfitted with a precision weapons station for enhanced lethality, and a robust swim capability, allowing it to operate within the littorals and beyond.

“The ACV provides a mobile capability that mechanizes the force to maintain tempo with the remainder of the [Marine Air-Ground Task Force]; specifically the M1A1 tank,” said Mullins. “It isn’t maintenance intensive because of its increased reliability, and it also provides greater protection against threats we encounter on the battlefield.”

The vehicle underwent substantial testing over the past two years to determine how it will protect Marines, be easier to maintain, and meet requirements for survivability and reliability. Testing took place at the U.S. Army Aberdeen Test Center in Maryland; the Amphibious Vehicle Test Branch aboard Camp Pendleton, California; the Yuma Test Center in Arizona; the U.S. Army Engineer Research and Development Center in Mississippi; and the White Sands Missile Range Army Base in New Mexico.

Additionally, the ACV was evaluated aboard the USS Somerset and the USS Anchorage to demonstrate its ability to launch from and recover to amphibious ships, and overall shipboard compatibility.

“Our test program was exhaustive in an effort to ensure we gathered all the data needed to make the best decision,” said Mullins. “We tested the ACV for survivability, mobility, water operations and reliability, and completed gunnery testing.”

Marines who participated in the operational assessment evaluated the vehicle favorably, Mullins said. Those who had previous experience with the AAV were enthusiastic and optimistic about operating the ACV in the future.

I Marine Expeditionary Force will be the first to receive the new ACV when fielding starts in the fourth quarter of 2020. Full operational capability is scheduled for 2023.
column6: MARINE CORPS BASE QUANTICO, VA, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州匡蒂科海军陆战队基地
column10: 海军陆战队系统司令部授予生产ACV合同
column11: 海军陆战队系统司令部授予了生产两栖作战车辆的合同，这是海军陆战队地面作战分队急需的现代化。在海军负责研发和采办的助理部长成功做出里程碑C决策后，价值1.98亿美元的合同选项将允许BAE Systems制造30辆低速生产车辆，这些车辆将于明年秋天开始交付。这些车辆将开始部分两栖攻击车车队的过渡。两栖攻击车已服役40多年，其许多零部件已过时，不再制造。因此，车辆的成本越来越高，维修也越来越困难。这一点，加上海军陆战队发现自己被简易爆炸装置威胁所困扰的不断变化的环境，使得人们需要一种新的、更具生存能力的作战车辆，它可以从船到岸甚至更远的地方机动。柯克・马林斯上校说：“为了在未来领先我们的对手一步，海军陆战队需要找到一种价格合理的现代化车辆，这种车辆能够显著增强AAV的能力和性能。”，ACV 1.1采办项目经理中的产品经理采办项目执行官陆地系统中的高级两栖攻击。ACV是一种八轮车辆，将提供类似于防地雷伏击保护车辆的保护，具有优于AAV的陆上机动性和机动性。它将配备一个精确的武器站，以增强杀伤力，并具有强大的游泳能力，使其能够在海岸线内外作战。“ACV提供机动能力，使部队机械化，与[海军陆战队空地特遣部队]的其余部分保持节奏；特别是M1A1坦克。”马林斯说。“由于可靠性的提高，它不是维护密集型的，它还提供了更好的保护，以抵御我们在战场上遇到的威胁。”该车在过去两年中进行了大量测试，以确定它将如何保护海军陆战队，更容易维护，并满足生存性和可靠性的要求。测试在马里兰州的美国陆军阿伯丁测试中心进行；加利福尼亚州彭德尔顿营地两栖车辆试验分队；亚利桑那州尤马考试中心；位于密西西比州的美国陆军工程师研发中心；此外，ACV在美国萨默塞特号和安克雷奇号上进行了评估，以证明其从两栖舰艇发射和回收的能力，以及总体的舰载兼容性。“我们的测试计划是详尽的，以确保我们收集了做出最佳决策所需的所有数据，”Mullins说。“我们测试了ACV的生存能力、机动性、水上操作和可靠性，并完成了射击测试。”马林斯说，参加作战评估的海军陆战队对该车进行了良好的评估。之前有AAV经验的海军陆战队成员对未来的ACV作战充满热情和乐观。我海军陆战队远征军将在2020年第四季度开始部署新的ACV时第一个接收到该车。全面行动计划运营能力计划在2023年实现。

column2: Cpl. Albert P. Gettings
column3:
U.S. Marine Corps Cpl. Albert P. Gettings who served with Fox Company, 2d Battalion, 6th Marine Regiment, 2d Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force, is commemorated by Fox Company, 2d Battalion, 6th Marine Regiment, 2d Marine Division at Camp Lejeune on Jan. 15, 2021. First Sgt. Adrian Munoz read Gettings’ Silver Star citation prior to a CrossFit workout known as the “Bert” Workout of the Day. Marines conducted the workout which consists of burpees, push-ups, lunges, squats, and running. During the workout, the Marines were constantly reminded to keep pushing through the pain and give their all “just as Cpl. Gettings did.”

Cpl. Gettings served as a team leader with Fox Company, 2d battalion, 6th Marine Regiment, 2d Marine Division, II Marine Expeditionary Force in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom. Cpl. Gettings and his squad came under small arms fire where Gettings was wounded along with his fellow Marine. Fully exposed, he continued to direct fire towards the enemy while his squad maneuvered against the enemy. Gettings was 27 years old when he passed away in 2006. He was mortally wounded by enemy fire. He was posthumously awarded the Bronze Star with a Combat V for valor in 2006. After reviewing his actions of bravery and selflessness, U.S. Marine Corps Gen. Joe Dunford upgraded the award to a Silver Star. Cpl. Gettings and other fallen Marines of their unit live on through the stories passed down by the Marines of Fox Company says Master Sgt. Neil Mason, who served alongside Cpl. Gettings.
column9: 北卡罗来纳州，美国
column10: 艾伯特・P・格廷下士
column11: 2021年1月15日，美国海军陆战队第二海军陆战队远征军第二海军陆战队第二师第六海军陆战队团第二海军陆战队第二营福克斯连第六海军陆战队第二团第二营第六海军陆战队第二团第二海军陆战队第二师纪念美国海军陆战队下士阿尔伯特・P・盖廷。第一中士阿德里安・穆尼奥斯（Adrian Munoz）在一项被称为“伯特”（Bert）训练的交叉配合训练前阅读了Gettings的银星奖。海军陆战队进行了这项训练，包括腹肌、俯卧撑、弓箭步、蹲下和跑步。在训练过程中，海军陆战队不断被提醒，要像格廷下士那样，继续克服痛苦，全力以赴。格廷下士曾担任福克斯连、第二营、第六海军陆战队团、第二海军陆战队师、第二海军陆战队远征军的队长，支持“伊拉克自由行动”。格廷斯下士和他的小队遭到轻武器射击，格廷斯和他的海军战友受伤。完全暴露在外的他继续向敌人开火，而他的小队则在向敌人机动。盖廷斯在2006年去世时只有27岁。他被敌人的炮火击伤致死。2006年，他因英勇而被追授“战斗V”铜星勋章。在回顾了他的勇敢和无私行为后，美国海军陆战队将军乔・邓福德将该奖项提升为银星奖。盖廷斯下士和他们部队的其他阵亡海军陆战队士兵通过福克斯连队的海军陆战队传下来的故事继续生活，与盖廷斯下士一起服役的尼尔・梅森上士说。

column2: Biography - Daniel P. Elkins
column3:
Daniel P. Elkins is the deputy director for the Mission and Installation Contracting Command Office of Public and Congressional Affairs at Joint Base San Antonio-Fort Sam Houston, Texas. The MICC, a subordinate command to the U.S. Army Contracting Command at Redstone Arsenal, Alabama, provides Army commands, installations and activities throughout the nation and Puerto Rico with responsive contracting solutions and oversight in the execution of their missions.

The MICC is made up of about 1,500 military and civilian members at two brigades, two field directorate offices and 30 field-level contracting offices that are responsible for contracting good and services in support of Soldiers as well as readying trained contracting units for the operating force and contingency environment when called upon. MICC contracts are vital in feeding more than 200,000 Soldiers every day, providing many daily base operations support services at installations, preparing more than 100,000 conventional force members annually, training more than 500,000 students each year, and maintaining more than 14.4 million acres of land and 170,000 structures.

The MICC Office of Public and Congressional Affairs develops and provides public and Congressional affairs policy guidance for MICC leaders and conducts active public information, community outreach and media relations programs to inform and educate the public, internal audience, industry and Congress about the command’s people and mission. The office aims to increase the understanding and support for the MICC’s operational contract support mission and its people through transparent communications to its key stakeholders. 

Prior to arriving at the MICC, he served as a public affairs action officer at the Air Force Personnel Center at Randolph Air Force Base, Texas, where he was responsible for planning and executing strategic public affairs communications for the Air Force Manpower Agency, Air Force Services Agency and AFPC in support of more than 450,000 personnel.

Mr. Elkins held a variety of positions of increasing responsibility as a career public affairs professional on active duty and as a federal cival servant over the last 30 years. Those include the full spectrum of public affairs duties including writing, photography, civic outreach, media relations, local and national advertising, crisis communications and Congressional affairs. He is a published author with advertorials appearing in the New England Journal of Medicine and National Jurist as well as news and technical writings at the Air Force and Army levels as well as in the Army acquisition trade publication AL&T Magazine.

His advanced education includes a Master of Science in Communications from St. Mary’s University in San Antonio, Texas, and the DOD Joint Course in Communications at Oklahoma University in Norman, Oklahoma. He also possesses a Bachelor of Arts in Communications from Louisiana Tech University in Ruston, Louisiana, and has completed the Office of Personnel Management Seminar for New Managers: Leading People.
column9: 美国德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥
column10: 传记-丹尼尔・P・埃尔金斯
column11: 丹尼尔・埃尔金斯（Daniel P.Elkins）是德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥-山姆堡-休斯顿联合基地公共和国会事务任务和安装合同司令部副主任。MICC是位于阿拉巴马州红石兵工厂的美国陆军合同司令部的下属司令部，负责提供陆军司令部，遍布全国和波多黎各的设施和活动，在执行其任务时提供响应性合同解决方案和监督。MICC由两个旅的约1500名军事和文职人员组成，两个外地首长级办公室和30个外地级合同办公室，负责合同货物和服务，以支持士兵，并在需要时为作战部队和应急环境准备训练有素的合同单位。MICC合同对于每天为200000多名士兵提供食物、在设施处提供许多日常基地行动支持服务、每年为100000多名常规部队成员做好准备、每年培训500000多名学生至关重要，MICC公共和国会事务办公室为MICC领导人制定并提供公共和国会事务政策指导，并开展积极的公共信息、社区外联和媒体关系计划，以告知和教育公众，关于司令部人员和任务的内部听众、行业和国会。该办公室的目标是通过与主要利益攸关方的透明沟通，增进对MICC业务合同支助特派团及其人员的理解和支持。在抵达MICC之前，他在德克萨斯州伦道夫空军基地的空军人事中心担任公共事务行动官，负责规划和执行空军人力局的战略公共事务沟通，空军服务局和AFPC为45万多名人员提供支持。在过去的30年里，埃尔金斯担任了各种各样的职位，作为一名在职的职业公共事务专业人员和一名联邦公民服务人员，其责任越来越大。这些包括全方位的公共事务职责，包括写作、摄影、公民外联、媒体关系、地方和国家广告、危机传播和国会事务。他是一名出版作家，在《新英格兰医学杂志》和《国家法学家》上刊登广告，在空军和陆军以及陆军采办贸易出版物《AL&T杂志》上发表新闻和技术文章。他的高等教育包括圣玛丽大学的通信理学硕士在得克萨斯州圣安东尼奥市和俄克拉荷马州诺曼市俄克拉荷马大学的国防部通信联合课程。他还拥有路易斯安那州鲁斯顿市路易斯安那理工大学的通信文学学士学位，并完成了为新经理（领导人员）举办的人事管理办公室研讨会。

column2: The Corps’ new Amphibious Combat Vehicle offers ‘significantly greater survivability, mobility’ than predecessor
column3:
The Marine Corps’ Amphibious Combat Vehicle program reached another milestone, proving the vehicle’s ability to deliver future combat power from ship to shore and follow-on objectives. Program Executive Officer Land Systems recently completed testing on the ACV, which proved the new vehicles' ability to not only take on challenging surf, but also complete a long swim from ship to shore and back.  

These major accomplishments facilitated the program moving from what was originally envisioned as an incremental approach, to one that will be known as the ACV family of vehicles, without the nomenclature of ACV 1.1 or ACV 1.2.
In June 2018, Marine Corps Systems Command awarded BAE Systems a contract to begin low rate initial production of the amphibious vehicles. Since then, the Advanced Amphibious Assault program office at Program Executive Officer Land Systems has continued conducting a variety of robust swimming and other tests on the platform.

Most recently, the ACV program office successfully completed 1.2 anticipated requirement testing, and determined the ACV technologically capable of fully replacing the legacy AAV.

‘Significantly greater survivability’

“We’ve landed on a vehicle that is very comparable in the ocean or in the water to the current AAV, with respect to performance,” said Col. Kirk Mullins, program manager for Advanced Amphibious Assault at PEO Land Systems. “We have a vehicle that has significantly greater survivability and mobility than the current platform, and one that―through demonstrated operational tests―the Marines are very happy with.”

Several capabilities were evaluated during recent testing, including the vehicle’s ability to embark and deploy off of an amphibious ship, its ship-to-shore threshold and a high-surf test, which subjected the vehicle to aggressive surf zones with waves reaching over six feet, said Mullins.

“The program office tested the vehicle to all of the ACV 1.2 transition requirements, and even subjected the vehicle to 9-foot waves without issues,” he said. “Because of this, the Marine Corps now was the opportunity to combine the program into a singular ACV family of vehicles program.”

The platform met the 1.2 requirements earlier than anticipated, which the program office credits in part to the competitive process by which the vehicle was selected.

Competition drives innovation

“The success the program has achieved today has a lot to do with how the program was structured and how it’s been executed,” said Angelo Scarlato, ACV 1.1 product manager at PEO Land Systems. “The competition [between industry to produce the ACV] worked, from getting increased performance out of our industry partners and the vehicle at a reasonable price.”

Scarlato also noted with the ACV 1.1 meeting the 1.2 requirements ahead of schedule, the Corps is able to completely avoid the incremental engineering, manufacturing and developmental costs associated with developing a different ACV 1.2 vehicle.

With the completion of 1.2 transition requirement testing, the program office is shifting their focus to operational effectiveness and suitability, force protection and survivability, and logistical sustainability testing, said Scarlato.

“The two statutory tests we have to undergo are [Initial Operational Test and Evaluation] and [Full-Up System Level] live-fire testing,” he said. “For IOT&E, we’re looking at operational effectiveness and operational suitability of the platform. For FUSL, we’re looking at force protection and survivability.”

The ACV is intended to serve Marines for at least the next 20-plus years. With that in mind, Scarlato said the ACV would also undergo logistics demonstration testing.

“For this, we’re focusing more on the suitability and sustainment aspects of the platform,” he said. “We’re not just looking at how effective it is in a combat environment, but also how logistically supportable the platform is.”

Putting the Warfighter first

In an unconventional move by the program office, Marine operators who tested the vehicle were given the opportunity to interface directly with the platform’s program managers and engineers―from both the AAA program office and BAE Systems―in order to provide constructive feedback on improving the vehicle’s design.

“There are some things that you just can’t capture from test reports and surveys that Marines usually fill out after these operational assessments,” said Mullins. “I wanted Marines to have a chance to physically put the ACV engineers and project officers on the vehicle to point out their suggestions for improvements, so when the engineers go back to their offices to design the fixes, they’d have a first-hand experience of what the Marines experienced.”

Mullins credits the project team and vehicle manufacturer for taking robust efforts to incorporate some of the Marines’ suggested changes, many of which will be included in the first release of ACVs later on this year. So far, the team has incorporated seven of the top feedback items provided by Marines. However, Mullins also wants Marines to know their additional feedback and suggestions could still be addressed in later builds of the ACV.

Aiming for continuous improvement by soliciting feedback is something the program office plans to carry into the future.

“We imagine doing something very similar with IOT&E, too,” said Scarlato. “It’s a continuous loop, soliciting feedback from your customer and designing changes to meet the customer’s needs.”
column6: MARINE CORPS BASE QUANTICO, VA, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州匡蒂科海军陆战队基地
column10: 美国陆军工程兵团的新型两栖作战车辆提供了比前一代“更大的生存能力和机动性”
column11: 海军陆战队的两栖作战车辆项目又达到了一个里程碑，证明了该车辆能够将未来的作战能力从船送到岸上，并实现后续目标。项目执行官陆地系统公司最近完成了对ACV的测试，这证明了新型车辆不仅具有挑战性冲浪的能力，而且能够完成从船到岸和从船到岸的长距离游泳。这些重大成就促进了该计划从最初设想的渐进式方法转变为将被称为ACV系列车辆的方法，并于2018年6月取消了ACV 1.1或ACV 1.2的命名，海军陆战队系统司令部授予BAE系统公司一份合同，开始低比例生产两栖车辆。从那时起，项目执行官陆地系统部的高级两栖攻击项目办公室继续在平台上进行各种强劲的游泳和其他测试。最近，ACV项目办公室成功完成了1.2预期需求测试，并确定ACV在技术上能够完全取代传统AAV。“显著提高生存能力”。柯克・马林斯上校说：“我们在海洋或水中降落的车辆在性能上与现有AAV相当。”，PEO陆地系统高级两栖攻击项目经理。“我们拥有一种比现有平台具有更大生存能力和机动性的车辆，并且通过演示的作战测试，海军陆战队非常满意。”在最近的测试中评估了几种能力，包括该车辆在两栖舰艇上登船和部署的能力，Mullins说，该公司的船到岸临界值和高海浪试验使车辆处于海浪超过6英尺的侵蚀性海浪区。项目办公室对车辆进行了所有ACV 1.2过渡要求的测试，甚至对车辆进行了9英尺海浪的测试，没有任何问题。“正因为如此，海军陆战队现在有机会将该计划合并为单一的ACV系列车辆计划。”该平台比预期更早地满足了1.2要求，这部分归功于车辆选择的竞争过程。竞争推动创新PEO Land Systems ACV 1.1产品经理安吉洛・斯卡拉托（Angelo Scarlato）说：“该计划今天取得的成功与该计划的结构和执行方式有很大关系，[行业之间的ACV生产竞争]以合理的价格从我们的行业合作伙伴和车辆中获得更高的性能。”斯卡拉托还指出，随着ACV 1.1提前满足1.2要求，美国陆军工程兵团能够完全避免与开发不同ACV 1.2车辆相关的工程、制造和开发成本增加。随着1.2过渡要求测试的完成，项目办公室正在将重点转移到斯卡拉托说：“作战效能和适用性、部队保护和生存能力以及后勤可持续性测试。我们必须进行的两项法定测试是[初始作战测试和评估]和[全系统级]实弹测试。”。“对于物联网与评估，我们关注的是平台的作战效能和作战适用性。对于FUSL，我们关注的是部队保护和生存能力。”ACV打算在未来20多年内为海军陆战队服务。考虑到这一点，斯卡拉托说，ACV还将进行后勤演示测试。“为此，我们更关注平台的适用性和持续性方面，”他说。“我们不仅关注平台在作战环境中的有效性，还关注平台的后勤保障能力。”在项目办公室的非常规行动中，将作战人员放在首位，测试车辆的海军陆战队操作员有机会直接与平台的项目经理和来自AAA项目办公室和BAE系统的工程师联系，以便就改进车辆设计提供建设性反馈“有些东西是海军陆战队在作战评估后通常填写的测试报告和调查中无法捕捉到的，”马林斯说。“我希望海军陆战队有机会亲自将ACV工程师和项目官员放在车辆上，提出他们的改进建议，这样，当工程师回到办公室设计修复方案时，他们就能亲身体验海军陆战队的经验。”Mullins赞扬项目团队和车辆制造商做出了巨大努力，将海军陆战队的一些建议变更纳入其中，其中许多将在今年晚些时候发布的ACV中包含。到目前为止，该团队已经纳入了海军陆战队提供的七个顶级反馈项。然而，Mullins也希望海军陆战队能够他们的额外反馈和建议仍然可以在以后的ACV构建中解决。通过征求反馈来实现持续改进是项目办公室计划在未来开展的工作。“我们设想在物联网与设备方面也做类似的事情，”斯卡拉托说。“这是一个持续的循环，征求客户的反馈，并设计更改以满足客户的需求。”

column2: P-38G Lightning under restoration
column3:
For almost a year, the P-38G Lightning was noticeably missing from the Heritage Park. Over time, people wondered where it went and when it would reappear in its rightful place.

The P-38 is currently being restored and repainted with the help of Airmen from the Aircraft Structural Maintenance unit assigned to the 3rd Maintenance Squadron. The ASM Airmen preserve the structure of aircraft, paint, and fabricate sheet metals and tubing to replace worn or damaged parts, for all active and static-display aircraft. 

“The restoration program is to fully refurbish the aircraft close to its original design,” said Air Force Master Sgt. Sarah Jornacion, 3rd MXS nondestructive inspection section chief. “It is not just a display, but preserving the heritage of the aircraft, and that’s what we do as maintainers. We take pride in bringing it back to its glory.”

To get to where they currently are, there were a lot of steps to restoring the P-38. These steps included moving and towing it inside a hangar. They also took multiple high-definition images, extensive notes, and measurements of the decals, and put the information into a computer. 

Once the data was in the system, a team of four Airmen spent three eight-hour shifts to sand, wash and remove residue from the aircraft. Before applying primer and paint, the Airmen methodically applied protection to surfaces not being painted. 

“It’s been a complicated process,” said Tech. Sgt. Matt Monnens, 3rd MXS aircraft structural maintenance chief lead. “The Air Force switched over to flat paint to all active aircraft, [but] most of the historical aircraft are high-gloss paint. When gloss paint is applied, attention to detail is key, because any flaws underneath can be easily seen.”

Monnens added little details are significant because veterans who had worked on or flown the Lightning would notice a slight change to the aircraft, so it was imperative for the Airmen to make sure to make it look realistic as possible. 

“The paint scheme is a lot harder than it looks because of its two-tone color pattern,” said Tech. Sgt. Renee Peaper, 3rd MXS aircraft structural maintenance craftsman. “It has been a struggle for us to replicate the original paint scheme. Even our most talented painters have had difficulty because of all the obstacles we were running into [such as finding the right color-scheme].”

Master Sgt. Richard Mabry, 3rd MXS aircraft structural maintenance section chief, said more than 30 individuals contributed to the restoration of the aircraft. 

Senior Airman Kurtis Steinecke and Airman 1st Class Jonathan Torres-Zayas, both assigned to ASM, are putting the final details on the aircraft before it returns to its original home. 

“This is a big team effort,” Mabry said. “Through ups and downs such as low manning, work constraints at the flight line and the challenging paint job, the Airmen continued to focus and work together as a team.”

Steinecke had the opportunity to show the aircraft to a family member who happened to trace it to their father who had flown the P-38 during World War II. 

“The family member was visiting Alaska and wanted to visit the Heritage Park because the family member’s father flew the aircraft that was on display,” Mabry said. “They had a brother who had their father’s flight log and traced it back to JBER, and the tail number happened to match the [one here].”

Regardless of the unfinished aircraft, the ASM granted the family’s request to see the aircraft and pay tribute to their dad. 

Steinecke and Torres-Zaya said it’s also important for them to finish this project because they are putting a stamp on the only G model in existence; the JBER plane is one of fewer than 30 P-38s remaining in the world. It is also one of only nine aircraft listed on the National Register of Historic Places. 

“It gives us the chance to be part of the bigger picture that everybody sees and not just the maintenance,” said Steinecke. “It’s not only us; it was a big team effort to get to this point close to the finish line.”

Steinecke and Torres-Zayas shared the same sentiments that when it comes to this aircraft, there is no room for error and that perfection is the key.
column9: 杰伯，AK，美国
column10: 恢复中的P-38G闪电
column11: 在将近一年的时间里，遗产公园的P-38G闪电明显失踪。随着时间的推移，人们想知道它去了哪里，什么时候会重新出现在正确的位置上。P-38目前正在第三维修中队飞机结构维修队飞行员的帮助下进行修复和重新喷漆。ASM飞行员保护飞机结构，为所有主动和静态显示飞机喷涂和制造金属板和管道，以更换磨损或损坏的零件。“修复计划是完全翻新飞机接近其原始设计，”空军少校Sarah Jornacion中士说，第三MXS无损检测科科长。“这不仅仅是一次展示，而是保存了飞机的传统，这也是我们作为维修人员所做的。我们为它重回辉煌而感到自豪。”为了达到目前的水平，我们采取了很多步骤来修复P-38。这些步骤包括在机库内移动和拖曳飞机。他们还拍摄了多张高清图像、大量笔记和对贴花的测量，并将信息输入计算机。一旦数据进入系统，一个由四名飞行员组成的小组花了三个八小时轮班对飞机进行打磨、清洗和清除残留物。在涂底漆和油漆之前，飞行员系统地对未涂油漆的表面进行保护。“这是一个复杂的过程，”第三代MXS飞机结构维修首席负责人、技术中士马特・蒙尼斯（Matt Monnens）说。“空军将所有现役飞机改用平漆，[但]大多数历史上的飞机都是高光泽油漆。当使用光泽油漆时，注意细节是关键，因为下面的任何缺陷都很容易看到。”Monnens补充说，小细节是重要的，因为曾经在闪电上工作或飞行过的老兵会注意到飞机的细微变化，因此飞行员必须确保飞机看起来尽可能逼真。第三代MXS飞机结构维修技师技术中士Renee Peaper说：“油漆方案比看起来难多了，因为它有两种色调的颜色图案。”。“我们一直在努力复制原始的油漆方案。即使是我们最有才华的油漆师也遇到了困难，因为我们遇到了所有的障碍[例如找到正确的颜色方案]。”MXS飞机结构维修三科科长理查德・马布里上士，他说，30多人参与了飞机的修复工作。高级飞行员Kurtis Steinecke和一等飞行员Jonathan Torres Zayas都被分配到ASM，他们正在飞机返回其原来的家之前，对飞机的最终细节进行说明。“这是一个巨大的团队努力，”马布里说。“经历了人员配备不足、飞行线的工作限制和艰巨的喷漆工作等起起落落，飞行员们继续集中精力，作为一个团队一起工作。”斯泰内克有机会将飞机展示给一位家庭成员，这位家庭成员碰巧找到了他们在二战期间驾驶P-38飞机的父亲。马布里说：“这名家庭成员当时正在阿拉斯加，想参观遗产公园，因为这名家庭成员的父亲驾驶了展出的飞机。”。“他们有一个兄弟，他有父亲的飞行日志，可以追溯到JBER，尾号恰好与[这里的一个]匹配。”不管这架未完工的飞机，ASM同意了家人的要求，让他们看看飞机并向父亲致敬。Steinecke和Torres Zaya说，完成这个项目对他们来说也很重要，因为他们正在给现存唯一的G模型打上印记；JBER飞机是世界上仅存的不到30架P-38飞机之一。它也是国家历史遗迹登记册上仅有的九架飞机之一。施泰内克说：“这让我们有机会成为每个人都能看到的大局的一部分，而不仅仅是维修。”。“这不仅仅是我们；这是一个大团队的努力，以达到这一点接近终点线。”斯坦内克和托雷斯・扎亚斯都有同样的想法，当谈到这架飞机时，没有错误的余地，完美是关键。

column2: RHC-P focuses on organizational health
column3:
HONOLULU (Oct. 17) --- Regional Health Command-Pacific, also known as RHC-P, conducted a half-day team training event where organizational leaders located in Hawaii and Joint Base Lewis McChord, Washington State, came together via virtual telecommunication to better the organization.

Comprehensive Soldier and Family Fitness Lead Master Resilience Trainer-Performance Expert, Jesse Michel, led the session and facilitated discussion on the Hawaii-side of the staff. 

"The staff on both sides of the ocean identified the common foundation, in terms of the qualities and characteristics that are going to make this team great and also identified action items how are they going to get there,” said Michel. 

RHC-P team member and Deputy G-3, Johnny Garnett, participated in the training from the Joint Base Lewis McChord site and stated that he found the training dynamic and interactive, as well as serving to further enhance staff cohesiveness.

 “With a very diverse yet seasoned staff, the instructors systematically depicted similarities in "common core" values defined by the RHC-P HQ Staff.  Superb instruction, conducted in an informal, structured setting and complemented by open discussions in a non-attribution milieu,” stated Garnett. 

Following the conclusion of the session, RHC-P Commanding General, Brig. Gen. Bertram Providence, thanked staff for their participation in the training and provided an insight into the next steps. 

“When it comes to improving our effectiveness, we must continually adopt the mentality that there is no finish line.  Every time we advance and get better, there will still remain an opportunity to further our progress. We owe such a commitment to excellence to ourselves and the beneficiaries that entrust their healthcare to us every day,” stated Providence. 

About RHC-P: 
RHC-P orchestrates the delivery of world-class medical care for service members, families and eligible beneficiaries, and provides medical readiness and diplomacy in support of United States Army Pacific in the Pacific Command area of responsibility.
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: RHC-P关注组织健康
column11: 檀香山（10月17日）--太平洋地区卫生司令部，也称为RHC-P，组织领导在夏威夷和华盛顿州刘易斯・麦考德联合基地进行了为期半天的团队培训，通过虚拟远程通信使组织更加完善。综合士兵和家庭健身首席教练、恢复力教练大师、绩效专家杰西・米歇尔（Jesse Michel）主持了会议，并促进了夏威夷员工的讨论。“在海洋两岸的员工们确定了共同的基础，在质量和特点方面，这将使这个球队伟大，并确定了行动项目，他们将如何到达那里，”米歇尔说。RHC-P团队成员和副G-3，Johnny Garnett，参加了训练从联合基地Lewis McCho。他说，他发现培训充满活力和互动性，有助于进一步增强员工的凝聚力。“由于员工非常多样化，但经验丰富，讲师系统地描述了“共同核心”的相似之处加内特表示：“RHC-P总部员工定义的价值观。出色的指导，在非正式、结构化的环境中进行，并辅之以非归属环境中的公开讨论。”。会议结束后，RHC-P指挥官Brig。伯特伦・普罗维登斯将军感谢工作人员参加培训，并就下一步行动提出了见解。“在提高效率方面，我们必须继续保持没有终点线的心态。每一次我们的进步和进步，都会有进一步进步的机会。我们对自己和每天将医疗保健托付给我们的受益人做出卓越的承诺。”天意。关于RHC-P：RHC-P为服役人员、家属和合格受益人提供世界一流的医疗服务，并在太平洋司令部责任区为美国陆军太平洋分部提供医疗准备和外交支持。

column2: Farewell 2018- RHC-P’s year-in-review
column3:
JOINT BASE LEWIS-MCCHORD, Wash. C As 2019 begins, it is again time to reflect on significant events that occurred at Regional Health Command-Pacific last year. 

Similar to previous years, RHC-P and its subordinate units contributed to the Army’s No. 1 priority C readiness. Region also supported health care delivery while developing organizations, leaders and Soldiers working toward a mission to provide medically ready forces and ready medical forces with a vision of being the premier health force, best-trained and equipped to support the nation’s call.

With over 229,000 beneficiaries, the Region is a hub for health care services including outpatient clinic visits, laboratory procedures, pharmacy prescription fills, immunizations, inpatient care and radiology procedures. Dental procedures, veterinary services and ensuring the health readiness of our deploying personnel round out the Region’s everyday functions.

Over the summer, RHC-P saw two major changes in leadership. Brig. Gen. Dennis P. LeMaster took command of RHC-P, while Command Sergeant Maj. Clark J. Charpentier assumed responsibility as the senior enlisted advisor. RHC-P also welcomed a new Deputy Commanding General, Brig. Gen. Michael L. Place.

The RHC-P command also repositioned its headquarters location from Hawaii to JBLM, continuing the support of responsive medical capabilities to U.S. Indo-Pacific Command, U.S. Army Pacific and I Corps.

READINESS 

During 2018, RHC-P’s forces remained healthy and prepared to meet any challenge.

Competitions such as the Pacific Regional Trials, Pacific Best Medic and Pacific Best Warrior Competition further the Region’s success by challenging Soldiers during military drills or sporting events. These competitions not only strengthen physical strength, but also build mental resolve.

The Pacific Regional Trials saw about 100 wounded, ill and injured Soldiers and Veterans compete in a multi-sporting event representing 12 Warrior Transition Battalions from across the Pacific, Atlantic, and Central regions. The Pacific Best Medic Competition saw competitors from Washington, Alaska, Hawaii, Japan and Korea compete in both physical and mental exercises needed to succeed as a medic on the battlefield. 

Although competitions coupled with training are key components contributing to a ready state, global health engagements were also key to Region’s readiness posture.

Over the past three years the Region has deployed on over 170 missions, and in 2018, efforts continued to provide these critical missions to further enhance health care outcomes in the Indo-Pacific region.  

GHE highlights include the opening of a Cambodia blood donor center in partnership with RHC-P’s military treatment facilities and units, Indo-Pacific and USARPAC. The Cambodia mission marked the grand opening of two blood donor centers, paving the way for the next step, accreditation. Additionally, a nine-person team from RHC-P, Madigan Army Medical Center and the Armed Forces Research Institute of Medical Sciences, traveled to Dhaka, Bangladesh, to conduct a second clinical laboratory and bio-preparedness subject matter expert exchange. 

These missions exemplify how the Region’s GHEs provide the opportunity to strengthen relationships with partner nations and other key stakeholders.

HEALTH CARE DELIVERY

The Region’s efforts to optimize the health of our beneficiaries by focusing on access, prevention, wellness and health care delivery was another priority in 2018.

Every year, MTFs within the Pacific region reach out to beneficiaries to educate about the importance of receiving relevant and timely care. Access to care is also at the forefront of our patient care. For example, this year, flu shot clinics were again held across the Region, with LeMaster leading the charge, receiving his vaccination at one of the MTFs. 

In 2018, Tricare held an open season for the first time. This change allowed beneficiaries to select plans to meet their needs, and their household budgets. The vision and dental programs were also revamped with the addition of more plans.

Place provided the opening remarks during the Region’s 7th annual Pacific Behavioral Health Summit. The annual summit brings together military and community health care professionals to share the latest behavioral health medical and technological innovations, research topics and approaches to care, improving access to care for beneficiaries.

PEOPLE

Each year the Region takes pride in ongoing efforts to develop civilian and Soldier leaders because people are the foundation of the Region’s success and the key to the future.

LeMaster held a senior leader symposium, bringing together commanders from the Pacific medical arena. During the two-day symposium, participants worked together to refine the RHC-P campaign plan, while also participating in sessions on operationalizing readiness, rapid hiring, leader development, performance planning, MHS GENESIS, and congressional updates on the National Defense Authorization Acts of 2017 and 2019.

Retirees are also a key component of the people who round out this great region. In October 2018, a retiree appreciation event was held in Hawaii to honor and recognize those who have served and continue to serve the military and the community.

HAWAII eMSM AND PUGET SOUND MHS

Lastly, we cannot forget our regional partners, the Puget Sound Military Health System and Hawaii enhanced Multi-Market System, who are co-located at the two headquarters locations and support medical assets for all Services. Both offices contribute to the Army Medicine and RHC-P missions throughout the year. 

LeMaster is the market manager for the Puget Sound MHS, while Place is the market manager for the Hawaii eMSM. LeMaster and Place oversee the efficient use of the joint service medical resources, so patients can access care when they need it, in the most efficient way possible, and at the best cost.

Under the Puget Sound MHS, projects such as the JBLM medical and dental sleep apnea team formed. The team sought to reduce cost and increase readiness for active-duty service members by increasing deployability through use of obstructive sleep apena devices other than a CPAP machine. The efforts were recognized by U.S. Army Medical Command with a Wolf Pack Award.

In 2018, the Hawaii eMSM continued to promote an unrivaled experience of care by leveraging partnerships, technology and resources, while fostering a ready force and healthy, resilient Ohana.

Some highlights include the continuation of a physical therapist initiative which provides inpatient and outpatient services to beneficiaries in MTFs across all Services. The Hawaii eMSM also received accolades for the implementation and management of several programs such as tele-behavioral health capabilities, consolidation of appointment systems into one central phone line and working groups who supported the Rim of the Pacific Exercise.

--------

To learn more about RHC-P and to read our stories go to www.army.mil/RHCPacific or connect with us at www.facebook.com/RegionalHealthCommandPacific

RHC-P oversees a premier medical force in the Indo-Pacific region, covering 36 nations across 16 time zones and comprised of nine commands - Bassett Army Community Hospital, Madigan Army Medical Center, Medical Department Activity C Japan, MEDDAC-Korea, Tripler Army Medical Center, U.S. Army Health Clinic-Schofield Barracks, the 18th Medical Command (Deployment Support), as well as Dental Health Command C Pacific and Public Health Command C Pacific.

One team C United across the Pacific
column6: JOINT BASE LEWIS-MCCHORD, WA, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国华盛顿州刘易斯-麦考德联合基地
column10: 告别2018-RHC-P的回顾之年
column11: 华盛顿州LEWIS-MCCHORD联合基地-随着2019年的开始，再次是反思去年太平洋地区卫生司令部发生的重大事件的时候了。与前几年类似，RHC-P及其下属部队为陆军的第一要务――战备做出了贡献。该地区还支持医疗服务的提供，同时发展组织、领导和士兵，致力于为医疗准备部队和医疗准备部队提供一个愿景，即成为首要的医疗力量，经过最好的培训和装备，以支持国家的号召。受益者超过229000人，该地区是医疗服务中心，包括门诊就诊、实验室检查、药房处方、免疫接种、住院治疗和放射治疗。牙科程序、兽医服务和确保我们部署人员的健康准备，使该地区的日常职能更加完善。在夏季，RHC-P见证了领导层的两次重大变化。布里格。丹尼斯・P・勒马斯特将军指挥RHC-P，而司令部中士克拉克・J・查彭蒂埃少校则担任高级应征顾问。RHC-P还欢迎新任副司令Brig。Michael L.Place将军。RHC-P司令部还将其总部位置从夏威夷重新定位到JBLM，在2018年继续支持美国印太司令部、美国陆军太平洋司令部和I军的应急医疗能力，RHC-P的部队保持健康，随时准备迎接任何挑战。太平洋地区试训、太平洋最佳医师和太平洋最佳战士比赛等比赛通过在军事演习或体育赛事中挑战士兵，进一步推动了该地区的成功。这些比赛不仅能增强体力，还能培养意志力。在太平洋地区的试训中，约有100名受伤、生病和受伤的士兵和退伍军人参加了一场多项目的比赛，他们代表了来自太平洋、大西洋和中部地区的12个战士过渡营。来自华盛顿、阿拉斯加、夏威夷、日本和韩国的参赛者参加了太平洋最佳医疗队比赛，他们参加了在战场上作为一名成功的医疗队所需的身体和心理训练。尽管比赛加上训练是形成就绪状态的关键组成部分，但全球卫生活动也是该地区就绪态势的关键。过去三年，该地区已部署了170多个任务，2018年，继续努力提供这些关键任务，以进一步提高印度-太平洋区域的卫生保健成果。GHE的亮点包括与RHC-P的军事治疗设施和单位、印度-太平洋和USARPAC合作开设柬埔寨献血中心。柬埔寨代表团标志着两个献血中心的隆重开幕，为下一步的认证铺平了道路。此外，来自RHC-P、Madigan陆军医疗中心和武装部队医学科学研究所的九人团队前往孟加拉国达卡，进行第二次临床实验室和生物准备主题专家交流。这些任务举例说明了该地区的GHE如何提供机会加强与伙伴国家和其他关键利益相关者的关系。医疗服务提供该地区通过关注获取、预防、健康和医疗服务提供来优化受益人健康的努力是2018年的另一个优先事项。每年，太平洋区域的MTF与受益人接触，教育他们接受相关及时护理的重要性。获得护理也是我们患者护理的最前沿。例如，今年，流感疫苗注射诊所再次在整个地区举行，由莱马斯特牵头，在一个MTF接受他的疫苗接种。2018年，Tricare首次举办公开赛。这一变化使受益人能够选择满足其需求和家庭预算的计划。随着更多计划的加入，视力和牙科项目也进行了修改。Place在该地区第七届太平洋行为健康峰会上发表了开幕词。一年一度的峰会汇集了军队和社区卫生保健专业人士，分享最新的行为健康医疗和技术创新、研究主题和护理方法，人们每年都在为发展平民和士兵领袖而不懈努力，因为人们是该地区成功的基础和未来的关键。莱姆斯特举行了一次高级领导人座谈会，召集了来自太平洋医学院的指挥官。在为期两天的研讨会期间，与会者共同努力完善RHC-P活动计划，同时还参加了关于操作准备、快速招聘、领导者发展、绩效规划、MHS起源、以及，以及国会对2017年和2019年《国防授权法案》的更新。退休人员也是这个伟大地区的重要组成部分。2018年10月，在夏威夷举行了一次退休人员感谢活动，以表彰和表彰那些曾经并继续为军队和社区服务的人。夏威夷eMSM和普吉特桑德MHS令人惊讶的是，我们不能忘记我们的区域合作伙伴，普吉特桑德军事卫生系统和夏威夷增强型多市场系统，世卫组织设在两个总部地点，为所有服务提供医疗资产支持。这两个办公室全年都为陆军医学和RHC-P任务做出贡献。LeMaster是Puget Sound MHS的市场经理，Place是夏威夷eMSM的市场经理。LeMaster和Place负责监督联合服务医疗资源的有效使用，使患者能够在需要时以最有效的方式、以最佳的成本获得护理。在普吉特湾MHS下，成立了JBLM医疗和牙科睡眠呼吸暂停团队等项目。该团队试图通过使用除CPAP机器以外的阻塞性睡眠apena设备来提高部署能力，从而降低成本，提高现役军人的准备状态。这些努力得到了美国陆军医疗司令部的认可，并获得了狼群奖。2018年，夏威夷eMSM通过利用合作伙伴关系、技术和资源，继续推广无与伦比的护理体验，同时培养了一支随时准备好的部队和一支健康的队伍，弹性Ohana。一些亮点包括继续实施物理治疗师计划，为MTF所有服务的受益人提供住院和门诊服务。夏威夷eMSM还因实施和管理远程行为健康能力等多个项目而获得赞誉，将预约系统整合为一条中央电话线和支持环太平洋演习的工作组。-------要了解更多关于RHC-P的信息并阅读我们的故事，请访问www.army.mil/RHCPacific或通过www.facebook.com/RegionalHealthCommandPacificRHC-P与我们联系，网址为www.facebook.com/regionalHealthCommandPacific地区，覆盖16个时区的36个国家，由9个司令部组成――巴塞特陆军社区医院、麦迪根陆军医疗中心、医疗部门活动――日本、韩国医疗发展援助中心、Tripler陆军医疗中心、美国陆军医疗诊所Schofield兵营、第18医疗司令部（部署支持），以及太平洋牙科卫生司令部和太平洋公共卫生司令部。一个团队在太平洋地区团结一致

column2: RHC-P reflects upon 2017 accomplishments
column3:
HONOLULU C (Dec. 7, 2017) Regional Health Command-Pacific reflects upon major accomplishments celebrated this year in support of its mission of providing combatant commanders with medically ready forces and ready medical forces conducting health service support in all phases of military operation. 

The Department of Defense's (DoD) new electronic health record, dubbed MHS Genesis, was successfully deployed at Madigan Oct. 21. MHS, which stands for military health system, integrates inpatient and outpatient solutions that will connect medical and dental information across the continuum of care, from point of injury to the military treatment facility. This includes garrison, operational, and en route care, increasing efficiencies for beneficiaries and healthcare professionals. According to a DoD Healthcare management System Modernization factsheet, when fully deployed, MHS Genesis will support the availability of electronic health records for more than 9.4 million DoD beneficiaries and approximately 205,000 Military Health System personnel globally. 

Madigan Army Medical Center, one of the largest military hospitals on the West Coast, opened the Department of Defense’s first Center for Autism, Resources, Education and Services (CARES) at Joint Base Lewis McCord (JBLM), in Washington State on Aug. 9. The center is a joint installation partnership between Madigan and the JBLM Armed Forces Community Service, which focuses on providing patient-centered care for military children with autism and their families.  “We believe that as we provide better support to our special needs kids and their families, our community and military readiness improves.  And that’s something we can all celebrate,” stated Madigan Commanding Officer, Col. Michael Place. Eligible patients receive occupational, physical and speech therapy, Applied Behavioral Analysis (ABA), Exceptional Family Member Program (EFMP) Systems Navigation, Child Youth School Services (CYSS) Respite Care and more. 

The region also co-hosted the Sixth Annual Behavioral Health Summit, Sept. 7-8 at Tripler Army Medical Center’s Kyser Auditorium, gathering mental health professionals from the Pacific region together to discuss best practices, emerging treatments, research topics and approaches to care to help military families and veterans on their journey towards lifelong resilience. RHC-P Chief of Staff, Col. Laura Trinkle provided opening remarks. "This summit is a shining example of unity, demonstrating the partnership we share delivering quality healthcare between Army Medicine, our friends at the VA, the behavioral health professionals in our communities and other trusted advocates. We are all here today, on an island in the middle of the Pacific working toward a common goal. Yet the collective improvements gained here will impact the way we deliver world-class medical care not just to our ohana on Oahu - but throughout the entire region.”

A Madigan subordinate unit, the California Medical Detachment from the Presidio of Monterey, began pediatrics and family medicine care in the newly opened Major General William H. Gourley Clinic VA-DoD Outpatient Clinic, located in Seaside, California. The facility, which conducted a ribbon cutting Aug. 3, allows for the treatment of military veterans of the Monterey peninsula military community, along with the family medicine and pediatrics TRICARE Prime patients of the Department of Defense. At the clinic, the VA’s health care system and the Army’s Patient Centered Medical Home model work in harmony, emphasizing the health partnership between patient and provider.  

RHC-P also held the Pacific Warrior Trials, held at Schofield Barracks, Hawaii. During the week-long competition which concluded Nov. 10, about 80 wounded, ill, or injured soldiers and veterans from the Pacific region trained and competed in eight adaptive sporting events ranging from swimming, track, field, shooting, archery, cycling, sitting volleyball and wheelchair basketball. Tripler Army Medical Center Commanding Officer, Col. Andrew Barr, summarized his thoughts on the stories he heard from participants, emphasizing the immense sense of accomplishment and resiliency among the Soldiers. "Through your effort, through your struggle, through your accomplishments, some of you rebelling in victory with medals, but all of you rebelling in your accomplishments and the ability to finish the race, that's what the Warrior Games are all about."

At the Army level, RHC-P took second place overall in the Army's Best Medic Competition, which concluded Oct. 29 at Camp Bullis, Texas, hosted by the U.S. Army Medical Command and the U.S. Army Medical Department Center and School. This year's competition, which included 28 teams, was designed to physically and intellectually challenge medics in a simulated tactical environment. The region was represented by 2nd Lt. Adam Schafer, 65th Medical Brigade and Sgt. Ryan Harpster, Bassett Army Community Hospital at the U.S. Army Best Medic team event alongside other two-person U.S. Army medic teams. "The most challenging part of the competition was staying sharp and attentive to the small details while I was very physically uncomfortable," stated Schafer. "There was never a point where I was not hot, freezing, sore, in pain or struggling with fire ant bites. It required a mental toughness to push out those distractions which was crucial for our success."

RHC-P also hosted various high-level distinguished visors to the region, which included the Second Lady of the United States, Acting Assistant Secretary of Defense for Health Affairs, and the Army Surgeon General. During these visits, RHC-P personnel were able to emphasize many of the outstanding programs, award-winning initiatives and staff making up the region. 

Throughout the year, RHC-P medical personnel also projected global health engagements and humanitarian missions for Nepal, Bangladesh, Malaysia, Myanmar, Sri Lanka, Palau, Vietnam, Cambodia, China and Mongolia. 
For more information on RHC-P, visit army.mil/rhcpacific, or visit the command’s facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/RegionalHealthCommandPacific.

For more top news stories from RHC-P, visit facebook.com/RegionalHealthCommandPacific.
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: RHC-P反思2017年的成就
column11: 檀香山―（2017年12月7日）太平洋地区卫生司令部回顾了今年庆祝的重大成就，以支持其为作战指挥官提供医疗准备部队以及在军事行动所有阶段提供卫生服务支持的医疗准备部队的使命。10月21日，被称为MHS Genesis的国防部（DoD）新电子健康记录在麦迪根成功部署。MHS是军事卫生系统的代表，它集成了住院和门诊解决方案，将医疗和牙科信息连接到整个医疗过程中，从受伤点到军事治疗设施。这包括驻军、运营和途中护理，提高受益人和医疗专业人员的效率。根据国防部医疗管理系统现代化概况，当全面部署时，MHS Genesis将为940多万国防部受益人和全球约205000名军事医疗系统人员提供电子医疗记录。Madigan陆军医疗中心是西海岸最大的军事医院之一，于8月9日在华盛顿州的Lewis McCord联合基地（JBLM）开设了国防部第一个自闭症、资源、教育和服务中心（CARES）。该中心是Madigan和JBLM武装部队社区服务之间的一个联合设施合作伙伴关系，该服务的重点是为患有自闭症的军人儿童及其家庭提供以患者为中心的护理。麦迪根指挥官迈克尔・普莱斯上校说：“我们相信，随着我们为有特殊需要的孩子及其家庭提供更好的支持，我们的社区和军事准备状况得到改善。这是我们大家都可以庆祝的事情。”。符合条件的患者接受职业、物理和言语治疗、应用行为分析（ABA）、特殊家庭成员计划（EFMP）系统导航、儿童青少年学校服务（CYSS）暂托护理等。该地区还于9月7日至8日在Tripler陆军医疗中心的Kyser礼堂共同主办了第六届年度行为健康峰会，来自太平洋地区的精神健康专业人士聚集在一起，讨论最佳实践、新兴治疗方法、，研究主题和护理方法，帮助军人家庭和退伍军人实现终身恢复力。RHC-P参谋长Laura Trinkle上校致开幕词。“这次峰会是一个团结的光辉范例，展示了我们在军队医学、VA的朋友、我们社区的行为卫生专业人员和其他值得信赖的倡导者之间分享优质医疗服务的合作。今天我们都在太平洋中部的一个岛上工作，共同的目标。在这里取得的选择性改进将影响我们提供世界级医疗服务的方式，不仅是我们在瓦胡岛的奥哈纳，而且是整个地区。”一个麦迪根下属单位，来自蒙特利普雷斯蒂奥的加利福尼亚医疗支队，在新开设的威廉・H・古利少将诊所开始了儿科和家庭医疗服务ic VA国防部门诊诊所，位于加利福尼亚州海滨。该设施于8月3日进行了一次剪彩，可用于治疗蒙特利半岛军事社区的退伍军人，以及国防部的家庭医学和儿科主要患者。在该诊所，VA的医疗保健系统em和陆军以患者为中心的医疗之家模式协调工作，强调患者和提供者之间的健康伙伴关系。RHC-P还举办了太平洋勇士选拔赛，在夏威夷斯科菲尔德兵营举行。在11月10日结束的为期一周的比赛中，约有80名受伤、生病或受伤的太平洋士兵和退伍军人该地区参加了游泳、田径、射击、射箭、自行车、坐式排球和轮椅篮球等8项适应性运动项目的训练和比赛。三联军医疗中心指挥官安德鲁・巴尔上校总结了他对参与者故事的看法，强调了巨大的同谋感通过你们的努力，通过你们的奋斗，通过你们的成就，你们中的一些人在获得奖牌的胜利中反叛，但你们所有人都在反叛你们的成就和完成比赛的能力，这就是勇士运动会的全部内容。“在陆军层面，RHC-P在陆军最佳医疗竞赛中总体排名第二，该竞赛于10月29日在德克萨斯州布利斯营结束，由美国陆军医疗司令部和美国陆军医疗部中心和学校主办。今年的比赛共有28支队伍，旨在模拟战术环境，在身体和智力上挑战医务人员。该地区由第65医疗旅第2中尉Adam Schafer和巴塞特陆军社区医院的Ryan Harpster中士代表参加了美国陆军最佳医疗队活动，其他两人组成的美国陆军医疗队也参加了活动。“比赛中最具挑战性的部分是保持敏锐和专注于小细节，而我的身体非常不舒服，”谢弗说。“我从来没有一点不热、不冻、不痛、不受火蚁叮咬。这需要一种精神韧性来排除那些对我们的成功至关重要的分心。”RHC-P还为该地区接待了各种高级贵宾，其中包括美国第二夫人，负责卫生事务的代理助理国防部长和陆军卫生部长。在这些访问期间，RHC-P人员能够强调该地区的许多优秀项目、获奖计划和员工。在这一年中，RHC-P医疗人员还计划为尼泊尔、孟加拉国、马来西亚、缅甸、斯里兰卡、帕劳、越南、柬埔寨、中国和蒙古开展全球卫生活动和人道主义任务。有关RHC-P的更多信息，请访问army.mil/rhcpacific，或访问司令部的facebook页面https://www.facebook.com/RegionalHealthCommandPacific.For 更多来自RHC-P的顶级新闻报道，请访问facebook.com/RegionalHealthCommandPacific。

column2: Marines meet the makers of the Amphibious Combat Vehicle
column3:
YORK, Pa.―Marines from the 3rd Assault Amphibian Battalion―slated to receive the first of the Corps’ new Amphibious Combat Vehicles―received the rare opportunity to visit the ACV’s main production facility and meet with the workforce building the vehicle.

On Oct. 16, representatives from Program Manager Advanced Amphibious Assault at Program Executive Officer Land Systems, Marine Corps Combat Development Command, Combat Development and Integration and 3rd AA Bn. visited one of the ACV’s primary manufacturing facilities in York, Pennsylvania, to tour the assembly line and speak with the contractors in charge of building the Corps’ next-generation vehicles.

Col. Kirk Mullins, program manager of AAA, under which the ACV program falls, said the event was a collective decision between himself and leadership at BAE, the vehicle’s manufacturer.

“We thought it would be really good for the workforce to actually meet some of the Marines for whom they’re building the vehicle―the Marines who will take these vehicles and employ them, potentially in harm’s way,” said Mullins. “From a Marine perspective, we are typically in ‘receive’-mode of new equipment, but we never really truly understand or appreciate how much work and effort goes into making that piece of equipment.”

During the visit, Mullins and his team emphasized the importance of delivering quality vehicles on schedule to BAE’s workforce.
