column10: RHC-P高层领导指导下一代
column11: 檀香山--（2017年10月16日）太平洋地区卫生司令部准将。伯特伦・普罗维登斯将军和RHC-P高级应征顾问萨金特少校理查德・沃森少校为莫阿纳鲁阿高中学生和空军初级后备军官训练团学员提供辅导，作为与干部的正式辅导课程的一部分。RHC-P高级领导访问了军校学员，为他们提供关于成为好公民的领导指导，制定“聪明”的目标和职业规划。普罗维登斯和沃森已经将导师制作为一项经常性的工作，在瓦胡岛的各个公立高中为学生提供导师制，尽管军方领导人的工作日程繁忙而漫长。作为2016年12月发布的总司令指南的一部分，普罗维登斯将重点放在了人身上，这是三个方面之一。“我们永远不能忘记，我们的人民是我们成功的基础，是我们未来的关键，”普罗维登斯说。RHC-P的任务是为作战指挥官提供具备医疗准备的部队，以及在所有作战阶段提供医疗服务支持的医疗部队。

column2: Stories that Inspire- RHC-P Soldier finds gold
column3:
Sgt. Mayra Bendavid, a combat medic assigned to Regional Health Command-Pacific (RHC-P), struck gold recently.  She is one of the Army’s newest Green to Gold selectees.

As a Soldier and valued member of the RHC-P command team, her exposure to strategic level operations and engagements opened her eyes to a side of the Army she was not exposed to before. 

“I feel fortunate that this past year, I had the opportunity to work at the region. Getting that exposure from a command perspective and that level of leadership is invaluable,” stated Bendavid. “By being a part of the RHC-P command team, I better understand what it means to lead and inspire, because I see it every day.”

When Bendavid left for basic training on Valentine’s Day in 2011, she was prepared for anything. Growing up she was always athletic and knew she was physically fit. She knew she was mentally fit and ready as well.

“I’m usually a safe person when making decisions in my life, but joining the Army, I didn’t hesitate at all.  After basic training I was assigned to Ft. Riley, in Kansas,” recalls Bendavid. “I just wanted to be a Soldier and wanted to join. I’m glad I did it. Within six months I was deployed to Afghanistan.”

During the nine months she spent in Afghanistan she was part of a female engagement team.

“I was part of a female engagement team, where our mission was to engage with the local female population in Afghanistan. Each company or unit selected female Soldiers to work alongside the Afghani Army and police to train females for the Afghani National Army,” recalls Bendavid. 

“The Afghanis didn’t have any females within their ranks, or a training program in place, so we came together to design a training regime which included Soldiering skills such as clearing a room, and doing searches.”
As a combat medic, Bendavid taught first aid and first responder skills.

“The opportunity I had in Afghanistan was so rewarding; to see all the females, eager, wanting to learn. They quickly picked up on everything we taught. It is still one of the most rewarding moments in my Army career.”

This next step of becoming an officer is consistent with her experience in Afghanistan and her life’s ambition to take on missions that benefit the greater good; actions that enhance not just one person’s life but also the lives of those she works with and serves alongside. She also knows that she will be in a position to lead and inspire others, giving other deserving Soldiers a chance to make their mark in the Army, serving their country.

“Soldiers are vital to the success and longevity of our organization.  Becoming an officer allows me the privilege of guiding Soldiers every day, and also provides me the opportunity to learn, develop and lead Soldiers across any spectrum,”  says Bendavid.

When the idea of joining the Army first entered Bendavid’s mind, she had no idea that her decision to enlist would take her to the places she has already been and opened the door to places she still can go. 

“Growing up first generation-American, in a single-parent home with five siblings gave me a unique outlook on life. I was not born into privilege. At a young age I was taught the significance of hard work and that nothing of importance in life was easy. Although delayed by different career paths, I stayed true to my initial aspiration of becoming a Soldier and enlisted into the Army.”

“It was not until I joined the military that I found a sense of purpose and I immediately realized that I had finally found my true calling,” she added.

Bendavid’s success is due in part to her solid support group and encouragement from her command team. 

“Brig. Gen. Bertram Providence planted a seed,” says Bendavid. “He told me 90 percent of the job is showing up, not just physically, but understanding the impact on everyone else and the future.”

Capt. Corey Lester, former Aide-de-Camp to the RHC-P commanding general, and Bendavid’s mentor, was also a driving force.  As a green to gold graduate, he was able to provide guidance as she navigated through her own process.

“As a Green to Gold graduate, I know what kind of Soldier it takes to succeed in the program,” said Lester. “After working with Sgt. Bendavid, it was obvious to me that she would be a competitive candidate.  I know she will be a future leader in the Army and make an impact on the future of the military.”

Bendavid holds fast to the teachings she gained as a child, that nothing of importance comes easy. As she prepares to take on the honorable responsibility of becoming a more influential leader, she goes in with the ultimate goal of positively impacting the lives of Soldiers and the Army.

“It was not until I joined the military that I found a sense of purpose and I immediately realized that I had finally found my true calling. I have surpassed my expectations of my career within the Army. When I first joined, I never thought I would be on the path to becoming an officer.”  

Even though she is not sure where she will end up after earning her degree, she is willing to go anywhere. She knows she has a strong network of support which is not only a big part of why she achieved gold, but she knows that network will still be there when she needs it.

“I am forever thankful for that.”
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: 激发灵感的故事-RHC-P士兵发现黄金
column11: 梅拉・本大卫中士是太平洋地区卫生司令部（RHC-P）的一名战斗医疗兵，最近获得金牌。她是陆军最新的绿到金入选者之一。作为一名士兵和RHC-P指挥团队的重要成员，她在战略级作战和交战中的经历让她看到了陆军中她从未接触过的一面。Bendavid说：“我感到幸运的是，在过去的一年里，我有机会在该地区工作。从指挥角度和领导水平获得这种曝光是非常宝贵的。”。“作为RHC-P指挥团队的一员，我更好地理解领导和激励意味着什么，因为我每天都能看到。”2011年情人节，当Bendavid离开去参加基础训练时，她做好了一切准备。在成长过程中，她总是运动健将，知道自己身体健康。她知道自己心理健康，也做好了准备。“我通常在做人生决定时是一个安全的人，但参军时，我一点也不犹豫。经过基本训练后，我被分配到堪萨斯州的莱利堡，”本大卫回忆道。“我只是想成为一名士兵，想加入。我很高兴我做到了。在六个月内，我被部署到了阿富汗。”在她在阿富汗度过的九个月里，她是一个女性交战小组的一员。Bendavid回忆道：“我是女性参与团队的一员，我们的任务是与阿富汗当地女性人口进行接触。每个公司或单位都挑选女性士兵与阿富汗军队和警察一起为阿富汗国家军队培训女性。”。“阿富汗人的队伍中没有女性，也没有培训计划，所以我们一起设计了一套培训制度，其中包括打扫房间和搜查等士兵技能。”作为一名战斗医疗人员，本大卫教授急救和急救技能。“我在阿富汗得到的机会是非常有意义的；看到所有渴望学习的女性。她们很快学会了我们所教的一切。这仍然是我军旅生涯中最有意义的时刻之一。”成为一名军官的下一步与她在阿富汗的经历和她一生的雄心壮志是一致的，她希望承担有利于更大利益的任务；这些行动不仅能改善一个人的生活，而且能改善与她一起工作和服务的人的生活。她还知道，她将能够领导和激励其他人“士兵对我们组织的成功和长久至关重要。成为一名军官使我有机会每天指导士兵，也使我有机会学习、发展和领导各个方面的士兵，”Bendavid说，当参军的想法第一次进入Bendavid的脑海时，她不知道参军的决定会把她带到她已经去过的地方，并为她仍然可以去的地方打开了大门。“在一个有五个兄弟姐妹的单亲家庭中长大的第一代美国人给了我独特的人生观。我并非生来就享有特权。在我很小的时候，我就被教导努力工作的重要性，生活中没有什么重要的事是容易的。尽管由于不同的职业道路而耽误了我的时间，但我仍然忠于我最初的梦想：成为一名真正的美国人她补充道：“直到我参军后，我才发现了自己的使命感，我立即意识到我终于找到了自己真正的使命。”Bendavid的成功部分归功于她坚实的支持团队和指挥团队的鼓励。“伯特伦・普罗维登斯准将播下了一粒种子，”本大卫说，“他告诉我，90%的工作都在展现，不仅仅是身体上的，而是理解对其他人和未来的影响。”科里・莱斯特上尉（Corey Lester）是RHC-P司令部的前助理，也是本大卫的导师，也是一个推动力。作为一名从绿色到金色的毕业生，他能够在她自己的过程中提供指导。“作为一名从绿色到金色的毕业生，我知道需要什么样的士兵才能在项目中取得成功，”莱斯特说。“在与本大卫中士合作后，我很明显，她将成为一名有竞争力的候选人。我知道她将成为军队未来的领导者，并对军队的未来产生影响。”Bendavid坚持她小时候的教诲，认为重要的事情来之不易。当她准备承担起成为更有影响力领袖的光荣责任时，她最终的目标是积极影响士兵和军队的生活。“直到我参军，我才找到了目标感，我立即意识到我终于找到了真正的使命。我在军队中的职业生涯超出了我的期望。当我第一次参军时，我从未想过我会走上成为一名军官的道路。”尽管她不确定自己拿到学位后会去哪里，但她愿意去任何地方。她知道自己拥有强大的支持网络，这不仅是她获得金牌的一个重要原因，而且她知道，当她需要时，这种支持网络仍将存在。“我永远对此表示感谢。”

column2: Stories that Inspire- RHC-P Soldier finds gold
column3:
Sgt. Mayra Bendavid, a combat medic assigned to Regional Health Command-Pacific (RHC-P), struck gold recently.  She is one of the Army’s newest Green to Gold selectees.

As a Soldier and valued member of the RHC-P command team, her exposure to strategic level operations and engagements opened her eyes to a side of the Army she was not exposed to before. 

“I feel fortunate that this past year, I had the opportunity to work at the region. Getting that exposure from a command perspective and that level of leadership is invaluable,” stated Bendavid. “By being a part of the RHC-P command team, I better understand what it means to lead and inspire, because I see it every day.”

When Bendavid left for basic training on Valentine’s Day in 2011, she was prepared for anything. Growing up she was always athletic and knew she was physically fit. She knew she was mentally fit and ready as well.

“I’m usually a safe person when making decisions in my life, but joining the Army, I didn’t hesitate at all.  After basic training I was assigned to Ft. Riley, in Kansas,” recalls Bendavid. “I just wanted to be a Soldier and wanted to join. I’m glad I did it. Within six months I was deployed to Afghanistan.”

During the nine months she spent in Afghanistan she was part of a female engagement team.

“I was part of a female engagement team, where our mission was to engage with the local female population in Afghanistan. Each company or unit selected female Soldiers to work alongside the Afghani Army and police to train females for the Afghani National Army,” recalls Bendavid. 

“The Afghanis didn’t have any females within their ranks, or a training program in place, so we came together to design a training regime which included Soldiering skills such as clearing a room, and doing searches.”
As a combat medic, Bendavid taught first aid and first responder skills.

“The opportunity I had in Afghanistan was so rewarding; to see all the females, eager, wanting to learn. They quickly picked up on everything we taught. It is still one of the most rewarding moments in my Army career.”

This next step of becoming an officer is consistent with her experience in Afghanistan and her life’s ambition to take on missions that benefit the greater good; actions that enhance not just one person’s life but also the lives of those she works with and serves alongside. She also knows that she will be in a position to lead and inspire others, giving other deserving Soldiers a chance to make their mark in the Army, serving their country.

“Soldiers are vital to the success and longevity of our organization.  Becoming an officer allows me the privilege of guiding Soldiers every day, and also provides me the opportunity to learn, develop and lead Soldiers across any spectrum,”  says Bendavid.

When the idea of joining the Army first entered Bendavid’s mind, she had no idea that her decision to enlist would take her to the places she has already been and opened the door to places she still can go. 

“Growing up first generation-American, in a single-parent home with five siblings gave me a unique outlook on life. I was not born into privilege. At a young age I was taught the significance of hard work and that nothing of importance in life was easy. Although delayed by different career paths, I stayed true to my initial aspiration of becoming a Soldier and enlisted into the Army.”

“It was not until I joined the military that I found a sense of purpose and I immediately realized that I had finally found my true calling,” she added.

Bendavid’s success is due in part to her solid support group and encouragement from her command team. 

“Brig. Gen. Bertram Providence planted a seed,” says Bendavid. “He told me 90 percent of the job is showing up, not just physically, but understanding the impact on everyone else and the future.”

Capt. Corey Lester, former Aide-de-Camp to the RHC-P commanding general, and Bendavid’s mentor, was also a driving force.  As a green to gold graduate, he was able to provide guidance as she navigated through her own process.

“As a Green to Gold graduate, I know what kind of Soldier it takes to succeed in the program,” said Lester. “After working with Sgt. Bendavid, it was obvious to me that she would be a competitive candidate.  I know she will be a future leader in the Army and make an impact on the future of the military.”

Bendavid holds fast to the teachings she gained as a child, that nothing of importance comes easy. As she prepares to take on the honorable responsibility of becoming a more influential leader, she goes in with the ultimate goal of positively impacting the lives of Soldiers and the Army.
 
“It was not until I joined the military that I found a sense of purpose and I immediately realized that I had finally found my true calling. I have surpassed my expectations of my career within the Army. When I first joined, I never thought I would be on the path to becoming an officer.”  

Even though she is not sure where she will end up after earning her degree, she is willing to go anywhere. She knows she has a strong network of support which is not only a big part of why she achieved gold, but she knows that network will still be there when she needs it.

“I am forever thankful for that.”

column2: RHC-P leads facilitation of NIMS workshop at MEDCOM
column3:
HONOLULU -- Regional Health Command-Pacific (RHC-P) carries on its tradition of excellence by being the first organization in the active Army to independently, without on-site assistance from the Center for the Army Profession and Ethics (CAPE) and Army Research Institute (ARI) to implement the Not in My Squad (NIMS) workshop.  

RHC-P’s regional program manager, Master Sgt. Kevin Edmondson also met another significant milestone recently.  He was the lead facilitator during the Army Medicine (AMEDD) level workshop. Edmondson, along with RHC-P facilitators, worked alongside Sgt. Maj. Wendell Mullen, AMEDD’s, SHARP program manager, who led the workshop. 

“When I first participated in the NIMS workshop in 2016, I had no idea it would grow into the accomplishment it has become for the region,” states Master Sgt. Kevin Edmondson, RHC-P’s SHARP program manager. “After assisting with the facilitation of a NIMS workshop for the 25th Infantry Division, myself and RHC-P’s leadership team saw the benefits of bringing the NIMS program to all direct reporting units in the region.” 

The mission of the NIMS workshop is to help junior NCOs assess the state of mutual trust and cohesion within their squads and teams as well as gain situational understanding in an effort to build and improve dignity, respect and inclusion. 

“The workshop allows NCOs an opportunity to talk about the challenges they face while building and maintaining a positive climate on their teams and squads,” explains Edmondson. 

Participants gathered from nearly every geographical location in the Army. In attendance at the workshop session that took place March 1-3, in San Antonio, Texas, were 28 NCOs in the rank of sergeant through sergeant first class, from several different military occupational specialties (MOS).

Edmondson’s team of RHC-P assigned facilitators included Master Sgt. Teresa Wilson-Mitchell, Sgt. 1st Class Kristen Stall, Staff Sgt. India Marquez, Staff Sgt. Dawn Irvine and Staff Sgt. Trisha Ronk. The team of facilitators was chosen because of their previous experience and participation with the NIMS workshop. 

During the three day workshop participants discuss topics ranging from the role of squad leaders in building unit climate, how leaders build and maintain positive unit climates and building an Army-wide culture of dignity, respect, inclusion and trust. NIMS participants also worked collaboratively to provide command level leadership feedback from the group discussions so they can impact change when and where feasible.

As Edmondson reflects on his role as the region’s program coordinator, he reflects on his personal goals as a Soldier.

“For years, growing up in the Army, I always heard and often said, if I ever get to a rank where I can influence change, I will," reflects Edmondson. “This workshop empowers the most junior NCOs to implement change. They no longer need to reach the rank of sergeant major or be a command sergeant major to do so. This is their opportunity to shape the Army, and Army Medicine, for years to come.”

Edmondson and his team will continue conducting the NIMS workshops around the region at Joint Base Lewis-McChord, Wash. and Ft. Wainwright, Alaska in March and at Camp Zama, Japan and U.S. Army Garrison-Yongsan in June.
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: RHC-P领导在MEDCOM举办NIMS研讨会
column11: 檀香山――太平洋地区卫生司令部（RHC-P）继承了其卓越传统，成为现役陆军中第一个独立实施非我的小队（NIMS）研讨会的组织，无需陆军职业道德中心（CAPE）和陆军研究所（ARI）的现场协助。RHC-P的区域项目经理Kevin Edmondson上士最近也遇到了另一个重要里程碑。他是陆军医学（AMEDD）级研讨会的主要主持人。Edmondson与RHC-P协调员一起，与AMEDD的SHARP项目经理温德尔・马伦少校一起工作，后者领导了研讨会。RHC-P夏普项目经理凯文・埃德蒙森上士表示：“当我在2016年首次参加NIMS研讨会时，我不知道它会发展成为该地区的成就。”。“我和RHC-P的领导团队在协助为第25步兵师举办NIMS研讨会后，看到了将NIMS计划推广到该地区所有直接报告单位的好处。”NIMS研讨会的任务是帮助初级士官评估其团队和团队内的相互信任和凝聚力状态，并获得情境理解，以努力建立和改善尊严、尊重和包容。埃德蒙森解释说：“研讨会让士官们有机会谈论他们面临的挑战，同时为他们的团队和小队营造并保持积极的氛围。”。参与者几乎来自军队的每个地理位置。参加3月1日至3日在得克萨斯州圣安东尼奥举行的研讨会的有28名士官，从一等士官到一等士官，他们来自不同的军事职业专业（MOS）。埃德蒙森的RHC-P指定协调员团队包括特蕾莎・威尔逊・米切尔上士、克里斯汀・斯泰尔一等士官，印度马奎斯上士、道恩欧文上士和特里沙・朗克上士。推动者小组的选择是因为他们以前的经验和参与NIMS研讨会。在为期三天的研讨会中，学员们讨论了从班长在营造部队氛围中的作用、领导如何营造和保持积极的部队氛围，以及在全军范围内营造尊严、尊重、包容和信任的文化等话题。NIMS参与者还合作提供来自小组讨论的指挥级领导反馈，以便他们能够在可行的时间和地点影响变革。当埃德蒙森反思他作为该地区项目协调员的角色时，他反思了他作为士兵的个人目标。埃德蒙森反映道：“多年来，在军队长大，我总是听到并经常说，如果我能成为一名能够影响变革的人，我会的。”。“这个研讨会授权最初级的士官实施变革。他们不再需要达到军士长军衔或成为指挥军士长才能实现变革。这是他们在未来几年塑造军队和军队医学的机会。”埃德蒙森和他的团队将于3月在华盛顿州刘易斯・麦考德联合基地和阿拉斯加温赖特堡，以及6月在日本扎马营地和美国陆军驻军永山继续在该地区举办NIMS研讨会。

column2: RHC-P’s Inspector General provides objective guidance
column3:
HONOLULU C For nearly 231 years the Army’s Office of the Inspector General (OIG) has served commanders through its dedicated practice of investigating and providing guidance to Soldiers and civilians so they stand ready to complete their missions.  

As the new year begins, Regional Health Command-Pacific, also known as RHC-P’s, OIG continues with the mission of providing objective and impartial support to RHC-P’s active-duty and civilian staff with clarification and guidance on commonly misunderstood Army regulations, policies, procedures and best practices. 

“We build on the enduring excellence of the inspector general system and extend the RHC-P commander's eyes, ears, voice and conscience to create a more credible, reliable and knowledgeable organization, with a reputation for providing confidential and accurate assistance to Soldiers, family members, civilian staff and patients,” states Lt. Col. Vernon Wheeler, RHC-P command inspector general. “We thoroughly embrace and display the core Army values; teach and train Soldiers and adaptive leaders.”

As one of the commander’s representatives, the OIG resolves issues as the directing authority to deciding allegations of impropriety. The OIG investigates violations of policy, regulation or law, mismanagement, unethical behavior, fraud and misconduct. The office also provides a safe environment for employees to seek assistance. The OIG works to educate all involved parties and ensures concerns are resolved at the lowest level possible, facilitating complicated or confusing guidance and procedures but always following regional, Army Medicine and Army regulations, policies and procedures.

“We identify systemic trends and issues throughout RHC-P, Army Medicine and the Army,” says Wheeler. “Then we work to develop and assist with the implementation of solutions to emerging trends in support of organizational success.  The OIG is responsible for inquiring and reporting on the discipline, efficiency, economy, morale, training and readiness within Army units,” added Wheeler.

The OIG is always available for assistance, but first and foremost, those seeking assistance should use the resources available at their unit or office, giving those responsible an opportunity to assist in resolving concerns.  For example, employees with grievances can first use their chain of command to address issues. If personnel feel they are not being properly supported, the OIG may be able to assist, or know someone who can.

No matter where assistance is sought, confidentiality will be maintained as best as possible. The OIG does not make recommendations on punishments or adverse actions. This allows them to remain neutral and impartial while fact finding, supporting the policy and regulatory guidance in place.

RHC-P’s OIG has office locations at Tripler Army Medical Center and Madigan Army Medical Center in order to support the larger populations at those facilities.  If employees are not located at one of those centers they can seek assistance at one of the regional offices in Hawaii or Joint Base Lewis-McChord, Washington. However, anyone can submit a complaint, allegation or request for information or assistance to any Army OIG worldwide.

To find an OIG, use the new IG locator app available on iTunes. To download the apps, search "IG Locator" and "IG Bookshelf" in the iTunes App Store. The locator app is a digital directory that contains contact information for Army OIGs both in the U.S. and overseas, Individuals located in the Pacific region can also email usarmy.tripler.medcom-tamc.list.ig@mail.mil.
column9: 美国檀香山
column10: RHC-P的监察长提供客观指导
column11: 檀香山―近231年来，陆军监察长办公室（OIG）一直致力于调查和指导士兵和平民，让他们随时准备完成任务，为指挥官服务。新年伊始，太平洋地区卫生司令部（也称为RHC-P）的OIG将继续为RHC-P的现役和文职人员提供客观公正的支持，澄清和指导通常被误解的陆军法规、政策、程序和最佳做法。“我们以监察长制度的长期卓越性为基础，扩展RHC-P指挥官的眼睛、耳朵、声音和良知，创建一个更加可信、可靠和知识渊博的组织，以向士兵、家属、文职人员和患者提供机密和准确的援助而闻名。”表示RHC-P司令部监察长Vernon Wheeler中校。作为指挥官的代表之一，OIG作为决定不当行为指控的指导机构解决问题。OIG调查违反政策、法规或法律、管理不善、不道德行为、欺诈和不当行为。该办公室还为员工寻求帮助提供了一个安全的环境。OIG致力于教育所有相关方，确保在尽可能低的水平上解决问题，促进复杂或混乱的指导和程序，但始终遵循地区、陆军医学和陆军法规、政策和程序。惠勒说：“我们确定了整个RHC-P、陆军医学和陆军的系统性趋势和问题。”。“然后，我们致力于开发和协助实施新趋势的解决方案，以支持组织的成功。OIG负责查询和报告陆军部队的纪律、效率、经济、士气、训练和准备情况。”Wheeler补充道。OIG始终可以提供帮助，但首先，寻求帮助的人应使用其所在单位或办公室的可用资源，让负责人有机会帮助解决问题。例如，有不满的员工可以首先使用其指挥系统来解决问题。如果认为他们没有得到适当的支持，OIG可能能够提供帮助，或认识能够提供帮助的人。无论在哪里寻求帮助，都将尽可能保持保密。OIG不会就惩罚或不利行动提出建议。这使他们在调查事实、支持e政策和监管指导到位。RHC-P的OIG在Tripler陆军医疗中心和Madigan陆军医疗中心设有办公地点，以支持这些设施中的更多人口。如果员工不在其中一个中心，他们可以向夏威夷的一个区域办事处或Lewis McCho联合基地寻求帮助但是，任何人都可以向世界各地的任何陆军OIG提交投诉、指控或信息或援助请求。要查找OIG，请使用iTunes上提供的新IG定位器应用程序。要下载应用程序，请搜索“IG定位器”和“IG书架”在iTunes应用商店中。locator应用程序是一个数字目录，包含美国和海外陆军OIG的联系信息，太平洋地区的个人也可以发送电子邮件至usarmy.tripler.medcom-tamc.list。ig@mail.mil.

column2: 213th Regional Support Group attends FIT-P+
column3:
Story by Staff Sgt. Lorene Mauro

FORT INDIANTOWN GAP, Pa. C Fifty five Soldiers from the 213th Regional Support Group joined other Pennsylvania Army National Guard units in attending the fourth iteration of the new Fitness Improvement Training Program Plus here August 6-20.

Soldiers from the 213th Regional Support Group, 28th Combat Aviation Brigade, the 28th Infantry Division Headquarters and Headquarters Battalion and 55th Armor Brigade Combat Team attended and served as cadre for this iteration. 

FIT-P+ is a commander recommended 148 hour course.  During the 15 day course, participants attend classes and training events geared towards a healthier lifestyle, resiliency, and reinforcing the Warrior Ethos and Army core competencies, said Sgt. 1st Class Jon Gibbons, the Individual Training Branch noncommissioned officer-in-charge. 

The course is designed to employ the Army’s total Soldier concept, he said. Soldiers attend nutritional counseling and fitness classes as well as practicing Soldier skills such as marksmanship, land navigation, combatives and other individual common tasks, Gibbons continued.

Sgt. Donald J. MacKenzie, a flight medic with Foxtrot Company 1/169th Aviation Battalion, 28th Combat Aviation Brigade, 28th Infantry Division and a medic during this iteration said there is definitely an exercise component of the course, but it’s also a lot more than that.

“I think they do a good job of getting away from just the [physical fitness] part of it,” said MacKenzie.

Spc. Allan J. Hopperstead, a health care specialist from the 28th Military Police Company, 728th Combat Sustainment Support Battalion, 213th Regional Support Group and a medic for FIT-P+ said he was impressed with the classes given during the program. 

“The nutrition classes really inform and help really break down plans to support fitness goals and maintain an overall healthier lifestyle,” said Hopperstead.

Spc. Drew M. Workman, an information systems specialist from the Headquarters and Headquarters Company 728th Combat Sustainment Support Battalion, 213th Regional Support Group and a participant in the program, said he enjoyed attending the program.

“They should make this an [annual training] for everyone,” said Workman. “It’s awesome. It feels like I’m in the Army; it was fun shooting, ruck marching and doing land [navigation],” he said.

The Soldiers were weighed, taped if needed, and given a diagnostic Army Physical Fitness Test at the beginning and end of the program.

The 213th Regional Support Group Soldiers lost a total of 390 and altogether the 106 Soldiers that participated in this iteration lost 727 pounds; that’s about 7 pounds per Soldier, said Gibbons. APFT scores went up by about 38 points on average, he added. 
 
For more information ‘like’ the 213th Regional Support Group on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/213RSG
column6: FORT INDIANTOWN GAP, PA, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国宾夕法尼亚州印第安敦堡盖普
column10: 第213次区域支持小组出席FIT-P+
column11: 宾夕法尼亚州洛伦・莫罗夫特・印地安敦盖普中士的故事――第213区域支援小组的55名士兵与其他宾夕法尼亚州陆军国民警卫队部队一起参加了8月6日至20日在这里举行的新健身改善训练计划的第四次迭代。来自第213区域支援小组的士兵，第28战斗航空旅、第28步兵师总部和总部营以及第55装甲旅战斗队参加了本次迭代，并担任了干部。FIT-P+是指挥官推荐的148小时课程。在为期15天的课程中，学员将参加旨在培养更健康的生活方式、恢复力、强化战士精神和军队核心竞争力的课程和培训活动，个人培训处士官、一等兵Jon Gibbons中士说。他说，该课程旨在运用陆军的全兵概念。士兵们参加营养咨询和健身课程，并练习士兵技能，如射击、陆地航行、战斗和其他个人常见任务，吉本斯继续说道。Donald J.MacKenzie是狐步公司第1/169航空营、第28战斗航空旅、第28步兵师的一名飞行医护人员，也是本次迭代中的一名医护人员。他说，课程中肯定有一个锻炼部分，但也远不止于此。“我认为他们在摆脱[身体健康]方面做得很好。”部分原因，”MacKenzie.Spc说。Allan J.Hopperstead是第28宪兵连、第728战斗维持支援营、第213区域支援小组的医疗专家，也是FIT-P+的一名医生。他说，他对课程中的课程印象深刻。Hopperstead.Spc说：“营养课程确实提供了信息，帮助我们分解计划，以支持健身目标，保持整体健康的生活方式。”。德鲁・沃克曼（Drew M.Workman）是总部和总部公司第213区域支援小组第728战斗维持支援营的信息系统专家，也是该项目的参与者。他说，他很喜欢参加该项目。“他们应该让这成为每个人的[年度培训]。”沃克曼说。他说：“这太棒了。感觉就像我在军队里一样；这是一场有趣的射击、行进和陆上（导航）运动。”士兵们被称了体重，如果需要的话，被录音，并在项目开始和结束时进行了诊断性的陆军体能测试。第213个地区支援小组的士兵总共减掉了390磅，参加这次迭代的106名士兵总共减掉了727磅；“每个士兵大约7磅，”吉本斯说。他补充说，APFT的分数平均上升了38分左右。更多信息，如Facebook上的第213个区域支持小组https://www.facebook.com/213RSG

column2: Hickam CDDAR team raises P-3 Orion
column3:
KALAELOA, Hawaii - Airmen from the Hawaii Air National Guard 154th Maintenance Squadron (MXS), and active duty 15th MXS successfully completed a lift of a P-3 Orion Aircraft Jan. 27 at Kalaeloa Airport. 

Lifting of the P-3 was part of an annual training exercise for Hickam’s Crash, Damaged, Disabled Aircraft, Recovery (CDDAR) team. 

“It [CDDAR] is a team of highly trained and specialized maintainers who work to quickly remove and recover a disabled aircraft with the goal of minimizing additional damage,” said Maj. Brian S. Mix, 15th MXS commander. “By doing so we can re-open the airbase or airport as quickly as possible while hopefully maintaining the aircraft in such a condition that it can be fully repaired and returned to service.”

Once investigative and safety operations have been completed, the CDDAR team utilizes a wide range of techniques and equipment to safely remove a disabled aircraft. 

“The team's capabilities cover the full spectrum of incident responses from simply towing an aircraft out of the dirt to lifting it off the ground with specialized air bags and cranes,” said Mix. 

Lifting the P-3 required close coordination and constant communication between the personnel operating five separate lift bag stations and six tethering positions. The exercise provided an opportunity for both initial and recurrent training as well as the inspection of CDDAR equipment.

“The P-3 lift included challenges such as multiple lift stations, wing angle, weight and balance, and multiple team coordination,” said Chief Master Sgt. Edward Essman, 154th MXS Aircraft Maintenance manager. “Assigned team chiefs for the training had to safely coordinate the stations to evenly lift the P-3 to a working height that would allow a successful recovery.”

According to Essman, no one lift or recovery operation is the same; each situation requires a tailored approach. 

“Every scenario is different so what type of aircraft, where the incident occurred and what type of incident happened would factor into our response posture,” said Essman. “In most instances, we would be responding with the crash investigators and help them preserve any evidence to be used in their investigation.”

In addition to guard and active duty airmen, exercise participants included Army, Coast Guard and civilian personnel.

“Total force integration enjoyed here is important,” said Essman. “We enjoy working and training with multiple services and are able to share lessons learned and improve response capability by building off each other's knowledge.”

According to Essman, Hickam’s CDDAR team has been called to respond to a few real world instances. In each of those cases, training such as January’s P-3 lift has proven invaluable. 

“Few functions require more precise individual and team actions, yet are provided even fewer occasions in which the individual and team can become proficient through actual hands on experience,” said Essman.

Naval Air Museum Barbers Point provided the decommission P-3 aircraft used in the exercise.
column9: 卡莱洛，你好，美国
column10: 希卡姆CDDAR团队举起P-3猎户座
column11: 夏威夷卡莱洛――1月27日，来自夏威夷航空国民警卫队第154维修中队（MXS）和现役第15 MXS的飞行员在卡莱洛机场成功完成了一架P-3猎户座飞机的升空。提升P-3是希卡姆坠毁、受损、失效飞机恢复（CDDAR）团队年度训练演习的一部分。MXS第15指挥官Brian S.Mix少校说：“CDDAR是一支训练有素的专业维修队伍，他们致力于快速拆除和修复失效的飞机，目的是最大限度地减少额外的损害。”。“通过这样做，我们可以尽快重新开放空军基地或机场，同时希望将飞机保持在可以完全维修和恢复使用的状态。”一旦调查和安全行动完成，CDDAR团队利用广泛的技术和设备安全地移除一架失效的飞机。Mix说：“该团队的能力涵盖了从简单地将飞机从泥土中拖出来，到使用专用气囊和起重机将其吊离地面的全方位事故响应。”。提升P-3需要在操作五个单独的提升袋站和六个栓系位置的人员之间进行密切协调和持续沟通。此次演习为初始和定期培训以及CDDAR设备检查提供了机会。“P-3升降机包括多个升降站、机翼角度、重量和平衡以及多个团队协调等挑战，”MXS第154号飞机维修经理爱德华・埃斯曼少校说。“指定的负责训练的队长必须安全地协调各站，将P-3均匀地提升到工作高度，以便成功地进行恢复。”埃斯曼说，没有任何一种提升或恢复操作是相同的；每种情况都需要量身定制的方法。“每种情况都是不同的，所以什么类型的飞机、事件发生在哪里以及发生了什么类型的事件都会影响我们的反应态势，”埃斯曼说。“在大多数情况下，我们将与坠机调查人员一起作出反应，并帮助他们保存任何证据，以用于调查。”除了警卫和现役飞行员，演习参与者还包括陆军、海岸警卫队和文职人员。“在这里，部队的全面整合非常重要，”议员说。“我们喜欢使用多种服务进行工作和培训，能够分享经验教训，并通过相互学习提高响应能力。”Essman表示，Hickam的CDDAR团队已经接到电话，以响应一些真实世界的实例。在每一种情况下，1月份的P-3升降机等训练都被证明是非常宝贵的。“很少有功能需要更精确的个人和团队行动，但提供给个人和团队通过实际实践经验变得熟练的机会更少，”议员说。海军航空博物馆巴伯斯角提供了演习中使用的退役P-3飞机。

column2: Mongolian Chief Medical Officer visits the RHC-P
column3:
HONOLULU - The Regional Health Command-Pacific (RHC-P) recently had the pleasure of having Lt. Col. Ganchimeg Lkhagvasuren, Chief Medical Officer for the Mongolian Armed Forces, visit the Oahu based RHC-P Military Health Readiness Platforms, Dec. 14-17, 2015. 

Lkhagvasuren’s visit continues the RHC-P's focus on medical diplomacy throughout the Indo-Asia-Pacific area of responsibility; sharing medical technologies, approaches, and best practices for the betterment of health throughout the region. 

The Mongolian military has a rich tradition of female Soldiers serving in leadership positions. During ancient times Genghis Khan appointed his daughters as Army Combat Generals and some women were Mongol city commanders.

In today's Mongolian Military Force, which averages around 25,000 Service Members, there are only 20 female officers who are at the rank of Lt. Col; none higher.

Lkhagvasuren will soon break that barrier, as she has been selected to be promoted to the rank of Colonel in the very near future; which will make her the highest ranking female officer in the Mongolian Armed Forces. 

During her visit to the RHC-P Headquarters, Lkhagvasuren met with RHC-P's Command Team, Brig General Patrick Sargent and Command Sgt. Maj. Robert Luciano, and she was able to ascertain RHC-P's approach to Access to Care and Army Medicine's philosophy of providing High Reliability Healthcare. 

She also had the opportunity to learn about the operational aspect of managing Army Medicine's largest region and she visited RHC-P's largest Health Readiness Platform, Tripler Army Medical Center (TAMC), where she saw how world class healthcare is provided on a large scale, as well as how a teaching hospital develops young healthcare providers into seasoned professionals.

Lkhagvasuren also met with RHC-P's Veteran Affairs partners here on Oahu, the VA Pacific Islands Healthcare System, where she and the VA staff discussed the differences and similarities between providing healthcare to the veterans of Mongolia and the United States. 

Lkhagvasuren took the opportunity during her time at TAMC to provide a presentation to the staff on the "Healthcare in the Mongolian Military Medical System". Those in attendance had the chance to see the challenges faced and approaches taken by Lkhagvasuren, and her team, as they provide healthcare to Mongolian force.

Perhaps one of the most interesting stops on her tour was Lkhagvasuren’s visit to the Fisher House - Tripler Army Medical Center. 

There, Lkhagvasuren seemed to thoroughly enjoy learning about Zachary and Elizabeth Fisher and their dedication to the Service Men and Women of the United States Armed Forces, as well as seeing how we use the Fisher House to support patients and family members who need a place to stay during periods of hospitalization and recovery, and she really enjoyed meeting the guests and experiencing the "Aloha Spirit" that only the Fisher House here in Hawaii can provide. 

Lkhagvasuren completed her week with a tour of the United States Army Health Clinic-Schofield Barracks (USAHC-SB) and the Warrior Transition Battalion-Hawaii, where she saw how Army Medicine directly impacts the War Fighter and their families. 

All-in-all, the week that Lkhagvasuren toured the RHC-P footprint was a great success in the continued efforts of building & strengthening professional medical relationships with the partner nations within the Pacific region. She was able to share as much about her healthcare system, as she obtained about the RHC-P's system for health.

Perhaps on her next visit, she can share how what she learned here, helped her develop the healthcare provided to the Mongolian Armed Forces.
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: 蒙古首席医疗官访问RHC-P
column11: 檀香山-太平洋地区卫生司令部（RHC-P）最近有幸邀请蒙古武装部队首席医疗官甘吉梅格・勒哈格瓦苏伦中校于2015年12月14日至17日参观了位于瓦胡岛的RHC-P军事卫生准备平台。Lkhagvasuren的访问继续了RHC-P对整个印度-亚太责任区医疗外交的关注；分享医疗技术、方法和最佳实践，以改善整个地区的健康状况。蒙古军队有着女性士兵担任领导职务的丰富传统。在古代，成吉思汗任命他的女儿为陆军作战将领，一些妇女担任蒙古城市指挥官。在今天平均约25000名服役人员的蒙古军队中，只有20名女军官担任中校军衔；没有比这更高的了。哈格瓦苏伦很快就会打破这一障碍，因为她已被选中在不久的将来晋升为上校；这将使她成为蒙古武装部队中级别最高的女军官。在访问RHC-P总部期间，Lkhagvasuren会见了RHC-P的指挥团队Patrick Sargent准将和指挥中士Robert Luciano少校，她能够确定RHC-P获得护理的方法和陆军医学提供高可靠性医疗的理念。她还有机会了解了管理陆军医学最大区域的运作方面，并参观了RHC-P最大的健康准备平台Tripler陆军医学中心（TAMC），在那里她看到了如何大规模提供世界一流的医疗服务，以及教学医院如何将年轻的医疗保健提供者培养成经验丰富的专业人员。Lkhagvasuren还与RHC-P的资深事务合作伙伴在瓦胡岛（弗吉尼亚州太平洋岛屿医疗系统）会面，在那里，她和退伍军人协会的工作人员讨论了为蒙古和美国退伍军人提供医疗服务的异同。Lkhagvasuren在TAMC期间利用这个机会向工作人员介绍了“蒙古军事医疗系统中的医疗保健”。与会者有机会看到Lkhagvasuren及其团队在为蒙古军队提供医疗保健服务时所面临的挑战和采取的方法。Lkhagvasuren此行最有趣的一站可能是参观Fisher House-Tripler陆军医疗中心。在那里，Lkhagvasuren似乎非常喜欢了解Zachary和Elizabeth Fisher以及他们对美国武装部队男女军人的奉献精神，也很喜欢看到我们如何利用Fisher House来支持住院和康复期间需要住宿的患者和家庭成员，她真的很喜欢会见客人，体验“阿罗哈精神”，只有夏威夷的费舍尔之家才能提供这种精神。Lkhagvasuren结束了她的一周，参观了美国陆军健康诊所Schofield Barracks（USAHC-SB）和夏威夷勇士过渡营，在那里她看到了陆军医学如何直接影响战士及其家人。总而言之，Lkhagvasuren参观RHC-P足迹的那一周是与太平洋地区伙伴国家建立和加强专业医疗关系的持续努力的一个巨大成功。她能够分享关于她的医疗系统的信息，就像她获得的关于RHC-P的医疗系统的信息一样。也许在下次访问中，她可以分享她在这里学到的知识，帮助她发展向蒙古武装部队提供的医疗保健。

column2: Vanguard Brigade first to equip with JBC-P upgrade
column3:
FORT STEWART, Ga. C The 4th Infantry Brigade Combat Team, or the Vanguard Brigade, of 3rd Infantry Division, is the first unit in the Army to be fielded the new Joint Battle Command-Platform, or JBC-P.

“It's primarily a situational awareness system,” said Col. Michael Thurston, the project manager of Mission Command with the Army’s Program Executive Office for Command, Control and Communications-Tactical. “The display shows a map of the area you're operating in, very much like a GPS.”

Thurston said JBC-P, which is a software upgrade to current tracking systems, can display friendly forces, opposing forces, obstacle information and graphics as well as mission essential information. All information can flow two ways from individual vehicles to higher and lower commands, and back down again. Thurston added it also builds on the command systems already in place.

The Vanguard Brigade was chosen as the first unit in the Army to field their vehicles and tactical operation centers with the upgraded software based on a few criteria, but the brigade commander, Col. Thomas Gukeisen, helped the brigade live up to their motto, “Out Front.”

“[Gukeisen] had seen the capability and he lobbied to get it into this unit because he wanted to be the first one to have it in the Army,” said Thurston.

“When you look at technology in the military, it's either evolutionary or revolutionary, and seeing what this can do, it's revolutionary,” said Gukeisen. “I saw this capability, so I asked if we could be the first unit equipped. I said I would love to have this system.”

Gukeisen's request was granted and the JBC-P fielding and training started early January and is scheduled to be complete by March this year. Pfc. Dajuan Gibson, a system support specialist with Headquarters and Headquarters Company, 4th IBCT, attended the operator course, as well as the maintainer course, which has enabled him to teach others.

“I think it'll benefit us because it's easier to teach,” said Gibson. “I could get people in an area and show them how to use it in a matter of minutes.”

Gibson noted the system is similar in some respects to the current systems, but the upgrade provides a more streamlined user-friendly interface.

“It has a little circle that has all different kinds of icons, and you just click on what you need,” Gibson said. “Everything is right there instead of having to look in different places.” 

Thurston visited the Vanguard Brigade, Jan. 21, during the beginning of a three-month brigade level exercise, Vanguard Focus, to assess how the fielding and training on the new system was progressing to help improve the program.

Thurston said the brigade’s training schedule allowed his team to see how the system is being used right away, unlike sometimes when new systems may be stored away until training is planned. “We get a lot of great feedback,” he added.

Gukeisen said the Vanguard Brigade will continue to give feedback on JBC-P during Vanguard Focus and beyond, such as during the brigade's scheduled summer rotation at the Joint Readiness Training Center, in Fort Polk, Louisiana.

“I think it's the future, I don't even think we've fully explored it, and that's the job of the first unit equipped, is to explore it,” said Gukeisen. “Now we're putting it through its full rigors.”
 
“From our perspective,” Thurston said, “we've got a great unit here with 4/3 ID that's fully embraced the new equipment fielding.”
column9: 美国佐治亚州斯图尔特堡
column10: 先锋旅首次装备JBC-P升级版
column11: 斯图尔特堡，佐治亚州――第三步兵师的第四步兵旅战斗队或先锋旅是陆军中第一个部署新联合作战指挥平台（JBC-P）的部队。“它主要是一个态势感知系统，”迈克尔・瑟斯顿上校说，陆军项目执行办公室的任务指挥部项目经理，负责指挥、控制和战术通信。Thurston说，JBC-P是对现有跟踪系统的软件升级，可以显示友军、敌军、障碍物信息和图形以及任务基本信息。所有信息可以通过两种方式从单个车辆流向上级和下级命令，然后再返回。瑟斯顿补充说，它还建立在现有指挥系统的基础上。先锋旅被选为陆军中第一个使用基于一些标准的升级软件部署车辆和战术作战中心的部队，但旅指挥官托马斯・古凯森上校帮助该旅实现了他们的座右铭“前线”瑟斯顿说：“[古凯森]已经看到了这种能力，他游说将其加入这支部队，因为他想成为第一个在军队中拥有这种能力的人。古凯森说：“当你观察军队中的技术时，它要么是进化的，要么是革命性的，看看它能做什么，它就是革命性的。”。“我看到了这种能力，所以我问我们是否可以成为第一个装备这种系统的单位。我说我很想拥有这种系统。”Gukeisen的请求得到了批准，JBC-P的部署和训练于1月初开始，计划于今年3月完成。总部和第四IBCT总部公司的系统支持专家Pfc.Dajuan Gibson参加了操作员课程和维护人员课程，这使他能够教授其他人。吉布森说：“我认为这将使我们受益，因为它更容易教学。我可以让人们在一个地区，并在几分钟内告诉他们如何使用它。”吉布森指出，该系统在某些方面与当前的系统相似，但升级提供了更精简的用户友好界面。吉布森说：“它有一个小圆圈，上面有各种各样的图标，你只需点击你需要的东西，一切都在那里，而不必看不同的地方。”1月21日，在为期三个月的旅级演习“先锋焦点”开始期间，瑟斯顿访问了先锋旅，以评估新系统的部署和训练进展如何，以帮助改进该计划。瑟斯顿说，该旅的训练日程安排使他的团队能够立即了解该系统的使用情况，而不是有时，新系统可能会被储存起来，直到训练计划完成。“我们得到了很多很好的反馈，”他补充道。古凯森说，先锋旅将在先锋集中训练期间和以后继续对JBC-P提供反馈，例如在该旅计划在路易斯安那州波尔克堡联合战备训练中心的夏季轮换期间。古凯森说：“我认为这是未来，我甚至不认为我们已经对它进行了充分的探索，而装备的第一支部队的工作就是探索它。现在我们正在对它进行全面的测试。”“从我们的角度来看，”瑟斯顿说，“我们这里有一支拥有4/3 ID的伟大部队，它完全接受了新装备的部署。”

column2: P-S GAR participates in first National Police Week
column3:
PETERSON AIR FORCE BASE, Colo. C National Police Week is a time set aside to honor the men and women of law enforcement at the local, state and federal level. This is also a time to remember officers who have given their lives in the line of duty.  

In 1962, President John F. Kennedy signed Public Law 87-726 designating May 15 as Peace Officers' Memorial Day. May 10 through May 15, 2021, is designated as National Police Week.

Although the holiday has been celebrated throughout the Department of Defense for 59 years, this year marked the newly formed Peterson-Schriever Garrison’s first opportunity to participate in National Police Week, with the 21st Security Forces Squadron, 50th Security Forces Squadron, and Office of Special Investigation Detachments 803 and 807 participating together in morale and remembrance events.

“Our unit, along with the other Front Range security forces units, held several activities throughout the week to pay special recognition to law enforcement officers, OSI agents and SF members who have made the supreme sacrifices in the line of duty for the safety and protection of others,” said Tim Omdal, 21st SFS deputy director. “Each of the activities during the past week allowed us to honor the fallen officers and renew our solemn vow to never forget their sacrifices and the families they left behind.”

The week’s events included a shooting competition at Schriever Air Force Base; an obstacle course at the U.S. Air Force Academy; and a police exposition, a golf tournament, and flag football at Peterson AFB.

“At the end of the day our desired outcome is to come together as one,” said Senior Airman Roderick Silvers, 21st SFS investigator. “It’s good to take a break and enjoy the time spent together in a safe environment, share some stories, make new friends and of course build some comradery with a few competitions to take home some hardware and bragging rights!”
column9: 美国科罗拉多州斯普林斯
column10: P-S GAR参加第一个国家警察周
column11: 科罗拉多州彼得森空军基地――国家警察周是专门用来纪念地方、州和联邦各级执法人员的时间。这也是一个纪念为执行任务而献出生命的军官的时刻。1962年，约翰・肯尼迪总统签署了第87-726号公法，将5月15日定为和平官员阵亡将士纪念日。2021年5月10日至5月15日被指定为国家警察周。尽管国防部59年来一直在庆祝这个节日，但今年是新组建的彼得森・施里弗驻军首次有机会参加国家警察周，第21安全部队中队，第50安全部队中队和特别调查分队办公室803和807一起参加士气和纪念活动。“我们的部队和其他前线安全部队部队在一周内举行了几次活动，以特别表彰执法人员、现场视察人员和SF成员，他们在履行职责时为他人的安全和保护做出了最大牺牲，”第21届SFS副总监Tim Omdal说。“过去一周的每一次活动都让我们能够向牺牲的军官致敬，并重申我们的庄严誓言，永远不会忘记他们的牺牲和他们留下的家人。”本周的活动包括施里弗空军基地的射击比赛；美国空军学院的障碍训练场；彼得森空军基地的警察博览会、高尔夫比赛和旗子足球。“最终，我们期望的结果是团结一致，”第21届SFS调查员、高级飞行员罗德里克・西尔弗斯（Roderick Silvers）说。“休息一下，在一个安全的环境中享受在一起的时光，分享一些故事，结交新朋友，当然，通过几场比赛建立一些同志关系，带回家一些硬件和吹牛的权利，这很好！”

column2: HRMC docks USS William P. Lawrence for maintenance availability
column3:
PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii C Hawaii Regional Maintenance Center (HRMC) docked Arleigh Burke-class guided-missile destroyer USS William P. Lawrence (DDG 110) March 9, completing one of the first major milestones in the ship’s docking selected restricted availability (DSRA).

This will be the second time HRMC has partnered with Vigor Marine, LLC to complete a surface ship DSRA at Pearl Harbor Naval Shipyard & Intermediate Maintenance Facility (PHNSY & IMF).

“We are thrilled to get underway with William P. Lawrence’s availability and look forward to a successful partnership with ship’s force and Vigor Marine,” said Capt. Daniel Kidd, HRMC Deputy Commander. “The work the team will complete during this scheduled maintenance period will help maintain and modernize this mighty warship so that she can get back to sea executing the Navy’s mission.”

DSRAs are routine maintenance availabilities planned in advance allowing the ship to receive necessary repairs, maintenance and modernization to ensure it operates at full technical capacity and mission capability for its entire designed service life. The ship will also receive a major combat systems installation to provide critical upgrades to its communication capabilities. In all, the planned work is expected to require more than 50,000 man-days to complete.

“We all have a sense of excitement as we begin the availability knowing our work directly impacts the Navy’s mission,” said HRMC William P. Lawrence Project Manager J.C. "Harry" Herrera. “The HRMC and Vigor team is laser-focused on executing first-time quality work that will return the ship back to sea on time for her crew.”

This DSRA marks the first time PHNSY & IMF docked a berthing and messing barge alongside a ship in Dry Dock 4. The barge provides working and living spaces for the ship’s crew when services such as berthing, climate control, food service, and water supply are not available on board during the availability. Due to scheduled repairs on the pier adjoining the dry dock, the barge could not be moored in its usual berth. Seeking an innovative solution, the shipyard docking team and HRMC determined docking the barge would allow the crew to have quick access to the ship throughout the availability.

The expected cost of William P. Lawrence’s DSRA is approximately $90 million, accounting for a part of the estimated $250 million in surface ship maintenance contracting executed throughout fiscal years 2020 and 2021 by PHNSY & IMF. With a combined civilian and military workforce of approximately 6,500 along with 700 contractors, the shipyard has an annual economic impact of $1 billion.

PHNSY & IMF is a field activity of Naval Sea Systems Command and a one-stop regional maintenance center for the Navy’s surface ships and submarines. It is the largest industrial employer in the state of Hawaii. It is the most comprehensive fleet repair and maintenance facility between the U.S. West Coast and the Far East, strategically located in the heart of the Pacific, being about a week’s steaming time closer to potential regional contingencies in the Indo-Pacific.

For more news from Pearl Harbor Naval Shipyard & IMF, visit navsea.navy.mil/Home/Shipyards/PHNS-IMF or facebook.com/PearlHarborNavalShipyard.
column9: 珍珠港，你好，美国
column10: HRMC停靠威廉・P・劳伦斯号军舰，以获取维修可用性
column11: 夏威夷珍珠港―夏威夷地区维修中心（HRMC）于3月9日停靠了美国海军威廉・P・劳伦斯号（DDG 110）阿利・伯克级导弹驱逐舰，完成了该舰停靠选定限制可用性（DSRA）的首批重要里程碑之一。这将是HRMC第二次与活力海军陆战队合作，人力资源管理委员会副指挥官丹尼尔・基德上尉说：“我们很高兴威廉・P・劳伦斯的到来，并期待着与该船的部队和活力海军陆战队建立成功的合作关系。”。“团队将在计划维护期间完成的工作将有助于对这艘强大的军舰进行维护和现代化，使其能够返回海上执行海军任务。”DSRA是预先计划的日常维护可用性，允许该舰接受必要的维修，维护和现代化，以确保其在整个设计使用寿命内以全技术能力和任务能力运行。该舰还将安装一个大型作战系统，为其通信能力提供关键升级。总的来说，计划中的工作预计需要超过50000个工作日才能完成。HRMC William P.Lawrence项目经理J.C.“Harry”Herrera说：“我们都有一种兴奋感，因为我们知道我们的工作直接影响海军的任务。”。“HRMC和Energy团队致力于执行第一次高质量工作，使船舶能够按时返回大海，为船员服务。”该DSRA标志着PHNSY&IMF首次在干船坞4将一艘停泊和清理驳船停靠在船舶旁边。当船舶在可用期内无法提供停泊、气候控制、食品服务和供水等服务时，驳船为船员提供工作和生活空间。由于计划对靠近干船坞的码头进行维修，驳船无法系泊在其常规泊位上。为了寻求创新的解决方案，造船厂船坞团队和HRMC决定将驳船停靠在船坞上，使船员能够在整个可用期内快速接近船舶。William P.Lawrence的DSRA的预计成本约为9000万美元，占PHNSY和IMF在2020和2021财年执行的估计2.5亿美元水面船舶维修合同的一部分。该造船厂拥有约6500名文职和军事人员以及700名承包商，每年产生10亿美元的经济影响。PHNSY和IMF是海军海洋系统司令部的一项现场活动，是海军水面舰艇和潜艇的一站式区域维修中心。它是夏威夷州最大的工业雇主。它是美国西海岸和远东之间最全面的舰队维修和维护设施，战略性地位于太平洋中心，距离印度-太平洋地区潜在的区域突发事件大约一周的航行时间。有关珍珠港海军造船厂和国际货币基金组织的更多消息，访问navsea.navy.mil/Home/shippyards/PHNS-IMF或facebook.com/pearlharbornavalshippyard。

column2: P-S GAR safety conducts confined spaces training
column3:
The Peterson-Schriever Garrison safety office led a confined spaces training in collaboration with the 21st Medical Squadron bioenvironmental flight and the Schriever Fire Department Sept. 24 at Schriever Air Force Base, Colorado, to ensure the 50th Space Communications Squadron members could execute their duty requirements.

According to the P-S GAR safety office, a confined space is an area with a limited means of getting in and out, is not meant for consistent work and is just large enough to enter. This particular training was conducted at a manhole on base.

Some of the hazards of entering confined spaces on base include oxygen deficiencies, encounters with wild life and exposure to vehicle exhaust.

“Sometimes we get complacent to hazards associated with our jobs because we do it every day,” said Tech. Sgt. Christopher Boze, P-S GAR occupational safety manager. “By doing this training, it’s a refresher for the units involved and can ultimately help bring the workers home at the end of the day.”

Without the training event, bioenvironmental and the fire department would be required to be in attendance at every entry into a confined space. The 50th SCS is planning on entering every manhole with communications lines running beneath them within the next year.

“We’re there to ensure [those going in the confined spaces are] following [Occupational Safety and Health Administration] and Air Force Standards,” said Master Sgt. Ashley Smith, P-S GAR safety superintendent. “Confined spaces is one of our scariest programs because someone could die if we don’t follow the proper protocols.”

The event also served as an opportunity for the Schriever Fire Department to test their response time.

“Multi-Agency Training makes us better prepared for a more effective emergency response for the base and the mission,” said Tracey Snyder, Schriever Fire Department assistant chief of training. “The department’s response time far exceeded [our goals.]”
column6: SCHRIEVER AIR FORCE BASE, CO, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国科罗拉多州施里弗空军基地
column10: P-S GAR安全部门开展受限空间培训
column11: 9月24日，在科罗拉多州施里弗空军基地，彼得森・施里弗驻军安全办公室与第21医疗中队生物环境飞行队和施里弗消防局合作，领导了一次密闭空间培训，为了确保第50空间通信中队成员能够执行其职责要求。根据P-S GAR安全办公室的说法，受限空间是进出手段有限的区域，不适合连续工作，只适合进入。这项特别的培训是在基地的一个检修孔中进行的。进入基地密闭空间的一些危险包括缺氧、遭遇野生动物和暴露在汽车尾气中。“有时我们对与工作相关的危险感到自满，因为我们每天都这样做，”技术中士克里斯托弗・博兹说，P-S GAR职业安全经理。“通过进行培训，这是相关单位的复习，最终有助于在一天结束时将工人带回家。”如果没有培训活动，生物环境和消防部门将被要求在每次进入受限空间时都到场。第50届SCS计划在明年内进入每个检修孔，检修孔下方铺设通信线路。P-S GAR安全总监Ashley Smith上士说：“我们在那里确保[进入密闭空间的人员]遵守[职业安全与健康管理]和空军标准。”。“密闭空间是我们最恐怖的项目之一，因为如果我们不遵守适当的协议，可能会有人死亡。”该活动还为施里弗消防局提供了一个测试其响应时间的机会。“多机构培训使我们能够更好地为基地和任务的更有效应急响应做好准备。”施里弗消防局培训副局长特雷西・斯奈德说。“该部门的响应时间远远超过[我们的目标]。”

column2: P-S GAR gains new space intelligence squadrons
column3:
The U.S. Space Force activated the 71st and 72nd Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance Squadrons Sept. 11, 2020, at Peterson-Schriever Garrison, Colorado.

The squadrons, which fall under Space Delta 7, made history as one of the first space intelligence squadrons activated in the USSF.

“The realignment of intelligence forces under the U.S. Space Force represents a generational opportunity to re-think the way we apply intelligence support to operations both in space and other supported domains,” said Senior Master Sgt. Justin Michaels, 71st ISRS superintendent. “It represents a chance for us to approach mission requirements in innovative ways that allows us to better understand the threat environment and ensure the safety and protection of our forces.”

Maj. Michael Harter, 71st ISRS commander, said the squadron presents intelligence support to all the Space Mission Deltas across the USSF. The unit provides intelligence professionals from six geographically separated detachments to work directly with space operators.

“We provide operational intelligence on adversary actions and reactions so space operators can best posture themselves to accomplish their mission,” Harter said.

Also operating on Peterson, with three geographically separated detachments, the 72nd ISRS provides tactically focused intelligence analysis, exploitation and reporting for the joint warfighter.

“We know the adversary is actively using space to do subversive and dangerous things,” said Maj. Kimberly Templer, 72nd ISRS commander.

One of the primary advantages of the ISR squadrons within the USSF, directly under Space ISR Delta 7, is the dissemination and utilization of operational intelligence in an expeditious, timely and efficient manner. 

Depending on the missions of the specific detachments, the units work on a 24/7 schedule. “It’s important for us to be aware of what we’re doing across Delta 7, because we all have a piece of the puzzle and to be able to put those pieces together is huge,” Templer said. “Even though the ISR squadrons and detachments are in different pockets of the space domain, it’s a symbiotic relationship.”

Operations in the space domain not only impact the military, but also have significant economic and communications implications for the global population, said Senior Master Sgt. Caleb Lloyd, 72nd ISRS superintendent.

“The American way of life is heavily reliant on the capabilities and assets the Space Force provides,” Lloyd said. “It’s our job to identify threats and understand adversary capabilities and intent so we can provide sound assessments to our senior leaders [so they can] make time-critical decisions on how we protect and defend.”
column6: SCHRIEVER AIR FORCE BASE, COLORADO, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国科罗拉多州施里弗空军基地
column10: P-S GAR获得新的空间情报中队
column11: 美国航天部队于2020年9月11日在科罗拉多州彼得森・施里弗（Peterson Schriever）加里森（Garrison）启动了第71和72情报监视和侦察中队。该中队隶属于太空三角洲7号（Space Delta 7），是美国空军首批启动的太空情报中队之一，创造了历史。第71届ISRS总监贾斯汀・迈克尔斯（Justin Michaels）高级军士长说：“美国航天部队的情报力量重组代表了一次新的机会，让我们重新思考如何将情报支持应用于太空和其他支持领域的行动。”。“这为我们提供了一个以创新方式处理任务要求的机会，使我们能够更好地了解威胁环境，确保我们部队的安全和保护。”第71任ISRS指挥官迈克尔・哈特少校说，该中队向整个USSF的所有空间任务三角洲提供情报支持。该部队提供来自六个地理位置不同的分遣队的情报专业人员，直接与空间操作员合作。“我们提供有关敌方行动和反应的作战情报，以便空间运营商能够以最佳姿态完成任务。”第72 ISRS也在彼得森作战，拥有三个地理位置不同的分遣队，为联合作战人员提供以战术为重点的情报分析、利用和报告。“我们知道对手正在积极利用太空进行颠覆和危险活动。”第72任ISR指挥官金伯利・坦普尔少校说。USSF内直接隶属于空间ISR Delta 7的ISR中队的主要优势之一是以快速、及时和高效的方式传播和利用作战情报。根据具体分遣队的任务，这些分队按24/7计划工作邓普勒说：“对我们来说，意识到我们在德尔塔7上所做的事情很重要，因为我们都有一块拼图，能够把这些拼图拼在一起是巨大的。即使ISR中队和分遣队位于太空领域的不同区域，这也是一种共生关系。”“太空领域的行动不仅影响军事，而且对全球人口具有重大的经济和通信影响，”高级少校、第72届ISRS总监Caleb Lloyd说。“美国的生活方式严重依赖于太空部队提供的能力和资产，”Lloyd说。“我们的工作是识别威胁，了解对手的能力和意图，以便我们能够向我们的高级领导提供合理的评估[以便他们]就我们如何保护和防御做出时间关键的决定。”

column2: P-S GAR preps for fiscal year close out
column3:
SCHRIEVER AIR FORCE BASE, Colo. C The Peterson-Schriever Garrison ramps up its activity as it aims to fulfill projects across both bases as the fiscal year closes Sept. 30.

During the fiscal year, which began from Oct. 1, the 21st Comptroller Squadron and 50th Contracting Squadron provide units funds to finance their missions.  

Throughout the close-out process, it’s important Airmen maintain good communication to fulfill projects. The close out includes multiple units and they must coordinate to ensure mission success.

“That necessary communication needs to occur between not only members of the squadron, but also between us and our teammates around this location and [U.S. Space Force Headquarters],” said Capt. Jeremy Lacewell, 21st CPTS director of operations.   

This connection includes the 50th CONS, which manages the government purchase card program and writes contracts to fulfill funding.   

Without the preparation from the mission partners, budget office and the contracting office, Staff Sgt. Arron Riffle, 50th CONS contracting officer, said the fiscal year close out wouldn’t be as successful.  

“The end of the fiscal year is about ensuring the appropriated funds are obligated before they expire [at midnight Sept. 30],” Riffle said. “All of that [work] is meaningless unless we are providing the supplies and services that the units need to be successful in their objectives.” 

The CPTS currently has 85 projects and requirements it plans to fund and Master Sgt. Wilfredo Mateo, 21st CPTS Financial Analysis flight chief, said that number could change.  

“Our local list of unfunded items and projects ebbs and flows as we work the numbers and packages with 50 CONS,” Mateo said.  

The 21st CPTS also provides financial support to mission partners. Earlier this year, the squadron helped U.S. Space Command complete a $25 million building lease agreement in addition to their required projects.

“This was certainly the largest dollar figure we’ve certified all year,” Mateo said. “We also helped USSPACECOM execute a $2 million project for their new office in [Washington] D.C., to give them a dedicated space as a combatant command.” 

The CPTS will also fund $387,000 to help remodel the Schriever AFB education center before the end of this year.  

“This will allow promotion testing on site versus having our members driving to the Peterson testing center,” Mateo said. “They’ll also be able to provide other testing services and have a dedicated classroom to conduct professional seminars and various courses. This is a huge quality of life improvement for our Airmen.” 

Lacewell hopes the final month of the fiscal year serves as a learning experience for younger Airmen. Rather than the period being stressful, Airmen can gather information from someone such as Lacewell, who is completing his fourth close out.  

“Airmen should ask as many questions as they can, but also sit with someone who is actively in that process and watch how he or she works through the different systems,” Lacewell said. “In a way, [close-outs] get easier with time because you start to understand what to look for around this time of the year.” 

Mateo also ensures Airmen are informed of their significance during the process and highlights how their duties affect the garrison. 

“Our Airmen work too hard to be limited by aging equipment, dilapidated work areas and concerns about their paycheck being correct,” Mateo said. “It takes a team of people to manage all the intricacies of accounting and budget for the base. Without us, I don’t think we’d be able to execute taxpayer dollars across our various mission sets and sustain our way of life.”
column9: 美国科罗拉多州斯普林斯
column10: P-S GAR为财年结束做准备
column11: 科罗拉多州施里弗空军基地――彼得森・施里弗驻军计划在9月30日财政年度结束时完成两个基地的项目。在10月1日开始的财政年度中，第21个主计长中队和第50个合同中队向部队提供资金，以资助其任务。在整个收尾过程中，飞行员保持良好的沟通以完成项目非常重要。收尾包括多个单位，他们必须协调以确保任务成功。“不仅中队成员之间需要进行必要的沟通，而且我们和我们在该地点周围的队友以及（美国航天部队总部）之间也需要进行必要的沟通，”第21届CPTS行动总监杰里米・拉斯韦尔上尉说。这种联系包括第50个CONS，它管理政府购买卡计划，并编写合同来履行资金。如果没有特派团合作伙伴、预算办公室和合同办公室的准备，第50届CONS合同官员参谋中士阿伦・里夫勒（Arron Riffle）表示，财政年度的收尾不会如此成功。Riffle说：“财政年度的结束是为了确保拨款在（9月30日午夜）到期之前履行义务。”。“除非我们提供部队成功实现目标所需的物资和服务，否则所有这些（工作）都是毫无意义的。”CPTS目前计划资助85个项目和要求，并掌握中士。第21届CPTS财务分析飞行负责人威尔弗雷多・马特奥（Wilfredo Mateo）表示，这一数字可能会发生变化。马蒂奥说：“我们当地没有资金的项目和项目清单随着我们与50名反对者一起计算数量和方案而起伏。”。第21个国家方案工作队还向特派团伙伴提供财政支助。今年早些时候，该中队帮助美国航天司令部完成了一项2500万美元的建筑租赁协议，以及他们所需的项目。马特奥说：“这肯定是我们全年所确认的最大金额。”。“我们还帮助USSPACECOM为其位于华盛顿特区的新办公室执行了一个价值200万美元的项目，为其提供一个作为战斗指挥部的专用空间。”CPTS还将在今年年底前出资38.7万美元，帮助改造施里弗空军基地教育中心。“这将允许在现场进行促销测试，而不是让我们的会员开车去彼得森测试中心，”马特奥说。“他们还可以提供其他测试服务，并有专门的教室进行专业研讨会和各种课程。这对我们的飞行员来说是一个巨大的生活质量改善。”拉斯韦尔希望财政年度的最后一个月能成为年轻飞行员的学习经历。飞行员可以从拉斯韦尔这样的人那里收集信息，而不是在紧张的时期，拉斯韦尔正在完成他的第四次收尾。“飞行员应该问尽可能多的问题，但也应该和积极参与这一过程的人坐在一起，观察他或她如何通过不同的系统工作，”拉斯韦尔说。“在某种程度上，随着时间的推移，[收尾]变得越来越容易，因为你开始了解在每年的这个时候应该寻找什么。”马特奥还确保飞行员在这个过程中了解他们的重要性，并强调他们的职责如何影响驻军。马蒂奥说：“我们的飞行员工作非常努力，不会受到设备老化、工作区域破旧以及担心薪水是否正确的限制。”。“需要一个团队来管理基地所有复杂的会计和预算。没有我们，我认为我们不可能在不同的任务组中执行纳税人的资金，也不可能维持我们的生活方式。”

column2: Honor guard hosts first P-S GAR graduation
column3:
The High Frontier Honor Guard hosted its first graduation since the COVID-19 pandemic and the standup of the Peterson-Schriever Garrison Sept. 1 at Peterson Air Force Base, Colorado.

The honor guard provides public and professional support to the community including retirement ceremonies and veteran funerals.

“A lot of the services we do are the last things families see regarding the military,” said Staff. Sgt. Michael Vialpando, High Frontier Honor Guard program manager. “It's important for [families] to see us give the most respectful and proper honors they deserve.”

To become a ceremonial guardsmen at the unit, Airmen must complete a two-week, 80 hour course that covers basic protocol and a ceremonial course that teaches the Airmen how to give the proper honors at any ceremony they support.

Vialpando said there is a high attrition rate due to the intensive training. “It's not for everybody. When you do funerals, a lot of people can't bear the atmosphere. You have to have thick skin to be here. We can't have someone breakdown or lose their bearing during a service.”

Seventeen Airmen completed the training and many would describe the experience as humbling.

“With my training and the support of my team, I know we’re well equipped to provide world-class support whenever we’re tasked to,” said Senior Airman Billie Fisler, High Frontier Honor Guard flight lead and distinguished graduate.

Despite the challenges 2020 has brought, the unit stays busy. In 2019, the High Frontier Honor Guard performed 473 services, 280 of those being funerals, with numbers projected to be similar at the end of this year.

Col. Jennifer Fitch, P-S GAR vice commander and presiding officer, charged the graduates to continue perfecting the skills they have learned to honor service members and their families.

“What you do is incredible and meaningful to everyone you touch with your perfection,” she said.
column6: PETERSON AIR FORCE BASE, CO, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国科罗拉多州彼得森空军基地
column10: 仪仗队主办第一届P-S GAR毕业典礼
column11: 高级边防仪仗队在科罗拉多州彼得森空军基地举办了自新冠疫情和9月1日彼得森・施里弗驻军站立以来的首次毕业典礼。仪仗队为社区提供公共和专业支持，包括退休仪式和退伍军人葬礼。高级边防仪仗队项目经理、参谋长迈克尔・维亚尔潘多（Michael Vialpando）说：“我们所做的很多服务都是家人在军队中看到的最后一件事。对于（家人）来说，看到我们给予他们应得的最尊重和适当的荣誉是很重要的。”要成为该部队的仪式卫兵，飞行员必须完成一个为期两周、80小时的课程，包括基本礼仪和一个仪式课程，该课程教飞行员如何在他们支持的任何仪式上给予适当的荣誉。维亚尔潘多说，由于密集的训练，损耗率很高。“这不是为每个人准备的。当你参加葬礼时，很多人无法忍受这种气氛。你必须有厚厚的皮肤才能在这里。我们不能让任何人在服役期间崩溃或失去他们的风度。”17名飞行员完成了训练，许多人将这种经历描述为谦卑。“在我的培训和团队的支持下，我知道无论何时我们都有能力提供世界一流的支持。”高级边防仪仗队飞行负责人、杰出毕业生、高级飞行员比莉・费斯勒说。尽管2020年带来了挑战，但部队仍然很忙。2019年，高级边防仪仗队执行了473项服务，其中280项是葬礼，预计今年年底的数量将相似。副警长詹妮弗・菲奇上校指挥官兼首席执行官要求毕业生继续完善他们所学到的技能，以向服役人员及其家人表示敬意。“你所做的对每一个接触到你的完美的人来说都是难以置信和有意义的，”她说。

column2: PHC-P EMBLs shift gears to fight COVID-19
column3:
TRIPLER ARMY MEDICAL CENTER, HONOLULU C For Public Health Command-Pacific Environmental Molecular Biology Laboratory personnel keeping others safe from disease is a top priority.

Located at Camp Zama, Japan, and Joint Base Lewis-McChord, Washington, the EMBLs’ mission is to protect the health of the force from vector borne diseases found in ticks, mosquitos, and fleas by testing arthropod samples found in austere environments. 

These services provide commanders insight to help mitigate disease risk and exposure in the Department of Defense community. 

“Our EMBLs are always on the cutting edge of identifying new diseases emerging in our area of responsibility,” explained Capt. Bradley Kearney, a biochemist and the PHC-P Laboratory Sciences director. “Normally, this is going to be vector borne diseases, but the EMBL mission is evolving.”

In January, Kearney and his team began tracking the news of an emerging new virus, SARS-CoV-2, with the help of Dr. Michael Butel, PHC-P’s chief of epidemiology. As the new disease, COVID-19, evolved, the team began to strategize ways the team could help clinical labs in Japan and Washington in the event of a pandemic. 

“We were having meetings frequently in preparation for what we anticipated would be a pandemic before it was hardly even called an epidemic,” said Kearney. “We normally don’t do human testing, but we were very far leaning forward in offering our hand out to assist other laboratory facilities, which have the certification to do human testing but did not have sufficient manpower or equipment to maintain a sustained testing surge.” 
 
As the weeks continued, PHC-P leadership and the EMBL teams worked to identify critical laboratory assets and skill sets to help with clinical testing at Madigan Army Medical Center in Washington and the Naval Health Research Center satellite laboratory co-located at Naval Hospital Yokosuka, Japan.

“Laboratory assets can take a very long time to spin up,” Kearney explained. “To get someone qualified to do laboratory testing the minimum threshold requires more than 50 weeks of advanced individual training, then an individual will need to do months of training in a clinical hospital. In order to have a rapid response we tapped into those that already had the training in place. Since our team conducts vector laboratory testing regularly we had 100% of our staff from both Japan and JBLM go to support clinical efforts due to the limited availability of laboratory testers.” 

To help fight COVID-19, Gary Crispell, a microbiologist, and Kearney launched COVID-19 testing in Japan while Milagros Solá, a microbiologist, and Spc. Darius Torres, a medical laboratory technician, supplemented the clinical lab staff at MAMC.

“You have to be highly qualified and trained on the right equipment to do COVID-19 testing,” said Solá. “We have to make sure that we are following all of the proper protocols to not only keep ourselves safe but to also make sure the samples are processed accurately. The results could be life or death for someone. Additionally, it takes a really special person to work under the stress and pressure of processing COVID-19 samples, because the results were needed by the medical staff yesterday.”

One of the most time-consuming portions of COVID-19 testing involved lysing, the process of breaking down a cell in order to release the genetic material for each sample.

“Every sample needs to be lysed and it could be a long process, since you have to pipette the sample multiple times before it can go onto an instrument to process it,” explained Torres. “If you don’t have enough people in the lab, you end up wasting a lot of time going back and forth between lysing the samples and running the equipment.”

By supplementing the lab staff at MAMC, Torres and Solá were able to take some of the stress off their clinical counterparts.
 
Kearney and Crispell, on the other hand, worked around the clock with one Navy contractor, Sheila Trisler, to single-handedly set up testing efforts for DoD personnel and family members stationed in Japan. 

“Rather than send samples back to San Diego to be processed, which would take precious time, we partnered with the Navy to stand up a testing location at the NHRC satellite lab,” explained Kearney. “We moved our specialized instrument from Camp Zama to Yokosuka and were able to run the first tests for DoD members within a week of the move.”

The new ability to test in Japan helped keep the DoD and naval missions going by quickly identifying pockets of COVID-19 and reducing spread within the community. 

“For me, it was very gratifying to run these clinical tests in order to clear personnel to go out on missions,” said Crispell. “But the most gratifying thing was when we found pockets of COVID in our community and worked with preventive medicine teams. They were able to respond quickly and conduct contact tracing to extinguish clusters of COVID.”

To reduce outbreaks, both locations partnered with preventive medicine teams to identify and test individuals who may have come in contact with COVID-19. 

“It truly is a team effort between laboratories and preventive medicine,” said Kearney. “Together, we do a lot of work behind the scenes to reduce the spread of diseases. Often people don’t even know about work we do together since we are stopping outbreaks before they happen.”

Kearney pointed out that while the overall footprint of microbiology and preventive medicine are relatively small within the medical community, the mission is extremely important, and they are ready to respond.
 
“Historically, disease and non-battle injuries have been the number one threat to military readiness,” said Kearney. “To help reduce this threat we are behind the scenes at all times ready to protect the DoD community as a whole.”
 
The ability to adapt and respond to the demands of COVID-19 has meant a lot to the PHC-P EMBL staff. 

For Solá helping the MAMC clinical lab was extremely personal. 

“Madigan was my first duty station,” said Solá. “I started out as an enlisted medical lab technician in 1993 and became the NCOIC. Three of the staff members that I used to work with are still there at the lab. I cannot explain how it makes me feel to be able to help my former teammates more than 25 years later as civilian employee. This mission is so incredibly important, I am very proud to help.”
   
While Solá has four years until retirement, Torres reflected on how this experience has impacted him as a young enlisted lab tech.
  
“A pandemic like this is not something that anyone ever expects. However, this experience has shown me that as a Soldier I’m not only able to battle what I was taught to fight, but together as a team we can battle such things as a pandemic.”

For Kearney, this experience is why he joined the Army. 

“The involvement with COVID-19 testing really gets at the reason why I joined the Army. I joined to provide my expertise and to provide my services as a biochemist to help support the warfighter and their families,” said Kearney. 

As members of PHC-P, Crispell, Kearney, Solá and Torres’s dedication to care for the health and well-being of others embraced the PHC-P credo of “100/0!” which means 100% accountability and responsibility and zero excuses for not giving your best every day. 

“Almost anything is achievable when all of the parties are invested,” said Crispell. “To me nothing is more important than the service members and civilians that we service.” 

As the Army continues to adapt to the demands of COVID-19, PHC-P EMBLs will continue to lead the way by providing reach back support for technical questions, and providing supplemental hands-on testing support in the event of a testing surge.

“For years, the Army’s number one priority has been readiness,” said Kearney. “The combined team of our Soldier, scientist and civilian workforce has directly and measurably made a positive impact on readiness during this pandemic. The Army laboratory enterprise stands with the rest of our healthcare force to continue the fight against COVID-19 and to support our warfighters with any medical challenge the future may hold.”
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: PHC-P EMBLs换档以对抗新冠病毒-19
column11: 檀香山TRIPLER陆军医疗中心――对于公共卫生司令部太平洋环境分子生物学实验室人员来说，保护他人免受疾病危害是头等大事。位于日本扎马营地和华盛顿刘易斯・麦科德联合基地，EMBLs的任务是通过测试在恶劣环境中发现的节肢动物样本，保护部队的健康免受蜱、蚊子和跳蚤中发现的媒介传播疾病的影响。这些服务为指挥官提供洞察，帮助降低国防部社区的疾病风险和暴露。生物化学家兼PHC-P实验室科学主任布拉德利・卡尼（Bradley Kearney）上尉解释说：“我们的EMBLs始终处于识别责任领域新出现疾病的前沿。”。“正常情况下，这将是媒介传播的疾病，但EMBL任务正在演变。”1月，卡尼和他的团队在PHC-P的流行病学主管迈克尔・巴特尔博士的帮助下，开始跟踪新出现的SARS-CoV-2病毒的消息。随着新疾病――新冠病毒-19的发展，研究小组开始制定策略，以便在发生大流行时帮助日本和华盛顿的临床实验室。卡尼说：“我们经常开会，为我们预期的大流行做准备，而大流行甚至还没有被称为流行病。”。“我们通常不进行人体试验，但我们在帮助其他实验室设施方面向前倾斜了很多，这些实验室有进行人体试验的认证，但没有足够的人力或设备来维持持续的试验激增。”随着几周的继续，PHC-P领导层和EMBL团队致力于确定关键实验室资产和技能集，以帮助在华盛顿的Madigan陆军医疗中心和位于日本横须贺海军医院的海军健康研究中心卫星实验室进行临床试验。“实验室资产可能需要很长时间才能运转。”卡尼解释道。“为了让某人有资格进行实验室测试，最低限度需要50周以上的高级个人培训，然后一个人需要在临床医院进行数月的培训。为了快速做出反应，我们利用了已经进行过培训的人员。因为我们的团队进行了病媒实验室培训由于实验室检测人员的有限，我们让来自日本和JBLM的100%的员工都去支持临床工作。”为了帮助对抗新冠病毒19，微生物学家加里・克里斯佩尔和卡尼在日本启动了新冠病毒19检测，而微生物学家米拉格罗斯・索拉和Spc.Darius Torres，一名医学实验室技术员补充了MAMC的临床实验室工作人员。“你必须具备很高的资格，并接受过正确设备的培训，才能进行新冠病毒-19检测，”Solá说。“我们必须确保遵守所有适当的协议，不仅确保我们自己的安全，而且确保样本得到准确处理。结果可能是某人的生命或死亡。此外，需要一个非常特殊的人在处理新冠病毒-19样本的压力下工作，因为结果“新冠病毒-19测试最耗时的部分之一是裂解，即分解细胞以释放每个样本的遗传物质的过程。托雷斯解释说：“每个样本都需要进行分析，这可能是一个漫长的过程，因为你必须用移液管多次才能将样本移到仪器上进行处理。如果实验室里没有足够的人员，你最终会在分析样本和运行设备之间来回浪费大量时间。”通过补充MAMC的实验室工作人员，托雷斯和索拉能够减轻临床同行的一些压力。另一方面，卡尼和克里斯佩尔与海军承包商希拉・特里斯勒（Sheila Trisler）日以继夜地合作，单独为驻扎在日本的国防部人员和家属建立测试工作。卡尼解释说：“我们没有将样本送回圣地亚哥进行处理（这将花费宝贵的时间），而是与海军合作，在NHRC卫星实验室设立了一个测试地点。我们将我们的专用仪器从扎马营地转移到横须贺，并能够在转移后一周内为国防部成员进行第一次测试。”在日本进行测试的新能力有助于国防部和海军的任务继续进行，因为它可以快速识别出新冠病毒-19的口袋，并减少在社区内的传播。“对我来说，进行这些临床测试是非常令人满意的，以便让人员能够执行任务，”Crispell说。“但最令人欣慰的是，我们在社区中发现了一些新冠病毒，并与预防医学小组合作。他们能够迅速做出反应，并进行接触追踪，以消灭成串的新冠病毒。”为了减少疫情爆发，这两个地区都与预防医学团队合作，以确定和检测可能接触过新冠病毒-19的个人。“这确实是实验室和预防医学之间的团队努力，”卡尼说。“我们一起在幕后做了大量工作，以减少疾病的传播。通常人们甚至不知道我们一起做的工作，因为我们在疫情发生之前就阻止了疫情的爆发。”卡尼指出，虽然微生物学和预防医学在医学界的总体影响相对较小，但这项任务极其重要，他们随时准备作出反应。“从历史上看，疾病和非战斗伤害一直是军事准备的头号威胁，”卡尼说。“为了帮助减少这种威胁，我们随时准备在幕后保护整个国防部社区。”适应和响应新冠病毒要求的能力对PHC-P EMBL工作人员来说意义重大。对于索拉来说，帮助MAMC临床实验室是非常个人化的。“麦迪根是我的第一个工作地点，”索拉说。“我从1993年开始是一名应征入伍的医疗实验室技术员，后来成为了NCOIC。我曾经共事的三名工作人员现在仍在实验室。我无法解释25年后作为文职雇员能够帮助我的前队友的感受。这项任务是如此的重要，我非常自豪能够虽然索拉离退休还有四年的时间，但托雷斯反思了这段经历对他作为一名年轻的实验室技术人员的影响。“像这样的大流行不是任何人都能预料到的。然而，这段经历告诉我，作为一名士兵，我不仅能够与我被教导要与之战斗的东西战斗，而且作为一个团队，我们可以一起与大流行这样的事情作斗争。”对于卡尼来说，这段经历就是他参军的原因。“参与新冠病毒-19测试确实是我参军的原因。我参军是为了提供我的专业知识，并作为一名生物化学家提供服务，以帮助支持战士及其家人。”作为PHC-P的成员，Crispell、Kearney、Solá和Torres致力于关心他人的健康和福祉，他们信奉PHC-P的信条“100/0！”，这意味着100%的责任感和责任感，没有理由不每天都做到最好。克里斯佩尔说：“当所有各方都投入时，几乎任何事情都是可以实现的。对我来说，没有什么比我们所服务的军人和平民更重要了。”随着陆军继续适应新冠病毒-19的要求，PHC-P EMBLs将继续领先，为技术问题提供回访支持，并在测试激增时提供补充的动手测试支持。“多年来，陆军的首要任务一直是做好准备，”卡尼说。“我们的士兵、科学家和文职人员组成的联合团队在这场大流行期间对战备状态产生了直接和可测量的积极影响。陆军实验室企业与我们的其他医疗力量站在一起，继续与新冠病毒-19作斗争，并支持我们的作战人员应对未来可能面临的任何医疗挑战。”

column2: USS John P. Murtha Holds Change of Command Ceremony
column3:
SAN DIEGO (July 10, 2020) Capt. Gervy J. Alota assumed command of San Antonio-class amphibious transport dock ship USS John P. Murtha (LPD 26) from Capt. Kevin A. Lane during a change of command ceremony July 10.

Alota’s most recent assignments were Deputy Director for Surface and Mine Warfighting Development Center Sea Combat Division and Deputy Executive Assistant for the Vice Chief of Naval Operations.

Lane’s tour aboard lasted from February 2015 to July 2020. He began his tour as executive officer before ascending to commanding officer in April 2019. He guided the ship through the pre-commissioning process, her first deployment which yielded a Battle Efficiency award. He was also instrumental in John P.Murtha’s participation in Rim of the Pacific 2018 Exercise, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s (NASA) Orion Program Underway Recovery Testing twice and the ship’s first basic and integrated phase training cycle.  

“It's been an honor to serve as commanding officer” Lane said.  “I am so proud of the crew for all they’ve done to make and keep John P. Murtha a great ship over the last 30 months. They represent the best of America, and you should all be proud.”  

Captain Tony Rodriguez, Commander, Amphibious Squadron Five, presided over the ceremony, and presented Lane the Legion of Merit for his performance as John P. Murtha commanding officer.

“Capt. Lane did a great job, his award says it all. We are extremely proud of the things he accomplished during his time as commanding officer.” 

Alota said he is as excited to take over the role of commanding officer as he is for the ship’s future.

“I am absolutely humbled and blessed to have this opportunity,” Alota said. “It is a dream come true to take command of a ship whose motto is, ‘Make a Difference.’ We are going to accomplish some spectacular things. I am here to serve the crew and together we are going to achieve greatness.”

Lane’s next assignment will be Special Assistant to Expeditionary Strike Group Three (ESG 3).

USS John P. Murtha is the 10th San Antonio-class amphibious transport dock ship of the United States Navy and is named in honor of Congressman John Murtha of Pennsylvania and homeported in San Diego and is part of Naval Surface Forces and U.S. 3rd Fleet. The ship first deployed May 2019. They completed their deployment on November 27, 2019. John P. Murtha’s exceptional performance lead to the 2019 Battle Efficiency Award. Additionally, the ship provided amphibious lift during the multi-na?tional exercise RIMPAC 2018, and twice supported NASA testing of at-sea recovery procedures for the Orion space capsule.
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州圣地亚哥
column10: 美国海军约翰・P・默塔号举行换帅仪式
column11: 圣地亚哥（2020年7月10日）格维・J・阿洛塔上尉担任圣安东尼奥级两栖运输码头舰“约翰・P・穆尔塔”号（LPD26）的指挥7月10日，凯文・A・莱恩上尉在换帅仪式上表示。阿洛塔最近的任务是水面和水雷作战发展中心海战部副主任和海军作战副总监的副执行助理。莱恩的船上之旅从2015年2月持续到2020年7月。在2019年4月晋升为指挥官之前，他以执行官的身份开始了他的旅行。他指导该船完成了预调试过程，这是该船的首次部署，获得了战斗效率奖。他还帮助John P.Murtha参加2018年环太平洋演习、美国国家航空航天局（NASA）猎户座计划进行了两次恢复测试以及该船的第一个基本和综合阶段训练周期。莱恩说：“担任指挥官是我的荣幸。”。“我为船员们在过去30个月中为使约翰・P・默萨号成为一艘伟大的战舰所做的一切感到骄傲。他们代表了美国最优秀的战舰，你们都应该感到骄傲。”两栖五中队指挥官托尼・罗德里格斯上尉主持了仪式，并授予莱恩作为约翰・P・默塔指挥官的荣誉勋章。“莱恩上尉干得很出色，他的奖项足以说明一切。我们为他在担任指挥官期间所取得的成就感到无比自豪。”阿洛塔说，他很高兴能够接任指挥官一职，就像他对该舰的未来一样。“能有这个机会，我感到非常谦卑和幸运，”阿洛塔说。“指挥一艘座右铭为‘有所作为’的战舰是一个梦想成真。我们将完成一些了不起的事情。我在这里为全体船员服务，我们将一起实现伟大。”莱恩的下一个任务是远征打击第三组（ESG 3）的特别助理“约翰・P・穆尔塔”号是美国海军第10艘圣安东尼奥级两栖运输船坞舰，是为纪念宾夕法尼亚州国会议员约翰・穆尔塔而命名的，在圣地亚哥返港，是海军水面部队和美国第三舰队的一部分。该船于2019年5月首次部署。他们于2019年11月27日完成部署。约翰・P・默塔的出色表现赢得了2019年战斗效率奖。此外，该船在2018年环太平洋多国演习期间提供了两栖升力，并两次支持美国宇航局测试猎户座太空舱的海上回收程序。

column2: NAVSUP WSS awards P-8A contract to small business
column3:
NAVSUP Weapon Systems Support (WSS) awarded a five-year, Indefinite Delivery Indefinite Quantity (IDIQ), long-term contract for the P-8A Poseidon Maritime aircraft estimated at $30 million to small business, S&K Aerospace, in May 2020. 

“It is a first time “break-out” where a small business will be responsible to manage the repair/upgrade and overhaul of 362 commercial common weapon replaceable assemblies (WRAs) used in support of the P-8A Poseidon Maritime aircraft,” said Debra Zaslow, Contracting Officer for PBL Center of Excellence.   

These items have been deemed “commercial common,” or items that can be used on both the P-8A, as well as, the Boeing 737 aircraft and were previously repaired primarily by large business Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs). 

“Under this contract, small businesses, performing as prime and subcontractors, will play a vital role in supporting the Navy’s P-8A aircraft. S&K Aerospace will manage parts repairs, upgrades and overhauls, and notify the Government contracting office of commercial configuration changes and obsolescence-related issues,” said Annette Stevenson, Deputy Director, NAVSUP WSS Office of Small Business Programs.

Since these 362 items are identical to the ones used on the Boeing 737, it was decided by the NAVAIR Program Office that items could be repaired at various Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Part 145 Repair Stations.

“These are the large nation-wide and world-wide networks of repair facilities used by airlines and other private aircraft, all of which are governed by FAA regulations,” said Zaslow. “S&K Aerospace has in-depth knowledge of Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)-governed repair processes, infrastructure, and regulations.”

This is the first time that NAVSUP WSS has procured repairs/upgrades/overhauls from approved Federal Aviation Administration 145 Repair Stations. As the prime contractor, S&K Aerospace will be responsible for maintaining all items under this contract and coordinating the necessary repair work to return items to ready for issue (RFI) condition via repair stations. 

This contract will enhance overall mission readiness for the P-8A weapon system by leveraging the existing commercial common items repair competitive environment to achieve benefits in cost and repair turnaround time. 

“This was an extremely complex requirement and source selection process involving multiple functional area experts across the Integrated Weapons Support Team, Contracting Department, Legal Counsel, and Office of Small Business,” said Lt. Cmdr. Ryan Tobin, Deputy Director for NAVSUP WSS PBL Center of Excellence. “This highly functional Source Selection Team analyzed all proposals and ultimately chose S&K Aerospace as providing best value to the government based on their successful performance approach, past performance, small business subcontracting plan, and price. This award is a big win for NAVSUP WSS, small business, and the P-8A community” 

NAVSUP WSS is one of 11 commands under Commander, NAVSUP. Headquartered in Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania, and employing a diverse, worldwide workforce of more than 22,500 military and civilian personnel, NAVSUP's mission is to provide supplies, services, and quality-of-life support to the Navy and joint warfighter. Learn more at www.navsup.navy.mil, www.facebook.com/navsupwss.
column9: 美国
column10: NAVSUP WSS向小型企业授予P-8A合同
