column11: NAVSUP武器系统支持部（WSS）于2020年5月向小型企业S&K Aerospace授予了一份为期五年、不确定交付、不确定数量（IDIQ）的P-8A波塞冬海上飞机长期合同，价值3000万美元。PBL卓越中心合同官黛布拉・扎斯洛（Debra Zaslow）说：“这是第一次“突围”，小企业将负责管理362个商用通用武器可更换组件（WRA）的维修/升级和大修，这些组件用于支持P-8A波塞冬海事飞机。”。这些项目被视为“商业通用”，或可用于P-8A和波音737飞机的项目，之前主要由大型商业原始设备制造商（OEM）维修。“根据该合同，作为主承包商和分包商的小型企业将在支持海军P-8A飞机方面发挥重要作用。s&K航空航天将管理零件维修、升级和大修，并将商业配置变更和过时相关问题通知政府合同办公室。”NAVSUP WSS小企业项目办公室副主任安妮特・史蒂文森说。由于这362件物品与波音737上使用的物品相同，NAVAIR项目办公室决定，这些物品可以在联邦航空管理局（FAA）的145部分维修站进行维修。Zaslow说：“这些是航空公司和其他私人飞机使用的大型全国性和全球范围的维修设施网络，所有这些设施都受美国联邦航空管理局（FAA）监管。S&K航空航天公司对美国联邦航空管理局（FAA）监管的维修流程、基础设施和法规有着深入的了解。”这是NAVSUP WSS首次从经批准的联邦航空管理局145个维修站采购维修/升级/大修。作为主承包商，S&K航空航天将负责维护本合同项下的所有项目，并协调必要的维修工作，以将项目返回准备发布（RFI）状态通过维修站进行维修。该合同将通过利用现有的商用通用件维修竞争环境，提高P-8A武器系统的总体任务准备度，以实现成本和维修周转时间方面的效益。NAVSUP WSS PBL卓越中心副主任Ryan Tobin中校说：“这是一个极其复杂的需求和来源选择过程，涉及综合武器支持团队、合同部门、法律顾问和小企业办公室的多个职能领域专家。”。“这个功能强大的资源选择团队分析了所有提案，并最终根据其成功的绩效方法、过去的绩效、小企业分包计划和价格，选择S&K Aerospace为政府提供最佳价值。该奖项是NAVSUP WSS、小企业和P-8A社区的一大胜利。”NAVSUP WSS是总部位于宾夕法尼亚州Mechanicsburg的NAVSUP司令部下属的11个司令部之一，在全球范围内雇用了超过22500名军事和文职人员，NAVSUP的任务是为海军和联合作战人员提供补给、服务和生活质量支持。有关更多信息，请访问www.NAVSUP.Navy.mil，www.facebook.com/navsupwss。

column2: PHC-P Soldier recognized as 2020 MEDCOM Exceptional SARC
column3:
Maj. Ran Du, Public Health Command-Pacific’s sexual assault response coordinator, was recognized as the 2020 Medical Command Exceptional SARC on May 7. 

Nominated for his efforts leading the PHC-P Sexual Harassment Assault Response and Prevention program, Du will represent MEDCOM as the nominee for the 2020 Department of Army Exceptional SARC award. 

“Each year, the Department of Defense recognizes one Exceptional Sexual Assault Response Coordinator from each of the services,” said Col. Heidi Mon, PHC-P’s commander. “We are very proud that Maj. Du’s nomination will now compete at the Department of Army level. His commitment to the SHARP program embodies the PHC-P credo of ‘100/0!’ which means 100 percent accountability and responsibility and zero excuses for not giving our best every day.” 

During his time as the PHC-P SARC, Du created an integrated and robust SHARP program across a geographically dispersed brigade. The program provides support to more than 500 personnel assigned to more than 50 installations, spanning five different countries and five U.S. states and territories within the Indo-Pacific. 
 
Du personally met with each of the five subordinate battalion commanders and actively engaged more than 14 victim advocates to ensure unit leaders fully supported the SHARP program.

“It all starts with the command’s support,” said Du. “It enables our victim advocates to promote a push for change rather than just having everyone participate in the mandatory training.”

To help advocate a change in culture, Du also assisted battalion victim advocates in partnering with local SHARP programs on Army, Navy, and Air Force installations to create an extended SHARP network. This integrated network ensured potential victims received the same services regardless of location.

“By working together as a team, we are able to encourage survivors to file reports while preventing sexual assault within the brigade before they happen,” Du said. “We are stronger together, and together we are here to advocate for the survivors’ needs.”  

As COVID-19 restrictions and stay-at-home orders went into effect in March, Du continued to advocate teamwork and cultural changes despite social distancing. Rather than letting Sexual Assault Awareness Prevention Month fall to the side, Du worked with victim advocates to host a virtual 5K race and Denim Day contest to help raise SAAPM awareness throughout the month of April. 

With hundreds of participants, Du and his team strengthened the commitment to cultural change and the SHARP program throughout the brigade by leading the way in the Indo-Pacific. 

“There are a lot of great things about the SHARP program, but I definitely think that it comes down to teamwork and commitment to the program,” Du explained. “When everyone is committed and willing to take on this challenge as a unit, great things happen. I think that if everyone in the Army can do what we did then we can definitely eliminate sexual assault.”

For Du, this nomination isn’t about him; it’s about the entire PHC-P team, he said.

“It’s a great honor to have the nomination, and I think of it as a team award,” explained Du. “It really is a reflection of teamwork and the work that our victim advocates have done throughout the brigade.”
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: PHC-P士兵被公认为2020年MEDCOM特殊SARC
column11: 5月7日，太平洋公共卫生司令部的性攻击反应协调员Ran Du少校被认定为2020年医疗司令部特别SARC。杜因领导PHC-P性骚扰应对和预防计划而获得提名，他将代表MEDCOM获得2020年陆军部特殊SARC奖提名人。PHC-P指挥官Heidi Mon上校说：“每年，国防部都会从每个军种中选出一名出色的性攻击反应协调员。”。“我们非常自豪杜少校的提名现在将在陆军部一级竞争。他对夏普计划的承诺体现了PHC-P“100/0！”的信条，这意味着100%的责任感和责任感，以及没有理由不每天尽全力。”在他担任PHC-P SARC期间，Du在一个地理位置分散的旅中创建了一个完整而强大的SHARP项目。该计划为500多名人员提供支持，这些人员被分配到印度洋-太平洋地区的50多个设施，分布在五个不同的国家和五个美国州和地区。杜军亲自会见了五名下属营指挥官，并积极与14名受害者权益倡导者进行了接触，以确保部队领导充分支持夏普计划。“这一切都是从司令部的支持开始的，”杜军说。“这使我们的受害者倡导者能够推动变革，而不仅仅是让每个人都参加强制性培训。”为了帮助倡导文化变革，杜还协助营受害者倡导者与陆军、海军和空军设施上的当地夏普项目合作，创建一个扩展的夏普网络。这一综合网络确保了潜在受害者无论在何处都能得到相同的服务。“通过团队合作，我们能够鼓励幸存者提交报告，同时在发生性攻击之前防止旅内发生性攻击，”杜说。“我们一起变得更强大，我们一起在这里倡导幸存者的需求。”随着新冠病毒-19限制和留在家中命令在3月份生效，杜继续倡导团队合作和文化变革，尽管社会距离越来越远。杜没有让性侵犯意识预防月落在一边，而是与受害者权益倡导者合作举办了一场虚拟的5公里比赛和牛仔日比赛，以帮助在整个4月份提高对SAAPM的认识。在数百人的参与下，杜和他的团队通过在印度-太平洋地区的领先地位，加强了对整个旅文化变革和夏普计划的承诺。“夏普项目有很多很棒的地方，但我绝对认为这要归结为团队合作和对项目的承诺，”杜解释说。“当每个人都致力于并愿意作为一个单位接受这一挑战时，伟大的事情就会发生。我认为，如果军队中的每个人都能像我们那样做，那么我们肯定可以消除性侵犯。”对于杜，这个提名与他无关；“这关乎整个PHC-P团队，”他说，“获得提名是一种莫大的荣誉，我认为这是一个团队奖，”杜解释道。“这确实反映了团队合作以及我们的受害者辩护律师在整个旅中所做的工作。”

column2: OBWC presented the OO-ALC L-A-M-P award
column3:
HILL AIR FORCE BASE, UTAH C 	When the Ogden Air Logistics Complex was having problems with the industrial product vendor program, which supplies small parts to its maintenance work force, they had to make some extremely important decisions in order to rectify the situation and to make sure the program got back on track and stayed there.

The Complex Business Operations Workload Management (OBWC) team brought extensive knowledge of the IPV program, and went to work immediately as subject matter experts putting plans in place in support of maintenance operations and accomplished astounding program numbers, many thought the IPV program would never see.

While turning heads over the last 18 months and with through the use of Art of the Possible, they began raising goals which has allowed for program constraints and road barriers to be quickly resolved.

The management team began exceeding the challenging requirements and expectations for this program through management of the IPV kitting process by developing an internal program dashboard used for tracking status and part supportability.

This dashboard has ultimately allowed a clear look into program constraints, resulting in outstanding numbers in kitting fulfillment and raising part supportability from a steady 19% month to month average to a steady 95% fulfillment.

With continued support towards the mission, the team successfully accomplished part supportabilities highest kitting fulfillment percentage reported at 92.95% for June, to 99.53% in July 2019, and lowest level of backlogged kits reported, from 262 to under 50 during the same time resulting in measured savings to the U.S. Air Force over $876 thousand dollars and hundreds of hours in the last 12 months.

In recognition of all their hard work in making sure the IPV program is headed in the right direction, the OBWC IPV management team was awarded the Logistics Airmen Mastering Possibilities, or L-A-M-P, Award by Brigadier General Cauley von Hoffman, Ogden Air Logistics Complex commander.
column6: HILL AIR FORCE BASE, UT, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国犹他州希尔空军基地
column10: OBWC颁发了OO-ALC L-A-M-P奖
column11: 犹他州希尔空军基地―当奥格登航空物流中心在工业产品供应商计划方面遇到问题时，该计划为其维修人员提供小型零件，他们必须做出一些极其重要的决定，以纠正这种情况，并确保项目回到正轨并保持不变。复杂业务运营工作量管理（OBWC）团队带来了IPV项目的广泛知识，作为主题专家，他立即投入工作，制定了支持维护操作的计划，并完成了令人震惊的项目数量，许多人认为IPV项目永远不会成功。在过去18个月里，通过使用艺术的可能性，他们开始提出目标，使计划约束和道路障碍得以迅速解决。管理团队通过开发用于跟踪状态和零件的内部计划仪表板，通过管理IPV配套流程，开始超越该计划的挑战性要求和期望可保障性。该仪表盘最终能够清晰地查看采办项目的约束条件，从而在装备完成率方面取得显著成绩，并将部分保障性从每月平均19%的稳定水平提高到每月平均95%的稳定水平。随着对任务的持续支持，该团队成功地完成了部件保障能力报告的6月最高配套完成率为92.95%，2019年7月达到99.53%，报告的积压配套最低，在过去的12个月中，美国空军节省了87.6万美元和数百个小时。鉴于他们为确保IPV计划朝着正确的方向发展所做的辛勤工作，OBWC IPV管理团队获得奥格登航空后勤综合体指挥官考利・冯・霍夫曼准将颁发的后勤飞行员掌握可能性奖（L-A-M-P）。

column2: USS John P. Murtha Holds Change of Command Ceremony
column3:
SAN DIEGO (April 3, 2019) Capt. Kevin Lane assumed command of San Antonio-class amphibious transport dock ship USS John P. Murtha (LPD 26) from Capt. Anthony Roach during a change of command ceremony April 3.

Lane served as John P. Murtha’s executive officer for 15 months from January 2018 to April 2019. 

Roach’s tour aboard lasted from February 2015 to April 2019. He began his tour as executive officer before assuming the position as commanding officer May 14, 2016. He guided the ship through the pre-commissioning process, Rim of the Pacific 2018 Exercise, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s (NASA) Orion Program Underway Recovery Testing and the ship’s first basic and integrated phase training cycle.  

“What an incredible journey it’s been,” Roach said.  “Even though I will be leaving this ship, a piece of my heart will be here on John P. Murtha forever. I will be following these great Americans as they embark on deployment.”  

Rear Adm. Joe Tynch III, commander, Logistics Group Western Pacific and the ceremony presiding officer, awarded Roach the Legion of Merit for his performance as John P. Murtha commanding officer.

“I have known Captain Roach for decades," said Tynch “He respects all those around him. He plans and drives toward the future. He always gets the jobs and tasks that need to be done, done. He has proven time and time again that he can take on any challenge and win.” 

Lane said he is as excited to take over the role of commanding officer as he is for the ship’s future.

“You never get to a moment like this alone,” Lane said. “This crew is brilliant at the basics and they get a little better each time they accomplish something. Along the way we have had some beautiful moments. What has been built here is special and I look forward to working with everyone to keep it going.” 

Cmdr. Clinton Blankenship will take over the position of John P. Murtha executive officer. 
He previously served as commanding officer at Navy Operations Support Center Springfield, Oregon. 

USS John P. Murtha is the 10th San Antonio-class amphibious transport dock ship of the United States Navy and is named in honor of Congressman John Murtha of Pennsylvania and homeported in San Diego and is part of Naval Surface Forces and U.S. 3rd Fleet.
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州圣地亚哥
column10: 美国海军约翰・P・默塔号举行换帅仪式
column11: 圣地亚哥（2019年4月3日）凯文・莱恩上尉在4月3日的换届仪式上从安东尼・罗奇上尉手中接过圣安东尼奥级两栖运输码头船USS John P.Murtha（LPD 26）的指挥权。莱恩在2018年1月至2019年4月期间担任约翰・P.Murtha的执行官15个月。罗奇的船上之旅从2015年2月持续到2019年4月。在2016年5月14日担任指挥官之前，他以执行官的身份开始了他的巡演。他指导飞船完成了预调试过程、2018年环太平洋演习、美国国家航空航天局（NASA）猎户座计划进行中的恢复测试以及飞船的第一个基本和综合阶段训练周期。“这是一次多么不可思议的旅程，”罗奇说。“即使我将离开这艘船，我的一颗心将永远留在约翰・P・默塔身上。我将跟随这些伟大的美国人展开部署。”西太平洋后勤集团指挥官兼仪式主持官乔・廷奇三世少将，由于罗奇作为约翰・P・默塔指挥官的出色表现，他被授予荣誉军团。“我认识罗奇上尉几十年了，”廷奇说“他尊重周围的人。他计划并推动未来。他总是得到需要完成的工作和任务。他一次又一次地证明，他可以接受任何挑战并取得胜利。”莱恩说，他对接任指挥官一职感到兴奋，就像他对该船的未来一样。莱恩说：“你永远不会独自经历这样的时刻。这支队伍在基础上非常出色，每完成一件事，他们都会变得更好。一路上，我们都有一些美好的时刻。这里所建造的一切都很特别，我期待着与每一个人一起努力，让这一切继续下去。”克林顿・布兰肯希普中校将接替约翰・P・穆尔塔执行官的职务。他曾担任俄勒冈州斯普林菲尔德海军作战支持中心的指挥官。约翰・P・穆尔塔号是美国海军第10艘圣安东尼奥级两栖运输码头舰，是为纪念美国国会议员约翰・穆尔塔而命名的ennsylvania和Homeport位于圣地亚哥，是海军水面部队和美国第三舰队的一部分。

column2: USS John P. Murtha Underway for NASA's Orion Mission
column3:
SAN DIEGO - San Antonio-class amphibious transport dock USS John P. Murtha (LPD 26) is underway to conduct Underway Recovery Test (URT) 7 in conjunction with NASA off the coast of Southern California. 
 
URT is part of a U.S. government interagency effort to safely practice and evaluate recovery processes, procedures, hardware and personnel in an open ocean environment that will be used to recover the Orion spacecraft upon its return to Earth.   
 
This will be the first time John P. Murtha will conduct a URT mission with NASA. Throughout the history of the program, a variety of San Antonio-class LPD ships have been utilized to train and prepare NASA and the Navy, utilizing a Boiler Plate Test Article (BTA).  The BTA is a mock capsule, designed to roughly the same size, shape, and center of gravity as the Crew Module which will be used for Orion.  
 
NASA and Navy teams have taken lessons learned from previous recovery tests to improve operations and ensure the ability to safely and successfully recover the Orion capsule when it returns to Earth following Exploration Mission-1 (EM-1) in December 2019. 
 
EM-1 will be an uncrewed flight, whose successful completion hopes to pave the way for future crewed missions and enable future missions to the Moon, Mars, and beyond.  
 
During URT-7, John P. Murtha will conduct restricted maneuvering operations. Small boats carrying Navy and NASA divers will deploy alongside the BTA to rig tending lines, guiding the capsule to Anchorage as the ship safely operates on station.  
 
Conducting both daytime and nighttime recovery operations, NASA crew members will work alongside the Navy to manage how the capsule is brought in, set down and safely stored.  

 NASA plans to conduct two more URT missions before EM-1 takes place. 
 
John P. Murtha is homeported in San Diego and is part of Naval Surface Forces and U.S. 3rd Fleet. 
 
Commander, U.S. Third Fleet leads naval forces in the Pacific and provides realistic, relevant training necessary for an effective global Navy. They coordinate with Commander, U.S. Seventh Fleet to plan and execute missions based on their complementary strengths to promote ongoing peace, security, and stability.  
For more news from Commander, U.S. 3rd Fleet, visit www.navy.mil/local/c3f/. 
For more news from USS John P. Murtha (LPD 26), visit https://www.public.navy.mil/surfor/lpd26/

column10: 美国航空航天局“猎户座”号航母约翰・P・默塔号正在执行任务
column11: 圣迭戈-圣安东尼奥级两栖运输码头USS John P.Murtha（LPD 26）正在南加州海岸与美国宇航局合作进行第7次海上恢复试验（URT）。URT是美国政府跨机构努力的一部分，旨在在公海环境中安全实践和评估回收过程、程序、硬件和人员，用于在猎户座航天器返回地球后回收。这将是约翰・P・默塔首次与美国宇航局一起执行轨道交通任务。在该计划的整个历史过程中，各种圣安东尼奥级LPD船舶都被用于训练和准备NASA和海军，使用锅炉板试验品（BTA）。BTA是一个模拟太空舱，其设计尺寸、形状和重心与用于猎户座的乘员舱大致相同。NASA和海军团队从先前的回收测试中吸取了经验教训，以改进操作，确保猎户座太空舱在2019年12月完成探索任务-1（EM-1）后返回地球时能够安全成功地回收。EM-1将是一次无人驾驶的飞行，它的成功完成希望为未来载人任务铺平道路，并使未来的月球、火星和更远的地方的任务成为可能。在URT-7期间，John P.Murtha将执行受限机动操作。载着海军和美国宇航局潜水员的小船将部署在BTA旁边，以便在船在空间站上安全运行时，操纵操纵索，引导太空舱到锚地。在白天和夜间进行回收操作时，NASA机组人员将与海军一起管理如何将太空舱带入、放下和安全储存。美国宇航局计划在EM-1发射前再执行两次城市轨道交通任务。约翰・P・穆尔塔在圣地亚哥返乡，是海军水面部队和美国第三舰队的一员。指挥官，美国第三舰队领导太平洋地区的海军力量，并为有效的全球海军提供必要的现实、相关的训练。他们与美国第七舰队司令协调，根据他们的互补优势规划和执行任务，以促进持续的和平、安全和稳定。有关美国第三舰队指挥官的更多消息，请访问www.navy.mil/local/c3f/。欲了解更多来自美国军舰约翰・P・默塔号（LPD26）的消息，请访问https://www.public.navy.mil/surfor/lpd26/

column2: Fort Hood Soldiers complete first MAP-P at CTC
column3:
KILLEEN, TX C Seven active duty Soldiers assigned to units on Fort Hood, graduated August 9th from Central Texas College’s Military Articulation Paramedic program. 

The program, the first of its kind for CTC, allows active duty Soldiers to earn their paramedic certification in less time than traditionally required, all while maintaining their active duty requirement.

Congressman John Carter, was one of the distinguished guest speakers for the evening. 

“You are the first, a first of something definitely needed for the Army,” Carter said. “So I really appreciate what we are doing here today; this will help men and women in uniform improve their skills while serving and meeting their obligations in the military.”

While the Soldiers have graduated from the program, they still will need to receive their certification through testing with the National Registry to be able to officially practice as a paramedic.
 
“Military Articulation Paramedic program gives the opportunities to expand the knowledge so they will be even more effective Soldiers,” Carter said. “It gives them skills they can use in the workforce when they get out.”

The class salutatorian and 3rd Armored Brigade Combat Team Soldier, Cpl. Jewel Lewis, 215th Brigade Support Battalion, was excited to have finished the course.

“It was an honor graduating this course,” said Lewis. “It was a long 9 and a half months, but it was good. We were able to advance our medical knowledge and I think it’s a very good opportunity for all the medics, but also people who are interested in the medical field.”

Lewis and most of her classmates are planning to continue their education by taking the offered Army courses, to become flight medics.

With support from government officials like Carter, Central Texas College administrators, and Fort Hood leadership, the classes will continue to be offered for Soldiers who are interested. 

“I foresee this program getting more and more popular, every year,” said Carter. “I hope to see it expand and grow. All of you that are part of this first both family and Soldiers be proud of the ground you’re plowing right now, because it’s going to bear great fruit in the future.”

The second cohort is already underway but the third cohort is scheduled to start in June 2019. Soldiers wishing to sign up for the program must first complete an admissions checklist. Information on all eligibility requirements, admissions, prerequisites and tuition assistance is available at the Fort Hood Education Services Division located in the Soldier Development Center, Bldg. 33009, room G201 or by calling CTC at 254-526-1265.
column9: 美国德克萨斯州基林
column10: 胡德堡士兵在反恐中心完成第一张地图-P
column11: 德克萨斯州基林――7名被分配到胡德堡部队的现役士兵于8月9日毕业于德克萨斯州中部学院的军事衔接辅助医疗计划。该计划是反恐委员会的第一个此类计划，允许现役士兵在比传统要求更短的时间内获得护理人员证书，同时保持其现役要求。国会议员约翰・卡特是当晚的特邀演讲人之一。卡特说：“你是军队绝对需要的第一人，第一人。”。“因此，我非常感谢我们今天在这里所做的工作；这将有助于男女军人在服役和履行其义务的同时提高他们的技能。”虽然士兵们已经从该项目毕业，他们仍然需要通过国家注册中心的测试获得认证，才能正式成为护理人员。“军事护理人员项目提供了扩展知识的机会，因此他们将成为更有效的士兵，”卡特说。“这给了他们在外出工作时可以使用的技能。”第三装甲旅战斗队士兵、第215旅支援营的Jewel Lewis下士对完成这门课程感到兴奋。“很荣幸从这门课程毕业，”Lewis说。“这是一个漫长的9个半月，但很好。我们能够提高我们的医学知识，我认为这对所有的医生以及对医学领域感兴趣的人来说都是一个非常好的机会。”刘易斯和她的大多数同学正计划通过参加提供的陆军课程继续他们的学业，在卡特等政府官员、德克萨斯州中部学院管理人员和胡德堡领导层的支持下，这些课程将继续为感兴趣的士兵提供。卡特说：“我预计这个节目每年都会越来越受欢迎。”。“我希望看到它扩大和成长。你们所有人都是第一个家庭的一部分，无论是家庭成员还是士兵，都为你们现在正在耕种的土地感到自豪，因为它将在未来结出硕果。”第二批已经开始，但第三批计划将于2019年6月开始。希望报名参加该项目的士兵必须首先填写入学检查表。有关所有资格要求、入学、先决条件和学费资助的信息，可向胡德堡教育服务部索取，该部位于士兵发展中心33009栋G201室，或致电254-526-1265与反恐委员会联系。

column2: SMSgt Billing receives AFRC Lance P. Sijan award
column3:
When the award was first presented in 1981, it was named in honor of the first U.S. Air Force Academy graduate to receive the Medal of Honor C Capt. Lance P. Sijan.

 Sijan was shot down over Vietnam Nov. 9, 1967, and evaded capture for 45 days despite enduring serious injuries. He later died as a POW in Vietnam and was posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor for heroism. Today, the Lance P. Sijan awarded is presented to individuals who have demonstrated outstanding leadership abilities across all Air Force Specialty Codes.

 Senior Master Sgt. James Billing, 434th Maintenance Squadron production superintendent, recently received the Lance P. Sijan award for all of Air Force Reserve Command for his leadership excellence from June 2016 to June 2017.

“Senior Master Sgt. Billing's position as the Assistant Superintendent for the 434th Maintenance Squadron requires a high degree of maintenance discipline, teamwork, leadership and skill all of which he possess in spades,” said Maj. Nicole Fink, 434th Maintenance Squadron commander. His sound decision making and stellar work ethic made him the ideal nominee for the Lance P. Sijan award."

 Billing was notified he received the Sijan award during a deployment to Turkey.

“It’s an honor to be nominated for it and to win for all of Air Force Reserve Command,” Billing said. “It just shows the great people that we have and are working with. Any leadership award comes down to the people that work for you C that do the job for you. They’re the ones that make my job easier. And our maintenance guys are outstanding; they do a great job and our planes are known to outdo active-duty and the Reserve for how well they fly and how they look. That all comes down to our maintenance guys.”

During the period which the award covers, Billing filled the role of multiple positions.

“When I was deployed to Turkey, I was the lead production superintendent there, covering all flightline maintenance,” Billing said. “We were able to set up Incirlik from bare bones; there was nothing there to support tankers; and we were able to fly missions within 24 hours. Then, here [at Grissom] I filled in for Chief Cassidy as the superintendent while he was deployed and maintained the day-today operations. In Chief Cassidy’s absence, I oversaw 10 maintenance back shops, coordinated with the flightline to make sure all planes flew and maintenance was done.”

Although Billing said he is unsure why he was nominated for the award, others disagree.

 "Senior Master Sgt. Billing is a consummate professional who is very deserving of this award," said Lt. Col. Dwight Meese, 434th Maintenance Group commander. “Senior Master Sgt. Billing important in his management of the MXS Periodic Inspection (PE) process, ensuring inspections are completed in a safe and timely manner so that the aircraft can be put back in the flying rotation with minimal downtime."

 The 434th ARW is the largest KC-135R Stratotanker unit in the Air Force Reserve Command. Men and women from the Hoosier Wing routinely deploy around the world in support of the Air Force mission.

 Stay connected with the 434th ARW on Facebook and Twitter.
column6: GRISSOM AIR RESERVE BASE, IN, UNITED STATES

column10: SMSgt Billing获得AFRC Lance P.Sijan奖
column11: 该奖项于1981年首次颁发时，是为纪念第一位获得荣誉勋章的美国空军学院毕业生――兰斯・P・西扬上尉而命名的。西扬于1967年11月9日在越南上空被击落，尽管身受重伤，但仍逃避追捕45天。他后来作为战俘死于越南，并因英雄主义而被追授荣誉勋章。今天，兰斯・P・西扬奖颁发给在所有空军专业代码中表现出杰出领导能力的个人。第434维修中队生产总监高级军士詹姆斯・比尔（James Billing）最近因其在2016年6月至2017年6月期间的卓越领导能力而获得空军预备役司令部兰斯・P・西扬奖。“高级军士长Billing作为第434维修中队助理警司的职位需要高度的维修纪律、团队合作、领导能力和技能，而所有这些都是他所具备的。”第434维修中队指挥官Nicole Fink少校说。他良好的决策能力和出色的职业道德使他成为兰斯・P・西扬奖的理想提名人。“Billing接到通知说，他在前往土耳其的一次部署中获得了西扬奖。“能够获得提名并赢得所有空军预备役司令部的荣誉。”比尔说。“这只是展示了我们拥有并正在与之合作的伟大人物。任何领导力奖项都归于那些为你工作的人――那些为你工作的人。他们让我的工作更轻松。我们的维修人员非常出色；他们做得很好，我们的飞机以其出色的性能超过现役和后备役而闻名Billing说：“在获奖期间，Billing担任了多个职位。当我被部署到土耳其时，我是那里的首席生产总监，负责所有的飞行线路维护。”。“我们能够赤裸裸地建立Incrlik；那里没有任何支持油轮的东西；我们能够在24小时内执行任务在卡西迪机长被部署和维护今天的行动时，我代替他担任机长。在卡西迪机长不在的时候，我监督了10个维修车间，与飞行线协调，以确保所有飞机都能飞行并完成维修。”尽管Billing说他不确定自己为什么被提名该奖项，但其他人不同意。“高级军士长Billing是一名完美的专业人员，非常值得获得该奖项，”第434维修组指挥官Dwight Meese中校说。“高级军士长Billing在MXS定期检查（PE）的管理中非常重要。”过程中，确保安全及时地完成检查，以使飞机能够在最短的停机时间内恢复飞行旋转。”第434 ARW是美国空军预备役司令部最大的KC-135R层流加油机部队。胡塞尔联队的男男女女通常部署在世界各地支持空军任务。在Facebook和Twitter上与第434 ARW保持联系。

column2: RHC-P chief of staff awarded Army Regent's award
column3:
Brig. Gen. Bertram Providence, Regional Health Command-Pacific commander, presented Col. Laura Trinkle, RHC-P chief of staff, with the American College of Healthcare Executives Army Regent’s Career Achievement Award, March 30 as she was unable to accept the award in person at the annual conference.  

In order to receive the award, a variety of criteria must be met, including proven leadership ability, demonstration of innovative and creative management, promoting growth in the organization throughout the community and contributing to the development of others in the healthcare profession.  

Trinkle said she’s humbled and honored to receive the award.  This award marks her second Army Regent Award.  She had previously been awarded the Army Regent’s Senior-Level Healthcare Executive Award.  

Providence said the caliber of people throughout the region was evident. "This is a well-deserved award and another indicator of the great things people in our region, like Col. Trinkle, do in support of our Army Medicine mission," he said.

column10: RHC-P参谋长获得陆军摄政王奖
column11: 布里格。3月30日，太平洋地区卫生司令部指挥官伯特伦・普罗维登斯将军向RHC-P参谋长劳拉・特林克尔上校颁发了美国医疗保健行政学院陆军摄政王职业成就奖，因为她无法亲自在年度会议上接受该奖项。为了获得该奖项，必须满足多种标准，包括经验证的领导能力、创新和创造性管理的展示、促进整个社区组织的发展以及为医疗行业其他人的发展做出贡献。Trinkle说她很荣幸能获得这个奖项。这是她第二次获得陆军摄政王奖。她之前曾获得陆军摄政王高级医疗保健执行官奖。普罗维登斯说，整个地区人民的素质是显而易见的。他说：“这是一个当之无愧的奖项，也是我们地区人民，比如特林克尔上校，为支持我们的陆军医疗任务所做的伟大事情的另一个标志。”。

column2: RHC-P Soldiers compete for the honor to wear the GAFPB badge
column3:
SCHOFIELD BARRACKS, HAWAII -- Regional Health Command-Pacific (RHC-P) Soldiers competed in the 2017 German Armed Forces Proficiency Badge (GAFPB) event co-hosted by the 303rd Ordinance Battalion (Explosive Ordnance Disposal), at Schofield Barracks, Hawaii. Soldiers from RHC-P competed alongside over 200 Soldiers from units around Oahu.

The GAFPB (German: Abzeichen für Leistungen im Truppendienst) is a decoration of the German Armed Forces, authorized for wear by the U.S. military, and awarded to soldiers of all ranks.  The GAFPB is one of the few approved foreign awards, and it is one of the most sought after awards to achieve.  

"As a Soldier who has earned a GAFPB badge, it was natural for me to step-up and assist with the coordination of this year's event," stated Master Sgt. Javier Najera, non-commissioned officer in charge, RHC-P.  "Master Sgt. Elisa Todd was also a driving force during the planning and execution of this event. She stepped up and worked side-by-side with me to ensure all participants experienced a streamlined process so that they could perform to their highest ability."

RHC-P participants included Army Medicine Soldiers from the U.S. Army Recruiting Command, Tripler Army Medical Center (TAMC), U.S. Army Health Clinic-Schofield Barracks (USAHC-SB), Dental Health Command-Pacific (DHC-P), Public Health Command-Pacific (PHC-P) and 18th Medical Command-Deployment Support (18th MEDCOM).  

Competitors faced four events over the course of three days. 

During day one of competition the first task Soldiers were challenged with was a 100 meter swim while wearing ACUs. Swimmers had a time constraint of four minutes and upon completion of the swim had to tread water and remove their ACUs. Day one continued in the afternoon with the basic fitness test consisting of an 11x10m sprint, a flex arm hang (chin-up test) and a 1000 meter run. 

A pistol qualification test awaited competitors on the second day.  Individuals fired an M9 in a prone position (2 shots), kneeling position (2 shots) and standing position (2 shots).  

The last day of competition was the ruck march.  Each Soldier rucked the distance carrying a 33 pound ruck sack.

In the end, thirteen RHC-P Soldiers earned a silver badge, while 8 Soldiers earned a bronze badge. Each competitor’s achievement was recognized at an award's ceremony held on Hamilton Field at Schofield Barracks on August 10, 2017.  Leaders from around the island came out to honor those who competed in this year’s event.

“The Soldiers who competed for the GAFPB this week are an example of the strength of force in our ranks,” stated Sgt. Maj. Richard Watson, senior enlisted advisor, RHC-P. “I am proud of this team of RHC-P Soldiers, as they carry on the tradition of Army excellence and represent the Army’s number one priority, readiness.”
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: RHC-P士兵竞逐佩戴GAFPB徽章的荣誉
column11: 夏威夷斯科菲尔德兵营――太平洋地区卫生司令部（RHC-P）士兵参加了2017年德国武装部队熟练程度徽章（GAFPB）活动，该活动由第303条例营（爆炸物处理）在夏威夷斯科菲尔德兵营共同主办。来自RHC-P的士兵与来自瓦胡岛周围部队的200多名士兵一起参加比赛。GAFPB（德语：Abzeichen für Leistungen im Truppendienst）是德国武装部队的一种勋章，经美国军方授权佩戴，授予所有级别的士兵。GAFPB是少数获得批准的外国奖项之一，也是最受欢迎的奖项之一。“作为一名获得了GAFPB徽章的士兵，我很自然地站出来协助协调今年的活动，”RHC-P的非委任主管Javier Najera上士表示。“Elisa Todd上士也是策划和执行本次活动的推动力。她走上前来，与我并肩工作，以确保所有参与者都经历了一个简化的过程，以便他们能够发挥最大的能力。”RHC-P参与者包括来自美国陆军招募司令部、三联军医疗中心（TAMC）、美国陆军健康诊所斯科菲尔德兵营（USAHC-SB）的陆军医疗兵太平洋牙科卫生司令部（DHC-P）、太平洋公共卫生司令部（PHC-P）和第18医疗司令部部署支援（第18医疗司令部）。参赛者在三天的时间内面临四个项目。在比赛的第一天，士兵们的第一个任务是戴着ACU游泳100米。游泳运动员的时间限制为四分钟，游泳结束后必须踩水并取下ACU。第一天下午继续进行c体能测试，包括11x10m短跑、屈臂悬吊（引体向上测试）和1000米跑。第二天，选手将进行手枪资格测试。个人在俯卧位（2发）、跪位（2发）和站立位（2发）射击M9。比赛的最后一天是卡车游行。每位士兵背着一个33磅重的卡车袋子，用卡车行进了一段距离。最终，13名RHC-P士兵获得了一枚银牌，8名士兵获得了一枚铜牌。2017年8月10日，在Schofield兵营的Hamilton Field举行的颁奖典礼上，每位选手的成就都得到了认可。来自全岛各地的领导人都站出来向参加今年比赛的人表示敬意。“本周参加GAFPB比赛的士兵是我们队伍中力量强大的一个例子，”RHC-P高级征兵顾问理查德・沃森少校说。“我为这支RHC-P士兵队伍感到自豪，因为他们继承了陆军卓越的传统，代表了陆军的首要任务，即准备就绪。”

column2: RHC-P paves way for global health engagements in 2016
column3:
HONOLULU--It is through strong partnerships with U.S. Pacific Command (PACOM) and U.S. Army in the Pacific (USARPAC) that Army Medicine’s Regional Health Command-Pacific (RHC-P) is able to commit the resources to provide greater physical and mental well-being through rapidly growing global health engagements. 

RHC-P alongside other U.S. government agencies, partner nations and global health stakeholders are constantly redefining, and refining, global health activities to improve the well-being of citizens in the Pacific. The combined efforts increase stability and cooperation in the Pacific and beyond.  Global health efforts are also inextricably linked to other disciplines and society sectors such as agriculture, economics, environment, religion and veterinary science which continually impact the global health field. 

Every engagement RHC-P commits resources to enhances our regional health partnerships and ensures our nation’s military force is ready to support any mission.

Global health activities are accomplished through various operations and activities including conferences, bi-lateral subject matter expert exchanges, humanitarian assistance and disaster relief exercises and medical support to operational missions in conjunction with partner nations.
Global health engagements (GHE) activities also include developing and implementing health preparedness measures and responses to threats like infectious diseases (zika, ebola, malaria, avian influenza, etc.) and non-communicable diseases (cancers, diabetes, heart diseases, etc.) that are not adequately controlled, prevented or deterred by a country’s boundaries. 

RHC-P's involvement with global health engagements has also allowed the region to gain credibility among the 36 Indo-Asia-Pacific countries in our area of responsibility.

“Army medicine has gained credibility as a partner of choice through our persistent health engagements with nations here in the Pacific,” says Lt. Col. Derek Licina, director, GHE, RHC-P. “We are still shaping how Army Medicine and the Department of Defense more systematically resource, plan, execute and assess global health engagements.  However, initial evaluations conducted by the Uniformed Services University Center for Global Health Engagement highlight GHEs are supporting U.S. government strategic objectives, generating readiness for our service members, and increasing the capacity of our partners to prepare for and conduct crisis response activities.”   

Over the past few years RHC-P has conducted approximately 60 health engagements, involving over 20 of the 36 countries in RHC-P’s area of responsibility in the Indo-Asia-Pacific region. The activities ranged from medical missions in partner countries to senior leader engagements at the region and at RHC-P’s military medical centers and clinics. 

Here is a quick look back at the 2016 health missions and senior leader engagements RHC-P conducted.

BANGLADESH

RHC-P’s efforts in Bangladesh support a U.S. Agency for International Development program where Army providers and Bangladesh civilian medical professionals assist women by surgically repairing fistulas. This mission also provides readiness training for providers while meeting country security cooperation objectives. During the most recent mission, 36 surgeries were performed and 13 lectures presented at leading medical facilities attended by over 800 Bangladeshi health professionals.

CAMBODIA

During the blood safety health engagement series, health professionals from RHC-P established and built upon relationships with Cambodia’s military medical staff and civilian provincial health managers. The team’s efforts facilitated a broad outreach effort to promote confidence and trust within the community and advanced Army Medicine objectives in support of PACOM and USARPAC’s strategic objectives.  The result was the opening of a critical asset, a national blood bank in Cambodia.  This health engagement effort enhances Cambodia’s ability to provide critical support to the civilian population, while supporting land forces contribution to regional and global security.  
CHINA

During the fall, RHC-P supported USARPAC and USPACOM efforts to engage China through a subject matter expert exchange focusing on acupuncture. Through the exchange, each nation increased their understanding of other unique approaches to health based on culture and science. The Chinese delegation gained a deeper understanding of how RHC-P’s military treatment facilities uses western and eastern medicine, while RHC-P gained insight into how traditional Chinese medicine can potentially assist with the management of patients with chronic pain, post-traumatic stress disorder and in response to disaster situations.

The visit by the Chinese delegation builds upon, and continues, subject matter expert exchanges between the two nations. 

KINGDOM OF THAILAND

A senior leader engagement between RHC-P and the Kingdom of Thailand provided the leaders in the Thai delegation a better understanding of how RHC-P orchestrates the delivery of world-class medical care for service members, families and eligible beneficiaries while enabling medical readiness and conducting health diplomacy in the Pacific.

RHC-P leadership recognized the Thai’s significant contributions to past global health engagements and regional exercises and encouraged future support and participation. Leaders from both sides expressed interest in identifying future ways to leverage health engagements to build upon a regionally sustainable health capacity that supports regional security.

PALAU

RHC-P’s Tripler Army Medical Center (TAMC) continued a long standing health mission with the Palau Ministry of Health.  This mission provides significant training value for both countries’ medical professionals while offering specialized surgical procedures for Palau citizens in need. 

For RHC-P Soldiers this on-going mission improves operational and deployment skill sets, enhances medical decision making in a resource constrained environment and increases medical proficiencies in foreign environments. During the most recent mission, providers also offered medical training to local medical staff on the evaluation and treatment of diseases of the head and neck.  

Over 400 outpatients were seen using more than 100 clinic procedures and 35 operative cases during this mission.  

SINGAPORE

TAMC, one of RHC-P’s largest subordinate military treatment facilities, supported an outbreak detection and intervention workshop in Singapore where the Department of Preventive Medicine C Infection Control & Epidemiology Service joined 41 participants from Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, Thailand, Singapore, Vietnam and the United States to improve infectious disease surveillance. Participants came from a diversity of backgrounds including health policy, epidemiology, public health and veterinary medicine.

The group worked together to advocated for decisive, safe, and effective outbreak response mechanisms, avenues to support the adoption of the International Health Regulation and worked towards sensitizing medical and disaster planners to ethical considerations in outbreak response. The course covered outbreak surveillance and intervention in a progression of differing contexts.  There were didactic sessions, tabletop and risk communication exercises, Ebola triage exercises as well as practical exercises. 

SRI LANKA

During an engagement in Sri Lanka, RHC-P taught humanitarian assistance/disaster relief (HA/DR) planning techniques to civilians, military and interagency governmental partners. The HA/DR mission established a relationship with local and interagency military medical staff to provide general medical, dental, optometry, and physical medicine care to underserved population in the host country. A medical exchange with subject matter experts on casualty evacuation, biomedical equipment repair and community public health outreach programs were also conducted.

The HA/DR effort also included an engineering project to repair local schools and public buildings while delivering medical services and donating medical supplies and equipment to the school. A total of almost 4000 patients were seen over five days.  This mission was successful in enhancing multi-national cooperation and improving local infrastructure and capabilities. 

VIETNAM

A seven-person Vietnamese delegation visited RHC-P for a command brief and tour of TAMC. The visit allowed leaders from both countries to share professional experiences in an effort to further strengthen the military medical and health partnerships in the Indo-Asia-Pacific region. 

The Vietnamese delegates expressed interest in future opportunities to work on building and expanding on sustainable health capacity in areas such as laboratory management, orthopedics, pain management, search and rescue, and disaster medicine.

FUTURE of GHEs at RHC-P

As RHC-P continues to move forward in 2017 and beyond, the region alongside PACOM and USARPAC, will strengthen and sustain relationships and friendships already forged, build new relationships and continue to provide quality health care to those in need or without access to basic or specialized medical care around the Pacific.

Planning for on-going and future global health engagements requires a focus on promoting cooperation, building capacity and taking actions to enhance stability with, within, and around partner and host nations across all service components as well as with other stakeholders.
  
RHC-P’s global health engagement team is also helping to set the standard for all service branches participating in health engagements efforts. The team recently attended the Association of Military Surgeons United States' (AMSUS) 125th annual meeting. At AMSUS the team presented a poster and participated in a panel to share experience based best practices which generated interest among attendees as a way to standardize global health efforts, approaches and standard operating procedures for future global health engagements.

RHC-P’s global health efforts seek to prevent disease and improve the health of systems and of individuals.  The knowledge learned and hard work from past activities paves the way for future, successful, health engagements in the Pacific.

column10: RHC-P为2016年全球卫生服务铺平道路
column11: 檀香山――正是通过与美国太平洋司令部（PACOM）和美国太平洋陆军（USARPAC）的紧密合作，陆军医学太平洋地区卫生司令部（RHC-P）才能够通过快速增长的全球卫生活动投入资源，提供更大的身心健康。RHC-P与其他美国政府机构、伙伴国家和全球卫生利益相关者一起，不断重新定义和完善全球卫生活动，以改善太平洋地区公民的福祉。共同努力加强了太平洋及以外地区的稳定与合作。全球卫生工作还与农业、经济、环境、宗教和兽医学等其他学科和社会部门密不可分，这些学科和部门不断影响着全球卫生领域。RHC-P的每一次参与都将投入资源，以加强我们的区域卫生合作伙伴关系，并确保我国军队随时准备支持任何任务。全球卫生活动通过各种行动和活动完成，包括会议、双边主题专家交流、，人道主义援助和救灾演习，以及与伙伴国家一起向行动任务提供医疗支持。全球卫生服务（GHE）活动还包括制定和实施卫生防备措施，以及应对传染病（寨卡、埃博拉、疟疾、禽流感等）等威胁以及国家边界无法充分控制、预防或阻止的非传染性疾病（癌症、糖尿病、心脏病等）。RHC-P参与全球卫生活动也使该地区在我们负责的36个印度-亚太国家中获得了信誉。“陆军医学通过我们与太平洋国家的持续卫生活动获得了作为首选合作伙伴的信誉，”陆军部主任德里克・利西纳中校说，GHE，RHC-P。“我们仍在塑造陆军医学和国防部如何更系统地为全球卫生服务提供资源、规划、执行和评估。然而，军警服务大学全球卫生服务中心进行的初步评估强调了GHEs支持美国政府的战略目标，产生了rea为我们的服务成员提供餐饮服务，并提高我们的合作伙伴准备和开展危机应对活动的能力。”在过去几年中，RHC-P开展了约60次医疗活动，涉及印度-亚太地区RHC-P责任区36个国家中的20多个国家。活动范围从在伙伴国家的医疗任务到在该地区以及RHC-P军事医疗中心和临床的高级领导活动ics。这里快速回顾一下2016年卫生任务和RHC-P高级领导参与的活动。孟加拉国RHC-P在孟加拉国的努力支持了美国国际开发署的一个项目，在该项目中，军队提供者和孟加拉国平民医疗专业人员通过手术修复瘘管来帮助妇女。该任务还提供了r在实现国家安全合作目标的同时，为供应商提供主动性培训。在最近的任务中，在主要医疗机构进行了36次手术，并举办了13次讲座，800多名孟加拉国卫生专业人员参加了讲座。坎波迪在血液安全卫生参与系列中，来自RHC-P es的卫生专业人员与柬埔寨军事医务人员和省级卫生管理人员建立并建立了关系。该团队的努力促进了广泛的外联工作，以促进社区内的信心和信任，并促进了军队医学目标，以支持PACOM和USARPAC的战略目标。结果是柬埔寨国家血库是柬埔寨的一项重要资产。这项卫生参与工作提高了柬埔寨向平民人口提供关键支持的能力，同时支持陆军对区域和全球安全的贡献。中国在秋季，RHC-P支持USARPAC和USPACOM通过su与中国进行接触以针灸为重点的对象问题专家交流。通过交流，每个国家都增加了对基于文化和科学的其他独特健康方法的了解。中国代表团对RHC-P的军事治疗设施如何使用西方和东方医学有了更深入的了解，而RHC-P在这方面也有了深入的了解中国代表团的访问是在两国主题专家交流的基础上进行的，并将继续下去。泰国王国高级领导人将tween RHC-P和泰国王国使泰国代表团的领导人更好地了解了RHC-P如何协调为服务人员、家庭和合格受益人提供世界级医疗服务，同时在太平洋地区实现医疗准备和开展卫生外交。RHC-P领导承认泰国对过去的全球卫生活动和区域演习做出了重大贡献，并鼓励了未来的支持和参与。双方领导人表示有兴趣确定未来利用卫生活动的方式，以建立支持区域安全的区域可持续卫生能力rmy医疗中心（TAMC）继续与帕劳卫生部进行长期的卫生任务。该任务为两国的医疗专业人员提供了重要的培训价值，同时为有需要的帕劳公民提供专门的外科手术。对于RHC-P士兵来说，这项持续的任务提高了操作和部署技能，增强了医疗能力在资源有限的环境中进行决策，并提高在国外环境中的医疗水平。在最近的任务中，供应商还向当地医务人员提供了关于头颈部疾病评估和治疗的医疗培训。400多名门诊患者使用了100多个临床程序新加坡TAMC是RHC-P最大的下属军事治疗机构之一，支持在新加坡举办的疫情检测和干预研讨会，预防医学部感染控制和流行病学服务与来自柬埔寨、印度尼西亚、老挝、马来西亚的41名参与者一起参加了研讨会ia、缅甸、泰国、新加坡、越南和美国共同致力于改进传染病监测。参与者来自不同背景，包括卫生政策、流行病学、公共卫生和兽医学。该小组共同倡导果断、安全和有效的疫情应对机制，以及解决问题的途径支持采用《国际卫生条例》，并致力于使医疗和灾害规划者对疫情应对中的道德考虑敏感。课程涵盖了不同背景下的疫情监测和干预。课程包括说教课程、桌面和风险沟通练习、埃博拉triage演习和实践演习。斯里兰卡参与了斯里兰卡的活动，RHC-P教授人道主义援助/救灾（HA/DR）向平民、军队和跨机构政府合作伙伴提供规划技术。医管局/DR特派团与当地和跨机构军事医务人员建立了关系，为东道国服务不足的人群提供普通医疗、牙科、验光和物理医疗护理。与主题专家就此外，医院管理局/灾难恢复中心还开展了伤员后送、生物医学设备维修和社区公共卫生外展计划。该项目还包括一项工程项目，在向学校提供医疗服务和捐赠医疗用品及设备的同时，对当地学校和公共建筑进行维修。共看到了近4000名患者五天多的时间。这次访问成功地加强了多国合作，改善了当地的基础设施和能力。越南越南越南七人代表团访问了RHC-P，进行了指挥简报和TAMC之旅。这次访问使两国领导人能够分享专业经验，以进一步加强合作印度-亚太地区的军事医疗和卫生伙伴关系。越南代表对未来在实验室管理、整形外科、疼痛管理、搜索和救援以及灾难医学等领域建设和扩大可持续卫生能力的机会表示了兴趣HC-P将在2017年及以后继续向前迈进，该地区将与PACOM和USARPAC一道，加强和维持已经建立的关系和友谊，建立新的关系，并继续为太平洋地区需要或无法获得基本或专业医疗服务的人提供优质医疗服务。规划持续和未来的全球卫生活动需要注重促进合作、能力建设和采取行动，以加强所有服务组成部分以及其他利益相关者与合作伙伴和东道国之间、内部和周围的稳定性。RHC-P的全球卫生活动团队也在帮助为所有服务部门制定标准他参与了医疗活动。该团队最近参加了美国军事外科医生协会（AMSUS）第125届年会。在AMSU上，团队展示了海报并参加了一个小组，以分享基于经验的最佳实践，这引起了与会者的兴趣，作为未来全球卫生活动的标准化全球卫生工作、方法和标准操作程序的一种方式。RHC-P的全球卫生工作旨在防止di从过去的活动中学习到的知识和辛勤工作为f

column2: National Guard Winston P. Wilson Small Arms Championships
column3:
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
April 5, 2017

Contact/ Release Authority: “Released”
Capt. Reese Walker
Public Affairs Officer
National Guard Marksmanship Training Center
(501) 212-4565
Theresa.L.Walker24.mil@mail.mil


National Guard Winston P. Wilson Small Arms Championships
~ 46th WPW Championship & 26th AFSAM

By Master Sgt. Jonathan D. Brizendine, National Guard Marksmanship Training Center

ROBINSON MANEUVER TRAINING CENTER, Ark. C Members of the Arkansas National Guard Marksmanship Training Center (NGMTC) prepare for the Guard’s national level marksmanship competitions scheduled to begin here April 22.

Events on the schedule include the 46th Winston P. Wilson (WPW) Sniper Championship (April 22 C April 27) and the 46th WPW Championship (April 30 C May 4), as well as, a multinational and interservice competition, the 26th Armed Forces Skill at Arms Meeting (AFSAM) (April 30 C May 5). These matches are designed to promote marksmanship training through competition between service members that is battle-focused using a controlled stressful environment.

This year’s WPW and AFSAM matches will include service members from Active Duty, National Guard, Marine Corp, Air Force, and Foreign Allies engaging targets with the M4/M4A1 and M16A2/A4 Rifles, and M21/M14, M24, M110/SR 25, M40A and M2010 sniper weapon systems at Ft. Chaffee Joint Maneuver Training Center, Ark. Each two-man sniper team will be evaluated on field firing, advanced marksmanship, field craft, shooter and spotter communication, and target engagement with a sidearm. 

While the snipers compete for top honors at Ft. Chaffee, other contenders will be zeroing their weapons on ranges at Robinson Maneuver Training Center in preparation for the small arms WPW Championship and AFSAM. Subsequent courses of fire will test their expertise with the M9 Pistol, the M4/M16 Rifle, and the M500 Shotgun.

Each match will culminate with an awards banquet celebrating the winners of individual, team events and the overall best performers. 

“Our soldiers and airmen have worked countless hours all year to ensure competitors have a safe and challenging experience,” said Col. Dennis J. Humphrey, NGMTC Commander. “As returning competitors can attest, all who attend are sure to come away with new contacts, new skills, and the pride of having represented their unit and region.”

This year’s matches are attracting more than 500 marksmen from around the globe. With national teams going head-to-head with one another and foreign allied teams from as far away as Italy, it promises to be a memorable experience for all who attend. Perhaps most importantly, competitors are certain to come away with more than just trophies.

“As competitive as they are, the matches aren’t solely about defining who is the best,” said Lt. Col. Todd C. Stuff, NGMTC Administrative Officer. “Ultimately, the focus is on training.”

“When the best marksmen from around the globe come together,” he continued “they bring with them valuable experience and insight which they enthusiastically share with their fellow warriors. The shooters then take what they learn back to their units and pass along their new skillsets to their soldiers and airmen.”

Training for accuracy is most important.

“The end goal is increased accuracy resulting in more troops coming home from deployments in one piece,” said Stuff. “When that happens, we’re all winners.”

For more information about getting involved, contact Maj. Dwayne Page 501-212-4531 or visit us on the web at www.ngmtc.wordpress.com.

-30-

column9: 美国阿肯色州北小石城
column10: 国民警卫队温斯顿・P・威尔逊小武器锦标赛
column11: 立即释放2017年4月5日联系/释放机构：“释放”里斯・沃克尔上尉公共事务官员国民警卫队射击训练中心（501）212-4565特蕾莎・沃克尔24。mil@mail.milNational卫兵温斯顿・P・威尔逊小武器锦标赛~第46届WPW锦标赛和第26届非洲桑比大师乔纳森・D・布里曾丹中士，国民警卫队射击训练中心阿肯色州罗宾逊机动训练中心-阿肯色州国民警卫队射击训练中心（NGMTC）的成员为定于4月22日在这里开始的国民警卫队国家级射击比赛做准备。计划中的活动包括第46届温斯顿・P・威尔逊（WPW）狙击手锦标赛（4月22日至4月27日）和第46届WPW锦标赛（4月30日至5月4日），以及，第26届武装部队武器技能会议（AFSAM）（4月30日至5月5日）是一场多国和军种间的竞赛。这些比赛旨在通过军人之间的竞争促进射击训练，这种竞争在可控的压力环境下以战斗为中心。今年的WPW和AFSAM比赛将包括现役军人、国民警卫队、海军陆战队、空军、，以及外国盟军使用M4/M4A1和M16A2/A4步枪以及M21/M14、M24、M110/SR 25、M40A和M2010狙击武器系统攻击目标。每个双人狙击手小组将接受野战射击、高级射击、野战艇、射手和观察员通信以及侧臂与目标交战的评估。当狙击手在查菲堡争夺最高荣誉时，其他竞争者将把武器瞄准罗宾逊机动训练中心的靶场，为小武器WPW锦标赛和AFSAM做准备。随后的射击课程将用M9手枪、M4/M16步枪和M500猎枪测试他们的专业技能。每场比赛将以庆祝个人、团队活动和整体最佳表现的获奖者的颁奖宴会结束。NGMTC指挥官丹尼斯・J・汉弗莱上校说：“我们的士兵和飞行员一年中工作了无数个小时，以确保竞争对手获得安全和富有挑战性的体验。”。“正如归来的参赛者可以证明的那样，所有参加比赛的人肯定会带来新的接触、新的技能，以及代表他们所在单位和地区的自豪感。”今年的比赛吸引了来自世界各地的500多名射手。随着国家队与其他国家队以及远至意大利的外国联队的对决，这将是所有与会人员难忘的经历。也许最重要的是，参赛者肯定会获得的不仅仅是奖杯。“尽管他们很有竞争力，但比赛不仅仅是定义谁是最好的，”NGMTC行政官员托德・C・斯塔夫中校说。“最终，重点是训练。”“当来自世界各地的最好的射手聚集在一起时，”他继续说“他们带来了宝贵的经验和见解，并热情地与战士们分享。然后，射击运动员将学到的知识带回部队，并将他们的新技能传授给士兵和飞行员。”准确度训练是最重要的。Stuff说：“最终目标是提高准确度，使更多的部队整装待发回国。当这种情况发生时，我们都是赢家。”有关参与的更多信息，请联系Dwayne少校第501-212-4531页或访问我们的网站www.ngmtc.wordpress.com.-30-

column2: RHC-P conducts bi-lateral engagement with United Kingdom
column3:
HONOLULU, Hawaii -- (Jan. 25, 2017) Regional Health Command-Pacific, also known as RHC-P, conducted a bi-lateral, senior leader engagement with military medical leads from the United Kingdom.

RHC-P Commanding General, Brig. Gen. Bertram Providence, along with other RHC-P and United States Army Pacific key leaders, provided a command briefing and engaged in discussions with United Kingdom Ministry of Defense senior leader, the Director of Medical Policy, Operations and Capability, British Maj. Gen. Martin Bricknell, along with Medical Operations Staff Officer, British Lt. Col. Helen Smyth. 

The global health engagement also focused on how RHC-P and United Kingdom military medical assets have engaged the Vietnam Ministry of Defense through subject matter exchanges in the past and also projected upcoming endeavors to support the Southeast Asian country in its deployment of a level 2 hospital to South Sudan in 2018. 

During the meeting, RHC-P and United Kingdom medical leaders also discussed how they could effectively integrate efforts to increase Vietnam's capacity and agreed to initiate multilateral planning in support of the Vietnam mission, which will support the Army Medical Command, United States Army Pacific and United States Pacific Command readiness and partnership objectives. 

About RHC-P: RHC-P orchestrates the delivery of world-class medical care for service members, families and eligible beneficiaries, and provides medical readiness and diplomacy in support of United States Army Pacific in the Pacific Command area of responsibility.
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: RHC-P与英国进行双边合作
column11: 夏威夷檀香山――（2017年1月25日）太平洋地区卫生司令部，也称为RHC-P，与来自英国的军事医疗领导进行了双边、高级领导接触。RHC-P司令部准将。伯特伦・普罗维登斯将军与其他RHC-P和美国陆军太平洋地区主要领导人一起，提供了指挥简报，并与英国国防部高级领导人、医疗政策、行动和能力总监、英国少将马丁・布里克内尔以及医疗行动参谋进行了讨论，英国中校海伦・斯迈思。全球卫生参与还集中于RHC-P和英国军事医疗资产过去如何通过主题交流与越南国防部进行接触，并预测将在2018年支持该东南亚国家在南苏丹部署二级医院。在会议期间，RHC-P和英国医疗领导人还讨论了如何有效整合提高越南能力的工作，并同意启动支持越南任务的多边规划，该任务将支持陆军医疗司令部，美国陆军太平洋司令部和美国太平洋司令部准备就绪和伙伴关系目标。关于RHC-P：RHC-P为服役人员、家属和合格受益人提供世界一流的医疗服务，并在太平洋司令部责任区为美国陆军太平洋分部提供医疗准备和外交支持。

column2: Florida Guardmen Participated in CERF-P Training at Camp Blanding
column3: Over 200 Airmen and Soldiers from the Florida National Guard trained for search and rescue, medical treatment, and command and control efforts that could occur after an attack or disaster on a populated area.  The CERF-P team, or Certified Chemical, Biological, Nuclear, and Explosives Package, completed their biannual requirements this weekend at Camp Blanding.  Members of the Stark community portrayed victims and work prosthetic wounds and costume blood to enhance the training scenario.
column9: 美国佛罗里达州布兰德营
column10: 佛罗里达卫兵参加了在布兰德营地的CERF-P训练
column11: 来自佛罗里达州国民警卫队的200多名飞行员和士兵接受了搜救、医疗、指挥和控制训练，这些训练可能发生在人口稠密地区的袭击或灾难之后。CERF-P团队，或经认证的化学、生物、核和爆炸物包，本周末在布兰德营地完成了两年一次的要求。斯塔克社区的成员描绘了受害者，用假肢伤口和化装血来强化训练场景。

column2: RHC-P enhances emergency response during RIMPAC 2016
column3:
FORD ISLAND, Hawaii (July, 14, 2016) -- Regional Health Command-Pacific (RHC-P) successfully led key medical activities aimed at enhancing humanitarian aid and disaster relief efforts across the region as part of Rim of the Pacific 2016. One such activity included a humanitarian assistance / disaster relief (HA/DR) scenario, developed in coordination with leaders from the Healthcare Association of Hawaii (HAH) and the Hawaii Disaster Medical Assistance Team (HDMAT), structured with the goal of enhancing disaster preparedness across U.S. and international partner government and private sector agencies. 
RHC-P Emergency Manager and a lead medical planner for the HA/DR, Thomas Bookman, said the plan not only rehearsed emergency response capabilities of Hawaii-area partners through the simulated movement of patients across 19 Hawaii-island area hospitals by land, air and sea, but the drill engaged Pacific partners, enhancing preparedness region-wide. 
A total of 312 simulated casualties were moved during the exercise.
“In the event of a national disaster, ports might be damaged, our international airports might be destroyed, and so we are going to be on our own for a long period of time. In the midst of a real crisis isn’t when you should start developing relationships. That partnership needs to be reinforced prior to that event ever happening,” Bookman said.
Bookman played a lead role in the scenario, acting as the minister of health for the fictional island of Griffin and working closely with international community liaisons with a multitude of organizations such as the International Federation of Red Cross, Japan’s Humanitarian Assistance and Emergency Relief Division of the International Cooperation Bureau, and the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. Additionally, teams from Canada, Australia, other foreign USAID equivalents, and international military partners in the Japanese Navy and Canadian Air Force played roles in the exercise. 
In addition to RHC-P, U.S. participants also included Tripler Army Medical Center, Healthcare Association of Hawaii, Hawaii Disaster Medical Assistance Team, Hawaii Disaster Aeromedical Staging Facility, the U.S. Army Health Clinic-Schofield Barracks, Veterans Affairs Pacific Islands Health Care System, 18th Medical Command, U.S. Army Garrison-Hawaii, 15th Medical Group CJoint-Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam, Marine Corps Base Kaneohe and 25th Infantry Division Combat Aviation Brigade. 
RHC-P also supported the Uniformed Services University Center for Global Health Engagements course on the Fundamentals of Global Health Engagements which included military and civilian representatives from all U.S. services, as well as international participants representing Australia, Canada, and China. 
Lt. Col. Derek Licina, RHC-P Director for Global Health Engagements (GHE), facilitated one of the lectures in a classroom setting and said that the? engagement provided an opportunity to share GHE best practices with international partners, which supports service component and combatant command Theater Security Cooperation objectives.
"The opportunity to candidly discuss global health engagement challenges and opportunities with our international colleagues will improve the overall quality of future activities conducted by our community of interest," said Licina.
RHC-P is also collaborating with the USU CGHE to monitor and evaluate the effectiveness of GHE in supporting partner nation capacity building, improving Department of Defense readiness through engagement, and achieving strategic military objectives.
Twenty-six nations, more than 40 ships and submarines, more than 200 aircraft and 25,000 personnel are participating in Rim of the Pacific exercise from June 30 to Aug. 4, in and around the Hawaiian Islands and Southern California.
RHC-P orchestrates the delivery of world-class medical care for service members, families and eligible beneficiaries, and provides medical readiness and diplomacy in support of United States Army Pacific in the Pacific Command area of responsibility.
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: RHC-P在2016年环太平洋峰会期间加强应急响应
column11: 夏威夷福特岛（2016年7月14日）――太平洋地区卫生司令部（RHC-P）成功领导了旨在加强整个地区人道主义援助和救灾工作的关键医疗活动，作为2016年环太平洋地区的一部分。其中一项活动包括与夏威夷医疗协会（HAH）和夏威夷灾难医疗援助团队（HDMAT）的领导人合作制定的人道主义援助/救灾（HA/DR）情景，旨在加强美国和国际合作伙伴政府和私营部门机构的防灾准备。RHC-P急救经理兼医管局/DR的首席医疗规划师托马斯・布克曼表示，该计划不仅通过模拟患者通过陆地、空中和海上穿越19家夏威夷岛地区医院，演练了夏威夷地区合作伙伴的应急响应能力，还让太平洋合作伙伴参与了演习，加强全区域的准备工作。演习中共转移了312名模拟伤亡人员。“如果发生全国性灾难，港口可能会受损，我们的国际机场可能会被毁，因此我们将在很长一段时间内独立自主。在真正的危机中，你不应该开始发展关系。这种合作关系需要在事件发生之前得到加强。”布克曼说。布克曼在这一场景中扮演了主角，担任虚构的格里芬岛的卫生部长，并与国际社会密切合作，与国际红十字联合会、日本国际红十字会人道主义援助和紧急救济司等多个组织保持联络此外，来自加拿大、澳大利亚、美国国际开发署其他外国对等机构以及日本海军和加拿大空军的国际军事伙伴的团队在演习中发挥了作用。除RHC-P外，美国参与者还包括三人r陆军医疗中心、夏威夷医疗协会、夏威夷灾难医疗援助团队、夏威夷灾难航空医疗中转设施、美国陆军医疗诊所Schofield兵营、退伍军人事务太平洋岛屿医疗系统、第18医疗司令部、美国陆军驻夏威夷部队、第15医疗小组――美国珍珠港联合基地，Marine兵团卡内奥赫基地和第25步兵师战斗航空旅。RHC-P还支持军警大学全球卫生服务中心全球卫生服务基础课程，该课程包括来自所有美国军种的军事和文职代表以及国际参与者RHC-P全球健康参与（GHE）主任德里克・利西纳中校在课堂上主持了其中一次讲座，并表示? 参与提供了一个与国际合作伙伴分享GHE最佳实践的机会，这支持了服务组件和作战指挥战区安全合作目标。“有机会与我们的国际同事坦率地讨论全球卫生参与的挑战和机遇，将提高我们感兴趣的社区开展的未来活动的整体质量，"said Licina.RHC-P还与USU CGHE合作，监测和评估GHE在支持伙伴国家能力建设、通过参与提高国防部战备状态以及实现战略军事目标方面的有效性。26个国家、40多艘舰船和潜艇、200多架飞机和25000架飞机6月30日至8月4日，在夏威夷群岛和南加州及其周边地区，0名人员参加环太平洋演习。RHC-P为服役人员、家属和合格受益人提供世界级医疗服务，并提供医疗准备和外交支持美国陆军太平洋一号n太平洋司令部责任区。

column2: PHC-P develops new Pre-Exercise Vector Surveillance program
column3:
This spring, Public Health Command-Pacific’s Entomology and Environmental Molecular Biology Laboratory service lines will launch the first ever Pre-Exercise Vector Surveillance program for the Indo-Pacific region.

The new initiative is a pilot program funded by the Global Emerging Infectious Surveillance program, also known as GEIS, a section of the Armed Forces Health Surveillance Branch.

The vision of GEIS is to mitigate the threat of emerging infectious diseases to the U.S. military through a global laboratory network. The network is designed to help influence force health protection decision-making and enhance global health security.

One of the primary ways GEIS accomplishes this task is by providing timely, actionable infectious disease surveillance information to Geographic Combatant Commands and partner agencies, according to Maj. Michael Kwon, director of PHC-P's Environmental Health Services Directorate.

“This initiative acquires fresh data on health threats related to vector-borne diseases,” Kwon explained. “The goal is to provide combatant commanders with relevant intelligence on the prevalence of pathogens transmitted by arthropods, in order to make informed force health protection decisions.”

Typically, vector-borne disease data is collected by advance exercise parties as part of an occupational and environmental health site assessment, or OEHSA.

“Field parties put in the heroic effort to get checklists completed, but there are competing interests for time. Often individuals prioritize those tasks they are most versatile in,” explained Kwon. “Historically, environmental scientists focused on potable water, air sampling for industrial chemicals, or collected data on other health threats, and insufficient time is spent on trapping for vectors.”

Capt. John Eads, chief of entomology at Camp Zama, Japan, recognized these hindrances to achieving an accurate site picture, namely a lack of standardized methodology, inconsistent manpower or capabilities.

So, when he first joined the PHC-P team, he began to find ways to leverage the PHC-P entomology program to better fit the needs of the Army and DoD to keep service members safe from vector-borne diseases.

“When I first got here, the entomology program had potential to be more expansive, with a larger footprint than the local area,” explained Eads. “The vision is to build the program to collect more data, more information, and improve the site picture of what was going on within Indo-Pacific as far as vector surveillance and pathogen detection.

“You can see with the pandemic, how quickly a disease can spread. That same concept applies to vector-borne diseases,” Eads said. “For example, if there are Soldiers in the Philippines for an exercise who contract dengue [fever], they can transmit this to others. During peak mosquito season it could be just a matter of weeks before a traveler contracts the infection and perpetuates the cycle.”

In early 2020, Eads was invited to Hawaii to brief military leaders on the importance of understanding vector-borne disease threats.

Eads attended his first GEIS meeting during this trip, and learned about how GEIS contributes to the protection of DoD healthcare beneficiaries and the global community through an integrated worldwide emerging infectious disease surveillance system.

?“That’s where I was first introduced to GEIS and their mission and vision, and it seemed to line up perfectly with my concept of one team from all branches working together to produce the best vector-borne disease data,” he said.

Eads recognized the powerful potential for providing combatant commanders with actionable intelligence on disease threats for the different environmental terrains of the Indo-Pacific region.

To kick start the initiative, Eads reached out to other subject matter experts at the Armed Forces Research Institute of Medical Sciences, also known as AFRIMS, to devise ways to utilize GEIS to obtain funding and solve force health protection gaps.

By June 2020, Eads had received leadership buy-in, and several days later submitted his official GEIS proposal to partner with AFRIMS teammates.

“AFRIMS in Thailand specializes more in animals such as rodents, collecting the rodents for testing for leptospirosis and other pathogens that we don’t test for,” explained Eads. “[AFRIMS] has a lot of biologists, so by partnering with them we could add to our capabilities and help each other out. So we included them in our proposal to GEIS and they included us in theirs.”

One of the main objective of the PHC-P proposal was to standardize a surveillance program throughout the Indo-Pacific utilizing committed assets synchronized with GEIS, AFRIMS, and U.S. Army Pacific.

The goal is to capture population and activity data on vectors identified in the region and assess the presence and prevalence of pathogens in locations occupied by DoD personnel.

“We want to build joint knowledge products that can be used by both GEIS and combatant commanders,” said Eads. “Final products will be two different formats of scientific data, one for GEIS and the other is real-time health risk assessments for combatant commanders.”

By developing these products, Eads and AFRIMS will identify threat variables, not only for operational considerations but also for the development of integrated pest management programs.

Kwon said the information provided by the products will have wide-ranging applications.

“The data that is released by the Army and GEIS gets used by a lot of researchers and scientists,” he said. “A lot of people in public health career fields depend on having reliable data that is consistent.”

One of the ways the PHC-P Pre-Exercise Vector Surveillance program will accomplish consistent data collection is by standardizing equipment and developing standardized operating procedures using next generation sequencing.

Eads said much of the data they gather is difficult to analyze accurately.

”People don’t trap vectors the same,” he explained. “Some people might use one type of bait, others might not. They might trap in locations that we didn’t perceive is good locations. So, [the] first step is ensuring accurate data that we know was collected consistently by the same means - that is imperative.”

One of the ways Eads plans to standardize the PHC-P Pre-Exercise Vector Surveillance program this spring is by sending a team of two personnel from PHC-P to conduct surveillance with the same traps, using the same tactics, techniques and procedures.

To help with this process, the team will travel to several locations armed with new Nanopore MinION testing equipment.

Eads said the MinION provides consistent new real-time analysis, and since the equipment is portable, can test vectors in the field using rapid next-generation DNA and RNA sequencing.

“By having equipment such as the Nanopore MinION on ground before an exercise, we have the capability to conduct genomic identification of pathogens in real-time,” explained Eads.

“So, for example, if dengue is all of a sudden detected, but we weren’t expecting dengue to be in that area, we can then target our trapping techniques for dengue-vectoring mosquitoes. This helps to identify the risks and to help commanders make informed decisions and protect the force,” he said.

Gary Crispell, a microbiologist at the PHC-P EMBL at Camp Zama, said the new equipment means the future of disease surveillance will no longer be restricted to a laboratory.

“We are now able to conduct next generation sequencing from anywhere on the planet with a device small enough to fit in your backpack,” Crispell said. “These tools have only been around for a few years, but are being rapidly adopted for the scientific research community.”

Since next generation sequencing produces tremendous amounts of genomic data, the team will also use GEIS funding to hire a bioinformatics technician to target and identify critical patterns in the DNA and RNA of the vector samples.

“They filter through the information and find that proverbial needle in a haystack to send to GEIS,” explained Eads. “If you think about how much DNA makes up the human genome, it’s a pretty daunting task to analyze this information, even when dealing with insect and arthropod vectors.”

In addition to using the Nanopore MinION in the field, the team will also use the two PHC-P EMBLs at Camp Zama and Joint Base Lewis-McChord, Washington, to help process vectors when travel is not possible.

This capability allows the team to process larger amounts of vectors both for exercises and for routine installation surveillance, which can help more costumers understand what threats are in specific locations of interest.

“The DoD community should be aware of our laboratory assets at JBLM and Camp Zama,” said Kwon. “Entomologists and molecular biologists are staged to assist the community with force health protection consultations and analyses.

“Collaboration and relationships are force multipliers, and in the long run, it is good for science,” Kwon added.

The team will send its data to GEIS to assist in other research projects, and will also use it to provide expertise in pest management and program support to Installation Management Command-Pacific, Regional Health Command-Pacific, and field Preventive Medicine units in the Indo-Pacific region.

“By being on that cutting edge of science having the most up-to-date equipment, having SMEs [subject matter experts] in the field, and a bioinformatics technician, we will have the possibility to protect all DoD personnel throughout the region by identifying diseases or health risks before they become a problem,” said Eads.

As Pre-Exercise Vector Surveillance program moves forward during its pilot year, Eads and his team will test two locations this fiscal year to prove the proof of concept, while also developing standards and SOPs for future years.

By doing so, the team will lay the groundwork for a fully standardized vector surveillance program that the U.S. Indo-Pacific Command can use before key exercises to keep service members safe and healthy.

Eads and his efforts to launch the new Pre-Exercise Vector Surveillance program embraces the PHC-P credo of “100/0!” which means 100% accountability and responsibility, and zero excuses for not giving your best every day.

To learn more about the PHC-P entomology program visit: https://phcp.health.mil/Services/Environmental-Health-Services/Entomology/
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: PHC-P制定了新的运动前病媒监测计划
column11: 今年春天，太平洋公共卫生司令部的昆虫学和环境分子生物学实验室服务线将在印度洋-太平洋地区启动有史以来第一个演习前病媒监测计划。这项新计划是由全球新兴传染病监测计划（又称GEIS）资助的试点计划，美国武装部队健康监测处的一个部门。GEIS的目标是通过全球实验室网络减轻新出现的传染病对美国军队的威胁。该网络旨在帮助影响部队健康保护决策并加强全球健康安全。据迈克尔・克文少校介绍，GEIS完成这项任务的主要方式之一是向地理作战司令部和合作机构提供及时、可操作的传染病监测信息，PHC-P环境卫生服务局局长Kwon解释说：“这项计划获得了与媒介传播疾病相关的健康威胁的新数据。”。“目标是向作战指挥官提供有关节肢动物传播的病原体流行情况的相关情报，以便作出知情的部队健康保护决定。”通常情况下，作为职业和环境健康现场评估的一部分，由先遣演习方收集病媒传播的疾病数据，Kwon解释说：“现场团队付出了巨大的努力来完成检查表，但时间上存在利益冲突。通常个人会优先考虑他们最擅长的任务。”。“从历史上看，环境科学家专注于饮用水、工业化学品的空气采样或收集其他健康威胁的数据，而在捕捉病媒方面花费的时间不足。”日本扎马营地昆虫学负责人约翰・埃德斯上尉认识到这些阻碍了获得准确的现场图像，也就是说，缺乏标准化的方法、不一致的人力或能力。因此，当他第一次加入PHC-P团队时，他开始想方设法利用PHC-P昆虫学计划来更好地满足陆军和国防部的需要，以确保服役人员免受病媒传播疾病的危害。Eads解释说：“当我第一次来到这里时，昆虫学项目有可能更加广泛，覆盖范围比当地更广。”。Eads说：“我们的愿景是建立一个项目，收集更多数据、更多信息，并改善印度-太平洋地区在病媒监测和病原体检测方面发生的情况。你可以看到在大流行中，疾病传播的速度有多快。同样的概念也适用于病媒传播疾病。”。“例如，如果菲律宾有士兵在演习中感染登革热，他们可能会将登革热传染给其他人。在蚊子高峰期，旅行者感染登革热并延续这种循环可能只需几周时间。”2020年初，Eads应邀前往夏威夷，向军方领导人简要介绍了解病媒传播疾病威胁的重要性。Eads在此次访问期间参加了他的第一次GEIS会议，并了解了GEIS如何通过全球新兴传染病综合系统为国防部医疗受益人和全球社区提供保护ous疾病监测系统。“这是我第一次被介绍给GEIS及其使命和愿景的地方，它似乎完全符合我的理念，即所有分支机构组成一个团队，共同工作，以产生最佳的病媒传播疾病数据。”他说。欧洲宇航防务集团认识到为作战指挥官提供印度-太平洋地区不同环境条件下疾病威胁的可操作情报的巨大潜力。为了启动这一计划，欧洲宇航防务集团联系了武装部队医学科学研究所的其他学科专家作为AFRIMS，设计利用GEI获得资金和解决部队健康保护缺口的方法。到2020年6月，Eads已获得领导层的认可，几天后，Eads向AFRIMS队友提交了其官方GEIS提案。Eads解释说：“泰国的AFRIMS更擅长于啮齿动物等动物，收集啮齿动物用于检测钩端螺旋体病和其他我们没有检测的病原体。”我们有很多生物学家，因此通过与他们合作，我们可以增加我们的能力并相互帮助。因此，我们将他们包括在我们向GEIS提交的提案中，他们也将我们包括在他们的提案中。”PHC-P提案的主要目标之一是利用与GEI、AFRIMS和美国陆军太平洋分部同步的承诺资产，在整个印度-太平洋地区实现监测计划的标准化。目标是获取该地区确定的病媒的人口和活动数据，并评估当地病原体的存在和流行情况国防部人员占用的ns。Eads说：“我们希望构建既可供GEI使用，也可供作战指挥官使用的联合知识产品。最终产品将是两种不同格式的科学数据，一种用于GEI，另一种用于作战指挥官的实时健康风险评估。”通过开发这些产品，Eads和AFRIMS将识别威胁变量，不仅用于运营考虑，也用于制定综合虫害管理计划。Kwon说，这些产品提供的信息将有广泛的应用。“军队和GEIS发布的数据被许多研究人员和科学家使用，”他说，“公共卫生职业领域的许多人都依赖于可靠的一致数据。”PHC-P运动前病媒监测计划实现一致性数据收集的方法之一是通过标准化设备和使用下一代测序开发标准化操作程序。Eads表示，他们收集的许多数据很难准确分析。“人们不会捕获相同的病媒，”他解释说：“有些人可能会使用一种诱饵，其他人可能不会。他们可能会在我们认为不好的地方设陷阱。因此，[第一步]是确保我们知道的准确数据是通过同样的方法收集的――这是必须的。”Eads计划在今年春季将PHC-P演习前病媒监测计划标准化的方法之一是，从PHC-P派遣一个由两名人员组成的小组，使用相同的战术、技术和程序，使用相同的陷阱进行监测。为了帮助这一过程，该小组将前往多个配备新型纳米孔仆从的地点测试设备。欧洲宇航防务集团表示，该小兵提供一致的新实时分析，而且由于该设备是便携式的，因此可以使用快速的下一代DNA和RNA测序在现场测试载体。Eads解释说：“通过在演习前在地面部署纳米孔仆从等设备，我们能够实时对病原体进行基因组鉴定。”。“因此，例如，如果突然发现登革热，但我们没有预料到登革热会出现在该地区，那么我们可以针对登革热传播蚊子的诱捕技术。这有助于识别风险，帮助指挥官做出明智的决定，保护部队。”扎马营PHC-P EMBL的微生物学家加里・克里斯佩尔说，新设备意味着疾病监测的未来将不再局限于实验室。“我们现在可以在地球上任何地方用一个小到可以放在背包里的设备进行下一代测序，”克里斯佩尔说。“这些工具只出现了几年，但正在迅速被科学研究界采用。”由于下一代测序产生了大量的基因组数据，该团队还将利用GEIS的资金聘请一名生物信息技术人员，以确定载体样本DNA和RNA中的关键模式。“他们过滤信息，大海捞针，将其发送给GEIS。”Eads解释道：“如果你想一想人类基因组中有多少DNA，分析这些信息是一项相当艰巨的任务，即使是在处理昆虫和节肢动物载体时也是如此。”除了在现场使用纳米孔仆从外，该团队还将使用扎马营地和华盛顿刘易斯・麦科德联合基地的两个PHC-P EMBL，在无法旅行时帮助处理媒介。该能力使团队能够处理大量媒介，用于演习和日常安装监控，这有助于p更多的客户了解特定地点的威胁。“国防部社区应该了解我们在JBLM和扎马营地的实验室资产，”Kwon说。“昆虫学家和分子生物学家正在协助社区进行部队健康保护咨询和分析。“协作和关系是力量倍增器，从长远来看，这有利于科学。”Kwon补充道。该团队将向GEIS发送数据，以协助其他研究项目，并将利用该数据为太平洋安装管理司令部、太平洋地区卫生司令部和印度太平洋地区的野战预防医学单位提供虫害管理和项目支持方面的专业知识。“通过拥有最先进的科学设备、该领域的SME（主题专家）和生物信息技术人员，我们将有可能在疾病或健康风险成为问题之前识别疾病或健康风险，从而保护整个地区的所有国防部人员。”Eads表示。随着演习前病媒监测计划在试点年的推进，Eads及其团队将在本财年对两个地点进行测试，以证明概念验证，同时为未来几年制定标准和SOP。通过这样做，该团队将为美国美国印太司令部可以在关键演习前使用，以确保服役人员的安全和健康。Eads及其启动新的演习前病媒监测计划的努力符合PHC-P信条

column2: SFS captain wins Lance P. Sijan AFRC Leadership Award
column3:
DOBBINS AIR RESERVE BASE, Ga. C During the Vietnam War, Capt. Lance P. Sijan, an Air Force Academy graduate and combat pilot, ejected from his disabled F-4C Phantom during a bombing mission in Laos. He evaded capture for more than six weeks, during which he experienced many hardships like shock and extreme weight loss from lack of food.

He was eventually captured by the North Vietnamese military, but not without a fight. Even in his weakened state, he was able to overpower one of the guards and make a temporary escape into the jungle before being captured again. At the prison camp, he was severely tortured during intense interrogations, but he refused to divulge any information to his captors.

He remained in captivity until his untimely death on January 22, 1968 when he contracted pneumonia shortly after being transported to the “Hanoi Hilton” prison camp in Vietnam.

Nearly a decade later, he was posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor by President Gerald Ford in recognition of his extraordinary heroism and courage that went above and beyond the call of duty. In 1991, the Air Force created the Lance P. Sijan USAF Leadership Award to further honor his legacy. 

Capt. Ryan Cheney, 94th Security Forces Squadron operations officer, was awarded the Sijan AFRC award this year in recognition of his exceptional leadership skills, which include managing a squadron of more than 50 security forces Airmen to protect nearly 6,000 base personnel.

“Hearing what the award was about and hearing about Lance P. Sijan and to be a nominee for any award that is dedicated to a leader of that caliber is really something,” said Cheney. “It’s an honor that anyone would look at me in that light.”

Cheney recognizes the unique challenges facing those who are in his charge. Due to the nature of the job, Defenders are required to work around the clock, in any weather, and any schedule, he said. Furthermore, as a newly-minted captain, he’s been a first lieutenant in a job that’s typically filled by a major.

“They’re really sacrificing so much,” Cheney explained. “An eight hour day isn’t an eight hour day for a Defender. It’s typically ten. A twelve hour day is the same. For a lot of them, they’ve already missed out on that time with their family.”

He credits his success as a leader to two things: one, getting to know his Airmen on a personal level, and two, offering them training opportunities to further advance their careers.

“Opportunity is the biggest thing,” Cheney said. “Some of our posts are really challenging, but if we focus on developing our Airmen and give them the opportunity to learn different aspects when we can, I think it’s a huge motivation factor.”

Cheney also finds motivation in leading his Airmen as well.

“They’re a great bunch,” said Cheney. “They’re hardworking and they’re professionals, and they’re in the eye of the entire wing every day. It’s just an honor to be part of that.”

His motivation doesn’t stop there though. He knows that winning the award isn’t the end goal. Rather than being complacent, he continues to strive toward becoming an even better leader for his Defenders.

“This has definitely been a vector check,” he said. “It makes me feel like I’m on the right path, but I’ve got a long way to go.”
column9: 美国佐治亚州
column10: SFS队长获得Lance P.Sijan AFRC领导奖
column11: 佐治亚州多宾斯空军储备基地――越南战争期间，空军学院毕业生、战斗飞行员兰斯・P・西扬上尉在老挝执行轰炸任务时从残废的F-4C幻影中弹射出来。他逃避追捕长达六个多星期，其间他经历了许多困难，如休克和因缺乏食物而极度减肥。他最终被北越军队抓获，但并非没有战斗。即使在虚弱的状态下，他也能制服一名警卫，在再次被抓获之前暂时逃到丛林中。在集中营里，他在激烈的审讯中受到了严刑拷打，但他拒绝向逮捕他的人透露任何信息。他一直被囚禁，直到1968年1月22日被送往越南“河内希尔顿”集中营后不久感染肺炎，不合时宜地死亡。近十年后，他被杰拉尔德・福特总统追授荣誉勋章，以表彰他超乎职责范围的非凡英雄主义和勇气。1991年，美国空军设立了兰斯・P・西扬美国空军领导奖，以进一步表彰他的遗产。今年，安全部队第94中队作战官瑞安・切尼上尉获得了Sijan AFRC奖，以表彰他卓越的领导技能，其中包括管理一个由50多名安全部队飞行员组成的中队，以保护近6000名基地人员。切尼说：“听到这个奖项是关于什么的，听到兰斯・P・西扬的消息，成为任何奖项的提名人，都是为了纪念这样一位才华横溢的领袖，这真是一件了不起的事情。任何人都能从这个角度看待我，这是一种荣誉。”切尼认识到他所负责的人所面临的独特挑战。他说，由于这项工作的性质，防守队员必须在任何天气、任何日程安排下24小时不间断地工作。此外，作为一名新上任的上尉，他是一名中尉，通常由少校担任。“他们真的牺牲了很多，”切尼解释道。“一天八小时对一名防守队员来说不是一天八小时。通常是十小时。一天十二小时也是一样。对于很多人来说，他们已经错过了与家人在一起的时间。”他把自己作为领导者的成功归功于两件事：一是在个人层面上了解他的飞行员，二是为他们提供培训机会，进一步推进他们的职业生涯。“机会是最重要的，”切尼说。“我们的一些职位确实具有挑战性，但如果我们专注于培养我们的飞行员，并在可能的情况下给他们机会学习不同方面的知识，我认为这是一个巨大的激励因素。”切尼也在领导他的飞行员中找到了动力。“他们是一群很棒的人，”切尼说。“他们工作努力，是专业人士，他们每天都在整个联队的眼睛里。能成为其中的一员，我感到很荣幸。”然而，他的动机并不止于此。他知道获奖并不是最终目标。他并没有自满，而是继续努力成为防守队员更好的领导者。他说：“这绝对是一次矢量检查。这让我感觉我走在了正确的道路上，但我还有很长的路要走。”

column2: RHC-P recognizes Soldiers, Civilians during creative Hail and Farewell
column3:
JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash. C Regional Health Command-Pacific got creative with its hail and farewell ceremony and awards ceremony here Tuesday, Sept. 29, due to restrictions and challenges presented by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Utilizing videoconferencing technology to allow for social distancing and for those teleworking to attend, the command recognized 15 Soldiers and civilians were recognized during the event.

The hail and farewell is a longstanding military tradition that celebrates those arriving at or departing a command.

The ceremony also recognized Soldiers and civilians receiving awards for their performance or upon their permanent changes of station.

RHC-P, the most geographically-dispersed command in Army Medicine, oversees Army medical treatment facilities and units in the Pacific Northwest, Alaska, Hawaii, Japan and South Korea.

A list of those recognized and awardees follows.

HAIL:

Maj. Garett Holt, Command Group

Capt. Alyssa Noltner, Command Group

Kevin Bosket, Clinical Operations

Joe Hockmuth, Clinical Operations

Lt. Col. Bill Uptergrove, Clinical Operations

Col. Lisa Miller, Clinical Operations

Lt. Col. Melissa Gue, G-4

Lt. Col. Ausha Partido, Recovery Care Office

Master Sgt. Christopher Mancilla, Recovery Care Office

Maj. Rose Hinkle, G-8

Master Sgt. Robert Hayward, Inspector General

Lt. Col. Hee Kim, G-3

Sgt. Maj. Joshua Motley, G-3

Sgt. 1st Class Brittney Bailey, G-3

Staff Sgt. Missyann Camacho-William, G-3

FAREWELL:

Kelly Nix, G-4

Dan Loguda, Recovery Care Office

Sgt. Maj. Jonathan Garand, Recovery Care Office

Master Sgt. Heather Richard, Recovery Care Office

Master Sgt. David Pring, Inspector General

Master Sgt. Paulette Ware, G-3

AWARDS:

Master Sgt. Paulette Ware, G-3, Meritorious Service Medal

Master Sgt. David Pring, Inspector General, Meritorious Service Medal

Derek ‘Derk’ Shoup, Office of General Counsel, Meritorious Civilian Service Award

Maj. Trinity Storey, G-3, The Surgeon General’s Coin
