column10: 霍拉西奥・里韦罗上将-水面勇士，非提名拉丁美洲领导人
column11: “中途岛奇迹”阻止了日本在太平洋的推进，两个月后，美国海军开始了这场战斗，这场战斗最终将返回东京，这条路始于南太平洋所罗门群岛，登陆日本控制的瓜达尔卡纳尔岛的海军陆战队和士兵。那是1942年8月，小霍拉西奥・里韦罗中校作为圣胡安号轻型巡洋舰（CL-54）上的助理炮兵军官，处于战斗最激烈的时期。仅仅在五个月前，里韦罗就开始训练他的团队，从一开始就负责飞船的后置电池。现在是他们发光的时候了。里韦罗对海上勤务并不陌生，他11年的大部分现役时间都是在水面舰艇上度过的。1942年8月7日，我们的海军陆战队在瓜达尔卡纳尔登陆时，里韦罗上尉（当时的副指挥官）在有效的支援火力下，干练地控制了圣胡安号航空母舰的后置炮台。“第二天，当敌人的大量岸基鱼雷飞机攻击时，他控制的炮台击落了几架攻击飞机，并击中了许多其他飞机，造成了随后的损失。”“在1942年10月对吉尔伯特群岛进行单独突袭时，他的炮台有效地促成了两艘日本巡逻舰的沉没和16名囚犯的俘虏，”引文中详述道，“1942年10月26日，在圣克鲁斯战役中，他出色地控制了后置电池，摧毁了许多敌方舰载飞机。。。“更好地理解，必须指出的是，授予该奖章的不是一个单一的英雄主义行为，而是里韦罗在1942年8月7日至1943年4月24日的战斗中表现出的一致性、可靠性和持续的卓越表现。他确实是一个战斗的地面战士。接任炮兵军官职务后，他在圣胡安号巡洋舰上的服役一直持续到1944年底，在南太平洋和中太平洋的大部分战役中，他都在该舰上服役，当时该舰是海军上将威廉・F・哈尔西指挥的掩护部队的一部分。圣胡安人在所罗门群岛的布干维尔看到了行动；1943年11月占领吉尔伯特群岛；在当年年底对拉包尔的一系列航母袭击中；1944年2月，马绍尔群岛发生了对夸贾林的袭击。1944年底，他短暂返回美国，委托美国匹兹堡号巡洋舰（CA-72），最初担任炮兵官，后来担任执行官。1945年6月5日，台风袭击了第三舰队的船只，造成33人受伤，但匹兹堡受到的打击最为严重。里韦罗，现在是该船的执行官，被认为是该船和船员生存的功臣。在狂风暴雨中，船头被风和汹涌的大海“像火柴头一样”折断想象一下，一艘没有船头的船一瘸一拐地返回港口，以冲破海浪。Rivero被告知该船的生还，以及他在风暴期间为该船准备的方向，以及一旦失去船头，如何处理损失控制工作。由于思维敏捷，他被授予荣誉军团勋章。“他在对船舶各部门负责人的明智和及时的指导，以及在极其危险的条件下，冒着生命危险，对船舶受损和淹没部分进行的即时检查方面表现尤为突出，”引文写道。他的行动“导致做出了正确的决定，正确地确定了损坏界限，并正确地引导了整艘船人员的努力，以确保没有人员伤亡，并有可能将船只安全地驶入港口。”该船随后将在硫磺岛战役和冲绳战役以及第一艘航母突袭东京期间看到行动。在他职业生涯的头二十年充满了冲突，在这期间，尽管面临挑战，他仍能表现出坚韧和韧性。面对障碍并克服它们，对他来说是一种常规情景。小霍拉西奥・里韦罗出生于1910年5月16日，出生于玛格丽塔・德卢卡・德里韦罗和霍拉西奥・里韦罗，出生于波多黎各庞塞，但在马纳蒂长大。从波多黎各圣胡安（现在的桑图尔奇）的中央高中毕业后，他获得了安纳波利斯美国海军学院的任命。他第一次乘船进入美国，是在前往巴尔的摩的途中，在塞文河上上学。四年后，他以优异成绩毕业，在1931年的441名学院毕业生中名列第三。里韦罗为我们的海军树立的榜样可以最好地概括为失败者之一，尽管这是一个坚持不懈的过程，展示了无与伦比的领导才能和获胜的诀窍。战后，里韦罗于1948年接受美国海军威廉・C・劳号驱逐舰（DD-763）的指挥。1951年，他再次指挥诺布尔号运输舰（APA-218），率领他的战舰，派遣海军陆战队前往韩国仁川进行两栖攻击。他以旗舰军衔指挥一号驱逐舰舰队。后来，肯尼迪总统亲自挑选他在古巴导弹危机期间指挥大西洋舰队两栖部队，并随后赞扬他的指挥在国家危机期间的准备就绪。1964年7月，他被任命为海军作战部副部长，直到1968年2月，他一直担任海军二号上将，负责监督越南战争的大部分行动，包括他热情倡导的布朗海军的复兴。当他执掌北大西洋公约组织的盟军时，在冷战最高峰的南欧，他能够将军事力量与我们的威慑原则和盟国之间的接触结合起来。“……面对有限的物质资源、地区政治动荡以及苏联对地中海的渗透大幅增加，他令人信服地凝聚了南部地区国家的共同决心；制定了应对苏联威胁的计划；实施了北大西洋公约组织的“灵活应对”战略他在1972年6月退休时被授予杰出服务勋章，根据这一勋章，他在各种复杂的国家和多国机动和演习中对盟军、海军和空军进行了密集训练。因此，即使在1971年从海军退役后，他仍不继续为国家服务也就不足为奇了。他由尼克松总统任命，1972年至1974年担任美国驻西班牙大使。为了显示他对自己岛屿的自豪感，他成为了美国退伍军人波多黎各自决委员会的名誉主席，他是厄瓜多尔共和国阿布顿・卡尔德隆勋章和巴西共和国梅里托海军勋章的接受者。里韦罗于9月24日去世，2000年，被埋葬在圣迭戈洛马角的罗斯克兰斯国家公墓。就连“传奇”这个词也没有体现里韦罗的服务被人们记住的模范方式。近40年的军装生涯，里韦罗成为了我们所有职业水面勇士的榜样，无论军衔或背景如何。没有一艘船上刻着他的名字，我们每个人都要为后世的水手们强化他的故事和榜样；尤其是那些穿着制服的拉丁裔领导人。下一次你考虑忽略某人或他们的一个想法因为口音、社会阶级或他们的下级，提醒你自己Rivero――即使是最不期望的，从最卑微的开始，坚持，正直，智慧和勇气，能够在我们的组织内达到领导的巅峰。里韦罗可能是个无名英雄，但是他的职业生涯证明了他不应该是任何人。要了解更多关于Horatio Rivero上将的信息，你可以访问海军历史和传统司令部https://www.history.navy.mil/ 了解更多关于军事访问中少数民族的信息https://www.ansomil.org.For 来自海军参谋长的更多消息，在Facebook上关注我们https://www.facebook.com/mynavyhr，推特https://twitter.com/mynavyhr 或参观https://www.navy.mil/cnp.Lt. Rolando Machado中校对此报告做出了贡献

column2: Rear Adm. Tom Anderson Debuts Rough Riders Award at SERMC
column3:
MAYPORT, Fla., ― Fourteen employees of the Southeast Regional Maintenance Center (SERMC) were honored as the first inductees into the new “Rough Riders Team” on Nov. 4 by Rear Adm. Tom Anderson, Commander, Navy Regional Maintenance Center (CNRMC) and Director, Surface Ship Maintenance and Modernization (SEA 21) of Naval Sea Systems Command (NAVSEA)..

“The Rough Rider award recognizes our people who go above and beyond the call of duty. Ship repair is a tough business, there are long hours and most people don’t understand or realize the amount of behind the scenes work that goes into getting these ships underway. It’s the people who embody President Roosevelt’s Rough Riders ethos of prioritize, communicate and finish that earn a spot on the team,” Anderson said during his visit to SERMC.

Six SERMC employees earned the SEA 21/CNRMC Rough Rider awards for overseeing and completing emergent repairs expeditiously on USS Detroit (LCS 7), ensuring the littoral combat ship was on time for its maiden deployment, the first LCS Freedom-variant block-buy ship to deploy on the East Coast.

The USS The Sullivans (DDG 68) maintenance team became Rough Riders for completing the ship’s CNO availability early and mission-ready. The team’s effective communication, teamwork and ability to resolve problems all played vital roles during the five-month endeavor. In total, 110 depot and numerous intermediate level work items were completed, including a major Vertical Launch System cooling upgrade, Ballistic Missile Defense package installation, Consolidated Afloat Network and Enterprise Services communications upgrade and several major structural improvements. 

“The standards are being set by the SERMC team members acknowledged here today with regards to on-time delivery and timely correction of material deficiencies on ships. This is exactly how we need to operate going forward. You correctly planned, made sure everything lined up during execution, and attacked each work item to completion in order to return the ship to the Fleet on time,” Anderson concluded.

CNRMC is a Naval Sea Systems Command (NAVSEA) field activity and oversees the operations of Regional Maintenance Centers in their execution of surface ship maintenance and modernization. SEA 21 is the dedicated life cycle management organization for the Navy's in-service surface ships and is responsible for managing critical modernization, maintenance, training and inactivation programs.

For more information about SERMC visit: http://www.facebook.com/SoutheastRMC
column9: 美国佛罗里达州梅波特
column10: 后方海军上将汤姆・安德森在SERMC首次颁发“粗野骑手奖”
column11: 佛罗里达州梅波特――11月4日，海军区域维修中心（CNRMC）指挥官兼海军海洋系统司令部水面舰艇维修和现代化（SEA 21）总监汤姆・安德森少将将将东南区域维修中心（SERMC）的14名员工荣膺为新“野蛮骑士队”的首批入伍者（海军）。。“粗糙骑士奖表彰了我们那些超越职责范围的员工。船舶维修是一项艰难的工作，工作时间很长，大多数人都不理解或意识到让这些船舶航行的幕后工作量。正是这些人体现了罗斯福总统的pri粗糙骑士精神安德森在访问SERMC期间说。SERMC的六名员工因在底特律号航空母舰（LCS 7）上监督并迅速完成紧急维修而获得SEA 21/CNRMC粗糙骑手奖，确保沿海战斗舰能够按时进行首次部署，这是第一艘部署在东海岸的LCS自由变型block buy战舰维修团队在尽早完成船舶的CNO可用性和任务准备方面成为了一名粗野的骑手。该团队的有效沟通、团队合作和解决问题的能力在五个月的努力中发挥了至关重要的作用。总共完成了110个基地和多个中级工作项目，包括一个主要的垂直L发射系统冷却升级、弹道导弹防御包安装、整合的海上网络和企业服务通信升级以及几项重大结构改进。“今天在这里承认的SERMC团队成员正在制定有关准时交付和及时纠正船舶材料缺陷的标准。这正是我们今后需要采取的操作方式。您正确规划，确保在执行过程中一切就绪，并攻击每个工作项以完成安德森总结道：“按时将船只送回舰队。”CNRMC是海军海洋系统司令部（NAVSEA）现场活动并监督区域维修中心执行水面舰艇维修和现代化的运作。SEA 21是海军现役水面舰艇的专用生命周期管理组织，负责管理关键的现代化、维修、培训和失活计划。对于有关SERMC访问的更多信息：http://www.facebook.com/SoutheastRMC

column2: Senate Confirms Rear Adm. Gillingham as next Navy Surgeon General
column3:
The U.S. Senate confirmed Rear Adm. Bruce L. Gillingham as the U.S. Navy’s next surgeon general on October 31, 2019.

“I am honored and privileged to represent Navy Medicine as the 39th Surgeon General of the Navy,” said Gillingham. “We are now engaged in a great power competition where our dominance is not assured, we must adapt and respond with urgency. The duty of every member of the Navy Medicine team is to provide a ready medical force and operational medical capabilities to save lives in the battlespace.”

Gillingham is the 39th Surgeon General of the Navy and the 43rd person to hold the title of Chief of Bureau of Medicine and Surgery. He is also the first orthopedic surgeon ever to serve as U.S. Navy Surgeon General.
The new Navy Surgeon General said he plans to use four priorities to guide Navy Medicine in the future fight. 

PEOPLE C Our military and civilian workforce is our greatest strength. 

PLATFORMS C Our equipment and capability sets required by our warfighters.  

PERFORMANCE C Our performance is measured by our support to our warfighters.  

POWER C Medical power projection will increase survivability.  

“Focusing on these four ‘Ps’ will drive us to mission success by increasing lethality through warfighter preparation and survivability.  To ensure continuity of care to our beneficiaries, Navy Medicine will continue to support the Defense Health Agency in transition, but our direction and focus must be on the 4 ‘Ps’,” said Gillingham.

Gillingham is a graduate of the F. Edward Hebert School of Medicine at the Uniformed Services of the Health Sciences.  He has served in various positions throughout his career to include director of Pediatric Orthopedic and Scoliosis Surgery; Associate Orthopedic Residency Program director; and director of Surgical Services.  While assigned to Naval Medical Center San Diego, he was instrumental in establishing the Comprehensive Combat and Complex Casualty Care Center (C5). Operationally, he served aboard the hospital ship USNS Mercy (T-AH-19) as staff orthopedic surgeon and as director of surgical services.  He deployed in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom II as battalion chief of Professional Services (Forward) for the 1st Force Service Support Group and officer in charge of the Surgical Shock Trauma Platoon, achieving a 98 percent combat casualty survival rate while providing echelon II surgical care during Operation Phantom Fury. Gillingham also served as commander, Navy Medicine West; commander, Naval Medical Center San Diego; deputy commander, Naval Medical Center Portsmouth; commanding officer, Naval Hospital Jacksonville, Florida; Pacific Fleet surgeon, and Fleet surgeon and director, Health Services, U.S. Fleet Forces. In 2011, he served as the Joint Support Force-Japan Surgeon in the aftermath of the Fukushima Nuclear Disaster, ensuring the safety of over 200,000 U.S. citizens, service members and families.

More information on Navy Medicine and the U.S. Navy Surgeon General is available on the Navy Medicine website at https://med.navy.mil or on the command’s Facebook, Twitter or LinkedIn accounts.
column9: 瀑布教堂，弗吉尼亚州，美国
column10: 参议院确认吉林厄姆少将为下一任海军卫生部长
column11: 2019年10月31日，美国参议院确认布鲁斯・L・吉林厄姆海军少将为美国海军下一任卫生部长。吉林厄姆说：“我荣幸地代表海军医学部担任海军第39任卫生部长。”。“我们现在正在进行一场大国竞争，在这种竞争中，我们的优势无法得到保证，我们必须立即适应并作出反应。海军医疗队每个成员的职责都是提供一支随时准备好的医疗力量和作战医疗能力，以拯救战场上的生命。”吉林厄姆是海军第39位卫生部长，也是第43位拥有医学和外科局局长头衔的人。他也是有史以来第一位担任美国海军总外科医生的整形外科医生。这位新任海军总外科医生说，他计划在未来的战斗中用四个优先事项来指导海军医学。人民――我们的军队和文职人员是我们最大的优势。平台――我们的作战人员所需的设备和能力集。绩效――我们的绩效是通过我们对作战人员的支持来衡量的。力量-医疗力量投射将提高生存能力。“专注于这四个‘P’将通过作战人员的准备和生存能力提高杀伤力，从而推动我们取得任务成功。为确保对受益人的持续护理，海军医学将继续支持国防卫生局转型，但我们的方向和重点必须放在这四个‘P’。”吉林汉说。吉灵汉是F.EdwardHebert医学院的毕业生，在卫生科学的制服服务。在整个职业生涯中，他担任过各种职位，包括儿科矫形外科和脊柱侧凸外科主任；骨科住院医师项目副主任；以及外科主任。在被分配到圣地亚哥海军医疗中心期间，他帮助建立了综合作战和复杂伤亡护理中心（C5）。在操作上，他曾在USNS Mercy（T-AH-19）号医院船上担任整形外科工作人员和外科服务主任。他作为第一部队勤务保障小组的专业服务营主任（前锋）和外科休克创伤排的负责人，在支持“伊拉克自由二号行动”时进行了部署，在“幻影狂怒”行动期间提供第二梯队外科护理的同时，实现了98%的战斗伤亡存活率。吉林厄姆还担任海军西医司令；圣地亚哥海军医疗中心指挥官；朴茨茅斯海军医疗中心副指挥官；佛罗里达州杰克逊维尔海军医院指挥官；太平洋舰队外科医生、舰队外科医生和美国舰队部队卫生服务部主任。2011年，他在福岛核灾难后担任联合支援部队日本外科医生，确保了20多万美国公民的安全，海军医学和美国海军卫生部长的更多信息，请访问海军医学网站https://med.navy.mil 或者在司令部的Facebook、Twitter或LinkedIn帐户上。

column2: Vice Adm. Forrest Faison Discusses the Future of Navy Medicine at AMSUS
column3:
NATIONAL HARBOR, Md. (NNS) C On Thursday, Nov. 29, Vice Adm. Forrest Faison, Navy surgeon general and chief, U.S. Navy of Bureau of Medicine and Surgery came together with military medicine leaders during AMSUS for a panel discussion on the future of the services as they begin to transition medical facilities to the Defense Health Agency (DHA). 

On Oct. 1, 2018 Navy Medicine began phase one of the DHA transition, transferring Naval Hospital Jacksonville administration, management and control to the DHA. While this transition presents significant change for Navy Medicine, the mission to keep Sailors, Marines and their families healthy and ready does not.

“The Navy is taking advantage of the many opportunities that come with this transformation. It allows us to focus on our true north and ensure we’re doing all we can to save lives and return sons and daughters home to their families” said Faison. 

Several transition initiatives and milestones were shared by the services, yet the recurring theme throughout the panel’s discussion revolved around the importance of readiness.

Faison went on to describe the unique ways in which Navy Medicine is supporting the transition and taking steps to maintain readiness as hospitals and clinics transition administration, management and control to the DHA. For patients, these reforms should have little or no effect on their experience, facility and physicians. Coverage will remain the same, and patients will continue to receive the same exceptional level of care and service.

“We are focused on a future of design, not default,” said Faison. 
To complement changes in the organizational construct of the DHA, Navy Medicine will establish Readiness and Training Commands that support the Navy’s mission and the DHA’s role of administration and management of the MTFs.

 “The Navy Medicine Readiness and Training Commands (NMRTCs) will focus on platform readiness and training so that beneficiaries can continue to receive the same level of care,” said Faison.

While the transition itself presents a great amount of change, the evolving future of warfare and health care will also continue to drive changes in the way the Navy delivers care. The emergence of great power competition and the growing capabilities of near-peer competitors to project seapower could indicate the next war at sea. 

“If you’re going to fight tonight, you’ve got to be able to save lives tonight,” Faison said. “Every mom and dad in America is depending on us to do that.” 

As the transition continues and the warfighting environment evolves, Navy Medicine will adapt and provide the necessary functions and capabilities needed to fight the next fight, whether it be on sea, land or in the air. 

The AMSUS Annual Meeting runs from Nov. 27 through Nov. 30 and brings together top military and federal health leaders, industry experts, and medical professionals. Topics such as global health, Military Health System transformation, DoD’s new electronic health record MHS GENESIS, virtual health, and pain management have been points of discussion over the course of the week. Speakers also share their knowledge of the latest advances in military and federal health care, including innovative research and patient care.

Navy Medicine is a global health care network of 63,000 personnel that provides health care support to the U.S. Navy, Marine Corps, their families and veterans in high operational tempo environments at expeditionary medical facilities, medical treatment facilities, hospitals, clinics, hospital ships and research units around the world.

column9: 瀑布教堂，弗吉尼亚州，美国
column10: 福雷斯特・费森副上将在美国海军医疗服务中心讨论海军医学的未来
column11: 马里兰州国家海港（NNS）C11月29日，星期四，海军卫生部长兼美国海军医学和外科局局长福里斯特・费森（Forrest Faison）副上将与军事医学领导人在美国军事医疗保障体系（AMSUS）会议上就医疗设施向国防卫生局（DHA）过渡的未来进行了小组讨论。2018年10月1日，海军医学部开始了DHA转型的第一阶段，将杰克逊维尔海军医院的行政、管理和控制移交给DHA。虽然这一转变为海军医学带来了重大变化，但保持海员、海军陆战队及其家属健康和准备就绪的使命却没有改变。“海军正在利用这一转变带来的诸多机遇。它使我们能够专注于我们的真正北方，确保我们正在尽一切努力拯救生命，让儿女们重返家园。”Faison说。各军种共享了一些过渡计划和里程碑，但整个小组讨论中反复出现的主题围绕着准备就绪的重要性。Faison接着描述了海军医学支持过渡的独特方式，并采取措施保持医院和临床的准备就绪cs将行政、管理和控制过渡到DHA。对于患者而言，这些改革对他们的经验、设施和医生的影响应该很小或没有影响。覆盖范围将保持不变，患者将继续获得相同的特殊护理和服务。“我们关注的是设计的未来，而不是默认。”为了补充DHA组织结构的变化，海军医学部将建立战备和训练司令部，以支持海军的任务以及DHA管理和管理MTF的角色。”海军医学战备和训练司令部（NMRTCs）将重点关注平台准备和培训，以便受益人能够继续获得同等水平的护理。”费森说。虽然转型本身带来了巨大的变化，但战争和医疗保健不断发展的未来也将继续推动海军提供医疗服务的方式发生变化。大国竞争的出现以及近邻竞争对手投射海权的能力不断增强可能预示着下一场海上战争。费森说：“如果你今晚要参加战斗，你今晚就必须能够拯救生命。美国的每一位父母都依靠我们来做到这一点。”随着过渡的继续和作战环境的演变，海军医学将适应并提供下一场战斗所需的必要功能和能力，无论是在海上、陆地还是在空中。AMSU年会从11月27日至11月30日举行，汇集了军队和联邦卫生界的顶级领导人、工业界专家和医疗专业人士。本周讨论的主题包括全球健康、军事卫生系统转型、国防部新的电子病历MHS成因、虚拟健康和疼痛管理。发言者还分享了他们对军事和联邦卫生保健最新进展的知识，包括创新研究和患者护理。海军医学是一个由63000名人员组成的全球医疗保健网络，在远征医疗设施、医疗设施、医院、诊所、医疗船等高作战节奏环境中为美国海军、海军陆战队及其家属和退伍军人提供医疗保健支持世界第二研究单位###

column2: Adm. Joel T. Boone Branch Health Clinic Change of Charge
column3:
The Adm. Joel T. Boone Branch Health Clinic held a change of charge ceremony here, June 22.

Cmdr. Dawn Freeman relieved Cmdr. Kathleen Cooperman as the officer in charge (OIC) of the health care triad that includes Boone Branch Health Clinic, the Northwest Branch Health Clinic and TRICARE Prime Clinic Virginia Beach.

“Two exemplary officers will cross paths on this stage today. This rotation of staff is somewhat unique to us in the Navy. Bill Gates has always been Microsoft, Bill Forbes always been Forbes. Majority of our corporate leadership has essentially run from the beginning, but not here, we have two or three years,” said the presiding officer present at the ceremony, Capt. Christopher Culp, Naval Medical Center Portsmouth’s commanding officer.  “Additionally, commands benefit immensely from the frequent infusion of new ideas, philosophies, direction, and style. It prevents anything from sitting on the back burner.”

Cooperman assumed the duties as OIC in September 2015, and she will be staying in the area since her next duty station is Navy Medicine East, located within the Naval Medical Center Portsmouth campus in Portsmouth, Virginia.

“As Boone triad OIC, I have been afforded the opportunity to serve with so many phenomenal people who are the ones who make it happen,” said Cooperman. “My job was really to move the barriers and clear the way for this incredibly talented staff could ensure we maintained access to care for the 43,000 beneficiaries that are enrolled to the triad.”

Cooperman was presented the Meritorious Service Medal for her accomplishments while OIC of the Boone Branch Health Clinic triad.  Some of the accomplishments during her time as OIC included overseeing a triad that provided health care to beneficiaries every day of the year.  More than 750 medical and 150 dental visits were completed, and 1,400 prescriptions filled for active duty and dependent beneficiaries. The triad also supported hurricane relief efforts in Puerto Rico late last year.  Recognition included the Vickie Garner award for excellence in quality and the Navy Surgeon General's Blue H gold level award.

As Freeman accepted the OIC position, she said, “To the staff, I am truly humbled by the opportunity to be your OIC. It is an honor and a responsibility that I do not take lightly.”  

Freeman, a Green Bay, Wisconsin native, becomes the newest OIC after completing a successful tour at the Navy Warfare Development command.  Other tours of duty include director for administration at Naval Health Clinic Quantico, NMCP associate director for Health Care Business Operations, associate director for operations for the Director of Surgical Services, in addition to deployments in support of Operation Enduring Freedom.

“Let us be reminded that the building that we occupy to administer healthcare to our beneficiaries was dedicated in 1972, after Admiral Joel T. Boone, a true American hero and patriot,” said Freeman.  “We will strive to maintain our clinic’s reputation as the number one branch clinic in Navy medicine. You have my word that I will do everything in my power to prepare us for the challenges that lie ahead. Let’s get to work.”

The Boone Branch Health Clinic triad is part of Naval Medical Center Portsmouth umbrella of care for beneficiaries throughout the Hampton Roads area.  NMCP is the U. S. Navy's oldest, continuously-operating hospital since 1830 and is a nationally acclaimed, state-of-the-art medical center, along with the area’s branch and TRICARE Prime clinics.  The medical center also supports premier research and teaching programs designed to prepare new doctors, nurses and hospital corpsmen for future roles in healing and wellness.
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州朴茨茅斯
column10: Joel T.Boone Branch健康诊所行政主管变更
column11: 6月22日，海军上将Joel T.Boone Branch健康诊所在这里举行了换岗仪式。道恩・弗里曼（Dawn Freeman）接替凯萨琳・库伯曼（Kathleen Cooperman）中校担任医疗三合会的负责人（OIC），该三合会包括布恩分行健康诊所、西北分行健康诊所和弗吉尼亚海滩TRICARE Prime诊所。“今天这个阶段有两位优秀军官将跨越这一阶段。我们海军中的这一轮换工作人员有些独特。比尔・盖茨一直是微软，比尔・福布斯一直是福布斯。我们的大多数公司领导层基本上都是从一开始就开始，但不是在这里，我们有两三年的时间。”出席仪式的主持官、朴茨茅斯海军医疗中心指挥官克里斯托弗・卡尔普上尉说：“此外，司令部从新思想、理念、方向和风格的频繁灌输中受益匪浅。这可以防止任何事情被搁置一旁。”库伯曼于2015年9月担任伊斯兰会议组织成员，她将留在该地区，因为她的下一个工作地点是海军医学东部，位于弗吉尼亚州朴茨茅斯海军医学中心朴茨茅斯校区内。库伯曼说：“作为布恩三合会伊斯兰会议组织，我有机会与这么多杰出的人一起服务，他们是促成这一目标的人。”。“我的工作实际上是消除障碍，为这些才华横溢的员工扫清道路，确保我们能够为注册加入三合会的43000名受益人提供护理。”Cooperman在担任Boone Branch Health Clinic triad的伊斯兰会议组织成员期间获得了荣誉服务奖章。她在伊斯兰会议组织期间的一些成就包括监督一个每年每天为受益人提供医疗服务的三合会。完成了750多次医疗和150次牙科检查，以及1400次产前检查剧本为现役和受抚养的受益人填写。去年年底，三合会还支持波多黎各的飓风救援工作。表彰包括Vickie Garner卓越品质奖和海军卫生部长蓝色H金级奖。她说，弗里曼接受了伊斯兰会议组织的职位，“对于员工们，我真的为有机会成为你们的伊斯兰会议组织而感到谦卑。这是一种荣誉和责任，我不会掉以轻心。”弗里曼是威斯康星州绿湾人，在海军作战发展司令部成功完成任务后成为最新的伊斯兰会议组织成员。其他职务包括海军医疗诊所Quantico的行政总监、NMCP医疗业务运营副总监、南爱尔兰共和国总监的运营副总监弗里曼说：“让我们记住，我们为受益人管理医疗保健所占用的大楼是在1972年，在乔尔・T・布恩上将（Joel T.Boone上将，一位真正的美国英雄和爱国者）之后修建的。”。“我们将努力保持我们诊所作为海军医学第一分支诊所的声誉。我向你保证，我将尽我所能为我们迎接未来的挑战做好准备。让我们开始工作。”Boone Branch Health Clinic triad是整个汉普顿路地区朴茨茅斯海军医疗中心受益人护理伞的一部分。NMCP是美国海军自1830年以来最古老、持续运营的医院，是一家全国知名、最先进的医疗中心，以及该地区的分支和TRICARE Prime诊所。该医疗中心还支持高级研究和教学项目，旨在培养新的医生、护士和医院医务人员，为未来的康复和健康工作做好准备。

column2: Vice Adm. Brown Gets Underway on LCS; impressed with capabilities, Sailors
column3:
SAN DIEGO ― Vice Adm. Rich Brown, commander, Naval Surface Forces (SURFOR), embarked USS Coronado (LCS 4) March 16, as the ship got underway from Naval Base San Diego for the final stage of Coastal Mine Reconnaissance (CMR) mission module testing.

The underway period gave Brown his first opportunity to experience how littoral combat ships (LCS) operate at sea. He told the crew he was impressed with the capabilities of the ship and her Sailors.

“These ships bring unmatched capability to the Surface Navy and provide flexibility to our fleet commanders,” said Brown.  “You can't understand the incredible capacity of these ships until you've been underway on one.”  

During the visit, Brown took an extensive tour of the ship, engaging with Sailors and answering their questions along the way.

“Having Vice Adm. Brown on board gave us the chance to talk to one of the top commanders in the Navy,” said Culinary Specialist 1st Class Michael Mahan, from South Kortright, New York. “Even with his comprehensive knowledge about Navy ships, he specifically wanted to know about our ship, our work environment and our equipment ― all the pros and cons and the issues we may be facing.”

While addressing the crew over the ship’s intercom system, Brown commended the Sailors on their successes thus far, yet challenged each Sailor to remain focused during the final stage of the CMR module testing.  

“This is the best day I’ve had in my first two months as the Surface Force commander,” said Brown.  “Like all Surface Warfare Officers I love being at sea and being able to get underway, but that experience is all the more rewarding when you see the dedication and professionalism the captain and crew have displayed during this testing phase.”

“I am impressed with this fantastic crew.  This is one of the best crews I have been around in my 33 years,” Brown said after the embark.  

Last month, and ahead of schedule, the ship completed the first stage of module testing, known as developmental testing. During developmental testing the ship's crew and aviation detachment exercised the module in realistic environmental conditions, verifying that the system is now ready for operational testing.

“I think this visit provided Vice Adm. Brown the LCS experience he was hoping for,” said Cmdr. Karl McCarthy, the ship’s commanding officer and a native of North Easton, Massachusetts. “He saw first-hand the vital testing we are conducting, heard from our operators about the tremendous capabilities that LCSs offer the Fleet, and he told us he was impressed with and applauded the continued growth and recent successes of USS Coronado and the entire LCS program.”

“This was a morale booster for our crew and we were honored to have SURFOR onboard our ship for his first underway on an LCS,” said McCarthy.

Coronado is one of four testing ships assigned to Commander, Littoral Combat Ship Squadron ONE. Since returning from deployment in late 2017, the ship has been testing the CMR module, which consists of the MQ-8B Fire Scout unmanned aerial vehicle, the AN/DVS-1 Coastal Battlespace Reconnaissance and Analysis (COBRA) system, and supporting software and containers. 

Brown assumed command of SURFOR in January 2018 after having served as commander of Navy Personnel Command (NPC) and deputy chief of naval personnel. 

SURFOR mission is to man, train and equip ships that provide fleet commanders with combat naval power at sea and to project that power ashore. 

For more news from Naval Surface Forces, visit http://www.navy.mil/local/cnsp/.

For more news on USS Coronado (LCS 4) and Littoral Combat Ship Squadron ONE, visit www.public.navy.mil/surfor/lcsron1/Pages/default.aspx
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州圣地亚哥
column10: 布朗副上将正在进行LCS；水手们对自己的能力印象深刻
column11: 圣地亚哥―海军水面部队（SURFOR）指挥官里奇・布朗（Rich Brown）副上将于3月16日登上美国海军科罗纳多号（LCS 4），当时该舰正从圣地亚哥海军基地启航，准备进行海岸水雷侦察（CMR）任务模块测试的最后阶段。启航期间，布朗首次有机会体验沿海作战舰艇（LCS）的作战能力在海上作业。他告诉船员们，他对该舰及其船员的能力印象深刻。“这些舰艇为水面海军带来了无与伦比的能力，并为我们的舰队指挥官提供了灵活性，”布朗说。“在你驾驶一艘军舰之前，你无法理解这些军舰难以置信的能力。”在访问期间，布朗对军舰进行了广泛的参观，与水手们进行了接触，并在途中回答了他们的问题。“有布朗副上将在船上，让我们有机会与海军最高指挥官之一交谈。”来自纽约南科尔特里赫特的一等烹饪专家迈克尔・马汉说。“尽管他对海军舰艇有着全面的了解，但他特别想了解我们的舰艇、我们的工作环境和我们的设备――所有的优点和缺点以及我们可能面临的问题。”布朗在通过舰艇的对讲系统向船员讲话时，赞扬了船员们迄今为止取得的成功，然而，在CMR模块测试的最后阶段，要求每位船员保持专注。布朗说：“这是我担任地面部队指挥官头两个月里过得最好的一天。”。“和所有水面作战军官一样，我喜欢在海上航行，能够上船，但当你看到船长和船员在测试阶段所表现出的奉献精神和专业精神时，这种经历就更有意义了。”“我对这支出色的团队印象深刻。这是我33年来最出色的团队之一。”布朗在登船后说。上个月，该船提前完成了模块测试的第一阶段，即开发测试。在开发测试期间，该船的船员和航空分队在实际环境条件下对模块进行了测试，以验证该系统现在已准备好进行操作测试。“我认为这次访问为布朗副上将提供了他所希望的LCS体验，”该舰指挥官、马萨诸塞州东北部人卡尔・麦卡锡中校说。“他亲眼目睹了我们正在进行的重要测试，从我们的运营商那里听到了LCS为舰队提供的巨大能力，他告诉我们，他对“科罗纳多”号航母和整个LCS计划的持续增长和最近的成功感到印象深刻并鼓掌。”“这对我们的船员来说是士气的鼓舞，我们很荣幸有冲浪者登上我们的船，这是他第一次乘坐LCS航行。”Coronado是分配给沿海战斗舰一中队指挥官的四艘测试舰之一。自2017年底部署归来以来，该舰一直在测试CMR模块，该模块由MQ-8B火力侦察无人机、AN/DVS-1沿海作战空间侦察和分析（COBRA）组成布朗在担任海军人事司令部（NPC）指挥官后，于2018年1月担任SURFOR的司令和海军人事部副部长。SURFOR的任务是为舰队指挥官提供海上作战力量的舰艇配备人员、训练和装备，并将这种力量投射到岸上。有关海军水面部队的更多消息，请访问http://www.navy.mil/local/cnsp/.For 更多关于科罗纳多号的新闻（LCS 4）和沿海战斗舰中队一号，请访问www.public.navy.mil/surfor/lcsron1/Pages/default.aspx

column2: Pennsylvania Native, Rear Adm. Matthew Kohler, Puts on Third Star
column3:
Rear Adm. Matthew J. Kohler, currently assigned as commander, Naval Information Forces (NAVIFOR) in Suffolk, Virginia, promoted to the rank of vice admiral July 6.

 Kohler is a 1983 graduate of Indiana University of Pennsylvania. He received his commission to ensign in 1984 through the Aviation Officer Candidate School, Pensacola, Florida, as a Naval Intelligence Officer. 

 Commander, U.S. Fleet Forces, Adm. Phil Davidson presided at the event.

 "Matt is the epitome of what Navy and information warfare leadership expects and needs to fight and win today and into the future," said Davidson. "Matt has excelled in a wide variety of highly demanding information warfare assignments and is more than ready to take his skills to the next level as a senior flag officer."

 After Kohler's wife pinned the 3-star rank insignia on his collars, Davidson administered the oath of office to one of the Navy's newest vice admirals.

 "These stars belong to each and every Sailor and Navy civilian throughout Naval Information Forces," said Kohler. "This promotion represents your hard work and dedication and I am truly thankful to work with such a professional team."

 Additionally, Kohler attributed much of his success to his wife, Melanie, who has supported his career for more than three decades while raising their two children. 

 Kohler's selection to vice admiral is the culmination of more than 33 years of leadership experience at sea and ashore. His operational tours include intelligence officer for Fighter Squadron 102 (F-14) on USS America (CV 66); director of intelligence (N2) for Commander Amphibious Squadron 1 on USS Peleliu (LHA 5); and N2 for Cruiser Destroyer Group 2, USS George Washington (CVN 73) Battle Group. 

 Ashore he served as an intelligence analyst and systems and communications officer for U.S. Naval Force Europe in London; junior intelligence officer detailer and assistant community manager, Bureau of Naval Personnel in Washington, D.C.; deputy director of intelligence (J2), Joint Warfare Analysis Center in Dahlgren, Virginia; director of intelligence operations United States Special Operations Command in Tampa, Florida; and director of intelligence (J2) for Joint Interagency Task Force South in Key West, Florida.

 Kohler has led Naval Information Forces Command since its establishment in October 2014. His other flag assignments include J2, U.S. Africa Command, in Stuttgart, Germany; deputy director of naval intelligence, OPNAV N2/N6I in Washington D.C.; deputy commander Fleet Cyber Command/U.S. 10th Fleet; and deputy chief of tailored access operations, National Security Agency, in Fort Meade, Maryland. 

 Kohler holds a master's degree from the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School in computer science and from the U.S. Army Command and General Staff College in military history.

 For more information on NAVIFOR, visit the command's web site at www.navifor.navy.mil, our Navy News Web page at www.navy.mil/local/navifor or Facebook page at www.facebook.com/USNavyInformationDominanceForces.

 For more Navy news, visit www.navy.mil, www.facebook.com/usnavy or www.twitter.com/usnavy.

 For more news from Naval Information Forces, visit www.navy.mil/local/navifor/.
column9: 萨福克，弗吉尼亚州，美国
column10: 宾夕法尼亚州本地人、海军少将马修・科勒扮演三星
column11: 海军少将马修・科勒（Matthew J.Kohler）目前被任命为弗吉尼亚州萨福克海军信息部队（NAVIFOR）指挥官，7月6日晋升为海军中将。科勒是宾州印第安那大学1983的毕业生。1984年，他通过佛罗里达州彭萨科拉的航空军官候选学校获得海军情报官的任命，担任海军少尉。美国舰队司令菲尔・戴维森上将主持了此次活动。戴维森说：“马特是海军和信息战领导层期望和需要在今天和未来作战并取得胜利的缩影。”。“马特在各种高要求的信息战任务中表现出色，并准备将自己的技能提升到高级旗舰军官的新水平。”科勒的妻子将三星军衔徽章别在他的衣领上后，戴维森向海军最新的一位海军中将宣誓就职。科勒说：“这些星星属于海军信息部队中的每一位海员和海军平民。”。“这次晋升代表了你的辛勤工作和奉献精神，我真的很感谢与这样一个专业团队合作。”此外，科勒将他的成功很大程度上归功于他的妻子梅兰妮，她在抚养两个孩子的同时支持了他的事业三十多年。科勒被选为海军中将是33年海上和岸上领导经验的结晶。他的行动之旅包括美国号航空母舰（CV 66）102战斗机中队（F-14）情报官；Peleliu号航空母舰（LHA 5）两栖中队1指挥官情报总监（N2）；和巡洋舰驱逐舰2组N2，乔治华盛顿号（CVN73）战斗群。在岸上，他曾担任美国驻伦敦欧洲海军的情报分析员、系统和通信官员；华盛顿特区海军人事局初级情报官员兼社区经理助理。；弗吉尼亚州达尔格伦联合战争分析中心情报副主任（J2）；佛罗里达州坦帕美国特别行动司令部情报行动主任；以及佛罗里达州基韦斯特南部联合跨机构特遣部队情报总监（J2）。自2014年10月海军信息部队司令部成立以来，科勒一直领导该司令部。他的其他军旗任务包括：驻德国斯图加特的美国非洲司令部J2；华盛顿海军情报局副局长，OPNAV N2/N6I。；舰队网络司令部副司令/美国第10舰队；以及马里兰州米德堡国家安全局定制访问行动副局长。科勒拥有美国海军研究生院计算机科学硕士学位和美国陆军指挥与参谋学院军事史硕士学位。有关NAVIFOR的更多信息，请访问司令部网站www.NAVIFOR.navy.mil、海军新闻网页www.navy.mil/local/NAVIFOR或Facebook网页www.Facebook.com/USNavyInformationDominanceForces。有关更多海军新闻，请访问www.Navy.mil、www.facebook.com/usnavy或www.twitter.com/usnavy。有关海军信息部队的更多新闻，请访问www.navy.mil/local/navifor/。

column2: Adm. Harris credits Hawaii’s role in Indo-Asia-Pacific rebalance
column3:
HONOLULU C Adm. Harry Harris, U.S. Pacific Command commander, spoke to government officials, private sector representatives and military leaders about Hawaii’s importance in the future of the Indo-Asia-Pacific during the annual Military Affairs Council (MAC) Meeting and Partnership Conference at Washington Place here, Jan. 15.

During his remarks Harris recognized the MAC and state leaders for their support in communicating how joint military forces in Hawaii support the national security strategy and ongoing rebalance initiative. 

“Due to the outstanding communications conducted by Governor Ige, Mayor Caldwell, Senator Schatz and Hirono, Representatives Gabbard and Takai, and all of our local state officials, decision makers in Washington and throughout the region are well aware that Hawaii remains the “Gateway to America’s rebalance to the Indo-Asia-Pacific,” Harris said.

Hawaii serves as a gateway to the rebalance by utilizing its assets in operations throughout the region and the defense of the homeland. Harris said that there is no doubt that the United States economic future is firmly tied to the Indo-Asia-Pacific and that everyone at every level must work together to strengthen civil and military relationships with each other and with other nations in the region. 

Harris then explained the state’s role in supporting the rebalance, stating that Hawaii is the only place in the world where all component commanders are geographically co-located together, allowing forces to train and operate jointly and benefit from a face-to-face relationship, an advantage made largely possible because of the support from the state. 

“This gives us an extraordinary advantage and it wouldn’t be possible without the continued dedication and support from Hawaii’s community, civic and industry leadership,” Harris said. “In addition to our forces in Hawaii, the presence and capabilities we are bringing forward into this theater are commensurate with the challenges that we face.”

The support has influenced the strengthening of partnerships such as the Philippine Supreme Court’s decision that the Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement (EDCA) is consistent with their constitution, strengthening security ties between the Philippines and the United States.

“The agreement will facilitate the enhanced rotational presence of the U.S. military in the region, and support the long-term modernization of the Armed Forces of the Philippines,” Harris said. “This will enable the United States and the Philippines to continue supporting the international rules-based order that has served the region so well.”

Despite successes within the Indo-Asia-Pacific, Harris emphasized that security and stability which the region has enjoyed can’t be taken for granted and that Hawaii’s role to the rebalance will continue to support PACOM’s commitment to the security and safety of the nation’s allies as possible threats in the region emerge.

“Security challenges such as North Korea threaten to destabilize the region and reverse the trends of transparency and prosperity that we’ve all enjoyed,” Harris said. “America is rebalancing to the Indo-Asia-Pacific to meet those challenges and reinforce the international rules-based order that has benefited the region for more than 70 years and Hawaii plays a critical role.”

At the end of his remarks, Harris thanked the MAC for their continued support.

“Thank you for everything you do in support of our men and women in uniform and helping to ensure that we remain ready to fight tonight and win,” Harris said. “May God bless our veterans, this great state and this beautiful city and may God bless our nation.”
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: 哈里斯上将赞扬夏威夷在印度-亚太再平衡中的作用
column11: 檀香山―美国太平洋司令部司令哈里・哈里斯上将在华盛顿广场举行的年度军事委员会（MAC）会议和伙伴关系会议上向政府官员、私营部门代表和军方领导人讲述了夏威夷在印度-亚太地区未来的重要性，1月15日。哈里斯在讲话中赞扬了陆委会和州领导人在传达夏威夷联合军事力量如何支持国家安全战略和正在进行的再平衡计划方面给予的支持。“由于州长伊格、市长考德威尔、参议员沙茨和广野、众议员加巴德和塔凯以及我们所有的地方州官员进行了出色的沟通，华盛顿和整个地区的决策者都清楚地意识到夏威夷仍然是“美国重新平衡印度-亚太地区的门户”哈里斯说。夏威夷通过在整个地区的军事行动和国土防御中利用其资产，成为实现再平衡的门户。哈里斯说，毫无疑问，美国的经济未来与印度-亚太地区紧密相连，各个层面的每个人都必须共同努力，加强民事和军事力量哈里斯随后解释了该州在支持重新平衡中的作用，指出夏威夷是世界上唯一一个所有部队指挥官在地理位置上都位于同一地点的地方，允许部队联合训练和作战，并从面对面的关系中受益“这给了我们一个非凡的优势，如果没有夏威夷社区、公民和行业领袖的持续奉献和支持，这是不可能的，”哈里斯说。“除了我们在夏威夷的部队外，我们在该战区的存在和能力与我们面临的挑战是相称的。”这种支持影响了伙伴关系的加强，例如菲律宾最高法院决定加强国防合作协议（EDCA）哈里斯说：“该协议将有助于加强美军在该地区的轮流驻扎，并支持菲律宾武装部队的长期现代化。”。“这将使美国和菲律宾能够继续支持基于规则的国际秩序，这一秩序在该地区发挥了巨大作用。”尽管在印度-亚太地区取得了成功，哈里斯强调，该地区所享有的安全与稳定不能被视为理所当然，夏威夷在重新平衡中的作用将继续支持太平洋司令部在该地区可能出现的威胁出现时对国家盟友的安全与保障的承诺。哈里斯说：“像朝鲜这样的安全挑战有可能破坏该地区的稳定，扭转我们大家都享有的透明和繁荣的趋势。”。“美国正在向印度-亚太地区重新平衡，以应对这些挑战，并加强基于规则的国际秩序，这一秩序已使该地区受益70多年，夏威夷发挥了关键作用。”哈里斯在讲话结束时感谢陆委会的持续支持。哈里斯说：“感谢你们为支持我们的男女军人所做的一切，感谢你们帮助我们确保我们今晚随时准备战斗并取得胜利。愿上帝保佑我们的退伍军人、这个伟大的州和这个美丽的城市，愿上帝保佑我们的国家。”

column2: Adm. Swift talks regional trends during Cooperative Strategy Forum
column3:
HONOLULU C U.S. Navy Adm. Scott Swift, commander of U.S. Pacific Fleet, spoke to more than 100 personnel at the Daniel K. Inouye Asia-Pacific Center for Security Studies (APCSS) during a cooperative strategy forum co-hosted by the Chief of Naval Operations Dec. 14.

During the forum Swift delivered a keynote speech to attendees that shared his expectations of those operating in the waters of the Indo-Asia-Pacific.

“I’m focused on the behavior of all naval and maritime forces in the region, not on any specific country,” Swift said. “I expect all naval and maritime forces, including my own, to operate responsibly, safely and in full compliance with international law.”

The event involved representatives from ten partner nations with a focus on participants gaining a better understanding of each other’s viewpoints and fostering improved future collaboration.

U.S. Navy Capt. Patrick Gibbons, chief of Naval Operations Staff operations, plans and strategy legal adviser and oceans policy adviser, explained how the forum builds relationships and strengthens collaborative efforts between the U.S. and its allies.

“This forum is designed to facilitate an exchange of views among all our allies and partners in the region,” Gibbons said. “This exchange of views helps us to understand each other’s approaches to the challenges in the region but it also facilitates personal relationships between the attendees. We have flag officers, O-6s, O-5s, and in the case of some countries O-4s who are going to be here and spend two days with their U.S. and other foreign country counterparts.”

U.S. Navy Cmdr. Jonathan Odom APCSS military professor and Cooperative Strategy Forum organizer, said that the APCSS also benefits from these types of multinational events.

“One of the top three priorities in our curriculum both in workshops and courses that we teach is now maritime security,” Odom said. “For us to hold an event here where you have the leaders or representatives of the leaders of the navies throughout this region discussing ways to cooperate on maritime issues is clearly quite an opportunity for us.”

As part of the event, Swift explained why maintaining cooperation between partner nations in the region is important.

“Today all Indo-Asia-Pacific nations benefit from a rising tide of prosperity,” Swift said. “We all have major stakes in this region’s continued success, especially at sea, where so much of our trade, investment and interaction take place.”

Swift then offered his thoughts on the way ahead for the Indo-Asia-Pacific region.

“I’m convinced the continued promotion of the rules-based system that evolved over the past 70 years remains the best way forward for all nations in this region, large and small, to continue to rise peacefully, confidently, securely, and economically,” Swift said. “My concern is that after many decades of peace and prosperity at sea, we may be seeing the leading edge of a return of ‘might makes right’ to the region. Such an approach may once again impact the vibrant but vulnerable waters of Southeast Asia.”
column9: 檀香山，你好，美国
column10: 斯威夫特上将在合作战略论坛上讨论地区趋势
column11: 檀香山―美国太平洋舰队司令斯科特・斯威夫特海军上将在丹尼尔・K・伊诺伊亚太安全研究中心（APCSS）与100多名人员交谈12月14日，在海军作战司令共同主持的合作战略论坛上，斯威夫特向与会者发表了主旨演讲，表达了他对印度-亚太水域作战人员的期望。“我关注的是该地区所有海军和海上部队的行为，而不是任何特定国家。”斯威夫特说。“我希望所有海军和海上部队，包括我自己的部队，都能负责任地、安全地、完全按照国际法运作。”来自十个伙伴国家的代表参加了这次活动，重点是让与会者更好地了解彼此的观点，促进未来更好的合作。海军作战参谋长、作战、计划和战略法律顾问兼海洋政策顾问帕特里克・吉本斯海军上尉解释了该论坛如何在美国及其盟国之间建立关系并加强合作。吉本斯说：“这个论坛旨在促进我们在该地区的所有盟友和伙伴之间交换意见。”。“这种意见交流有助于我们了解彼此应对该地区挑战的方法，但也有助于促进与会者之间的人际关系。我们有国旗官、O-6、O-5以及一些国家的O-4，他们将在这里与美国和其他外国同行共度两天“美国海军指挥官乔纳森・奥多姆（Jonathan Odom）APCSS军事教授兼合作战略论坛组织者说，APCSS也从这些类型的多国活动中受益。“我们课程中最重要的三个优先事项之一，包括研讨会和我们教授的课程，现在是海上安全，”奥多姆说。“对于我们来说，在这里举办一次活动，让该地区各国海军领导人或代表讨论如何在海事问题上进行合作，这显然是一个很好的机会。”作为活动的一部分，斯威夫特解释了为什么保持该地区伙伴国家之间的合作非常重要。斯威夫特说：“今天，所有的印度-亚太国家都受益于日益高涨的繁荣浪潮。我们在该地区的持续成功中都有着重大的利害关系，特别是在海上，我们的贸易、投资和互动如此之多。”斯威夫特接着提出了他对印度-亚太地区未来道路的看法。斯威夫特说：“我相信，继续推进过去70年来形成的以规则为基础的体系，仍然是该地区所有国家，无论大小，继续和平、自信、安全和经济崛起的最佳途径。”。“我担心的是，在海上几十年的和平与繁荣之后，我们可能会看到‘强权使权利’回归该地区的前沿。这种做法可能会再次影响到充满活力但脆弱的东南亚海域。”

column2: VCNO, Adm. Howard visits top supplier of valves for Navy ships
column3:
PRARIE DU SAC, Wisc. C Adm. Michelle Howard, vice chief of naval operations, toured the Milwaukee Valve plant in Prairie du Sac, Wisconsin, Nov. 20.

Milwaukee Valve Company is the Navy’s largest supplier of shipboard valves. 

“I was reading an article on all the great work that’s done up here and said ‘If I’m ever in Wisconsin, I want to see where these valves are made,’” said Howard. “You wouldn’t believe that a land locked state in the middle of the country would have such a strong tie to the Navy.” 

Milwaukee Valve Company has been in partnership with the Navy since the 1960s and provides close to 12,000 valves for each individual aircraft carrier.

Howard said that she wanted to emphasize to the employees how important their job was to keeping ships at sea so they can continue to defend the nation.
 
“We’re extremely proud to have Adm. Howard visit us today,” said Rick Giannini, CEO of the Milwaukee Valve Company. “The Marine and Navy business is an extremely important part of what we do so we are pleased that she wanted to come see what we do.”

Giannini is also the chairman of the Aircraft Carrier Industrial Base Coalition (ACIBC). The coalition represents approximately 400 businesses that supply components and services for U.S. Navy aircraft carriers.
ACIBC seeks to preserve the strength of the aircraft carrier force and promote the value of the Aircraft Carrier Industrial Base as a vital part of the nation’s overall defense structure.

“The shipbuilding industry is alive and well and we need support from our congressional members to keep building ships to support the defense of this great country,” said Giannini.
column6: PRAIRIE DU SAC, WI, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国威斯康星州萨克大草原
column10: 霍华德上将访问海军舰艇阀门的顶级供应商
column11: 威斯康辛州萨克广场-海军作战副总司令米歇尔・霍华德上将于11月20日参观了威斯康辛州大草原杜萨克密尔沃基阀门厂。密尔沃基阀门公司是海军最大的船用阀门供应商。霍华德说：“我读了一篇关于这里所有伟大工作的文章，说‘如果我来威斯康星州，我想看看这些阀门是在哪里制造的。’”。“你不会相信一个内陆国家会对海军有如此强的联系。”密尔沃基阀门公司自20世纪60年代以来一直与海军合作，为每艘航空母舰提供近12000个阀门。霍华德说，她想向员工强调，他们的工作对于保持船只在海上航行是多么重要，这样他们才能继续保卫国家。密尔沃基阀门公司首席执行官Rick Giannini说：“霍华德上将今天来访，我们感到非常自豪。海军陆战队和海军业务是我们工作中极其重要的一部分，因此我们很高兴她想来看我们的工作。”Giannini也是航空母舰工业基地联盟（ACIBC）的主席该联盟代表了大约400家为美国海军航空母舰提供部件和服务的企业。ACIBC寻求保持航空母舰部队的实力，并提升航空母舰工业基地作为国家整体防御结构重要组成部分的价值。吉安尼尼说：“造船业是生机勃勃的，我们需要国会议员的支持，以继续建造船只，支持这个伟大国家的国防。”。

column2: NPS Welcomes Retired Vice Adm. Edward Moore Jr. Into Hall of Fame
column3:
The Naval Postgraduate School (NPS) inducted its newest member, retired Vice Adm. Edward Moore Jr., into the university's prestigious Hall of Fame (HOF) during a virtual ceremony, Jan. 26, making him the 24th person to be welcomed into this revered community since 2001. As a unique addition to Moore’s induction, retired Adm. Cecil Haney presented Moore for induction following his SECNAV Guest Lecture to the university community.

Moore joined the U.S. Naval Reserves as an enlisted Sailor in 1963. In June 1968, he received his degree in Psychology at Southern Illinois University (SIU) and was commissioned as an officer. In 1974 he became a graduate of NPS when he completed his master’s degree in management.

According to Moore, his NPS education was beneficial in several ways, making him a stronger critical thinker and problem solver.

“I found myself using knowledge and analytical skills learned at NPS in most of my subsequent tours whether at sea or ashore, especially my Executive Officer and Commanding Officer tours, and my tour as the Personnel and Manpower division director for the Pacific Fleet,” said Moore.

Moore's service included commanding officer of USS Cowpens in 1989, where he was the ship’s first commander, and the first African American commanding officer of an Aegis-cruiser. While on the Cowpens, Moore led the ship, along with three other ships, in an attack on Iraqi nuclear weapons site in Baghdad on January 17, 1993. 

He then went on to serve as commander of U.S Naval Forces in the Persian Gulf in 1996, commanding the Carl Vinson Task Group and Cruiser-Destroyer Group 3 with successful missile strikes against Iraqi military sites in Operation Desert Strike. Upon his promotion to Vice Admiral in 1998, he became the highest ranking African American Naval officer on active duty through his retirement in 2001.

Moore continued to serve the Navy in a different capacity following his retirement, becoming Vice President for Anteon, and later General Dynamics Information Technology, providing personnel to engineering support. He retired fully in 2012 from the business.

He now continues his legacy by giving back to the community. He volunteered at Four Seasons Hemet Veterans Support Group and California Alumni Chapter of Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc., helping homeless veterans and youth in Riverside and San Bernardino counties in California. He has been on the board of directors of the San Diego Fleet Week Foundation, San Diego Armed Forces YMCA, Navy Federal Credit Union, Surface Navy Association, and National Boy Scouts of America.

A compelling story, written by Moore’s son Edward Anthony Moore III titled, “Tearing Down Racism or Erasing Our History.”

"Amid the controversy surrounding the tearing down of confederate statues and the potential renaming of military bases, I came across an article that mentioned Carl Vinson and his historic support of segregation. It immediately dawned on me that my father, a man who attended school with the Little Rock 9 and their siblings during desegregation, had been stationed to command a ship named after a man who had directly opposed his equality," he wrote. 

"It was important for him to be selected because it proves that when brought to the front line, in the light of nomination, people cannot deny great people of their quality of work and consistency regardless of race, religion, or creed," said U.S. Navy Lt. Brandon Carter, am NPS student. "For those who have been disenfranchised or marginalized, it demonstrates to them that the mindset of the powers that are shifting to become more accepting and understanding of hard-working men and women. Men and women who have had the energy to break down social and racial barriers while maintaining an extensive resume of sustained superior performance."

NPS President retired Vice Adm. Ann Rondeau noted that recognizing the incredible service and accomplishments of our most distinguished alumni is an inspiration to the university and all those who serve.

“As a leader, warfighter and trailblazer, it is an honor to formally commend and induct Vice Adm. Moore into our prestigious NPS Hall of Fame,” said Rondeau. “Showcasing individuals who have attained the highest levels of public service and made significant contributions to our Navy and our society can only set the standards for all of us serving who dare to do great and remarkable things.”

"VADM Moore is the epitome of resilience and mental toughness," added Carter. "He has gone from being an enlisted sailor to an officer, becoming the first black person to command an AEGIS Cruiser and reach the highest rank any black person in the Navy has seen and then continued to serve as a senior executive in the defense field. Even after all that, he has been able to still give back to his community because service has been that important to him." 

In addition to his NPS Hall of Fame induction, Moore has also been inducted into the Arkansas Black HOF in 1999, SIU distinguished Graduate in 2003 and inducted to the Buffalo Soldiers Museum HOF in 2013.

“It is truly a humbling experience to be recognized by induction into the school’s Hall of Fame,” said Moore. “Thousands of students over the years have benefited from the educational, professional, cultural, social, and environmental skills imparted to them in their time here as a student. Most have probably applied what they learned in productive ways, personally and professionally. So, it is a clear honor to be singled out as having lived up to the expectations that the school has for all students.”

Watch the complete ceremony welcoming Moore into the university’s Hall of Fame on the NPS YouTube Channel.
column9: 蒙特利，加利福尼亚州，美国
column10: NPS欢迎退休副上将爱德华・摩尔进入名人堂
column11: 海军研究生院（NPS）在1月26日的一个虚拟仪式上，将其最新成员、退休副海军上将爱德华・摩尔（Edward Moore Jr.）引入该校享有盛誉的名人堂（HOF），使他成为自2001年以来第24位受人欢迎的人。作为摩尔入职培训的一个独特补充，退休海军上将塞西尔・哈尼（Cecil Haney）在他向大学社区的SECNAV客座演讲后，向摩尔介绍了他的入职培训。摩尔于1963年作为一名应征海员加入美国海军预备队。1968年6月，他在南伊利诺伊大学（SIU）获得心理学学位，并被任命为军官。1974年，当他完成管理硕士学位时，他成为了NPS的毕业生。摩尔说，他的NPS教育在几个方面是有益的，使他成为一个更强的批判性思考者和问题解决者。“我发现自己在随后的大部分巡演中，无论是海上还是岸上，都运用了在NPS学到的知识和分析技能，特别是我的执行官和指挥官巡演，以及我作为太平洋舰队人事和人力司司长的巡演。”摩尔说。摩尔曾在1989年担任过美国军舰考彭斯号的指挥官，当时他是该舰的首位指挥官，也是宙斯盾巡洋舰的首位非裔美国人指挥官。1993年1月17日，在考彭斯号上，摩尔率领该舰和其他三艘军舰袭击了位于巴格达的伊拉克核武器基地。他随后1996年，他继续担任美国驻波斯湾海军司令，指挥卡尔・文森特遣部队和巡洋舰驱逐舰第3组，在“沙漠打击行动”中成功地对伊拉克军事基地进行了导弹袭击。1998年，他晋升为海军中将，成为activ上级别最高的非裔美国海军军官2001年退休后，摩尔继续以不同的身份为海军服务，成为安顿公司（Anteon）的副总裁，后来成为通用动力信息技术公司（General Dynamics Information Technology）的副总裁，为工程支持提供人员。他于2012年从该公司完全退休。现在，他通过回报公司，继续他的遗产Muny.他志愿参加了四个赛季的赫米特退伍军人支持组织和加利福尼亚校友会Kappa Alpha PSI兄弟会，帮助加利福尼亚Riverside和圣贝纳迪诺郡的无家可归的退伍军人和青年，他在圣地亚哥舰队周基金会、圣地亚哥武装部队YMCA、海军联邦CR董事会上担任董事。编辑联盟、水面海军协会和美国国家童子军。摩尔的儿子爱德华・安东尼・摩尔三世写了一篇引人入胜的故事，题为“摧毁种族主义或抹杀我们的历史”"在围绕拆除南部邦联雕像和可能重新命名军事基地的争议中，我看到一篇文章提到卡尔・文森及其对种族隔离的历史支持。我立刻意识到，我的父亲，一个在种族隔离期间与小石城9号和他们的兄弟姐妹一起上学的人，曾经他写道：“他被派去指挥一艘以一位直接反对他平等的人命名的船，这对他来说很重要，因为这证明，当他被带到前线时，根据提名，人们不能否认伟大人物的工作质量和一贯性，而不分种族、宗教或信仰，美国海军中尉布兰登・卡特（Brandon Carter）说。"对于那些被剥夺权利或被边缘化的人来说，这向他们表明，权力的心态正在转变，变得更加接受和理解辛勤工作的男女。有精力打破社会和种族障碍的男女，同时保持广泛的持续优异表现退休副海军上将安・朗多指出，认识到我们最杰出的校友们令人难以置信的服务和成就是对大学和所有服务者的鼓舞。Rondeau说：“作为一名领导者、作战人员和先驱者，能够正式表彰和引导摩尔副上将进入我们享有盛誉的NPS名人堂是一种荣誉。”。“展示那些在公共服务中达到最高水平并为我们的海军和社会做出重大贡献的个人，只能为我们所有敢于做伟大和卓越事情的服务人员制定标准。”“瓦德・摩尔是韧性和精神韧性的缩影，”卡特补充道他从一名应征入伍的水手变成了一名军官，成为第一个指挥宙斯盾巡洋舰的黑人，达到了海军中任何黑人都见过的最高级别，然后继续担任国防领域的高级管理人员。尽管如此，他仍然能够回馈他的社区，因为他的服务已经得到了改善即使如此，这对他来说也很重要。“除了他的NPS名人堂入职培训外，摩尔还于1999年进入阿肯色州布莱克霍夫学院，2003年获得萧伯纳杰出毕业生，2013年进入布法罗士兵博物馆霍夫学院。”摩尔说，“通过入职培训进入学校名人堂，这真是一次令人谦卑的经历。”。“多年来，成千上万的学生受益于他们在这里作为学生时所学到的教育、专业、文化、社会和环境技能。大多数学生可能以富有成效的方式，个人和专业地应用了他们所学的知识。因此，被选为不辜负e在NPS YouTube频道上观看欢迎摩尔进入大学名人堂的完整仪式。

column2: Rear Adm. H. W. Howard III relieved Rear Adm. Collin P. Green as Commander, Naval Special Warfare Command (NSWC) during a change of command ceremony.
column3:
NAVAL AMPHIBIOUS BASE CORONADO (NNS) C (Sep. 11, 2020) Rear Adm. H. W. Howard III relieved Rear Adm. Collin P. Green as Commander, Naval Special Warfare Command (NSWC) during a change of command ceremony at Naval Amphibious Base Coronado, Sept. 11, 2020.

U.S. Army General Richard D. Clarke, commander, United States Special Operations Command (USSOCOM) was the presiding officer.

“But on all days, today, September 11th, we all remember an event that changed many things for our country. And for our special operations forces, it changed our course, it changed many of our joint force individuals, and changed many families for years to come. And I would ask everyone to keep that foremost in your mind today, as we recognize the import of today's event,” said Clarke. “For 19 years, SOF has been the tip of the spear operating around the globe to protect our American people, our interest and our way of life. From the beginning the Navy SEALs and the entire NSW team has been an absolutely essential part of that effort. …The incredible ethos of teamwork and excellence established in the tradition of this command firmly holds true today.”

Green assumed command of NSWC in July 2018 and in his next assignment, he will serve as chief of staff, U.S. Special Operations Command.

Howard arrives as Commander, NSWC from his most recent assignment as Commander, U.S. Special Operations Command Central located at MacDill Air Force Base, Fla.

NSW Command is committed to its Sailors and the deliberate development of their tactical excellence, ethics, and leadership as the nation’s premiere maritime special operations force supporting the National Defense Strategy.
NSW is the maritime component of U.S. Special Operations Command, and its mission is to provide maritime special operations forces to conduct full-spectrum operations, unilaterally or with partners, to support national objectives.
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州科罗纳多
column10: 霍华德三世少将在换帅仪式上接替柯林・P・格林少将担任海军特种作战司令部司令。
column11: 海军两栖基地科罗纳多（NNS）C（2020年9月11日）海军两栖基地科罗纳多（2020年9月11日）换届仪式上，霍华德三世少将接替科林・P・格林少将担任海军特种作战司令部（NSWC）司令。美国特种作战司令部（USSOCOM）指挥官理查德・克拉克将军是主持会议的官员。“但在所有的日子里，今天，9月11日，我们都记得一个事件，它改变了我们国家的许多事情。对于我们的特种作战部队来说，它改变了我们的路线，它改变了我们的许多联合部队人员，并在未来数年中改变了许多家庭。我希望大家今天记住这一点，因为我们认识到，这一点他是今天活动的重要参与者，”克拉克说。“19年来，特种部队一直是保护我们的美国人民、我们的利益和我们的生活方式的长矛的尖端。从一开始，海军海豹突击队和整个新南威尔士州团队就是这一努力的绝对必要的一部分……在这一传统中建立的令人难以置信的团队精神和卓越精神。”今天，我们坚信这一点。”格林于2018年7月担任新南威尔士州特种作战司令部司令，在他的下一次任务中，他将担任美国特种作战司令部参谋长。霍华德从他最近的一次任务――位于佛罗里达州麦克迪尔空军基地的美国特种作战司令部中央司令部――上任，担任新南威尔士州特种作战司令部司令部司令。新南威尔士州司令部致力于其海员和delibe作为支持国防战略的全国首屈一指的海上特种作战部队，评估其战术卓越性、道德和领导力的发展。新南威尔士州是美国特种作战司令部的海上部门，其任务是提供海上特种作战部队，以开展全谱作战，unilatera说或与合作伙伴合作，支持国家目标。

column2: Vice Adm. Brown Holds All-Hands Call at Naval Base Coronado
column3:
Vice Adm. Brian B. Brown, Commander, Naval Information Forces (NAVIFOR) held an all-hands call for Sailors at Naval Base Coronado (NBC), March 5.

This visit marks the first time Brown convened such an event open to all San Diego area commands to speak about his increased role in the Information Warfare (IW) Community since assuming command of NAVIFOR in June 2018.

“IW is a warfighting discipline, a set of warfighting capabilities, and an enabler for all Navy mission areas,” said Brown. “It underpins every warfighting domain from sea to land, to air, to undersea, to cyber, to space. It is a complex network of human talent, machines, spectrum, and data that provides our Force with non-kinetic options, increases lethality of kinetic options, enables maneuver and distributed maritime operations, and delivers the home-field advantage at the away game.”

During the all-hands call, Brown presented on topics including IW integration into the fleet; manning, training and equipping personnel; the future of the IW community; impacts of the creation of the U.S. Space Force, and the expansion of IW Commander beyond Expeditionary Strike Groups to Amphibious Ready Groups.

“We’ve been charged with focusing our efforts on great power competition,” said Brown. “We went through many years of being the only superpower and now we find ourselves, over the last decade or so, with a rising China and rejuvenated Russia in a different kind of global competitive space than we had back in the 1980s. The ability to control information used to be much easier. Now we find ourselves in a time where information is the coin of the realm and how effectively we control information determines our ability to observe, orient, decide, and act faster than our competition. It's a much more cognitive space and it requires are different kind of fighting force.”

Brown also answered questions from members of the audience and presented outstanding Sailors and civilians with challenge coins, expressing gratitude for their hard work and dedication to their craft.

“It was great being able to ask a three-star admiral questions and receive honest answers on the spot,” said Information Systems Technician 2nd Class Jocelyn Rivas, a Sailor assigned to Naval Communications Training Center San Diego. “It wasn’t just officers and senior enlisted, it was a good mix of junior and senior Sailors. But my favorite part was seeing my peers being recognized on stage for their hard work.”

NAVIFOR is the Navy's IW Type Command under U.S. Fleet Forces Command, focused on generating agile and technically superior manned, trained, equipped, and certified combat-ready IW forces to ensure the US Navy will decisively deter, compete, and win.
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州科罗纳多
column10: 布朗副上将在科罗纳多海军基地召集全体人员
column11: 海军信息部队（NAVIFOR）指挥官布莱恩・布朗（Brian B.Brown）副上将于3月5日在科罗纳多海军基地（NBC）举行了一次全体船员的电话会议。这次访问标志着布朗首次召开这样一个向所有圣地亚哥地区司令部开放的活动，谈论他在信息战（IW）中日益重要的作用布朗说：“信息战是一门作战学科，是一套作战能力，是所有海军任务区的一个促成因素。”。“它支撑着从海上到陆地、空中、海底、网络到太空的每个作战领域。它是一个由人力、机器、频谱和数据组成的复杂网络，为我们的部队提供非机动选择，提高机动选择的杀伤力，实现机动和分布式海上作战，并提供本土战场优势。”在全掌通话中，布朗介绍了包括信息战融入舰队；人员配备、培训和装备；信息战社区的未来；美国太空部队的建立，以及信息战指挥官从远征打击小组扩大到两栖作战小组的影响。布朗说：“我们一直致力于大国竞争。”。“我们作为唯一的超级大国经历了许多年，现在我们发现，在过去十年左右的时间里，中国的崛起和俄罗斯的复兴与20世纪80年代不同。控制信息的能力过去要容易得多。现在我们发现自己处在一个信息不发达的时代他说：“这个领域的重要性以及我们控制信息的有效性决定了我们观察、定位、决策和行动的能力，比竞争对手快得多。这是一个认知空间，需要不同类型的战斗力。”布朗还回答了观众的提问，并向杰出的水手和平民赠送了挑战币，对他们的辛勤工作和献身精神表示感谢。“能够在现场向一位三星级海军上将提问并得到诚实的回答真是太好了。”信息系统技术员二等兵Jocelyn Rivas说，他是圣地亚哥海军通信训练中心的一名海员。“不仅仅是军官和高级士兵，它是初级和高级水手的良好组合。但我最喜欢的部分是看到我的同龄人因为他们的辛勤工作而在舞台上得到认可。”海军是美国舰队司令部下属的海军信息战型司令部，专注于培养灵活、技术卓越的有人、训练有素、装备精良的海军，以及经过认证的战备信息战部队，以确保美国海军将果断地遏制、竞争并获胜。

column2: Vice Adm. Robert Sharp Visits IWTC Virginia Beach Students and Staff
column3:
By Information Warfare Training Command Virginia Beach

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. C Vice Adm. Robert Sharp, director of the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) visited and spoke with staff and students at Information Warfare Training Command (IWTC) Virginia Beach, Oct. 18.

During his time at IWTC Virginia Beach, Sharp met with the Geospatial Intelligence (GEOINT) “C” school staff and discussed the successful kickoff of the new Intelligence Specialist (IS) 2025 course. 

The GEOINT “C” school provides Navy enlisted intelligence specialists with the knowledge and skills to perform at the apprentice level as geospatial interpreters and basic strike support fundamentals afloat and ashore under all conditions with limited supervision.

Intelligence Specialist 1st Class Kalil Negronrodriguez, the lead for GEOINT “C” school, provided Sharp with a breakdown of the IS 2025 curriculum, which began Oct. 7. Negronrodriguez also shared how the instructors are training the students to develop more critical thinking skills with a deeper understanding of the end product.

“Vice Adm. Sharp was extremely personable, he listened to what the junior enlisted at IWTC Virginia Beach had to say and even knew some of his junior enlisted Sailors by name,” shared said Intelligence Specialist 1st Class Garrett Speer, a GEOINT instructor IWTC Virginia Beach. “He spoke about his vision for the future of GEOINT, was very supportive of working with IWTC Virginia Beach GEOINT team to get our curriculum up to NGA standards, and to give new GEOINT analysts a solid foundation.”

Sharp was also able to meet with students from the Naval Intelligence Officer Basic Course (NIOBC). He discussed being one of the first officers to attend the Intelligence Officer Basic Course at Layton Hall on Dam Neck Annex, Virginia Beach, and provided insight into the decisions that drove his career choices.  

“One out of three times in my career people said ‘do not choose that job or you will ruin your career,’” Sharp said.  “I tell you this; if there is something you are passionate about, go do it and do it well!  What is needed in our community changes often.”

Sharp also took questions from the students on a range of topics that included where artificial intelligence will take us, 3D printing capabilities and new capabilities such as Global Command and Control System (GCCS) 1.

He also provided advice. 

“In our profession, we get into senior situations quickly and you are growing the skill sets for those situations. Our warfighting skill set is making complex situations simple with intelligence support to operations and providing the right level of information,” shared Sharp.

“It was exiting to hear how our community anticipates the evolution of the intelligence officer in a time where our relationship with technology is increasingly symbiotic,” said Lt. Lydia Miller, a NIOBC student. 

Sharp closed by saying, “I wish you luck in dealing with the challenges ahead.  When I retire from NGA in 12 years [jokingly], I will be happy to know you are standing the watch.  I wish you continued happiness and success.”

“My personal thanks to Vice Adm. Sharp for taking time out of his busy schedule to share his perspective with our staff and students,” said Capt. Richard Bosworth, commanding officer, IWTC Virginia Beach. “We genuinely appreciate his interest in directly observing and discussing our training of the next generation.”

IWTC Virginia Beach, located in Dam Neck Annex, currently offers 65 courses of instruction in information technology, cryptology, and intelligence with an instructor and support staff of 280 military, civilian, and contractors who train over 6,500 students every year. It is one of four schoolhouses for Center for Information Warfare Training (CIWT) and oversees learning sites at Jacksonville and Mayport, Florida; Kings Bay, Georgia; and Groton, Connecticut to continue aligning IW community training.

With four schoolhouse commands, two detachments, and training sites throughout the United States and Japan, CIWT is recognized as Naval Education and Training Command’s top learning center for the past three years. Training over 20,000 students every year, CIWT delivers trained information warfare professionals to the Navy and joint services. CIWT also offers more than 200 courses for cryptologic technicians, intelligence specialists, information systems technicians, electronics technicians, and officers in the information warfare community.

For more news from Center for Information Warfare Training domain, visit www.navy.mil/local/cid/, https://www.public.navy.mil/netc/centers/ciwt/, www.facebook.com/NavyCIWT, or www.twitter.com/NavyCIWT.
column9: 弗吉尼亚海滩，弗吉尼亚州，美国
column10: 罗伯特・夏普副上将访问IWTC弗吉尼亚海滩学生和员工
column11: 弗吉尼亚州弗吉尼亚海滩信息战训练司令部-弗吉尼亚海滩――10月18日，美国国家地理空间情报局（NGA）局长罗伯特・夏普副上将访问了弗吉尼亚海滩信息战训练司令部（IWTC）。在IWTC弗吉尼亚海滩期间，夏普会见了地理空间情报（GEOINT）“C”学校的工作人员，并讨论了新的情报专家（IS）2025课程的成功启动。GEOINT“C”学校为海军征募的情报专家提供知识和技能，使他们能够在有限的监督下，在所有条件下，在海上和岸上担任地理空间译员和基本的打击支援基础。情报专家一级卡利勒・内格罗・罗德里格斯，GEOINT“C”的领导者学校提供了从10月7日开始的IS 2025课程的细目。Negronrodriguez还分享了教员如何培训学生，使他们在更深入地理解最终产品的基础上发展更具批判性的思维技能。“夏普副上将非常有风度，他倾听了弗吉尼亚海滩国际水上运动中心的少年士兵们所说的话，甚至知道一些少年士兵的名字。”共享情报专家一等兵加雷特・斯佩尔（Garrett Speer），GEOINT讲师IWTC弗吉尼亚海滩（IWTC Virginia Beach）。“他谈到了他对GeInt未来的愿景，非常支持与IWTC弗吉尼亚海滩GeIGET团队合作，使我们的课程达到NGA标准，并给新GeNIT分析师一个坚实的基础。”Sharp还能够与海军情报官员基础课程（NIOBC）的学生见面。他讨论了成为首批参加弗吉尼亚海滩Dam Neck附件Layton Hall情报官基础课程的警官之一的问题，并深入了解了推动他职业选择的决策。夏普说：“在我的职业生涯中，有三分之一的人说‘不要选择那份工作，否则你会毁了你的职业生涯’。”。“我告诉你，如果你对某件事充满激情，那就去做，把它做好！我们社区需要的东西经常变化。”夏普还回答了学生们提出的一系列问题，包括人工智能将带我们去哪里，3D打印功能和新功能，如全球指挥控制系统（GCCS）1。他还提供了建议。“在我们的职业中，我们很快就进入了高级情境，而你正在为这些情境培养技能。我们的作战技能通过对作战的情报支持和提供适当级别的信息，使复杂情境变得简单，”Sharp说。NIOBC学生莉迪亚・米勒（Lydia Miller）中尉说：“在我们与技术的关系日益共生的时代，听到我们的社区如何预测情报官员的发展，我感到非常激动。”夏普最后说：“我希望你在应对未来的挑战时好运。当我在12年后从NGA退休时（开玩笑地说）。”“我个人感谢夏普副上将在百忙之中抽出时间，与我们的员工和学生分享他的观点，”弗吉尼亚海滩国际水族馆指挥官理查德・博斯沃思上尉说。“我们真诚地感谢他对直接观察和讨论我们对下一代的培训的兴趣。”IWTC Virginia Beach位于Dam Neck附件，目前提供65门信息技术、密码学和情报课程，拥有280名军事、民用和承包商的教员和支持人员，每年培训6500多名学生。它是信息战训练中心（CIWT）的四所校舍之一并监督佛罗里达州杰克逊维尔和梅波特、佐治亚州国王湾和康涅狄格州格罗顿的学习基地，以继续协调信息战社区培训。CIWT在美国和日本拥有四个校舍司令部、两个分遣队和培训基地，被公认为海军教育和培训司令部的最佳学习中心过去三年，CIWT每年培训20000多名学生，为海军和联合军种提供训练有素的信息战专业人员。CIWT还为密码技术人员、情报专家、信息系统技术人员、电子技术人员和信息战社区官员提供200多个课程nity.有关信息战训练领域中心的更多新闻，请访问www.navy.mil/local/cid/，https://www.public.navy.mil/netc/centers/ciwt/，www.facebook.com/NavyCIWT，或www.twitter.com/NavyCIWT。

column2: Vice Adm. Matthew Kohler Engages With IWTC Virginia Beach Students and Staff
column3:
By Lt. Tiya DeGhetto, Information Warfare Training Command Virginia Beach

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. C Vice Adm. Matthew Kohler, deputy chief of naval operations for information warfare (OPNAV N2N6) and director of naval intelligence, visited Information Warfare Training Command (IWTC) Virginia Beach to speak with 24 Information Warfare Officer Intermediate Course (IWOIC) students, Aug. 5.

The IWOIC provides the concepts, knowledge, and skills necessary for information warfare (IW) officers to succeed in O4 milestone tours. Training focuses on the integrated application of IW at the operational and tactical levels of war. Senior officers provide mentorship on leadership and ethics.  

During this two week course, students are also provided senior-level instruction of the IW strategy and way ahead, followed by a detailed view of programmatics, state of threat, global force management, manpower and budget programs, video teleconferences with several IW flag officers and in-depth exposure to priorities and challenges affecting each of the individual communities.

"The purpose of this course is for you to see where you are going,” shared Kohler. “Have a mentor, reach out to leaders, and ask questions. Every tour is an opportunity.”

Kohler discussed the evolution of the IW community, from when it began in 2009 to how it will be celebrating its 10-year anniversary in October.  He also discussed the IW community’s footprint, and how it has grown to be over 12,000 personnel afloat.

The discussion then led to where the IW community was going.  

“The information warfare community is taking advantage of aligning ourselves with the expeditionary strike groups, like we did with the carrier strike groups,” added Kohler.  

He also recommended reading the following strategies:  Maritime Superiority 1.0 and 2.0, and the IW community s implementation plan, “Information Warfare in the Era of Great Power Competition.”

During the class discussion, he also emphasized the importance of cyber warfare as an operational arm of IW, and how the IW pin identifies IW personnel in a professional way.

“Vice Adm. Kohler’s discussion was an excellent ‘God’s eye view’ into the highest reaches of the information warfare mission and its key role in the greater strategic environment,” said Lt. Cmdr. Michael Nataro, an IWOIC student. "It’s an environment that is constantly changing, and thereby forces us to constantly adapt in order for us to maintain the necessary advantage.” 

Throughout the discussion, Kohler also answered multiple questions from students such as:
-	Reserve enlisted IW pin requirements.
-	The proposed change from unrestricted line officer to line officer, and how it could affect promotion.
-	Is there a plan to develop a path for the IW community in the Reserve Officer Training Corps?
-	Are other services aligning to the Navy’s IW community?
-	What are the greatest challenges for the IW community?

“My personal thanks to Vice Adm. Kohler for taking the time out of his busy schedule to speak with our IWOIC students,” said Lt. Cmdr. Brielle Adamovich, executive officer of IWTC Virginia Beach. "Exposure to his leadership and mentorship is a great opportunity for the next generation of information warfare leaders.” 

IWTC Virginia Beach, located in Dam Neck Annex, currently offers 65 courses of instruction in information technology, cryptology, and intelligence with an instructor and support staff of 280 military, civilian, and contractors who train over 6,500 students every year.  It is one of four schoolhouses for Center for Information Warfare Training (CIWT) and oversees learning sites at Jacksonville and Mayport, Florida; Kings Bay, Georgia; and Groton, Connecticut to continue aligning IW community training.

With four schoolhouse commands, two detachments, and training sites throughout the United States and Japan, CIWT is recognized as Naval Education and Training Command’s top learning center for the past three years. Training over 21,000 students every year, CIWT delivers trained information warfare professionals to the Navy and joint services. CIWT also offers more than 200 courses for cryptologic technicians, intelligence specialists, information systems technicians, electronics technicians, and officers in the information warfare community.

For more news from Center for Information Warfare Training domain, visit www.navy.mil/local/cid/, www.netc.navy.mil/centers/ciwt/, www.facebook.com/NavyCIWT, or www.twitter.com/NavyCIWT.
column9: 弗吉尼亚海滩，弗吉尼亚州，美国
column10: 马修・科勒（Matthew Kohler）副上将与IWTC弗吉尼亚海滩的学生和员工进行了接触
column11: 弗吉尼亚州弗吉尼亚海滩信息战训练司令部Tiya DeGhetto中尉C海军信息战作战副司令（OPNAV N2N6）和海军情报总监Matthew Kohler副上将访问了信息战训练司令部（IWTC）8月5日，弗吉尼亚海滩将与24名信息战军官中级课程（IWOIC）学生进行对话。IWOIC提供信息战（IW）军官在O4里程碑之旅中取得成功所需的概念、知识和技能。训练的重点是信息战在作战和战术层面的综合应用。高级官员提供领导力和道德方面的指导。在这两周的课程中，学生们还将获得信息战战略和未来道路的高级指导，随后将详细了解计划、威胁状态、全球部队管理、人力和预算计划，与几个IW旗舰官员进行视频电话会议，深入了解影响每个社区的优先事项和挑战。“本课程的目的是让您了解自己的发展方向，”Kohler分享道。“请一位导师，联系领导，并提出问题。每一次参观都是一次机会。”科勒讨论了信息战社区的演变，从2009年开始到10月将如何庆祝其成立10周年。他还讨论了信息战社区的足迹，以及它是如何发展到超过12000名员工。然后讨论了信息战社区的发展方向。科勒补充道：“信息战界正在利用与远征打击集团结盟的优势，就像我们与航母打击集团结盟一样。”他还建议阅读以下战略：海上优势1.0和2.0，以及信息战界的实施计划，“大国竞争时代的信息战。”在课堂讨论中，他还强调了网络战作为信息战作战部门的重要性，以及信息战pin如何以专业方式识别信息战人员。“科勒副上将的讨论是对信息战任务的最高领域及其在更大战略环境中的关键作用的极好的‘上帝视角’，”IWOIC学生迈克尔・纳塔罗中校说这是一个不断变化的环境，因此迫使我们不断适应，以保持必要的优势。”在整个讨论过程中，科勒还回答了学生们提出的多个问题，如：-预备役士兵信息战pin要求。-拟议的从无限制的一线军官到一线军官的变更，以及这将如何影响晋升。-是否有计划为预备役军官训练团的信息战社区开发一条道路？-是否有其他服务与海军的信息战社区保持一致？-信息战社区面临的最大挑战是什么？“我个人感谢科勒副上将在百忙之中抽出时间与我们的信息战社区学生交谈，”弗吉尼亚海滩信息战社区执行官Brielle Adamovich中校说。“对下一代信息战领导人来说，接触他的领导和导师是一个很好的机会。”IWTC Virginia Beach位于Dam Neck附件，目前提供65门信息技术、密码学和情报课程，拥有280名军事、民用和承包商的教员和支持人员，每年培训6500多名学生。它是信息战训练中心的四所校舍之一（CIWT）并监督佛罗里达州杰克逊维尔和梅波特、佐治亚州国王湾和康涅狄格州格罗顿的学习基地，以继续协调信息战社区培训。CIWT在美国和日本拥有四个校舍司令部、两个分遣队和培训基地，被公认为海军教育和培训司令部的最佳学习中心在过去的三年中，CIWT每年培训超过21000名学生，为海军和联合军种提供训练有素的信息战专业人员。CIWT还为密码技术人员、情报专家、信息系统技术人员、电子技术人员和信息战社区官员提供200多个课程nity。有关信息战训练领域中心的更多新闻，请访问www.navy.mil/local/cid/、www.netc.navy.mil/centers/ciwt/、www.facebook.com/NavyCIWT或www.twitter.com/NavyCIWT。

column2: NSSC Supply Officer Receives 2020 Vice Adm. Robert F. Batchelder Award
column3:
The Navy League announced the selectees of the 2020 Vice Adm. Robert F. Batchelder Award, May 20.

Lt. Naomi Green was selected as one of the four recipients for the work she accomplished as the supply officer while stationed aboard the Ohio-class guided-missile submarine USS Florida (SSGN 728) (Blue) homeported at Naval Submarine Base Kings Bay, Georgia. 

Green, who is currently assigned to Naval Submarine Support Center Kings Bay, said she is humbled by her selection.

“There are so many great supply officers, doing amazing jobs supporting our warfighters and ensuring we are ready for sea who are going unrecognized,” said Green. “I am grateful to be surrounded by such outstanding officers and am deeply humbled at the opportunity to be honored alongside them.”

The award is presented annually by the Navy League to Supply Corps officers who made significant contributions to operating forces’ supply readiness and positively impacted the Supply Corps.

Green, a Sacramento, Calif. native, says she joined the Navy nearly 22 years ago to do something meaningful with her life.

“I honestly feel like joining the Navy was the best decision I ever made,” said Green.

Green said she has received great mentorship and guidance throughout her naval career and credits her motivation to the people she works with. 

“Every day I strive to support those that rely on me, not to let them down,” she said. “Each morning I wake up and I get the opportunity to do it all over again.  It’s a very gratifying experience.”

Her advice to others who are working toward their professional goals is to keep pushing and stay positive.

“Try and recognize that tough jobs prepare you for the tougher jobs you will have in the future,” said Green. “Seek out relationships with mentors that can provide you guidance and career advice and be generous enough to pass it on to those around you.” 

The award honors the memory of Vice Adm. Batchelder, who served on active duty from 1917-1957 and retired as Inspector General at the Bureau of Supplies and Accounts, now the Naval Supply Systems Command.

Naval Submarine Base Kings Bay is homeport to all East Coast Ohio-class submarines, to include six ballistic-missile and two guided-missile submarines.

For more news from Commander, Submarine Group 10, visit www.sublant.usff.navy.mil/CSG10/ or follow us on www.facebook.com/submarinegroupten/.
column9: 美国佐治亚州
column10: NSSC供应官获得2020年罗伯特・F・巴奇尔副上将奖
column11: 海军联盟于5月20日宣布了2020年罗伯特・F・巴契尔副上将奖的获选者。内奥米・格林（Naomi Green）被选为四位获奖者之一，她在担任补给官期间完成了工作，当时她驻扎在俄亥俄级导弹潜艇美国佛罗里达号（SSGN 728）（蓝色）上，该潜艇位于佐治亚州国王湾海军潜艇基地。格林目前被分配到海军潜艇支援中心国王湾，她说，她对自己的选择感到谦卑。“有这么多优秀的补给官，他们在支持我们的战士方面做了令人惊叹的工作，并确保我们准备好出海，而这些人将不被认可，”格林说。“我很高兴能被如此优秀的军官包围，并为有机会与他们并肩作战而深感谦卑。”该奖项每年由海军联盟颁发给为作战部队的补给准备做出重大贡献并对补给部队产生积极影响的补给部队军官。萨克拉门托的格林，格林说，她在将近22年前加入海军是为了做一些有意义的事情。“我真的觉得加入海军是我做过的最好的决定。”格林说，她在整个海军生涯中得到了很好的指导和指导，并把她的动力归功于与她一起工作的人。她说：“我每天都努力支持那些依赖我的人，而不是让他们失望。”。“每天早上醒来，我都有机会重来一次。这是一次非常令人欣慰的经历。”她对其他正在努力实现职业目标的人的建议是继续努力，保持积极。“努力认识到艰难的工作会让你为将来更艰难的工作做好准备，”格林说。“寻求能为你提供指导和职业建议的导师的关系，并慷慨地将其传递给你周围的人。”该奖项是为了纪念Batcheld副上将，他在1917-1957年间服役，退休后担任物资和会计局监察长，现在是海军补给系统司令部。国王湾海军潜艇基地是所有东海岸俄亥俄级潜艇的母港，包括六艘弹道导弹潜艇和两艘导弹潜艇。有关潜艇组10指挥官的更多消息，请访问www.sublant.usff.navy.mil/CSG10/或访问www.facebook.com/submarinegroupten/。

column2: 19 SFS Airman finished ADM training as first female in 5 years
column3:
The coolness of the metal spread over the left side of her face as she gently laid her cheek on the buttstock of an M24 sniper weapon system.
 
“Send it!” The command was given. 

She emptied the hot air from her lungs, peered through the sweat dripping from her brow down the rifle’s scope as she slowly squeezed the trigger.

BOOM! 

The only sounds able to pierce through the foam barriers wedged in her ears were the commands given and the explosions of weapons being fired in the distance. The blast from the barrel jolted her back which caught her off guard, but she quickly regained her focus and waited on the next command from her spotter.

Senior Airman Jennifer Gamez, 19th Security Forces Squadron installation entry controller, qualified as the first female advanced designated marksman in approximately five years. 

ADM training was nowhere in the scope of opportunities for Gamez’s when she considered joining the Air Force. She worked as a civilian in the Lackland Air Force Base dining facility in San Antonio, Texas. After watching trainees day-in-and-day-out go through Basic Military Training, Gamez decided to join the Air Force.

From the moment she made that decision, Gamez began her journey of resilience.

She initially had a hard time finding a recruiter, but she didn’t give up. Once she found one, she struggled to pass the Armed Service Vocational Aptitude Battery test. None of those challenges discouraged her. She was determined to join the less than one percent of Americans who protect their country through military service. Eventually, she passed, and her new life to blasted into motion.

Gamez was put into the security forces career field, and although initially she was not too excited about it, she grew to enjoy her job. 

One day while Gamez was out working, she got a call to leave her post and come back to the squadron. Butterflies filled her stomach as she came to her flight chief’s office worried she had made a mistake on the job, unaware she was about to be chosen for a highly sought-after opportunity. 

“I was scared I wasn’t going to do well,” Gamez said. “One of my biggest fears is failure. My squadron was sending me and relying on me to pass, and I didn’t want to disappoint them.”

Despite her uncertainty, Gamez traveled to Fort Bliss, Texas, with another security forces member to complete training. 

ADM training qualifications rely heavily on individuals working in teams of a shooter and a spotter. To her surprise, Gamez’s journey of resilience continued when working as a team didn’t come as easy as she’d imagined. Being disconnected greatly affected the probability of qualifying, so she knew they’d have to dig deep and work harder.

“Your qualification is in your spotter’s hands, so they can fail you,” Gamez said. “If you don’t pass, you’re going home.”

Right before her first qualification, Gamez and her comrade came together, and like a well assembled weapon, their execution was accurate and unstoppable.

From that moment forward, Gamez and her partner went above and beyond to pass the course. The trust they developed for one another helped Gamez achieve the title “Best Spotter” and her comrade “Best Shot.”

“It’s awesome how we got better at being able to trust each other,” Gamez said. “Trust is everything when it comes to qualifying at ADM training.”

Gamez and her comrade completed their training and returned to the 19th SFS as advanced designated marksmen. Gamez overcame her fear of failure and realized she could do more than she ever thought she could. 

“They [19th SFS] chose me for a reason,” Gamez said. “They see something in me I don’t see in myself.”

Gamez continued to work in the squadron like normal until another individual came to her and congratulated her on becoming the first woman in about five years to complete ADM training. Shocked with disbelief, Gamez double checked the information, and sure enough, she was notified of this incredible accomplishment. 

Part of Gamez’s shock was the fact that no other female had finished the training she just completed in such a long time. 

She hopes that other females realize that if she can break through her fear of failure and complete ADM training, other women can too. 
“If I can do it, anybody can do it,” she said. “I passed ADM and know they can do it too.”

Gamez’s path of resilience gave her the ammunition it took to succeed. Every fear and uncertainty that crossed her path was one more challenge Gamez set her mind to overcome. 

“Whenever my mind is set on something, I’m stuck on it,” Gamez said. “I’m going to finish it.”

And she did.
column6: LITTLE ROCK AIR FORCE BASE, AR, UNITED STATES
column9: 美国阿肯色州小石城空军基地
column10: 19名SFS飞行员作为5年来第一名女性完成了ADM培训
column11: 当她将脸颊轻轻地放在M24狙击武器系统的枪托上时，金属的冷气弥漫在她的左脸上。“快来！”命令下达。她把肺里的热空气排了出去，透过额头上滴下的汗水顺着步枪的瞄准镜往下看，慢慢地扣动扳机。砰！唯一能穿透她耳朵里的泡沫屏障的声音是发出的命令和远处发射的武器爆炸声。来自枪管的爆炸震得她背部发抖，这让她措手不及，但她很快恢复了注意力，等待着侦察员的下一个命令。第19安全部队中队安装入口控制员高级飞行员詹妮弗・加梅兹（Jennifer Gamez）获得了约五年来第一位女性高级指定射手的资格。当Gamez考虑加入空军时，ADM培训不在其机会范围之内。她在德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥市的拉克兰空军基地用餐设施中担任文职人员。在看着学员们日复一日地接受基本军事训练后，Gamez决定加入空军。从她做出这一决定的那一刻起，Gamez开始了她的恢复之旅。她最初很难找到一名招聘人员，但她没有放弃。一旦她找到了一个，她就努力通过武装部队职业能力倾向测试。所有这些挑战都没有使她气馁。她决心加入不到百分之一的通过服兵役保护国家的美国人的行列。最终，她通过了考试，她的新生活开始了。Gamez进入了安全部队的职业领域，虽然起初她对此不太兴奋，但她渐渐喜欢上了自己的工作。一天，当Gamez外出工作时，她接到一个电话，要求离开岗位回到中队。当她来到飞行主管办公室时，心里七上八下，担心自己在工作中犯了一个错误，因为她不知道自己即将被选中接受一个备受追捧的机会。Gamez说：“我害怕自己做得不好。”。“我最大的恐惧之一是失败。我的中队派我去并依靠我通过，我不想让他们失望。”尽管她不确定，Gamez还是和另一名安全部队成员前往德克萨斯州的Fort Bliss完成训练。ADM培训资格在很大程度上依赖于射手和观察员团队中的个人。令她惊讶的是，当作为一个团队工作并不像她想象的那么容易时，Gamez的恢复之旅仍在继续。断开连接极大地影响了排位赛的可能性，因此她知道他们必须深入挖掘，更加努力地工作。“你的资格掌握在你的观察员手中，因此他们可能会让你不及格，”Gamez说。“如果你不及格，你就要回家了。”就在她第一次获得资格之前，Gamez和她的同伴走到了一起，就像一把组装得很好的武器，他们的执行是准确的、不可阻挡的。从那一刻起，Gamez和她的搭档就不断地通过课程。他们相互之间建立的信任帮助Gamez获得了“最佳观察者”的称号和“最佳射击”的战友。Gamez说：“我们如何能够更好地相互信任，真是太棒了。”。“在ADM训练的资格认证中，信任是一切。”Gamez和她的同伴完成了训练，并作为高级指定射手回到了第19届SFS。Gamez克服了对失败的恐惧，意识到她可以做的比她想象的更多。“他们选择我是有原因的，”Gamez说。“他们在我身上看到了一些我在自己身上看不到的东西。”Gamez继续像往常一样在中队工作，直到另一个人来找她，祝贺她成为大约五年来第一位完成ADM培训的女性。Gamez震惊于难以置信，再次检查了信息，果然，她被告知了这一不可思议的成就。Gamez感到震惊的一部分是，没有其他女性完成了她刚刚完成的训练，这是她在这么长时间内完成的。她希望其他女性意识到，如果她能突破对失败的恐惧，完成ADM训练，其他女性也能做到。“如果我能做到，任何人都能做到，”她说。“我通过了ADM，我知道他们也能做到。”Gamez的恢复力给了她成功所需的弹药。她遇到的每一个恐惧和不确定性都是加梅兹决心克服的又一个挑战。“每当我下定决心做某件事时，我就会被困在上面，”Gamez说。“我要完成它。”她做到了。

column2: Rear Adm. Kathleen Creighton Visits and Shares Wisdom with IWTC Virginia Beach
column3:
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. C The deputy commander for the Joint Force Headquarters C Department of Defense Information Networks (JFHQ-DODIN) visited Information Warfare Training Command (IWTC) Virginia Beach to speak with staff and students, June 25.

In her opening remarks Rear Adm. Kathleen Creighton said, “It’s a pleasure to have the opportunity to talk to future leaders in our Navy.”

Creighton expanded upon her experience at JFHQ-DODIN, how DODIN encompasses all networks of every branch of the military, and the requirements to be a Joint Staff officer. She also emphasized the importance of defensive cyberspace as a prime opportunity for career growth in the Navy and for Joint assignments. 

She answered students’ questions ranging from how to prepare and be successful in the information warfare community, the future of cyber warfare, information professional career path, future of the warrant officer community and expectations within the information warfare community.

On the discussion of how to prepare and be successful in the information warfare community,  Creighton said, "Think about your network of people you trust, mentors or those you have served with.  Be willing to serve around the globe in tough jobs. I would suggest taking the path that creates the most balance.  Everyone’s path to success is different.”

Additionally, Creighton conveyed a few career “Pearls” that she has learned during her career:

1)	Career success is a team sport.
2)	Make informed career decisions and then own the consequences.
3)	Be where the decisions get made.
4)	Performance in milestone and command billets is what gets you promoted.
5)	Take care of yourself and your family.
6)	You’re a “1 percenter.

To conclude, Creighton said, "Own your decisions and accept the consequences that come with them. Take care of yourself and your family; no one will do that for you.”

In discussion with the staff, Cmdr. Andrew Boyden, commanding officer for IWTC Virginia Beach, provided Creighton an overview of the command’s mission, vision, tenets, and course curriculum. 

“My personal thanks to Rear Adm. Creighton for taking the time out of her busy schedule to speak with our staff and students," said Boyden. "Exposure to her leadership and mentorship is a great opportunity for the next generation of leaders.
