IWTC Virginia Beach currently offers 65 courses of instruction in information technology, cryptology, and intelligence with an instructor and support staff of 280 military, civilian, and contract members who train over 6,400 students every year at five training sites in the Hampton Roads area.  It is one of four school houses for Center for Information Warfare Training and also oversees learning sites at Jacksonville and Mayport, Florida; Kings Bay, Georgia; and Groton, Connecticut to continue aligning IW community training. 

JFHQ-DODIN is a component-command of U.S. Cyber Command and has the global command and control (C2) mission for DODIN operations and Defensive Cyberspace Operations Internal Defensive Measures. This involves proactively defending the DODIN from threats and intrusions through C2 over all DoD components including the 10 combatant commands, 5 Service Cyber Components (including the U.S. Coast Guard), and 28 Agencies & Fields Activities. 

For more news from Center for Information Warfare Training enterprise, visit http://www.navy.mil/local/cid/, http://www.netc.navy.mil/centers/ciwt/, http://www.facebook.com/NavyCIWT, or http://www.twitter.com/NavyCIWT.
column9: 弗吉尼亚海滩，弗吉尼亚州，美国
column10: 凯萨琳・克雷顿少将访问IWTC弗吉尼亚海滩并与之分享智慧
column11: 弗吉尼亚州弗吉尼亚海滩――6月25日，国防部信息网络联合部队总部（JFHQ-DODIN）副指挥官访问了弗吉尼亚海滩信息战训练司令部（IWTC），与教职员工和学生交谈。凯萨琳・克雷顿少将在开幕词中说，“很高兴有机会与我们海军未来的领导人交谈。”Creighton在JFHQ-DODIN的工作经验、DODIN如何涵盖军队各个分支的所有网络以及成为联合参谋的要求等方面进行了扩展。她还强调了防御性网络空间作为海军职业发展和联合任务的主要机会的重要性。她回答了学生们的问题从如何在信息战社区做好准备并取得成功、网络战的未来、信息职业生涯道路、准尉社区的未来以及信息战社区内的期望出发。关于如何在信息战社区做好准备并取得成功的讨论，Creighton他说：“想想你信任的人、导师或共事过的人的关系网。愿意在艰难的工作中为全球服务。我建议你走一条能创造最大平衡的道路。每个人的成功之路都是不同的。”此外，克雷顿还传达了一些职业“珍珠”她在职业生涯中学到的东西：1）职业成功是一项团队运动。2）做出明智的职业决策，然后承担后果。3）在做出决策的地方。4）在里程碑和指挥账单上的表现是你升职的原因。5）照顾好自己和家人。6）你是“百分之一的人。总之，克里顿说，”承认你的决定并接受随之而来的后果。照顾好你自己和你的家人，没有人会为你这样做。”在与员工讨论时，IWTC弗吉尼亚海滩指挥官安德鲁・博伊登中校向克雷顿概述了司令部的使命、愿景、宗旨和课程设置。博伊登说：“我个人感谢克雷顿少将在百忙之中抽出时间与我们的员工和学生交谈。”对下一代领导人来说，接触到她的领导和导师是一个很好的机会。IWTC弗吉尼亚海滩目前提供65门信息技术、密码学和情报方面的教学课程，有280名军事、民事和合同成员的教员和支持人员，每年在f位于汉普顿路地区的ive训练基地。它是信息战训练中心的四所校舍之一，同时监督位于佛罗里达州杰克逊维尔和梅波特、乔治亚州国王湾和康涅狄格州格罗顿的学习基地，以继续协调信息战社区训练。JFHQ-DODIN是美国网络司令部的一个组成司令部，拥有DODIN作战和防御性网络空间作战的全球指挥与控制（C2）任务内部防御措施。这包括通过国防部所有组成部分，包括10个作战司令部、5个军种网络组成部分（包括美国海岸警卫队），通过C2主动防御DODIN免受威胁和入侵，以及28个机构和现场活动。有关信息战训练企业中心的更多新闻，请访问http://www.navy.mil/local/cid/, http://www.netc.navy.mil/centers/ciwt/, http://www.facebook.com/NavyCIWT或http://www.twitter.com/NavyCIWT.

column2: Vice Chief of Naval Operations Adm. Bill Moran visits SSC Atlantic
column3:
CHARLESTON, S.C. C Adm. Bill Moran, Vice Chief of Naval Operations (VCNO), visited Space and Naval Warfare Systems Center (SSC) Atlantic Nov. 9 to see the center’s capabilities and meet its workforce.

After several morning briefs, including an overview by SSC Atlantic Commanding Officer Capt. Scott Heller and Executive Director Chris Miller, Moran held an all hands call for the entire SSC Atlantic team. The admiral began by noting that when he graduated from the Naval Academy in 1981, the Navy had a goal of 600 ships, and neared that goal with 594 ships, with roughly 95 of them forward deployed all around the world. Today’s Navy has 276 ships and still has roughly 95 of them deployed all around the world.

“Today, we have the ability to know where the adversaries are, what they are thinking and what they are preparing to do. Our ability to do that is wrapped up in what you are doing here at SSC Atlantic with information systems that let us observe areas of concern, orient ourselves to fight, provide information to strike groups and make decisions rapidly so we can act before the adversary,” Moran said.

“The secret sauce is not the ships, it’s the people who deliver these capabilities efficiently and effectively,” Moran said. “What you are doing to design, develop, deliver and sustain the Information Warfare solutions helps us get the right weapons systems to the right place at the right time,” he added. “It’s like the blood running through the arteries of our Navy.

“What you do is incredibly important,” the admiral told hundreds of employees assembled in the SSC Atlantic conference center and more watching via VTC. “Technology is moving so fast in ISR, networks and cyber. You are now required to move faster than ever. You are innovating and thinking at a fast pace and partnering with the right people in the commercial sector to deliver the capabilities we need,” Moran added.

“I want it faster!” is the refrain from warfighters that is being heard at all levels of the Department of Defense, and the Navy is leading across the joint community in speed to capability, the admiral said. “You are essential to that mission, and I’m proud of what you are doing here,” he said. “There is no better service than service to one’s country.”

Following the all hands call, Moran toured the Common Submarine Radio Room (CSRR) where SSC Atlantic teams procure, design and test communications systems that are common across all submarine classes and enhance submarine platform mission effectiveness while reducing acquisition and life-cycle costs. The admiral then saw the Multipurpose Reconfigurable Training System, a PC-based, network controlled system with single-touch and multi-touch liquid crystal displays that simulate the exact equipment submariners use onboard the boat. It was developed at SSC Atlantic to train Sailors to use CSRR components. 

Accompanying the admiral during the Charleston visit were SPAWARSYSCOM Commander Rear Adm. Christian 'Boris' Becker, Program Executive Officer for Command, Control, Communications, Computers and Intelligence (PEO C4I) Rear Adm. Carl P. Chebi, and Space Systems; and John Pope, executive director, PEO C4I and a former commanding officer of SSC Atlantic.  During morning briefs the VCNO learned about SSC Atlantic’s human capital strategy and Technical Growth Areas that support current and future fleet capabilities.  In addition, Becker and Chebi briefed Moran on the SPAWAR Strategic Vision. 

During a working lunch, Moran learned about several successful SSC Atlantic programs that address the Chief of Naval Operations goals, including model-based systems engineering, REDHAWK and Cryptologic Carry On Capability.  

SSC Atlantic provides systems engineering and acquisition to deliver Information Warfare capabilities to the Naval, Joint and National Warfighter through the acquisition, development, integration, production, test, deployment, and sustainment of interoperable Command, Control, Communication, Computers, Intelligence, Surveillance, Reconnaissance (C4ISR), Cyber and Information Technology (IT) capabilities. For more information visit http://www.public.navy.mil/spawar/Atlantic.
column9: 查尔斯顿，SC，美国
column10: 海军作战部副部长比尔・莫兰上将访问SSC大西洋
column11: 南卡罗来纳州查尔斯顿――海军作战部（VCNO）副部长比尔・莫兰上将于11月9日访问了大西洋空间与海战系统中心（SSC），了解该中心的能力并与工作人员会面。在几个上午的简报后，包括SSC大西洋指挥官斯科特・海勒上尉和执行主任克里斯・米勒的概述，莫兰召集了整个SSC大西洋小组的全体成员。这位海军上将首先指出，1981年他从海军学院毕业时，海军的目标是拥有600艘军舰，接近这一目标的有594艘军舰，其中大约95艘部署在世界各地。今天的海军拥有276艘军舰，其中大约95艘部署在世界各地。“今天，我们有能力知道对手在哪里，他们在想什么，他们准备做什么。我们有能力做到这一点，这取决于你们在SSC大西洋公司所做的工作，我们有信息系统，让我们观察关注的领域，确定自己的作战方向，向打击小组提供信息，并做出决策莫兰说：“我们能迅速地在敌人面前采取行动，关键不在于船只，而在于人们能高效地提供这些能力。”。“你们在设计、开发、交付和维持信息战解决方案方面所做的工作有助于我们在正确的时间将正确的武器系统运到正确的地点，”他补充道。“这就像血液流过我们海军的动脉。“你们所做的事极其重要。”海军上将告诉数百名员工聚集在SSC大西洋会议中心，更多的人通过VTC观看。“技术在ISR、网络和网络领域发展得如此之快。你现在需要比以往任何时候都更快。你正在以更快的速度进行创新和思考，并与商业部门的合适人员合作，以提供我们所需要的能力，”莫兰补充道。“我希望更快！”这位海军上将说，国防部各级都听到了对作战人员的克制，海军正在领导整个联合社区的速度和能力。他说：“你对这项任务至关重要，我为你在这里所做的一切感到骄傲。没有比为国服务更好的服务了。”在全体人员呼叫后，莫兰参观了公共潜艇无线电室（CSRR）SSC大西洋团队采购、设计和测试所有潜艇级别通用的通信系统，提高潜艇平台任务效能，同时降低采办和寿命周期成本。海军上将随后参观了多用途可重构训练系统，这是一种基于PC的网络控制系统，具有单触式d多点触摸液晶显示器，模拟潜艇在船上使用的精确设备。该显示器由SSC大西洋公司开发，用于训练水手使用CSRR组件。陪同海军上将访问查尔斯顿的还有SPAWARSYSCOM指挥官、指挥、控制、通信项目执行官克里斯蒂安・鲍里斯・贝克尔少将通信、计算机和智能（PEO C4I）海军少将卡尔・P・切比和空间系统；PEO C4I执行董事、SSC大西洋公司前指挥官约翰・波普。在上午的简报中，VCNO了解了SSC大西洋公司的人力资本战略和支持当前和未来舰队能力的技术增长领域。此外，贝克尔和切比向莫兰简要介绍了SPAWAR战略愿景。在一次工作午餐期间，莫兰了解了几个成功的SSC大西洋项目，这些项目旨在实现海军作战司令部的目标，包括基于模型的系统工程、红鹰和密码随身携带能力。SSC大西洋提供系统工程和采办，以提供信息战能力通过获取、开发、集成、生产、测试、部署和维持可互操作的指挥、控制、通信、计算机、情报、监视、侦察（C4ISR）、网络和信息技术（IT），为海军、联合和国家作战人员提供便利功能。有关更多信息，请访问http://www.public.navy.mil/spawar/Atlantic.

column2: USS Jimmy Carter Officer Receives Rear Adm. Willis A. Lent Award
column3:
BANGOR, Wash. (NNS) -- Lt. John Wayne Walker, from Houston, Texas, assigned to the Seawolf-class fast-attack submarine USS Jimmy Carter (SSN 23), was presented with the 2017 Rear Adm. Willis "Pilly" A. Lent Tactics and Warfighting Award during a Navy League luncheon held at Bangor Plaza, May 9.

The award, which is also known as the Pilly Lent Award, is sponsored by the Bremerton-Olympic Peninsula Chapter of the Navy League. The selection was most comprehensively carried out by many experienced submarine officers, up through the submarine squadron commander level and approved by Rear Adm. Frederick Roegge, commander, Submarine Force, U.S. Pacific Fleet (COMSUBPAC).

“The Willis A (Pilly) Lent award was established last year to recognize and honor the most tactically proficient submarine department head in the Pacific Fleet,” said Capt. Alan Beam (ret.), President of the Bremerton-Olympic Peninsula Council of the Navy League of the United States. “It is fitting that this year’s awardee, Lt. John Wayne Walker, is the navigator of USS Jimmy Carter (SSN 23); charged with developing and perfecting submarine tactics for the US Fleet. He is literally the best of the best serving on the largest and stealthiest SSN in the US Navy.“

Submarine commanding officers each nominated their top department head for this award. Squadron commanders researched each candidate and forwarded their top choice to COMSUBPAC. Roegge announced the winner in a Navywide message released March 20. 

“Possessing a relentless ability to turn any Sailor into a professional war fighter, he was a driving force behind Jimmy Carter being awarded the 2016 Commander, Submarine Development Squadron 5 Battle Efficiency “E” for operational excellence,” said Cmdr. Melvin Smith, Jimmy Carter’s commanding officer.  “Lt. Walker truly embodies the spirit of Rear Adm. Lent in his approach to aggressive tactics and leadership.”
column9: 美国华盛顿州班戈
column10: 吉米・卡特号军舰军官获得威利斯・A・伦特海军少将奖
column11: 班戈，华盛顿。（NNS）--5月9日，在班戈广场举行的海军联盟午餐会上，来自得克萨斯州休斯顿的约翰・韦恩・沃克中尉被分配到“海狼”级快攻潜艇吉米・卡特号（SSN 23）上，获得了2017年海军少将“皮利”A・伦特战术和作战奖。该奖项也称为皮利伦特奖，由海军联盟布雷默顿奥林匹克半岛分会赞助。此次选拔由许多经验丰富的潜艇军官进行，直至潜艇中队指挥官级别，并由美国太平洋舰队（COMSUPAC）潜艇部队指挥官弗雷德里克・罗格（Frederick Roegge）少将批准“Lent奖是去年设立的，旨在表彰和表彰太平洋舰队中战术最熟练的潜艇部门负责人，”美国海军联盟布雷默顿奥林匹克半岛委员会主席艾伦・比姆上尉（ret.）说。“今年的获奖者约翰・韦恩・沃克中尉是吉米・卡特号航母（SSN 23）的领航员，负责为美国舰队开发和完善潜艇战术，这是很合适的。他实际上是美国海军规模最大、最隐蔽的SSN中最优秀的一员。“潜艇指挥官们都提名了他们的最高部门负责人来获得这个奖项。中队指挥官研究了每个候选人，并将他们的最佳选择转发给了COMSUBPAC。罗格在3月20日发布的一条全球消息中宣布了获胜者。吉米・卡特的指挥官梅尔文・史密斯（Melvin Smith）中校说：“他拥有将任何一名海员转变为职业战斗机的不屈不挠的能力，是吉米・卡特被授予2016年潜艇开发中队第5战斗效率“E”级指挥官，以表彰其卓越作战能力的推动力。”。“沃克中尉在其进攻战术和领导方式中真正体现了伦特少将的精神。”

column2: Adm. Harris and CIA Talk Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month
column3:
CAMP H.M. SMITH, Hawaii -- Adm. Harry B. Harris, commander of U.S Pacific Command (PACOM), delivered a speech on Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month to the CIA Headquarters via video-teleconference May 8.
“It’s an honor to speak to you in observance of Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month,” said Harris. “I’m sorry my schedule changed and I couldn’t be there in person, but this topic is especially important to me and I hope that I can give you all something to think about.”
	The month of May represents Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month in recognition of the first Japanese immigration to the U.S. on May 7, 1843. It also commemorates the completion of the transcontinental railroad, whose tracks were laid mostly by Chinese immigrants, on May 10, 1869. 
Harris has spent almost half of his Naval career in the Pacific. It’s not just the responsibilities of duty that makes the Pacific important to Harris; he was born in Japan to a Japanese mother. His father was an enlisted Sailor in the U.S. Navy.
“My dad’s sea stories formed some of my earliest memories and inspired me to serve, but it was my mother who taught me the true meaning of service,” said Harris. “While my father fought in World War II, my mother and her family experienced the cruelties of war in Japan.  She was from Kobe.  She lost her home, her school, some of her family members, and friends in air raids.  After surviving the destruction that war brought to Imperial Japan―as well as the post-war deprivations of the late '40s―she met and then married an American Sailor, my father.”
Growing in a culturally diverse family gave Harris first-hand experience on the ever-changing shift in diversity the world continues to experience. He feels embracing change, diversity, and inclusiveness allows growth throughout the military ranks to accurately depict the country’s demographic.
“I believe that embracing diversity is vital to both our present and our future,” said Harris.  “We cannot achieve healthy growth without it.  One former Chief of Naval Operations rightly said that as leaders, we must not be locked in time―we must anticipate and embrace the demographic changes of tomorrow to build an organization that always reflects our country’s make up.”
The military’s continued expansion in diversity through race, religion, sex, and sexual orientation has enabled opportunities for personnel from a variety of backgrounds.  The Pearl Harbor-based USS Chung-Hoon (DDG 93) reminds Harris of the ship’s namesake and the impact he had on the Navy.
“Gordon Chung-Hoon, a Hawaiian-born American of Chinese heritage, was the first officer of Asian Pacific descent to command a Navy warship, USS Sigsbee,” said Harris.  “In 1945, when a kamikaze suicide plane caused explosions and flooding onboard his destroyer, Chung-Hoon’s leadership enabled the crew to save the ship.  Awarded the Navy Cross for his actions, he was later promoted to rear admiral, the first officer of Asian Pacific heritage to make Flag rank.”
Harris credits the accomplishments of individuals like Chung-Hoon for paving the way for even further diversity and the increased perspective it brings.
“Diversity is about the power of choosing the best from the entire population―and not selecting the top of a sub-group,” said Harris.  “It's about new and different ideas that spring naturally from the attributes our people bring with them from their various walks of life.”
In his closing remarks to the CIA Headquarters, Harris asked the audience to value one another and to focus on what everyone has in common.
“I’m challenging each and every one of you to do your part in continuing to move our nation forward in the right direction,” said Harris. “That right direction is valuing each individual on the basis of their contributions. This becomes easy if we focus on what we all have in common―a love for our country.”
column6: CAMP H.M. SMITH, HI, UNITED STATES
column9: 史密斯营地，你好，美国
column10: 哈里斯上将和中情局谈论亚裔美国人和太平洋岛民遗产月
column11: 夏威夷H.M.史密斯营地――美国太平洋司令部（PACOM）指挥官哈里・哈里斯上将于5月8日通过视频电话会议向中央情报局总部发表了关于亚裔美国人和太平洋岛民遗产月的演讲。“很荣幸在纪念亚裔美国人和太平洋岛民遗产月的活动中与大家讲话，”哈里斯说。“很抱歉，我的日程改变了，我不能亲自去那里，但这个话题对我来说特别重要，我希望我能给大家一些思考。”5月代表着亚裔美国人和太平洋岛民遗产月，以表彰1843年5月7日第一批日本移民到美国。它还纪念1869年5月10日横贯大陆的铁路完工，该铁路的铁轨主要由中国移民铺设。哈里斯几乎一半的海军生涯都是在太平洋度过的。对哈里斯来说，太平洋地区的重要性不仅仅在于责任；他在日本出生，母亲是日本人。他的父亲是美国海军的一名应征水手。“我父亲的航海故事形成了我最早的记忆，激励我去服役，但是我母亲教会了我服役的真正意义，”哈里斯说。“当我父亲参加第二次世界大战时，我母亲和她的家人在日本经历了战争的残酷。她来自神户。她在空袭中失去了自己的家、学校、一些家庭成员和朋友。在经历了战争给日本帝国带来的破坏以及战后40年代末的贫困之后，她告诉我说哈里斯在一个文化多元化的家庭中成长，这让他亲身体验到了世界多样性不断变化的变化。他认为，拥抱变化、多样性和包容性可以让整个军衔的增长准确地描述国家的人口结构。“我相信拥抱多样性对我们的现在和未来都至关重要，”哈里斯说。“没有它，我们就无法实现健康增长。一位前海军作战司令正确地说，作为领导人，我们不能被锁定在时间上，我们必须预测并接受明天的人口变化，以建立一个始终反映我国构成的组织。”军队通过种族、宗教、性别和性取向不断扩大多样性，为来自不同背景的人员提供了机会。总部位于珍珠港的美国军舰“忠勋”号（DDG 93）让哈里斯想起了该舰的名字以及他对海军的影响。“戈登・忠勋，一位夏威夷裔美国人，具有中国血统，是第一位指挥海军军舰“西格斯比”号的亚太裔军官，”哈里斯说。1945年，当一架神风队自杀式飞机在他的驱逐舰上造成爆炸和洪水时，Chung Hoon的领导使船员们得以拯救这艘船。由于他的行为，他被授予海军十字勋章，后来他被提升为少将，成为亚太地区第一位升旗的军官哈里斯认为，像忠勋这样的个人所取得的成就为进一步的多样性铺平了道路，也为多样性带来了更大的前景。“多样性是指从全体人口中选择最好的，而不是从一个小组中选择最高层的力量，”哈里斯说。哈里斯在中情局总部发表的闭幕词中要求听众相互尊重，关注每个人的共同点。哈里斯说：“我要求你们每一个人尽自己的一份力量，继续推动我们的国家朝着正确的方向前进。正确的方向是根据每个人的贡献来评估他们的价值。如果我们专注于我们所有人的共同点――对国家的爱，这将变得容易。”

column2: USS Maine (B) Officer Receives Rear Adm. Willis A. Lent Award
column3:
The award, which is also known as the Pilly Lent Award, was sponsored by the Bremerton-Olympic Peninsula Chapter of the Navy League and given to Medlin because of his outstanding tactical performance, individual achievements, and excellence in leadership as the best performing tactical submarine department head in the U.S. Pacific Submarine Force. This is the first time the award has been presented. 

"Lt. Cmdr. Medlin was selected for this award because, after competing with over one hundred highly qualified submarine department heads, he was considered the best in fulfilling the warfighting and leadership skills of Rear Adm. Pilly Lent’s legacy,” said retired Capt. Will Lent, son of Rear Adm. Pilly Lent.  “The selection was most comprehensively carried out by many experienced submarine officers, up through the submarine squadron commander level and approved by Rear Adm. Frederick Roegge, commander, Submarine Force, U.S. Pacific Fleet (COMSUBPAC). I have met Lt. Cmdr. Medlin, and being a long time submariner myself, I fully concur with the selection, and believe him to be a most impressive young man.”

Medlin was recognized for his achievements by the Mayor of Bremerton, Mrs. Patty Lent, and the Secretary of State, Mrs. Kim Wyman.  His name was also engraved on a plaque that was presented to him at the Washington State Capital. Medlin will be honored again at the annual Armed Forces Day Gala Dinner, May 21.

“The award comes at the most perfect time to celebrate its namesake, Rear Admiral Willis Lent, one of the most outstanding submarine commanding officers of WWII,” said Mayor Lent. “Especially due to the christening of the newest Virginia-class submarine USS Washington (SSN 787) joining the fleet in 2016, this award will have a historical legacy for Sailors serving on Pacific Fleet submarines. It is very special that the first recipient is actually based here at Naval Base Kitsap-Bangor.”

Submarine commanding officers each nominated their top department head for this award. Squadron commanders researched each candidate and forwarded their top choice to COMSUBPAC. Roegge announced the winner in a Navy-wide message released March 22. 

“Lt. Cmdr. Medlin’s outstanding performance and service to the submarine force honor Rear Adm. Pilly Lent and his legacy as one of the most outstanding war-fighting submarine officers of World War II,” said Roegge.
column9: 美国华盛顿州奥林匹亚
column10: 缅因州军舰（B）军官获得威利斯A・伦特海军少将奖
column11: 该奖项也被称为Pilly Lent奖，由海军联盟布雷默顿奥林匹克半岛分会赞助，授予梅德林，因为他出色的战术表现、个人成就、，作为美国太平洋潜艇部队中表现最佳的战术潜艇部门负责人，领导能力卓越。这是该奖项首次颁发。“梅德林中校之所以被选为这个奖项，是因为在与100多位高素质的潜艇部门负责人竞争后，他被认为是在履行皮利・伦特海军少将遗产中的作战和领导技能方面最出色的，”皮利・伦特海军少将的儿子、退休的威尔・伦特上尉说。“此次选拔由许多经验丰富的潜艇军官进行，直至潜艇中队指挥官级别，并由美国太平洋舰队（COMSUPAC）潜艇部队指挥官弗雷德里克・罗格少将批准.我见过梅德林中校，我本人也是一名长期的潜艇驾驶员，我完全同意他的选择，并相信他是一位给人留下深刻印象的年轻人。”梅德林因其成就获得布雷默顿市长帕蒂・伦特夫人和国务卿金・怀曼夫人的认可。他的名字也刻在华盛顿州首府赠送给他的一块匾额上。梅德林将在5月21日举行的一年一度的武装部队日庆祝晚宴上再次受到表彰。“这个奖项是在最完美的时候颁发的，以庆祝它的名字，海军少将威利斯・伦特，二战中最杰出的潜艇指挥官之一，”伦特市长说，“特别是由于最新的弗吉尼亚级潜艇华盛顿号（SSN 787）的命名2016年加入舰队，这一奖项将为太平洋舰队潜艇上服役的海员留下历史遗产。第一位获奖者实际上驻扎在Kitsap Bangor海军基地，这是非常特别的。”潜艇指挥官们各自提名他们的最高部门负责人获得该奖项。中队指挥官研究了每个候选人，并将他们的最佳选择转发给了COMSUBSPAC。罗格在3月22日发布的海军消息中宣布了获胜者。罗格说：“梅德林少校在潜艇部队中的出色表现和服务，使皮利・伦特少将及其作为二战中最杰出的作战潜艇军官之一的遗产受到表彰。”。

column2: Training Squadron 22 earns Adm. John H. Towers Flight Safety Award
column3:
The Order of Daedalians presented the “Golden Eagles” of strike Training Squadron (VT) 22 the 2020 Adm. John H. Towers Flight Safety Award during a small ceremony held at the squadron aboard Naval Air Station (NAS) Kingsville, Texas, March 1.

The award recognizes the Naval Air Training Command squadron that has made the most significant contributions to the Naval Aviation Safety program throughout the year. 

All student naval aviator and student naval flight officer training squadrons under the Naval Air Training Command are eligible to receive this award. Selection is based on squadrons’ safety records, quality of mishap reports and time between mishap reports, all while considering the number of aircraft being flown and number of days the aircraft spent detached from the squadron.

Order of the Daedalians National Commander retired Air Force Maj. Gen. Jerry Allen presented the award to VT-22 Commanding Officer Marine Lt. Col. Kevin Goodwin. Chief of Naval Air Training Rear Adm. Robert Westendorff also attended the ceremony to congratulate the Golden Eagles team.  

“Adm. Towers was a pioneer in aviation safety,” Allen said. “VT-22 compiled a remarkable flight safety record in 2020. You flew demanding sorties, accomplished carrier-arrested landings and deployed to El Centro, California, for weapons training. You took the initiative to conduct a host of safety programs to keep the focus on flying safely. This award reflects the hard, smart work of every member of the squadron.”

VT-22 has received the Towers Award four times, most recently in 1994. 

“VT-22 being recognized in this manner is a tremendous accomplishment and one that meets our mission of safely and efficiently training students,” Goodwin, a native of Milton, Massachusetts, said. “Our instructor pilots and students work tirelessly to ensure safety is the primary factor in our decision-making process. Every instructor and student is empowered to stop any evolution if safety becomes a factor or there is any confusion hindering safe operations. Essentially, if there is any doubt, there is no doubt.

“During a year that saw our flight hours reduced and COVID-19 fundamentally changing the way we operate, VT-22 rose to the challenge and optimized our training opportunities to overcome many barriers to production.” 

All CNATRA squadrons incorporate Safety Management Systems into daily operations. Operational Risk Management (ORM) begins before a flight is even scheduled, with the assurance that all personnel are qualified and current. On the day of the flight, each brief includes a discussion about potential ORM issues that may exist. Those ORM decisions are made continually throughout the flight in an effort to avoid unsafe circumstances.

“My command priority is safety,” Westendorff said. “There’s no mission we do to train an aviator or naval flight officer that’s worth unnecessarily jeopardizing lives. We always accept some risk when we fly, but with a safety mindset and by implementing ORM approaches, we mitigate those risks.” 

All safety issues and concerns are brought to the squadron’s attention as quickly as possible through a variety of means, including all-hands calls and checklists, to ensure all aviators are aware of new procedures and associated risks.

“Our CNATRA safety team develops and supports a safety-value culture in conjunction with high-velocity learning,” CNATRA Aviation Safety Officer Henry Schwerdtfeger said. “This is the foundation of our squadron safety management systems and how we continue to create the finest aviation professionals.”

Headquartered at Randolph Air Force Base, San Antonio, the Order of Daedalians is a non-profit organization that advocates for air and space power, and honors past and present military aviators. The award, named for Adm. John H. Towers who was designated a naval aviator in 1911, recognizes squadrons for their commitment to flight safety. Towers was known for many pioneering accomplishments during his career, including the establishment of the first naval flight school in Pensacola, Florida.

VT-22, formed in 1949, conducts strike training for student naval aviators in the Navy, Marine Corps and select international military partners. VT-22 is one of two strike training squadrons under Training Air Wing 2 aboard NAS Kingsville.
column9: 金斯维尔，美国
column10: 第22训练中队获得海军上将约翰・H・托尔斯飞行安全奖
column11: 在德克萨斯州金斯维尔海军航空站（NAS）中队举行的小型仪式上，Daedalians骑士团向罢工训练中队（VT）22“金鹰”颁发了2020年约翰・H・塔尔斯海军上将飞行安全奖，3月1日。该奖项表彰了海军航空训练指挥中队，该中队在全年为海军航空安全计划做出了最重大的贡献。海军航空训练司令部下属的所有海军飞行学员和海军飞行学员训练中队都有资格获得该奖项。选择基于中队的安全记录、事故报告的质量和事故报告之间的时间，考虑到飞行的飞机数量以及飞机与中队分离的天数，《Daedalians国家指挥官令》（Order of the National Commander）退休空军少将杰里・艾伦（Jerry Allen）将该奖项颁发给VT-22指挥官海军陆战队中校凯文・古德温（Kevin Goodwin）。海军航空训练司令罗伯特・韦斯滕多夫海军少将也出席了祝贺金鹰队的仪式。艾伦说：“托尔斯上将是航空安全领域的先驱。”。“VT-22在2020年创造了非凡的飞行安全记录。您的飞行要求很高，完成了航母拦截着陆，并被部署到加利福尼亚州的El Centro进行武器训练。您主动开展了一系列安全计划，以保持对安全飞行的关注。该奖项反映了该组织每一位成员的辛勤和智慧VT-22曾四次获得塔楼奖，最近一次是在1994年。来自马萨诸塞州米尔顿的古德温说：“VT-22以这种方式被认可是一项巨大的成就，符合我们安全有效地培训学生的使命。”。“我们的指导员、飞行员和学生不知疲倦地工作，以确保安全是我们决策过程中的首要因素。如果安全成为一个因素或存在任何妨碍安全操作的混乱，每个指导员和学生都有权阻止任何演变。基本上，如果有任何疑问，就没有疑问。“在一年中，我们的飞行时间缩短，新冠病毒-19从根本上改变了我们的运营方式，VT-22勇敢地迎接挑战，优化了我们的培训机会，克服了许多生产障碍。”所有CNATRA中队都将安全管理系统纳入日常运营。运营风险管理（ORM）在飞行计划开始之前开始，确保所有人员都合格且最新。在飞行当天，每个简报都包括对可能存在的潜在ORM问题的讨论。这些ORM决策在整个飞行过程中不断做出，以避免不安全的情况。“我的指挥优先权是安全，”Westendorff说：“我们所做的任务不是训练一名飞行员或海军飞行官员，而是不必要地危及生命。我们在飞行时总是会接受一些风险，但出于安全考虑，通过实施ORM方法，我们可以减轻这些风险。”所有安全问题和担忧都会通过各种方式尽快引起中队的注意，包括所有举手电话和检查表，以确保所有飞行员了解新程序和相关风险。“我们的CnnRA安全团队结合高速学习开发和支持一种安全价值文化，”CnnRA航空安全官员Henry Schwerdtfeger说，“这是我们中队安全管理系统的基础，也是我们如何继续创造最好的航空专业人员。”Daedalians骑士团总部位于圣安东尼奥的伦道夫空军基地，是一个非营利组织，倡导空中和空间力量，并向过去和现在的军事飞行员致敬。该奖项以1911年被指定为海军飞行员的约翰・H・托尔斯上将命名，表彰各中队对飞行安全的承诺。托尔斯在他的职业生涯中，他以许多开创性的成就而闻名，包括在佛罗里达州彭萨科拉建立了第一所海军飞行学校。VT-22成立于1949年，为海军、海军陆战队和选定的国际军事伙伴的海军学生飞行员进行打击训练。VT-22是Traini旗下的两个打击训练中队之一纳辛那斯金斯维尔上的ng航空联队2号。

column2: Navy Cyber and Networks Talk Fleet Cyber Security
column3:
NEWPORT NEWS, Va. C The Navy’s Information Assurance and Cyber Security Program Office (PMW 130) and Tactical Networks Program Office (PMW 160) hosted a Fleet Stakeholders Working Group (FSWG) Jan. 24 to 26.  

Adm. Phil Davidson, commander, U.S. Fleet Forces, kicked off the event with a keynote speech.  Davidson noted the last two groups to return from deployment, the Dwight D. Eisenhower Carrier Strike Group and the Wasp Amphibious Ready Group, were actively involved in combat operations during their deployments. 

“Every group that deploys must be ready to employ their defense systems at any time,” said Davidson.   “U.S. naval forces currently enjoy advantages over our adversaries in the undersea domain, in networks, modularity and in people.” 

Focusing on the Navy’s advantages, he noted that Navy networks “enable naval fires and sensors persistent access to command and control so that commanders are able to employ the right platforms against the right targets at any time.” 

Davidson  also challenged the participants to develop battle management tools for the operational level of warfare that match the capabilities of the tools now employed at the tactical level.   

The three-day working group provided a discussion forum for afloat fleet representatives, fleet information technology (IT) leads (N6s), cyber operators and maintainers, resource sponsors, and supporting shore command and acquisition community personnel.  The objectives of the FSWG were to enhance awareness and to promote understanding of PMW 130 and PMW 160 programs, their capabilities and limitations in the fleet today, and plans for future.  The FSWG also provided an opportunity for direct user feedback, which was achieved through a series of panel discussions, plenary briefings and breakout focus groups.

Rear Adm. Christian “Boris” Becker, Program Executive Officer Command, Control, Communications, Computers and Intelligence (PEO C4I), moderated a panel discussion which included Rear Adm. Nancy A. Norton, director of Warfare Integration for Information Warfare (OPNAV N2/N6F)/deputy director, Navy Cybersecurity, and Rear Adm. Matthew J. Kohler, commander, Naval Information Forces (NAVIFOR).  

The panel discussed the need for understanding network baselines and decreasing network and cyber-defense tool application times. According to Becker, “PEO C4I recognizes the need to make our programs more modular so we are able to reduce installation duration and enable installation outside of Chief of Naval Operation availabilities.”

Becker also challenged the 250 personnel in attendance to develop processes and procedures to modernize and maintain as quickly as possible, recognizing the critical importance of networks in ongoing and future combat operations.  

“The FSWG is a very productive tool for the Fleet,” said Master Chief Petty Officer Richard Okrasinski, Submarine Forces information technology force lead. “As hard as it is for the Fleet Sailor to get off the boat or ship to attend, the opportunity to talk directly to the program managers, engineers and acquisition professionals is well worth the time. 

The ability for type commanders to bring deck-plate issues to the engineers and meet face to face is key to successfully solving problems.  I enjoyed meeting the engineers and program managers and teams that develop and help maintain our systems as we work together to solve the problems of keeping our systems cyber resilient.”

According to Capt. Kurt Rothenhaus, PMW 160 program manager, working with key stakeholders to align efforts is critical to the combat readiness of the Fleet.  

“We must maintain a focus that everything we do in PMW 160 impacts Sailors at sea operating, maintaining, and securing our systems in order to support the Navy mission afloat,” he stated.   

"What good are our networks if we can’t secure them and ensure their operability?" asked Mr. Rob Diaz, PMW 130 program manager. "Keeping an open dialogue with our stakeholders allows us to collaborate on our modernization efforts as we strive to secure our systems so commanders can communicate with each other during critical operations." 

PMW 130 plans, manages and executes program resources to ensure continued protection of Navy and joint information, telecommunications and information systems from hostile exploitation and attack. PMW 130’s mission is to acquire and sustain cyber security products and services to ensure strong authentication, data integrity, confidentiality, non-repudiation and availability of network resources and information. 

PMW 160 is PEO C4I’s program office for tactical networks, providing operationally effective and cost-efficient networks for Navy tactical forces. PMW 160 delivers integrated wide area, local networking and foundation computing systems to support a robust network of cyber ready, geographically dispersed Naval Force supporting Joint and coalition global operations.
column9: 新港新闻，弗吉尼亚州，美国
column10: 海军网络与舰队网络安全对话
column11: 弗吉尼亚州纽波特纽斯――海军信息保障和网络安全计划办公室（PMW 130）和战术网络计划办公室（PMW 160）于1月24日至26日主办了一个舰队利益相关者工作组（FSWG）。美国舰队司令菲尔・戴维森（Phil Davidson）上将在活动开始时发表了主题演讲。戴维森指出，最后两个从部署中返回的小组，德怀特・D・艾森豪威尔航母攻击小组和黄蜂两栖准备小组，在部署期间积极参与作战行动。戴维森说：“部署的每个小组都必须随时准备使用他们的防御系统。”。“美国海军目前在水下领域、网络、模块化和人员方面都比我们的对手拥有优势。”他在谈到海军的优势时指出，海军网络“使海军火力和传感器能够持续访问指挥和控制，以便指挥官能够在任何时候对正确的目标使用正确的平台。”戴维森还向与会者提出挑战，要求他们为作战级别开发与战术级别所用工具能力相匹配的作战管理工具。为期三天的工作组为海上舰队代表、舰队信息技术（IT）领导（N6s）提供了一个讨论论坛，网络操作员和维护人员，资源赞助者，以及支援海岸指挥和采办社区人员。FSWG的目标是提高认识，促进对PMW 130和PMW 160计划、其目前在舰队中的能力和局限性以及未来计划的了解。FSWG还提供了一个机会直接用户反馈，通过一系列小组讨论、全体简报和分组焦点小组实现。Christian“Boris”Becker少将，项目执行官指挥、控制、通信、计算机和情报（PEO C4I），主持了一次小组讨论，其中包括海军信息战作战集成总监（OPNAV N2/N6F）/海军网络安全副总监Nancy a.Norton少将和海军信息部队指挥官Matthew J.Kohler少将（海军信息部队）该小组讨论了了解网络基线和减少网络和网络防御工具应用时间的必要性。Becker说，“PEO C4I认识到需要使我们的程序更加模块化，以便我们能够缩短安装时间，并在海军作战司令部可用性之外进行安装。”贝克尔还要求250名与会人员制定流程和程序，以尽快实现现代化和维护，同时认识到网络在当前和未来作战行动中的关键重要性。“FSWG是舰队的一个非常高效的工具，”潜艇部队信息技术部队负责人理查德・奥克拉辛斯基少校说。“对于舰队水手来说，下船或下船参加是很困难的，但直接与项目经理、工程师和采办专业人员交谈的机会是非常值得的。类型指挥官将甲板问题提交给工程师并与工程师面对面的能力是成功解决问题的关键。我喜欢ed会见了开发和帮助维护我们系统的工程师、项目经理和团队，共同解决保持系统网络弹性的问题。”PMW 160项目经理Kurt Rothenhaus上尉表示，与关键利益相关者合作协调工作对于舰队的战备至关重要。“我们必须保持一个重点，即我们在PMW 160中所做的每件事都会影响海上的水手操作、维护和保护我们的系统，以支持海军的海上任务，”他说。“如果我们不能保护它们并确保它们的可操作性，我们的网络又有什么好处呢？”PMW 130项目经理Rob Diaz先生问道。“与利益相关者保持公开对话，使我们能够在努力确保系统安全的同时，就现代化工作进行合作，以便指挥官能够在关键行动期间相互沟通。"PMW 130计划、管理和执行项目资源，以确保持续保护海军和联合信息、电信和信息系统免受恶意攻击。PMW 130的任务是获取和维持网络安全产品和服务，以确保强大的身份验证、数据完整性、机密性和PMW 160是战术网络的PEO C4I的程序办公室，为海军战术部队提供可操作的有效和成本有效的网络。PMW 160提供集成的广域网、本地网络和基础计算系统，以支持强大的网络准备网络。，地理位置分散的海军部队，支持联合和联盟全球作战。

column2: Training Squadron 35 Receives Adm. John H. Towers Flight Safety Award
column3:
The Order of Daedalians awarded the “Stingrays” of multi-engine Training Squadron (VT) 35 with the 2019 Adm. John H. Towers Flight Safety Award, March 16.

The award recognizes the squadron that has made the most significant contributions to the Naval Aviation Safety program throughout the year. 

All student naval aviator and student naval flight officer training squadrons under the Naval Air Training Command are eligible to receive this award. Selection is based on squadrons’ safety records, quality of mishap reports and time between mishap reports, all while considering the number of aircraft being flown and number of days the aircraft spent detached from the squadron.

Training Air Wing 4 Commodore Capt. Kevin Delano presented the award on behalf of the Daedalians to VT-35 Commanding Officer Marine Lt. Col. Brian Dennis on the flight line at Naval Air Station Corpus Christi.

“I am incredibly proud of our team at VT-35 for being recognized with this tremendous honor,” Dennis said. “I can tell you the backbone of our organization is our 10 civilian employees, some of whom have been here over 10 years. Although none directly work in the safety department, they are the quiet professionals who allow the uniform wearers to focus on operations, training, and safety.

“Each and every Stingray had a part in the daily operations that allowed us to be recognized, to include our highly professional and extremely hard-working students. Our safety department is the conscience of our squadron and ensures that our pilots are briefed and ready regarding the latest hazard reports, pertinent safety information and trends in aviation safety. As for the rest of our Stingrays, there is no team I would rather be a part of and I feel blessed and lucky to have such a tremendous cadre of officers and civilians who keep the bar so high, making sure we do business the right way C every sortie, every day.”

Cmdr. Nathan Bitz oversees the safety program across the entire Naval Air Training Command and said VT-35 last received the award in 2005. 

“We are always striving to improve the Naval Aviation Safety Management System to continue producing the finest military aviation professionals,” Bitz said. “When we have the chance to recognize those who go above and beyond in support of this goal, it is an honor to do so.” 

Retired Air Force Major Gen. Jerry Allen of the Order of the Daedalians coordinated presentation of the award. 

“Adm. Towers was a founding member of the Daedalians and we salute him for being an outstanding military aviation pioneer,” Allen said. “Congratulations to the stinging Stingrays of VT-35 for your superior flying safety performance.”

Headquartered at Randolph Air Force Base, San Antonio, the Order of Daedalians is a non-profit organization that advocates for air and space power, and honors past and present military aviators. The award, named for Adm. John H. Towers who was designated a naval aviator in 1911, recognizes squadrons for their commitment to flight safety. Towers was known for many pioneering accomplishments during his career, including the establishment of the first naval flight school in Pensacola, Florida.

VT-35, established in 1999, provides multi-engine training and designation to members of the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps. VT-35 provides student naval aviators with basic and advanced multi-engine training and is one of four squadrons under Training Air Wing 4 at NAS Corpus Christi.
column9: 科珀斯克里斯蒂，德克萨斯州，美国
column10: 第35训练中队获得海军上将约翰・H・托尔斯飞行安全奖
column11: Daedalians骑士团于3月16日授予多引擎训练中队（VT）35“黄貂鱼”2019年海军上将约翰・H・托尔斯飞行安全奖。该奖项表彰了该中队在全年为海军航空安全计划做出的最重大贡献。海军航空训练司令部下属的所有海军飞行学员和海军飞行学员训练中队都有资格获得该奖项。选择基于中队的安全记录、事故报告的质量和事故报告之间的时间，考虑到飞行的飞机数量以及飞机与中队分离的天数，训练航空联队4准将凯文・德拉诺上尉代表Daedalians在海军科珀斯克里斯蒂航空站的飞行线上向VT-35海军陆战队指挥官布莱恩・丹尼斯中校颁发了该奖项。丹尼斯说：“我为我们的VT-35团队获得如此巨大的荣誉而感到无比自豪。”。“我可以告诉你，我们组织的骨干是我们的10名文职雇员，其中一些已经在这里工作了10年以上。虽然没有人直接在安全部门工作，但他们是安静的专业人员，让穿制服的人能够专注于操作、培训和安全。“每一条黄貂鱼都参与了我们的日常操作，这让我们得到了认可，包括我们高度专业和非常勤奋的学生。我们的安全部门是我们中队的良心，确保我们的飞行员了解最新的危险报告、相关安全信息和趋势至于其他黄貂鱼，我不想加入任何一支队伍，我感到幸运和幸运的是，拥有如此庞大的军官和平民队伍，他们保持着如此高的标准，确保我们以正确的方式开展业务――每一次出击，每一天。”Nathan Bitz中校负责整个海军航空训练司令部的安全计划，并表示VT-35上一次获得该奖项是在2005年。“我们一直在努力改进海军航空安全管理系统，以继续培养最优秀的军事航空专业人员，”Bitz说。“当我们有机会表彰那些为支持这一目标而超越自我的人时，我们感到非常荣幸。”退休的Daedalians骑士团空军少校Jerry Allen协调颁发了该奖项。“托尔斯上将是Daedalians的创始成员，我们向他致敬，因为他是一位杰出的军用航空先驱，”艾伦说。“祝贺VT-35的刺鳐飞行安全性能优异。”Daedalians骑士团总部位于圣安东尼奥的伦道夫空军基地，是一个非营利组织，倡导空中和空间力量，并向过去和现在的军事飞行员致敬。该奖项以1911年被指定为海军飞行员的约翰・H・托尔斯上将命名，表彰各中队对飞行安全的承诺。托尔斯他以其职业生涯中的许多开创性成就而闻名，包括在佛罗里达州彭萨科拉建立了第一所海军飞行学校。VT-35成立于1999年，为美国海军和海军陆战队成员提供多引擎训练和指定。VT-35为海军飞行学员提供基本和高级多引擎训练是北美科珀斯克里斯蒂空军第四联队训练的四个中队之一。

column2: Vice Adm. Brown Engages with the Fleet to Receive Feedback, Discuss Surface Force Vision
column3:
From Commander, Naval Surface Force, U.S. Pacific Fleet Public Affairs

Vice Adm. Richard Brown, Commander, Naval Surface Forces (CNSF), visited Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam, Nov. 3-6, as part of his waterfront engagement series.

During his trip to Hawaii, Brown toured guided-missile destroyer USS Preble (DDG 88) and guided-missile cruiser USS Port Royal (CG 73), conducted a surface warfare officer call, and a commanding officer roundtable.

“Everything we do is to build combat ready ships and battle-minded crews,” said Brown during the surface warfare officer call. “That means ships are materially sound, leaving no redundancy at the pier and crews ready to fight, win, and come home.”

The Hawaii visit is part of waterfront engagements by Brown. The engagements provide an opportunity for the fleet to engage with Brown, provide feedback, and ask questions about the vision for the Surface Force. 

Earlier this year, Brown visited Sailors in Rota, Spain; Manama, Bahrain, and Mayport, Florida. Throughout his visits, Brown discussed efforts to build combat ready ships and battle-minded crews, while preparing for the high-end fight. 

“We are the premier surface force in the world, second to none, that controls, succeeds, and provides combat naval power to our nation when and where it needs it,” Brown emphasized throughout his travels. “There is no other surface force that’s like us.”

The feedback from the waterfront engagements around the fleet has been positive. 

“When he visited our ship, he was adamant about fixing the important issues, such as focusing on a warrior mindset and bringing back pride in the surface community,” said electrical officer Ensign Andrew Maus aboard USS Preble.
 
“We’ve got the best commanding officers in the world,” Brown said. “The way that we command in the United States Navy is different than any other navy. Not only do we have the best commanding officers in the world, we’ve got the best officers and we have the best crews. That’s why we’re the premier surface force. Hands down.”

The mission of CNSF is to man, train, and equip the Surface Force to provide fleet commanders with credible naval power to control the sea and project power when and when needed.
column6: JOINT BASE PEARL HARBOR-HICKAM, HI, UNITED STATES
column9: 珍珠港-希卡姆联合基地，美国
column10: 布朗副上将与舰队接洽，接受反馈，讨论地面部队愿景
column11: 11月3日至6日，美国太平洋舰队公共事务司令理查德・布朗海军陆战队司令参观了珍珠港-希卡姆联合基地，这是他在海滨作战系列中的一部分。在访问夏威夷期间，布朗参观了“普雷布尔”号导弹驱逐舰（DDG 88）此外，皇家港号（CG73）导弹巡洋舰还进行了一次水面作战军官呼叫和一次指挥官圆桌会议。“我们所做的一切都是建造战备舰和有战斗意识的船员，”布朗在水面作战军官呼叫中说。“这意味着船只在物质上是完好的，码头上没有多余的人员，船员们准备战斗、胜利和回家。”这次夏威夷之行是布朗海滨活动的一部分。交战为舰队提供了与布朗交战的机会，提供反馈，并就地面部队的愿景提出问题。今年早些时候，布朗访问了西班牙罗塔的水手；巴林麦纳麦和佛罗里达梅波特。在整个访问过程中，布朗讨论了在为高端战斗做准备的同时，为建造战备舰和有战斗意识的船员所做的努力。“我们是世界上首屈一指的地面部队，首屈一指，能够在国家需要的时候和地点控制、成功地向国家提供海军战斗力，”布朗在整个旅途中都强调道。“没有其他地面部队像我们一样。”舰队周围的海滨战斗反馈是积极的。“当他访问我们的飞船时，他坚持要解决一些重要的问题，比如关注战士的心态，恢复水面社区的自豪感，”海军陆战队军官安德鲁・莫斯少尉在“普雷布尔”号上说，“我们拥有世界上最优秀的指挥官，”布朗说。“我们在美国海军的指挥方式不同于任何其他海军。我们不仅拥有世界上最好的指挥官，我们拥有最好的军官，我们拥有最好的船员。这就是为什么我们是首要的地面部队。放手。”CNSF的使命是人、训练，并装备地面部队，为舰队指挥官提供可靠的海军力量，以便在需要时控制海洋和投射力量。

column2: Vice Adm. C. Forrest Faison, III, Retires as Navy’s 38th Surgeon General
column3:
WASHINGTON (NNS) C Vice Adm. C. Forrest Faison, III, the Navy’s 38th Surgeon General, celebrated the culmination of 39 years of active duty service at a retirement ceremony at the Navy Yard in Washington, DC, Oct. 25, 2019. 

Secretary of the Navy, Richard V. Spencer presided over the ceremony, and former Chief of Naval Operations Adm. John Richardson, USN (Ret.), gave remarks. 

“I’m particularly grateful for the steady hand Admiral Faison provided in our military medical transformation efforts, strengthening readiness and increasing maneuverability. Thanks to his efforts and the hard work of all of our Navy medical professionals, the Department is better prepared to confront a complex world & respond wherever needed,” said Spencer. 

The ceremony commemorated both Faison’s career as well as the role of Navy Medicine in the support to the daily readiness of the Fleet and Marine Corps. 

“It has been the privilege of a lifetime to honor the trust placed in our hands by those we serve and their families,” said Faison. “The Navy Medicine team is ready and dedicated to doing everything within our power to provide those we serve with the best care our nation can offer so that each Sailor and Marine can return home safely and alive.” 

A native of Norfolk, Virginia and Cleveland, Ohio, Faison graduated from Rocky River High School in Cleveland. He went on to earn his bachelor's degree from Wake Forrest University in 1980 and received a commission as a Naval officer through the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences (USUHS) in 1980, completing his medical degree in 1984 at USUHS.  He is also a board certified and a Distinguished Professor of Military Medicine and an associate clinical professor in pediatrics.

During his tenure as Surgeon General, Faison led the way as Navy Medicine redefined itself from a primarily military treatment facility-based care model to a readiness focused, critical wartime enterprise in support of operational medical platforms and enhanced Fleet and Marine Corps Operational unit integration.

Among his many contributions to improving Navy Medicine, Faison dedicated himself to ensuring Hospital Corpsmen were prepared to fight tonight as he directed a comprehensive review, rewrite and update of the Hospital Corpsman “A” school curriculum. His attention to the Hospital Corpsman trauma training curriculum leveraged civilian partnerships to augment the clinical and trauma training experiences to better prepare warrior caretakers for casualty responses. 

He established the Navy’s Global Health Specialist Program to ensure professionals who have global health experience, skills and training receive specialized certifications to fill key positions across the Department of Defense, interagency and international communities.  As part of this effort, Navy Medicine successfully conducted a trauma collaborative exchange with the government of Vietnam to provide emergency medicine services.  The resulting effort strengthened allied medical trauma capacities and provided Navy medical teams the opportunity to sustain their trauma skills in an unfamiliar and resource-constrained environment.

Faison also led the first deployment of the Department of Defense’s $4.3 billion electronic health record system “MHS GENESIS” at Naval Hospital Bremerton and Naval Health Clinic Oak Harbor, Washington.  The new computer system will be implemented at all military medical facilities to manage health information in a single health record across the continuum of care for service members, veterans, and their families.

As Faison retires, Rear Adm. Terry Moulton will serve as the Acting Navy Surgeon General until a new Surgeon General is confirmed. 

“As I close this chapter of almost 40 years of service, I know our Navy and Marine Corps is in good hands because they are in your hands. I know you will continue to do what you have always done since the founding of our nation: honor the trust,” Faison said. “I wish each of you all life’s blessings ahead and please know that you go forward with my deepest thanks and admiration for all you do.” 

Navy Medicine is a global health care network of 63,000 personnel that provide health care support to the U.S. Navy, Marine Corps, their families and veterans in high operational tempo environments, at expeditionary medical facilities, medical treatment facilities, hospitals, clinics, hospital ships and research units around the world.

For more information about Navy Medicine, visit www.med.navy.mil
column9: 美国华盛顿特区
column10: 副上将C.福里斯特・费森（C.Forrest Faison），三世，作为海军第38任卫生部长退休
column11: 华盛顿（NNS）――2019年10月25日，海军第38任卫生部长、副上将C.福里斯特・费森三世在华盛顿海军造船厂举行的退休仪式上庆祝了39年的现役生涯。海军部长理查德・斯宾塞（Richard V.Spencer）主持了仪式，前海军作战司令、美国海军陆战队司令约翰・理查森（John Richardson）发表了讲话。“我特别感谢Faison海军上将在我们的军事医疗转型努力中提供了坚定的支持，加强了战备状态并提高了机动性。由于他的努力和我们所有海军医疗专业人员的辛勤工作，国防部为应对复杂的世界做好了更好的准备，并在需要时作出反应。”斯宾塞说。仪式纪念了费森的职业生涯以及海军医学在支持舰队和海军陆战队日常准备工作中的作用。费森说：“能够尊重我们所服务的人及其家人对我们的信任，是我们一生的荣幸。”。“海军医疗队已经准备好，并致力于尽我们所能为我们的服务人员提供我们国家所能提供的最佳护理，使每个水手和海军陆战队员都能安全和活着回家。”费森出生于弗吉尼亚州诺福克和俄亥俄州克利夫兰，毕业于克利夫兰洛基河高中。他于1980从威克福雷斯特大学获得学士学位，并于1980年通过美国卫生科学军队服务大学（UUHS）获得海军军官学位，1984年在UUHS完成医学学位。他还是一名获得委员会认证的杰出军事医学教授和儿科临床副教授。在担任卫生部长期间，Faison带领海军医学从以军事治疗设施为主的护理模式重新定义为以准备为中心的护理模式，支持作战医疗平台和加强舰队与海军陆战队作战单元整合的关键战时企业。在他为改进海军医学做出的诸多贡献中，费森致力于确保医院医务人员做好今晚作战的准备，他指导了一项全面审查，重写和更新医院医务人员“A”学校课程。他对医院医务人员创伤培训课程的关注利用民间伙伴关系来增强临床和创伤培训经验，以便更好地为战士看护人员应对伤亡做好准备。他建立了海军全球健康专家计划，以确保具有全球健康经验、技能和培训的专业人员获得专业认证，以填补国防部、跨机构和国际社会的关键职位。作为这项工作的一部分，海军医学部成功地与越南政府进行了创伤协作交流，以提供紧急医疗服务。由此产生的努力加强了盟军的医疗创伤能力，并为海军医疗队提供了在陌生和资源有限的环境中保持创伤技能的机会。费森还领导了国防部价值43亿美元的电子健康记录系统“MHS GENESIS”的首次部署在华盛顿的布雷默顿海军医院和橡树港海军健康诊所。新的计算机系统将在所有军事医疗设施中实施，以便在军人、退伍军人及其家属的连续护理过程中，在单一健康记录中管理健康信息。随着费森退休，海军少将特里・莫尔顿将担任海军代理卫生部长，直到新的卫生部长得到确认。费森说：“在我结束近40年服役的这一章时，我知道我们的海军和海军陆战队掌握在你们手中，因为他们掌握在你们手中。我知道你们将继续做你们自建国以来一直做的事情：尊重信任。”。“我祝愿你们每一个人前途无量，并请你们知道，我对你们所做的一切表示最深切的感谢和钦佩。”海军医学是一个由63000名人员组成的全球医疗网络，为美国海军、海军陆战队及其家属和退伍军人在高速作战环境中提供医疗支持，在世界各地的远征医疗设施、医疗设施、医院、诊所、医疗船和研究单位。有关海军医学的更多信息，请访问www.med.Navy.mil

column2: Vice Adm. Raquel Bono discusses leadership, mentorship in visit to NUWC Division Newport
column3:
NEWPORT, R.I. ― When Vice Adm. Raquel Bono was a child, she often wondered why her father worked such long, late hours. Her family had immigrated to the U.S. from the Philippines when she was 6 months old so that her father could attend medical school at the University of Minnesota, and some years later he was working as a Navy surgeon.

One night, Bono waited up to see her father before going to bed and the two had a conversation that left a profound impact on her life, she told Naval Undersea Warfare Center (NUWC) Division Newport’s workforce during a speech held on May 10, as part of the command’s celebration of Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month.

“He came home one night and I said, ‘Daddy, why do you work so long? When I grow up, I want to work at a hospital so I can see you every day,’” Bono said. “At the time, I didn’t know that girls could be doctors, but my father told me that I could be whatever I wanted.

“My conversation with my father really kick-started who I was and helped me to fulfill the opportunities that my parents gave to me,” said Bono, who is the first female, medical, three-star admiral in the history of the U.S. Navy, and serves as the director of the Defense Health Agency.

“I thought that was really cool until I went to get my shoulder boards; I had to get them special ordered,” Bono said. “I told them, when you special order them, don’t quite break that mold because I’m hoping someone behind me can use them too.

“I also take a lot of leadership from what I’ve learned as a parent, wife and colleague.”

Leadership and mentorship were at the crux of Bono’s all-hands talk, which was presented by NUWC Newport’s Equal Employment Opportunity, Diversity and Inclusion Office. From that early conversation with her father, Bono was inspired and has had a distinguished career in the Navy for more than 40 years.

In reflecting on her many years of service, Bono admitted that she could not have envisioned this path when her career began. “When my father told me I could be whatever I want, I had no idea that not only would I get to train as a trauma surgeon, but that I could also get to be a three-star admiral,” Bono said. “I had no idea what was in store for me. I can tell you, every step of the way eventually prepared me for the job I have today.

“You may not know exactly where life is going to take you, but you want to be prepared as you make your way on your journey.”

Leadership and mentorship played a critical role in that respect for Bono, and she shared some of the lessons she has learned along the way.

The ability to align in a direction that a group collectively wants to go and then to make things happen are two critical aspects of leadership, Bono noted while acknowledging the difficulties that process presents.

“It does make people uncomfortable, and the first thing that they’ll probably do is say no,” Bono said. “As leaders and mentors, you need to reflect on how you want to do it and how you are going to develop the skills to do that.

“As you look to your own leadership, help them develop the tools to create change in your environment, and then push forward within those lines of effort.”

An epiphany Bono had during her general surgery residency helped to illustrate this. At the time, she was the second female to enter the Navy program and the first to graduate. It is customary, Bono explained, for attendees to bombard the trainees in the operating room with a constant stream of questions to gauge their fundamental knowledge.

“I came out of there and was completely defeated,” Bono said. “I walked into the locker room and there was only one thing I could think to do; I was so overwhelmed, I got into a stall and I burst into tears.”

As she sat there in a stall in the women’s locker room, it occurred to Bono that her colleagues in the men’s locker room would have had time to talk about the case before they entered the operating room.

“Rather than make it about that, I thought, ‘what do I need to do to close the gap? If I’m going through this, who else is going through the same level of frustration? What can I do to make it better for [women]?’” Bono said. “I made a commitment to myself to try to make it easier for them. That’s a large part of what being a mentor is all about.”

A few years later, it was Bono’s turn to be the attendee who was grilling a trainee. Sure enough, after the surgery, she found the overwhelmed woman sobbing in a bathroom stall.

“I put my hand over the stall, said, ‘give me your beeper, take a few hours and come back when you feel better because what you need is time and perspective,’” Bono said. “I wish someone would have done that for me. I’ve oriented my career in knowing what I can do to make things better for people ― even if it’s a moment for a quiet cry.

“I can be that safe harbor to vent. Sometimes, all you need to do is to be able to hear yourself out loud. I will listen to whatever they need me to listen to. What I’ve found is most people just need to talk out loud and get a few nudges.”

In addition to her experiences, Bono also noted that her family’s military legacy has shaped her views of leadership and mentorship. Her grandfather served in the U.S. Army and retired as a colonel, while her brother is retired Rear Adm. Anatolio B. Cruz III. Bono and Cruz III are the only siblings of Filipino descent to hold flag-officer rank simultaneously.

“As a leader and mentor, the most important thing is understanding that I serve a greater mission than myself,” Bono said. “My father wanted to make sure that we gave back to the country we adopted. I am here to serve others and understand how best to serve others so that they can make better things happen.

“When I see organizations such as [NUWC Newport] where you have the same attention to detail, it not only resonates with me, it also encourages me that this is the best model. It’s a hallmark of our military and Navy. We build our strength on knowing that we serve each other.”

These are lessons she has instilled not just in coworkers but in her children as well. Bono described a moment similar to the one she had with her own father when one of her daughters was 7 years old. 

“I told her what it’s like to be a doctor and medical officer. We talked about what it’s like to meet people that need your help,” Bono said. “I also explained that as a naval officer, I serve our country, I am part of a group of Sailors ― 300,000 across the world ― and how important it is to be a part of the military.

“My daughter is dialed in on me, and that was one of my moments. She said to me when I was finished, ‘Momma, can boys be doctors too?’”

NUWC Division Newport, part of the Naval Sea System Command, is one of two divisions of the Naval Undersea Warfare Center. NUWC Division Newport’s mission is to provide research, development, test and evaluation, engineering and fleet support for submarines, autonomous underwater systems, undersea offensive and defensive weapons systems, and countermeasures. NUWC’s other division is located in Keyport, Washington.
column9: 新港，国际扶轮，美国
column10: 拉克尔・博诺副上将在访问纽波特NUWC分部时讨论了领导力和导师关系
column11: 纽波特，R.I.-当副上将拉克尔・博诺还是个孩子的时候，她经常想知道为什么她的父亲工作这么长时间，这么晚。她的家人在6个月大的时候从菲律宾移民到美国，以便她的父亲能在明尼苏达大学就读医学院，几年后他作为一名海军外科医生工作。5月10日，作为司令部庆祝亚裔美国人和太平洋岛民遗产月的一部分，波诺在一次演讲中告诉海军海底战争中心（NUWC）新港分部的员工，她在睡觉前等着看望父亲，两人的谈话对她的生活产生了深远的影响。“一天晚上，他回到家，我说，‘爸爸，你为什么工作这么久？等我长大了，我想在医院工作，这样我就可以每天见你，’”波诺说，“当时，我不知道女孩可以当医生，但我父亲告诉我，我可以做我想做的任何事。”。波诺是美国海军历史上第一位女性、医学界、三星级海军上将，也是国防卫生局局长。他说：“我和父亲的谈话让我真正了解了自己，帮助我实现了父母给我的机会。”。博诺说：“在我去买垫肩板之前，我一直认为这很酷；我必须特别订购垫肩板。我告诉他们，当你特别订购垫肩板时，不要打破这种模式，因为我希望我身后的人也能使用垫肩板。我还从我作为父母、妻子和同事所学到的经验中汲取了很多领导力。”领导和指导是波诺全力以赴演讲的关键，这次演讲由纽波特大学的平等就业机会、多样性和包容性办公室主办。从与父亲的早期对话中，波诺受到了启发，并在海军度过了40多年的杰出生涯。回顾她多年的服役经历波诺承认，当她的职业生涯开始时，她无法想象这条道路。“当我父亲告诉我，我可以成为我想要的任何人时，我不知道我不仅可以接受创伤外科医生的培训，而且还可以成为一名三星级上将，”波诺说。“我不知道接下来会发生什么。我可以告诉你，这条路的每一步最终都让我为今天的工作做好了准备。“你可能不知道生活会带你去哪里，但你希望在旅途中做好准备。”领导和指导在这方面对博诺起到了至关重要的作用，她分享了她在这一过程中学到的一些经验教训。博诺在承认过程中遇到的困难的同时指出，朝着团队共同希望的方向保持一致，然后使事情发生是领导的两个关键方面波诺说：“这确实会让人们感到不舒服，他们可能会做的第一件事就是说不。作为领导者和导师，你需要思考你想如何去做，以及你将如何去培养做到这一点的技能。”。“当你期待自己的领导时，帮助他们开发工具，在你的环境中创造变化，然后在这些努力范围内向前推进。”博诺在普外科住院期间的顿悟有助于说明这一点。当时，她是第二位进入海军项目的女性，也是第一位毕业的女性。博诺解释说，按照惯例，与会者会在手术室不断地向学员提问，以评估他们的基本知识。“我从那里出来，被彻底打败了，”博诺说。“我走进更衣室，只有一件事我能想做：我太不知所措了，我走进了一个摊位，哭了起来。”当她坐在女更衣室的一个隔间里时，波诺突然想到，她男更衣室的同事们在进入手术室之前，本来有时间谈谈这个案子的。博诺说：“我没有就此发表看法，而是想，‘我需要做些什么来缩小差距？如果我经历了这一切，还有谁会经历同样程度的挫折？我能做些什么来让（女性）更好呢？’”。“我对自己做出了承诺，努力让他们更容易接受。这是作为一名导师的很大一部分。”几年后，轮到博诺作为与会者来拷问一名实习生。果然，手术后，她发现这位不知所措的妇女在浴室的隔间里哭泣。波诺说：“我把手放在摊位上，说，‘把你的呼机给我，花几个小时，等你感觉好点再回来，因为你需要的是时间和视角。’”。“我希望有人能为我做到这一点。我的职业生涯定位于知道我能做些什么来为人们做得更好――即使这是一个安静哭泣的时刻。“我可以成为发泄情绪的避风港。有时候，你所需要做的就是能够听到自己大声说出来。我会听他们需要我听的任何东西。我发现大多数人只需要大声说出来，然后轻轻推一下。”除了她的经历外，博诺还指出，她的家族军事遗产塑造了她对领导力和导师关系的看法。她的祖父曾在美国陆军服役并作为上校退休，而她的兄弟是退休的陆军少将阿纳托利奥・克鲁兹三世。博诺和克鲁兹三世是菲律宾后裔中唯一拥有军衔s的兄弟姐妹同时，博诺说：“作为一名领导者和导师，最重要的是理解我所肩负的使命比我自己更大。我父亲希望确保我们能够回报我们所接纳的国家。我在这里是为了服务他人，了解如何最好地服务他人，以便他们能够让更好的事情发生。”。“当我看到[NUWC Newport]这样的组织同样关注细节时，这不仅让我产生共鸣，也让我相信这是最好的模式。这是我们军队和海军的一个标志。我们的实力建立在相互服务的基础上。”这些都是她不仅向同事，也向孩子们灌输的经验。博诺描述了一个与她自己的父亲在一个女儿7岁时的经历相似的时刻。“我告诉她当医生和医务人员的感觉。我们讨论了遇到需要你帮助的人的感觉。”博诺说：“我还解释说，作为一名海军军官，我为我们的国家服务，我是一群水手中的一员――世界各地有30万人――成为军队的一员是多么重要。”我女儿接到我的电话，这是我的一个时刻。当我结束时，她对我说，‘妈妈，男孩也能成为医生吗？’NUWC新港分部是海军海洋系统司令部的一部分，是海军水下作战中心的两个分部之一。NUWC新港分部的任务是为潜艇、自主水下系统、水下进攻和防御武器系统以及cou提供研究、开发、测试和评估、工程和舰队支持NUWC的另一个部门位于华盛顿的凯波特。

column2: FCC/C10F Intelligence Officer Receives Rear Adm. Edwin T. Layton Award
column3:
FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md. (NNS) - Cmdr. David Varona, deputy assistant chief of staff for intelligence, U.S. Fleet Cyber Command / U.S. 10th Fleet (FCC/C10F), was named as one of the recipients of this year’s Rear Adm. Edwin T. Layton Award for Leadership and Mentorship.

“I am truly honored and humbled to have received this award,” said Varona. “Some of the most impressive officers I've been honored to serve with were former winners, three here at FCC/C10F alone.  The naval intelligence community has always had strong leaders, so to be selected for this recognition is extremely humbling.

Established by the Director of Naval Intelligence in 2001, the Rear Adm. Edwin T. Layton Award for Leadership and Mentorship recognizes Sailors for outstanding leadership and mentorship in the furtherance on naval intelligence performance. The awardees have exemplified the leadership qualities of honor, courage, and commitment. Furthermore, each have been clearly recognized as a model leader for the naval intelligence community.

Varona emphasized his selection reflected the successes of his fellow shipmates at FCC/C10F. 

“My selection speaks more to the successes of the team I am a part of than anything I've done individually,” said Varona. “We are truly fortunate to have some of the best from the Navy intelligence community right here at FCC/C10F, be it civilians, officers, chief petty officers, and our junior enlisted. This award belongs to the FCC/C10F team here and the leadership we have across the ranks.”

Captain John Watkins, chief of staff, FCC/C10F, credited Varona’s selection to his character.

“Although he gives the credit for winning the award to his team, Cmdr. Varona’s leadership and dedication to his team is why he was selected for this award,” said Watkins. “He makes my job easy. He is an incredibly talented leader with contagious enthusiasm and impeccable standards of personal conduct.”

When asked what leadership attributes are necessary for intelligence officers just coming into the community, Varona offered some advice. 

“First, always be sincere,” said Varona. “This is what I’ve anchored on in my own approach to leadership.  If you are honest with your team and honest with your leadership, your intent and desire will be clear and you can focus on the mission. Second, be professionally inquisitive. The credibility you need to do your job effectively is not something easily attainable in standard work hours. Take the time to read and learn.  It will pay dividends for you. Third, and finally, lean on your senior enlisted. Get out and talk to people, get buy in and perspective from your senior enlisted and listen to what they have to say.  The corporate knowledge inherent in our workforce is astounding, and your teams can do amazing things when they are empowered and feel they own part of the solution.”

Rear Adm. Edwin T. Layton, the award's namesake, was primarily known for his code-breaking techniques in support of Adm. Chester Nimitz during World War II. His techniques ultimately contributed to providing information that was vital to winning the Battle of Midway. 

Varona also emphasized the importance of family and mentors making an invaluable difference in his career. 

“The success I’ve enjoyed this far would not have happened without the support of my family, my kids, the constant sacrifice of my wife in particular, and the support of my parents,” said Varona. “The people closest to me gave me the confidence to believe in myself from the start. I've had several professional role models I've looked up to in my career, most notably Capt. Jason Hines and Capt. Craig Whittinghill from within our community, and plenty of others from without.”   

FCC is responsible for Navy information network operations, offensive and defensive cyberspace operations, space operations and signals intelligence.  Comprised of over 14,000 Sailors, Reservists and civilians stationed across the world, C10F is the operational arm of FCC and executes its mission through a task force structure similar to other warfare commanders. 

For news and information from Commander, U.S. Fleet Cyber Command / U.S. 10th Fleet, visit www.navy.mil/local/FCCC10F/ or follow us on twitter @USFLEETCYBERCOM.
column6: FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, MD, UNITED STATES
column9: 乔治堡G.米德，马里兰州，美国
column10: FCC/C10F情报官员获得埃德温・T・莱顿海军少将奖
column11: 马里兰州乔治・G・米德堡（NNS）――美国舰队网络司令部/美国第十舰队（FCC/C10F）负责情报的副助理参谋长戴维・瓦罗纳中校被提名为今年埃德温・T・莱顿海军少将领导力和导师奖的获得者之一。“我真的很荣幸和谦卑地获得了这个奖项。”瓦罗纳说。“与我共事的一些最令人印象深刻的军官是前获奖者，仅在FCC/C10F就有三名。海军情报界一直都有强有力的领导人，因此被选中获得这一荣誉是非常令人谦卑的。海军情报总监于2001年设立了埃德温・T・莱顿海军少将奖领导和导师制表彰海员在推进海军情报工作方面的杰出领导和导师制。获奖者展示了荣誉、勇气和承诺等领导品质。此外，他们都被公认为海军情报界的模范领导者。瓦罗纳强调他的选择反映了他在FCC/C10F的同事们的成功。“我的选择更多地体现了我所在团队的成功，而不是我个人所做的任何事情，”瓦罗纳说。“我们真的很幸运，FCC/C10F的海军情报界有一些最优秀的人，无论是平民、军官、军士长还是我们的初级士兵。这个奖项属于这里的FCC/C10F团队以及我们在各个级别的领导层。”FCC/C10F的参谋长约翰・沃特金斯上尉将瓦罗纳的获奖归功于他的性格。“虽然他将获奖归功于他的团队，但瓦罗纳中校的领导能力和对团队的奉献精神是他被选为该奖项的原因，”沃特金斯说。“他让我的工作变得轻松。他是一位极具才华的领导者，具有感染力的热情和无可挑剔的个人行为标准。”当被问及刚进入社区的情报官员需要具备哪些领导素质时，瓦罗纳提出了一些建议。“首先，永远要真诚，”瓦罗纳说。“这就是我在自己的领导方法中所强调的。如果你对你的团队诚实，对你的领导诚实，你的意图和愿望就会明确，你可以专注于任务。其次，要有专业的好奇心。有效地完成工作所需的可信度在标准工作中是不容易达到的几个小时。花时间阅读和学习。这将为你带来回报。第三，也是最后一点，依靠你的资深士兵。走出去与人交谈，接受你的资深士兵的观点，倾听他们的意见。我们员工队伍中固有的企业知识令人震惊，当他们被赋予权力，并感到自己是解决方案的一部分。”与该奖项同名的陆军少将埃德温・莱顿（Edwin T.Layton）主要以其在二战期间支持切斯特・尼米兹（Chester Nimitz）少将的破译代码技术而闻名。他的技术最终有助于提供对赢得中途岛战役至关重要的信息。瓦罗纳还强调了家庭和导师做出无价贡献的重要性瓦罗纳说：“如果没有家人、孩子们的支持，尤其是妻子的不断牺牲，以及父母的支持，我就不会有今天的成功。”。“与我最亲近的人从一开始就给了我自信，让我相信自己。在我的职业生涯中，我有好几个职业榜样，其中最著名的是我们社区内的杰森・海因斯上尉和克雷格・惠廷希尔上尉，还有很多其他人。”FCC负责海军信息网络作战、攻防网络空间作战、空间作战和信号情报。C10F由驻扎在世界各地的14000多名海员、预备役军人和平民组成，是FCC的作战部门，通过与其他国家类似的特遣部队结构执行其任务战争指挥官。有关美国舰队网络司令部指挥官/美国第十舰队的新闻和信息，请访问www.navy.mil/local/FCCC10F/或在twitter@USFLEETCYBERCOM上关注我们。

column2: Rear Adm. Robert Hayes becomes Director of Joint Interagency Task Force West
column3:
HONOLULU - Joint Interagency Task Force West held its 18th change of command ceremony bidding farewell to U.S. Coast Guard Rear Adm. Donna L. Cottrell and welcoming Rear Adm. Robert P. Hayes, at Camp H. M. Smith, April 12.
Cottrell, a native of Wellington, Ohio, served as the Director of Joint Interagency Task Force West from March 2017 to April 2019.  She will be reporting as Commander to U.S. Coast Guard District Nine, in Cleveland, Ohio.
During Cottrell’s tenure as director, Joint Interagency Task Force West analysts identified suspect shipping events that led to several successful joint law enforcement operations seizing approximately four metric tons of cocaine, two metric tons of methamphetamine, and 90 metric tons of precursor chemicals.  Working with regional partners, she initiated a new cooperative effort with partner nations operating in the Pacific through exercise PACIFIC SNOW, a first for the Task Force, leading to increased intelligence sharing to combat the flow of transnational crime in the region.

Under Rear Adm. Cottrell’s watch, Joint Interagency Task Force West received the U.S. Interdiction Coordinator Award for its efforts in assisting law enforcement with the shutdown of the largest illicit dark web marketplace, Alpha Bay, and the arrest of the administrator and co-conspirators.

Incoming director Rear Adm. Hayes, a native of Connecticut, has over 30 years of service. He most recently served as the Coast Guard’s Assistant Commandant for Intelligence, at the Coast Guard Intelligence Coordination Center in Washington D.C.  There, Hayes oversaw the efforts of over 1,100 intelligence professionals who conduct the Coast Guard’s intelligence programs, including collection activities, analysis and production, geospatial intelligence, counterintelligence, cryptology, and critical IT and security functions.

Joint Interagency Task Force West plans and conducts Department of Defense counterdrug activities in order to increase regional stability and disrupt transnational criminal organizations that threaten global interests in the U.S. Pacific Command area of responsibility.
column6: CAMP H. M. SMITH, HI, UNITED STATES
column9: 史密斯营，你好，美国
column10: 海军少将罗伯特・海斯（Robert Hayes）成为西部联合跨部门特遣部队的指挥官
column11: 檀香山――4月12日，美国俄亥俄州惠灵顿的跨部门联合特遣部队西部在H.M.史密斯营地举行第18次换帅仪式，向美国海岸警卫队后方海军上将唐娜・L・科特雷尔告别，并欢迎后方海军上将罗伯特・P・海斯，2017年3月至2019年4月，担任西部联合跨机构工作队主任。她将作为指挥官向俄亥俄州克利夫兰的美国海岸警卫队第九区报告。在科特雷尔担任主任期间，西部联合跨机构特遣部队分析人员发现了可疑的航运事件，这些事件导致了几次成功的联合执法行动，查获了约4公吨可卡因，两公吨甲基苯丙胺和90公吨前体化学品。她与区域合作伙伴合作，通过太平洋雪演习与太平洋地区的合作伙伴国家展开了新的合作，这是工作队的首次演习，导致加强情报共享，以打击该地区的跨国犯罪流动。在科特雷尔少将的监督下，西部跨机构联合特遣部队因其在协助执法部门关闭最大的非法黑暗网络市场Alpha Bay以及逮捕管理员和共谋者方面所做的努力而获得美国阻截协调员奖。即将上任的主任Rear Adm.Hayes出生于康涅狄格州，任职超过30年。他最近在华盛顿特区的海岸警卫队情报协调中心担任海岸警卫队情报助理指挥官。在那里，海斯监督了1100多名情报专业人员的工作，他们负责海岸警卫队的情报项目，包括收集活动、分析和制作，地理空间情报，反情报，密码学，以及关键的IT和安全功能。联合跨机构特遣部队西部计划并开展国防部反毒活动，以加强地区稳定，瓦解威胁美国太平洋司令部责任区全球利益的跨国犯罪组织。

column2: Rear Adm. Christopher Alexander Assumes Command of Naval Surface and Mine Warfighting Development Center
column3:
Rear Adm. Christopher Alexander, a native of Key West, Fla., assumed command of Naval Surface and Mine Warfighting Development Center (SMWDC), headquartered in San Diego, May 10th without a change of command ceremony due to his predecessor being transferred ahead of Alexander’s arrival to fill an urgent operational role.

Prior to SMWDC, Alexander was most recently the Commanding Officer of Surface Warfare Schools Command located onboard Naval Station Newport, R.I.

Alexander is the fifth SMWDC Commander since its 2015 establishment as the Surface Warfare community’s Warfighting Development Center.

“I am truly humbled and honored to assume command of SMWDC. To be able to work with some of the best surface warfare tacticians to build and refine doctrine, tactics, techniques and procedures (TTP) for the Surface Warfare community is an immense and exciting opportunity. SMWDC has been in great hands with the Commanders who have come before me and I am excited to see where we will go in the future,” said Alexander.  

SMWDC is designated the Executive Agent for and responsible to Commander, Naval Surface Force, U.S. Pacific Fleet (COMNAVSURFPAC), for Surface Warfare Combat Training Continuum (SWCTC) planning, development, and implementation, including management of the Warfare Tactics Instructor (WTI) program, Surface Tactical Training Syllabi (STTS), and the associated Training and Readiness matrix.

“The Surface Force rolled out a six-month SWCTC pilot program aboard two destroyers this year, to test the DDG 51 STTS and tactical action officer grading criteria,” said Alexander. “The data from this pilot will aid in the follow-on implementation of SWCTC which will result in an automated system that tracks qualifications, currency, proficiency and experience throughout a watchstander’s career.”

A great deal of SMWDC’s planning and execution is accomplished by WTIs, the top-talented Surface Warfare officers that applied, selected and trained to become warfighting experts, in one of four surface warfare areas C amphibious warfare, integrated air and missile defense, mine warfare or anti-submarine warfare / surface warfare. WTIs plan and execute Surface Warfare Advanced Tactical Training (SWATT) exercises with increasing complexity that continues to challenge surface combatants and their crews to become more proficient and lethal at the individual, watch team, unit and strike group levels. These exercises ultimately foster battle-minded crews and combat ready ship for the high-end fight. 

Top-talented junior surface warfare officers interested in becoming WTIs can send an email to SWO_WTI@navy.mil for more information about the WTI program and their graduate education opportunities.
column9: 美国加利福尼亚州圣地亚哥
column10: 克里斯托弗・亚历山大少将担任海军水面和水雷作战发展中心的指挥
column11: 克里斯托弗・亚历山大少将（Christopher Alexander）出生于佛罗里达州基韦斯特（Key West），5月10日担任总部位于圣地亚哥的海军水面和水雷作战发展中心（SMWDC）的指挥，但由于其前任在亚历山大抵达之前被调往担任紧急作战任务，因此未举行指挥仪式。在SMWDC之前，Alexander最近是位于R.I.纽波特海军基地的水面作战学校司令部的指挥官。Alexander是自2015年作为水面作战社区的作战发展中心成立以来的第五位SMWDC指挥官。“我真的很荣幸能够担任SMWDC的指挥。能够与一些最优秀的水面作战战术家合作，建立和完善条令、战术、技术和程序（TTP）对于水面作战社区来说，这是一个巨大而激动人心的机会。SMWDC一直与我之前的指挥官们密切合作，我很高兴看到我们未来的发展方向，”亚历山大说。SMWDC被指定为美国太平洋舰队海军水面部队指挥官的执行代理，并对其负责（COMNAVSURFPAC），用于地面作战作战训练连续体（SWCTC）的规划、开发和实施，包括对作战战术指导员（WTI）计划、地面战术训练大纲（STT）以及相关训练和准备矩阵的管理。亚历山大说：“地面部队今年在两艘驱逐舰上推出了为期六个月的SWCTC试点计划，以测试DDG51 STT和战术行动官的评级标准。”。“来自该试点的数据将有助于SWCTC的后续实施，从而形成一个自动化系统，该系统将跟踪观察员职业生涯中的资格、货币、熟练程度和经验。”SMWDC的大量规划和执行工作由WTIs完成，WTIs是在四个水面战领域之一――两栖作战、综合防空和导弹防御、水雷战或反潜战/水面战――应用、选拔和培训成为作战专家的顶级水面战军官d执行地面战高级战术训练（SWAT）越来越复杂的演习继续挑战水面作战人员及其船员，使其在个人、观察小组、部队和打击小组层面上变得更加熟练和致命。这些演习最终培养具有战斗意识的船员和为高端战斗做好战斗准备的舰艇。顶尖的初级水面作战军官希望成为WTI的人可以向SWO发送电子邮件_WTI@navy.mil有关WTI计划及其研究生教育机会的更多信息。

column2: Rear Adm. Christina Alvarado Talks Leadership, Hispanic Heritage at LATINA Style Symposium
column3:
WASHINGTON (NNS) -- Rear Adm. Christina (Tina) Alvarado, deputy chief for Reserve policy, U.S. Navy Bureau of Medicine and Surgery, joined five Hispanic military leaders for a panel at the National LATINA Style Awards to offer guidance and advice on leadership and self-development.

 Alvarado's journey into the military was an unconventional one. She worked as a critical care nurse before moving to Washington, D.C. as a full-time staffer at the Senate Committee on Veterans Affairs, following the footsteps of her biological grandmother, who was one of the first female staffers on Capitol Hill. The veterans she met inspired her to join the Navy as a Reserve critical care nurse. Shortly thereafter, she deployed to Operation Desert Storm.

 She went on to establish Navy Medicine's first reserve expeditionary medical facility (EMF), EMF Dallas in 2011. She was the first nurse to serve as the commanding officer of what was once a "fleet hospital" and one of the first women to do so as well. She and her team were given the honor of plankowners as the first Sailors to staff the EMF. Since that time, a total of four Reserve EMFs have been created within Navy Medicine.

 "Having the honor of being a commanding officer with a team that accomplished a first like that was enormously satisfying," Alvarado said. "There aren't many positions to go post-command, so I thought it'd be my last one and I'd retire as a captain."

 Shortly thereafter she picked up her first star for rear admiral lower half, and five years later, with her second star, she's still serving as Navy Reservist.

 During the LATINA Style panel, Alvarado told the group about a young Hispanic woman and Navy nurse she recently met. It was this officer's first time interacting with a flag officer. The woman expressed her admiration for Alvarado, and said, "You've made me realize that someday I may have the opportunity to be in your position."

 That statement is one that has changed Alvarado's perspective on the importance of her role as a leader.

 "At that moment, I started to wear my stars differently," Alvarado said. "Holding a position of leadership isn't about the person in the position or the traditions of honor that come along with it. Rather it's about what that position represents for those striving to do better for themselves and those around them. I probably work harder now than I ever have before, because the young men and women of the Navy depend on me and I will not let them down."

 "Success is never a solo journey, and I never measure success by what I have done," said Alvarado. "My success is measured by the accomplishments of those I've had the honor to lead. My shipmates in Navy Medicine have proven to me, through their accomplishments and the work we've done together in the last 29 years, that I have all the success I'll ever need." 

 LATINA Style is a national magazine dedicated to the needs and concerns of the contemporary Latina professional working woman and the Latina business owner in the United States, showcasing Latina achievements in all areas, including business, science, civic affairs, education, entertainment, sports, and the arts.

 Navy Medicine is a global health care network of 63,000 personnel which provides health care support to the U.S. Navy, Marine Corps, their families, and veterans in high operational-tempo environments, at expeditionary medical facilities, medical treatment facilities, hospitals, clinics, hospital ships, and research units around the world.

Editors Note: Article post was originally posted on September 19, 2017, to the Navy News Service and may be found at http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=102499
column9: 美国华盛顿特区
column10: 克里斯蒂娜・阿尔瓦拉多（Christina Alvarado）少将在拉丁风格研讨会上谈论领导力、西班牙裔传统
column11: 华盛顿（NNS）――美国海军医学和外科局预备役政策副局长克里斯蒂娜・阿尔瓦拉多少将（蒂娜・阿尔瓦拉多）与五名西班牙裔军事领导人一起参加了国家拉丁风格奖颁奖典礼，就领导力和自我发展提供指导和建议。阿尔瓦拉多的参军之旅是非传统的。她曾是一名重症护理护士，后来搬到华盛顿特区，成为参议院退伍军人事务委员会的全职工作人员。她的生母是国会山上第一批女职员之一。她遇到的退伍军人激励她加入海军，成为一名后备重症护理护士。此后不久，她被部署到沙漠风暴行动。2011年，她在达拉斯建立了海军医学部第一个预备役远征医疗设施（EMF）。她是第一位担任“舰队医院”指挥官的护士，也是第一位担任指挥官的女性。她和她的团队被授予浮游生物所有者的荣誉，成为EMF的第一批工作人员。自那时以来，海军医学部共创建了四个后备EMF。阿尔瓦拉多说：“有幸成为一个团队的指挥官，完成了第一个这样的任务，这是非常令人满意的。”。“指挥部的职位不多，所以我想这是我最后一个职位，我会以船长的身份退休。”此后不久，她为海军少将下半身选上了第一颗星，五年后，凭借第二颗星，她仍然担任海军预备役。在拉丁风格的座谈会上，阿尔瓦拉多向大家讲述了她最近遇到的一位年轻的西班牙裔女性和海军护士。这是这位军官第一次与国旗军官互动。这位女士表达了她对阿尔瓦拉多的钦佩之情，并说：“你让我意识到，总有一天我会有机会站在你的立场上。”这句话改变了阿尔瓦拉多对她作为领导者的重要性的看法。阿尔瓦拉多说：“那一刻，我开始以不同的方式佩戴我的星星。”。“担任领导职务与该职位的人或随之而来的荣誉传统无关，而是与该职位对那些努力为自己和周围人做得更好的人所代表的意义有关。我现在可能比以往任何时候都更加努力工作，因为海军的年轻男女依靠阿尔瓦拉多说：“成功从来不是一次单独的旅行，我从不以我所做的来衡量成功。”。“我的成功是以我有幸领导的人的成就来衡量的。我在海军医学方面的同事们通过他们的成就和我们在过去29年中共同完成的工作向我证明，我拥有我所需要的所有成功。”LATINA Style是一本全国性杂志，致力于满足当代拉丁裔职业女性和美国拉丁裔企业主的需求和关注，展示拉丁裔在各个领域的成就，包括商业、科学、公民事务、教育、娱乐、体育和艺术。海军医疗是一个由63000名人员组成的全球医疗网络，在远征医疗设施、医疗设施、医院、诊所、医疗船等处，为美国海军、海军陆战队及其家属和退伍军人在高作战节奏环境中提供医疗支持，编辑注：文章最初于2017年9月19日发布在海军新闻服务处，可在http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=102499

column2: Rear Adm. Evans participates in Chicago Federal Executive Board Regional Congressional Briefing
column3:
CHICAGO - Rear Adm. Stephen C. Evans, commander, Naval Service Training Command (NSTC), participated as one of the guest speakers for the Chicago Federal Executive Board Regional Congressional Briefing Monday, at the Federal Reserve Bank downtown Chicago.

The briefing was held to connect federal agencies in order to share resources and information as well as to present ways to enhance shared goals such as emergency preparedness, workforce development and government and community partnerships.

Evans highlighted the importance of these partnerships throughout the Midwest region and the responsibility of the Navy as a vital part of the community.

"We are particularly proud of our wonderful relationship with our neighbors," said Evans. "With the help of the Chicago Federal Executive Board, our Navy is intertwined and fully engaged throughout the Midwest."

The overall military economic impact in Illinois is approximately $13.3 Billion, providing more than 150,000 jobs for active duty, reserve military and civilian payroll. This impact accounts for nearly 2 percent of the state's gross domestic product (GDP).

Naval Station Great Lakes (NSGL) is the largest military installation in Illinois and the largest training station in the Navy. Partnering with federal agencies, NSGL plays an active role devoted to neighboring communities.

In 2014 NSGL raised more than $375,000 for area charities through the Combined Federal Campaign. In the past 12 years, NSGL has reduced energy use by 43 percent and nearly 70 percent of the vehicle fleet use alternative fuels. NSGL is also a leading blood donor in the Chicagoland area. 

Evans concluded by discussing the impacts of maintaining partnerships with the community.

"Our mission is training," said Evans. "While we have no ships or aircraft at Naval Station Great Lakes, our capital asset is people. And we have some of the finest Sailors in the Navy training the newest Sailors in the Navy, many of them hailing from communities right here in the Midwest."

NSTC, headquartered on NSGL, oversees 98 percent of initial officer and enlisted accessions training for the Navy, as well as the Navy's Citizenship Development programs. NSTC includes Recruit Training Command (RTC), Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps (NROTC) at more than 165 colleges and universities, Officer Training Command (OTC) in Newport, R.I., and Navy Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps (NJROTC) and Navy National Defense Cadet Corps (NNDCC) citizenship development programs at more than 570 high schools worldwide.
column9: 芝加哥，伊利诺伊州，美国
column10: 埃文斯少将参加芝加哥联邦执行委员会地区国会简报会
column11: 芝加哥――海军服役训练司令部（NSTC）指挥官斯蒂芬・埃文斯（Stephen C.Evans）少将作为嘉宾之一参加了周一的芝加哥联邦执行委员会地区国会简报会，在芝加哥市中心的联邦储备银行举行的简报会旨在连接联邦机构，以共享资源和信息，并介绍如何加强应急准备等共同目标，劳动力发展以及政府和社区伙伴关系。埃文斯强调了这些伙伴关系在整个中西部地区的重要性，以及海军作为社区重要组成部分的责任。埃文斯说：“我们特别为我们与邻国的良好关系感到自豪。”。“在芝加哥联邦执行委员会的帮助下，我们的海军在整个中西部交织在一起并充分参与。”伊利诺伊州的总体军事经济影响约为133亿美元，为现役军人、预备役军人和文职人员提供了超过150000个工作岗位。这一影响占该州国内生产总值（GDP）的近2%。五大湖海军基地（NSGL）是伊利诺伊州最大的军事设施，也是海军最大的训练基地。NSGL与联邦机构合作，在邻近社区发挥积极作用。2014年，NSGL通过联合联邦运动为地区慈善机构筹集了37.5万美元。在过去12年中，NSGL将能源使用量减少了43%，近70%的车队使用替代燃料。NSGL也是芝加哥地区的主要献血者。埃文斯最后讨论了与社区保持伙伴关系的影响。“我们的任务是培训，”埃文斯说。“虽然我们在五大湖海军基地没有船只或飞机，但我们的资本资产是人。我们有一些海军中最优秀的水手训练海军中最新的水手，其中许多人来自中西部的社区。”NSTC总部位于NSGL，监督98%的海军初级军官和应征入伍人员培训，以及海军公民发展计划。NSTC包括165多所院校的新兵训练司令部（RTC）、海军预备役军官训练团（NROTC）、位于R.I.新港的军官训练司令部（OTC）、海军初级预备役军官训练团（NJROTC）和海军国防学员团（NNDCC）全世界570多所高中的公民发展项目。

column2: Vice Adm. Grooms emphasizes networking, sharing ideas during NNOA Tidewater Meeting
column3:
NORFOLK C Stressing that he “never passes up an opportunity to chat with those you care about,” Vice Adm. Bruce Grooms, deputy chief of staff for Capability Development at NATO Headquarters Supreme Allied Command Transformation, spoke with members of the sea services and military retirees during the monthly Professional Military Education (PME) meeting, presented by the Tidewater Chapter of the National Naval Officers Association (NNOA), on March 10. 

During his conversation at Breezy Point on Naval Station Norfolk, Grooms emphasized the importance of NNOA.

“NNOA is a wonderful opportunity for us C folks in uniform and retired C to share in a forum that can be helpful,” said Grooms. “There’s always someone in a room like this who’s been there. More importantly, there’s always someone in a room like this who actually cares. Caring is the first step in helping you over a hurdle.”

Also Grooms encouraged attendees to meet and openly discuss when they think they may be facing a challenge, comparing seeking assistance to making a phone call.

“It’s always better to make the 411 call C let me share some info C than make the 911 my life is on fire, emergency call,” said Grooms. “I can fix any 411 situation; 911s are hard.”

A native of Cleveland, Grooms graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy, where he later became the school’s first African-American commandant of midshipmen.

In addition, Grooms, who completed nuclear power training, has served in nearly every capacity aboard a variety of submarines. He is one of the “Centennial Seven,” the seven African-American officers who have commanded a ship in the submarine service’s first 100 years. Also Grooms was selected as the Vice Admiral Stockdale Inspirational Leadership Award winner for 1999.

Grooms provided career guidance as well. He discussed the importance of really knowing the data on one’s Fitness Report (FITREP) as one way to know where an individual stands at his or her command.

“The data on FITREPS should never come as a surprise,” said Grooms. “If you don’t know where you stand, then you don’t where you want to be.”

Grooms also reminded the attendees that the NNOA national conference will be held in July in San Diego, which often includes senior level leadership in attendance.

“Every year for the last several years, the chiefs of the sea services have attended the national conference because they care about it. But what’s been missing is you folks,” said Grooms. “I need as many of you to be there because what we try to do is have opportunities to talk about really important topics, and some of the senior leadership only get fleeting moments to talk to you about those important topics.”

Tidewater NNOA meets on the third Tuesday of each month. The mission of NNOA is to actively support the Sea Services C Marines Corps, Navy, and Coast Guard C in the development of a diverse officer and civilian leadership corps through recruitment, retention, and career development.
column9: 美国弗吉尼亚州诺福克
column10: 新郎副上将强调在NNOA潮水会议期间建立网络，分享想法
